374
1
FAMILY  Agaricaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Agaricus deserticola  G. Moreno, Esqueda & Lizarraga^  in Moreno, Lizarraga, Esqueda & Coronado, Mycotaxon 112: 292. 2010;  Longula texensis  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Zeller  Mycologia 37(5): 636. 1945;  Agaricus texensis  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Geml, Geiser & Royse (invalid name);  Longia texensis  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Zeller;  Gyrophragmium texensis  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Massee;  Secotium texense  Berk. & M.A. Curtis
ENGLISH NAMES  gastroid Agaricus
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Agaricus deserticola looks like a dry, thick stemmed whitish to buff mushroom with an unexpanded cap (the margin still attached to the stem), but the dark brown spore mass consists of crowded, convoluted, folded or branched plates and/or cavities instead of well-developed gills. Zeller(6) described Longula texensis var. major (without a Latin diagnosis) from California and Mexico which is larger (15-30cm tall with stem bulbose, 5-7cm in diameter at the base when fresh), and has a more conspicuously scaly cap. RANGE Arora says Agaricus deserticola is apparently widespread in the arid and semi-arid areas of the West of North America (from TX to CA and north at least to OR). Zeller(6) examined collections from OR, CA, NM, and TX. Var. 'major' was described from CA and Mexico.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  3-9cm or more, ovoid to spherical or broadly convex or somewhat flattened, "margin at first joined to cap by a veil"; white to buff becoming tan to ocher or brownish when old; dry, "smooth or often breaking up to form white to brown fibrillose scales or warts" that may wear away when old, "becoming fragile as it dries out, often rupturing longitudinally in age (especially near margin)"^, (Arora), cap 3-9cm across, 2-7cm deep, nearly spherical or depressed spherical to broadly convex, at first closed below by a veil; "smooth or rupturing into loose or appressed scales", cream or buff becoming darker (dark warm brown) and sordid grayish when mature, (Zeller)
INNER LAYER  firm; "white, but bruised areas often stained yellowish" (or sometimes pinkish-stained in stem)^, (Arora), in stem yellowish or pinkish, (Zeller)
INTERIOR  spore mass "composed of crowded, convoluted, folded or branched plates and/ or cavities", free from the stem (at least when old); brownish becoming deep chocolate brown to blackish when mature and usually exposed or partially exposed when old^, (Arora), 1-2cm deep, gill-like to "variously united and anastomosing forming irregular cavities, free from the stem", ventricose; becoming bone brown to black, (Zeller)
STEM  2-10cm x 1.5-3.5(5)cm or longer, equal or thicker at base, percurrent [going through spore mass], "firm and solid when fresh, becoming tougher or even woody as it dries out"; white or colored like cap; smooth or longitudinally striate; volva present or absent (usually intergrown with stem and therefore inconspicuous), veil 2-layered, at first continuous with cap margin and stem, but when old usually pulling away from stem or separating from the cap to form a superior ring on stem^, (Arora), 2-3.5cm wide in lower part, usually narrowing upward, (fruitbody 5-12cm tall), abruptly narrowed in upper part into a percurrent columella widening in its upper part to underlie the upper cap surface, the stem firm becoming woody on drying, solid; colored like the cap surface; smooth, usually becoming striate; lower part of veil sometimes splitting longitudinally but usually forming a double annulus, the upper part left in the form of a cap, (Zeller), stem-columella 3-8cm x 2-3.5cm, woody by maturity; smooth or striate, (Smith(4))
ODOR  pleasant^ (Miller)
TASTE  mild^ (Miller)
EDIBILITY  unknown (Arora)
HABITAT  single, scattered, or gregarious "in poor soil, waste places, irrigated fields, lawns, disturbed areas, etc.", apparently widespread in arid and semi-arid areas, fruiting after rains or artificial watering^, (Arora), usually in semiarid, waste places, February to November, (Zeller)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-7.5 x 5-6.5 microns, nearly round, smooth, capillitium absent^, (Arora), spores 6.2-7.5 x 5-6.3 microns, nearly round to slightly oboval, smooth, dark brown, sterigmal scar prominent; basidia 4-spored, broadly clavate, (Zeller)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'living in desert'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Arora(1)* (as Longula texensis), Phillips(1)* (as Longula texensis), Miller(14)* (as Longula texensis), Smith(4)* (as Longula texensis), Zeller(6) (as Longula texensis), Desjardin(6)*
2
FAMILY  Agaricaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Agaricus inapertus  Vellinga^  Mycologia 95(3): 453. 2003;  Endoptychum depressum  Singer & A.H. Sm.  Brittonia 10: 216. 1958
ENGLISH NAMES  mountain gastroid Agaricus
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Agaricus inapertus looks like and unexpanded gilled Agaricus, but it has only rudimentary gills and never opens out. It has a pallid, fleshy spore mass that becomes dark brown. Fruiting is under mountain conifers.^ It is a common sequestrate species in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Collections were examined by Singer(13) from OR and ID. It was recorded by Thiers(4) for CA. Oregon State University has collections from WA, OR, and CA.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  surface of cap stains yellow with KOH^ (Singer)
OUTER SURFACE  3-15cm across, "rounded or convex or flattened on top", often centrally depressed when old, margin depressed around stem and joined to it by a veil, sometimes pulling away from stem when old or the cap rupturing irregularly; "white to dingy whitish or buff", often staining yellow or amber when bruised and when old (and sometimes staining vinaceous brown near bottom); "surface smooth or occasionally scaly"^, (Arora), 3-9.5cm across, much less high than wide, not or only rarely opening on the underside (but with a stem), at first pulvinate [cushion-shaped] to hemispheric or somewhat spherical, soon becoming flattened spherical or depressed spherical, when old practically always distinctly depressed in center; white to dingy pallid in upper part, colored the same but tending to become tinged vinaceous in the lower part; dry, unpolished, obscurely innately radially fibrillose to bald but at times becoming somewhat diffracted-scaly; peridium sometimes as thick in the upper as in the lower part, or 0.1-0.45cm in the upper and only 0.05-0.1cm in the lower part, opening by irregular rupture or by being gnawed open by rodents, (Singer)
INNER LAYER  "firm becoming tough in age", white, often bruising yellow^, (Arora), flesh firm, fleshy, somewhat tough and more so when old; white, tending to stain yellow where bruised, (Singer)
INTERIOR  spore mass "composed of branched or contorted, crowded plates (rudimentary gills) or elongated chambers"; pallid soon becoming chocolate brown to blackish brown, usually powdery when mature and not normally exposed except when old^, (Arora), somewhat gill-like, consisting of elongated chambers but gill-like plates not consistently vertically arranged, slowly becoming powdery but much less so than in puffballs or even Chlorophyllum agaricoides, even when old, (Singer)
STEM  1-4cm x 0.8-3cm or longer, "equal or tapered, usually short", firm, percurrent [going through the cap flesh]; white or stained like cap; smooth; veil rather tough, covering the juncture of cap margin and stem, not normally rupturing but sometimes breaking away from stem when old, ring absent^, (Arora), stem 1-3cm x 0.8-2cm, wider in the middle or more or less equal, "solid, eventually becoming hollow (or rather hollowed by worms)"; colored as the cap; subglabrous [almost bald]; columella continuous with stem, narrowing upward but reaching the upper cap surface, for the most part free of the spore mass; veil of volval origin apical (just beneath where stem joins cap), rather narrow, firm, fimbriate [fringed], ascendant (but not sheathing in the manner of a volva), (Singer)
ODOR  "usually sweet (like almond extract or anise) when young but often unpleasant or musty at maturity"^, (Arora), almonds or anise, the odor of over-mature fruitbodies rather disagreeable, and in dried material distinctly cumarinous, (Singer)
TASTE  almond or anise^ (Singer)
EDIBILITY  firm specimens said to be edible (Arora)
HABITAT  single to gregarious or clustered "in duff or soil under conifers (or sometimes aspen)", mountains of western North America, especially late summer and fall^, (Arora), underground or subhypogeous [somewhat underground], "growing in clumps, side by side and sometimes one above the other", eventually the upper part of the fruitbody emerging from the ground, found on clay soil near conifers in mountain areas, August, (Singer), fruits in late summer and fall (Smith(4))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-10 x 5.5-8 microns on average (but variable), round to elliptic, smooth, thick-walled^, capillitium absent, (Arora), spores 6-8(9.8) x 5.3-7.7 microns, round or nearly round, smooth, "with a thick compound wall consisting of a pale-colored (olive-yellow) entire exosporium, a deep-mahogany-colored episporium beneath it, and an endosporium which has the same color as the exosporium" (the overall coloration deep sepia, as in many Agaricus species), without a trace of a germ pore, with a straight or oblique short hilar appendage; basidia forming a hymenium, "either all 4-spored, or in other populations often with some (1)2-spored basidia intermixed", 21-27 x 8-8.7 microns, clavate, colorless, basidioles clavate to clavate-vesiculose; no cystidia seen; hyphae of the regular hymenophoral trama and the cap surface filamentous and colorless; subhymenium cellular; hyphae of all tissues without clamp connections, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pressed down' or 'depressed'
SIMILAR  Chlorophyllum agaricoides has a whitish spore mass that becomes yellowish then pale brown, has a shorter stem, and fruits in grass, cultivated ground or wasteland.
SOURCES  Arora(1)* (as Endoptychum depressum), Singer(13) (as Endoptychum depressum), Smith(4) (as Endoptychum depressum), Thiers(4) (as Endoptychum depressum), Trudell(4)* (as Endoptychum depressum), Vellinga(5), Trappe(13)*
3
FAMILY  Paxillaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Alpova diplophloeus  (Zeller & C.W. Dodge) Trappe & A.H. Sm.  group^  apud Trappe, Beih. Nova Hedwigia 51: 286. 1975;  Alpova cinnamomeus  C.W. Dodge;  Rhizopogon diplophloeus  Zeller & C.W. Dodge;  Rhizopogon  parvisporus  Bowerman
ENGLISH NAMES  red gravel, alder truffle
NOTES  The Alpova diplophloeus group is distinguished by a nearly spherical to ovoid fruitbody, with a cinnamon-colored surface when mature, a deep reddish orange or deep reddish brown bruising reaction, a spore mass that is reddish brown at maturity and consists of small gel-filled chambers and pallid veins, and underground growth with a preference for alder. There are distinctive microscopic characters as well, including spores that are amyloid when young and inamyloid when mature, 6-spored to 8-spored basidia, and a distinctive peridial layer with clamp connections - dermatocystidia are present and often conspicuous^. |The Alpova diplophloeus group consists of at least three species according to Hayward(1) who used a combination of molecular and morphological characters. The holotypes of two of these are from the Pacific Northwest: Alpova diplophloeus from Friday Harbour WA, and Alpova concolor from Siuslaw National Forest OR (with supporting material from Maple Ridge, BC). Hayward(1) say of Alpova concolor (with Latin name italicized) "The structurally distinct two-layered peridium and existence in the Pacific Northwest of the United States causes us to suspect that Zeller and Dodge included this species in their concept of Alpova diplophloeus even though the holotype of Alpova diplophloeus does not belong to this species. At least among surveys that have deposited sequences in international sequence repositories, this species appears to be more common than A. diplophloeus". A third species, Alpova cinnamomeus (synonym Rhizopogon parvisporus) was described from Michigan and occurs also at least in Newfoundland-Labrador. |The three species can be differentiated as follows. Alpova diplophloeus has a structurally single-layered peridium, and spores more than 2.2 microns wide, whereas the other two have two structurally distinct layers and spores on average less than 2.2 microns wide. In Alpova cinnamomeus, the peridium separates easily from the gleba (spore mass), and the peridia cells collapse fully on drying, whereas in Alpova concolor the peridium is not easily separable and the peridial cells do not collapse fully on drying. The characters of Alpova diplophloeus include 1) a poorly differentiated peridium with variation in the peridium only in pigmentation (darker near surface of fruitbody), 2) wide spores (some more than 3.5 microns at widest point) with 1 or very rarely 2 droplets, and 3) an association with Alnus rubra, A. incana, and A. rhombifolia. The characters of Alpova concolor include 1) a 2-layered peridium, 2) dermatocystidia (rare), 3) spores with 2-droplets, and 4) an association with Alnus rubra and A. rhombifolia. The characters of Alpova cinnamomeus include 1) a peridium reviving poorly and easily separated from the spore mass when revived, 2) relatively large gleba chambers with large buffer cells, 3) frequently 2 droplets in spores, and 4) an association with A. alnobetula and perhaps others. |The Alpova diplophloeus group are abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). |RANGE The Alpova diplophloeus group occur along Pacific Coast from CA to AK, and also known from moist habitats in Rocky Mountains, MI, NT, and NF, (Smith(4)). Collections were examined from BC, WA, OR, NF, NWT, AK, CA, CO, MI, UT, and WY, (Trappe(11)). The group are abundant in the Pacific Northwest, found from BC south to northern CA and east to the east coast, also in Europe, (Trappe(13)). They are frequent on foray lists for BC and collections from BC are at Pacific Forestry Centre and the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 on sections of dried material dark green on both spore mass and peridium; "KOH giving a reddish pigment diffusing from the peridium into the mounting medium but the peridium itself soon rusty brown in sections"^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  0.6-3(4.5)cm across, typically almost spherical to ovoid; light yellowish pink when young, darkening to reddish brown or brown when old, "where bruised soon changing to deep reddish orange or deep reddish brown"; "rhizomorphs absent to sparse, fine, appressed"^, (Smith(4)), " 0.5-3(5)cm broad, oblong or oval to nearly round, or less commonly irregularly lobed. Outer surface pallid to pinkish-yellowish-buff when young, soon becoming yellow-brown to cinnamon, reddish-brown, or brown, usually staining dark reddish-orange to reddish-brown where bruised; smooth or with only a very few rhizomorphs (mycelial threads)", (Arora), 1-2.5cm across, spherical to rather irregular in outline; when fresh "clay color" but "becoming darker brown on bruising and when dried blackish with some ochraceous tones showing in the depressions"; surface scantily fibrillose from appressed fibrils, few rhizomorphs present, scattered appressed fibrils leading to the scattered rhizomorphs, (Smith(30)), 0.6-3(4.5)cm across, mostly nearly spherical to ovoid but sometimes pulvinate [cushion-shaped] or irregularly lobed; peridium [surface layer] up to 0.1cm thick, when young finely pruinose and pallid, "soon becoming light yellowish pink, then reddish brown to yellowish brown", at maturity smooth and reddish brown to strong brown; where bruised the surface soon changing to deep reddish orange or deep reddish brown; "in cross section light yellow to yellowish brown"; when dried, dark brown to dark reddish brown, often olive-tinged or mottled with lighter shades; "rhizomorphs when present concolorous, sparse, fine, appressed", (Trappe(11))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  sticky-gelatinous; "chamber contents pale yellow to olive when young, soon discoloring to reddish brown or orange brown when exposed, near maturity brownish orange to reddish brown", (Smith(4)), "composed of small chambers separated by pale yellow or whitish veins; chambers 0.5-3mm broad, filled with a gelatinous substance, pallid to pale yellowish or olive when young, becoming orange-brown to reddish-brown to dark vinaceous-brown at maturity," reminiscent of red gravel, (Arora), mottled to virgate and with irregular cavities, at maturity filled with spores; when dry near russet and the consistency bone hard, (Smith(30)), sticky-gelatinous, with gel-filled chambers 0.05-0.3cm broad separated by pale yellow veins; chamber contents when young "pale yellow to olive but soon discoloring to reddish brown or orange brown when exposed", "near maturity brownish orange to reddish brown and darkening only slightly or not at all when exposed, when dried yellowish brown to brownish black", (Trappe(11))
STEM  no columella^, (Smith(30))
ODOR  fruity at maturity^ (Trappe(11), Smith(4)), usually fruity at maturity (Arora)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under alder; June through December^, (Smith(4)), widely scattered to gregarious in humus or soil (usually buried) under or near alder, (Arora), mycorrhizal with Alnus (Trappe(13))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 4-5.5(6) x (1.8)2.2-2.8 microns, elliptic to oblong^, (Smith(4)), spores 4.5-5.5 x 2.3-2.8 microns, elliptic, oblong, or in some cases allantoid in one view, or with slightly lateral protrusion causing the spore to be slightly angular, colorless in KOH singly but in masses pinkish buff, amyloid when young but inamyloid (yellow brown) when mature, basal scar inconspicuous; basidia 6-spored to 8-spored, 10-16 x 4-5 microns; tramal plates of interwoven colorless nongelatinous hyphae 2-6 microns wide; peridium a trichodermium of hyphae with rusty-fulvous walls mostly thickened somewhat, the cells in the layer up to 25 microns wide and about isodiametric to elongated, the layer appearing cellular as a result, at the outer surface the hyphal ends more or less projecting or the tips crooked and coiled around each other, septate, the cells many odd shapes and smooth-walled; clamp connections present on colored hyphae of peridium; all tissues inamyloid, (Smith(30)), spores elongate, smooth, thin-walled, colorless to pale brownish, (Trudell), spores 4-6 x 1.5-3 microns (Arora), spores for A. diplophloeus (minimum/first quartile/mean/third quartile/maximum) (4.0)5.2-5.70-6.0(7.0) x (2.0)2.1-2.45-2.5(3.0) microns, oblong to broadly allantoid, thick-walled, smooth, with 1 or very rarely 2 oil droplets, in Melzer's reagent empire yellow to buff in mass, (Hayward(1)), spores for Alpova concolor (4.0)5.0-5.40-6.05[sic](6.0) x (1.5)2.0-2.1-2.1(3.0) microns, oblong to allantoid, thin-walled, 2 droplets when suspended in 3% KOH, empire yellow to buff yellow in mass in Melzer's reagent, (Hayward(1)), spores for Alpova cinnamomeus (4.0)5.0-5.10-5.15(7.0) x (1.8)2.0-2.12-2.17(3.0) microns, oblong to allantoid, thin-walled, smooth, typically with 2 droplets in KOH but some spores with 1 or 3 oil droplets, empire yellow to buff yellow in mass in Melzer's reagent, (Hayward(1))
NAME ORIGIN  from Greek "diplo-" meaning "double" and "-phloeus" meaning "rind", for the 2-layered peridium, (Trappe, M.(1)); "concolor" refers to "the similarly dark rusty brown peridium and gleba when dried"
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon species lack the viscid-gelatinous spore mass, are often larger, and often have different tree associations, (Trudell). Melanogaster species also have a gelatinous spore mass, but are "brown to black and the spores are thick-walled and brown to purple", (Trudell).
SOURCES  Smith(30) (as Rhizopogon diplophloeus), Hayward(1), Trappe(11), Trappe(13)*, Smith(4), Trudell(4)*, Arora(1)*, Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Siegel(2)*
4
FAMILY  Paxillaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Alpova trappei  Fogel^  Mycologia 69: 841. 1977;  == Melanogaster luteus  Zeller sensu Trappe;  == Alpova luteus  (Zeller) Trappe
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include a nearly spherical to flattened fruitbody with a brilliant yellow surface that fades, similarly colored rhizomorphs especially at the base, a rubbery gelatinous spore mass that is brownish yellow becoming brownish black, the gel-filled chambers separated by white to light yellow veins, an odor that may be mildly garlicky or fruity, underground fruiting under conifers, and mostly elliptic spores 4.0-6.5 x 1.8-3 microns on 4-8(12)-spored basidia.^ Fogel discussed the difficulties with the name Alpova luteus. Alpova trappei may be more closely related to Melanogaster species than to the Alpova spp. associated with alder. Alpova trappei is common among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE A. trappei is found at least in OR and CA, (Smith, Fogel). The distribution is OR to northern CA in the Cascade Mountains, (Trappe(13)), and Mexico (Trappe, M.(3)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  "KOH on fresh peridium dark brown, on dried peridium instantly dark reddish brown soon becoming black", on fresh spore mass dark brown, soon black; FeSO4 "on fresh peridium light brown, on dried peridium slowly dark brown", on fresh spore mass quickly greenish black^, (Fogel)
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-4.5cm broad, nearly spherical to flattened; brilliant yellow when young, fading to dull yellow mottled with orange-brown, where bruised not staining or slowly becoming dull brown^, (Smith), 0.5-4.5cm across, nearly spherical to flattened or lobed; when young "brilliant yellow, with age fading to dull yellow mottled with or nearly completely orange brown to reddish brown, where bruised not staining or slowly becoming dull brown, in wet weather lubricous and spotted with droplets of brown exudate", "when dried dull olive, often brown mottled", peridium 0.02-0.03cm thick, (Fogel)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  rubbery-gelatinous, chamber contents brownish yellow when young becoming brownish black by maturity^, (Smith), rubbery-gelatinous, "with gel-filled chambers separated by white to light yellow, meandering veins", the chamber contents when young brownish yellow, when mature becoming brownish black, when dried brownish black, (Fogel)
STEM  rhizomorphs fine, colored as surface, appressed, most abundant near the base^, (Smith), rhizomorphs "fairly abundant near base and widely scattered on side and top", colored as surface, fine, appressed; "basal mycelium brilliant yellow", massed in soil near fruitbody, (Fogel)
ODOR  mildly garlicky to fruity when old^, (Smith), "variously described as mildly garlicky to fruity in age", (Fogel)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under conifers, April through October^, (Smith), underground, a probable mycorrhizal associate with Abies spp. (fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and possibly other Pinaceae, April through October, low to middle elevations, (Fogel), April to December (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 4.0-6.5(8.5) x 1.8-3(3.5) microns, mostly elliptic^, (Smith); spores 4.0-6.5(8.5) x 1.8-3(3.5) microns, mostly elliptic but a few fusiform [spindle-shaped], oblong, reniform [kidney-shaped], etc., "obscurely truncate cupped", smooth, "in KOH light yellowish gray to light brownish yellow singly, brown to dark reddish brown in mass", "in Melzer's reagent pale orange yellow to pale brownish yellow singly, orange brown to dark brown in mass", thin-walled, in cotton blue the walls strongly cyanophilic when young, acyanophilic at maturity; basidia 4-8(12)-spored, 8-16 x 4-6 microns, clavate, "borne among gelatinizing hyphae stuffing the chambers", autolysing by maturity, thin-walled, sterigmata short, cylindric; tramal walls 20-50 microns thick, the mediostratum of hyphae 3-10 microns wide that are subparallel, colorless, highly gelatinized, "near the chambers interwoven divergent from the mediostratum"; subcutis 50-250 microns thick, of hyphae 3-8 microns wide that are colorless, tightly woven, thin-walled, with occasional cells inflated up to 25 microns, "the walls of hyphae progressively more gelatinized near the gleba and confluent with tramal tissue"; epicutis 20-40 microns thick, of hyphae 3-10 microns wide, yellowish brown, appressed, thin-walled, with occasional cells inflated up to 25 microns, "the color mostly in the cell contents and diffusing into the fluid of KOH mounts"; clamp connections present, (Fogel) 
NAME ORIGIN  refers to James Trappe, author of a 1975 revision of the genus Alpova
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(4) (as Alpova luteus), Fogel(3), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe(11) (as Alpova luteus), Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)
5
FAMILY  Ambisporaceae, Order Archaeosporales, Class Glomeromycetes, Phylum Glomeromycota
LATIN NAMES  Ambispora gerdemannii  (S.L. Rose, B.A. Daniels & Trappe) C. Walker, Vestberg & A. Schuessler^  in Walker, Vestberg, Demircik, Stockinger, Saito, Sawaki, Nishmura & Schuessler, Mycol. Res. 111(2): 148. 2007;  Glomus gerdemannii  S.L. Rose, B.A. Daniels & Trappe  Mycotaxon 8(1): 297. 1979
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Ambispora gerdemannii is not visible to the naked eye but included because it was considered to be a Glomus species. Spores are formed singly or in loose clusters or small fruitbodies in soil, the spores 140-198 x 149-230 microns, round to nearly round or elliptic (broader than long when not round), colorless and smooth when young, becoming pale yellow brown and roughened when old, the spore wall 5-10(13) microns thick, of 5 layers, attached hypha 7-12 microns wide, straight, readily detaching, the walls thickened a short distance from the point of attachment.^ The online Species Fungorum, accessed March 26, 2014 gave the current named as Ambispora gerdemannii. RANGE The type collection was found in OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  spores naked, formed singly or in loose clusters or small fruitbodies in soil
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "on volcanic soils in climatically stressed and pioneer sites"; associated in the field with vesicular-arbuscular mycorrhizae of Ceanothus velutinus, C. prostratus, and C. integerrimus, (forming mycorrhizae in pot culture with C. velutinus)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 140-198 x 149-230 microns, round to nearly round or elliptic (broader than long when not round), colorless and smooth when young, becoming pale yellow-brown and roughened when old, spore wall 5-10(13) microns thick, of 5 layers: 1) the outermost +/- 0.5-1.0 microns thick, colorless, smooth when young, when old "becoming roughened and cracked and flaking away in pieces", 2) 2-5 microns thick, colorless and fused-laminated when young, when old "becoming pale yellowish brown and degrading progressively inward to flake away as amorphous pieces of laminations", 3) 1-2 microns, colorless, smooth, separable, 4) +/- 0.1 micron thick, colorless, adherent to the 5th layer, 5) 2-3 microns thick, yellow, spore contents of colorless oil droplets 7-25(50) microns in diameter; attached hypha 7-12 microns wide, straight, readily detaching, "the walls thickened a short distance from the point of attachment, occluded by thickening of the 2nd spore layer"; reaction to Melzer's reagent not distinctive
NAME ORIGIN  "In honor of Dr. James W. Gerdemann for his contributions to knowledge of the Endogonaceae, particularly those of Oregon." (Rose)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Rose(1)
6
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Arcangeliella gardneri  (Zeller & C.W. Dodge) Zeller & C.W. Dodge^  Ann. Mo. bot. Gdn 22: 367. 1935;  Zelleromyces gardneri  (Zeller & C.W. Dodge) Singer & A.H. Sm.  Mem. Torrey bot. Club 21(3): 23. 1960;  Gymnomyces gardneri  Zeller & Dodge;  Lactarius gardneri  (Zeller & C.W. Dodge) Pierotti (proposed new combination)
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include a nearly spherical to irregular, cream to clay-color fruitbody (in alcohol), a spore mass with small, spherical to irregular cavities, a dendroid columella resembling thickened septa, and microscopic characters including nearly round spores with amyloid ornamentation forming a broken reticulum, and lactiferous ducts. RANGE Arcangeliella gardneri is infrequent from western OR to northern CA, (Trappe).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2.5cm x 1.5cm x 1.5cm in alcohol, drying 1.4cm x 0.8cm x 0.8cm, nearly spherical to irregular, depressed; cream to yellow ocher in alcohol, drying tawny olive; latex white according to H.E. Parks
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  drying cream to clay-color; cavities small, spherical to irregular
STEM  columella dendroid [branching in root-like fashion], resembling much thickened septa
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under leaves of Quercus agrifolia (Coast Live Oak), December, (Zeller), associated with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Quercus, (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-13 x 6-11 microns, nearly round, usually somewhat elongate, reticulate, rugose under oil immersion, colorless^; basidia 2-spored, 25-29 x 9-10 microns, colorless, sterigmata slender, 6-7 microns long; septa 60-80 microns thick, colorless, with lactiferous ducts, columella of quite gelified, colorless hyphae, with lactiferous ducts, drying russet-brown; peridium 100-150 microns thick, of homogeneous colorless prosenchyma, "except a narrow scissile layer of periclinal hyphae next to the gleba", (Zeller), spores 9-12.5(15) x 6.5-8.5(10) microns, broadly elliptic to nearly round, ornamentation strongly amyloid, 0.25-0.5 microns high with a "pattern of crooked ridges, warts fused into crests and these connected to give the effect of a broken reticulum", nearly colorless in KOH, sterigmal appendage inconspicuous, about 2 microns long; basidia 4-spored, 26-37 x 7-9 microns, clavate; pseudoparaphyses 20-25 x 10-12 microns, clavate; cystidia 24-35 x 10-16 microns, ellipsoid-mucronate, thin-walled, readily collapsing, contents homogeneous or nearly so, (Singer(10) study of the type)
NAME ORIGIN  after N.L. Gardner, who collected the type
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Zeller(16), Trappe(13), Singer(10) (as Zelleromyces)
7
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Arcangeliella tenax  A.H. Sm. & Wiebe^  Mycologia 55: 422. 1963
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Arcangeliella tenax is a sequestrate Lactarius; characterized by relatively large size of fruiting body, pale buff color, white unchanging latex, spore mass gill-like but convoluted to lacunose, poorly developed stem, peppery taste, and spores that have a strongly amyloid ornamentation and a smooth plage, (Thiers(4))^; Arora describes A. tenax and A. lactarioides as very similar to if not the same as A. crassa; Smith(24) described this species from Mt. Hood, OR; Thiers(4) in 1979 gives a description of the species from CA, but Thiers(6) in 1984 gives Arcangeliella tenax A.H. Sm. & Wiebe as a synonym of Arcangeliella crassa Singer & A.H. Sm.; the list in Trappe(13) keeps them separate and provides a citation for the transfer to Gastrolactarius (the transfer not found on the online Species Fungorum, accessed March 24, 2014 or April 1, 2018).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  7cm wide, 5.5cm high, pale buff, not changing color on injury; moist to slightly tacky^, (Smith(4)), 7cm wide and 5.5cm high, "convex-depressed with the depression slightly off-center", "margins irregularly and unevenly appressed to stem-columella", the spore mass completely enclosed; peridium pale buff when fresh, not changing color with injury, near "pinkish buff" when dried; "moist and very slightly tacky but appearing unpolished", (Smith(24)), 4-8cm in diameter, 2-6cm high, flat-convex to convex when young becoming flat to shallowly depressed "to highly irregular and uneven in outline when mature"; near "pinkish-buff" to "pale pinkish buff" when young, unchanging or darkening to "cinnamon buff" when old, unchanging when bruised; dry to moist or sometimes subviscid, dull, bald or obscurely appressed-fibrillose on the disc, (Thiers(4))
INNER LAYER  1.2cm thick near stem-columella, thinning to 0.1cm at margin, firm in disc; pale ochraceous (colored as surface), "unchanging or becoming very slightly pinkish when cut"^, (Smith(24)), 1-2cm thick on disc, thinner toward margin, firm; white to "pinkish buff", unchanging on exposure, (Thiers(4)); milk: white, opaque, unchanging, (Smith(4)), present in cortex of stem-columella, spore mass, and disc of peridium, "abundant at first but after 30-45 seconds disappearing and showing only as slight white granulosity", "pure white, thin, milky-opaque, unchanging", (Smith(24)), scant, white, unchanging on exposure, not staining the flesh or cap, (Thiers(4))
INTERIOR  spore mass completely enclosed, maze-like; pale ochraceous, (Smith(4)), spore mass attached to the stem-columella and peridium, cavities labyrinthiform to lacunose, rather large, 0.2-0.3cm, "irregular, empty to partly filled, walls marked with scattered white granules"; pale ochraceous (colored as flesh), "unchanging or becoming slightly pinkish when cut", (Smith(24)), spore mass "typically completely enclosed by the peridium" [outer wall], "rarely becoming exposed when old", gill-like but plates "completely folded and convoluted, often anastomosed and lacunose"; near "ochraceous buff" to "pinkish buff", unchanging when exposed, (Thiers(4))
STEM  4.5cm long and 2.5cm wide at top, stem-columella, colored as cap^, (Smith(4)), stem-columella 4.5cm long, 2.5cm wide at top, solid, narrowed slightly near base; colored as peridium, (Smith(24)), 0.5-1.5cm x 0.5-1cm, "often obscure and poorly developed", often eccentric [off-center], solid or often hollow when mature; colored as cap; dry, bald, (Thiers(4))
ODOR  "moderately sweetish-fungoid when fresh, not distinctive in dried specimens", (Smith(24)), strong, unpleasant, (Thiers(4))
TASTE  milk quickly and strongly peppery^, (Smith(4)), milk immediately and very strongly peppery, (Smith(24)), immediately peppery (Thiers(4))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  conifer forest^ (Smith(4)), type single "in clay soil along an old road through a conifer woods mostly composed of firs", about half exposed, (Smith(24)), under red fir (Thiers(4) for California), associated with Pinaceae (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  print presumably unobtainable
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8.5-10.3 x 6.5-8 microns, elliptic, "ornamented with complete to broken reticulum"^, (Smith(4)), spores 8.5-10.3 x 6.5-7.5(8) microns, elliptic, thin-walled, inamyloid but ornamentation strongly amyloid in form of "a complete to broken reticulum with rather small meshes, prominences 0.3-0.5 microns high and the coarse bands about as broad, finer lines also present, plage area smooth or with greatly reduced faintly amyloid ornamentation"; basidia (2,3)4-spored, 38-50 x 9-12 microns, clavate, thin-walled, colorless in KOH, macrocystidia not abundant, 33-48 x 9.5-12 microns, "ventricose to ventricose-rostrate (somewhat fusoid) with obtuse to subacute apices"; subhymenium "not differentiated from remainder of hymenophoral trama, of compactly interwoven hyphae often with cells 8-10(12) microns broad, but not sphaerocyst-like", laticiferous hyphae 8-12 microns wide and with colorless granular content revived in KOH; peridium "of heteromerous tissue, the sphaerocysts thin-walled or walls slightly thickened and yellowish in KOH and in some slightly refractive, collapsing in drying and reviving slowly"; epicutis of peridium 200 microns or more thick, hyphae 3-6 microns wide, appressed, interwoven, "with thin, smooth to slightly encrusted nongelatinous walls, those at the surface ochraceous in KOH"; clamp connections none, (Smith(24)), spores 7.5-10 x 5.5-7.2 microns, elliptic, "walls ornamented with a strongly amyloid, complete to more commonly broken reticulum, with a rather large smooth plage"; basidia 4-spored, 35-47 x 9-15 microns, clavate, thin-walled; cystidia "embedded in spore-bearing surface and often not easily detected", 35-50 x 8-15 microns, "ventricose to fusoid to subclavate, moderately thick-walled", colorless in KOH and Melzer's reagent; hymenophoral trama interwoven, lacking sphaerocysts, pale yellow in KOH and Melzer's reagent; cap trama "interwoven, with numerous conspicuous masses of sphaerocysts"; epicutis composed of "narrow compact layer of closely appressed interwoven hyphae", pale yellow in KOH and Melzer's reagent, not gelatinous; clamp connections absent, (Thiers(4))
NAME ORIGIN  from tenax = tenacious (Latin)
SIMILAR  Lactarius crassus is similar but A. tenax differs in the sphaerocysts having walls thin enough to collapse readily, spores with higher ornamentation, and the plage is faintly ornamented (hence very weakly amyloid) as opposed to the plage in L. crassus which is covered by a mass of amyloid material, also L. crassus has a more distinctly cellular hymenium than G. tenax and the hymenophoral tissue when revived in KOH is not as tough, (Smith(24))
SOURCES  Smith(24) (as Arcangeliella), Smith(4) (as Arcangeliella), Thiers(4) (as Arcangeliella, colors from Ridgway), Arora(1) (as Arcangeliella), Thiers(6) (as Arcangeliella), Trappe(13)
8
FAMILY  Helvellaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Balsamia alba  Harkn.^  Proc. Calif. Acad. Sci., Ser. 3, Bot. 1: 264. 1899
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Balsamia alba has a sordid white, nearly spherical fruitbody with prominent warts, and a firm spore mass. It fruits underground in association with oak.^ RANGE Balsamia alba is rare from western OR to southern CA (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  large, nearly spherical; sordid white; with prominent warts ("profunde verrucosa")
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  firm
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  associated with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Pinus (pine), Quercus (oak), (Trappe), in ground under Quercus in California (Sacc.)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores about 18 x 12 microns, cylindric, guttulate; asci 8-spored, small, ellipsoid
NAME ORIGIN  means 'white'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Saccardo's Syll. fung. XVI: 811.(Latin); Trappe(13)
9
FAMILY  Helvellaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Balsamia magnata  Harkn.^  Proc. Calif. Acad. III. I: 264. 1899;  Pseudobalsamia magnata  (Harkn.) Gilkey
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) an orange to reddish brown, depressed-spherical, verrucose fruitbody, infolded at the apex, 2) a pale interior with irregular canals (or sometimes chambers) lined with hymenium and filled with hyphae or somewhat open, converging toward the apex and opening to the surface at one or several points, 3) a mycelial tuft more or less persistent at the base, 4) smooth, colorless spores measuring 20-24 x 12-14 microns, irregularly arranged in crowded irregular 8-spored asci, and 5) paraphyses arranged in a palisade.^ It is common in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). Arora(1) says it is common for a truffle in CA and OR in winter and spring. RANGE Balsamia magnata has been found in OR and CA, (Gilkey). It has been reported from AZ (Arora(1)). It is found from OR to southern CA and CO, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-2cm across, spherical to somewhat compressed or flattened, the top usually infolded, exterior "divided into numerous rounded to pointed warts, occasionally with small depressions"; bright orange to reddish brown to brownish pink^ or occasionally black (but may be whitish when very young), (Arora, who however says that the name Pseudobalsamia nigrens [== nigrescens] has been used for the black form (species?)), 1-2cm across, somewhat depressed-spherical; orange to reddish brown, (Gilkey)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "white to pale yellowish, even when mature", composed of crowded folds that form maze-like canals, "the canals united or separated into several chambers and either open or filled loosely with cottony hyphae", canals usually converging at top or sometimes at several points^, (Arora), "consisting of closely crowded folds, often united, separating labyrinthine canals or sometimes closed chambers, all lined by hymenium and generally filled with hyphae", (Gilkey)
STEM  base often with a tuft of mycelium^, (Arora), more or less persistent mycelial tuft at base, (Gilkey)
ODOR  not distinctive^ (Trappe, M.)
TASTE  not distinctive^ (Trappe, M.)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to usually gregarious "under various trees and shrubs (oak, pine, madrone, etc.)"^, (Arora), in forests (Gilkey), associated with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Pinus, Quercus, (Trappe(13)), Pinus, Abies, Pseudotsuga, Quercus; year round (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 20-24 x 12-14 microns, cylindric to elliptic or nearly round, smooth when mature, colorless, usually with 3 oil droplets^; asci typically 8-spored, "mostly imbedded in the tissue between the veins or canals", (Arora), spores 20-24 x 12-14 microns, round-elliptic, smooth, colorless, irregularly arranged in ascus; asci 8-spored, crowded and irregular, spherical-ellipsoid, stipitate; paraphyses principally in regular palisade; "surface verrucae pseudoparenchymatous throughout, the cells thick-walled, becoming smaller and thinner-walled below, changing to loose hyphae beneath the verrucae", (Gilkey)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Balsamia nigrans has a black fruitbody (as opposed to orange to reddish brown), sharp and coarse verrucae, and narrow venae externae closely filled with hyphae, (Gilkey). Pachyphloeus citrinus can also be bright orange but Balsamia magnata has a pale interior and smooth spores, (Arora(1)).
SOURCES  Gilkey(3) (as Pseudobalsamia magnata), Smith, J.E.(1), Arora(1), Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)
10
FAMILY  Helvellaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Balsamia nigrans  Harkn.^  Proc. Calif. Acad. III. 1: 264. 1899 [as 'nigrens'];  Pseudobalsamia nigrans  (Harkn.) Gilkey [as 'nigrens']
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a black somewhat depressed-spherical fruitbody, infolded at the apex and with coarse, angular warts, 2) a pale interior with irregular canals or sometimes chambers, and 3) colorless ascospores measuring 20-37 x 12-15 microns, with barely perceptible colorless meandering lines around the circumference.^ The original name was "nigrens" which is not grammatical - it more likely represents "nigrans" than "nigrescens" since the fungus is black from the beginning rather than "becoming black" or "blackish". The description is derived from Castellano(1) except where noted. It is infrequent among truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Balsamia nigrans is found in OR and northern CA, (Trappe(13)). It is found from central CA to northwest OR (Trappe, M.(3)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  somewhat depressed-spherical; black; coarsely and sharply verrucose; peridium up to 0.04cm thick^, (Castellano), with prominent angular warts (Trappe, M.)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  pale with irregular canals or sometimes chambers (derived from Arora), whitish, marbled with white veins (Trappe, M.)
STEM  point of attachment of mycelial tuft more or less distinct at base [character of genus Pseudobalsamia according to Gilkey]
ODOR  not distinctive^ (Trappe, M.)
TASTE  not distinctive^ (Trappe, M.)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground associated with various Pinaceae spp., particularly Pinus jeffreyi (Jeffrey Pine) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), "and at low to mid elevation"^, (Castellano), associated with Pseudotsuga, Pinus, Quercus (oak), (Trappe(13)), associated with Pinus, Abies (fir), Pseudotsuga, Quercus, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 20-37 x 12-15 microns, oblong, the walls thin and ornamented with minute, barely perceptible, colorless meandering lines around the circumference, spores colorless, with one or more droplets^; asci 40-60 x 30-40 microns, saccate to elliptic, colorless, pale yellow in Melzer's reagent, "tapered to a foot-like to straight base" when young, walls less than 0.5 microns thick; spore mass containing the asci of densely interwoven, colorless, thin-walled hyphae 3-4 microns wide, inner lining of empty locules of hyphae similar but 4-6 microns wide with colorless walls +/-0.5 microns thick, and brown in mass; epicutis of peridium up to 300 microns thick, of radial rows of subrectangular cells 10-40 x 8-18 microns, with red-brown walls thickened to often completely filling the cell, cells readily separable; subcutis of peridium +/- 100 microns thick, "similarly aligned and of similar size and shape but with brown-yellow walls 2-5 microns thick (change from thick-walled to thin-walled cells abrupt and at relatively uniform line)", (Castellano), spores elliptic, smooth, colorless, (Trappe, M.)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'black'
SIMILAR  Balsamia magnata is somewhat similar but Balsamia nigrans differs in the black fruitbody (as opposed to orange to reddish brown for B. magnata), the sharp and coarse verrucae, and the narrow venae externae closely filled with hyphae, (Gilkey).
SOURCES  Castellano(1)* (as Balsamia nigrens), Gilkey(3) (as Pseudobalsamia nigrens), Arora(1) (discussing Balsamia), Trappe, M.(3)* (as Balsamia nigrens), Trappe(13)* (as Balsamia nigrens)
11
FAMILY  Helvellaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Balsamia vulgaris  Vittad.^  Monogr. Tuberac. (Milano): 30. 1831
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Balsamia vulgaris has a minutely papillose fruitbody with wide chambers inside, an offensive odor and taste, an association with conifers, and spores about 28 x 10-11 microns in 8-spored asci.^ The description is derived from Saccardo's Syll. fung. except where indicated. RANGE Balsamia vulgaris is rare in western WA and OR to southern CA, (Trappe).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  large, often sinuous-furrowed? [sinuosa-exarata], excavated in places, minutely papillose
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  chambers somewhat wide; septa thick and pellucid in the middle
STEM  
ODOR  heavy, offensive, mouse-like, sharp
TASTE  unpleasant
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  associated with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Pinus (pine), (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores about 28 x 10-11 microns, elongate-cylindric, smooth, with three droplets^; asci 8-spored, ovate-oblong, blunt, narrowing downward into a rather long filament, about 65 microns long; paraphyses linear and densely crowded? [linearibus dense stipatis]
NAME ORIGIN  means 'common'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Saccardo's Syll. fung. VIII: 877; XIX: 137; XII: 909 (Latin), Trappe(13)
12
FAMILY  Helvellaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Barssia oregonensis  Gilkey^  Mycologia 17: 254. 1925
ENGLISH NAMES  depressed truffle
NOTES  Features include an ocher-buff to reddish brown, somewhat flattened fruitbody typically with a depression at the top into which several canals empty, a white to pale gray interior, absence of a mycelial tuft, underground growth with Douglas-fir, and smooth colorless spores measuring 24-36 x 12-21 microns on 8-spored asci.^ It is considered abundant among truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It has been found at least in OR, ID, and CA, (Smith). It is found from western WA to ID and northern CA, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across, somewhat spherical but "usually more or less flattened or slightly lobed, typically with a prominent depression or cavity at the top", firm but not hard; pale ocher-buff to orange-cinnamon to brick red or reddish brown; "smooth to roughened or finely warted"^, (Arora), 1-2.5cm across, "somewhat lobed to +/- flattened, with a depression forming an irregular cavity"; ochraceous buff to orange-cinnamon; "surface scabrous to warted", (Smith), "light ochraceous-buff" to "orange-cinnamon", (Gilkey(3), colors from Ridgway), 1-2.5cm across, reddish yellow, (Gilkey(1))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "composed of empty, unconnected, broad or narrow canals, many of which empty into the depression (i.e., more or less solid except for the canals)"; white to pale gray, even when mature^, (Arora), "with unconnected canals opening into central depression" (Smith), canals and chambers lined by felt-like hymenium, (Gilkey(3))
STEM  no mycelial tuft at base^ (Arora, Gilkey(1))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single or in small groups in soil in woods, associated with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and possibly other trees, commonest in spring and early summer^, (Arora), beneath tree of Cascara sagrada, (Gilkey(1)), with relatively young Pseudotsuga menziesii, mostly 10-60 years old; year round, but mostly late winter to late spring, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 24-36 x 12-21 microns, oblong-elliptic, smooth, colorless^; asci mostly 8-spored, forming a palisade that lines the canals, (Arora), 26-32 x 12-17 microns, colorless; asci 8-spored, indehiscent, typically cylindrical, (Smith), spores 26-32 x 12-17 microns, elliptic, smooth, colorless, uniseriate or incompletely biseriate; asci 120 x 20-30 microns, mostly cylindric, often curved; paraphyses extending 40-50 microns beyond asci, slender, not swollen at tips, (Gilkey(3)), hymenium consisting or regularly arranged asci and paraphyses; "cortex mostly consisting of coarse hyphae, these sometimes uniting near the surface to form irregular pseudoparenchyma, swollen tips of the hyphae sometimes projecting from the surface", (Gilkey(1))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'from Oregon'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Arora(1), Smith(4), Gilkey(3), Gilkey(1), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)*
13
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Cazia flexiascus  Trappe^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 49: 336. 1989
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a solid, nearly spherical fruiting body with a basal depression, 2) a whitish surface, 3) a light purplish gray interior spore mass, with white sterile veins radiating through the spore mass from the base, 4) the veins lined microscopically with a disorderly hymenium of cylindric to saccate, usually crooked, inamyloid, (5)7-8-spored asci interspersed with chains of inflated cells and scattered paraphyses, 5) the spores elliptic with a single droplet and minutely verrucose-reticulate ornamentation, and 6) the peridium of repent hyphae incorporating occasional large, isodiametric cells.^ The description is derived from Trappe(9). Laessoe(2) place this genus in Pezizaceae. It is infrequent among truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It is found from western OR to southern CA, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  3% KOH on fresh spore mass instantly yellow; "fresh sections mounted in KOH instantly greenish yellow, the color soon fading"
OUTER SURFACE  4.5 x 3.5cm, nearly spherical, "slightly lobed and furrowed, with a basal depression"; "nearly white (with faint yellowish brown cast)", bald; some white veins emerging from interior (venae externae)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  spore mass light purplish gray, "marbled with white veins radiating from a near-white basal pad, some emerging through the peridium" (venae externae)
STEM  
ODOR  faintly pungent
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type erumpent in a mowed lawn under an introduced Quercus (oak) species, but usual habit presumed to be underground
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 13-16 x 10-12 microns, elliptic, incompletely warty-reticulate, the ornamentation 0.2-0.4 microns tall, colorless, with one droplet, spore wall 1 micron thick, weakly cyanophilic in cotton blue^; asci with (5)7-8 uniseriate to incompletely or completely biseriate spores, 105-150 x 20-28 microns, "irregularly cylindric to saccate, mostly crooked", thin-walled, colorless, inamyloid, "obscurely croziered at the base of a tapered stem"; hymenium disorderly, lining labyrinthine venae externae, "composed of asci interspersed among chains of isodiametric cells" 10-20 microns in diameter, "scattered to abundant, greatly inflated cells" 20-75 microns in diameter, and "scattered, cylindric paraphyses" 7-10 microns wide with clavate tips up to 15 microns wide; trama of interwoven to subparallel hyphae 5-15 microns wide at septa, the cells often inflated to 10-25 microns; venae externae "loosely stuffed with hyphae similar to those of trama" but including many cells inflated to 20-75 microns; peridium 100-150 microns thick, of repent, interwoven hyphae 3-15 microns wide at septa, the cells often inflated to 10-25 microns, "the hyphae at the surface averaging smaller than those near the gleba"
NAME ORIGIN  from "flexus", Latin for "crooked", and "ascus", in reference to the distinctively bent asci
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Trappe(9), Laessoe(2), Trappe(13)*
14
FAMILY  Boletaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Chamonixia brevicolumna  A.H. Sm. & Singer^  Brittonia 11: 219. 1959
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include somewhat spherical fruitbody with surface olive ocher but soon stained blue where bruised, at times scattered fine rhizomorphs, spore mass reddish-cinnamon when exposed, but soon stained blue, columella that is a rounded-truncate unbranched basal plug of sterile tissue, underground growth, and microscopic characters including brown spores with even to irregular longitudinal ridges, on 2-spored or 4-spored basidia^; found at least CO, ID, (Smith(4)), rare northern ID (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1.8-2.5cm across, somewhat spherical, unpolished; olive ocher but soon stained blue where bruised; peridium well-developed, at times with scattered fine rhizomorphs^, (Smith(4)), 1.8-2.5cm across, 1.5-2cm deep, somewhat spherical; at first near olive-ocher or bluish olive but soon stained blue where bruised; unpolished, at times with scattered fine rhizomorphs over surface, (Smith(29))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  reddish-cinnamon when first exposed, soon stained blue, chambers minute^, (Smith(4)), "chambered, the cavities minute, having a basically tubular structure; reddish cinnamon when fresh but the tramal plates staining blue when cut", (Smith(29))
STEM  having a distinct basal point of attachment, columella a rounded basal plug extending into the interior up to a third of its thickness, unbranched, soon stained blue where cut^, (Smith(4)), having a distinct basal point of attachment; columella "a truncate to rounded basal plug" extending into spore mass from one fifth to one third of the thickness of the spore mass but unbranched in the specimens examined, buff-yellow when fresh but soon stained blue when cut, (Smith(29))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under ground in spruce-fir forests, summer^, (Smith(4))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15-18 x 10-13 microns, rusty brown in KOH and obscurely grooved to finely wrinkled^, (Smith(4)), spores 15-18 x 10-13 microns, elliptic, many with small sterigmal appendage; "outer layer of the wall forming ridges, the inner layer deeper colored (rusty cinnamon or fulvous) in KOH and dark reddish rusty brown in Melzer's reagent", the eternal part of the inner layer darker in color in KOH than the innermost part, ridges in KOH varying from almost colorless to yellowish or pale cinnamon, "wavy or more rarely straight, often anastomosing, irregular, not all extending from the base to the apex of the spore but roughly longitudinal, entire or lacerate", "apical pore or callus usually distinct but generally with a blister of outer wall material over it", colorless perisporium present but seldom very distinct; basidia 2-spored or 4-spored, 27-41 x 12-17 microns, "often with a large and opaque vacuole"; sterigmata small or somewhat elongated (up to 10 x 12 microns), "conic to straight or curved either inwards or outwards"; cystidia none; pseudoparaphyses 12-20 microns wide; subhymenium narrow and rather poorly developed, consisting of versiform (subvesiculose, elongated, small and irregular) colorless elements that often seem to curve away from the trama; hymenophoral trama uniform, colorless, not gelatinized, its hyphae 3-8.5 microns wide, elongated, interwoven, thin-walled; peridium duplex, the inner layer (context) "bright lemon to chrome yellow in KOH from a pigment dissolving in the mount", consisting of hyphae 2.5-5 microns wide, "arranged tangentially or occasionally ascending, interwoven"; outer layer of peridium a trichodermal palisade, "of elongated thin-walled elements which are frequently septate with some cells inflated" (about 16-19.5 x 15-18 microns), the outermost part consisting of "mostly filamentous elements which are often decumbent over the surface to give a falsely fibrillose effect"; hyphae of columella 2-7 microns wide, colorless, "filamentous, irregularly interlaced but loosely arranged"; clamp connections absent from all hyphae, (Smith(29))
NAME ORIGIN  refers to short columella
SIMILAR  Chamonixia caudata does not bruise blue, (Smith(29)). Chamonixia caespitosa has a columella that extends through the spore mass (percurrent) and larger spores, (Smith(29), but note that Castellano(1) say the stem-columella varies from percurrent to only a small basal pad in C. caespitosa and the Castellano(1) spore size for that species overlaps the Smith(29) spore size of C. brevicolumna).
SOURCES  Smith(4), Smith(29), Castellano(1) (discussing C. caespitosa), Trappe(13)
15
FAMILY  Boletaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Chamonixia caespitosa  Rolland^  Bull. Soc. Myc. Fr. 15: 76. 1899
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a somewhat spherical fruitbody with the base indented, 2) a surface that is white to olivaceous or brown but soon stained blue where bruised, 3) a spore mass that is white staining blue and becoming dark brown from spores, 4) an unbranched columella that extends through the spore mass, 5) underground growth under conifers, and 6) brown spores with even to irregular longitudinal ridges on 4-spored basidia.^ It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It has been found in WA, OR, CA, NY, France, and Germany, (Castellano). It has been found from southwestern BC to northern CA, CO, (Trappe(13)). There is a Paul Kroeger collection from BC deposited at University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-2.6 x 0.8-4cm, somewhat spherical, the base indented; white or when well matured olivaceous, "quickly staining deep blue when exposed or cut"; felty; peridium readily separable^, (Castellano), 2-3cm across, 1.3-2cm high, somewhat spherical to flattened on top, slightly lobed, depressed around a short stem; "white at first, slightly tinged buffish brown when the spores mature, rapidly turning deep indigo blue when bruised, this color eventually fading to greenish blue, but then remaining almost unchanged in drying"; peridium separable (when mature often peeling away in places), silky fibrillose, about 0.04cm thick when fresh, thinner in places, peridium absent or very little developed around stem, (Smith), 1.5-2(3)cm across, +/- spherical, "whitish at first, later brown, spotting black-blue when handled"; smooth to somewhat wrinkled, finely fibrillose to bald; peridium 0.03-0.05cm thick, (Breitenbach)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "with labyrinthine locules, nongelatinized", when young "white and staining blue when exposed, especially near peridium", when mature "dark brown from spores massed on the locule surfaces"^, (Castellano), "chambers small, oblong, not filled with spores at maturity", visible next to stem as peridium is absent or little developed around stem; "white at first, then dark army brown to vinaceous buff", (Smith), chambers irregularly oblong; spore mass white when young, brown-black when mature, (Breitenbach)
STEM  stem-columella varying from percurrent [going through spore mass], 0.2-0.3cm thick and protruding from the base, to only a small basal pad, "the context at first white but later often becoming yellow to pale orange-brown near and below the base, quickly blueing when exposed"^, (Castellano), about 0.4cm high, 0.3cm wide, solid, "narrowed toward the base which continues into white rhizomorphs"; white, turning blue like the outer surface of the fruitbody; columella percurrent through the spore mass "as a narrow but distinct unbranched structure" about 0.05cm wide, (Smith), base tapering into short rudimentary stem, (Breitenbach), with a prominent basal rhizomorph (Trappe, M.)
ODOR  pleasant, slightly resinous, (Castellano), not distinctive (Smith)
TASTE  not distinctive^ (Castellano, Smith)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground in association with various Pinaceae spp., particularly Abies amabilis (Pacific Silver Fir) and Tsuga sp. (hemlock) at high elevation and Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) in coastal forests; fruits June through November^, (Castellano), fruitbodies develop underground and can become visible on surface when mature, (Breitenbach)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 13-22 x 10-16 microns excluding ornamentation, broadly elliptic, "6-14 straight to spiraling, often forked, dark brown, longitudinal ridges 3-5 microns tall, the lateral margins of the ridges ragged, the ridges not meeting at the spore apex", sterigmal attachment +/- 1 x 2 microns^; basidia 4-spored, 32-38 x 15-20 microns; cystidia absent; trama of colorless, subparallel hyphae 3-5 microns wide, "the walls thin or slightly gelatinous thickened"; peridial subcutis of several tiers of more or less isodiametric, colorless, thin-walled cells up to 30 microns in diameter, often in radially aligned rows; peridial epicutis of loosely interwoven to appressed, colorless, thin-walled hyphae 7-9 microns wide; clamp connections absent, (Castellano), spores 18-20.5 x 12.7-15.2 microns, oblate, rich brown when mature, epispore long remaining colorless, finally brown, "irregularly wrinkled to form 8-10 longitudinal ribs", apex "slightly papillate but this often obscured by the wrinkles of the epispore", sterigmal appendage short, narrow, and colorless; basidia 4-spored, mostly about 36 x 18 microns, "in a true hymenium"; subhymenium "somewhat indefinite in thickness, of isodiametric cells"; hyphae of tramal plates 4-5 microns wide, colorless, only slightly gelatinous; "hypodermial zone of almost isodiametric cells somewhat radially arranged"; epicutis of peridium of appressed yellowish hyphae 7-9 microns wide; clamp connections absent, (Smith), spores 18-22 x 13-15 microns, oval, with longitudinal ribs, apex tuberculate, base with distinct apiculus; basidia 2-4-spored, 40-50 x 15-20 microns, clavate, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'caespitose' (clustered)
SIMILAR  Chamonixia caudata does not bruise blue, (Smith(29)). Chamonixia brevicolumna has a columella that is a rounded-truncate basal plug of sterile tissue, and smaller spores, (Smith(29), but note that Castellano(1) say the stem-columella varies from percurrent to only a small basal pad in C. caespitosa and the Castellano(1) spore size for that species overlaps the Smith(29) spore size of C. brevicolumna).
SOURCES  Castellano(1)*, Smith(29), Breitenbach(2)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)*
16
FAMILY  Boletaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Chamonixia caudata  (Zeller & C.W. Dodge) A.H. Sm. & Singer^  Brittonia 11: 217. 1959;  Arcangeliella caudata  Zeller & C.W. Dodge  
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include light brown to dark yellowish brown or maroon fruitbody that is spherical or pear-shaped, the fleshy spore mass with small chambers radiating somewhat from the base, white to yellowish becoming cinnamon brown, the stem white with velvety surface, and microscopic characters including spores with longitudinal ridges on 2-spored and 4-spored basidia^; frequently parasitized by Hypomyces chrysospermum, (Smith), found at least OR, CA, (Smith), rare, southwestern OR to northern CA, (Trappe(13)); Chamonixia ambigua (Zeller & C.W. Dodge) A.H. Sm. & Singer is illustrated by Desjardin(6) for CA and given as a synonym of Chamonixia caudata by the Index Fungorum, accessed January 20, 2015.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.8-2cm across, spherical or pear-shaped, the base narrowing, the top flattened or rounded; "varying from light brown to dark yellowish brown or maroon" except for a small area around the short stem^, (Smith), yellowish-brown to brown or maroon, does not stain blue, (Arora), velvety (Zeller)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  fleshy; "chambers small, irregular and radiating somewhat from the base of the columella"; white to yellowish, cinnamon brown when old or when dried^, (Smith)
STEM  stem-columella with the stem part almost white, near mummy-brown to olive-brown when dried (in the type), the surface velvety; columella part present "as a sterile base varying to percurrent or with lateral branches"^, (Smith), short, whitish, (Arora)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under oak and other hardwoods (Arora), in leaf mold of Quercus (oak), (Smith)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-15 x 9-11 microns, elliptic to ovate, "the primary ornamentation in the form of longitudinal ridges irregular in shape and extending from over one half to the full length of the spore, the secondary ornamentation as cross ridges and tubercles, causing the spores to appear reticulate at times", with distinct apical pore, inner wall thick (1.5-2 microns), spores dark red brown in Melzer's reagent, dull brown in KOH^; basidia 2-spored and 4-spored, the sterigmata prominent; cystidia and paraphyses not seen (hymenium revived poorly, according to Zeller and Dodge cystidia large, clavate, and colorless and paraphyses 19-20 x 4-5 microns, cylindric, obtuse, colorless, and septate); hyphae of tramal plates poorly revived (according to Zeller and Dodge of loosely interwoven, colorless hyphae); "epicutis of peridium a trichodermium of septate hyphae in which the cells are narrowed to the cross walls and some of the apical cells actually become separated"; clamp connections not seen, (Smith), spores 9-15 microns long, with apical pore, (Arora), basidia 24-26 x 9-13 microns, sterigmata short, stout, 3-6 microns long; peridium 200-300 microns thick in upper part, very thin or wanting below, "composed of radial septate hyphae perpendicular to the surface, forming pseudoparenchymatous tissue having cells about 9-10 x 11-13 microns, the septa of the hyphae becoming constricted and finally abjointing spherical to oblong oidia-like cells from the surface of the peridium", (Zeller)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with a tail'
SIMILAR  Chamonixia caespitosa and C. brevicolumna stain blue and have more conspicuous longitudinal ridges, (Smith)
SOURCES  Smith(29), Arora(1), Zeller(16), Trappe(13), Desjardin(6)* (as Chamonixia ambigua)
17
FAMILY  Agaricaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Chlorophyllum agaricoides  (Czern.) Vellinga^  Mycotaxon 83: 416. 2003;  Endoptychum agaricoides  Czern.;  Secotium agaricoides
ENGLISH NAMES  gastroid Lepiota, gastroid Agaricus, puffball Agaric
NOTES  Chlorophyllum agaricoides looks like an unexpanded Agaricus or Lepiota, white becoming brownish, but has only rudimentary gills and never opens out: it has a whitish fleshy spore mass that becomes yellowish then pale brown. The stem, which is white but discolors, extends up into the spore mass and usually extends down slightly below the cap (up to 2cm).^ RANGE Chlorophyllum agaricoides has been found in the Rocky Mountains up to 3000m elevation, and also in cultivated areas - it has been recorded from AB, MB, ON, Ukraine, Algeria, Asia, Australia, and New Zealand, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen). It is widely distributed throughout North America (Phillips). A collection was used from Italy (Vellinga(4)). There are collections from BC at the University of British Columbia and collections from ID and WA at the University of Washington. Oregon State University has collections from OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  (1)2-7(10)cm across, and 2.5-10(12)cm high, cap spherical to oval to pear-shaped, broadly conic, or heart-shaped (narrower at top); white becoming buff to tan, ocher or brownish; dry, fibrillose, sometimes developing Lepiota-like scales that give it a shredded appearance; margin typically joined to stem^, (Arora)
INNER LAYER  white when fresh, but in one form staining vinaceous-brown when exposed^, (Arora)
INTERIOR  spore mass like contorted gills, chambered; "at first white and fleshy, then turning yellowish and finally becoming brown to yellow-brown in old age, and sometimes powdery"^, (Arora), whitish becoming pale brown when mature (Phillips)
STEM  extending up into spore mass, sometimes entirely internal, "but usually extending slightly below the cap (up to 2cm), usually thickest at base of cap"; white when fresh, but often discoloring like the cap when old; "usually with a mycelial cord at base"; veil not clearly differentiated from cap^, (Arora), whitish becoming yellowish (Phillips)
ODOR  like cabbage in mature specimens^ (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), none (Miller)
TASTE  mild^ (Miller)
EDIBILITY  caused hemolytic anemia in a dog, which had eaten a mature fruitbody (DE Desjardin pers. obs. as reported in Vellinga(5)); said to be edible when young (Arora), edible when young and tastes sweet and nutty (Lincoff)
HABITAT  single, scattered, in groups, or even in dense clusters on lawns, flower beds, fields, and waste places^, (Arora), May to October (Phillips)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-9(11) x 5-7 microns, elliptic, smooth, with a thick inner wall that has an apical pore^; capillitium absent, (Arora), spores 6.5-8 x 5.5-7 microns (Phillips)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'like Agaricus'
SIMILAR  Agaricus inapertus has a pallid spore mass that becomes blackish, has a longer stem, and fruits in conifer woods.
SOURCES  Arora(1)* (as Endoptychum agaricoides), Phillips(1)* (as Endoptychum agaricoides), Miller(14)* (as Endoptychum agaricoides), Lincoff(2)* (as Endoptychum agaricoides), Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)* (as Endoptychum agaricoides), Trudell(4)* (as Endoptychum agaricoides), Vellinga(4), Vellinga(5)
18
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Choiromyces alveolatus  (Harkn.) Trappe^  Mycotaxon 2(1): 114. 1975;  Piersonia alveolata  Harkn.
ENGLISH NAMES  hard truffle
NOTES  Choiromyces alveolatus is characterized by a lobed fruiting body that is white to yellow or brown, a spore mass that is yellow-orange with pale colored veins, and the unique golfball-like spores, usually on 4-spored asci.^ The description is derived from Castellano(1). It is infrequent among truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It has been found in WA, OR, and CA, (Castellano). It is listed for ID by Hawker in Fogel(7).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  up to 5cm across, slightly lobed; white, becoming yellow or brown; scabrous, sometimes pubescent [finely hairy]
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "yellow with orange-colored dots, separated by pale-colored veins"
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under soil surface associated with various Pinaceae species, particularly Abies procera (Noble Fir), other Abies, Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), and T. mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock) above 1300m elevation, May through November
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 22-36 microns, round, "golfball-like", "minutely alveolate, walls of alveoli half as wide as alveolar cavities", 10-14 alveoli across diameter, spores yellow or brown^; asci 1-4-spored, generally 4-spored, 80-104 x 64-72 microns, borne in distinct large nests, generally irregularly bent or variously shaped by inward extending branches of the internal veins (venae internae), generally long-stemmed, "crowded, club-shaped, more or less deformed", "separated by fascicled, swollen-tipped paraphyses"; 'outer cortical "tissue" of branched intermingled hyphae, often projecting from surface, forming hairs; structure beneath, becoming pseudoparenchymatous, of distinctly angled cells reaching 20 microns in diam, cells becoming smaller within, changing to subcortical structure of compactly arranged, sometimes connected hyphae running parallel to surface of ascocarp; thickness of peridium, 220-600 microns'; venae externae "generally short, lined with paraphyses, filled with loose, branched hyphae similar to outer cortical layer"; venae internae "much branched, broadened at angles, varying in width but mostly slender, of compact hyphal structure similar to subcortex, becoming pseudoparenchymatous in places"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'alveolate'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Castellano(1)*, Arora(1), Fogel(7), Trappe(13)
19
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Choiromyces meandriformis  Vittad.^  Monogr. Tuberac. (Milano): 51 (1831);  Choiromyces venosus  (Fr.) Th. Fr.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Choiromyces meandriformis is characterized by its large size and a unique spore ornamentation of spines and rods that are up to 6 microns high and 1 micron wide, usually on 8-spored asci.^ It is rare among truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It has been found in Lane County, OR and is widespread in Europe, (Trappe(13)). It has been found in OR, CA, WV, and Europe, (Castellano(1) as C. venosus),. A collection was used from IA (Bonito(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  up to 10cm broad or more, irregularly folded-lobed; "pallid, pink-buff or paler, in places spotted vinaceous buff to fawn color"; "almost smooth, slightly fibrillose, more so in the folds"; peridium thin^, (Castellano), up to 12cm across, irregular knobbly, yellowish brown; smooth, (Dennis), up to 10cm across, often folded-lobed; pale; almost smooth, (Hansen, L.)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "solid with gray-buff later brown, labyrinthine parts"^, (Castellano), soft drying hard; "white, becoming yellowish and streaked with numerous irregular wavy ochraceous lines", (Dennis), solid, with grayish, later brownish, labyrinthine veins, (Hansen, L.)
STEM  none
ODOR  "faint when fresh (like Tuber rufum)"^, (Castellano), strong and aromatic, (Dennis)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under soil surface associated with various Pinaceae species, particularly Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) at low elevation, in October^, (Castellano)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores round, 22-30 microns, including spine and rods that are 3-6 microns high, 16-19 microns broad without ornamentation, pale brown at maturity, biseriate or irregular^; asci 8-spored (rarely fewer), sack-shaped, spore-bearing part 100-120 x 50-60 microns, stem up to 120 microns long; sterile part of gleba of hyphae 5 microns wide (a few up to 15 microns), colorless, loosely woven; "fertile parts of similar hyphae more densely packed"; peridium 400 microns thick, "with an outer pseudoparenchymatic layer, appearing faintly brown", main layer colorless, of interwoven hyphae, (Castellano), spores 16-21 microns in diameter, round, yellow, bearing irregular, blunt, often curved spines up to 4 microns long; asci 8-spored, up to 180 x 70 microns, clavate, (Dennis), spores 22-30 microns in diameter including ornamentation, round, with "spine-like, irregular, pointed or blunt processes", 3-6 microns long, pale brown when mature; asci 8-spored, clavate, biseriate or irregular; peridium thin, about 400 microns thick, (Hansen, L.)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'veiny'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Castellano(1)* (as Choiromyces venosus), Trappe(13)*, Dennis(1), Hansen, L.(1) (as Choiromyces venosus), Bonito(1)
20
FAMILY  Gomphidiaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Chroogomphus albipes  (Zeller) Y.C. Li & Zhu L. Yang^  in Li, Yang & Tolgor, Fungal Diversity 38: 92. 2009;  Brauniellula albipes  (Zeller) A.H. Sm. & Singer  Mycologia 50: 936. 1959;  Brauniellula nancyae  A.H. Sm.  Mycologia 50: 931. 1958;  Brauniellula crassitunicata  Pacioni & Fogel  Mycologia 82: 618. 1990
ENGLISH NAMES  gastroid pine spike
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include 1) a dry to slightly viscid cap covered with grayish fibrils on an ocher to orange ground, often becoming vinaceous when old, 2) ocher to orange flesh, 3) distorted convoluted gills that usually remain covered, 4) a short, ochraceous to dull orange stem that usually become vinaceous-stained, and 5) microscopic characters including large spores on 4-spored basidia, and prominent leptocystidia. Brauniellula albipes is thought to be sequestrate form of Chroogomphus. It resembles Chroogomphus spp. but has rudimentary gills if any, and is often buried or half-buried.^ Chroogomphus albipes is listed as the current name in the online Species Fungorum, accessed February 10, 2015. It is an infrequent sequestrate species in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Collections were examined from ID, CA, CO, NV, UT, and WY, (Pacioni). It is common in the Sierra Nevada and Cascades as well as in ID (Arora), and is also found in AZ (States). A collection from BC is at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  peridium bluish black in Melzer's reagent when fresh, in FeSO4 very quickly turning black, in KOH becoming red or darker purplish red^, (Smith(23))
OUTER SURFACE  (0.5)1-6cm across, "rounded to convex or lobed, or sometimes flattened on top", margin often lobed, at first attached to the stem by the veil, "separating from the veil in age but remaining incurved"; ocher to pale or dull orange "beneath a layer of flattened grayish to brownish-gray fibrils", often becoming vinaceous when old; "dry to very slightly viscid, fibrillose"^, (Arora), (0.5)1-5cm across, blunt bell-shaped to convex or depressed, margin irregular and often lobed and at first connected to stem-columella by thin fibrillose veil, margin becoming free from stem when old but remaining downcurved; grayish to dark drab fibrils on ochraceous ground color that changes slowly when old to vinaceous to purplish red; dry, appressed-fibrillose, or when wet subviscid, (Smith(23))
INNER LAYER  thick, firm; "pale orange to ochraceous when fresh"^, (Arora), thick; ochraceous to ochraceous orange when young and fresh, (Smith(23))
INTERIOR  spore mass "composed of crowded, convoluted plates and/or cavities", "usually remaining covered by the veil, but sometimes partially exposed"; "ochraceous to pale orange, becoming darker (grayish to nearly black) as spores mature"^, (Arora), "a convoluted mass of loculate to lamellate-intervenose tissue", the part of the spore mass becoming exposed usually appearing somewhat lamellate [gill-like], "very few of the interior cavities actually opening to the outside", typically remaining covered by veil and incurved peridial margin but in a few fruitbodies opening out slightly to expose lower part of spore mass; ochraceous at first, but when old drab from spores, (Smith(23))
STEM  0.3-2cm x 0.5-1cm, equal or narrowed in lower part, "often so short that it scarcely protrudes below the cap", solid, firm; ochraceous to dull orange, often becoming vinaceous or reddish-stained when old and / or at base; usually fibrillose; veil "fibrillose, ochraceous or becoming vinaceous"^, (Arora), 0.3-1.5cm x (0.5)0.8-1cm at top, equal or narrowed in lower part, solid; ochraceous overall but when old finally vinaceous red, streaked with ochraceous to vinaceous fibrils from the thin dry veil, "base often reddish from these fibrils", (Smith(23))
ODOR  not distinctive^ (Smith(23))
TASTE  not distinctive^ (Smith(23))
EDIBILITY  unknown (Arora)
