HABITAT  single or scattered to densely gregarious or clustered "in duff under conifers (especially fir and pine)" in mountains, often buried or half-buried in humus layer, summer and early fall^, (Arora), single to cespitose under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), (Smith)
SPORE DEPOSIT  print not obtainable
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16-20 x 6.5-9 microns, elliptic to spindle-shaped, smooth^, (Arora), spores 16-20 x 6.5-9 microns, elliptic, smooth, smoky yellow-brown in water mounts of fresh material, pale melleous in KOH either fresh or revived, strongly pseudoamyloid (dark red-brown) in Melzer's reagent either fresh or revived, wall thickened slightly (less than 1 micron thick), no apical differentiation observed; basidia 4-spored, 44-52 x 9-12 microns, colorless and with "granular" content fresh, dull orange-brown to yellowish in Melzer's reagent; cystidia abundant, 100-150 x 14-26 microns, "subventricose to subcylindric, more or less tapered to an obtuse or subacute apex, walls flexuous toward apex, thin-walled, when fresh with vinaceous-red incrustations around medial area in age, when revived in KOH, content vinaceous red, yellowish-hyaline in Melzer's sol."; hyphae of tramal plates 4-8 microns wide, "subparallel and curving out slightly to an interwoven subhymenium, the hyphae thin-walled, with scattered incrusting particles some of which are reddish as revived in KOH", some hyphae distinctly though weakly amyloid (with blue to lilac walls) when fresh, reaction very erratic in dried material; hyphae of context colorless but in sections revived in KOH the section showing a pinkish tint, mostly not incrusted; hyphae of cuticle 4-5 microns wide, "radially arranged, much incrusting material present and this reddish in KOH on revived sections"; clamp connections none, (Smith(23)), after several years in herbarium, the reddish coloration of the cystidia in KOH did not occur, or at most, there was a very faint change, (Thiers), leptocystidia 130-140 x 30-36 microns, encrusted with vinaceous debris, (States)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with white foot'
SIMILAR  Brauniellula crassitunicata of NM (given here as a synonym) is similar macroscopically but differs in having thick-walled cystidia and slightly smaller spores with a central apiculus (spores (7)10-17(20) x (5.5)6-8(9.5) microns versus 14.5-20 x 10.5-12 microns), (Pacioni).
SOURCES  Smith(23) (as Brauniellula), Arora(1)* (as Brauniellula), Smith(4) (as Brauniellula nancyae), Thiers(4) (as B. nancyae), Pacioni(1) (regarding B. crassitunicata), States(1) (as Brauniellula), Miller(19) (as Chroogomphus albipes), Trappe(13) (as Brauniellula)
21
FAMILY  Gomphidiaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Chroogomphus loculatus  Trappe & O.K. Mill.^  Mycologia 62: 833. 1970
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Chroogomphus loculatus is a sequestrate Chroogomphus, which may be a variety of Chroogomphus tomentosus, (Miller(19)). It is characterized by 1) the nongelatinous cuticle and pigmented cap tissue that is amyloid, 2) the loculate to strongly intervenose nature of the hymenophore, and 3) large spores with a smoky black spore deposit. It is a rare sequestrate species (Trappe(13)), and known from a single site.^ RANGE It is known from Willamette National Forest in OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2.5-7cm across, convex, "margin expanding fully or sometimes remaining almost unexpanded"; "with appressed or repent fibrillose scales which are dark olive over a pale orange to pale yellow ground color, pale brown"; dry^, (Castellano), 2.5-7cm across, convex, margin expanding fully or sometimes almost unexpanded; 'dry, with appressed or repent fibrillose scales which are smoky olive over a pale orange to pale yellowish ground color (4A3-5A3), near "capucine buff" to "pale ochraceous buff"', (Miller(6))
INNER LAYER  flesh pale orange but often olive stained near stem base^, (Castellano), fleshy, pale orange, in stem fleshy, pale orange but often olive-stained near base, (Miller(6))
INTERIOR  spore bearing surface decurrent, very irregular, forming enclosed locules due to numerous interveined connections, clearly loculate; pale pink at first darkening to brown orange when old^, (Castellano), spore bearing surface decurrent, "very irregular forming enclosed chambers due to numerous intervenose connections", clearly loculate; "pale pinkish at first darkening to brownish orange (5C4) in age", (Miller(6))
STEM  2.5-8cm x 1.5-3.5cm, somewhat ventricose [wider in middle] tapering to a dull pointed base, "often fused to 3/4 or more of total length"; pale orange or vinaceous tinged above ring zone, below pallid to yellow, streaked with olivaceous fibrils, olive tomentose over base; dry; mycelium surrounding the base pink; partial veil fibrillose remaining in some as an obscure fibrillose zone^, (Castellano), 2.5-8cm x 1.5-3.5cm, somewhat wider in middle, narrowing to dull pointed base, often fused to three quarters or more of length; pale orange or vinaceous tinged above ring zone, below "pallid to yellowish, streaked with olivaceous fibrils, olive tomentose over the base"; dry; partial veil fibrillose remaining in some as an obscure fibrillose zone, (Miller(6))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  beneath soil surface associated with various Pinaceae species, particularly Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock), at 1400 meters elevation, October^, (Castellano), type single to mostly cespitose [in tufts] with fused stems, under Tsuga mertensiana at 1400m, (Miller(6))
SPORE DEPOSIT  smoky black (Miller(6))
MICROSCOPIC  spores (15)19-30 x 6-9 microns, ovate to elongate-ovate in face view, subfusiform [somewhat spindle-shaped] in side view, walls up to 1 micron thick, brown-black in KOH, deep red, ochraceous to yellow contents in Melzer's reagent^, (Castellano), spores (15)19-30 x 6.0-9.0 microns, ovate to elongate-ovate in face view, subfusiform in side view, slightly thickened walls (1 micron), deep red, ochraceous to yellow contents in Melzer's reagent; basidia 4-spored, 48-72 x 11-15 microns, clavate, thin-walled, colorless in Melzer's reagent and KOH; pleurocystidia and cheilocystidia numerous, 108-200(260) x (13)17-29 microns, nearly cylindric, long fusiform to elongate clavate, walls thin to thick (up to 1.5-3.0 microns), colorless to light yellowish contents in Melzer's reagent, with yellowish walls, protruding 1/2 - 2/3 above hymenium, "sometimes partially covered with dingy yellow-brown incrusted material"; clamp connections absent on fruiting body but present on hyphae of basal mycelium, (Miller(6))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'loculate', referring to the locules in the spore-bearing surface
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Miller(6) (colors from Ridgway(1) and from Kornerup(1)), Castellano(1)*, Miller(19), Trappe(13)*
22
FAMILY  Cortinariaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Cortinarius bigelowii  Thiers & A.H. Sm.^  Mycologia 61: 531. 1969
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Cortinarius bigelowii is characterized by a pale alutaceous to yellowish cap, grayish brown gills when young, a stem with a basal marginate bulb, thin but persistent veil breaking only when old, and growth underground or occasionally breaking through.^ RANGE It is fairly common in ID (Arora). It has been collected in AB and ID, (Miller). It is rare from the Cascade Mountains of OR and WA to central ID, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  cap 3-6cm, convex becoming nearly flat but very irregular in outline; "pale alutaceous but often with a thin mycelial coating causing a hoary appearance"; viscid when young and fresh, but often dry when collected"; veil copious, pallid, seldom breaking, typically remaining as a thin but dense layer of radial fibrils covering the gill cavity"^, (Thiers), cap pale alutaceous to yellowish; veil thin but persistent, breaking only when old, (Smith), cap pale yellow-brown to yellowish; veil whitish, persistent, (Arora), 4-6.4cm across, broadly convex, flat when old; light yellow-brown; "sticky when very young, soon dry"; partial veil "dense, cortinous-membranous, buff with olivaceous hues, soon deep rusty brown from the spores", often remaining as a cover over the gills, (Miller)
INNER LAYER  white, unchanging when bruised^, (Thiers)
INTERIOR  gills adnate, close, narrow to moderately broad; '"avellaneous" (grayish brown) becoming pallid brownish with a lilaceous reflection, finally dull cinnamon from spores'^, (Thiers), gills "adnate, close, medium broad"; yellowish at first, tinted lilac-gray to rusty brown when old, (Miller)
STEM  about 1cm long and 0.6-1cm, with marginate bulb 2-3cm wide at first^, (Thiers), with basal marginate bulb, (Smith), short fat bulbous (Arora), 1.5-3.4cm x 1.2-2.3cm, with abrupt, depressed, basal bulb; dull white; dry, (Miller)
ODOR  none^ (Thiers)
TASTE  none^ (Thiers)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  cespitose [in tufts] to scattered "under the duff or just breaking through, under conifers"^, type found in June, (Thiers), tends to grow under duff, (Arora), usually single at the line between the mineral soil and the duff, (i.e. produced underground or occasionally breaking through), white-bark pine region of Idaho, summer and early fall, (Smith), single to several, under the duff or just breaking through when mature, with conifers at high elevations; summer and fall, (Miller)
SPORE DEPOSIT  easily obtained despite underground growth^ (Smith), dark rusty brown (Miller)
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-11 x 6-7 microns, ovate in face view, inequilateral in side view, rather coarsely verrucose-rugulose [warty-wrinkled], fulvous in KOH, brighter rusty brown in Melzer's reagent^; basidia 4-spored, 30-38 x 7-9 microns, colorless in KOH; pleurocystidia none, cheilocystidia basidium-like; cap trama homogeneous and colorless "beneath a thin gelatinous pellicle of brownish (in KOH) narrow appressed hyphae"; clamp connections present, (Thiers)
NAME ORIGIN  after Howard E. Bigelow, the collector of the type
SIMILAR  Cortinarius magnivelatus and Cortinarius wiebeae also tend to grow under duff and have a persistent veil, but Cortinarius bigelowii has a pale yellow-brown to yellowish cap, a whitish veil, and a short, fat bulbous stem, (Arora). Cortinarius verrucisporus has a yellow to yellow-brown or rusty-stained cap but has a yellowish veil, and very coarsely warted spores, (Arora). Cortinarius saxamontanus also has a coarse fibrous veil but 1) is light yellow with a brownish orange to strong brown disc, 2) has a white context that often changes to very pale violet in the stem when young, 3) has a longer (1.5-5.5cm) bulbous stem, and 4) has larger spores than C. bigelowii, (Fogel(1)).
SOURCES  Thiers(2), Smith(8)*, Miller(14)*, Arora(1), Trappe(13), Fogel(1)
23
FAMILY  Cortinariaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Cortinarius magnivelatus  Morse ex Thiers & A.H. Sm.^  Mycologia 61: 534. 1969
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Distinguishing features are whitish color, underground growth, and a tough thick persistent white veil that darkens on handling.^ It is an infrequent sequestrate species in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Cortinarius magnivelatus has been found in OR, CA, NV, and UT, (Castellano). Distribution includes southwestern OR, northern CA, and NV, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  cap 3-6.5cm, convex becoming flat-convex, sometimes becoming shallowly depressed to umbonate, margin incurved to strongly decurved and attached to the stem by a membranaceous veil at all stages; white when young, becoming pale yellow to yellow, then moderate orange-yellow to dark orange-yellow with age or bruising; moist to dry, usually appearing bald when young, occasionally silky-appressed fibrillose, becoming innately fibrillose to somewhat tomentose; cortina persistent as a heavy, thick membrane, remaining attached to the stem, satiny-white, spores deposited inside^, (Castellano), cap 3-10cm, convex becoming flat or irregularly wavy, margin incurved; white, or white at margin and ocher toward center, often stained buff or ochraceous when old or where bruised; moist or dry, smooth or fibrillose; veil "thick, tough, membranous, elastic, whitish, typically covering the gills through maturity or shredding radially but not normally detaching from the cap and stalk", and "reminiscent of a rubber band", (Arora)
INNER LAYER  thick, firm; white to buff^, (Arora)
INTERIOR  gills adnate to shallowly depressed, thin, not fragile, even when dry, several tiers of subgills, abundantly forked near and at stem; white to pale orange-yellow when young becoming near brown-orange to yellow-brown when mature, unchanging when bruised; edge entire becoming locally eroded at maturity, completely covered by veil^, (Castellano), slightly decurrent to adnate or adnexed, close, often forked near stem; whitish when very young becoming buff and then tawny-brown to brown (Arora)
STEM  1.5-6cm x 1-3cm, typically somewhat bulbous at base, occasionally equal to tapering slightly^, (Castellano), 4-6cm x 1-3cm, often enlarged in lower part, solid; colored as cap or whiter (Arora)
ODOR  not distinctive^ (Castellano), mild (Arora)
TASTE  not distinctive^ (Castellano)
EDIBILITY  unknown
HABITAT  forms fruiting bodies underneath the soil surface associated with roots of conifers above 1500m elevation, May through August^, (Castellano), single to gregarious under mountain conifers (especially fir and pine), usually buried in duff, (Arora), April to September, montane with Pinus, Abies, Tsuga, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  rusty-brown
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8.5-11(14) x 5-8 microns, elliptic, asymmetrical, minutely verrucose to rugulose, thin-walled, (Castellano)^, spores 9-14 x 6-8 microns, elliptic, roughened, (Arora), spores 9.5-14 x 6-8 microns, elliptic, "somewhat inequilateral in side view, verrucose to rugulose"; basidia 4-spored, 27-32 x 8-10 microns, colorless, clavate; pleurocystidia not seen, cheilocystidia present, difficult to locate, 18-23 x 4-6 microns, colorless, "cylindric to ventricose to nearly filamentous, thin-walled"; gill trama regular or nearly so, colorless, hyphae 5-7 microns wide; cap trama interwoven, homogenous, colorless in KOH; cap cuticle "differentiated only as a narrow layer of compactly interwoven hyphae"; "clamp connections present, abundant in the veil tissue", (Thiers)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with large veil'
SIMILAR  Cortinarius wiebeae (discovered in the Cascades) is similarly colored, grows underground and has a persistent veil, but is larger with thin, fragile gills that are brown or rusty (not whitish) when young, (Arora). C. wiebeae appears related but C. magnivelatus is distinguished by 1) gills that are white to very pallid when young, not hazel (ferruginous) as in C. wiebeae and gills of C. magnivelatus are firm and resistant rather than fragile and eroded, 2) gills are forked in C. magnivelatus, 3) the annulus in C. magnivelatus is very tough and persistent and never becomes free, 4) spores are slightly larger in C. magnivelatus, 5) cheilocystidia are differently shaped, and 6) there are numerous clamp connections in the veil tissue of C. magnivelatus, (Thiers(2)). Cortinarius bigelowii also tends to grow underground and has persistent veil, but has a pale yellow-brown to yellowish cap, and a short fat bulbous stem, (Arora). Cortinarius verrucisporus has a yellow to yellow-brown or rusty-stained cap, a thinner, yellowish veil, and very coarsely warted spores, (Arora).
SOURCES  Castellano(1)*, Arora(1)*, Thiers(2), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trudell(4)*, Trappe(13), Desjardin(6)*
24
FAMILY  Cortinariaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Cortinarius pavelekii  (Trappe, Castellano & P. Rawl.) Peintner & M.M. Moser^  Mycotaxon 81: 181. 2002;  Thaxterogaster pavelekii  Trappe, Castellano, & P. Rawl.  Mycotaxon 75: 174. 2000
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Cortinarius pavelekii is characterized by 1) a pale yellow-gray to pale brown-gray fruiting body that is convex to top-shaped, 2) white flesh, 3) a dark red-brown to dark brown spore mass with radiate-labyrinthiform locules, 4) a percurrent stem-columella that often protrudes beyond the base of the fruiting body and is white to gray on the surface, 5) growth in association with roots of Picea sitchensis and Pinus contorta, and 6) narrow warty brown spores from 2-4-spored basidia.^ It is an infrequent sequestrate species in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Cortinarius pavelekii has been found on the northwestern OR coast, (Trappe(13)). It has been found at least in WA and OR (Castellano(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.7-4cm x 1.2-3.5cm, convex to turbinate [top-shaped], the margin appressed against protruding base or seceded up to 0.1cm to expose underlying locules; "pale yellow-gray to pale brown-gray on the disc", towards the margin the same color or grading to olive-gray or brown gray, often radially streaked; surface "thickly slimy-viscid when wet, shiny when dry"^, (Trappe(2)), up to 5cm across, yellowish gray to brown; "thickly slimy-viscid when wet, shiny when dry", (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  with radiate-labyrinthiform [maze-like] locules, "dark cinnamon to dark brown"; "with a percurrent stipe-columella that often protrudes beyond the glebal base"; columella columnar and 0.1-0.2cm broad or often greatly enlarged near the base, "white to gray, in wet weather subviscid or with a viscid zone where the pileus margin is appressed, the context white throughout or in age becoming brown-yellow below"^, (Trappe(2)), dark red-brown to dark brown, (Castellano), chambered; dark cinnamon, (Trappe, M.(3)), columella is enlarged near base and sometimes protrudes beyond bottom of fruitbody (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  percurrent stem-columella that often protrudes beyond the base of the spore mass^, (Trappe(2))
ODOR  faint or sometimes musty - radish-like to sweet medicinal^ (Trappe(2))
TASTE  not distinctive^ (Trappe(2))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "endemic to mature to old-growth forests or forests with an old-growth legacy of coarse woody debris, usually in mossy places", from sea level to +/- 250 meters elevation, underground in association with the roots of Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce) and Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine)^, (Trappe(2)), always underground, rarely breaking soil surface; fruiting March to June, occasionally November, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14-18(21) x (8)9-10(11) microns excluding ornamentation, elliptic, the ornamentation of narrow lines and warts 0.1-0.5(1) microns tall and broad, sometimes nearly partially reticulate, asymmetric appendage +/- 1 x 1.5 microns, spore wall +/- 1.5 microns thick, brown in KOH, golden brown in Melzer's reagent^; basidia 2-4-spored, 30-40 x 9-11 microns, sterigmata +/- 5 x 1.5 microns; subhymenium of more or less isodiametric cells 5-15(20) microns in diameter; trama composed of hyphae 3-6 microns wide at the septa, subparallel, colorless, thin-walled, "some cells inflated up to 15 microns, infrequent golden brown laticiferous hyphae present"; context composed of hyphae 3-10 microns wide at septa, loosely interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, the cells mostly inflated to 5-20(30) microns, many isodiametric; peridium a tangled ixotrichodermium of hyphae 3-4 microns wide, colorless, thin-walled; no clamp connections, (Trappe(2))
NAME ORIGIN  after Henry Pavelek who found the type, and who is a past president of the Oregon Truffling Society
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Castellano(1)* (as Thaxterogaster pavelekii), Trappe(2) (as Thaxterogaster pavelekii), Trappe, M.(1)* (as Thaxterogaster pavelekii), Trappe, M.(3)* (as Thaxterogaster pavelekii), Trappe(13) (as Thaxterogaster pavelekii)
25
FAMILY  Cortinariaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Cortinarius pinguis  (Zeller) Peintner & M.M. Moser^  Mycotaxon 81: 181. 2002;  Thaxterogaster pinguis  (Zeller) Singer & A.H. Sm.  Brittonia 10: 211. 1958 [as pingue]
ENGLISH NAMES  gastroid Cortinarius, slimy pouch
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include 1) a viscid to greasy smooth cap that is buff to olive-yellow to dingy yellow-brown or dark brown, 2) a spore mass of contorted plates and chambers that is yellowish becoming dull brown to pale or dark cinnamon-brown, 3) a stem-columella with a with similar range of color to the cap but often purple or lilac where exposed to light, 4) a yeasty odor and unpleasant taste, 5) growth above the ground or underground under conifers especially in the mountains, 6) brownish spores that are warty and sometimes wrinkled, and 7) basidia 4-spored, a few 2-spored.^ Several other Thaxterogaster species occur in the United States, some undescribed (Arora). Cortinarius pinguis is an abundant sequestrate species in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Collections of Cortinarius pinguis were examined from WA, OR, ID, CA, and WY, and the distribution includes CO, (Singer). It has also been found in western AB (Kernaghan) and BC (collection by Oluna Ceska at University of British Columbia; Paul Kroeger, pers. comm.).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-5cm broad, "rounded or obtuse to convex or lobed", the top often flattened somewhat when old; "buff to olive-yellow to dingy yellow-brown or dark brown"; "slightly viscid to slimy when moist, smooth"^, (Arora), 1-5cm across, usually not as high as broad, depressed-spherical, flattened or convex, in many collections rather misshapen, the spore mass completed enclosed or lower part of spore mass exposed; olive-yellow ("honey yellow" to "Isabella color"), darkening when old to deep dingy yellow-brown ("bister"), at least on the disc; glutinous or strongly viscid when wet, bald, smooth, rarely splitting vertically, (Singer), ocher to olive yellowish; greasy, (Phillips)
INNER LAYER  firm; "white or tinged cap color"^, (Arora), fleshy; pale dull honey-color fading to pallid, (Singer)
INTERIOR  spore mass composed of crowded, contorted plates and/or small chambers; "yellowish becoming dull brown" to pale or dark cinnamon brown^, (Arora), 0.6-1cm deep, "cinnamon buff" becoming "cinnamon"; loculate [chambered] with irregular chambers up to 0.1-0.15cm in diameter, chambers usually not extended in gill-like fashion but if so with anastomosing veins to produce a reticulate appearance, the gill-like development almost always most significant near lower part of spore mass where the spore mass has come free from the columella (generally when cap horizontally expanded), the spore mass separating in some the full length of the columella and in others not at all, (Singer)
STEM  0.5-4.5cm x 0.8-2.5cm, "very short or rudimentary in some forms", well developed in others, equal or swollen at base, percurrent [going through spore mass]; "dull yellowish to buff or colored like the cap, often purple or lilac where exposed to light"; "smooth, often viscid near base when moist"; veil "fibrillose or cobwebby, persisting or disappearing"^, (Arora), 1.0-4.5 x 0.8-2.5cm, always well developed, but short, more or less equal or widening downward, stuffed; purple, possibly from gluten as not purple when dried or preserved; glutinous, smooth, bald; columella continuous with stem and sometimes completely exposed by separation of the spore mass but not glutinous or purple but rather dry and yellowish, almost equal or only slightly narrowing upward; veil glutinous, sometimes forming a ring when mature but this ring often not persistent, the veil colored as the surface of the stem but soon fading, (Singer)
ODOR  yeasty (Phillips), not distinctive (Singer)
TASTE  unpleasant (Phillips), not distinctive (Singer)
EDIBILITY  unknown (Arora), not edible, it is thought, (Phillips)
HABITAT  single to gregarious in duff under conifers especially under spruce in the mountains, (Arora), single to gregarious, rarely cespitose [clustered] (3-5) under duff or projecting through it in conifer forests in mountain areas, June to September, (Singer), September to November (Phillips), usually found in the mountains under Abies (fir), from summer into fall, (Trudell)
SPORE DEPOSIT  not obtainable
MICROSCOPIC  spores (12)14-16.5 x 8-9.5 microns, elliptic to somewhat oblong, warty and/or wrinkled^, (Arora), spores (12)14-16.5(20) x (6.5)8-9.5(10.8) microns, elliptic to elliptic-oblong or oval-oblong, verrucose from a bright and deep rusty ornamentation that is coarser in many spores on or near the apex, (the ornamentation exosporial with a distinct episporium and endosporium underneath and at times a demonstrable thin perisporium over the exosporium), hilar appendage obliquely inserted, rarely basal, spores remaining attached to sterigmata even at maturity; basidia 4-spored, a few 2-spored, 28-35.5 x 9-11.5 microns, colorless, a few fulvous in dried material, clavate, sterigmata acute and often half-sickle-shaped, basidioles spherical; few pseudoparaphysoid bodies present; cystidia none; trama of tramal plates regular, some aggregations of hyphae fulvous in dried material but most single hyphae colorless, with thin-walled clamped hyphae; peridial hyphae "similar and the peridium showing an enormously extended gelatinous pellicle-like outer layer" that is at least 100 microns thick (as revived in KOH), the pellicle consisting of narrow, loosely arranged, colorless, thin-walled, smooth hyphae embedded in a gelatinous mass; all hyphae with clamp connections, (Singer), spores brownish in 3% KOH (Phillips)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'fat, oily, thick' (Latin)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(14) (as Thaxterogaster pinguis, colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Arora(1)* (as Thaxterogaster pinguis), Phillips(1)* (as Thaxterogaster pinguis), Smith(4)* (as Thaxterogaster pinguis), McKnight(1)* (as Thaxtergaster pinguis), Ammirati(5) (as Thaxterogaster pinguis), Kernaghan(1) (as Thaxterogaster pinguis), Trappe, M.(1)* (as Thaxterogaster pinguis), Trudell(4)* (as Thaxterogaster pinguis), Trappe(13)* (as Thaxterogaster pinguis), Desjardin(6)*
26
FAMILY  Cortinariaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Cortinarius saxamontanus  Fogel^  Mycologia 86(6): 798. 1994
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include a flat to convex, yellowish to brownish cap, gills entirely covered by a tough, yellowish veil that persists in fully expanded caps, a yellowish bald stem with a bulbous base, stem flesh that may change to pale violet when young, and partly emergent growth from June to July in alpine areas.^ The description is derived from Fogel(1). RANGE It was described as a species from CO, ID, NV, and UT. It has been recorded from WA (photograph included here). It was sequenced by Liimatainen(2) from WA.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  cap 2.2-10cm across, flat to convex, expanding with wavy outline, margin recurved; margin 'light yellow', occasionally 'light greenish yellow', disc 'brownish orange', 'pale yellow', 'light orange yellow', or 'strong brown', unchanging with handling or exposure; apparently dry and bald
INNER LAYER  flesh in stipe white becoming 'very pale violet' to 'very light purple', not changing in larger fruitbodies
INTERIOR  gills normally developed, appearing decurrent in small fruitbodies, free in large ones, thin, brittle, 0.7-1cm broad, several tiers of subgills present entirely covered by tough veil; 'brownish orange' or 'strong yellow brown' to 'strong brown', unchanging when bruised
STEM  1.5-7.5cm x 0.9-2.5cm, base bulbous and 1.5-4.5cm wide; stem 'light yellow'; bald; veil "persistent as a dense layer of radial fibrils", cap margin attached to "a tough, thickened, fibrillar," 'light yellow' cortina which stretches from cap to stem and persists in fully expanded fruitbodies, cortina rupturing during drying, fragments staying attached to stem 
ODOR  "fungoid, not distinctive"
TASTE  not noted
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  subemergent, forming humps about 5cm high in the duff where they have failed to emerge, associated with Pinus (pine) and Abies (true fir) species, fruiting from late June to late July at 2500-3500 meters elevation
SPORE DEPOSIT  deposits spores on the inside of the veil
MICROSCOPIC  spores (10)11-13(15) x 7-9 microns, subelliptic to broadly elliptic in face view, inequilateral in side view with laterally placed hilar apex, "tuberculate-rugose, some warts anastomosing to appear as short lines", 'deep orange', immature spores dextrinoid, spore wall up to 0.5 microns thick^; basidia 4-spored, 33-37 x 6-11 microns, clavate, thin-walled, colorless, base truncate without clamp connection; cystidia absent but sterile basidioles 25-30 x 10 microns, clavate, colorless, thin-walled; clamp connections absent in cap and stipe but present in veil
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin 'saxum' meaning 'rock' and Latin 'montanus' meaning 'pertaining to mountains', may refer to the Rocky Mountains where some collections were found
SIMILAR  Cortinarius bigelowii also has a coarse fibrous veil but is light brown with a very short (1cm) bulbous stem, has white unchanging flesh, and has smaller spores, (Fogel).
SOURCES  Fogel(1), color in single quotation marks from Kelly(2), Liimatainen(2)
27
FAMILY  Cortinariaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Cortinarius verrucisporus  Thiers & Smith^  Mycologia 61: 533. 1969
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include 1) a tan to yellowish or yellowish brown, or rusty-stained fruitbody that has a similarly colored, permanent veil stretching from stem or stem base to the cap margin at all stages of development, the veil often tearing radially, and 2) conspicuously coarsely warted spores. It is rare among sequestrate species in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)).^ RANGE Cortinarius verrucisporus was described from CA (Thiers(2)). It occurs in ID, northern CA and CO, (Trappe(13)). Arora(1) says it is fairly common in the Sierra Nevada. Dick Bishop reports it from OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  cap 3-6cm across when mature, convex when young, becoming flat-convex to flat or shallowly depressed, often "highly irregular and undulating in outline", margin strongly incurved, attached to stem "by a tenacious permanent veil during all stages of development"; 'when very young white to "light buff" (tan), very soon becoming "ochraceous tawny" (rusty brown) with some areas colored near "sulphur yellow" to "chamois" to "clay color"'; "dry to moist, innately fibrillose to subtomentose when young", unchanging or becoming bald to obscurely fibrillose when old; "partial veil permanent, tough, fibrous", colored as the surface of the cap^, (Thiers), cap yellow to yellow-brown or rusty-stained; yellowish veil stretches from stem or stem base to cap margin and usually tears radially, (Arora), cap 3-7cm across, convex, expanding to flat-convex, margin incurved then downcurved, often wavy; at first pallid to pale buff with innate appressed fibrils, these becoming yellowish to tawny when old, the disc then often dingy reddish brown; partial veil yellowish, fibrillose, remaining attached to cap when mature, spores released via radial tears in partial veil, (MykoWeb)
INNER LAYER  flesh up to 1cm thick, firm; yellow, unchanging when exposed, both in cap and in stem^, (Thiers), cream buff (MykoWeb)
INTERIOR  gills "subdecurrent to adnate, close to subdistant", fragile, thin, somewhat ventricose, becoming noticeably crisped when dry, several tiers of subgills; 'pallid to "pale olive buff" when young becoming "amber brown" as spores mature', edges colored as faces; edges entire^, (Thiers), gills broad (Arora), gills adnate to notched, broad, up to 1cm broad, subgills in 3-4 series; pallid becoming dull rusty brown from spores, (MykoWeb)
STEM  1-1.5cm x 1-1.5cm at top, poorly developed and somewhat obscure, equal to slightly bulbous, solid; colored as cap; "covered with partial veil during all stages of development"^, (Thiers), frequently underdeveloped (Arora), 1-3cm x 1-2cm, equal to bulbous, if bulbous often marginate; covered by veil, (MykoWeb)
ODOR  not distinctive^ (Thiers)
TASTE  not distinctive^ (Thiers)
EDIBILITY  unknown (MykoWeb)
HABITAT  type single in humus under conifers, (Thiers), single to scattered, often found well buried in conifer duff in mountains; occasional in spring, rare in fall, (MykoWeb)
SPORE DEPOSIT  dull rusty brown^ (MykoWeb)
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10.5-13.0 x 6.5-8.0 microns, oval, conspicuously verrucose-roughened with large, coarse warts that often unite to form short reticulations, noticeably thick-walled^; basidia 4-spored, 27-30 x 7-9 microns, clavate, colorless in KOH; pleurocystidia and cheilocystidia apparently absent; cap cuticle differentiated as a layer of appressed hyphae that stain vinaceous in KOH, walls subgelatinous in KOH; "clamp connections present throughout, abundant in the veil tissue", (Thiers), spores very coarsely warted (Arora)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with verrucous [warty] spores'
SIMILAR  Cortinarius magnivelatus is whitish with a thicker veil that (as in C. verrucisporus) typically covers the gills through maturity, (Arora). Cortinarius wiebeae is whitish with thin, fragile gills that are brown or rusty (not whitish) when young, (Arora). Cortinarius bigelowii has a pale yellow-brown to yellowish cap, but the veil is whitish, (Arora).
SOURCES  Thiers(2) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway(1)), Arora(1), MykoWeb(1), Trappe(13)*, Desjardin(6)*
28
FAMILY  Cortinariaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Cortinarius wiebeae  Thiers & A.H. Sm.^  Mycologia 61: 529. 1969
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Cortinarius wiebeae is characterized by an underground habit, ferruginous gills, a heavy veil, and small basidia.^ RANGE Cortinarius wiebeae was described from OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  cap 6-13cm, broadly convex becoming nearly flat or finally slightly depressed, margin inrolled for a long time; white, becoming somewhat tan colored on handling and with drying; dry, silky, with radiating fibrils; veil persistently extending from cap margin to stem and only when old shredding radially^, (Thiers)
INNER LAYER  3cm thick near stem, firm, confluent with stem; white^, (Thiers)
INTERIOR  gills sinuate, crowded, numerous tiers of subgills, broad (up to 1.3cm), narrowed toward both extremities, very thin and fragile; '"hazel" (ferruginous) when fresh and young, dark rusty brown from spores in age'; edges eroded^, (Thiers)
STEM  4-9cm x 2.4-4cm, club-shaped, up to 5cm thick at base, solid; whitish when fresh; dry, "coated with white fibrils from copious veil ending in a submembranous annulus"^, (Thiers)
ODOR  faintly radish-like^ (Thiers)
TASTE  mild^ (Thiers)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type gregarious and hypogeous under a fir tree, (Thiers), under soil surface associated with roots of Pseudotsuga menziesii and Pinus ponderosa above 1200m^, (Castellano), tends to grow under the duff (Arora)
SPORE DEPOSIT  "Sanford's brown", (Thiers), dark brown (Castellano)
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-11 x 6-7.5 microns, subelliptic in face view, obscurely inequilateral in side view, warty-rugulose (warty-wrinkled)^; basidia 4-spored, 17-22 x 5.5-7 microns; pleurocystidia none, cheilocystidia scattered, colorless, filamentose, 3-4 microns in diameter; clamp connections rare and very inconspicuous, (Thiers)
NAME ORIGIN  after the collector Etna Wiebe
SIMILAR  Cortinarius magnivelatus is similar but C. wiebeae is larger with thin, fragile gills that are brown or rusty (not whitish) when young (Arora). C. magnivelatus is distinguished by 1) gills that are white to very pallid when young, not hazel (ferruginous) as in C. wiebeae and the gills in C. magnivelatus are firm and resistant rather than fragile and eroded, 2) gills are forked in C. magnivelatus, 3) the annulus in C. magnivelatus is very tough and persistent and never becomes free, 4) spores in C. magnivelatus are slightly larger, 5) cheilocystidia are differently shaped, and 6) there are numerous clamp connections in the veil tissue of C. magnivelatus, (Thiers). Cortinarius bigelowii also tends to grow underground and has a persistent veil, but also has a pale yellow-brown to yellowish cap, and a short fat bulbous stem, (Arora). Cortinarius verrucisporus has a yellow to yellow-brown or rusty-stained cap, a yellowish veil, and very coarsely warted spores, (Arora).
SOURCES  Thiers(2), Castellano(1), Arora(1)
29
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Cortinomyces niveus  (Cribb) Bougher & Castellano^  Mycologia 85(2):280. 1993;  Hymenogaster niveus  Vittad.;  Protoglossum niveum  (Vittad.) T.W. May  Muelleria 8(3): 287. 1995  (proposed current name)
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a small, somewhat spherical, snow-white fruitbody that reddens to the touch when fresh and dries brown, 2) a brown spore mass with large cavities, 3) a sterile base, 4) a geranium odor, 5) underground growth, 6) spores that are warted apart from a smooth apex and that have a claw-like apiculus, and 7) 2-spored basidia.^ Bougher and Castellano moved Hymenogaster niveus Vittad. to Cortinomyces by virtue of its small warty spores, but they note that "predominance of a smooth spore apex and a cupped (claw-like) hilar appendix are not typical of other species of the genus. However, in the other Cortinomyces [italics] species a low proportion of spores with a torn or cupped hilar appendix do occur in some collections, and the ornamentation is sometimes reduced at the spore apex.", (Bougher). The online Species Fungorum, accessed February 9, 2019, gives the current name as Protoglossum niveum (Vittad.) T.W. May, Muelleria 8(3): 287 (1995), but MycoBank, accessed the same day, retains Cortinomyces niveus as the current name. It is not included in the Trappe(13) list of truffles from the Pacific Northwest. The description derived from Dodge(2). RANGE Collections were examined by Dodge(2) from OR, PQ, MI, Germany, Italy, and United Kingdom.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  about 1cm across, somewhat spherical, drying somewhat irregular; 'snow-white, reddening to the touch when fresh, drying "ochraceous-tawny" to "buckthorn-brown" or even darker'^, (Dodge)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  cavities large; "light fuliginous, becoming very dark brown"
STEM  sterile base evident^, (Dodge)
ODOR  of Pelargonium (geranium)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground under hardwoods and conifers, May to September
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15-18.5 x 9.5-11.5 microns, ovoid-citriform [ovoid - lemon-shaped] to elliptic-citriform, warted, with short, blunt, colorless apiculus^; basidia 2-spored, 8-9 x 5-6 microns, pyriform, projecting above the septa, not numerous and collapsing early, so that the sterigmata seem to arise directly from the septal hyphae; septa thin, 15-20 microns thick, "composed of slender, compact, gelified hyphae"; peridium 300-320 microns thick, drying 60-110 microns thick, "composed of compactly woven hyphae (prosenchyma in islands)" with larger varicose hyphae 5-6 microns wide, (Dodge)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'snow white'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Dodge(2) (as Hymenogaster niveus, colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Bougher(1), Trappe(13)
30
FAMILY  Bolbitiaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Descolea albella  (Massee & Rodway) Kuhar, Nouhra & M.E. Sm.^  in Kuhar, Smith, Mujic, Truong & Nouhra, Fungal Biology 121(10): 883. 2017;  Descomyces albellus  (Massee & Rodway) Bougher & Castellano  Mycologia 85(2): 282. 1993;  Hymenogaster albellus  Massee & Rodway;  Hymenogaster zeylandicus  Petch;  Hymenogaster maideni  Rodway
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to irregular fruitbody with a whitish, dry surface having yellow tufts or fibrils that are quite dense when young, 2) a spore mass that is white becoming cream or gray and soon dark brown, 3) a usually absent columella, 4) a point of attachment that is usually small and inconspicuous, 5) underground growth under Eucalyptus, 6) large truncate spores with isolated warts and short ridges, the spores inconsistently dextrinoid and with a conspicuous perisporium that is sometimes loose and flanging, 7) 1-spored and 2-spored basidia, and 8) a peridiopellis with an outer layer of golden, thick-walled hyphae and an inner layer of colorless interwoven thin-walled hyphae, mainly with cylindric end-cells, the end-cells forming a trichoderm as they merge gradually with the outer layer.^ RANGE Collections were examined from Oregon, California, Brazil, Chile, Uruguay, South Africa, Australia, and New Zealand, (Dodge), and HI, France, Sri Lanka, and Australia, (Bougher). Note however that Trappe(13) do not list it for the Pacific Northwest. Shannon Berch has found it under eucalyptus in BC.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-3cm across, angiocarpic, spherical, somewhat spherical, or irregular; peridium "white or cream with yellow tufts or fibrils which are often quite dense when young" but scattered or evanescent [fleeting] later, paler when old; dry^, (Bougher(1)), 2-3cm across, somewhat spherical; white, turning yellowish to "light buff", drying "yellow-ocher" or "ochraceous buff"; innate fibrous, drying rugose [wrinkled], (Dodge)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "dry, with irregular empty locules"; "white at first then pale cream or grey, soon dark brown"^, (Bougher), spores mass 'becoming fragile, "Sudan brown" to "Argus brown", cavities irregular', (Dodge)
STEM  columella / sterile tissue "usually absent, when present forming a sterile basal pad, sparse dendroid sterile veins or a short, truncate columella", point of attachment often small, inconspicuous^, (Bougher)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground "in litter near ectomycorrhizal plants, particularly Myrtaceae", probably indigenous to Australia but now widespread throughout the world in gardens and plantations of Eucalyptus and other Myrtaceae, (Bougher), under Quercus (oak), fruiting in Oregon in October, (Dodge)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 13-19(20) x 7-11(13) microns, citriniform [lemon-shaped], subfusiform [somewhat spindle-shaped], elliptic, "verrucose with isolated irregular warts and short ridges", inconspicuous or up to 1 micron tall, spores inconsistently dextrinoid, bright yellow brown in KOH, perisporium "conspicuous (often yellow-brown in KOH), sometimes loose and flanging, not covering apex", spore wall usually thin, apex "smooth rostrate to rounded in some spores", apiculus "entirely truncate to sometimes cup-like or torn"^; basidia 1-spored and 2-spored, 23-40 x 6-10 microns, clavate or cylindric, colorless, "soon collapsing with a yellow encrusting necropigment"; hymenium a closely packed palisade of colorless basidia, and basidioles (up to 23 x 13 microns); hymenophoral trama hyphae 3-4 microns wide, colorless or pale yellow (in KOH), clamped, parallel or slightly interwoven; subhymenium "narrow and poorly differentiated"; peridiopellis nongelatinized, 2-layered: outer layer of hyphae 4-15 microns wide, golden, thick-walled (1 micron), clamped, inner layer broad, of hyphae 3-7 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, thin-walled (<0.5 micron), clamped, mainly with cylindric end-cells "but some scattered vesiculose or pyriform end-cells up to 35 x 15 microns may also be present, end-cells forming a trichoderm as they merge gradually with the outer peridium"; clamp connections conspicuous in all tissues, (Bougher), spores 14.5-17 x 9.6-11.1 microns including utricle, elliptic-citriform [elliptic - lemon-shaped], roughened by an evenly applied, alveolate utricle [bladder-like covering] that extends to the base of the apiculus, dark brown, the young spores elliptic and smooth without utricle or apiculus but usually with a pedicel attached, in some apparently semi-mature spores, "the utricle is less closely applied above, having a flaring tendency"; basidia 2-spored, 15-18 x 11-13 microns, broad-cylindric, sterigmata short, about 2-3 microns long; septa thin, fragile, 12-25 microns thick, composed of colorless, thin-walled, parallel hyphae; peridium thin, 18-30 microns thick, colorless, "the outer part composed of loosely applied, yellowish hyphae", the inner part of more compact, stupose hyphae, (Dodge)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'white', 'albellus' is diminutive form of 'albus'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Bougher(1) (as Descomyces albellus), Dodge(2) (as Hymenogaster albellus) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Trappe(13)
31
FAMILY  Gomphaceae, Order Gomphales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Destuntzia fusca  Fogel & Trappe^  Mycologia 77(5): 740. 1985
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Destuntzia species have warty to wrinkled elliptic spores that are pigmented grayish yellow to light olive, have neither an organized hymenium nor a percurrent columella, and have gel in the locules of the spore mass, as well as clamp connections, (Hymenogaster spp. may have similar spores); Destuntzia fusca characterized among Destuntzia species by dark brown to black spore mass, bone-like consistency when dried, short spore ornamentation, and presence of sphaerocysts in the tramal plates; fruitbodies are small, cushion-shaped and pallid, in time becoming pale brown-rose^; rare, western OR to northern CA, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  up to 1.2-1.5cm across, pulvinate [cushion-shaped]; pallid, in time becoming pale brown-rose, drying brown orange; bald^, (Castellano), up to 1.2-1.5cm across when fresh, 1.2 x 0.8cm when dried, pulvinate; pallid, in time (overnight) becoming 'dull brownish rose' [color from Kelly(3)], drying brownish orange; bald; peridium +/- 0.025cm thick, (Fogel)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  when dried consisting of brown-black, elongate locules 0.07 x 0.03-0.05cm in diameter, filled with gel-embedded spores, separated by white to dull yellow veins^, (Fogel)
STEM  columella a pulvinate base up to 0.3-0.5cm with irregular branches, rhizomorphs lacking^, (Fogel)
ODOR  not distinctive^ (Fogel)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under soil surface associated with roots of Notholithocarpus densiflorus (Tan Oak), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) below 1000m, October and December, (Castellano), underground in Tsuga-Pseudotsuga-Notholithocarpus stands in December, (Fogel)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-11 x 5-6 microns, including ornamentation but not pedicel, elliptic, ornamentation warty-rugulose, 0.5 microns or less long, dark grayish yellow in KOH, inner spore wall 0.25 microns, pedicel central, tubular, colorless, 1-4 x 1.5 microns broad^; basidia 4-spored, reviving poorly, 40-50 x 8-11 microns, obovate, colorless, thin-walled, no clamp connection observed at basal septum, sterigmata tubular, 2-4 x 1.5-2 microns, basidioles not reviving; trama 25-75 microns wide, of hyphae 3-4 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, gelatinous, septate, "cells inflated to 12 microns", clamp connections present, "sphaerocysts common in axes of tramal plates"; peridium 440-519 microns thick, 2-layered: peridial subcutis 190-231 microns thick, confluent with trama, of hyphae 3-4 microns wide at septa, periclinal, colorless, thin-walled, becoming inflated to 8 microns, clamp connections present, peridial epicutis 198-250 microns thick, of hyphae 3-4 microns wide, periclinal, colorless, thin-walled, cells not becoming inflated, clamp connections present, (Fogel)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'fuscous' (dark blackish brown), referring to color of spore mass
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Fogel(6), Castellano(1), Kelly(3), Trappe(13)
32
FAMILY  Gomphaceae, Order Gomphales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Destuntzia rubra  (Harkn.) Fogel & Trappe^  Mycologia 77(5): 735. 1985;  Hymenogaster ruber  Harkn.;  Hymenogaster versicolor  Harkn.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Destuntzia species have warty to wrinkled elliptic spores that are pigmented grayish yellow to light olive, have neither an organized hymenium nor a percurrent columella, and have gel in the locules of the spore mass, as well as clamp connections, (Hymenogaster spp. may have similar spores). Destuntzia rubra is characterized among Destuntzia species by distinctive monosporous basidia, a thick peridium, and prominent, conic warts ornamenting the spores (warts are striate under scanning electron microscope). Other features of Destuntzia rubra include a white fruiting body that becomes deep pink in its upper part, bruises blue-pink, shows pink when cut, and dries red, a strong fishy odor, and underground fruiting.^ It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It has been found from northwestern OR to northern CA, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2-2.5cm when fresh, 1.6cm x 1.2cm when dried, kidney-shaped to nearly spherical; white at first, becoming deep pink in upper part, grading to white in lower part when mature, slowly staining blue-pink when bruised, pink when cut, drying medium red; pubescent [finely hairy], with adherent soil; peridium 0.1-0.15cm thick^, (Fogel)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  composed of dark grayish yellow to olive-brown, spherical locules about 0.02cm broad, filled with gel-embedded spores at maturity^, (Fogel)
STEM  columella absent or a pulvinate [cushion-shaped] base up to 0.6cm x 0.3cm with a few radiating branches; rhizomorphs basal, colored as the outer surface of the fruitbody^, (Fogel)
ODOR  strong, "fishy-rancid"^, (Fogel)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under the soil surface associated with roots of Abies grandis (Grand Fir), Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone), Notholithocarpus densiflorus (Tanoak), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Sequoia sempervirens (Redwood), below 650 meters elevation, March to December^, (Castellano), underground under Pseudotsuga menziesii, Quercus (oak), and Notholithocarpus, from December to July, (Fogel), mycorrhizal host Pseudotsuga (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-11 x 7-9 microns including ornamentation but not pedicel, conic vertically striate warts, 0.5-2 x +/- 1.5 microns broad, "warts smaller on sides of spore than on ends", spores light olive in KOH and Melzer's reagent (immature spores colorless), "inner spore wall 0.5 microns thick, base truncate with a cup or eared flange formed from the pedicel of mature spores, pedicel of immature spores 2-3 x 2 microns"^; basidia 1-spored, 40-50 x 4-8 microns, cylindric to clavate, colorless, "walls thickened slightly, clamp connection present at basal septum", "projecting into locules, not forming a euhymenium", basidioles 40-50 x 8-10 microns, clavate, colorless, walls thickened slightly; trama 35-50 microns wide, of hyphae 2-4 microns wide that are subparallel, colorless, thin-walled, gelatinous, refractive, and septate, cells inflated to 8 microns, occasional large (9 microns wide) hyphae present, clamp connections rare; peridium 875-1500 microns thick, of two layers: subcutis 625-1030 microns thick, confluent with trama, of hyphae 3-4 microns wide at septa, inflated to 10 microns, tightly interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, clamp connections infrequent, epicutis 250-470 microns thick, of hyphae 2-4 microns wide, (becoming inflated to 5 microns wide), tightly interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, clamp connections small, common, a band of interwoven, irregular, aseptate, thick-walled (1-2 microns) hyphae 4-12(18) microns wide occurs at the junction of the subcutis and the epicutis, associated with the thick-walled hyphae are colorless, thick-walled (2 microns), subglobose to ellipsoid cells 29-54 x 22-48 microns which arise from the thin-walled hyphae, (Fogel)
NAME ORIGIN  means "red", "possibly in reference to color of peridium in alcohol"
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Fogel(6), Castellano(1)*, Arora(1)*, Trappe(13)*
33
FAMILY  Gomphaceae, Order Gomphales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Destuntzia subborealis  (A.H. Sm.) Fogel & Trappe^  Mycologia 77(5): 736. 1985;  Hymenogaster subborealis  A.H. Sm.  Mycologia 58: 111. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to lobed fruitbody with whitish surface, when old with yellow fibrils, spore mass dark vinaceous brown at maturity, lack of reaction of surface to KOH or FeSO4, and microscopic characters including minutely warty basidiospores, peridium with long aseptate, colorless, thick-walled hyphae^; type found in ID
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  neither KOH nor FeSO4 reacting on surface^ (Smith(27))
OUTER SURFACE  0.4-1.2cm across, spherical to lobed, "dry, whitish, fibrillose, on aging the fibrils turn yellowish", "surface not staining from bruising"^, (Smith(27))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "very soon dark vinaceous brown"; "chambers not distinct to naked eye"^, (Smith(27))
STEM  "columella present only as thickened tramal plates", fruitbody lacking a definite point of attachment^, (Smith(4)), "columella absent but whitish streaks extending to the peridium (the tramal plates, but these thicker than in most species)", (Smith(27))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in hemlock-cedar forests^, (Smith(4)), in duff in Tsuga-Thuja association, (Smith(27))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x 4.5-5.5 microns, ellipsoid, with a minute inconspicuous apiculus, "warts at times arranged obscurely into diagonal lines or an obscure reticulum, usually no pattern evident", "no apical differentiation (pore or callus) observed", spores pale tawny in Melzer's reagent, pale ochraceous to dull tan in KOH, walls slightly thickened (0.5 microns)^; hymenium and tramal plates "not well enough revived to observe details", the plates appeared gelatinous in KOH and in Melzer's reagent "and the chambers were so full of spores that basidia were not clearly seen"; context of peridium of inflated hyphae 5-12(16) microns wide, very closely interwoven, very thin-walled, colorless (both in KOH and in Melzer's reagent), this tissue continuing into the tramal plates; peridium with an epicuticular region of hyphae 4-15 microns wide, interwoven, with walls 2-3 microns thick, the walls colorless in KOH and practically colorless in Melzer's reagent, "in the broader hyphae the walls often pitted"; clamp connections none found, (Smith(27))
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(27) (as Hymenogaster), Smith(4) (as Hymenogaster), Fogel(6)
34
FAMILY  Elaphomycetaceae, Order Eurotiales, Class Eurotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Elaphomyces 'anthracinus'  Vittad.^  Monogr. Tuberac. (Milano): 66. 1831
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include a nearly black fruitbody with fine warts, a fairly thick, silver gray inner covering layer, a blackish spore mass, underground growth in association with Ponderosa Pine (hardwoods in Europe), and nearly black spores with crowded low spines.^ The description is derived from Castellano(1). It is rare among truffles in the Pacific Northwest, and it is not certain that this species is identical to the one described from Europe, (Trappe(13)). RANGE It has been found in Deschutes County, OR, (Trappe(13)). It has been found in OR, ID, and Europe, (Castellano).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2-3cm across, "slightly flattened with low depressions, covered by dark, firm earthy crust of blackened mycorrhiza and scanty dark red-brown mycelium", cortex "on mature specimens almost black with a flush of dark brown, obscurely and finely warty, in most specimens with one large smooth well-delimited spot with green discoloring mycelium, brittle and hard, separable from peridium", peridium 0.15-0.2cm thick, pale silvery-gray when fresh but soon turning slate gray, soft
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  pulverulent [powdery] when mature, black with distinct olivaceous sheen
STEM  
ODOR  not distinctive
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under the soil surface associated with roots of Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine) in Oregon and with roots of assorted Fagaceae in Europe
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 21-25 microns in diameter, round, "dark brown to almost black, densely set with crowded, low spines"^; asci not seen; cortex 250-250 microns thick with broad flat warts, protruding part 100 microns high, 200 microns wide, "made up of pseudoparenchymatic tissue, dark brown", walls 1-2 microns thick, subparallel hyphae between warts 4-5 microns wide and slightly paler brown; peridium well distinguished from cortex, hyphae pale brown, colorless, thick-walled, 3-4 microns wide in outer part, more loosely woven and 6-7 microns wide within; capillitium scanty, of 2 microns wide, colorless hyphae encrusted with olivaceous pigment
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Castellano(1)*, Trappe(13)
35
FAMILY  Elaphomycetaceae, Order Eurotiales, Class Eurotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Elaphomyces 'asperulus'  Vittad.^  Monogr. Tuberac.: 69. 1831
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  common in Pacific Northwest (although it is not certain that the species found in the Pacific Northwest is identical to the European one), widespread in Northern Hemisphere, (Trappe(13)), in Europe including Denmark, Finland, Norway, Sweden, (Hansen, L.(1))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  pea-sized to hazelnut sized or walnut sized, yellow-fulvous, finally becoming very pale; cortex thick, reddish gray to sordid red-violaceous, (Sacc. Syll. fung.)
INNER LAYER  inner peridium homogeneous in section, not marbled
INTERIOR  [presumably a shade of brown or black]
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in coniferous forests, rarely under Betula (birch), (Hansen, L.)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores when mature 25-38 microns in diameter, [presumably round], "individual spines scarcely discernible", "forming a cracking epispore" of 1 micron high, coalescent spines, immature spores colorless, with a very thin epispore, (Hansen, L.), spores black, 25-30 microns in diameter, (Sacc. Syll. fung.)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'asperulate', appearing roughened with tiny points
SIMILAR  Elaphomyces granulatus has individual spines easily discernible and 2-4 microns long, and immature spores (within asci) colorless with a distinctly radially striate epispore, (Hansen, L.(1))
SOURCES  Hansen, L.(1), Trappe(13), Saccardo's Syll. fung. VIII: 869; XIX: 636; XII: 948 (in Latin)
36
FAMILY  Elaphomycetaceae, Order Eurotiales, Class Eurotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Elaphomyces 'decipiens'  Vittad.^  Monogr. Tuberac.: 68. 1831
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include pea-sized to hazelnut-sized fruitbody that is described as orange then black and also as pale brown, the surface nearly smooth to warty, the outer layer thick and marbled in cross-section, underground growth in association with conifers, and round spores 18-28 microns in diameter^; description derived from Saccardo's Syll. fung. on the online Species Fungorum; infrequent in OR and northern CA, although it is not certain that the species found in the Pacific Northwest is identical to the European one, (Trappe(13)), also in Europe including Italy, France, and the Czech Republic, (Saccardo's Syll. fung.)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  pea-sized to hazelnut-sized; pale brownish? ("brunneo-pallescente"), also described as reddish yellow then black? ("flavo-rufescens dein nigricans"); nearly smooth to minutely and unequally verruculose; cortex thick, becoming white, with variegated brown-fuscous spots? ("cortice crasso, albicante, maculis brunneo-fuscis variegato")
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  brunneo-fuscous
STEM  
ODOR  subnauseous or light fungal
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  associated with Pinaceae (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 18-28 microns in diameter [presumably round], at first smooth, "primo levia, episporio dein pustulatim secedente atro exasperata"^; asci 3-4-spored
NAME ORIGIN  means 'deceiving'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Saccardo's Syll. fung. VIII: 867; XIX: 636; XII: 948 (in Latin), Trappe(13)
37
FAMILY  Elaphomycetaceae, Order Eurotiales, Class Eurotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Elaphomyces 'granulatus'  Fr.^  Syst. mycol. (Lundae) 3(1): 58. 1829
ENGLISH NAMES  common deer truffle
NOTES  Features include 1) a more or less spherical fruitbody with a thick rind-like skin that is not marbled in cross-section, the surface pale to dingy ochraceous, 2) a spore mass that is cottony to powdery, colored dark brown to black when mature, and 3) large spores that are round with short spines and are produced on asci, (Arora).^ It is often parasitized by Cordyceps, and may be the most common underground fruiting fungus in North America, (Smith(4)). It is abundant among truffles in the Pacific Northwest, but represents a species complex temporarily designated by a European name, none in the Pacific Northwest being identical with the European species (Trappe(13)). RANGE Elaphomyces granulatus has been reported from BC in Redhead(5), from WA by Jumpponen(1), and from OR by Luoma(1) and Fogel(8). It is listed for ID by Hawker (in Fogel(7)), and reported from CO by Fogel(7). It has been found in the United Kingdom (Hawker(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2-4cm across, spherical to nearly spherical, often with adhering strands of yellow mycelium; pale to dingy ochraceous, ornamented with firm coarse warts; peridium thick, firm^, (Smith), 2-5cm across, "round to somewhat oval, very firm"; "sometimes pallid when young but usually pale to dingy ochraceous or yellow-brown"; exterior "usually covered with small hard warts (but these often hidden by a crust of soil, yellowish mycelium, and / or mycorrhizal rootlets)"; peridium [skin] rind-like, firm and thick (0.2-0.5cm) showing a very thin yellowish outer layer when sectioned, "and a thick white to grayish inner layer that may feature darker (brown) zones", but not marbled, (Arora)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "dark brown to black and powdery at maturity"^, (Smith), "at first hollow, soon stuffed with cottony tissue, eventually becoming powdery when spores mature"; "white at first, soon grayish to purplish (and often separated into chambers by whitish bands), finally becoming blackish and powdery", (Arora)
STEM  none^ (Arora)
ODOR  not very distinctive^ (Arora), faintly metallic (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  yes according to some reports but not choice, used for centuries in Europe as aphrodisiac and truffle substitute, (Arora)
HABITAT  scattered at or several centimeters below ground, "under conifers or hardwoods, summer or fall, widely distributed"^, (Smith), single, scattered or gregarious "in soil or humus under conifers or less commonly hardwoods", usually 5-8cm below surface, "often embedded in or resting on clay soil at point where it meets the humus layer", (Arora), year round (Bacon)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 28-45 microns in diameter, round, dark red-brown in KOH, with closely set short soft spines aggregated into irregular clusters^; asci fleeting, (Smith), spores 24-45(65) microns, "round, thick-walled, blackish-brown to very dark reddish-brown under the microscope, ornamented with short spines or warts", asci "mostly 8-spored, round to pear-shaped, not forming a hymenium", and disintegrating before spores fully mature, (Arora), mature spores 23-32 microns in diameter with individual spines easily discernible and 2-4 microns long, immature spores (within asci) colorless with a distinctly radially striate epispore, (Hansen, L.)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin meaning "granular", because of appearance of peridium^, (Lincoff(1))
SIMILAR  Elaphomyces asperulus has mature spores 25-38 microns in diameter, "individual spines scarcely discernible", "forming a cracking epispore" of 1 micron high, coalescent spines, immature spores colorless, with a very thin epispore, (Hansen, L.(1)). Elaphomyces muricatus is somewhat similar but its peridium is marbled in cross-section. Other non-marbled Elaphomyces are best distinguished microscopically. Scleroderma spp. usually have a distinct base or point of attachment, lack the small hard warts, usually grow closer to the surface or above it, and differ microscopically.
SOURCES  Smith(4), Arora(1) (as E. granulatus group), Lincoff(1)*, Redhead(5), Jumpponen(1), Luoma(1), Fogel(7), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Hansen, L.(1), Trappe(13), Fogel(8), Hawker(1), Bacon(1)*
38
FAMILY  Elaphomycetaceae, Order Eurotiales, Class Eurotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Elaphomyces 'muricatus'  Fr.^  Syst. mycol. (Lundae) 3(1): 59. 1829
ENGLISH NAMES  marbled deer truffle
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to lobed fruitbody with a thick rind-like skin that is pimpled on the exterior and marbled in cross-section, the surface color yellow-brown to ocher brown, 2) a spore mass that is cottony to powdery, colored grayish to purplish when mature and often separated into chambers by whitish bands, and 3) large spores that are round with short spines and are produced on mostly 8-spored asci.^ Elaphomyces 'muricatus' may be parasitized by Cordyceps. It is abundant among truffles in the Pacific Northwest [and common elsewhere in North America], but represents a species complex temporarily designated by a European name, none in the Pacific Northwest being identical with the Europeans species (Trappe(13)). The description is derived from Arora(1) for Elaphomyces muricatus group except where specified. RANGE Elaphomyces muricatus has been reported from BC in Redhead(5), from WA by Jumpponen(1), from OR by Luoma(1), and from CA by Desjardin(6). It is found in the United Kingdom (Hawker(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2-5cm across, spherical to ovoid or somewhat lobed, very firm; ocher brown or yellow-brown; exterior "covered with minute hard pointed warts that give it a pimpled appearance", but these often hidden by crust of soil and mycorrhizal rootlets that is easy to brush away; peridium [skin] rind-like, firm and thick (0.2-0.5cm), "marbled when sectioned (dark brown to purplish brown with whitish to vinaceous-tinged veins)"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  at first hollow, soon stuffed with cottony tissue, eventually becoming powdery when spores mature; white at first, soon grayish to purplish (and often separated into chambers by whitish sterile bands), finally becoming blackish and uniformly powdery^, (Arora), somewhat gooey when young, becoming a fine black powder (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  none
ODOR  not very distinctive^, (Arora), metallic, unpleasant (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  unknown
HABITAT  single to gregarious in soil or duff in woods^, (Arora), associated with members of Pinaceae and Fagaceae (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 18-30 x 18-30 microns, "round, warted or warted-spiny, dark brown to black under the microscope"^; asci "round to pear-shaped or irregular, mostly 8-spored, not forming a palisade (hymenium) and disintegrating soon after the spores form (and before they completely mature)"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'spiny like a murex' (a shellfish yielding a purple dye)
SIMILAR  Elaphomyces granulatus has a peridium that is not marbled in cross-section. Elaphomyces reticulatus is described as "Inner peridium obscurely marbled (in section), pale brown with whitish to pink veins; cortex mainly with flat warts", spores 19-28 microns in diameter with spines 2-2.5 microns long, whereas Elaphomyces muricatus is described as "Inner peridium distinctly marbled, dark reddish brown with pale brown veins; cortex mainly with pointed warts" and spores are 18-40 microns in diameter with spines 1.5-2.5 microns long, (Hansen, L.(1)). Scleroderma species usually have a distinct base or point of attachment, lack the small hard warts, usually grow closer to the surface or above it, and differ microscopically.
SOURCES  Arora(1) (as Elaphomyces muricatus group), Redhead(5), Jumpponen(1), Luoma(1), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Hansen, L.(1), Hawker(1), Trappe(13)*, Desjardin(6)*, Siegel(2)* (as Elaphomyces muricatus group)
39
FAMILY  Elaphomycetaceae, Order Eurotiales, Class Eurotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Elaphomyces 'reticulatus'  Vittad.^  Monogr. Lycop. p.107, t.3, f.11, Tul. Fungi hypogaei p.107
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include orange to yellowish fruitbody covered with blunt warts, the cortex compact and in section hard and obscurely marbled, underground growth in association with pine, and microscopic characters including round spores 19-28 microns in diameter with spines 2-2.5 microns long^; rare in western OR although it is not certain that the species found in the Pacific Northwest is identical to the European one, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  orange to yellowish; covered with blunt warts; cortex compact, subcorneous [somewhat hardened like horn], (Sacc. Syll. fung.), "Inner peridium obscurely marbled (in section), pale brown with whitish to pink veins; cortex mainly with flat warts", (Hansen, L.)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  presumably some shade of brown or black (Sacc. Syll. Fung. describes spores as "nigro-purpurascentibus" - purplish black)
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  associated with Pinus (pine) (Trappe), in hardwood forest (Hansen, L.)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 19-28 microns in diameter, [presumably round], with spines 2-2.5 microns long^, (Hansen, L.)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'reticulate'
SIMILAR  Elaphomyces muricatus has "Inner peridium distinctly marbled, dark reddish brown with pale brown veins; cortex mainly with pointed warts." and spores are 18-40 microns in diameter with spines 1.5-2.5 microns long, (Hansen, L.(1))
SOURCES  Hansen, L.(1), Saccardo's Syll. fung. VIII: 867; XIX: 638; XII: 949 (in Latin), Trappe(13)
40
FAMILY  Elaphomycetaceae, Order Eurotiales, Class Eurotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Elaphomyces subviscidus  (Zeller) Trappe & Guzman^  Madrono 21: 128. 1971;  Scleroderma subviscidum  Zeller
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a somewhat spherical, white to grayish fruitbody encrusted by soil held together with pale hyphae, 2) a peridium 0.1-0.2cm thick with a thin yellowish outer layer and a thicker pallid inner layer, 3) a dark brown powdery spore mass, 4) an onion odor, 5) growth in association with conifer roots, and 6) microscopic characters including round spores with crowded spines, often in clusters of 8. It is rarely collected.^ RANGE Elaphomyces subviscidus has been found at least in OR, ID, (Castellano), and CO (Fogel).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  surface of peridium not reactive with KOH^, (Trappe)
OUTER SURFACE  5cm x 3cm, "white to grayish, drying yellowish"; smooth, "encrusted with soil held by inconspicuous but abundant pale hyphae emerging from the surface"; peridium 0.1-0.2cm thick when dry, reviving to 0.25-0.3cm thick, with a thin, yellowish outer layer and a thick, pallid inner layer^, (Trappe), up to 5cm x 3cm, somewhat spherical; "white to dull gray, drying light yellow to brownish orange"; smooth, not subviscid, "encrusted with soil held together by abundant light yellow hyphae and hyphal tufts emerging from surface"; peridium 0.25-0.3cm thick, "with a thin, pale yellow outer layer and a thick, white to light gray inner layer", (Fogel)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  spore mass dark brown, powdery^, (Trappe), dark brown before maturity, nearly black when mature, "a powdery mass of spores and hyphae", (Fogel)
STEM  none
ODOR  of onions^ (Fogel)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type above ground on decayed granite soil, (Trappe), underground associated with roots of Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine) and Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock) at high elevation (2200 m), June and August, (Castellano), in Colorado underground in a Pinus ponderosa stand (Ponderosa Pine) with a scattered understory of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), 2135m elevation, (Fogel)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-21 x 12-21 microns excluding ornamentation, 14-23(24) with ornamentation, round, with crowded spines 1-2 microns long and +/- 0.2 microns thick, separated by 0.2-0.5 microns or sometimes joined in twos and threes by ridges "but never formed into a partial reticulum, embedded in an inconspicuous, mucilaginous matrix", spores containing a large round oil droplet, the smaller spores with walls up to 0.5 microns thick and with very dark brown color and the larger spores thin-walled and tending to be lighter brown^; asci not detected, but spores often in spherical clusters of 8; gleba hyphae dispersed among spores, mostly 1.5-3.0 microns wide (but a few 5-6 microns wide), colorless to pale yellowish brown, thin-walled; dark brown, amorphous deposits scattered throughout between hyphae; inner peridium +/- 2500 microns thick, abruptly differentiated from the outer layer as +/- circumferentially aligned but interwoven fascicles of a few to nearly 100 colorless, highly refractive hyphae 4-8 microns wide with walls mucilaginous-thickened to nearly filling the cells, yellowish amorphous debris scattered throughout; outer peridium +/- 150 microns thick, "yellowish in cross section, densely interwoven of single to fascicled hyphae" 3-5 microns wide, with walls mostly colorless and thin but in places thickened to 0.5 microns and often yellowish, the entire layer obscured by colorless to yellowish amorphous debris; emerging superficial hyphae 2.5-4 microns wide, sinuous, colorless, thin-walled, (Trappe), spores (12)17-27(29) microns including ornamentation of crowded spines 1-2 x 0.2 microns, separated by 0.2-0.5 microns or often joined in twos and threes by ridges but never forming a partial reticulum, "embedded in a gelatinous matrix, often separating from the spore surface when cover slip is tapped"; asci 38-50 microns in diameter, spherical, colorless, thin-walled; glebal hyphae 1.5-4(6) microns wide, with occasional swellings and short lateral branches, apices obtuse [blunt], hyphae colorless to pale yellowish brown, brown amorphous deposits frequent between hyphae in cotton blue - lactic acid; inner peridial layer of interwoven fascicles of a few to many, colorless to pale yellow hyphae 4-8 microns wide with refractive thickening of the walls to 1-3 microns; outer layer of peridium 100-150 microns thick, of periclinal, single to fascicled hyphae 3-5 microns wide with colorless to pale yellow, thin to slightly thickened walls; emerging superficial hyphae 2.5-4 microns wide, sinuous, colorless, thin-walled, (Fogel)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'subviscid': Zeller reported this species to be subviscid on the surface
SIMILAR  This is the only Elaphomyces species in the Pacific Northwest with a confirmed name, but there are a multitude of undescribed Elaphomyces species (M. Beug, pers. comm.).
SOURCES  Trappe(4), Castellano(1)*, Fogel(7)
41
FAMILY  Endogonaceae, Order Endogonales, Class Uncertain, Phylum Zygomycota
LATIN NAMES  Endogone acrogena  Gerd., Trappe & Hosford^  Mycologia Memoir 5: 22. 1974
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features includes small bright yellow convoluted irregular fruitbody without true peridium but with tufts of hyphae that become matted over surface, growth on soil or on mosses, and microscopic characters including very large spores (zygospores) formed in radiate rows with the youngest at the surface^; description derived from Gerdemann(1); endemic to WA
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  up to 0.4 x 0.7 x 1cm, "greatly lobed, convoluted and irregular", formed from folded tissue up to 0.2cm thick; "bright yellow when fresh, light tan-yellow when dry"; true peridium absent, but during development, "tufts of glebal hyphae radiate from the surface, becoming matted over the surface by maturity"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  spore mass "developing acrogenously from a sterile or nearly sterile base of interwoven hyphae"
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  epigeous [above ground], fruiting on soil surface or on mosses, from low elevations to near timberline, May, September, and October
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  zygospores variable in size and shape, 15 x 30-80 x 59 microns, the mature spores within a chain varying from small to large, round, elliptic, ovate or irregular, "becoming flattened and angular from pressure", spore wall up to 5 microns thick, of two variable layers^; gametangia 15 x 7 microns, "thin-walled and ephemeral, equal in size, parallel, uniting at their tips, with the zygospore forming above the point of union"; gleba "developing acrogenously from a sterile or nearly sterile base of interwoven hyphae as radiate hyphae intermingled with radiate rows of zygospores that are often tightly adpressed in chains, the oldest spores at the base, the youngest at the actively growing surface"
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin "acrogenus" (born at apices), referring to the acrogenous development of spores in rows
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Castellano(1), Gerdemann(1)
42
FAMILY  Endogonaceae, Order Endogonales, Class Uncertain, Phylum Zygomycota
LATIN NAMES  Endogone flammicorona  Trappe & Gerd.^  Trans. Brit. Mycol. Soc. 59: 403-407. 1972;  = Endogone lactiflua  sensu Fischer, Buchholz et auctt. pl.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a small, underground, lobed, irregular fruitbody, 2) a thin, white to buff peridium that often disappears, 3) a spore mass that is white at first, then buff to salmon and finally orange-brown, often exuding a sticky latex, and 4) microscopic characters including very large spores (zygospores) that are enclosed in a spore mantle that is mostly in a single layer with a spiral, sinuous pattern.^ The description is derived from Gerdemann(1) except where noted. In is widespread but infrequent in North America and Europe, (Gerdemann). It is abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest, (Trappe(13)). RANGE Collections were examined from WA, OR, ID, and CA, (Gerdemann). It was collected from Victoria BC by Jake Kerr and identified by Shannon Berch. It is distributed in North America and Europe, (Trappe(13)). It is found in the United Kingdom (Hawker(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.3-2.5cm across, when immature mostly spherical to somewhat spherical and white, when mature "mostly lobed and convoluted and buff to dull orange-brown with soil particles frequently adhering to surface"; peridium "thin, white, becoming buff, often disappearing on mature specimens"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  at first white, becoming buff or salmon and finally orange-brown when fully mature, "often exuding a sticky latex when cut"
STEM  
ODOR  not distinctive^ (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  unknown (Trappe, M.(3))
HABITAT  hypogeous [underground] or rarely subhypogeous, "in coniferous forests from coastal areas to relatively low elevations in the mountains and in seedling beds of a tree nursery"; spring, early summer, fall, and early winter; occurring among ectomycorrhizae of Pinaceae^, (Gerdemann), most often found "in young stands of trees in mixed woods"; sometimes "fruits by the tens of thousands in conifer nurseries"; occurs year-round, (Trappe, M.(3)) 
SPORE DEPOSIT
