MICROSCOPIC  zygospores 52-120 x 42-99 microns, round to elliptic or oboval, usually longer than broad, containing oil droplets 2-3 microns across, spore wall 3.5-7 microns thick, consisting of a thin, deep yellow to brown outer wall 1-2 microns thick "that is yellow to pale orange in Melzer's reagent" and a thick, colorless to light yellow inner wall up to 6 microns thick; spores enclosed in a tightly adherent hyphal mantle 5-20 microns thick, "usually a single layer of hyphae encircling each spore in a spiral, sinuous manner, with lateral walls pressed together", "in cross section bases of hyphae (adjacent to spore) and lateral walls greatly thickened, the thickening becoming progressively thinner toward the outer, generally thin-walled hyphal surface, thickened lateral walls of two adjacent hyphae coalesced to form pointed flame-shaped projections" from spore^; gametangia "up to 35(40) microns broad, thin-walled and ephemeral, not visible on mature spores, parallel, of unequal size, with the zygospore budding from the tip of the larger of the two", (Gerdemann), spores 52-120 x 42-99 microns, round to elliptic or oboval, "each one enclosed within tightly appressed hyphae that in face view look like a fingerprint and in cross section like a crown of flames", (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin "flammi-" (flame) and "corona" (crown), referring to the flame-shaped projections of the spore mantle as seen in cross section
SIMILAR  Endogone lactiflua and E. flammicorona differ in the following ways: 1) the sporocarp of E. lactiflua is nearly spherical to elliptic or kidney-shaped, rarely lobed or irregular, whereas the sporocarp of E. flammicorona is generally lobed or irregular, 2) spores of E. lactiflua are round to elliptic, generally wider than long with a width of 94-190 microns, whereas spores of E. flammicorona are round, elliptic, or obovoid, usually longer than wide with a width of 42-99 microns, 3) the outer spore wall of E. lactiflua becomes dark reddish brown in Melzer's reagent, whereas the outer spore wall of E. flammicorona becomes yellow to pale orange in Melzer's reagent, 4) the spore mantle of E. lactiflua consists of several layers of interwoven hyphae, appears netted in cross-section, and separates readily from spore walls, whereas the spore mantle of E. flammicorona generally consists of a single layer of spirally arranged hyphae, appears as flame-shaped projections in cross-section, and adheres tightly to spore walls, and 5) the gametangia of E. lactiflua are thick-walled, often persistent, and up to 80 microns wide, whereas the gametangia of E. flammicorona are thin-walled, ephemeral and generally not visible on mature specimens, and not broader than 40 microns, (Gerdemann).
SOURCES  Gerdemann(1), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Hawker(1), Trappe(13)*
43
FAMILY  Endogonaceae, Order Endogonales, Class Uncertain, Phylum Zygomycota
LATIN NAMES  Endogone lactiflua  Berk. & Broome^  Ann. Mag. Nat. Hist. Ser. 1. 18: 81-82. 1846;  = Endogone lanata  Harkn.;  = Endogone rosea  Zeller
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a small somewhat spherical, ellipsoid, or kidney-shaped, underground fruitbody with a thin, white peridium that partially or completely disappears when old, 2) a spore mass that is pale yellow when young exuding a sticky latex, then a loosely woven white tissue dotted with brown spores, and finally collapsing to leave an aggregation of large spores, and 3) microscopic details, including very large spores (zygospores) enclosed in a mantle in two to many layers, frequently branching and intertwined, not spirally arranged.^ The description is derived from Gerdemann(1) except where noted. It is widely distributed, and rather common in its habitat. Among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest it is considered abundant, and it is common in tree nurseries, (Trappe(13)). RANGE Collections were examined from WA, OR, AK, CA, also found in eastern North America and Europe, (Gerdemann). It is found in the United Kingdom (Hawker(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.3-0.9(1.5)cm across, somewhat spherical to ellipsoid or kidney-shaped, "in occasional collections lobed and irregular"; peridium thin (partially or completely disappearing when old), white
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  sometimes sterile at base, when young "pale yellow and exuding a sticky latex, later appearing as a rather loosely woven, dry white tissue dotted with brown spores, and finally with the glebal tissue mostly collapsed to leave a brown aggregation of spores"
STEM  "usually with a basal attachment to the soil"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground, in coniferous or oak forests from sea level to subalpine zones, generally April through July but occasionally as late as November, probably ectomycorrhizal association with members of Pinaceae as well as Quercus garryana (Garry Oak)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  zygospores 94-190 x 71-180 microns, orange-brown, round to elliptic, usually broader than long, spore wall 5-11 microns thick, consisting of a brown outer wall 1-3 microns thick "that stains deep reddish brown in Melzer's reagent" and "a thicker, yellow, inner wall", immature spores "embedded in thin-walled vesicular hyphae", "as spores mature becoming enclosed in hyphal mantles 5-50 microns thick, composed of two to many layers of thick-walled, intertwining, branching and anastomosing hyphae, in cross section appearing netted and fairly readily separating from the outer wall of cut spores"^; gametangia "up to 65(80) microns broad, often becoming thick-walled and persisting, parallel, of unequal size, with the zygospore budding from the tip of the larger of the two", (Gerdemann), peridium 20-40 microns thick, composed of hyphae 3-6 microns wide, sparingly septate, branching, and interwoven; gleba "composed of zygospores and their envelopes of closely adhering hyphae (1-6 microns wide) and wider (8-20 microns wide), thick-walled (2 microns) structural hyphae", (Berch(2) who say the specimen is "tentatively identified" as E. lactiflua)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin "lacti-" (milk) and "fluo" (flowing), referring to the latex exuded by cut surfaces of fresh young fruitbodies
SIMILAR  Endogone flammicorona and E. lactiflua differ in the following ways: 1) the sporocarp of E. lactiflua is nearly spherical to elliptic or kidney-shaped, rarely lobed or irregular, whereas the sporocarp of E. flammicorona is generally lobed or irregular, 2) spores of E. lactiflua are round to elliptic, generally wider than long with a width of 94-190 microns, whereas spores of E. flammicorona are round, elliptic, or obovoid, usually longer than wide with a width of 42-99 microns, 3) the outer spore wall of E. lactiflua becomes dark reddish brown in Melzer's reagent, whereas the outer spore wall of E. flammicorona becomes yellow to pale orange in Melzer's reagent, 4) the spore mantle of E. lactiflua consists of several layers of interwoven hyphae, appears netted in cross-section, and separates readily from spore walls, whereas the spore mantle of E. flammicorona generally consists of a single layer of spirally arranged hyphae, appears as flame-shaped projections in cross-section, and adheres tightly to spore walls, and 5) the gametangia of E. lactiflua are thick-walled, often persistent, and up to 80 microns wide, whereas the gametangia of E. flammicorona are thin-walled, ephemeral and generally not visible on mature specimens, and not broader than 40 microns, (Gerdemann).
SOURCES  Gerdemann(1), Berch(2), Hawker(1), Trappe(13)
44
FAMILY  Endogonaceae, Order Endogonales, Class Uncertain, Phylum Zygomycota
LATIN NAMES  Endogone oregonensis  Gerd. & Trappe^  Mycologia Memoir 5: 21. 1974
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a small spherical to irregular fruitbody enclosed in white cottony peridium and adherent soil, 2) a spore mass that exudes white latex when cut and contains white to pale dingy yellow spherical spore clusters separated by bands of soil or white hyphae, 3) growth underground in association with conifer roots below 350m elevation and 4) microscopic characters including very large spores (zygospores).^ The description derived from Gerdemann(1). It is rare among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest. RANGE Endogone oregonensis is endemic to OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.6-2cm across, spherical to ellipsoid or lobed and irregular, "enclosed in a thin, white, cottony peridium with much adhering soil"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  spore mass "exuding white latex when cut", containing pallid to pale sordid yellow, spherical spore clusters up to 0.2cm across, separated from each other by bands of soil or white hyphae
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground associated with roots of Picea sitchensis (Sitka spruce), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), below 350m elevation, February, July, September, November^, (Castellano), underground, in coniferous forests (Picea, Pseudotsuga, Tsuga) at elevations less than 500m, June, July, September, and November, (Gerdemann)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  zygospores 77-150 x 44-120 microns, round to elliptic or oval, pale yellow, spore wall 5-7 microns thick, of two layers, the outer wall colorless to pale yellow and generally slightly thicker than the colorless inner wall, "spores not enclosed in a hyphal mantle, separated from each other by thin-walled vesicular hyphae that are often crushed between the thickly crowded spores"^; gametangia "ephemeral, observed only on immature spores, equal or subequal in size, uniting at or near their tips with the zygospore budding from near the point of union or from one of the two gametangia"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'from Oregon'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gerdemann(1), Castellano(1)*
45
FAMILY  Endogonaceae, Order Endogonales, Class Uncertain, Phylum Zygomycota
LATIN NAMES  Endogone pisiformis  Link ex Fr.^  Syst. Mycol. 2: 296. 1823;  = Endogone xylogena  (Sacc.) J. Schroet. sensu J. Schroet.;  = Endogone ludwigii  Buchholz;  = Endogone sphagnophila  G.F. Atk.;  = Endogone occidentalis  Kanouse
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a small spherical to elongate or lobed orange-yellow fruitbody with a basal indentation or cavity, 2) a thin white peridium that is transparent when wet, 3) growth underground or above ground in soil or humus, on coniferous wood, on old polypores, or on sphagnum moss, usually at high elevation, and 4) microscopic characters including very large spores (zygospores) distributed randomly within the spore mass.^ The description is derived from Gerdemann(1) except where noted. In the Pacific Northwest it is the most frequently collected Endogone species. RANGE Collections were examined from BC, WA, OR, AK, CA, (Gerdemann). Distribution also includes in Canada MB, NB, NS, ON, and PQ, (Dalpe). It was also examined from CT, MD, ME, MI, NH, NY, TN, WV, (Thaxter in Berch), and NC (Grand & Randall in Berch). It has been found in the United Kingdom (Hawker(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.1-0.6(1)cm across, somewhat spherical to elongate or much lobed, "smaller specimens usually indented at base, the larger often with a basal opening that extends into a central cavity"; "bright orange-yellow when moist, becoming light yellow to nearly white when dry"; peridium thin, white^, (Gerdemann), when wet, "the peridium is transparent and the sporocarps appear waxy and yellow or orange - yellow owing to the pigmentation of the underlying zygospores", when dried, the peridium becomes whitish and appears scaly; little debris adheres to peridium, (Berch)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  orange-yellow^ (Berch)
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground or above ground, in soil or humus, on coniferous litter, wood or bark of fallen trees, old fruitbodies of polypores, or on sphagnum, "in mountains up to timberline and occasionally at low elevations", fruiting after heavy rains in late summer or fall through winter, "and in spring and early summer, when it is often found under the edges of melting snowbanks"; apparently a saprophyte or mycoparasite^, (Gerdemann)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  zygospores 27-75(83) x 27-65(75) microns, round, elliptic or oboval, walls colorless to pale yellow, "up to 10 microns thick, composed of an outer wall up to 3 microns and a thicker, inner wall up to 8 microns", "spore contents of deep-yellow oil globules that often fade to light yellow"^; gametangia "parallel, equal or subequal in size, thin-walled and ephemeral, observed only on immature spores, uniting at or near their tips, the zygospores budding mostly from the point of union but occasionally forming above one gametangium"; gleba "containing coarse, vesicular, thin-walled hyphae" up to 15 microns wide, "often becoming crushed between the crowded zygospores"; peridium composed of hyphae 1-8 microns wide, loosely interwoven, thick-walled, (Gerdemann), spores contain yellow lipid globules that impart a granular appearance, spores not have a hyphal envelope; gametangia typically not ephemeral; gleba contains branching structural hyphae that are wide (up to 20 microns) and thick-walled (4 microns) in addition to the sporogenous hyphae; the peridium is "15-40 microns thick and composed of loosely interwoven or distinctly clustered hyphae that terminate in whiplike extensions that may project from the surface of the sporocarp", these whip-like extension arise from the structural hyphae in the gleba, (Berch)
NAME ORIGIN  means "pea-shaped"
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gerdemann(1), Dalpe(1) (in French), Berch(2), Hawker(1)
46
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Fevansia aurantiaca  Trappe & Castellano^  Mycotaxon 75: 155. 2000
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Fevansia aurantiaca is characterized by the combination of a sticky gelatinous spore mass with gel-filled locules, a pale pink-orange to orange brown color to the spore mass and outer surface, large inflated cells in the trama, extracellular orange pigment deposits in the subcutis and trama, and other microscopic characters. It is rare among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)).^ The description is derived from Trappe(2) except where noted. RANGE It is endemic to OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2-2.3cm x 1.7-1.9cm, nearly spherical, lobed; "pale brown-orange to orange-brown"; "with much adherent soil and debris"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  firm, moist; "pale pink-orange to orange-brown, the color a combination of orange to orange-brown trama and pale yellow to pale brown-yellow spore masses filling the rounded locules"; sterile veins 0.02-0.1cm wide, colored as trama, meandering through; "sections of dried mature specimens with dark red-orange, glassy-resinous deposits"^, (Trappe), locules look like goblets as viewed from above (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  no attachment point evident; columella lacking
ODOR  strongly oily-fruity (Trappe), not distinctive (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  not recorded
EDIBILITY  unknown (Trappe, M.(3))
HABITAT  underground under mature coniferous forests, 1000-1700 meters, probably ectomycorrhizal with Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and other species of Pinaceae, August^, (Trappe), August to November (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-13 x (3.5)4-5 microns, fusoid, smooth, pale yellow singly in Melzer's reagent but gray-yellow in mass, colorless in KOH singly but gray-yellow in mass, with 2-3 large droplets, the walls 0.5 microns thick, cyanophilic^; basidia not found, hymenium and subhymenium not found; trama with narrow central stratum of hyphae 1.5-5 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, the broad zones between central strand and locule margins of colorless, thin-walled hyphae with most cells inflated to 6-20 microns wide to appear nearly pseudoparenchymatous, "pigment deposits throughout as in peridial subcutis", "sterile veins structured similarly to tramal central strand"; peridium 100-200 microns thick: subcutis 75-175 microns thick, of hyphae 1.5-5 microns wide at septa (with occasional cells inflated to 5-10 microns), interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, when young "with scattered extracellular deposits of amorphous orange pigment in KOH, in Melzer's reagent the pigment dissolving into yellow to orange pigment globules", when mature "with massive extracellular deposits of orange to bright red pigment in KOH, in Melzer's reagent the pigment dissolving into orange to brown pigment globules", epicutis +/- 25 microns thick, of hyphae 1.5-4 microns wide, appressed, colorless, thin-walled, "the cell contents pale olive-yellow to orange"; clamp connections not found
NAME ORIGIN  means "pale orange", referring to the color of the glebal trama^, (Trappe)
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon spp. are olivaceous to brown in mass rather than grayish yellow, (Trappe(13)).
SOURCES  Trappe(2), Castellano(1), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)
47
FAMILY  Morchellaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Fischerula subcaulis  Trappe^  Mycologia 67: 936. 1975
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include nearly spherical to slightly lobed fruitbody with pinkish gray to brown surface, firm pink to dark purple interior, well-developed stem-columella, and microscopic characters including ascospores with dark brown warts up to 15 microns tall^; rarely collected, from southwestern WA and western OR, but can be locally abundant when found, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  negative reaction on surface to KOH, FeSO4, and ethanol^, (Trappe(7))
OUTER SURFACE  0.8-2.5cm x 1.3-2.5cm, nearly spherical to slightly lobed; pinkish gray to grayish yellowish pink becoming brown when old; furrowed^, (Smith), 0.8-2.5cm x 1.3-2.5cm, nearly spherical to slightly lobed, the indented base giving rise to a dense basal tuft or pad; pinkish gray to grayish yellowish pink when young, soon mottled with darker areas and when mature "moderate brown marbled with light brown where veins emerge"; minutely scabrous, furrowed where veins emerge from the spore mass, (Trappe(7))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  firm, grayish pink becoming dark grayish purple to nearly black marbled with white branches of the columella^, (Smith), very firm; grayish pink when young, becoming dark grayish purple to nearly black by maturity, marbled with narrow, white, stuffed veins "that radiate obscurely from the columella and emerge through the peridium", (Trappe(7))
STEM  distinct stem-columella or basal pad (a dense mycelial tuft at base)^, (Smith), basal tuft or pad frequently extended as recurved stem, 0.2-1.2cm x 0.2-0.5(1)cm, colored as the outer surface, with inside light grayish reddish brown, the stem-columella ending as a dense mycelial tuft, (Trappe(7))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  probably associated with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas fir) and other conifers, maturing in summer and fall^, (Smith), in coniferous or mixed conifer-alder forests, probably mycorrhizal with Pseudotsuga menziesii, Abies procera (Noble Fir), and possibly other conifers, (Trappe(7))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 60-77(96) x 55-73 microns, ornamented with dark brown spines that may be agglutinated to form irregular warts and ridges^; asci versiform, 8-spored, (Smith), spores 60-77(96) x 55-73 microns including epispore, 40-54(70) x 25-46 microns without, elliptic, colorless and smooth when young, but when mature brown and ornamented with obscure dark brown flexuous [wavy] spines 6-15 x 1-2 microns agglutinated into conic to irregular warts and ridges, deep reddish brown in Melzer's, weakly cyanophilic, walls 1-2 microns thick; asci 1-6(8)-spored, embedded randomly in tramal tissue, ellipsoid to obovoid, reniform or clavate, when young 120-170 x 55-80 microns, when mature 120-230 x 65-100 microns, "tapered to abruptly attenuated to a short, uncroziered stipe 6-10 microns in diam", when young walls colorless and thin, when mature "3 or more layered and 1-3 microns thick, nonamyloid"; peridium "100-150 microns thick, of elongate to inflated cells 5-30(40) microns in diam, with yellow to brown walls 1-2(3) microns thick, the outer cells often emergent from the surface and larger in diam than those beneath"; glebal fertile tissue rather abruptly differentiated from peridium as colorless to light brown walled, "interwoven hyphae 3-10 microns in diam at septa, but cells often inflated (up to 25 microns), the walls +/- 0.5 microns thick"; glebal veins 50-200 microns broad, when young lined with a palisade of colorless to yellow, thin-walled cells 30-50 x 7-12(25) microns, many growing out to loosely stuff the veins with colorless hyphae 5-10 microns in diameter; "stipe-columella of subparallel hyphae 5-10 microns wide with yellow to brown wall 0.5-1 micron thick, near the soil attachment the walls somewhat thicker and irregularly surface-granulated", (Trappe(7))
NAME ORIGIN  means "somewhat stemmed"
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Trappe(7), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
48
FAMILY  Boletaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Gastroboletus ruber  (Zeller) Cazares and Trappe^  Mycotaxon 42: 339-345. 1991;  Truncocolumella rubra  Zeller
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Boletes category. Features include 1) nearly spherical to top-shaped or lobed fruitbody lacking a distinct cap, 2) rose to reddish brown covering that is smooth and thin, usually disappearing over the tube mouths which are tinged reddish orange to red, 3) tubes pale yellow to dark olive, and blue when bruised or exposed, not vertical, divided into narrow maze-like cavities, 4) short pale yellow stem-columella that branches into the interior of the spore mass and that turns blue when bruised or exposed, 5) development under the soil surface associated with mountain conifers, and 6) large spores.^ Gastroboletus ruber is the current name in the online Species Fungorum, accessed April 1, 2018, but in MycoBank, accessed the same day, the current name is Truncocolumella rubra. The species will likely be recombined into a bolete genus such as Neoboletus. Gastroboletus ruber is common among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Gastroboletus ruber is found in WA, OR, and CA, (Castellano)..
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2-5.5cm x 2-4cm, nearly spherical to top-shaped or lobed, peridium [outer layer] rose to brown-red or red-brown and persistent at top of stem, dingy pale yellow to dark red-brown and usually disappearing where covering tube mouths but sometimes partially persisting and then becoming yellow-brown to cinnamon and depressed in the tube mouths to give a reticulate appearance^, (Cazares), 2-5cm broad, 2-4cm high, broadly pear-shaped to nearly spherical; peridium (outer layer) yellowish at first, becoming reddish where exposed, aniline yellow where covered by soil, surface thin and almost entirely disappearing by maturity, (Smith), 2-3.5cm broad, 2.5-3cm high, broadly pear-shaped, peridium thin, almost entirely disappearing by maturity, reddish, (Zeller)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  initially of separable tubes 0.5-1.0 mm in diameter and divided into maze-like locules +/- 0.2 mm wide, on expansion, tubular organization disrupted but locules still radiate and are up to 0.5(0.8)mm wide; pale yellow when young, dark olive when mature, tube mouths tinged red-orange to red when mature, turning blue where bruised or cut^, (Cazares), cavities relatively large, maze-like; "dingy pale yellow, changing to bluish on bruising and exposure, drying raw umber to rusty brown", (Smith), cavities in spore mass relatively large, maze-like, spore mass sordid light yellow, turning blue on bruising or exposure, (Zeller), pores up to 1mm wide, angular to irregular, (Bessette)
STEM  up to 1.5cm broad at top when percurrent [going through spore mass], columnar to dendroid, percurrent or not, with many branches reaching or nearly reaching the peridium, projecting as much as 1cm below the glebal base; pale yellow outside and inside, turning blue instantly when cut^, (Cazares), 0.7-1.5cm thick, "almost percurrent at times and also with narrow plate-like branches radiating laterally and terminally, extended below as a sterile base", "yellowish, changing to blue when bruised or exposed, drying yellowish", (Smith), columella stout, 0.7-1.2cm broad, "almost percurrent, with narrow branches radiating laterally and terminally", "extended below as a sterile base", (Zeller), 1-2cm x 1-2cm, tapered downward; colored like cap; dry, (Bessette)
ODOR  not distinctive^ (Cazares)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  unknown (Bessette)
HABITAT  fruitbodies develop under the soil surface associated with the roots of assorted Pinaceae species above 1,350 m in elevation, particularly Abies amabilis, A. procera, A. magnifica var. shastensis, Pinus monticola, or Tsuga mertensiana, August through September^, (Castellano), single to gregarious or cespitose, underground or emergent, Cascade Mountains at elevations 1200-1800m, (Cazares), emergent from heavy duff under conifers, especially hemlock, during late summer in the Cascade Mountains of Washington, (Smith), type emergent from heavy duff under hemlock, (Zeller)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (8)9-15(20) x 4-6 microns, subfusiform [somewhat spindle-shaped], smooth, inamyloid, pale green to olive in KOH, walls up to 0.5 microns thick^; basidia 2-spored to 4-spored, 26-40 x 7-11 microns, cylindric to clavate, colorless, thin-walled; cystidia scattered, 25-50 x 4-14 microns, fusoid-ventricose, colorless to pale olive in KOH, thin-walled, lacking incrustations; peridial epicutis "initially differentiated as a palisade of cylindric to clavate dermatocystidia 15-30(70) x 3-10 microns", colorless to pale yellow in KOH, becoming a disrupted turf over the gleba but remaining a palisade over percurrent columellar apices; clamp connections absent, (Cazares), spores (10)11-14(15) x 4-5.5(6) microns, narrowly oval to nearly oblong, smooth, weakly pseudoamyloid, yellowish in KOH, wall thickened up to 0.5 microns; basidia 4-spored, 26-33 x 9-11 microns, clavate; cystidia scattered, 38-50 x 9-14 microns, fusoid-ventricose, tapered gradually to acute apex, colorless to yellow in KOH, a few with yellow inclusions in KOH, thin-walled, not incrusted; epicutis "a palisade of thin-walled dermatocystidia over the youngest peridia"; clamp connections absent, (Smith), spores 10-12.5 x 4.5-5.5 microns, oblong-elliptic, ochraceous brown, (Zeller)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'red'
SIMILAR  Gastroboletus turbinatus similar but has a distinct cap, (Bessette).
SOURCES  Cazares(4), Smith(29) (as Truncocolumella rubra), Castellano(1)*, Bessette(3)*, Arora(1) (as Truncocolumella rubra), Zeller(7) (as Truncocolumella rubra), Trappe(13)
49
FAMILY  Boletaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Gastroboletus subalpinus  Trappe and Thiers^  Brittonia 21: 245. 1969;  Boletus subalpinus  (Trappe & Thiers) M. Nuhn, Manfr. Binder, A.F.S. Taylor, Halling, Hibbett  Fungal Biology 117 (7-8): 479-511. 2013 (proposed current name)
ENGLISH NAMES  gastroid king-bolete
NOTES  Also listed in Boletes category. Features include 1) a whitish to buff cap, 2) white flesh that does not turn blue, 3) tubes oriented at various angles and often covered by a membrane extending down from cap, 4) whitish pores that finally darken to olive brown, 5) a short stem colored as the cap, and 6) development under the ground under mountain conifers, often with partial exposure at maturity.  It is common among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)).^ The species belongs in a bolete genus. Boletus subalpinus is a homotypic synonym in MycoBank, accessed February 18, 2018, and the currently accepted name in Species Fungorum, accessed the same day. RANGE Gastroboletus subalpinus is fairly common a higher elevations in CA, OR, and Washington, (Bessette). There is a collection from Washington at the University of Washington by P. Matheny in 1996, but Castellano(1)(1999) gives sites only in CA and OR and says "not known from Washington". The type is from Cloud Cap Oregon, not far from Washington.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  5-12cm across, convex becoming flat to depressed or somewhat irregular; "whitish to buff or pale tan", sometimes darkening somewhat when old; "smooth to slightly velvety, often pitted and/or wrinkled, not viscid but often covered with dirt and debris"; margin extending down over tubes as thin white membrane that often disappears or breaks up when old^, (Arora), 6-10cm across, convex becoming flat to deeply depressed to flat-convex when mature, bolete-like in general appearance, often highly pitted and wrinkled and irregular in outline; "warm buff" to "light buff" to "pale olive buff" to "pinkish cinnamon", unchanging when old or darkening to near "clay color" to "buckthorn brown" (colors from Ridgway); dry to moist, bald to velvety to subtomentose, typically covered with soil and debris; peridium on lateral and undersides of spore-producing area "white, thin, velvety, persistent except for scattered, circular ruptures" over mouths of occasional tubes when old, (Thiers)
INNER LAYER  thick, soft; "white or with yellow to olive discolorations", not turning blue when bruised but sometimes staining pinkish^, (Arora), 0.3-1.5cm thick at disc, tapering to margin, soft; white or on some fruitbodies "with sordid yellowish or olivaceous zones", in some fruitbodies "slowly staining pinkish to grayish lavender when cut", in stem white, unchanging, (Thiers)
INTERIOR  pallid or whitish becoming grayish yellow to buff and finally darkening to olive-brown, not turning blue when bruised; tubes occasionally vertical especially near stem but mostly at various angles, colored more or less like pores^, (Arora), pores less than 1mm across, colored like tubes, unchanging when bruised; tube layer 1-3cm thick, but markedly decreased in thickness in both directions from thickest area, depressed to seceded from stem, strongly projecting beyond upper cap surface but then covered by the thin, pallid, lateral outer covering; occasionally tubes vertical near stem but mostly curved and oriented 20 degrees from vertical, or angled upward near edges of fruitbody, "dark olive buff" to "pale olive buff", when old becoming "buffy citrine" to "citrine drab", (Ridgway colors), (Thiers), pores circular to angular, (Bessette)
STEM  2-6cm x 2-5cm, narrowing downward or sometimes equal or even swollen in lower part, solid; white to buff, sometimes darkening to tan when old, base sometimes orange-yellow; dry, often dirty^, (Arora), 2-5cm x 2-4.5cm at top, base up to 3-4cm wide; subventricose [more or less wide in middle] or narrowing downward, occasionally "equal to bulbous at the base"; dirty white to "warm buff" to "light buff" in some, the base "apricot yellow" (Ridgway colors); dry, but typically covered with adhering debris, bald to velvety to subtomentose with the top reticulate when gleba has seceded, (Thiers), no annulus (Bessette)
ODOR  mild to farinaceous^ (Thiers)
TASTE  mild, pleasant^, (Thiers)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious "in soil or duff under mountain conifers in late spring and summer", developing underground but often partially exposed when mature^, (Arora), single to gregarious, underground or partly emerging, under Pinus albicaulis or Abies magnifica and possibly other conifers of montane and subalpine forests, "Commonly found late spring and summer", (Thiers), developing under soil surface associated with the roots of various Pinaceae above 1550m elevation, particularly Abies magnifica (Red Fir), Pinus albicaulis (Whitebark Pine), and Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock), September and October, (Castellano), with Pinus albicaulis, Pinus contorta, Abies, Tsuga mertensiana, at relatively high elevations to the tree line; July to October, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-16(18) x 4.5-6(8) microns, elliptic to spindle-shaped, smooth, yellowish to brown^, (Arora), spores 10-16(18) x 4.5-6(8) microns, elliptic, oblong to subovate [somewhat oval], "occasionally irregularly constricted near middle", smooth, light yellow to ochraceous in Melzer's reagent and KOH, moderately thick-walled; basidia 4-spored, 40-48 x 8-13 microns, clavate, colorless and guttulate in KOH, thin-walled, brachybasidioles 25-40 x 7-12 microns, similar in shape and appearance to basidia; cystidia "often abundant when young, especially on the pores, apparently collapsing and appearing infrequently with age, single or sometimes clustered", 24-75 x 7-10 microns, subcylindric to clavate to tapered, colorless in KOH and Melzer's reagent, thin-walled; epicutis of peridium on top of fruitbody of densely interwoven, much branched hyphae 4-15 microns wide, with erect, tapered, blunt-tipped terminal cells 25-45 x 7-12 microns, sparsely scattered over surface; clamp connections absent, (Thiers)
NAME ORIGIN  means "subalpine, growing below the timber line"^ (Both(1))
SIMILAR  Boletus barrowsii and Boletus edulis are somewhat similar but both have vertical tubes.
SOURCES  Thiers(7), Arora(1), Bessette(3)*, Castellano(1)*, Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)*, Both(1)
50
FAMILY  Boletaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Gastroboletus turbinatus  (Snell) A.H. Smith and Singer^  Brittonia 11: 208-210. 1959;  Boletus turbinatus  Snell  Mycologia 28(1): 20. 1936;  Boletellus turbinatus  (Snell) Singer
ENGLISH NAMES  gastroid bolete, bogus bolete
NOTES  Also listed in Boletes category. Features include 1) an irregular to top-shaped cap that is yellowish brown to reddish brown sometimes with yellowish or reddish tinges, 2) yellow flesh that turns blue when exposed, 3) yellowish tubes that are irregular and not vertically oriented, 4) angular pores that are yellow or tinged orange and turn blue when bruised, 5) a short stem that is yellow with reddish tinges and turns blue when bruised, and 6) growth under conifers, often partly buried.^ The taxon will likely be recombined as one or more species in a bolete genus. Var. flammeus, known from Idaho, grows on the ground under fir and has a pale golden cap with red blotches, bright red pores when young, and shorter spores 11-14 x 7-9 microns, (Bessette). Var. flammeus may occur elsewhere in the Pacific Northwest and other varieties are not well documented. Among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest, G. turbinatus is common, (Trappe(13)). RANGE Gastroboletus turbinatus is found in WA, OR, and ID, and is apparently widely distributed in the western US and also found in MO, (Smith). It is also found in CA (Castellano).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2-5(8)cm across, convex to slightly depressed to irregular; usually brown to reddish brown to bright yellow with red or brown spots and stains; "dry, minutely velvety, often pitted or wrinkled"^, (Arora), 2-5(8)cm across, convex becoming flat or slightly depressed; bister to mummy-brown, golden-yellow or bay-red, or with a reddish to orange-salmon tinge at least along marginal area; dry, velvety, when old subtomentose [somewhat tomentose], (Smith)
INNER LAYER  soft; yellow, typically bruising blue quickly; in stem base often reddish^, (Arora), flesh "yellow in the peridium, often partly pinkish in the stipe-columella, tending to stain blue when injured and later becoming red to brownish in these areas, especially on drying", (Smith)
INTERIOR  "pinkish to reddish, orange, or yellow", typically turning blue quickly when bruised; tubes irregular and sinuous or oriented at various angles other than vertical, greenish yellow to yellow^, (Arora), pores round at first and about 0.5mm across, when old with large angular depressions reaching 1 mm across; tube chambers reaching 1-3cm or more in length but diminishing in length in both directions from the place where they are longest, "strongly projecting beyond the peridium or remaining covered by its extended thin portion, either strongly depressed or nearly free from the apex of the columella, more rarely broadly attached to the columella"; interior of gleba yellow and quickly turning blue on exposure, pores in some specimens becoming reddish at mouths when mature or when old, (Smith), 1-2 per mm, angular, "covered by a thin membrane at first", surface irregular and uneven; yellow, sometimes tinted orange, quickly turning blue when bruised; "tubes 1-3cm long, irregular and not vertically arranged", depressed near stem, (Bessette)
STEM  1-4(7)cm x 1-2.5cm, equal or narrowing at base, often protruding only a short distance below tubes, solid; "yellow or with reddish streaks or granules or colored like the cap", sometimes reddish when old and often reddish at base; dry^, (Arora), 1-2(7)cm x 0.8-2cm, equal or narrowing downward, often not projecting much below gleba, solid; unpolished in upper part, "yellow or more orange-yellow to reddish toward the base, turning blue when bruised, sometimes finally becoming reddish"; frequently finely rivulose [with river-like lines] "because of the cracking of a brownish to reddish layer, the layer finally breaking up into minute points, at times brown-furfuraceous in a narrow zone", stem finally becoming bald; no veil, (Smith)
ODOR  slight and insignificant^ (Smith)
TASTE  slight and insignificant^ (Smith)
EDIBILITY  unknown (Arora)
HABITAT  single to scattered or gregarious "on ground in woods or at their edges, often partially buried", (Arora), on humus under conifers, often Abies spp. (fir), along mountain paths and roadsides, July through September, (Smith), spring through fall (Trudell)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (9.5)13.5-18 x 6.5-9.5 microns, elliptic to spindle-shaped, smooth, brown or golden^, (Arora), spores (9.5)13.5-18(20) x (5.5)6.5-9.5 microns, elliptic to oblong or slightly oval, honey-colored, often with a fulvous tinge, "walls simple at first, later thickening and becoming 3-layered", "apex obtuse to acute and the wall there either continuous or showing a slight pore"; basidia mostly 4-spored but sometimes with 1, 2 or 3 spores, 35-38 x 9-14 microns, "rather voluminous, vesiculose-pedicellate to clavate", colorless or yellow in KOH, basidioles scattered, variable in size or shape, about 33 x 9 microns, mostly somewhat clavate, colorless; "pseudoparaphyses similar in size and shape to the basidioles but without protoplasmic content and hence not likely to produce spores"; cystidia rare but present in interior as well as pores, 35-60 x 9.5-17 microns, ventricose-mucronate to more often ventricose in middle and ampullaceous-pedicellate, often with a long thin neck, colorless, later either colorless or golden yellow to brownish, apex usually obtuse; clamp connections absent, (Smith)
NAME ORIGIN  means "shaped like a spinning top, obconical, turbinate", (Both(1))
SIMILAR  Gastroboletus ruber lacks a distinct cap and has narrower spores.
SOURCES  Smith(29), Bessette(3)*, Arora(1)*, Castellano(2)*, Trudell(4)*, Thiers(7), Trappe(13), Both(1)
51
FAMILY  Boletaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Gastroboletus vividus  Trappe & Castellano^  Mycotaxon 75: 158. 2000
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Boletes category. Features include 1) a bright yellow and red cap, 2) pale yellow flesh that stains slowly red where exposed, 3) yellow pores that turn olive and then red-orange to red, 4) tubes that are olive and often contorted, 5) an abruptly bulbous yellow stem that is red-furfuraceous at top, 6) growth underground or partially underground under conifers, and 7) microscopic characters including inamyloid spores on (2-)4-spored basidia^. The species will likely be recombined into a bolete genus. The description derived from Trappe(2) except where specified. It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Gastroboletus vividus is found from southern OR Cascade Mountains to northern CA, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  Melzer's reagent nonreactive on fresh or dry flesh
OUTER SURFACE  fruitbody 3.5-6.5(8)cm x 3-5cm, like a bolete but with cap margins strongly turned up when mature; cap surface "moderate yellow with red areas or red blushed overall"; dry, felty
INNER LAYER  "pale yellow, very slowly staining pale red where exposed", with narrow, olive to red zones at tube attachment and immediately beneath cap surface; in stem red at top, pale yellow in lower part, unchanging when exposed
INTERIOR  pores 0.5-2.0mm, circular to elliptic, adnate-seceding; brilliant yellow at first but soon becoming olive and by maturity red-orange to dark red, not blueing where bruised; tube layer 1-2cm thick, tubes "aligned from slightly below horizontal to nearly vertically upward, often contorted", olive
STEM  2-3cm x 1-3cm, abruptly bulbous below tube layer; brilliant yellow to sordid yellow; red-furfuraceous at top 
ODOR  not distinctive
TASTE  not distinctive
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  growing underground or partially underground under mature conifers (Abies concolor, A. magnifica var. shastensis, Pinus contorta and Tsuga mertensiana), July to September, (Trappe(2)), above 1650m elevation (Castellano)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (11)13-18(22) x 6-7(8) microns, fusoid or occasionally oboval, smooth, inamyloid ("in Melzer's reagent pale yellow singly and brown-yellow in mass"), "in KOH golden yellow singly and bright brown-yellow in mass"^; basidia (2-)4-spored, 30-45 x 9-11 microns, clavate; cystidia absent; cap cuticle a loose tangle of hyphae, thin-walled hyphae 4-8 microns wide at septa, the cells mostly slightly inflated; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  means "brightly colored"^ (Trappe(2))
SIMILAR  Gastroboletus amyloideus Thiers is somewhat less brightly colored and has amyloid spores, (Trappe(2)).
SOURCES  Trappe(2), Castellano(1)*, Trappe(13)
52
FAMILY  Suillaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Gastrosuillus imbellus  (Trappe) Thiers^  Mem. N.Y. bot. Gdn 49: 358. 1989;  Gastroboletus imbellus  Trappe  Brittonia 21: 249-251. 1969
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Boletes category. There is doubt about whether this is a distinct species - it is thought to be a distorted Suillus punctatipes. Gastrosuillus imbellus is characterized by 1) drab color, 2) persistent hanging veil remnants on cap margin, 3) short tubes oriented at an angle to vertical, 4) pores mostly blocked by folds and outgrowths of wall tissue, 5) short laterally attached stem-columella, 6) pungent-farinaceous odor, 7) slightly bitter taste, and 8) formation under the soil surface.^ The description is derived from Thiers(7) unless otherwise specified. Gastrosuillus imbellus is endemic to OR and known from a single site there, (Castellano).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  with 5% KOH, tube mouths turn dark brown, bases deep lilac, flesh near cap surface deep lilac
OUTER SURFACE  5cm across, convex, expanded, bolete-like in appearance except for lateral attachment of cap to stem; grayish yellow ground color, overlain by dark olivaceous fibrils to produce overall sordid gray appearance; moist but not viscid, cap surface with a few broad cracks that extend deeply into flesh, which is blushed rose where exposed in this way; margin with hanging ragged membranous veil remnants from a 0.2-0.3cm wide extension of the cap surface
INNER LAYER  2cm thick at attachment of stem, soft; "white with scattered pale yellow stained areas", a rosy zone above the tubes and a 0.2cm thick olive-hygrophanous zone under the cap surface, "slowly and erratically staining light sordid brownish where cut"; in stem pallid with vinaceous blush near base and turning slowly sordid when cut
INTERIOR  gleba (spore producing tissue) exposed and tubulose; pores 1-4 per mm, round, mostly blocked by folds and outgrowths of wall tissue; tubes oriented at about 40 degrees from vertical, decurrent, short (not over 0.2cm long), pale grayish olive
STEM  stem-columella 3cm long, 1.5cm at apex, equal except narrowing slightly at base, laterally attached to cap; dull yellowish at top, grading to sordid cream in middle part, to pale salmonaceous with copious dark brown stains at base; dry at top, "upper half with dark brown to blackish glandular dots which are minute singly but often coalesced into patches up to one-half mm broad"
ODOR  pungent-farinaceous
TASTE  slightly bitter
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single under Tsuga mertensiana and Abies amabilis, midsummer, (Thiers), "sporocarps beneath the soil surface associated with the roots of Abies grandis, A. lasiocarpa, Tsuga mertensiana, with an understory of Antennaria lanata, Fragaria sp., Pachistima myrsinites, Sorbus sitchensis, and Vaccinium sp. at 1,650m elevation", (Castellano)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-10 x 2.5 microns, narrowly to broadly elliptic to obovate, smooth, pale yellow in Melzer's reagent, colorless in KOH, most with 1 or 2 large droplets and often with several smaller ones^; basidia 20-30 x 3-5(7) microns, colorless in KOH, brachybasidioles similar to basidia but shorter; cystidia 25-60 x 4-6 microns, fascicled, colorless to vinaceous to dark brown in KOH "with much brown, amorphous material deposited at the base of the clusters, cylindric to fusoid-ventricose or irregularly constricted"; epicutis of peridium in KOH of granulated pale brownish, thin-walled hyphae 2-6 microns wide, subcutis similar except hyphae 5-12 microns wide and much yellowish to pale vinaceous debris present, in Melzer's reagent epicuticular hyphae yellowish and subcuticular hyphae more or less vinaceous stained; orange-brown pigment balls scattered throughout; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  means "not beautiful" (Both(1))
SIMILAR  Suillus pungens is also drab in color and unpleasant in odor and taste, but has normal tubes and pores, (Thiers).
SOURCES  Thiers(7) (as Gastroboletus), Castellano(1) (as Gastroboletus), Both(1) (as Gastroboletus)
53
FAMILY  Suillaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Gastrosuillus suilloides  (Thiers) Thiers^  Mem. N. Y. bot. Gdn 49: 358. 1989;  Gastroboletus suilloides  Thiers  Brittonia 21: 248. 1969;  Suillus suilloides  (Thiers) Kretzer & T.D. Bruns  Mycologia 89(4): 589. 1997  (proposed new name)
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in the Boletes category. Features of Gastrosuillus suilloides include 1) a hypogeous to partly emergent fruitbody that is convex to nearly round, the surface yellowish brown to cinnamon brown or pinkish brown, dry, and bald becoming fibrillose-scaly or tomentose, 2) unchanging buff to cream context, 3) a spore mass with distorted greenish-yellow tubes, and small irregular pores of the same color, 4) an poorly developed stem-columella colored like the cap, 5) mild odor and taste, 6) growth under conifers at higher elevations, and 7) microscopic characters including fascicled darkly staining cystidia and spore shape that both suggest Suillus.^ The description is derived from Thiers(7). RANGE Gastrosuillus suilloides was described from CA but according to Noah Siegel (pers. comm.) has been recorded also from OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2.5-5cm across when mature, "convex to subglobose to plano-convex during all stages of development"; peridium ' "ochraceous buff" to "cinnamon brown" to "buckthorn brown" to occasionally as dark as "mikado brown" to "sayal brown" ' when older, "unchanging when bruised"; dry, bald when young, "often becoming fibrillose to tomentose to appressed fibrillose scaly with age, sometimes becoming areolate with age"
INNER LAYER  context 0.3-0.7cm thick, "ochraceous buff" to pale "cream color", "unchanging when exposed"
INTERIOR  gleba distinctly "tubulose", tubes typically exposed at maturity (but "arranged so as to make a spore deposit impossible"); greenish yellow to olive-yellow, "unchanging when bruised or exposed"; pores "small, irregular", colored as tubes
STEM  stem-columella typically poorly developed, 0.5-1.0cm x 0.3-0.5cm; more or less colored as the cap during all stages of development; dry, tomentose to appressed-fibrillose
ODOR  not distinctive
TASTE  not distinctive
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious, "hypogeous to partially emergent", under conifers including Abies magnifica (California Red Fir) and Pinus contorta ssp. murrayana (Sierra Lodgepole Pine) in higher elevations of the Sierra Nevada of California, late summer
SPORE DEPOSIT  none
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.4-12 x 3.5-4.5 microns, elliptic to inequilateral, some appearing oval or "occasionally more or less constricted at the midportion", "smooth, walls slightly thickened, sterigmal appendages oblique"^; basidia 4-spored, 20-37 x 6-8 microns, narrowly clavate to subcylindric, clavate to depressed at the center, colorless in KOH; brachybasidioles 15-23 x 4-8 microns, clavate; cystidia "abundant to numerous", 35-55 x 5-11 microns, "clavate to cylindric to subcylindric", "typically clustered and staining dark brown in KOH and Melzer's" as in Suillus; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  means 'like Suillus'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Thiers(7) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway(1))
54
FAMILY  Gomphaceae, Order Gomphales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Gautieria caudata  (Harkn.) Zeller & C.W. Dodge^  Ann. Mo. Bot. Gard. 21: 698. 1934;  Hymenogaster caudatus  Harkn.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a somewhat spherical, roughly convoluted surface that is blackish brown in preservative, 2) a dark purplish brown to fuscous spore mass that has white septa broader than the cavities, 3) the base with an appendage leading from rhizomorphs, 4) a nearly percurrent columella, and 5) microscopic characters including spores 13-17.6 x 7-10 microns with 6-8 slightly warted somewhat branched ridges that often have a spiral tendency, and 2-spored basidia.^ The description is derived from Dodge(2). It is rare in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It has been found at least in OR (Smith, J.E.) and CA, (Dodge), It is found in CA, Marin County and south, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  up to 5cm across, (type consists of 3 1/2 specimens, the largest being 2.4cm x 3.2cm x 3.7cm in preservative), somewhat spherical, roughly convoluted; "fuscous", "blackish brown" in preservative
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "Benzo brown" to "fuscous" (dry after preservative), "cavities irregular, empty; septa white, broader than cavities"
STEM  base fleshy, with a caudal appendage 1-2cm long and 0.2cm thick, leading from rhizomorphs; columella nearly percurrent [going through spore mass], 0.2cm wide, narrow, with plate-like branches
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Sequoia and Quercus in California, March to April
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 13-17.6 x 7-10 microns, narrowly elliptic or oboval, "with 6-8 slightly warted, somewhat branched striations, often with a spiral tendency", "russet", pedicellate^; basidia 2-spored, rather indistinct, cylindric, sterigmata as long as the spores; "septa white, broader than the cavities, 200-300 microns thick, of gelified, compact prosenchyma and rather indistinct cylindric basidia"; "peridium formed by gelification of what would otherwise be the hymenial layer of the external septa"
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  About 15 other Gautieria species in the Pacific Northwest are due to be described by States and Fogel (Trappe(13)).
SOURCES  Dodge(2) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Smith, J.E.(1), Trappe(13)
55
FAMILY  Gomphaceae, Order Gomphales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Gautieria gautierioides  (Lloyd) Zeller & C.W. Dodge^  Ann. Mo. Bot. Gard. 21: 697. 1934;  Hymenogaster trabuti  Zeller & C.W. Dodge;  Hymenogaster gautierioides  Lloyd
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include a convoluted surface, a bright yellow-brown spore mass with cavities mostly covered by peridium, a slightly developed stem arising from fine brown rhizomorphs, and microscopic characters including spores 16-21 x 8-10 microns with 5-9 ridges and usually prominently warted, on mostly 4-spored basidia.^ It is infrequent among truffles in the Pacific Northwest. RANGE Gautieria gautierioides has been found at least in OR, ID, and CA, (Smith), and AZ (States). It has been found in northwestern OR to northern CA (var. gautierioides) and western WA to northern CA (var. candida), (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  about 3cm across, somewhat spherical with convoluted surface; "Verona brown" in preserved material^, (Dodge), 1-3cm, peridium white at first, (Smith), 0.5-3cm across, irregularly lobed; white peridium gradually breaking down to expose spore mass when mature, (States)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  bright yellow-brown, cavities mostly remaining covered by the peridium but some chambers usually exposed at maturity^, (Smith), "Brussels brown"; cavities irregular, empty, (Dodge), firm but fragile and crumbly when dry; buff to "cinnamon brown", the "cinnamon brown" spore mass contrasting with the "light buff" tramal tissue, (States)
STEM  stem slightly developed, arising from very fine, brown rhizomorphs; columella dendroid^, (Dodge), with brown basal rhizomorphs, columella basal with percurrent white veins branching through the spore mass, (States)
ODOR  mild when young becoming slightly garlic-like and offensive when old^ (States)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under conifers and hardwoods^, (Smith), under Acer (maple), Arbutus (madrone), Quercus (oak), and Sequoia, April to October, (Dodge), mycorrhizal with Pinaceae (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16-21 x 8-10 microns, round when young but becoming elliptic, with 5-9 striations, usually prominently warted, "cinnamon" to "cinnamon-buff", with 1 to 3 droplets, short-pedicellate^; basidia mostly 4-spored, 25-30 x 10-16 microns, obovoid to clavate, colorless, multiguttulate, sterigmata stout, 5-8 microns long; cystidia 8 microns in diameter, subcylindric, thin-walled; paraphyses 3-4 microns wide, filiform, septate, guttulate; septa 180-240 microns thick, colorless, composed of a pseudoparenchyma of large, subspherical to polyhedral cells; peridium "composed of loosely woven, large, septate hyphae with swollen cells", soon disappearing; rhizomorphs composed of septate hyphae with prominent clamp connections, (Dodge), spores 15-21 x 9-11 microns, (Smith), spores 16-22 x 9-12(13) microns, elliptic, "with pronounced longitudinal ridges not fully continuous to the base and somewhat warted in the midsection", the base pedicellate; basidia 4-spored, 25-40 x 8-10 microns, "interspersed with cystidial elements similar in dimensions but with subcylindric rather than clavate apices", (States)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'like Gautieria', originating before it was in this genus (Hymenogaster gautierioides Lloyd)
SIMILAR  About 15 other Gautieria species in the Pacific Northwest are due to be described by States and Fogel (Trappe(13)).
SOURCES  Dodge(2) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), States(2) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
56
FAMILY  Gomphaceae, Order Gomphales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Gautieria 'magnicellaris'  (Pilat) E.L. Stewart & Trappe^  in Cazares et al. Mycologia 84(3): 349. 1992
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a somewhat spherical or irregularly lobed fruitbody with an inconspicuous to absent peridium, the exposed lobules ochraceous to brown, and locules up to 0.2cm across, 2) a branched, grayish white columella, 3) underground growth associated with pine or White Fir, and 4) microscopic characters including large measuring spores 21-29 x 12-15.5 microns with 10-13 longitudinal to slightly spiraling ridges, on 4-spored basidia.^ This species is not treated in Trappe(13), possibly because the name may be misapplied. RANGE It is known from OR, CA, MI, NY, Mexico, and Europe (Castellano(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  "KOH on spore mass red-brown, quickly fading, trama no reaction; FeSO4 on spore mass green-gray, gray-yellow-green"^, (Castellano)
OUTER SURFACE  1.5-2.5cm x 1.6cm, somewhat spherical or irregularly lobed; peridium lacking, the exposed locules ochraceous to brown^, (Cazares), 1.1-2.4cm x 0.9-2.7cm (dried), spherical, somewhat spherical, irregularly lobed, flattened or depressed at the point of attachment, locules large and fully exposed; peridium "drying brown from the exposed spore mass", exposed tramal tissue "mostly drying thin and obscured by spores", where visible pale yellow to red-brown, (Castellano)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  brown, with a branched grayish white columella and locules up to 0.2cm across^, (Cazares), spore mass drying brown to red-brown, trama tissue drying pale yellow and red-brown; locules 0.05-1cm x 0.05-0.6cm, labyrinthiform to rounded, some continuous through the entire fruitbody, empty, (Castellano)
STEM  branched grayish white columella^, (Cazares), columella when mature "not prominent, white, drying pale orange-yellow", (Castellano)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under the soil surface associated with roots of Pinus spp. (pine) in Mexico and Abies concolor (White Fir) in western North America above 1650m elevation, July through October^, (Castellano), single to gregarious, underground under Pinus (pine) in a coniferous forest and under Quercus (oak) in a mixed Quercus-Pinus forest, (Cazares)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 21-29 x 12-15.5 microns "including sterigmal appendage and an epispore 1-2 microns thick of 10-13 longitudinal to slightly spiraling ridges", yellow-brown, sterigmal appendage 2-4 microns in diameter^; basidia 35-50 x 12 microns, clavate, colorless to pale olive, thin-walled, brachybasidioles 20-40 x 6-16 microns, cylindric; subhymenium cellular; trama plus hymenium 200-395 microns in diameter, the trama of hyphae 4-7 microns wide that are thin-walled, colorless to pale olive, and interwoven, (Cazares), spores 17-24 x 12-15(18) microns including sterigmal appendage and epispore, 17-24 x 8-12 microns excluding epispore, elliptic to broadly elliptic, "ornamentation of 9-13 forking and anastomosing, longitudinal to occasionally spiraling ridges", (1)2-3.5(4) microns tall, 3-5 microns broad, "in KOH pale green-yellow singly, yellow in mass, slowly cyanophilic", "sterigmal appendage 2-3 microns at base of epispore, 1-3 microns long", wall +/- 1.5 microns thick; basidia "4-spored, 40-60 x 11-16 microns, thin-walled, broadly clavate, sterigmata 2-2.5 x 2-2.5 microns", brachybasidioles 15-33 x 7-9 microns; cystidioid elements infrequent; subhymenium "a palisade of subpolygonal cells 9-32 x 7-13 microns, thin-walled, merging into intertwined hyphae of the trama", trama of hyphae 2-7 microns wide, colorless, thin-walled, septate, weakly gelatinized when old, oleiferous hyphae "rare, detectable in Melzer's reagent"; columella of colorless hyphae inflated up to 10 microns, with spines +/- 1 micron "projecting from the inner wall toward the interior"; peridium "(margins of exposed locules) of tiers of napiform cells 7-30 x 10-25 microns"; clamp connections absent, (Castellano)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'large celled', perhaps referring to the large spores
SIMILAR  About 15 other Gautieria species in the Pacific Northwest are due to be described by States and Fogel (Trappe(13)).
SOURCES  Cazares(2), Castellano(1)*, Trappe(13)
57
FAMILY  Gomphaceae, Order Gomphales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Gautieria monticola  (Harkn.) Harkn.^  Cal. Acad. Sci. Bull. 1: 30. 1884;  Hymenogaster monticolus  Harkn.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) an irregularly lobed, brown fruitbody with a thin outer layer that soon wears away to expose the cavities of the firm, rubbery, ochraceous-tawny to grayish brown spore mass, 2) often a mycelial cord at base, 3) a distinct, slender, branching columella, 4) a strong odor when old, 5) a location underground or on the ground under mountain conifers, and 6) microscopic characters including spores measuring 10-15 x 6-9 microns with 7-10 longitudinal or oblique ridges, and basidia that are mostly 2-spored.^ It is abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest. RANGE Distribution in the Pacific Northwest is from BC to northern CA (Trappe(13)). It is common in the mountains of the western United States (Trappe, M.(3)). It has been reported to Oregon Truffling Society for BC and OR, and by J. Smith et al. from OR. Paul Kroeger deposited a collection from BC at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  (1)2-9cm across, "round to elongated or irregularly knobby (potato-like)"; pallid when very young, soon becoming light brown to ocher to rusty brown or dull brown; peridium "very thin, soon wearing away to expose the spore-bearing cavities"^, (Arora), 10cm across and about 3cm high, irregularly lobed, nearly flat above and below; "Dresden brown" to "mummy-brown"; peridium (or rather the outer part of the gleba) 0.014-0.016cm thick, (Dodge)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  spore mass when fresh firm, rubbery, crisp, not fragile; ocher brown to rusty brown to dull cinnamon to dull brown at maturity; composed of numerous irregularly shaped cavities, 0.05-0.3cm^, (Arora), "ochraceous-tawny" to grayish brown; cavities small, empty, (Dodge), firm, rubbery; cinnamon-colored "with cartilaginous veins and an inconspicuous to distinct white to translucent columella", (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  often with a mycelial cord at base; "distinct columella usually present and often penetrating to the centre of the spore mass", thin, often branched; whitish or translucent^, (Arora), sterile base not prominent, columella very slender, branching, (Dodge)
ODOR  often strong when old, sometimes of decaying onions^, (Arora), very strong when old, like sour milk, (Miller), sweet-oily, may become nauseating, (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  mild^ (Miller)
EDIBILITY  edible according to some, but rubbery, (Arora)
HABITAT  single, scattered or in groups or clusters, sometimes partially exposed at maturity, in duff under conifers, especially mountain conifers, late spring through early fall^, (Arora), on the ground under conifers (Dodge), associated with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Pinus (pine), Abies (fir); March to November (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-15 x 6-9 microns, elliptic, longitudinally grooved, rusty-brown to ocher-brown under the microscope^, (Arora), spores 9-13 x 6.5-8 microns, elliptic to oboval, "with 7-10 longitudinal or oblique striations, sometimes slightly warted", "ochraceous-tawny", with one to several droplets; basidia mostly 2-spored, "arising from erect, septate hyphae 16 x 6-7 microns, ovoid", sterigmata "filiform, 7-10 microns long"; septa 120-400 microns thick, colorless, "composed of more or less gelified hyphae parallel with the hymenial surface"; "peridium or rather the outer portion of the gleba 140-160 microns thick, composed of hyphae with greatly gelified walls enclosing dirt in the outer portion", (Dodge), spores 10-16 x 7-9 microns, elongate lemon-shaped with longitudinal ridges (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'living in mountains'
SIMILAR  About 15 other Gautieria species in the Pacific Northwest are due to be described by States and Fogel, including Gautieria angustispora States & Fogel nom. prov. (Trappe(13)). Gautieria angustispora nom. prov. is a common member of the G. monticola complex in Idaho and Montana but less so in Oregon and Washington where G. monticola does indeed predominate (J. States, pers. comm. on http://www.fungaljungal.org/truffle.htm).
SOURCES  Dodge(2) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Smith(4), Arora(1)*, Miller(14)*, Smith, J.E.(1), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)*, Desjardin(6)*
58
FAMILY  Gomphaceae, Order Gomphales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Gautieria 'morchelliformis'  Vittad.^  Monogr. Tuberac. 26. 1831;  Gautieria morillaeformis  Quel.;  Gautieria villosa  Quel.
ENGLISH NAMES  plated puffball
NOTES  features include somewhat spherical to oblong fruiting body with thin outer covering that soon disappears, spore mass of short radiating plates that is white at first but soon becomes ocher-tawny, rhizomorphs at base, strong odor, underground growth with hardwoods, and microscopic characters including spores 12-24 x 8-12.5 microns with 8-10 longitudinal ridges, basidia 2-3-spored^; It is not included in Trappe(13) possibly because the name is misapplied; collections examined by Dodge(2) from OR, CA, NY, Austria, Czechoslovakia, France, Italy, and Switzerland, Lincoff(2) gives range as NY to OH, also West Coast; found in United Kingdom (Hawker(1))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-5cm across, "roundish to oblong; with thin outer covering soon disappearing"^, (Lincoff(2)), 1-3cm across, spherical to oblong; peridium thin in early stages, soon disappearing, (Dodge)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  spore mass of short radiating plates, white, becoming ocher-tawny to rust-brown; "an arrangement of labyrinthine plates and broad cavities radiating from base"^, (Lincoff(2)), "ochraceous-tawny" to "hazel", cavities 0.1-0.6cm across, somewhat spherical to irregular, mostly radiating from the base, septa white when broken, (Dodge), ochreous rust-colored, consisting of broad cells 0.15-0.8cm x 0.1-0.4cm, "powdery because of the spores", (Lincoff(1))
STEM  "composed of branching, rooting strands (rhizomorphs)"^, (Lincoff(2)), with basal stem-like, usually much branched rhizomorph; columella "rudimentary, merely a subspherical summit of the rhizomorph, from which rather thick septal plates radiate into the gleba", (Dodge)
ODOR  often strong (Lincoff(2)), strongly fetid when fresh (Zeller(2) for an Oregon collection), very strong odor of bouillon cubes, (Lincoff(1))
TASTE  sweetish flavor^ (Lincoff(1))
EDIBILITY  eaten in Europe but not recommended because little known about edibility of similar species or of this one in North America (Lincoff(1))
HABITAT  in clay soil under hardwood trees and shrubs, often in oak woods, develops underground and often emerges at maturity^, (Lincoff(2)), in clay soil, under hardwood trees and shrubs, spring, summer, and fall, (Dodge)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-24 x 8-12.5 microns, with 8-10 rather sinuous striae, with one or two droplets, pedicellate^; basidia 2-3-spored, about as large as the spores, colorless, granular, sterigmata "filiform, as long as the spores"; cystidia in the upper cavities, not prominent; paraphyses clavate, septate, colorless; septa about 75 microns thick, white when broken, stupose, (Dodge), spores 12-24 x 8-12.5 microns, spindle-shaped, longitudinally lined, ocher, (Lincoff(2)), spores 12-24 x 8-12 microns, broadly elliptic, with 8-10 lengthwise ribs, rust-colored, (Lincoff(1))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'morel-shaped'
SIMILAR  about 15 other Gautieria species in the Pacific Northwest are due to be described by States and Fogel (Trappe(13)). See also SIMILAR section of Protogautieria lutea.
SOURCES  Dodge(2) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Smith(4), Lincoff(1)* (as G. morchellaeformis), Lincoff(2)*, Zeller(2), Hawker(1), Trappe(13)
59
FAMILY  Gomphaceae, Order Gomphales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Gautieria otthii  Trog^  Naturforsch. Ges. Bern Mitt. 1857: 43. 1857 (in Nos. 388-390);  Gautieria graveolens  Vittad.  var. otthii  (Trog) Zeller & C.W. Dodge
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to somewhat spherical, flat or depressed fruitbody that is white with red tones but becoming brown to yellow-brown, spore mass pale brown to yellow brown with maze-like cavities generally radiating away from small stem, branching columella, underground growth associated with conifer roots, and microscopic characters including spores 13-18 x 7-10 microns with about 9-12 ridges and 4-spored basidia with short sterigmata^; found at least OR, CA, Switzerland, (Castellano), Trappe(13) mentions a var. odora nom. prov. States and Fogel as infrequent from BC to ID and northern CA
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH immediately a faint dark red-orange on peridium; FeSO4 pale green on peridium; Melzer's reagent, quickly red-brown on peridium, soon fading^, (Castellano)
OUTER SURFACE  up to 5cm across, spherical to somewhat spherical, flat or depressed; "white with red tones, but emergent apical surfaces becoming brown" with patches of ocher to yellow^, (Castellano), depressed-spherical, up to 3cm across when fresh, drying 1cm x 2cm, "cinnamon" to "Sayal brown" or "tawny-olive" when dry; peridium not seen, (Dodge)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  pale brown to yellow brown; locules up to 0.05-0.2cm, labyrinthiform, generally radiating away from the stem, empty^, (Castellano), "cinnamon" to "Sayal brown"; cavities labyrinthiform, empty, minute, (Dodge)
STEM  columella up to 0.2cm wide, cartilaginous, gray-white drying red-brown, branching near base^, (Castellano), stem 0.2cm in diameter, broken off short in specimen available; columella unbranched, reaching at least one-third the height of the fruitbody, (Dodge)
ODOR  weak, unpleasant^, (Dodge)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  associated with roots of Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine) and other Pinaceae between 800m and 1650m^, (Castellano), fruiting in June in Switzerland, (Dodge)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores "13-18 x 7-10 microns including sterigmal appendage and epispore, 13-18 x 5-7 microns excluding epispore", elliptic, "often somewhat flattened at the apex", ornamentation of 9-12, sometimes forking, longitudinal ridges, 0.5-1.5(2) microns tall, 2-3 microns broad, "ridge margins humped to cleft, grooves between ridges smooth to finely crenulate", in Melzer's reagent spores "red-orange singly, dark red-orange in mass", in KOH "pale green-yellow singly, yellow in mass", slowly cyanophilic, wall +/-1 microns thick, "sterigmal appendage truncate, prominent, 1-2 microns wide"^; basidia 4-spored, (12)18-30(45) x 6-9 microns, clavate, thin-walled; subhymenium "of subpolygonal cells 10-30 x 5-13 microns, progressively smaller as the subhymenium merges into the linear hyphae composing the trama"; trama narrow, of hyphae 3-5 microns wide, colorless, thin-walled, gelatinizing when old, oleiferous hyphae present; columella of hyphae 1-5 microns wide, colorless, inflated to 18 microns wide adjacent to septa, inflated areas filled with granules and spines +/-1 micron long, "projecting from the inner wall surface toward the interior"; peridium 65-150 microns thick, "of thick-walled, napiform cells" 17-40 microns in diameter, (Castellano), spores 12-16 x 6-8 microns, apex rounded, with about 10 smooth striations, "ochraceous-tawny", short pedicellate; basidia 4-spored, 10-14 x 6-8 microns, clavate, sterigmata short; septa 90-180 microns thick, "composed of slender highly gelified hyphae"; peridium not seen, (Dodge)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  about 15 other Gautieria species in the Pacific Northwest are due to be described by States and Fogel (Trappe(13))
SOURCES  Dodge(2) (as G. graveolens var. otthii, colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Castellano(1), Trappe(13)
60
FAMILY  Gomphaceae, Order Gomphales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Gautieria parksiana  Zeller & C.W. Dodge^  Mycologia 14(4): 196. 1922
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include a somewhat spherical to irregular fruitbody with an ochraceous to pale fulvous surface, white rhizomorphs, a thick (for Gautieria) persistent peridium, a pinkish brown spore mass, a branched columella, underground growth, and microscopic characters including spores measuring 14-24 x 8-12 microns with 9-11 longitudinal ridges, and basidia that are usually 2-spored.^ It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Collections were examined from OR and CA, (Dodge). It has been found from southern WA to southern CA, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.9-3.5cm across, ochraceous to pale fulvous at first, rhizomorphs white; peridium thick, persistent^, (Smith), yellow-orange to ocher, (Arora), 1-5cm across, somewhat spherical to irregular, some specimens drying light "ochraceous-buff" to "ochraceous-tawny", others drying "buckthorn-brown" to "mummy brown"; peridium persistent, 0.024-0.042cm thick, (Zeller), irregularly spherical, peridium persistent; white to brown; cottony, (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  chambers 0.1-0.25cm wide, (Smith), cavities 3-4 per mm, empty, spherical to irregular; spore mass drying "ochraceous-tawny" to "Dresden-brown", (Zeller), pinkish brown, drying ochraceous-tawny to Dresden brown, (Dodge), firm, rubbery; cinnamon-colored, with an obscure to prominent columella; base with a robust rhizomorph, (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  columella branched; rhizomorphs 0.1-0.2cm wide, white, usually branching from a distinct radicle [root-like structure]^ (Zeller)
ODOR  oily to fishy^, (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under hardwoods and conifers, April to June, (Smith), gregarious in soil under Heteromeles (Christmas berry), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), and Quercus (oak), March to June, (Dodge), with Pseudotsuga, Pinus (pine), Tsuga (hemlock), Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), Quercus; year round (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (12)14-17(18) x 8-11 microns^, (Smith), spores 14-19 x 7-11 microns, ovate to citriform [lemon-shaped], with 9-11 (usually 10) rounded longitudinal ribs giving the appearance of striations, pale olivaceous under the microscope, "buckthorn-brown" in mass; basidia usually 2-spored, 28-38 x 7-10 microns, clavate, arising from the trama obliquely, colorless; septa 65-100 microns thick, colorless, "of interwoven hyphae generally extending longitudinally"; "peridium 240-420 microns thick, stupose, of very fine hyphae", (Zeller), spores oval-elliptic, (Dodge), spores 14-24 x 9.5-12 microns, narrowly elliptic, longitudinally ridged, (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  named after H.E. Parks of the University of California
SIMILAR  About 15 other Gautieria species in the Pacific Northwest are due to be described by States and Fogel (Trappe(13)).
SOURCES  Zeller(2) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Dodge(2), Smith(4), Arora(1), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)
61
FAMILY  Gomphaceae, Order Gomphales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Gautieria plumbea  Zeller & C.W. Dodge^  Ann. Mo. Bot. Gard. 5: 138-139. 1918
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include convoluted fruitbody with brownish olive to blackish brown surface, the peridium lacking or disappearing early, slate-colored spore mass with irregular cavities mostly radiating from the branching, percurrent, columella, stem 0.2cm thick, and microscopic characters including spores 11-16 x 6.5-8 microns that develop 7-10 wavy striae, basidia 1-4-spored^; collections examined from BC, ID, (Dodge), rare, BC to ID and northern CA (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  4cm across, cordate [heart-shaped], surface convoluted, "light brownish olive" to "mummy brown"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "plumbeous-black", "slate color" in preservative, drying "fuscous-black", gelified; "cavities irregular, mostly radiating from the columella, empty"
STEM  stem 0.2cm thick; columella "branched, percurrent, gelified"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under conifers
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 11-16 x 6.5-8 microns, young spores oval to elliptic, smooth, becoming striate with 7-10 wavy striae, spores "English red" to "burnt sienna", short-pedicellate^; basidia 1-4-spored, 20-26 x 9-10 microns, clavate, colorless, sterigmata less than half the length of the spores; cystidia 52-61 x 25-35 microns, obovoid, colorless, guttulate, often somewhat apiculate; paraphyses 4-5 microns wide, narrowly clavate, colorless, guttulate, septate, some knobbed at tip, some filiform; subhymenial layer "pseudoparenchymatous, of large angular cells"; septa about 300 microns thick, composed of highly gelified, colorless hyphae
NAME ORIGIN  probably after the color of the gleba which is "plumbeous-black"
SIMILAR  about 15 other Gautieria species in the Pacific Northwest are due to be described by States and Fogel (Trappe(13))
SOURCES  Dodge(2) (colors in double quotes from Ridgway), Trappe(13)
62
FAMILY  Gomphaceae, Order Gomphales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Gautieria pterosperma  States, Trappe, and E.L. Stewart nom. prov.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a cinnamon, nearly spherical to cushion-shaped, irregularly folded and lobed fruitbody, 2) absence of a peridium, 3) a whitish, rubbery columella, 4) a basal rhizomorph, and 5) microscopic characters including spores with tall longitudinal ridges.^ This is a provisional species from the unpublished Ph. D. thesis of E. L. Stewart, OSU. 1974. The description is derived from Trappe, M.(3) except where noted. It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It has been found from western OR to CA (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  can be up to golfball-sized or larger, nearly spherical to cushion-shaped, irregularly folded and lobed, lacking peridium; cinnamon-colored
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  somewhat friable but with a whitish, rubbery columella, (Trappe, M.(3)), yellowish to bright yellow brown or ocher (Arora)
STEM  cord-like rhizomorph protrudes from a basal depression
ODOR  mildly fruity or sweet-nutty
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  associated with Pinus (pine), Abies (fir), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock); April to September
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-15 x 8-14 microns, elliptic to nearly round, with tall, longitudinal ridges ("wings") in KOH
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with winged spores'
SIMILAR  About 15 other Gautieria species in the Pacific Northwest are due to be described by States and Fogel (Trappe(13)).
SOURCES  Arora(1), MykoWeb(1), Trappe(13), Trappe, M.(3)*
63
FAMILY  Geastraceae, Order Geastrales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Geastrum bushnellii  (L.S. Dominguez & Castellano) Jeppson & E. Larss.^  in Jeppson, Larsson & Nilsson, Syst. Biodiv. 11(4): 445. 2013;  Radiigera bushnellii  L.S. Dominguez & Castellano  Mycologia 88(5)  873. 1996
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to nearly spherical fruitbodies that are yellowish white and felty to cottony, with adhering debris, spore mass almost black when mature, at first containing irregularly shaped chambers, spherical yellow-white columella with chambers radiating from it, growth underground, and microscopic characters including round, verrucose, brown spores, 6-8-spored basidia, and poorly developed or absent capillitial threads^; description derived from Dominguez(1) except where noted; rare, Tillamook and Yamhill Counties in OR, (Trappe(13)); collections examined from OR, (Dominguez)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  up to 2cm across, spherical to nearly spherical; yellowish white, felty to cottony, laden with debris; peridium three-layered, up to 0.25cm thick, the outermost an easily removed mycelial layer about 0.02-0.05cm thick
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  almost black at maturity, at first containing irregularly shaped chambers, some tramal hyphae persisting as white scales immersed in dark powdery mass; columella spherical with glebal chambers radiating from it, yellow-white
STEM  columella spherical
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground, under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Asarum caudatum (wild ginger), at about 120m elevation, May and August, (Dominguez), probably saprophytic (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT
