MICROSCOPIC  spores 4-5(6) microns, round, verrucose, ornamentation up to 0.5 microns tall, spores brown, wall 1 micron thick, apiculus sometimes inconspicuous^; basidia 6-8-spored, 12-15 x 5-8 microns, lecythiform, "constricted below the apex, apex rounded, clamped at base, with an acuminate apex when young", sterigmata 1 micron long; tramal hyphae 1.5-3 microns wide, clamped; capillitium absent or poorly developed (meaning that "few threads can be found within the gleba and, when found, they are thin-walled, not pigmented and short"), up to 3 microns wide, not abundant, thin-walled with broad lumen, light yellow brown, ribbon-like; columella of hyphae 1.5-3 microns wide, wavy, tapering, colorless, aseptate, thin-walled, nonclamped; peridium up to 2500 microns thick, with three layers 1) the outermost mycelial layer 200-500 microns thick, of hyphae 1.5-2 microns wide, colorless, aseptate, unbranched, 2) a fibrous layer 80-105 microns thick, of hyphae 1.5-3 microns wide, aseptate, unbranched, reacting positively with cotton blue in lactic acid, (a layer of clamped, thin-walled hyphae appears between fibrous and mycelial layers but collapses at maturity), 3) a pseudoparenchymatous layer up to 2000 microns thick, of large, thin-walled, colorless, inflated cells up to 50 microns in diameter
NAME ORIGIN  after W. Bushnell, member of the North American Truffling Society and collector of the type
SIMILAR  Geastrum fuscogleba is larger, with abundant capillitial threads, (Dominguez). Geastrum taylorii has mycelial layer of thick-walled, hyphae arranged perpendicularly to surface, and spores are smaller, (Dominguez). Compare also with Schenella spp.
SOURCES  Dominguez(1) (as Radiigera), Trappe(13) (as Radiigera)
64
FAMILY  Geastraceae, Order Geastrales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Geastrum fuscogleba  (Zeller) Jeppson & E. Larss.^  in Jeppson, Larsson & Nilsson, Syst. Biodiv. 11(4): 445. 2013;  Radiigera fuscogleba  Zeller  Mycologia 36: 633. 1944.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to nearly spherical, smooth fruitbody that is whitish to yellow brown, 2) a spore mass that is whitish becoming yellow brown, with strands oriented in a maze-like manner, and radiating from a columella that is club-shaped to nearly spherical, 3) habitat underground or above ground in duff under a variety of trees, and 4) microscopic characters including round, brown, verrucose spores, lecythiform to lageniform 6-8-spored basidia, and abundant capillitial threads.^ It is common among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Geastrum fuscogleba is found from WA south to Mexico and east to ID and CO, (Trappe(13)). Collections were examined from WA, OR, ID, CA, CO, UT, and Mexico, (Dominguez).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-5cm across, spherical to nearly spherical; light yellow brown; surface sometimes laden with debris; peridium waxy when sectioned after drying, to 0.24cm thick, more or less firm^, (Dominguez), 4-8cm across, white to "old gold" or "isabella color", sometimes with purplish tints, drying "wood brown" or lighter; "smooth but sometimes with innate reticulate fibrils"; peridium of three layers, not readily separating from each other but separating from spore mass on drying, (Zeller), peridium (outer layer) thick, crisp; brown; surface felty, (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  medium yellow brown to dark yellow brown when mature, "glebal strands radiating from columella that are oriented in a more or less labyrinthiform manner and colored dirty white when young"^, (Dominguez), white throughout at first, drying olive brown, (Zeller), "with a capitate columella from which fibers radiate out to connect with the peridium"; white throughout at first, the spores borne along the radiating fibers in mass, when mature making that part of the spore mass black and powdery, (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  columella when immature club-shaped, whitish, up to 0.18cm tall^, (Dominguez), "with a distinct, slightly projecting basal attachment"; "sterile base broadly conic in vertical section", crowned by a nearly spherical columella that is "soft, pithy toward the center and more cottony further out", 0.5-0.8cm in diameter, (Zeller)
ODOR  metallic-pungent or mildewy^, (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground under Abies concolor (White Fir), Acer macrophyllum (Bigleaf Maple), Alnus sp. (alder), Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone), Arctostaphylos spp., Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-cedar), Corylus californica (California Hazel), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Quercus agrifolia (California Live Oak), at 70-1640m elevation, March through October, (Dominguez), fruits year-round (Trappe, M.(3)), underground or above ground in duff of coniferous forest, (Zeller), probably saprophytic (Trappe(13))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 4.5-7(8) microns, round, verrucose, verrucae to 0.5 microns tall, spores brown^; basidia 6-8-spored, 11 x 7 microns, lecythiform to lageniform, colorless, clamped, sterigmata short (1 micron); glebal strands radiating from columella and "oriented in a more or less labyrinthiform manner", composed of hyphae 1.5-2 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, aseptate, positive reaction with cotton blue in lactic acid; capillitium 5(7) microns wide, debris laden, brown, thick-walled (1-2 microns), tapering, with rounded apices, attached to peridium and columella when immature, remnants of tramal plates persisting between capillitial threads; peridium up to 2400 microns thick, multi-layered, 1) outer mycelial layer 30-400 microns thick, composed of hyphae 3-5 microns wide, septate, colorless, clamped, thin-walled, negative reaction with cotton blue in lactic acid, intermingled with some conductive hyphae that have cytoplasm with positive reaction to cotton blue in lactic acid, when immature the outer stratum of mycelial layer tends to be pseudoparenchymatous and the inner stratum of the mycelial layer tends to be plectenchymatous, the whole layer collapsing when mature (and flaking off in thin scales when scratched), the mycelial layer sometimes covered on the outside by a layer of "evanescent, hyaline, nonseptate, hyphae (hyphal layer) to 3 microns diam", 2) fibrous layer 100-375(600) microns thick, composed of hyphae 2-5 microns wide, compact, periclinal, sometimes wavy to straight, almost parallel, septate, walls up to 2.5 microns thick, 3) pseudoparenchymal layer up to 2200 microns thick, of thin-walled, colorless, inflated cells, up to 50 microns in diameter, 4) endoperidium "not always present or obscure", 12-20(45) microns thick, composed of "light brown, thin-walled hyphae, intermingled with hyaline, clamped, thin-walled, 3-5 microns diam. hyphae" (the clamped hyphae can be absent), (Dominguez), spores 4.7-5.2 microns, round, alveolate-echinulate, "echinulae somewhat truncate, often connivent at their apices", spores dark; basidia 4-spored to many-spored, broadly pyriform, with short sterigmata; gleba "composed of radiating fascicles of hyphae and capillitium arranged to simulate tubes", fascicles attached to the columella and inner wall of peridium; fascicular hyphae small, almost colorless, with short branches, all basidia-bearing; capillitium 2.7-3.2 microns wide, unbranched, flexuous [wavy], dark, "walls uneven, sometimes almost moniliform"; peridium of 3 layers, the outer very thin, filamentous, the middle about 1000 microns thick (drying to papery thinness), of light-colored, large-celled parenchyma, the inner layer about 2000 microns thick, somewhat gelatinous, drying to thin, flinty hardness, inner surface of this layer a very thin filamentous layer of hyphae very similar to capillitium, (Zeller)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with fuscous spore mass'
SIMILAR  Geastrum bushnellii has no capillitial threads or they are poorly developed, (Dominguez). Geastrum taylorii has a mycelial layer of thick-walled hyphae arranged perpendicularly to the surface, and spores are smaller, (Dominguez). See also SIMILAR section of Schenella simplex.
SOURCES  Dominguez(1) (as Radiigera), Zeller(5) (as Radiigera, colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Trappe, M.(1)* (as Radiigera), Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)* (as Radiigera)
65
FAMILY  Geastraceae, Order Geastrales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Geastrum taylorii  (Lloyd) Jeppson & E. Larss.^  in Jeppson, Larsson & Nilsson, Syst. Biodiv. 11(4): 445. 2013;  Radiigera taylorii  (Lloyd) Zeller  Mycologia 36: 636. 1944
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to nearly spherical fruitbody that is smooth and light yellow brown, the tough outer skin up to 0.35cm with a tendency to separate between layers when dried, 2) a spore mass that is white to pale orange yellow becoming dark yellow-brown to dark gray-brown, 3) a well developed columella that is spherical to elongate or capitate, from which radiate maze-like locules, 4) basal rhizomorphs or basal scar present in some specimens, 5) underground growth under conifers, 6) small round spores, 7) lecythiform to lageniform 6-8-spored basidia, and 8) the outer mycelial layer of the peridium composed of thick-walled hyphae arranged perpendicularly to the surface.^ It is common among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It is found from southwestern WA to northern CA, NM, (Trappe(13)). Collections were examined from WA, OR, CA, and NM, (Dominguez).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH gives yellow reaction on surface and also in cross-section, Melzer's reagent negative, FeSO4 pale green^, (Dominguez) 
OUTER SURFACE  (1.5)3-4cm across, spherical to nearly spherical; light yellow brown, smooth, without debris; peridium up to 0.35cm thick, tough, with a tendency to separate between layers when dried^, (Dominguez), 2-3cm across, nearly spherical; drying dull drab or lighter; even, smooth, or slightly velvety; peridium of two closely attached layers that become easily separable when dry, the outer "egg-shell thin when dry, cartilaginous", the inner white, gelatinous, about 0.3-0.4cm thick when fresh, "drying very thin and light buff", (Zeller)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  spore mass white to pale orange yellow when immature, dark yellow-brown to dark gray-brown when mature, with well developed columella that is spherical to elongate or capitate, up to 0.18cm high, "from which radiate densely crowded, labyrinthiform locules"^, (Dominguez), buffy-brown, (Zeller)
STEM  some specimens with well developed basal rhizomorphs or basal scar^, (Dominguez), with a distinct basal rooting scar; sterile base white, pulvinate [cushion-shaped] in vertical section, crowned by a nearly spherical, "white, cottony-soft columella, sometimes detached from the base as a free core", sometimes almost disappearing, (Zeller)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground under Abies concolor (White Fir), Alnus sinuata (Sitka Alder), Pinus spp. (pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Quercus spp. (oak), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock), and Umbellularia californica (California Bay Laurel) at 190-1870m elevation, from April to January, most often August through October^, (Dominguez), underground under loose leaf mould of redwood, (Zeller), probably saprophytic (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 3-4 microns, round, verrucose, verrucae to 0.5 microns tall, spores brown, with conspicuous basal scar, apiculus almost flat, slightly prominent^, (Dominguez); basidia 6-8-spored, 20-24 x 5-10 microns, lecythiform to lageniform with a rounded apex, clamped at base, sterigmata short, 1 micron; trama hyphae 1.5-2 microns wide, remnants "of amorphous tramal material and cell wall fragments forming white, crystal-like structures present at columella and gleba"; capillitium in tufts, 4 microns wide, pale brown, aseptate, "tapering and with rounded apices, rarely branched, lumen absent to narrow, surface coarse from randomly attached glebal remnants, not smooth, threads attached at the inner peridial layer and to the rounded columella"; columella of hyphae up to 2.5 microns wide, entangled, cottony, colorless, with tapered to rounded apices, positive reaction with cotton blue in lactic acid, in immature stages clamp connections present, but absent when mature; peridium multi-layered, up to 3500 microns, 1) outermost mycelial layer 250-550 microns thick, of two strata, the outer of hyphae 5-7 microns wide (to 12 microns according to Askew & Miller (1977)), interwoven, compact, thick-walled, with rounded apices, unequal in length but anticlinally arranged, sometimes debris laden over the layer surface, the inner stratum of the mycelial layer of hyphae 2-2.5 microns wide, compactly interwoven, unbranched, negative reaction with cotton blue in lactic acid, an additional amorphous layer between the mycelial layer and the fibrous layer underneath, also negative reaction with cotton blue in lactic acid, collapses at maturity, and there are sometimes, most often in young specimens, hyphae up to 1.5 microns wide, that cover the outside peridial surface, 2) fibrous layer 70-150 microns thick, of hyphae 1.5-3 microns, periclinal, compact, pale-colored, aseptate, rarely branched, positive reaction with cotton blue in lactic acid, 3) pseudoparenchymatous layer 1900-3000 microns thick, of thin-walled, colorless, inflated cells up to 50 microns in diameter, smaller near the fibrous layer, 4) endoperidium "not always present, poorly developed, of pale, thin-walled, capillitial-like hyphae" intermingled with colorless, clamped, thin-walled hyphae, (Dominguez), spores 2.5-3.75 microns, round, slightly verrucose, slightly straw-colored to very light brown in mass; basidia up to 11-spored or 12-spored, "borne in groups along the radiating hyphae", pyriform [pear-shaped]; "capillitium in fascicles of long, parallel, non-branched filaments", fascicles extending radially from columella to inner layer of peridium, composed of capillitial filaments and hyphae bearing the basidia, capillitial filaments colorless to slightly straw-colored, some large, up to 4 microns wide, usual ones smaller, 2-2.5 microns wide, (Zeller)
NAME ORIGIN  after C. Wilder Taylor who collected the type
SIMILAR  Geastrum fuscogleba and Geastrum bushnellii have larger spores, and their mycelial layer does not have thick-walled hyphae arranged perpendicularly to the surface, (Dominguez). See also SIMILAR section of Schenella simplex.
SOURCES  Dominguez(1) (as Radiigera), Zeller(5) (as Radiigera), Trappe(13) (as Radiigera)
66
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Genabea cerebriformis  (Harkn.) Trappe^  Mycotaxon 2(1): 118. 1975;  == Genea cerebriformis  (Harkn.) Gilkey;  == Myrmecocystis cerebriformis  Harkn.;  = Myrmecocystis candida  Harkn.
ENGLISH NAMES  white geode truffle
NOTES  Features include 1) a small, creamy whitish (pale grayish yellow to light tan), spherical to convoluted, warty fruitbody with an interior labyrinthine cavity that is less warty, 2) growth underground under trees especially Douglas-fir, and 3) microscopic characters including large round ascospores which are covered with long slender spines when mature that often adhere at their tips.^ It is common among truffles in the Pacific Northwest, (Trappe(13)). RANGE It is found from western WA and OR to southern CA, (Trappe(13)), and also in Mexico (Castellano(4)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.4-1.5(2.5)cm across, but usually under 1cm, often roundish when small, usually quite irregular when larger (knobby, lobed, or brain-like) and with several openings to the interior; white to yellowish white or yellow-gray; covered by small, more or less conic warts superimposed on each knob^, (Arora), 0.5-2cm across, creamy white, convoluted, with several openings to interior, surface warted, (Smith), 0.5-2cm across, "conspicuously convolute with generally several openings"; creamy-white; verrucose, (Gilkey), pale grayish yellow to light tan, (Smith, M.E.), rarely more than 1cm across; fragile, brittle, (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "often a single cavity in small specimens", but in larger ones usually consisting of a maze-like system of canals "formed by infolding and inward projections of the wall; colored more or less like exterior"^, (Arora), "with infoldings and projections of the walls forming labyrinthine canals", (Smith), cavity "by infoldings of and projections from the walls, becoming a system of labyrinthine canals"; less verrucose than outer surface, (Gilkey)
STEM  none
ODOR  mild or strong^, (Arora), pleasant, faintly garlicky, (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  unknown (Arora)
HABITAT  underground, single to gregarious in soil or humus in woods and under trees, especially Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir)^, (Arora), deciduous and coniferous woods, especially under Douglas fir, spring, (Smith), leaf mold, in hardwood woods or coniferous woods, (Gilkey), fruits only in spring in the western United States and summer in Mexico, (Castellano), with Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga, and Quercus (oak); March to October (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 28-44 x 28-44 microns, round, smooth at first but covered with long slender spines when mature; colorless to grayish yellow (when old)^; asci arranged in a palisade, typically 8-spored, (Arora), spores colorless at first becoming smoky yellow and ornamented with long soft spines that often adhere at their tips when mature, asci 8-spored, cylindric to +/- clavate, (Smith), spores 28-44 x 28-44 microns, round, smooth and colorless when young, becoming smoky yellow when mature "and densely covered by long, soft spines, these often coalescing in groups, making the spore surface appear irregularly rugose" [wrinkled], 1-seriate or incompletely 2-seriate; asci "normally 8-spored but often some spores not maturing", "crowded, more or less deformed by pressure, cylindric to somewhat clavate"; paraphyses "fascicled among the densely crowded asci"; hymenium "sometimes double, partitioned into mostly curved large pockets"; "cortices principally pseudoparenchymatous, the cells becoming smaller within, changing to prosenchyma toward the hymenium", (Gilkey), spores borne in sock-like asci, (NATS), spores densely spiny (echinulate); asci clavate to ellipsoid to irregular, hymenium regularly separated into pockets by sterile zones, (Smith, M.E.), spores 29-34 microns in diameter, round, with densely crowded spines 2-3 microns tall, (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with the form of a brain', from 'cerebrum' (Latin) meaning 'brain'
SIMILAR  Genea species in the Pacific Northwest have brown to black fruitbodies, a basal tuft of hymenium, and nearly round to elliptic spores. Gilkeya compacta has round to nearly round spores and like G. cerebriformis lacks a basal tuft of mycelium, but fruitbodies are reddish to vinaceous, the warts on the spores are broad and rounded, asci are cylindric, and the hymenium is continuous, whereas G. cerebriformis has pale grayish yellow to light tan fruitbodies, spiny spores, asci that are clavate to ellipsoid to irregular, and hymenium that is regularly separated into pockets by sterile zones, (Smith, M.E.). See also SIMILAR section of Hydnotrya cerebriformis, and Hydnotrya variiformis.
SOURCES  Arora(1), Smith(4), Gilkey(3) (as Myrmecocystis cerebriformis), NATS(1), Trappe, M.(1)*, Smith, M.E.(1), Castellano(4), Colgan(2), Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)*
67
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Genea arenaria  Harkn.^  Proc. Calif. Acad. III. 1: 263. 1899
ENGLISH NAMES  hairy geode truffle
NOTES  Features include 1) an irregularly lobed, brown fruitbody, 2) an exterior that is warty, has scattered long brown hairs, and has an opening to the interior, 3) an interior that is hollow (irregular due to infolding), and colored like the exterior or paler, 4) a basal tuft of mycelium, 5) underground growth especially under live oak, and 6) microscopic characters including elliptic spores with minute scattered warts that are according to Smith, M.E.(1) "irregularly shaped (obtuse to truncate, tips anvil-topped or forked)", on typically 8-spored asci. It is common among truffles in the Pacific Northwest.^ RANGE It is found from western OR to southern CA and Mexico, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm broad, "usually irregularly lobed or coarsely knobby (at least at maturity)"; "brown to pale brown, divided into small, often pyramidal warts and covered with scattered long brown to dark brown hairs"^, (Arora), 1-2.5cm across, irregular, coarsely lobed and folded; brown; verrucose, "scatteringly hispid" with long, brown hairs, (Gilkey), 0.8-2.2cm across dried, nearly spherical to lobed and furrowed, hollow, with apical orifice having a round to irregularly wavy opening; light brown to brown; warts on outer surface rounded to subangular 0.007-0.025cm wide and 0.005-0.01cm tall, "usually with a sparse brown tomentum in the furrows and scattered to abundant setae tending to cluster on the warts" (hairs easily worn away: check the furrows), (Smith, M.E.)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "basically hollow, but the cavity usually irregular in shape due to infolding of the outer wall; inner surface finely warted and colored like the exterior or paler; sterile tissue whitish"^, (Arora), cavity irregular, though infolding of the wall, (Gilkey), cavity single, rounded to irregular, in occasional specimens broadly open (cup-like), (Smith, M.E.)
STEM  mycelial tuft attached at base of fruitbody, usually darker than the outer surface of the fruitbody, (Smith, M.E.), with or without a basal tuft of mycelium (Arora)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  unknown (Arora)
HABITAT  single, scattered, or in small groups in soil under trees (mainly live oak), typically November through April^, (Arora), "under shrubs" (Gilkey from Harkness)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores averaging 22-32 x (16)20-24 microns, mostly elliptic, "with minute scattered warts"^; asci arranged in a palisade, typically 8-spored, (Arora), spores 22-32 x 22-24 microns, "covered by scattered, irregular, usually truncate papillae"; "outer half of the cortex pseudoparenchymatous" [presumably asci and paraphyses clothe the inner wall, based on characters of genus, the paraphyses slender and septate and uniting beyond the asci to form a secondary pseudoparenchymatous cortex]; long brown hairs are septate, (Gilkey), spores 20-28 x 15-23 microns excluding ornamentation, elliptic to broadly elliptic, colorless, ornamentation consisting of cones 0.5-2.5(4) x 0.5-2(3) microns "with obtuse to truncate, anvil-topped or forked tips" [on other species in article, height given before width]; asci about 200 x 18-22 microns, colorless, thin-walled; paraphyses 3-4 microns wide, colorless, thin-walled, septate, "the tips exceeding the asci and forming a tissue of small isodiametric cells which grade to larger, pigmented, thick-walled cells similar to those of the peridium but lining the ascomatal chamber"; setae at apex of peridial warts in clusters, each seta 250-600(900) microns long and 8-12(15) microns wide at base, tapering gradually to 3-6 microns wide at tips, (Smith, M.E.) 
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of sand'
SIMILAR  Genea harknessii and Genea gardneri have black fruitbodies, (Smith, M.E.(1)). Gilkeya compacta has reddish to vinaceous fruitbodies and round to nearly round spores, and there is no basal tuft of mycelium, (Smith, M.E.(1)). Genabea cerebriformis has pale grayish yellow to light tan fruitbodies and round, spiny spores, (Smith, M.E.(1)).
SOURCES  Arora(1), Gilkey(3), Smith, M.E.(1), Trappe(13)*
68
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Genea gardneri  Gilkey^  Univ. Calif. Publ. Bot. 6: 301. 1916
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a small, black, wrinkled, folded fruitbody with a verrucose surface, and an opening at the top, 2) an irregular, hollow interior, 3) growth under conifers and oaks, and 4) microscopic characters including spores measuring 32-36 x 28-34 microns with large crowded warts, the spore surface often appearing conspicuously pitted at maturity.^ It is fairly common at low elevations in Pacific Coast states, (Trappe, M.(3)). Trappe(13), however, does not include the species. RANGE It has been found in OR and CA (Gilkey).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-1.5cm across, black; "much wrinkled and folded, the surface minutely verrucose"^, (Gilkey), nearly spherical to contorted "with an opening to an internal cavity"; black; finely warty, (Trappe, M.)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  interior cavity is "very irregular from infolding of the wall but rarely from inward projections", [Genea species as described by Gilkey have an opening at the apex into a convoluted hollow interior]^, (Gilkey), the finely warty, black surface that covers the outer surface also covers the cavity, (Trappe, M.)
STEM  base with a tuft of brown hyphae^ (Trappe, M.)
ODOR  mild to slightly garlicky^ (Trappe, M.)
TASTE  mild^ (Trappe, M.)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  with Pinus (pine), Abies (fir), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), and Quercus (oak), January to September^, (Trappe, M.), under oaks (Gilkey)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 32-36 x 28-34 microns, "papillose, the papillae large, crowded, low, generally semiglobose", "uniseriate or rarely incompletely 2-seriate, sometimes few maturing in an ascus"^; "hymenium sometimes divided by sterile bands into pockets"; "outer layer of both cortices pseudoparenchymatous, with large, dark, thick-walled cells, these becoming small, thin-walled, and colorless inward, gradually changing to prosenchyma", (in Genea species as described by Gilkey, paraphyses are slender and septate and unite beyond the asci to form a secondary pseudoparenchymatous cortex), (Gilkey), spores 32-36 x 28-34 microns, "often conspicuously pitted at maturity", "hymenial layers not fused together to form a double hymenium", (Smith, M.E.), spores 32-36 x 28-34 microns, broadly elliptic to round, ornamented with broad, low, rounded warts that dissolve in KOH, (Trappe, M.)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Genea harknessii is very similar but has smaller spores that are smooth at first but finely warted at maturity, (Arora), Genea harknessii has spore ornaments with pointed to irregular protrusions at tips, ornaments not typically crowded on spore surface, spores 24-32 x 21-29 microns, (Smith, M.E.); Genea arenaria has light brown to brown fruitbodies, (Smith, M.E.); Gilkeya compacta has reddish to vinaceous fruitbodies and round to nearly round spores, and there is no basal tuft of mycelium, (Smith, M.E.(1)); Genabea cerebriformis has pale grayish yellow to light tan fruitbodies and round, spiny spores, and there is no basal tuft of mycelium, (Smith, M.E.(1))
SOURCES  Gilkey(3), Arora(1), Smith, M.E.(1), Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)
69
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Genea harknessii  Gilkey^  Univ. Calif. Bot. 6: 300. 1916
ENGLISH NAMES  dark geode truffle
NOTES  Features include 1) a dark brown to black truffle up to 2.5cm that is lobed and warty, 2) an interior cavity that is warted and dark brown to blackish with irregular projections from the wall, and 3) microscopic characters including spores measuring 24-28 x 22-27 microns that are smooth at first but finely warty at maturity, (warts with pointed to irregular protrusions at tips, warts not typically crowded on the spore surface), on 8-spored asci.^ This is "apparently a complex of morphologically indistinguishable species", (Smith, M.E.). It is common among truffles in the Pacific Northwest. RANGE Distribution is western WA and OR to northern CA, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-2.5cm across, spherical to "flattened to very knobby and irregularly lobed", usually with an opening at the top to the interior; dark reddish brown "to dark brown to dark gray or black (but often with a thin whitish covering of hyphae when very young), divided into small, often pyramidal warts"^, (Arora), 2cm or less, somewhat lobed; dark brown to black; verrucose, (Gilkey)
INNER LAYER  flesh thin, fragile, brittle, and white to gray^, (Trappe, M.(3))
INTERIOR  "basically hollow, but often interrupted by irregular projections of sterile tissue from the outer wall", "inner surface of wall warted and dark brown to blackish or bluish-gray", "sterile tissue white to grayish"^, (Arora), with cavity "greatly modified by irregular projections from the wall", (Gilkey), convoluted and hollow, surface black and warty, (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  usually with a tuft of mycelium at base^ (Arora)
ODOR  garlicky^ (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious in humus or soil under oak, manzanita, Baccharis (coyote bush), and other trees and shrubs^, (Arora), with leaf mold under trees and shrubs (Gilkey), associated with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) and Quercus (oak), (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 24-28 x 22-27 microns, elliptic to nearly round, colorless, smooth at first but finely warted when mature^; asci 8-spored, arranged in a palisade (hymenium), (Arora), spores 24-28 x 22-27 microns, rarely larger, nearly round, "covered by variable semiglobose or truncate verrucae", uniseriate or incompletely biseriate; asci cylindric to slightly clavate, loosely enclosing the spores, "cortices pseudoparenchymatous, with dark, thick-walled cells through the verrucae, changing inward to tangled hyphae; hymenium often double through coalescence of the inward projections, divided by sterile strands connecting the outer and inner cortices into sometimes distinct fertile pockets", (Gilkey), spores 24-32 x 21-29 microns, ornaments with pointed to irregular protrusions at tips, ornaments not typically crowded on the spore surface, (Smith, M.E.), 25-32 x 21-29 microns, nearly round to elliptic, ornamented with cones mostly 1-3 microns tall and broad, (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  means "of Harkness", for H.W. Harkness, pioneer 19th Century truffle taxonomist, (Trappe, M.(1))
SIMILAR  Genea gardneri "is very similar but has larger, coarsely warted spores", (Arora). G. gardneri has different spore ornamentation, and the surface is often conspicuously pitted at maturity, (Smith, M.E., (1)). Genea arenaria has light brown to brown fruitbodies, (Smith, M.E.). Gilkeya compacta has reddish to vinaceous fruitbodies and round to nearly round spores, and there is no basal tuft of mycelium, (Smith, M.E.(1)). Genabea cerebriformis has pale grayish yellow to light tan fruitbodies and round, spiny spores, (Smith, M.E.(1)).
SOURCES  Arora(1)*, Gilkey(3), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Smith, M.E.(1), Trappe(13)
70
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Geopora cercocarpi  D. Southw. & J.L. Frank^  Mycologia 103: 1196. 2011
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Cups category. Features include pale tan cups with rusty external hairs, white interior, underground habitat in association with Cercocarpus ledifolius, and microscopic characters including relatively large spores.^ The description is derived from Southworth(1). G. cercocarpi is considered to be an ectomycorrhizal mutualist with C. ledifolius. G. cercocarpi is found in OR and UT (Southworth).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-5.5cm across, 0.4-2.3cm high, cup-shaped or disk-shaped, distinct margin inrolled; outer surface pale tan with rusty hairs that are more dense in immature fruitbodies and more dense near the base in mature fruitbodies
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  spore-bearing surface white
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to scattered, "buried under leaf litter or deeper in soil", under the canopy of Cercocarpus ledifolius (curl-leaf mountain mahogany), collections recorded May to July
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (20)23-32 x 13-18 microns, elliptic, smooth, colorless, containing one central droplet; asci 8-spored, 200 x 18-21 microns, colorless, inamyloid, thin-walled, uniseriate; paraphyses exceeding asci by up to 30 microns, 5.0 microns wide, thread-like, straight, unbranched, septate, rounded at tip; hairs up to 1500 x 13-14 microns, branched, rusty brown to colorless, cell wall surface rough, wall 1.5 microns thick, septa 0.7 micron centrally but thicker at margin, tips rounded; ectal excipulum about 50 microns thick, "cells generally rounded, non-interlocking", 26-30 x 20-22 microns, colorless, medullary excipulum thicker, up to 600 microns, of dense textura intricata, cells 9-18 microns in diameter, colorless
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Cercocarpus'
SIMILAR  Geopora arenosa has smaller fruitbodies and narrower spores, (Southworth).
SOURCES  Southworth(1)
71
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Geopora cooperi  Harkn.^  Bull. Calif. Acad. 1: 168. 1885;  Geopora harknessii  E. Fisch. ex Gilkey;  Geopora magnifica  Gilkey;  Geopora annulata  Gilkey
ENGLISH NAMES  fuzzy truffle, fuzzy false truffle, Cooper's truffle, pine truffle
NOTES  Features include 1) large size for a truffle, 2) a more or less spherical fruitbody with a fuzzy brown outer surface, 3) a visible convoluted interior, 4) growth usually buried or partially buried especially under mountain conifers, and 5) microscopic characters including smooth broadly elliptic to round spores, on usually 8-spored asci.^ It is abundant among truffles throughout the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It is common in the northern Rocky Mountains, and is also known from CA north to AK, (Smith). Distribution includes OR, ID, CA, MI, and northern Europe, (Gilkey). There are collections at the University of Washington from WA, ID, AK, CO, MI, and UT.  There are collections at Oregon State University from WA, OR, ID, AK, AZ, CA, and CO. There are collections at the University of British Columbia from BC. It occurs in WY (Perry), and also in Mexico and Europe (Trappe, M.(3)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2-7cm across, spherical to nearly spherical; pale to dark brown; fuzzy from fine hairs^, (Smith), 2-7(10)cm across, spherical or nearly spherical but often squirrel-eaten; "fuzzy or velvety from a coating of light brown to dark brown hairs, usually furrowed", (Arora), 0.5-10cm across, "slightly lobed to strongly convolute"; pale to dark brown; more or less verrucose [warty], coarsely brown-tomentose, the tomentum continuing inward on the folds, (Gilkey)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  much convoluted; white to whitish streaked with brown^, (Smith), "deeply convoluted, the folds often touching each other" but leaving at least some open spaces between them; white to creamy or yellowish tan, "usually streaked with tan or brown", (Arora), comparatively simple to very irregular, "consisting of long labyrinthine canals resulting from folds and projections", that are generally readily separable but sometimes connected and so crowded that the tips of the paraphyses from opposing surfaces meet, (Gilkey)
STEM  none^ (Smith)
ODOR  usually mild, but in one form like fermented cider^, (Arora), faintly aromatic (Trudell), mild to radish-like or garlicky (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  edible (Arora)
HABITAT  single, scattered, or gregarious on or in ground under hardwoods and especially conifers, spring, summer, and fall, in Alaska has been found under willow and aspen^, (Arora), summer and fall, (Smith), with Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Abies (fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Larix (larch), Salix (willow), (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 18-24 x 10-16 microns, ovoid-elliptic, colorless^; asci 8-spored, cylindric, operculate, dehiscent, (Smith), spores 18-27(30) x (10)13-21 microns, "broadly elliptic in one form, round or nearly round in another", smooth, colorless, with one oil droplet; asci forming a distinct palisade lining the empty spaces or canal between the visible folds, usually 8-spored, (Arora), spores 18-24 x 10-16 microns, elliptic to long-elliptic, mostly uniseriate; asci 140-200 x 16-28 microns, "cylindric to somewhat clavate, rounded or somewhat pointed at the apex"; "external wall and folds more or less pseudoparenchymatous between the hymenium and the surface tomentum; outer cells of the cortex colored and larger than the inner colorless cells", (Gilkey), spores 16-21 microns in diameter, elliptic, smooth, (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  means "of Cooper", for J.G. Cooper, who made the first collections of the species in California in the early 1880s, (Trappe, M.(1))
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Hydnotrya cerebriformis and Hydnotrya variiformis.
SOURCES  Smith(4), Arora(1)*, Trudell(4)*, Lincoff(2)*, McKnight(1)*, Gilkey(3), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)*, Perry(2), Desjardin(6)*
72
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Gilkeya compacta  (Harkn.) M.E. Sm. & Trappe^  in Smith, Trappe & Rizzo Mycologia 98(5): 705 (2007) [2006];  == Genea intermedia  Gilkey;  == Hydnocystis compacta  Harkn.;  == Myrmecocystis compacta  (Harkn.) Gilkey
ENGLISH NAMES  red geode truffle
NOTES  Features include 1) a reddish or reddish brown to vinaceous purple, lobed fruitbody with a warty surface and an apical opening, 2) a hollow interior with a pink to whitish surface that is less warty than the outer surface, 3) absent basal tuft of hyphae, 4) underground growth, and 5) microscopic characters including round or nearly round spores with hemispheric papillae varying in size, on typically 8-spored asci.^ Smith, M.E.(1) proposed the new genus Gilkeya for this species (differing from Genea by vinaceous peridium, lack of basal tuft of hyphae, and round spores). This species is not to be confused with Genea compacta Harkn. It is common among truffles in the Pacific Northwest. RANGE It is found from western OR to ID, southern CA and Mexico, (Trappe(13)). It has been found in WA by Colgan(2). It has been found in OR, ID (rare), CA, and Mexico, (Smith, M.E.(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-2cm across, subglobose [nearly spherical] to convoluted, hollow, with a small hairless apical opening; pink to vinaceous; verrucose [warty], lacking hairs^, (Smith, M.E.), 0.5-2.5cm across, sometimes somewhat spherical (especially when young), but more often lobed or knobby; reddish to reddish brown, vinaceous, or vinaceous purple; "the lobes or protuberances superimposed with minute warts", (Arora), 1-2cm across, "vinaceous-purple" (Ridgway color), verrucose, (Gilkey)
INNER LAYER  flesh is fragile, brittle, and white^, (Trappe, M.(3))
INTERIOR  "basically hollow, but often interrupted by irregular projections of sterile tissue from the outer wall; inner surface warted, pink to whitish; sterile tissue also white to pinkish"^, (Arora), inner wall "seashell pink" (Ridgway color), less verrucose than outer wall, (Gilkey)
STEM  lacking a tuft of hyphae^ (Smith, M.E.)
ODOR  not distinct^ (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  not distinct^ (Trappe, M.(3))
EDIBILITY  unknown (Arora)
HABITAT  single to gregarious; underground in soil in woods^, (Arora), leaf mold, (Gilkey), February to August, mostly April to June, (Trappe, M.(3)), associated with Quercus (oak), Abies (fir), Pinus (pine), and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) in pure or mixed stands, March through August, but mostly May and June, (Smith, M.E.)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 28-43 x 25-38 microns excluding ornamentation, nearly round to round, ornamentation of colorless, rounded papillae 2-3(7) microns tall and 2-6(15) microns broad, "the interpapillary spore surface with smaller papillae and granules"^; asci 250-280 x 31-45 microns, cylindric, walls up to 2 microns thick when young but thinning to +/- 0.5 microns by maturity, hymenium continuous; peridium "of inflated, thick-walled cells", interior of fruitbody "lined with an epithecium similar to the peridium", (Smith, M.E.), spores averaging 36-40 x 36-40 microns, round, finely warty when mature; asci typically 8-spored, asci arranged in a palisade, (Arora), spores 36-40 microns, smooth and colorless when young, "irregularly covered at maturity by semiglobose papillae varying in size on a single spore from 5 microns in height to minute granules often coalescing in irregular groups", uniseriate; paraphyses "crowded among the asci, enlarging and coalescing beyond the asci to form a secondary cortex, and apparently again emerging as free tips at the surface of the ascocarp cavity"; "cortices coarsely pseudoparenchymatous throughout; hymenium nearly continuous", (Gilkey)
NAME ORIGIN  "compacta" means "compressed or compacted together", possibly referring to the tendency of fruitbodies to form in groups, (Smith, M.E.)
SIMILAR  Similar Genea species have fruitbodies that are brown to black, a basal tuft of mycelium, and nearly round to elliptic spores, (Smith, M.E.). Genabea cerebriformis has pale grayish yellow to light tan fruitbodies, densely spiny spores, and asci "clavate to ellipsoid to irregular, hymenium regularly separated into pockets by sterile zones", (Smith, M.E.). See also SIMILAR section of Genea arenaria, Genea gardneri, and Genea harknessii.
SOURCES  Smith, M.E.(1), Gilkey(3) (as Myrmecocystis compacta), Trappe(5) (as Genea intermedia), Trappe, M.(1)* (as Genea intermedia), Trappe, M.(3)*, Arora(1) (as Genea intermedia), Colgan(2) (as Genea intermedia), Trappe(13)*
73
FAMILY  Glomeraceae, Order Glomerales, Class Glomeromycetes, Phylum Glomeromycota
LATIN NAMES  Glomus caledonium  (T.H. Nicolson & Gerd.)  Trappe & Gerd.^  Mycologia Memoir 5: 56. 1974;  == Endogone macrocarpa var. caledonia  T.H. Nicolson & Gerd.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Glomus caledonium forms fruitbodies up to 0.6cm in soil, with round chlamydospores 130-279 microns in diameter that have an outer colorless layer easily separable from the yellow to brown inner layer.^ In Trappe(8), the masculine ending on caledonius is changed to a neuter ending (because Glomus is a neuter noun despite the ending), and a "c" is added. The description is derived from Gerdemann(1). It is common in the Pacific Northwest, (Trappe(13)). RANGE Gerdemann(1) examined collections from WA, OR, CA, and the type is from UK (Scotland). Trappe(13) say it is widespread in the northern hemisphere.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  sporocarp [fruitbody] up to 0.6cm across, nearly spherical, with pallid peridium
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  gleba light brown
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in soil in fields, parks, orchards, and forests, probably occurring throughout the year^, (Gerdemann), forms arbuscular mycorrhizae with many plants (Trappe(13))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  chlamydospores 130-279 x 120-272 microns, generally round or nearly round but sometimes elliptic or irregular, spore wall 6-10(16) microns thick, composed of colorless outer layer 1-4(8) microns thick that is easily separable from yellow to brown inner layer 4-8(10) microns thick; occurring singly or occasionally in sporocarp^; pallid peridium of colorless thin-walled hyphae 8-25 microns wide
NAME ORIGIN  means "pertaining to Scotland", where type was found
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gerdemann(1), Trappe(8), Trappe(13)
74
FAMILY  Glomeraceae, Order Glomerales, Class Glomeromycetes, Phylum Glomeromycota
LATIN NAMES  Glomus convolutum  Gerd. & Trappe^  Mycologia Memoir 5: 42. 1974
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Glomus convolutum forms fruitbodies less than a centimeter in size which are bright orange to yellow, in or on soil or on conifer needles and rotted wood near snowbanks, with many spores each enclosed in a hyphal mantle.^ Trappe(8) corrected the Latin ending to neuter, because Glomus is a neuter noun despite its ending. The description is derived from Gerdemann(1). It is common in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It is specifically found in WA, OR, and CA at high elevations, (Trappe(13)). Gerdemann(1) examined collections from WA, OR, CA, and MT.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  sporocarp [fruitbody] 0.2-0.9cm across, "much lobed, convoluted, infolded, and irregular, verrucose, hard and brittle, bright orange to orange-yellow when moist, light orange to yellow when dry, at times with some adhering debris", peridium absent
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  gleba approximately 0.2cm thick
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground or on ground, on soil or conifer needles and rotted wood near melting snowbanks, June to August^, Gerdemann(1), probably saprobic rather than mycorrhizal (Trappe(13))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  chlamydospores 81-193 x 67 -193 microns, round to oboval, each spore in mantle 5-50 microns thick of intertwined thin-walled hyphae 1.5-5 microns wide, spore wall 8-15 microns thick, spores filled with yellow oil drops when fresh
NAME ORIGIN  means "convolute", referring to the form of the fruiting body
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gerdemann(1), Trappe(8), Trappe(13)
75
FAMILY  Glomeraceae, Order Glomerales, Class Glomeromycetes, Phylum Glomeromycota
LATIN NAMES  Glomus fasciculatum  (Thaxt. sensu Gerd.) Gerd. & Trappe^  Mycologia Memoir 5: 51. 1974;  == Endogone fasciculata  Thaxt.;  = Endogone macrocarpa f. media  Tul. & C. Tul.;  = Endogone arenacea  Thaxt.;  = Rhizophagites butleri  Rosend.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  The sporocarp [fruitbody] is up to 0.8cm in diameter, grayish brown and tuberculate, without a peridium and containing spores 35-105 microns in diameter when they are round, the spores "free in soil, in dead rootlets, in loose aggregations, in small compact clusters, and in sporocarps".^ Trappe(8) corrected the Latin ending to neuter, because Glomus is a neuter noun despite its ending. The description is derived from Gerdemann(1). It is abundant in the Pacific Northwest and common worldwide, (Trappe(13)). RANGE Gerdemann(1) examined collections from BC, WA, OR, ID, and CA. It was noted to be a common mycorrhizal fungus, also widely distributed elsewhere in North America and Europe, and known from Trinidad and Australia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  sporocarp [fruitbody] up to 0.8cm by 0.5cm by 0.5cm, irregularly spherical or flattened; grayish brown; tuberculate
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground: in dunes, cultivated fields, meadows, orchards, and forests, greenhouses (where sometimes on top of soil), collected most commonly in November through February in the field^, (Gerdemann), forms arbuscular mycorrhizae with many plants (Trappe(13))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  chlamydospores 35-105 microns in diameter when round, 75-150 x 35-100 microns when nearly round to oboval, elliptic, nearly lens-shaped, cylindrical or irregular; smooth or appearing rough from debris; spores borne "free in soil, in dead rootlets, in loose aggregations, in small compact clusters, and in sporocarps"; spore walls 3-17 microns thick, colorless to light yellow or yellow brown, "the thicker walls often minutely perforate with thickened inward projections"; peridium absent
NAME ORIGIN  means "clustered"
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gerdemann(1), Trappe(8), Trappe(13)
76
FAMILY  Glomeraceae, Order Glomerales, Class Glomeromycetes, Phylum Glomeromycota
LATIN NAMES  Glomus geosporum  (T.H. Nicolson & Gerd.) Walker^  Mycotaxon 15: 56. 1982;  == Endogone macrocarpa  (Tul. & C. Tul.) Tul. & C. Tul.  var. geospora  T.H. Nicolson & Gerd.;  == Glomus macrocarpum  var. geosporum  (T.H. Nicolson & Gerd.) Gerd. & Trappe
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Glomus geosporum is not visible to the naked eye but is included because some Glomus species are visible. Features include development as large chlamydospores in the soil without a fruitbody, the spores 110-290 microns, round to broadly elliptic, light yellow brown when young, darkening with maturity, with a long extension of spore wall thickening along the spore-bearing hypha.^ The description is derived from Gerdemann(1). RANGE Collections were examined from WA, OR, and CA, (Gerdemann(1) as Glomus macrocarpum var. geosporum). Collections were examined from AZ, IA, GA, Mexico, Netherlands, and the United Kingdom, (Walker).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  fruiting bodies not known: spores occur singly in soil (Walker)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  soil (Walker)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  chlamydospores formed singly in soil, 110-290 microns, round to nearly round or broadly elliptic, "smooth and shiny or with a dull appearance, or roughened from adherent debris", "light yellow-brown and transparent to translucent when young, becoming dark yellow-brown to dark red-brown at maturity", in Melzer's reagent, young spores becoming slowly deep red, older spores usually darken or become orange brown, walls total 4-18 microns thick, 3-layered, with a thin, colorless, tightly adherent outer wall less than 1 micron, most easily observed in young spores and sometimes absent in mature spores, a yellow-brown to red-brown laminated middle wall 3-16 microns thick, and a yellow to yellow-brown inner wall less than 1 micron thick that appears membranous and forms a septum separating the spore contents from the lumen of the attached (subtending) hypha, walls often become perforated when old, spores with one (or rarely two) straight to recurved, simple to slightly funnel-shaped subtending hypha up to 200 microns long, 10-24 microns wide, with yellow to dark yellow-brown wall thickening that extends 30-100 microns along the hypha from the spore base, spore contents "of uniform oil droplets when young", "becoming increasingly granular in appearance with age"^, (Walker), chlamydospores 110-290 x 100-290 microns, round to broadly elliptic, dark brown to black, (Gerdemann)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'earth-spored'
SIMILAR  The spores of Glomus macrocarpum may be the same size and color, but lack an inner wall and a septum, and may have spores formed in loose clusters, (Walker).
SOURCES  Walker(1), Gerdemann(1) (as Glomus macrocarpum var. geosporum)
77
FAMILY  Glomeraceae, Order Glomerales, Class Glomeromycetes, Phylum Glomeromycota
LATIN NAMES  Glomus halonatum  S.L. Rose & Trappe^  Mycotaxon 10(2): 413. 1980
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Glomus halonatum is not normally visible to the naked eye, but is included because some Glomus species are visible. Trappe(8) corrected the Latin ending to neuter, because Glomus is a neuter noun despite its ending. Chlamydospores are borne singly in soil or in loose clusters of 3-7 spores within a loosely wefted peridium, the spores 200-280 microns in diameter, rounded, the spore wall 18-35 microns thick, typically 2-layered, the outer colorless and amorphous, giving the appearance of a halo, becoming roughened when old, the inner brown wall often prominently lamellate, ornamented with crowded spines 0.5-0.2 microns. The attached hypha is 5-6 microns wide at the spore, widening to as much as 17 microns away from the spore.^ The description is derived from Rose(2). RANGE Glomus halonatum has been found in OR, Mexico, and the United Kingdom.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  chlamydospores are "single in soil or in small, loose clusters of 3-7 spores within a loosely wefted peridium"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Ceanothus velutinus in arid volcanic soils in Oregon, with roadside grasses in grasslands in Mexico, under Hippophae rhamnoides (sea-buckthorn) in sand dunes in United Kingdom; associated in the field with vesicular-arbuscular mycorrhizae of Ceanothus velutinus and Hippophae rhamnoides
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  chlamydospores 200-280 microns in diameter, round to nearly round, light brown to brown, wall 18-35 microns thick, of 2-3 layers: the outermost layer 8-12(20) microns thick, colorless, amorphous, "sometimes with obscure radial striations", when young smooth, when old becoming roughened, an inner layer 10-15 microns thick, brown, often prominently lamellate [made up of thin plates], "ornamented with crowded spines 0.5 x 0.2 microns that extend into the outer layer", old spores sometimes with a third innermost layer, dark brown and +/- 5 microns thick, spore contents of oil droplets of varying size; attached hypha is straight, extending through the outer colorless wall wherein it is constricted to 5-6 microns wide, at the surface of the outer colorless wall this subtending hypha is expanded to 11-13 microns wide, and at +/- 10 microns below the outer colorless wall inflated to as much as 17 microns wide, hyphal walls near the spore totaling 5-8 microns thick, with a thick colorless outer layer and a thin brown inner layer, hypha often with a septum +/- 30 microns below the attachment
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin meaning "haloed": "in transmitted light in optical cross section, hyaline outer spore wall appears as a bright ring around the spore"^, (Rose)
SIMILAR  "The echinulations of the inner wall of G. halonatus resemble those of G. monosporus spores which, however, have but a thin outer wall, a hyphal mantle partially to totally enclosing the spores, and a subtending hypha that typically recurves along the spore surface" [Latin names italicized] (Rose). "Glomus halonatus differs from G. caledonius (T.H. Nicolson & Gerd.) Trappe & Gerd. in having an amorphous poorly separable outer wall and echinulate inner wall vs. the nonmucilaginous, separable outer wall and smooth inner wall of the latter." [Latin names italicized] (Rose).
SOURCES  Rose(2), Trappe(8)
78
FAMILY  Glomeraceae, Order Glomerales, Class Glomeromycetes, Phylum Glomeromycota
LATIN NAMES  Glomus lacteum  S.L. Rose & Trappe^  Mycotaxon 10(2): 415. 1980
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Glomus lacteum is not visible to the naked eye but is included because some Glomus species are visible. Glomus lacteum spores "are distinctive in their combination of frequently multiple hyphal attachments, white color, and a thin, smooth, singly layered spore wall".^ The description is derived from Rose(2). Trappe(8) corrected the Latin ending to neuter, because Glomus is a neuter noun despite its ending. RANGE The type collection is from central OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  chlamydospores borne singly in soil, without a fruitbody
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in arid, volcanic soil in edaphically stressed sites; associated in the field with vesicular-arbuscular mycorrhizae of Ceanothus velutinus and of Purshia tridentata (antelope-brush)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  chlamydospores 150-220 microns in diameter, round to nearly round, milky white, opaque, shiny smooth, spore walls single, 3-5 microns thick, colorless, contents colorless, "granular or of globules of varying size"; attached hyphae 1-3 per spore, 6-12 microns wide, straight, colorless, "with walls slightly thickened only for a short distance from the spore", "in most spores 2 hyphae merge near the spore to form a single attachment", but another hypha is often "attached 10-20 microns away from the attachment point of the merged hyphae, and sometimes yet another hypha is attached at a still greater distance from that of the merged hyphae"
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin, "milk-white", referring to the opaque milky appearance of the spores under incident light^, (Rose)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Rose(2), Trappe(8)
79
FAMILY  Glomeraceae, Order Glomerales, Class Glomeromycetes, Phylum Glomeromycota
LATIN NAMES  Glomus macrocarpum  Tul. & C. Tul.^  Giorn. Bot. Ital. Pt. 1, 2: 63. 1845;  == Endogone macrocarpa  (Tul. & C. Tul.) Tul. & C. Tul.;  = Endogone pampaloniana  Bacc.;  = Endogone guttulata  E. Fisch.;  = Endogone nuda  Petch
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  The very large spores of Glomus macrocarpum measure 90-180 microns and are usually nearly round. They occur in clusters in soil or in fruitbodies up to 1.2cm wide. Fruitbodies are irregularly spherical to ellipsoid and beige to brown, with or without a white, cottony peridium that collapses when touched.^ Trappe(8) corrected the Latin ending to neuter, because Glomus is a neuter noun despite its ending. Gerdemann(1) examined "large-spored" collections of the type variety with spores often exceeding 150 microns in diameter (ranging up to 230 microns), and "small-pored" collections with spores ranging from 50-150 microns. Berch(2) recombined as separate Glomus species three of the synonyms given by Gerdemann(1): E. versiforme Karst. (here considered Diversispora versiformis, see SIMILAR), E. tenebrosa Thaxter, and E. australis Berk. As a result the spore size ranges only up to 140 microns. Gerdemann(1) also examined collections from Washington, Oregon, and California of var. geosporus, which is distinguished from the type variety "in not forming sporocarps, in its very dark spore walls, and in the long extension of wall thickening along the spore-bearing hyphae", (Gerdemann) but this has subsequently been raised to species status as Glomus geosporum (T.H. Nicolson & Gerd.) Walker. At least in the wide sense G. macrocarpum is abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest and locally common worldwide, and forms arbuscular mycorrhizae with many plants, (Trappe(13)). RANGE The "large-spored" collections examined by Gerdemann(1) came from CA, and the "small-spored" from BC, WA, OR, CA; they said that the species is widely distributed over much of the world. Berch(1) examined collections in a narrow sense from OR, CA, PQ, ME, France, and the USSR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  sporocarp [fruitbody] up to 1.2cm wide, irregularly spherical to ellipsoid, hemispheric or "consisting of a layer of spores partially enclosing a lump of soil, exterior often covered with soil particles"; peridium "white and cottony, collapsing when touched, often partially or completely absent", sporocarps "at times with immature white chlamydospores at the surface, becoming brown when handled"^, (Gerdemann), sporocarp [fruitbody] up to 0.9cm x 0.8cm x 0.8cm, irregularly spherical or lobed, not enclosed by an intact peridium; beige or brown when fresh, golden brown when dried, (Berch(2))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  in section, the spore mass contains soil debris and no cavity, and it may exude an oily latex^, (Berch(2))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in soil in forests, meadows, fields, orchards, and greenhouses, throughout the year^, (Gerdemann)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  chlamydospores 93-206(230) microns, usually round to nearly round, occasionally elliptic or oboval, smooth or appearing rough from debris, spore wall "up to 14 microns thick, light yellow-brown to brown, often becoming perforated at maturity"; spores borne in sporocarps or in open clusters^, (Gerdemann), chlamydospores (90)120(140) x (70)110(130) microns in lectotype, but up to 180 microns in some collections, usually slightly longer than wide, nearly round to round, to irregular, spores wall of 2 distinct layers, the inner 6-12 microns thick and yellow, the outer 1-2 microns and colorless, (Berch(1)), chlamydospores (80)120(190) x (65)110(170) microns, outer spore wall smooth and colorless, swells in KOH, and is 1-4 microns thick, the inner spore wall is yellow or orange-brown, unaffected by KOH, 3-12 microns thick, and may be laminate; "gleba consists of brown chlamydospores embedded in loosely packed, highly branched, thin-walled, interwoven, light beige hyphae that are 5-15 microns wide", (Berch(2))
NAME ORIGIN  means "large-fruited"
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Glomus geosporum. Berch(2) describe Diversispora versiformis  (P. Karst.) Oehl, G.A. Silva & Siever as follows: fruitbody irregularly shaped, 0.8cm x 0.44cm x 0.3cm, peridium usually lacking; in the dried type fragments were yellow-brown or red-brown; habitat temperate greenhouses (in potting soil for example) and occasionally from natural environments in temperate locations, also found in subtropical forests; chlamydospores 60-195 x 55-195 microns, dull yellow or yellow brown or orange brown with a wall 4-11 microns thick composed of a 1-5 microns thick sloughing colorless outer layer adhering to a 5.5-7 microns thick inner wall that is yellow-brown in broken section; subtending hypha "straight or recurved and occasionally may expand slightly below the point of attachment", (3)10(13) microns wide, usually absent from mature spores, wall up to 3 microns thick at point of attachment and tapering to about 1 micron within 12 microns; pore closed by a thin, septum-like occlusion "arising from the inner wall layer". Collections were examined from Oregon, California, Massachusetts, Finland, Italy, Latvia, Poland, and Australia; however, one of the five collections from OR is the type of Diversispora epigaeum Diversispora epigaea (B.A. Daniels & Trappe) C. Walker & A. Schuessler which they synonymize with D. versiformis but is still maintained as separate in the online Species Fungorum, accessed May 17, 2016. Another of the collections is a paratype and the California collection is a paratype. (Berch(2)). 
SOURCES  Gerdemann(1), Trappe(8), Berch(1), Berch(2), Hawker(1), Trappe(13)
80
FAMILY  Glomeraceae, Order Glomerales, Class Glomeromycetes, Phylum Glomeromycota
LATIN NAMES  Glomus melanosporum  Gerd. & Trappe^  Mycologia Memoir 5: 46. 1974
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Glomus melanosporum is about 1cm in size, ovate, growing in soil, exuding latex when cut, the sporocarp with white loose hyphae interspersed by light brown to dark reddish brown or nearly black chlamydospores that have a single layered wall grading from a dark brown exterior to a near colorless interior.^ The description is derived from Gerdemann(1). Trappe(8) corrected the Latin ending to neuter, because Glomus is a neuter noun despite its ending. It is infrequent in the Pacific Northwest, (Trappe(13)). RANGE Glomus melanosporum occurs in WA, CA, and OR in mountains, (Trappe(13)). The holotype collection is from OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  sporocarp [fruitbody] 1.2cm by 1.2cm by 0.8cm, ovate, "surface with white loose hyphae interspersed with light brown to dark reddish-brown chlamydospores, exuding creamy latex when cut"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  gleba brownish black, containing light brown to dark reddish brown or nearly black chlamydospores
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection in soil underground
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  chlamydospores 166-277 x 129-244 microns, nearly round to oboval or broadly elliptic, light brown to dark reddish brown or nearly black, spore wall 8-13 microns thick and when mature grading in color from dark reddish brown at outer surface to light yellow or almost colorless near inner surface
NAME ORIGIN  means "black-spored"
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gerdemann(1), Trappe(8), Trappe(13)
81
FAMILY  Glomeraceae, Order Glomerales, Class Glomeromycetes, Phylum Glomeromycota
LATIN NAMES  Glomus microcarpum  Tul. & C. Tul.^  Giorn. Bot. Ital. Pt. 1,  2: 63. 1845;  = Endogone microcarpa  (Tul. & C. Tul.) Tul. & C. Tul.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  The large spores of Glomus microcarpum are borne free in the soil in loose aggregations, or in fruiting bodies up to 0.5cm with a peridium. The fruiting body is irregularly spherical and light brown.^ Glomus is the only endomycorrhizal genus that forms truffle-like fruitbodies (Trappe, M.(3)). The description is derived from Gerdemann(1) except where specified. Trappe(8) corrected the Latin ending to neuter, because Glomus is a neuter noun despite its ending. Glomus microcarpum is abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest, and it is locally common worldwide, forming arbuscular mycorrhizae with many plants, (Trappe(13)). RANGE Gerdemann(1) examined collections from WA, OR, ID, and it is also reported from CA, MI, Europe, and Australia. It is found in the United Kingdom (Hawker(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  sporocarp [fruitbody] up to 0.5cm across, irregularly spherical, light brown; peridium a thin layer of interwoven hyphae similar to those in interior^, (Gerdemann), fruitbody "consisting of spores in small, compact clusters that are usually but not always enclosed in interwoven white hyphae", spores "also formed individually or in loose aggregations among roots", (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  
STEM  
ODOR  mild to slightly garlicky^ (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  mild^ (Trappe, M.(3))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in soil in fields, orchards, and forests; collected May to November in the field^, (Gerdemann), year round (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  chlamydospores 35-49 microns diameter, round to nearly round, also free in soil and then 25 x 25-55 x 32 microns and round to elliptic or oboval or irregular; spore wall up to 7 microns thick, colorless to light yellow, laminate, smooth or appearing roughened from debris; peridium a thin layer of hyphae similar to those in gleba, with spores interspersed but less abundantly than in gleba, (Gerdemann), spores 25-55 microns, round to elliptic or irregular, colorless to light yellow, with walls up to 7 microns thick, arising at the end of a hypha, (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  means "small-fruited"
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gerdemann(1), Trappe(8), Hawker(1), Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)*
82
FAMILY  Glomeraceae, Order Glomerales, Class Glomeromycetes, Phylum Glomeromycota
LATIN NAMES  Glomus monosporum  Gerd. & Trappe^  Mycologia Memoir 5: 41. 1974
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Glomus monosporum is not generally visible to the naked eye but is included because some Glomus species are visible. It is less than half a millimeter in size, in soil, characterized by 1-2 spores per "fruitbody", with the spore surface often minutely spiny.^ The description is derived from Gerdemann(1). Trappe(8) corrected the Latin ending to neuter, because Glomus is a neuter noun despite its ending. RANGE Gerdemann(1) examined collections from WA and OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  sporocarp [fruitbody] 0.015-0.045 x 0.017-0.047cm, spherical to ellipsoid, containing mostly 1, occasionally 2, or rarely 3 chlamydospores
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  forests, fields, and greenhouses, August through March in the field
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  chlamydospores 140-330 microns, generally round or nearly round or rarely elliptic, spore walls 4-10 microns thick and dull brown, consisting of a thin outer wall that often flakes off and a thick inner wall, the inner wall with minute spines that protrude into the outer wall, spores containing oil drops or occasionally filled with colorless thin-walled hyphae 3-6 microns wide; peridium "of branched, interwoven, thin-walled hyphae", the innermost 4-10 microns wide, the surface hyphae 1.5-2.5 microns wide, spores enclosed to unenclosed by hyphae
NAME ORIGIN  means "with one spore"
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gerdemann(1), Trappe(8)
83
FAMILY  Glomeraceae, Order Glomerales, Class Glomeromycetes, Phylum Glomeromycota
LATIN NAMES  Glomus mosseae  (T.H. Nicolson & Gerd.) Gerd. & Trappe^  Mycologia Memoir 5: 40. 1974;  == Endogone mosseae  T.H. Nicolson & Gerd.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Glomus mosseae is not generally visible to the naked eye but is included because some Glomus species are visible. It is characterized by a funnel-shaped spore base.^ The description is derived from Gerdemann(1). RANGE Glomus mosseae is widespread in the Pacific Northwest, and Gerdemann(1) examined collections from OR, AK, CA, and HI, and reports are noted from IL, Germany, UK, Pakistan, Australia, and New Zealand. It was reported from WA by Colgan(2).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  sporocarp [fruitbody] up to 0.1cm in diameter, globose to ellipsoid, 1-10 spored
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground, "from coastal dune sands to mountain forests and semi-arid zones; especially common in alkaline flats, fields, roadbanks, and forest clearings", collected throughout the year
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  chlamydospores 105 x 310 x 110-305 microns, round to oval, oboval, or somewhat irregular, (with one or occasionally 2 funnel-shaped bases 20-30 (50) microns in diameter), yellow to brown, walls 2-7 microns thick; peridium of loosely interwoven, irregularly branched, colorless, septate hyphae 2-12 microns wide, with walls up to 0.5 microns thick, "frequently anastomosing to from a thin network, enclosing the chlamydospores completely, incompletely, or with some spores unenclosed"
NAME ORIGIN  in honor of Dr. Barbara Mosse, the discoverer of the species
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gerdemann(1), Colgan(2)
84
FAMILY  Glomeraceae, Order Glomerales, Class Glomeromycetes, Phylum Glomeromycota
LATIN NAMES  Glomus occultum  C. Walker^  Mycotaxon 15: 50. 1982
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Glomus occultum is a microscopic species included here because it is a member of the genus Glomus which includes larger species. No fruitbody is known. Chlamydospores are 15-100 x 20-120 microns, oval to oboval, subangular to irregular, less often more round, colorless to white, inamyloid, cyanophilic, and attached at one point of the surface to the end of a hypha.^ The description is derived from Walker(1). RANGE Collections were examined from OR, IA, IL, Netherlands, and United Kingdom, (Walker).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  fruiting body unknown, spores occur singly in soil
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  borne singly or in loose clusters in the soil, or in compact clusters in the cortex of roots; associated with the roots of various plants, forms vesicular-arbuscular mycorrhizae in pot culture
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  chlamydospores 15-100 x 20-120 microns, often broader than long (the attached hypha being taken as an axis), oval to oboval, subangular to irregular, less often round to nearly round, colorless to white, inamyloid, cyanophilous, spore wall 1-layered to 2-layered with an additional rough outer deposit of granular material that sloughs when old, outer deposit up to 2 microns thick except at spore base where it may be greatly thickened, outer wall when present less than 1 micron thick, often indistinct, inner wall (1)1.5-2.5(5) microns thick, usually of two sometimes indistinct laminations; subtending hyphae funnel-shaped to simple, 5-50 microns long, 3-10 microns wide at spore base, tapering to 2-5 microns wide, "attached axially or eccentrically and recurved to straight, sometimes closed distally by a septum"
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin "occultum" meaning "hidden", "referring to the obscurity of the spores caused by their small size, angular shape, and lack of coloration"
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Walker(1)
85
FAMILY  Glomeraceae, Order Glomerales, Class Glomeromycetes, Phylum Glomeromycota
LATIN NAMES  Glomus pubescens  (Sacc. & Ellis)  Trappe & Gerd.^  Mycologia Memoir 5: 57. 1974;  == Sphaerocreas pubescens  Sacc. & Ellis;  == Stigmatella pubescens  (Sacc. & Ellis) Sacc.;  == Sclerocystis pubescens  (Sacc. & Ellis) Hoehn.;  == Endogone pubescens  (Sacc. & Ellis) Zycha
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Glomus pubescens is not generally visible to the naked eye but is included because some Glomus species are visible. It is up to 1 mm in diameter, growing on rotten sticks, white to brownish yellow, sparsely pubescent, with chlamydospores under 50 microns in diameter.^ The description is derived from Gerdemann(1). RANGE It is known in the Pacific Northwest from 2 collections near the OR coast.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  sporocarp [fruitbody] 0.06-0.1cm across, round, white to brownish yellow
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "yellowish brown with a basal pad of white hyphae similar to those of the peridium"
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  two collections growing on rotten hardwood sticks, May and June
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  chlamydospores 20-48 x 18-45 microns, nearly round to elliptic, smooth, filled with oil droplets of variable size, spore walls 3-6 microns thick, nearly colorless to light yellow; peridium "thin but covering most spores, composed of a tangled layer of hyaline, thin-walled hyphae 1-2 microns diam from which hyphal tips emerge both singly and in tapered fascicles to form a coarse, sparse to crowded pubescence 50-100 microns tall"; spores sometimes seeming radially aligned but "more often randomly massed"
NAME ORIGIN  means "pubescent" referring to peridium
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gerdemann(1)
86
FAMILY  Glomeraceae, Order Glomerales, Class Glomeromycetes, Phylum Glomeromycota
LATIN NAMES  Glomus radiatum  (Thaxt.) Trappe & Gerd.^  Mycologia Memoir 5: 46. 1974;  == Endogone radiata  Thaxt.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features are large spores with thick walls and a striking radial arrangement of spores within the fruiting body.^ Trappe(8) corrected the Latin ending to neuter, because Glomus is a neuter noun despite its ending. It is infrequent (Trappe(13)). RANGE Glomus radiatum occurs in OR and WA in the Cascade Mountains, (Trappe(13)). Gerdemann(1) examined collections from OR, WA, NY, and notes reports also from PQ, ME, and NH, (Gerdemann). It occurs also in CA and WV, (Castellano).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  sporocarp [fruitbody] up to 0.9 x 0.7cm x 0.3cm, generally flattened and lobed, attached to roots or organic matter, near white to gray-yellow where surface hyphae become matted^, (Castellano)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  associated with roots of Chamaecyparis nootkatensis (Alaska yellow-cedar) and Sequoia sempervirens (Redwood) below 1650m elevation (Castellano), underground, "in the Pacific Northwest from wet mountain soils (stream banks and hummocks in a boggy, montane meadow)", October and November, (Gerdemann)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  chlamydospores 60-110(120) x 48-75(90) microns, elliptic to oblong, oboval or rarely round, "arranged in a distinct radial pattern, grouped or widely dispersed in a matrix of coarse thin-walled hyphae", spore wall "4-8 microns thick, laminate, light yellow"^, (Gerdemann)
NAME ORIGIN  means "radiate", referring to the radiate arrangement of spores from the sporocarp base (Gerdemann)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Castellano(1), Gerdemann(1), Trappe(8), Trappe(13)
87
FAMILY  Glomeraceae, Order Glomerales, Class Glomeromycetes, Phylum Glomeromycota
LATIN NAMES  Glomus rubiforme  (Gerd. & Trappe) R.T. Almeida & N.C. Schenck^  Mycologia 82(6): 709. 1990;  == Sclerocystis rubiformis  Gerd. & Trappe
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Glomus rubiforme is not visible to the naked eye but is included because some Glomus species are visible. It is up to 0.68 mm, growing in soil, yellow brown to dark brown and resembling a miniature blackberry.^ RANGE Gerdemann(1) examined collections from WA and OR, and it has been reported from MI.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  sporocarp [fruitbody] 0.07cm by 0.008-0.038cm by 0.018cm, yellow brown to dark brown, resembling a miniature blackberry; peridium absent^, (Almeida)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in soil in fields, orchards, meadows, beach dune sands, throughout the year, (Gerdemann)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  chlamydospores 27-125 x 29-87(110) microns, oboval to elliptic, yellow brown to dark brown, inner wall 3-7.6 microns thick up to 13.5 microns at spore base, yellow-brown to brown, laminate, often perforated, and often with thick perforated projections on inner surface, outer wall 0.5-3.0 microns thick, colorless and evanescent; sporocarp consisting of a layer of chlamydospores surrounding a central plexus of hyphae^, (Almeida)
NAME ORIGIN  means "having the form of Rubus", referring to the resemblance of the sporocarp to a miniature blackberry
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Almeida(1), Gerdemann(1) (as Sclerocystis rubiformis)

FAMILY  Glomeraceae, Order Glomerales, Class Glomeromycetes, Phylum Glomeromycota
LATIN NAMES  Glomus vesiculiferum  (Thaxt.) Gerd. & Trappe^  Mycologia Memoir 5: 49. 1974;  == Endogone vesiculifera  Thaxt.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Glomus vesiculiferum forma a 1cm whitish crust on the soil surface, containing thick, walled chlamydospores overlain by a peridium-like layer of elongate thin-walled vesicles.^ The description is derived from Gerdemann(1). Trappe(8) corrected the Latin ending to neuter, because Glomus is a neuter noun despite its ending. RANGE Glomus vesiculiferum is known from the holotype collection in OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  sporocarp [fruitbody] 1.3cm by 1cm, forming crust on soil surface; whitish
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type on soil surface of potted Philodendron in greenhouse
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  chlamydospores produced in tubercles, round or nearly round and 49-85 microns, to occasionally oboval or elliptic and up to 100 x 70 microns, spore wall "4-8 microns thick, laminate, pale yellow", surface of sporocarp covered with a peridium-like layer of thin-walled vesicles up to 152 x 103 microns
NAME ORIGIN  means "vesicle-bearing"
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gerdemann(1) (as Glomus vesiculifer), Trappe(8), Berch(2) (as G. vesiculifer)
89
FAMILY  Gomphidiaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Gomphogaster leucosarx  (A.H. Sm. & Singer)  O.K. Mill.^  Mycologia 65: 227. 1973;  Brauniellula leucosarx  A.H. Sm. & Singer
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a pale vinaceous cap that soon becomes blackish spotted, 2) white cap flesh that becomes tinged vinaceous buff when cut, 3) a drab-gray spore mass of minute chambers without gill structure, 4) a stem base that is yellow inside and out, 5) growth under pine, 6) large, elongate spores, and 7) basidia that are mostly 4-spored, a few 2-spored.^ The description is derived from Smith(23). It is rare (Trappe(13)). RANGE Gomphogaster leucosarx was described from ID (Smith(23)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1.5cm broad, convex-depressed, irregular, margin lobed, peridium thin; ground color pale vinaceous but surface soon blackish spotted; "surface with debris adhering to it but apparently not viscid"
INNER LAYER  peridium thin, interior white but slowly becoming tinged vinaceous buff when cut, in stem-columella white but slowly becoming pale vinaceous, with base lemon yellow inside
INTERIOR  spore mass "drab-gray, oval in longitudinal section, consisting of minute chambers, no gill-structure visible", free from columella to top of gastrocarp, peridium curved in around the spore mass at the lower edge so that the latter is not truly exposed to the outside but no veil is present
STEM  1.2cm long and 0.6cm wide, solid; lemon yellow at base
ODOR  not distinctive
TASTE  not distinctive
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type single under Pinus contorta
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15-19.8 x 7-9 microns, oval to elliptic in face view, obscurely inequilateral in side view, apex rounded, "no apical discontinuity but occasional spores with bifid apex", smooth, walls slightly thickened, smoky brown in both KOH and Melzer's reagent^; basidia mostly 4-spored, a few 2-spored, 50-60 x 10-14 microns, clavate, when fresh the content nearly lemon yellow in Melzer's reagent, dull yellow as revived in Melzer's reagent, colorless in KOH; cystidia 65-90 x 18-35 microns, "clavate to fusoid-ventricose, apex rounded to obtuse, wall thin or with slight irregular thickenings, when fresh often incrusted with amorphous material which is vinaceous red in KOH, dingy yellowish as revived in KOH"; subhymenium absent, "the basidia originating in the tissue of the tramal plate"; tramal plates of hyphae 5-9 microns wide "and with short cells, floccose, interwoven"; peridium of hyphae 4-9 microns wide, loosely arranged, floccose, "the cells not much inflated but many heavily incrusted with yellowish to brown material (in KOH), no gelatinous hyphae seen anywhere"; clamp connections none
NAME ORIGIN  means 'white flesh'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(23) (as Brauniellula leucosarx), Miller(7), Arora(1), Trappe(13)
90
FAMILY  Hydnangiaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
