LATIN NAMES  Hydnangium carneum  Wallr.^  in Dietrich, Fl. Reg. Boruss. [Fl. Koenigr. Preuss.] 7: no. 465. 1839;  Octaviania carnea  Corda;  Octavianina mollis  Kuntze;  Hydnangium soderstroemii  Lagerh.;  Hydnangium roseum  (Harkn.) Singer & A.H. Sm.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a smooth, somewhat spherical fruitbody that is dull reddish becoming pale flesh-color, 2) a spore mass with medium-sized irregular cavities that is dull reddish becoming flesh-color, 3) a sterile base present as a mycelial tissue-like pad, 4) absent columella, and 5) microscopic characters including inamyloid, colorless, spiny, round spores 11-15 microns in diameter, long 2-spored basidia, and broad hyphae of the mediostratum of the tramal plates.^ RANGE Collections were examined from OR, CA, MA, Jamaica, Uruguay, Austria, Finland, France, Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Portugal, Sweden, United and the Kingdom, (Dodge). There is a collection from BC at Pacific Forestry Centre.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across, occasionally larger (+/- 3.5cm), spherical to depressed or irregular; "dull reddish when young, later shining and flesh-color"^, (Singer), "spherical or oblately spheroidal"; pale flesh color; smooth; peridium compact, fibrous, (Dodge), pink to pinkish brown; felty, (Trappe, M.(3)), 1-5cm across, (Buczacki)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "at first fragile, becoming fleshy"; dull reddish when young, later flesh-colored; "chambers rather spacious and, especially in the center, quite irregular in form"^, (Singer), "very pale, drying brownish, brittle, cavities irregular, medium size", (Dodge), lacunose, fragile, marbled, (Lincoff), soft and by maturity friable; pink, (Trappe, M.(3)), white then pinkish (Buczacki)
STEM  "with a rather strong basal attachment of mycelium, rhizomorphs not present"; "sterile base present as a mycelial tissue-like pad at point of attachment", columella none^, (Singer), no columella or sterile base seen, (Dodge), often with a sterile base and sometimes with a columella (Trappe, M.(3))
ODOR  none in particular^ (Lincoff)
TASTE  none in particular^ (Lincoff)
EDIBILITY  fair (Lincoff, but note history of nomenclatural confusion)
HABITAT  introduced from Australia as a mycorrhizal associate of Eucalyptus spp.^, (Castellano), widespread in all warm temperate areas or in greenhouses, beneath various hardwoods, but associated essentially with eucalyptus; in warm climates in winter and spring under leaf litter, (Lincoff), November to May (Trappe, M.(3)), all year (Buczacki)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 11-15 microns, round, ornamentation in the form of pointed cones 1.7-2.2 microns high and 1-1.7 microns across at base, "separate but often touching at their bases", "pale yellow in Melzer's reagent and ornamentation inamyloid", colorless in KOH, wall 0.8-1.3 microns thick, "sterigmal appendage short and inconspicuous"^; basidia 2-spored, 40-52(65) x 10-13 microns, "narrowly clavate to subcylindric, thin-walled, readily collapsing, basidioles also readily collapsing", pseudoparaphyses none; cystidia none; subhymenium of hyphae 5-10 microns wide, "compactly arranged but thin-walled and delicate, collapsing readily, giving a cellular appearance in sections but basic arrangement not clear from dried material"; tramal mediostratum of hyphae 6-12 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, smooth, thin-walled, the cells somewhat inflated and readily collapsing, no sphaerocysts seen; peridial context (subcutis) composed of hyphae 5-12 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, very delicate, readily collapsing; epicutis of peridium of hyphae 3-8 microns wide, colorless, thin-walled, readily collapsing, the zone not distinctly separated from context; sphaerocysts none; oleiferous hyphae none; clamp connections present, (Singer), spores 9.5-14 microns, (averaging about 16 microns including spines), round, echinulate [spiny], averaging 16 echinulae on median limb of circle, echinulae plus exospore about 3 microns, spores colorless singly, dilute honey colored in mass; basidia 2-spored, 18-20 x 10-13 microns, sterigmata 5-6 microns long; cystidia large, smooth, colorless; "septa 20-28 microns thick between hymenial layers, about 55 microns to tops of paraphyses, stupose, composed of slender gelified hyphae"; peridium "150-270 microns thick, compact, fibrous, stupose", (Dodge), spores 10-18 microns, round, spiny, (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin meaning "flesh-colored"^ (Lincoff)
SIMILAR  "Of the several northern species [of Hydnangium] studied by Singer and Smith (1960), only H. carneum [name in italics] Wallr. appears to be valid", (Castellano).
SOURCES  Singer(10), Dodge(1), Castellano(4), Lincoff(1)*, Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Buczacki(1)*, Desjardin(6)*, Siegel(2)*
91
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hydnobolites californicus  E. Fisch.^  Fedde Repertorium VII (1909) p.194
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a sordid to brownish fruitbody slightly to irregularly folded, with interior canals opening at the furrows, 2) narrow winding canals in the interior, and 3) microscopic characters including pale round ascospores with a coarse honeycomb-like reticulum.^ It is infrequent among truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE The distribution includes CA, IN, ME, and TN, (Gilkey). Hydnobolites californicus is known from CA and OR, (Castellano(4)). It is found from western OR to southern CA, (Trappe(13)). A collection from British Columbia at the Pacific Forestry Center was determined by J. Dennis.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-3cm across, slightly to very irregularly folded, the canals opening at the furrows; consistency gristly; at first sordid, becoming brownish when mature; surface with occasional short hairs^, (Gilkey)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  canals narrow, mostly long, winding^, (Gilkey), Hydnobolites species in general have gray to yellowish brown spore mass, marbled with white veins, (Castellano)
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under trees^ (Gilkey), mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Pinus (pine), Quercus (oak), (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14-18 x 14-18 microns, very coarsely alveolate, the angles projecting as coarse blunt spines 4 microns long, 3-4 alveoli across the diameter of the spore, spores yellowish when mature, loosely arranged in ascus^; asci scattered irregularly through the hyphal structure, irregularly spherical-ellipsoid; "pseudoparenchymatous cortex continuing as the border of the canals, 8 microns thick; cells irregular in size, the inner somewhat smaller than the outer, changing gradually to the loose hyphae of the interior; hyphae coarse, 4-10 microns thick"; surface with occasional short, septate hairs of 2 or 3 cells, (Gilkey), Hydnobolites spores described as follows: 12-24(30) microns in diameter excluding ornamentation, round, with broad-meshed honeycomb-like reticulum 3-4 microns tall, colorless to pale brown in water, in Melzer's reagent not distinctive, (Castellano)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'from California'
SIMILAR  Other genera with round reticulate spores have the spores darkly pigmented, with the exception of Terfezia, (Castellano).
SOURCES  Gilkey(3), Castellano(4), Trappe(13)*
92
FAMILY  Discinaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hydnotrya cerebriformis  Harkn.^  Proc. Calif. Acad. III. 1: 266. 1899
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a nearly spherical convoluted fruitbody up to 2.5cm across that is dull reddish brown to purple-brown or salmon, 2) a white or yellowish spore mass penetrated by long, maze-like, branching, narrow canals, 3) typically a strong garlic odor when mature, 4) habitat often inside rotten wood, and 5) microscopic characters including round spiny spores and inamyloid 8-spored asci.^ RANGE Hydnotrya cerebriformis was reported from BC to the North American Truffling Society. It was reported for WA by Jumpponen(1). It was listed for ID by Hawker (in Fogel(7)). The type is from CA (Gilkey). It was recorded from CO by Fogel(7). A collection from OR was used by O'Donnell(2). It is not listed in Trappe(13).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  dull reddish-brown to purple-brown^, (Arora), up to 2.5cm across, nearly spherical, "coarsely lobed, with several deep, close folds"; salmon color; minutely villose, (Gilkey), pinkish to reddish brown; covered with fine short hairs, (Trudell)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  complex convoluted^ (Arora), "white or yellowish, penetrated by long labyrinthine, branching, narrow canals, the walls lined by hymenium; canals hollow but often so narrow that the tips of opposite paraphyses come in contact", (Gilkey)
STEM  none
ODOR  typically strong garlic odor when mature^ (Arora), somewhat garlic-like, but pungent, (Trudell)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  often inside rotten wood, (Arora), leaf mold (Gilkey), in montane conifer forests (Trudell)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores round, minutely spiny; asci inamyloid, (Arora), spores 25-32 x 25-32 microns, nearly round, minutely papillose, brown, (Gilkey)^, asci 8-spored, 200 x 28-32 microns, cylindric; canals often so narrow that tips of opposite paraphyses come into contact, (Gilkey)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with the form of a brain', from 'cerebrum' (Latin) meaning 'brain'
SIMILAR  Hydnotrya variiformis also has a complex or convoluted interior (at least in large specimens), a fondness for growing inside rotten wood, and inamyloid asci, but H. cerebriformis has a more consistently complex or convoluted interior (not unlike Geopora cooperi), is usually slightly darker (dull reddish-brown to purple-brown), typically has a strong garlicky odor when mature, and has round minutely spiny spores, (Arora). Geopora cooperi has a fuzzy exterior. Genabea cerebriformis has warts. See also SIMILAR section of Hydnotrya inordinata, Hydnotrya subnix, and Hydnotrya tulasnei.
SOURCES  Arora(1), Gilkey(3), Trudell(4)*, Jumpponen(1), Fogel(7), O'Donnell(2), Trappe(13)
93
FAMILY  Discinaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hydnotrya cubispora  (E.A. Bessey & B.E. Thomps.) Gilkey^  Ore. St. Monogr. Bot. 1: 23. 1939;  Genea cubispora  E.A. Bessey & B.E. Thomps.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Hydnotrya cubispora is a brownish to pinkish-cinnamon usually terrestrial species with a more or less hollow (but lobed) interior and microscopic characters including spores that are often cubical when young (as in the asci), becoming round by maturity, an outer spore wall that is irregularly thickened, and 8-spored asci.^ It is infrequent among truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Hydnotrya cubispora has been found western WA and OR to the eastern US (Trappe(13)). It is found in OR, AK, the Great Lakes region, and northeastern North America, (Smith). It has been recorded from OR, NB, NS, AK, ME, MI, and TN, (Gilkey). Distribution is southern AK south to OR, and NF and QC south to WV and west to MI, (Trappe, M.(3)). There are R. Bandoni collections from BC at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-2cm across, "somewhat lobed with a single opening to the interior"; pale pinkish buff to pinkish cinnamon^, (Smith), 0.5-2cm across, "somewhat lobed and folded, with typically a single opening, rarely more"; "pale pinkish buff" or "pinkish cinnamon" or "isabella color" (colors from Ridgway); "the outer surface minutely villose", (Gilkey), "rounded to irregular, much infolded to form large canals and chambers within"; pinkish brown to brown, (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "basically empty but irregular due to lobing of fruiting body"^, (Smith), "the cavity generally simple but somewhat irregular from the surface lobing", (Gilkey)
STEM  
ODOR  mild^ (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  mild^ (Trappe, M.(3))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in mixed woods^ (Smith), sandy soil and leaf mold in mixed woods (Gilkey), usually terrestrial (Arora), with Pinus (pine), Abies (fir), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Picea (spruce); March to November (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 30-60 microns, brown, +/- cubical when young (as in asci), becoming +/- round by maturity, outer spore wall irregularly thickened^; asci 8-spored, cylindric, arranged in palisade, (Smith), spores 30-60 microns, the terminal spore conspicuously elongated and occasionally reaching 90 microns; so crowded when young that they appear cubic, many retaining cubic shape when mature, epispore irregularly thickened, uniseriate; mature asci cylindric, narrowed and truncate at apex; paraphyses exceeding the asci by 100-120 microns, filiform, somewhat swollen; peridium 240-500 microns thick, "the outer layer of pseudoparenchyma changing within to prosenchyma and tangled hyphae", (Gilkey), spores 30-48(60) x 25-30 microns "including the thick epispore, rumpled-cylindrical but appearing more or less rectangular in cross section, brown at maturity", (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with cubic spores' 
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(4), Gilkey(3), Arora(1), Trappe, M.(3)* (and spores shown), Trappe(13)
94
FAMILY  Discinaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hydnotrya inordinata  Trappe & Castellano^  Mycotaxon 75: 167. 2000
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Hydnotrya inordinata is characterized by small, convoluted to enfolded fruiting bodies and large spores with disorderly ornamentation. Other features include gray-pink pubescent fruitbodies that become dark red-brown and smooth, the canals and locules lined with pink-white that becomes dark red-brown as spores mature, underground growth associated with the roots of conifers, and microscopic characters including (6-)8-spored asci.^ It is rare among truffles in the Pacific Northwest. RANGE Hydnotrya inordinata is endemic to OR (Castellano), occurring in the Cascade Mountains at relatively high elevations (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.8-3cm across, irregular, convoluted and infolded with one or a few openings from the interior; gray-pink becoming dark red-brown; pubescent becoming more or less smooth, "but with soil and organic matter adhering to the surface at maturity"^, (Trappe)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  complex, with folds forming canals and locules 0.05-0.3cm broad, trama [flesh] colored as surface of fruiting body or paler, the canals and locules lined with pink-white which becomes dark red-brown as spores mature^, (Trappe)
STEM  
ODOR  not distinctive^ (Trappe)
TASTE  not distinctive^ (Trappe)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  usually associated with roots of Abies amabilis, Pinus contorta, Pseudotsuga menziesii, and Tsuga heterophylla from 1100m to 2000m elevation, March, April, July^, (Castellano), underground under mature Abies amabilis (Pacific Silver Fir) and Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock) at about 1800m elevation, July, (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 20-30 x 20-28 microns in water excluding ornamentation, 2-5 microns larger in KOH mounts, round to elliptic, ornamentation of crowded, flexuous [wavy], tapered spines 2-3(4) x 0.2-1 microns, "these sometimes erect and free but more often disorderly and mucilage embedded, aggregated into clusters or collapsed into indistinct mats, young spores often with surface deposits of brown amorphous material", spore walls +/- 1 microns thick, spore contains a single large droplet, spore color nearly colorless when young, brown-yellow when mature, the same in Melzer's, young spores cyanophilic, mature spores cyanophilic or not, uniseriate^; asci (6-)8-spored, "cylindric, mostly born in a hymenium but many also embedded in the subhymenium", colorless, straight to sinuous, fragile and mostly breaking under pressure in microscopic mounts, +/-300 x 25-33 microns with a long tapered base, the apex rounded, the lateral walls +/- 1 micron thick, "the walls immediately below the apex thickened up to 3 microns, the apex itself thin-walled and neither pored nor operculate, pale yellow in Melzer's reagent"; paraphyses crowded, 4-6 microns wide, septate, colorless, thin-walled, "the cells below the tips not or only slightly inflated", the tips clavate and inflated to 5-8(10) microns, "exceeding the asci by 70-100 microns and completely enclosing them"; gleba with a medullary excipulum (trama) up to 0.1cm thick, of hyphae 4-8(10) microns wide at septa, tightly interwoven, colorless, mostly thin-walled, occasional cells inflated to 5-15(30) microns, subhymenium "similar to medullary excipulum except cells generally not inflated"; peridium 120-180 microns thick, ectal excipulum of peridium 40-75 microns thick, of colorless to yellow, spherical to ellipsoid cells and obtuse to clavate, emergent hyphal tips 10-38 microns wide, the walls 0.5-2.5 microns thick, "the cells generally aligned in radiate rows", ental excipulum of peridium 40-120 microns thick, of hyphae 5-12 microns wide at the septa, interwoven, colorless to yellow, mostly thin-walled, the cells mostly inflated to 8-30 microns, as fruitbody matures "scattered cells and lengths of aseptate hyphae filling with brown, amorphous pigment", (Trappe)
NAME ORIGIN  means "disorderly" in reference to the spore ornamentation^, (Trappe)
SIMILAR  Hydnotrya cerebriformis is larger with smaller spores and the spiny ornamentation is relatively orderly, (Trappe).
SOURCES  Trappe(2), Castellano(1)*, Trappe(13)
95
FAMILY  Discinaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hydnotrya michaelis  (E. Fisch.) Trappe^  Mycotaxon 2(1): 113. 1975
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a somewhat spherical, yellow, yellow-brown to red-brown underground fruitbody divided into brain-like lobes, 2) an outer surface that is smooth to finely downy, 3) an interior that in cross-section is ocher-yellow to purple-brown, and labyrinthine with broad channels that lack an outside connection, 4) a pleasant to garlicky odor, 5) an association with conifers, and 6) microscopic characters.^ The description derived from www.grzyby.pl accessed May 17, 2012. It is infrequent among truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE The known distribution of Hydnotrya michaelis is the OR and WA Cascade Mountains to the Rocky Mountains, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-3(5)cm across; somewhat spherical, divided into a couple of cerebriform lobes (reminding one of Helvella); yellow, yellow-brown to red-brown; smooth or finely pubescent^, (www.grzyby.pl)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  in cross section irregularly labyrinthine, ocher-yellow to purple-brown, with broad channels, without outside connection; hymenium formed on the surface of the lobes^ (www.grzyby.pl)
STEM  
ODOR  initially pleasant, later like garlic^ (www.grzyby.pl)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  mycorrhizal with Pinaceae (Trappe(13))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 20-42 x 15-30 microns, elliptic, smooth at first, becoming roughened when mature, red-brown, with one or two droplets; asci 8-spored^ (www.grzyby.pl)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  http://www.grzyby.pl/gatunki/Hydnotrya_michaelis.htm, accessed May 17, 2012, Trappe(13)
96
FAMILY  Discinaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hydnotrya subnix  Trappe & Castellano^  Mycotaxon 75: 169. 2000
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a dark red brown irregular convoluted fruiting body growing underground, 2) an interior consisting of canals and locules lined the same color as the outside, 3) a spicy garlic odor and taste, and 4) round spores with mucilage-covered spines and soon covered by an amorphous brown irregular warty partial reticulum, and 5) mostly 8-spored asci.^ It is rare among truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Hydnotrya subnix is endemic to WA and known from single site in Skamania County (Castellano(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  5-6.5cm across, irregular to deeply convoluted and infolded, lacking openings from interior; dark red-brown; bald to minutely roughened^, (Trappe(2))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  complex, with folds forming canals and locules 0.1-1cm broad, colored as surface of fruiting body, the canals and locules lined with concolorous hymenial surface, the tips of the paraphyses exceeding the asci and colored white to pale red-brown^, (Trappe(2))
STEM  
ODOR  strongly of spicy garlic^ (Trappe(2))
TASTE  strongly of spicy garlic^ (Trappe(2))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  usually in association with roots of Abies amabilis (Pacific Silver Fir) at 1000m elevation, June^, (Castellano), subhypogeous [partly underground] under a small, receding, icy snow bank +/- 10cm thick, near Abies amabilis, about 950m elevation, June, (Trappe(2))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 23-30 microns in diameter excluding ornamentation in water and KOH, round to rarely elliptic, ornamentation when young of minute, crowded, mucilage-embedded spines about 1 micron tall, "the spines soon covered by an amorphous, brown, irregular, warty partial reticulum 3-5 microns tall, the ridges and warts 0.5-4 microns broad", spore walls about 1 micron thick, with large single droplet at maturity, in Melzer's reagent spores yellow when young and orange-brown when mature, young spores cyanophilic, older spores cyanophilic or not, uniseriate^; asci mostly 8-spored, 300-340 x 25-40 microns with a long tapered base, cylindric, mostly from hymenium but some also embedded in subhymenium, colorless, straight to sinuous, the apex rounded, lateral walls about 0.5-1 micron thick but immediately below apex 2 microns, apex thin-walled and neither pored nor operculate, pale yellow in Melzer's reagent; paraphyses crowded, 4-6 microns in diameter, septate, colorless, thin-walled, "the cells below the tips not or only slightly inflated", the tips clavate and inflated to 5-8(10) microns, "exceeding the asci by 80-130 microns and completely enclosing them"; gleba with a medullary excipulum (trama) 300-500 microns thick, of hyphae 4-8(10) microns wide at the septa, tightly interwoven, colorless, mostly thin-walled, occasional cells inflated to 5-15(30) microns, "scattered cells and lengths of hyphae with brown contents", subhymenium "similar to medullary excipulum except cells not generally inflated"; peridium 130-300 microns thick, ectal excipulum of peridium 40-60 microns thick, a palisade of colorless, obtuse to clavate, tapered, and irregular emergent hyphal tips 5-15(25) microns wide, the wall thin to 1 micron thick, occasional cells with brown contents, ental excipulum of peridium 90-250 microns thick, of hyphae 5-12 microns wide at the septa, colorless to brown, interwoven to radiate, mostly thin-walled, the cells mostly inflated to 8-30(40) microns, "scattered cells and lengths of sparingly septate hyphae with brown contents", (Trappe(2))
NAME ORIGIN  means "under snow", in reference to the occurrence of the type under a melting snow bank in spring^, (Trappe)
SIMILAR  Robust specimens of Hydnotrya cerebriformis are similar but have larger spores and the spines on the spores remain visible at maturity (spines in H. subnix become hidden under mucilaginous reticulum) (Trappe(2), using Gilkey 1939).
SOURCES  Trappe(2), Castellano(1)*, Trappe(13)
97
FAMILY  Discinaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hydnotrya tulasnei  Berk. & Broome^  Ann. Mag. Nat. Hist. 18: 78. 1846
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include irregularly spherical fruitbodies up to 4cm across, reddish brown with wrinkled pitted surface, interior folds forming maze-like cavities, and microscopic characters including irregularly round, coarsely papillose spores on 8-spored asci.^ It is infrequent among truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Hydnotrya tulasnei is found in western OR, Europe, and Japan, (Trappe(13)). In the US it is "recorded mostly from the northeast and northwest coastal forests, but also occasional in the mountains", (Trappe, M.(3)). Smith gives a distribution for the Great Lakes eastward, but it was reported from OR by Fogel(8), and there are several reports from OR to the Oregon Truffling Society. It also occurs in ME, PA, MI, and the United Kingdom, (Gilkey).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-4cm across, more or less convoluted; brown^, (Smith), up to 4cm across, irregularly spherical; reddish brown; downy, with wrinkled and pitted surface, (Dennis), 1-4cm across, more or less convolute; brown, (Gilkey), "rounded to irregular, furrowed"; brown to purplish brown, (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  complex, with anastomosing folds forming canals and chambers^, (Smith), permeated by maze-like cavities communicating with the exterior; pinkish or russet, (Dennis), consisting of anastomosing folds forming canals and chambers (Gilkey), pink at first, later colored as outer surface, "with canals and scattered, small, open chambers", (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  
ODOR  odoriferous when mature (Arora), musty (Dennis), faintly pungent to garlicky when young, becoming musty and unpleasant when old, (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  avoid alcohol beverages when eating this species (Trappe, M.(3))
HABITAT  developed in the surface layers of woodland soils, both coniferous and hardwood^, (Dennis), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) (Trappe(13)), with Pinus (pine), Abies (fir), Pseudotsuga, Tsuga (hemlock), (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 30-44 microns, irregularly round, coarsely papillose^; asci mostly cylindric, 8-spored, (Smith), spores 20-35 microns, round, reddish brown, with large and irregular warts up to 7 microns high, spores usually irregularly arranged; asci in a hymenium lining the cavities, 8-spored, up to 230 x 70 microns, clavate; paraphyses longer than asci and sometimes meeting across the cavities, slender, (Dennis), spores 30-44 microns, irregularly round, coarsely papillose or lobed, uniseriate to irregularly arranged; asci clavate to cylindric; paraphyses somewhat swollen at tips, (Gilkey), spores 30-44 microns in diameter, irregularly round "but appearing angular when packed tightly together in asci", "ornamented with an amorphous, rounded-warty outer layer", brown at maturity, (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  "in honor of the pioneering nineteenth-century French truffle taxonomists, the brothers Rene and Charles Tulasne (Rene wrote the species descriptions; Charles painted beautifully detailed illustrations of them)" (Trappe, M.(3), acute accent on second e in Rene)
SIMILAR  Hydnotrya cerebriformis is similar and also brown to reddish-brown, but H. tulasnei has coarsely warted spores (Arora).
SOURCES  Smith(4), Dennis(1), Gilkey(3), Arora(1), Courtecuisse(1)*, Fogel(8), Trappe, M.(3)* (and showing spores), Trappe(13)
98
FAMILY  Discinaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hydnotrya variiformis  Gilkey^  Mycologia 39: 444. 1947
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to lobed minutely velvety fruitbody that is whitish to yellowish or brownish, 2) an interior varying from a simple cavity with a prominent opening to a very convoluted interior, whitish at first but the fertile tissue often brownish to pinkish orange at maturity, 3) growth in soil or inside very rotten wood, and 4) microscopic characters including elliptic spores that are pitted and wrinkled, borne on typically 8-spored asci.^ Var. variiformis is orange brown, and var. pallida is white to cream when young and pale, dull orange when fully mature, (Trappe, M.(3)). Hydnotrya variiformis is common among truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It is found from southern BC to northern CA and the Rocky Mountains, (Trappe(13)). It has been reported frequently from OR to the Oregon Truffling Society. It was reported from WA by Jumpponen(1), from OR by J. Smith et al., from WY by Fogel(7), and given for OR, CA, and WY by Gilkey(3). There are collections from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre and the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.7-4cm across, spherical to somewhat flattened, depressed or lobed; minutely velvety, whitish to creamy to buff or yellowish to cinnamon-buff or brownish, not warted^, (Arora), 0.7-3cm across, more or less spherical to somewhat depressed; "cinnamon-buff" to "cream-buff" (colors from Ridgway); minutely velvety, (Gilkey(2)), white to cream when young and pale, dull orange when fully mature (Trappe, M.(3) for var. pallida)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "variable in configuration, but small specimens often containing a simple cavity with a prominent opening, and larger ones usually with several chambers or narrow, branching canals formed by crowding and infolding of the outer wall; canals usually empty but their sides often fused; white or pallid but the hymenium (fertile tissue) often brownish to pinkish-orange at maturity"^, (Arora), "simple with a single opening to complexly convolute and internally divided into many cavities with several openings"; somewhat paler than exterior, (Gilkey(3)), from "simple cavity and conspicuous opening" to "extremely lobed with interior cavity reduced to many small chambers and narrow branching canals among crowded and fused folds, opening obscurely to the surface at several points", (Gilkey(2)), interior "convoluted with several chambers, tissue fragile and brittle", (Trappe, M.(3) for var. pallida)
STEM  none
ODOR  not distinctive^ (Trappe, M.(3) for var. pallida)
TASTE  not distinctive^ (Trappe, M.(3) for var. pallida)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single or in groups in soil or inside very rotten wood under conifers in Sierra Nevada, Cascades, and other western mountains^, (Arora), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Pinus (pine), and Abies (fir), "often in well-decomposed wood and other organic materials on the forest floor"; May to October, (Trappe, M.(3) for var. pallida)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores "32-36 x 24-28 microns, elliptical, smooth becoming minutely pitted and wrinkled at maturity, yellowish-brown under the microscope"^, non-amyloid asci in palisade that lines the canals or cavity, typically 8 spored, (Arora), spores 32-36 x 24-28 microns, elliptic, minutely and irregularly lacunose-rugose, yellow-brown, uniseriate when mature; asci 240-280 microns long, somewhat clavate at first, becoming cylindric; paraphyses 6 microns wide, extending 120-140 microns beyond asci, slightly enlarged at tip; cortex pseudoparenchymatous without, changing to "intertwined, branching hyphae running perpendicular to asci", (Gilkey(2)), 25-30 x 10-15 microns, elliptic, "colorless to pale yellow and enclosed in an amorphous sheath decorated with scattered, tiny pits", (Trappe, M.(3) for var. pallida)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin "vari-" meaning "variable" and "-formis" meaning "form", for its highly variable shaped, (Trappe, M.(1))
SIMILAR  Hydnotrya cerebriformis is similar in having a complex or convoluted interior (at least in large specimens), fondness for growing inside rotten wood, and non-amyloid asci, but H. cerebriformis has a more consistently complex or convoluted interior (not unlike Geopora cooperi), is usually slightly darker (dull reddish-brown to purple-brown), typically has a strong garlicky odor when mature, and has round minutely spiny spores. Geopora cooperi has a fuzzy exterior. Genabea cerebriformis has warts.
SOURCES  Arora(1), Gilkey(2), Gilkey(3), Jumpponen(1), Smith, J.E.(1), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)*, Fogel(7)
99
FAMILY  Hymenogastraceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hymenogaster alnicola  A.H. Sm.^  Mycologia 58: 113. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include irregularly shaped fruitbody with surface white and cottony at first, later variegated snuff brown and pallid olivaceous yellow, spore mass pallid becoming grayish brown, rudimentary columella cushion-shaped with branches, faintly fragrant odor, underground growth under alder, and microscopic characters including fusoid spores with wrinkles that are not longitudinally oriented, the basidia 2-spored and 4-spored^; infrequent, ID to western OR and northern CA, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH slightly brownish on surface, FeSO4 greenish on surface, internally FeSO4 gives distinctly olive reaction, although it is not clear from the description whether this refers to the columella or to the interior as a whole^, (Smith(27))
OUTER SURFACE  1-1.5cm across, irregular, white and cottony when fresh, later variegated snuff brown and pallid olivaceous yellow^, (Smith(4)), 1-1.5cm across, very irregular in shape; white-cottony when fresh from a thin coating of hyphae but this disappears leaving color variegated snuff-brown and pallid olivaceous yellow; fruitbody fragile when dried and the white young peridium dries dark tan, (Smith(27))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  pallid becoming grayish brown, dull cinnamon as dried^, (Smith(4)), pallid when fresh becoming near "wood-brown" (Ridgway color), drying dull cinnamon; chambers small, (Smith(27))
STEM  columella rudimentary: cushion-shaped, radiate-branched from the top of the cushion^, (Smith(27)) 
ODOR  faintly fragrant^, (Smith(27)) 
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection underground under alder in July^, (Smith(27)), mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest Alnus (alder), (Trappe) 
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16-20(24) x (8)9-12(13) microns, broadly fusoid, with a slight to distinct beak, with an outer loose wrinkled layer, the wrinkles not longitudinally oriented, in Melzer's reagent very dark bay-brown, in KOH dingy tawny, sterigmal appendage weak but distinct^; basidia 2-spored and 4-spored, 30-35 x 6-8(9) microns, narrowly clavate, basidioles resembling immature basidia; cystidia none; subhymenium cellular, the cells 5-10 microns in diameter; tramal plates of subparallel hyphae 3-7 microns wide, some yellow oleiferous hyphae present that are 8-13 microns wide; context "prosenchymatous with some inflated cells present, and a laticiferous system with some elements with reticulate content and some homogeneous and ochraceous"; peridium 2-layered, epicutis of peridium composed of hyphae 4-7 microns, appressed, septate, the cells 2-3 times as long as wide, with yellow incrusting pigment on the walls, subcutis of peridium of inflated colorless to ochraceous cells 8-15 microns in diameter, thin-walled, (yellow as revived in KOH); clamp connections present but rare, (Smith(27)) 
NAME ORIGIN  means 'living with alder'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(27), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
100
FAMILY  Hymenogastraceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hymenogaster boozeri  Zeller & C.W. Dodge^  Ann. Mo. Bot. Gard. 21: 653. 1934
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include depressed-spherical fruitbody with surface whitish staining brownish, spore mass pallid to grayish brown, cheese-like odor, underground growth under oak, and microscopic characters including large fusoid spores on 2-spored basidia, hymenial cystidia, thick-walled brown hyphae 8-16 microns wide in peridial context, along with sphaerocyst-like cells, and lack of clamp connections^; common, western WA and OR, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-1.5cm across, depressed-spherical, whitish staining brownish where touched; smooth^, (Dodge) 
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  pallid to grayish brown drying cinnamon buff^, (Smith(4)), with large cavities, almost white to grayish brown, drying cinnamon buff (Dodge)
STEM  columella not noted^ (Smith(4))
ODOR  of fresh specimens cheese-like ^(Smith(4)), odor "like cheese (fermentation)", (Dodge)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest Corylus (hazel), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe), under Quercus (oak), April, (Smith(4))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 26-35(40) x 9.5-15 microns, elongate-fusoid, wrinkled longitudinally on outer layer, inner wall 1-1.5 microns thick and fulvous, "tapered to a subacute apex but not beaked or only slightly so", in Melzer's reagent fulvous^; basidia 2-spored, 8.5-11 microns wide, clavate, colorless to ochraceous in KOH; cystidia rare, 30-40 x 8-12 microns, narrowly fusoid, "apices acute, smooth, thin-walled, originating in subhymenium"; subhymenium "mostly of filamentous intricately interwoven hyphae"; epicutis of peridium composed of hyphae 3-6 microns wide, very much branched, yellowish in KOH and in Melzer's reagent; context of hyphae 8-16 microns wide, somewhat thick-walled, ochraceous brown, many cells inflated to 25-30 microns, "interhyphal debris present and some incrustation on many hyphae"; clamp connections not seen, (Smith(27)), sterigmata very short (about 2-3 microns), stout, (Dodge)
NAME ORIGIN  after L.M. Boozer, who found the type
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Dodge(2), Smith(4), Smith(27), Trappe(13)
101
FAMILY  Hymenogastraceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hymenogaster farinaceus  A.H. Sm.^  Mycologia 58: 115. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  "The diagnostic features of this species are the dull grayish brown color when fresh, farinaceous taste, greenish gray reaction of tramal plates and columella in FeSO4, the bister spores revived in KOH with their very inconspicuous sterigmal appendage ... the abundant sphaerocysts in the peridial context and lack of clamp connections", (Smith(27))^; described from MI by Smith, reported for OR to Oregon Truffling Society, but not included in Trappe(13)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  tramal plates and columella greenish gray in FeSO4^ (Smith(27))
OUTER SURFACE  1-1.5cm across, 0.8-1cm high, "flattened, surface wrinkled and furrowed toward point of attachment and broadly lobed"; "grayish, silky, pale dull grayish brown fresh"^, (Smith(27))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  dull cinnamon, chambers elongate and sinuous^, (Smith(27))
STEM  columella rudimentary, in the form of a short basal pulvinate [cushion-shaped] protuberance about 0.1cm high, pallid in section; attached at base of columella but no root or obvious rhizomorph^, (Smith(27))
ODOR  subfarinaceous [somewhat farinaceous]^, (Smith(27))
TASTE  strongly farinaceous^ (Smith(27))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under hardwoods (oak, maple, and basswood mixed) with pine and hemlock nearby, July^, (Smith(4) for MI), gregarious and emergent on a roadway, "trees within 100 ft. of the spot where the specimens were found were one oak, two beeches, three maples, with hemlock and pine some distance away", (Smith(27))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 13.5-18(20) x 10-13 microns, oval, verrucose-rugulose [warty-wrinkled], bister revived in KOH, "very inconspicuous sterigmal appendage (one may at first be misled into thinking the apical beak is the sterigmal appendage)"^; basidia 40-45 x 8-9 microns, mostly 2-spored, subcylindric, colorless, thin-walled, brachybasidioles present in hymenium; cystidia none; subhymenium cellular 2-4 cells deep; tramal plates consisting of a central strand of hyphae 4-9 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, thin-walled; context a mixture of filaments and areas of sphaerocysts up to 25 microns in diameter "and the walls yellowish in KOH, at times appearing to be composed mainly of sphaerocysts", their walls thin, smooth, and colorless to ochraceous in KOH; peridium with a cutis of hyphae 3-6 microns wide, appressed, colorless, nongelatinous, smooth; clamp connections absent, (Smith(27))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'farinaceous', presumably referring to taste
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(27), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
102
FAMILY  Hymenogastraceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hymenogaster gardneri  Zeller & C.W. Dodge^  Ann. Mo. Bot. Gard. 21(4): 649. 1934
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) an irregular, dingy white fruitbody that becomes brown and has a smooth to flocculent surface that is soon checked or cracked, 2) a spore mass that is firm, watery, and brown, 3) underground growth under oak in spring, and 4) microscopic characters including elliptic to spindle-shaped spores that are dark brown and warty-wrinkled with distinct longitudinal folds, the basidia 2-spored and 4-spored.^ Smith regards Zeller 8466 as being this species, and describes it along with the type because of the incomplete information available from the type, saying, "The spores are not as conspicuously ornamented as in the type but in this group (the large spored species) I hesitate to emphasize the difference. Zeller's collection was made from under maple in May at Comstock, Oregon. This habitat and the vernal fruiting period are consistent with the type." (Smith(27)). Because of the uncertainty, both microscopic descriptions are used here. It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Hymenogaster gardneri occurs from western OR to northern CA, (Trappe(13)). The type is from CA and Zeller 8466 from OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-15cm [note type description says 1-1.5cm], irregular; dingy white becoming brown; smooth to flocculent, soon checked or cracked at surface^, (Smith(4)), 1-1.5cm in diameter, irregular in shape, very firm and compact; "at first dirty white, becoming brown, drying buff-brown"; checking and cracking, surface smooth to flocculent, (Dodge)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  firm, watery; brown^, (Smith(4)), firm, watery; brown; cavities relatively small, (Dodge)
STEM  columella not noted^ (Smith(4))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in clay soil under oak (Smith(4) for CA), in clay soil under Quercus (oak) and Salix (willow), March, (Dodge)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 24-31 x 14-18 microns, elliptic to subfusoid [somewhat spindle-shaped], +/- beaked, "warty-wrinkled with distinct longitudinal folds"^; "cuticle of peridium of interwoven hyphae"; clamp connections absent, (Smith(4)), "spores very dark brown, broad-ellipsoid, tapering to both ends, epispore smooth, thick, but with a very dark, rough, torn utricle with more or less longitudinal folds as shown by immature spores, pedicellate, 18.5-26 x 11.5-14 microns"; basidia 2-spored and 4-spored, narrowly clavate; "septa of colorless prosenchyma, drying 10-20 microns thick"; peridium of tough, colorless, homogeneous prosenchyma, "with flocci of hyphae on the surface, drying 80-150 microns thick", (Dodge), spores 24-31 x 14-18 microns, elliptic to subfusoid and more or less beaked, "coarsely wrinkled but at most only obscurely longitudinally ridged, varying to verrucose-wrinkled", sterigmal appendage usually prominent, spores bister in Melzer's reagent, rusty brown in KOH, outer layer merely ochraceous, "inner layer thick, homogeneous and dark tawny in KOH, no obvious plugs or canals extending through the outer layer"; peridium "of interwoven nongelatinous hyphae yellowish in KOH, cuticular region without any clear differentiation as a layer"; clamp connections not seen, (Smith(27) for type), spores 19-25 x 11-15 microns, varying from elliptic with a beak and sterigmal appendage to broadly fusoid, near bister in Melzer's reagent, dark rusty brown in KOH, "outer layer wrinkled-verrucose but in distinct longitudinal folds, the layer 0.5-2 microns thick as revived in KOH", "inner wall dark rusty brown in KOH and homogeneous, 2-2.5 microns thick", beak when present smooth and solid; basidia 4-spored, 28-36 x 9-12 microns, the sterigmata often clavate when immature; tramal plates of hyphae 3-6 microns, interwoven, thin-walled, of more or less equal width throughout their length; subhymenium cellular when mature, the cells 4-12 microns in diameter; "Epicutis of peridium a loosely interwoven layer of hyaline thin-walled hyphae 3-7 microns in diam, rarely a few hyphae with somewhat thickened walls slightly refractive in KOH, individual hyphae yellowish in Melzer's sol.; context of peridium of interwoven hyphae 4-12 microns in diam; with sphaerocysts up to 22 microns diam singly or in chains or in groups; hyphal walls lacking incrustations but some hyphae contain amorphous refractive material"; clamp connections absent, (Smith(27) for Zeller 8466)
NAME ORIGIN  after N.L. Gardner, who found the type^, (Dodge)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Dodge(2), Smith(4), Smith(27), Trappe(13)
103
FAMILY  Hymenogastraceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hymenogaster gilkeyae  Zeller & C.W. Dodge^  Ann. Mo. Bot. Gard. 21(4): 649. 1934.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a nearly spherical to irregular, white to grayish fruitbody with a smooth to silky surface, 2) a spore mass that is dark umber, 3) a sterile base that is cushion-shaped to conic, 4) an odor of musty flowers and witch-hazel, 5) underground growth under Aesculus and oak, and 6) beaked spores 16-22 x 11-14 microns that are warty at first and warty-wrinkled when old, 7) 2-spored, and according to Dodge(2) also 4-spored basidia.^ It is common among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Hymenogaster gilkeyae has been found at least in OR and CA, (Smith(4)). Distribution is southwestern WA to northern CA, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across, nearly spherical to irregular, "white to grayish, drying pale buff"; smooth to silky^, (Smith(4)), 1-2.5cm across, depressed-spherical to irregular; snow white to grayish, drying "cartridge-buff" to "cream-buff" (Ridgway colors); smooth to silky, (Dodge)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  dark umber when fresh, drying "snuff brown" (Ridgway color)^, (Dodge) 
STEM  sterile base pulvinate [cushion-shaped] to conic^, (Dodge)
ODOR  of musty flowers and witch-hazel^ (Dodge)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  mycorrhizal host in Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe), in mixed woods and under Aesculus and Quercus, November to April, (Dodge)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16-22 x 11-14 microns, elliptic to subfusoid, with a distinct beak, warted to warty-wrinkled^, "cuticle of peridium of loosely interwoven hyphae with some free ends projecting", clamp connections absent, (Smith(4)), spores 15-22 x 10-11 microns, oval-citriform [oval - lemon-shaped], "with prominent apiculus and pedicel, at first with utricle which sloughs ragged, leaving verrucose surface"; basidia 2-spored and 4-spored, sterigmata short, stout; septa 37-56 microns thick, of colorless prosenchyma of vesicular cells, scissile at angles; peridium colorless, "homogeneous, prosenchymatous, 130-200 microns thick with a very thin stupose surface", (Dodge), spores 16-22 x 11-14 microns, elliptic to subfusoid, "with a beak and a sterigmal appendage 3-5 microns long and claw-like", outer wall layer warty with no sign of longitudinal furrows, ochraceous in KOH, "the outer layer at first continuous but with plugs extending to surface, in age this layer warty-wrinkled", inner wall homogeneous and rusty ochraceous in KOH, 1.5-2.5 microns thick, spores in Melzer's reagent yellow-brown; basidia 2-spored, 23-30 x 7-9 microns, "narrowly clavate, readily collapsing, projecting when sporulating", cystidium-like structures present and "fusoid-ventricose with obtuse apices (these are suspected of being immature basidia)"; subhymenium of sphaerocysts up to 25 microns in diameter; tramal plates with a central strand of hyphae 3-5 microns wide, or up to 10 microns, with occasional cells up to 15 microns and sphaerocyst-like; "context of interwoven hyphae with enlarged cells scattered or in groups, all pale dingy buff as revived in KOH"; epicutis of peridium of hyphae 2-5 microns wide, loosely interwoven, narrow, with some free ends projecting but no true turf or trichodermium; clamp connections absent, (Smith(27))
NAME ORIGIN  after H.M. Gilkey, who made one of the early collections
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Dodge(2), Smith(27), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
104
FAMILY  Hymenogastraceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hymenogaster glacialis  Cazares & Trappe^  Mycotaxon 38: 246. 1990
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  distinguished from other Hymenogaster species by small size, the fleeting, thin peridium, and the relatively large locules of the spore mass, other features include somewhat spherical, sordid white fruitbody with felty surface, deep brown spore mass, absent columella (but some young fruitbodies may have sterile tissue at base), and microscopic characters including elliptic spores with warty-wrinkled ornamentation, on 4-spored basidia^; description derived from Cazares(3), rare, Chelan County, WA, (Trappe(13)), described from WA
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.3-0.6cm across, somewhat spherical; sordid white, unchanging on drying; surface felty
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  'deep brown', locules irregularly shaped and up to 0.1cm in diameter, randomly arranged
STEM  columella absent, but some young fruitbodies have cottony sterile tissue at base
ODOR  not distinctive
TASTE  not determined
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground under stones in wet area among dwarf Salix roots in raw moraine
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15-18(19) x (11)12-15(16) microns including ornamentation (but not beak or pedicel), broadly elliptic to elliptic, ornamentation warty-wrinkled and up to 2 microns tall, apex papillate, 1-3 x 1-3 microns, paler that rest of spore, not ornamented, base of spore truncate, 1-2 microns wide, in Melzer's reagent spores golden brown singly, orange brown to reddish brown in mass, in KOH brown singly and dark brown in mass^; basidia 4-spored, 20-25 x 5-9 microns, cylindric, colorless, thin-walled, clamp connections absent at base; subhymenium of 2-3 rows of colorless, thin-walled, compactly arranged, subglobose, 5-20 microns in diameter; trama 20-80 microns wide, of hyphae up to 5 microns wide, subparallel to interwoven, compact, colorless, thin-walled, nongelatinous, clamp connections absent; peridium 30-150 microns thick, evanescent [fleeting], epicutis of peridium 20-100 microns thick, of hyphae up to 5 microns at septa, colorless, thin-walled, with elongated to inflated cells up to 20 microns in diameter, subcutis of peridium 30-60 microns thick, of hyphae up to 5 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  Latin 'icy, frozen', referring to the Lyman Glacier where the type was found
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Cazares(3) (color in single quotation marks from Kelly(3)), Trappe(13)
105
FAMILY  Hymenogastraceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hymenogaster griseus  Vittad.^  Monogr. Tuberac. 23. 1831
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include small nearly spherical fruitbody that is white at first, drying cinnamon-buff to snuff-brown, the surface whitish-downy to innate-fibrillose, spore mass gray soon becoming dark and drying bister, sterile base barely visible, odor of lily-of-the-valley, growth under hardwoods, and microscopic characters including elliptic wrinkled spores 20-25 x 11-13 microns on 2-spored basidia^; collections examined from OR, Argentina, Italy, (Dodge), found in United Kingdom (Hawker(1))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-1.5cm across, nearly spherical, not shrinking much on drying; white at first, drying "cinnamon-buff" to "snuff-brown"; whitish-villous to innate-fibrillose^, (Dodge), 0.5-1.5cm across, nearly spherical, often flattened; white then red-brown; finely downy, (Buczacki)
INNER LAYER  peridium very thick^ (Buczacki)
INTERIOR  gray, soon becoming dark, drying "bister"^ (Dodge), gray to dark brown "with small to medium irregular scattered cavities", (Buczacki)
STEM  sterile base scarcely visible^ (Dodge), absent (Buczacki)
ODOR  of Convallaria majalis (European lily of the valley)^ (Dodge), lily-of-the-valley (Buczacki)
TASTE  indistinct^ (Buczacki)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Populus, Quercus (oak), and Fagus (beech)^, (Dodge), underground or at soil surface in organic soil on alkaline sites, with hardwoods, especially Fagus (beech), or with conifers; usually in large groups; summer to fall, (Buczacki)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 20-25 x 11-13 microns, elliptic, "distal end obtuse and rounded, undulating surface with a clear wrinkled utricle, brown becoming black", "pedicel 2-3 microns long, 3-4 microns in diameter"^; "basidia long, cylindric, 2-spored, sterigmata stout, 11-13 microns long"; paraphyses slender, septate; septa composed of hyphae 30-40 microns wide, thin-walled; peridium 185 microns thick, densely stupose, (Dodge), spores 19-26 x 10-14 microns, elliptic to spindle-shaped, "smooth but with persistent wrinkled outer coat", dark brown, (Buczacki)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'gray', referring probably to the color of the spore mass
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Dodge(2) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Hawker(1), Buczacki(1)* 
106
FAMILY  Hymenogastraceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hymenogaster idahoensis  A.H. Sm.^  Mycologia 58: 105. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include nearly spherical, bald, viscid fruitbody that is yellowish olive buff to dingy tan-olive, spore mass dull cinnamon, small stump-like columella, underground growth in spruce-fir forests, and microscopic characters including verrucose-roughened spores with dimensions 13-16 x 8-10 microns, 2-spored basidia, absent cystidia, clamp connections present^; most Hymenogaster species are related to Hebeloma, but this species is related to Cortinarius and will need a new name, (Trappe(13) who informally use the name "Protoglossum" for this species and Hymenogaster sublilacinus), rare, central ID, (Trappe(13)), type found in ID
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  neither KOH nor FeSO4 reacting on peridium, gleba (interior) dingy olive with FeSO4, (Smith(4))
OUTER SURFACE  2-3.5cm across, nearly spherical, thinly glutinous to viscid, evenly yellowish olive buff to dingy tan-olive^, (Smith(4)), 3-3.3cm across, irregularly near-spherical; evenly a yellowish "olive-buff" (duller and with more olive than argillaceous); bald, thinly glutinous to viscid
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  dull cinnamon, radiating from a small stump-like columella^, (Smith(4)), gleba (spore mass) "of plates radiating from a small stump-like columella 3-5 mm broad producing elongate-sinuous cavities, dull cinnamon in color"
STEM  small stump-like columella 0.3-0.5cm broad^ (Smith(27))
ODOR  mild^ (Smith(27))
TASTE  mild^ (Smith(27))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in spruce-fir forests^, (Smith(4)), type single under spruce-fir, August, (Smith(27))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 13-16 x 8-10 microns, oval to elliptic, "verrucose-roughened with apical ornamentation darker and denser", thick-walled, strongly ochraceous in KOH^; basidia "2-spored, many ochraceous in KOH"; cystidia none seen; epicutis of peridium of hyphae 2-3 microns wide, narrow, gelatinous, "arranged in a tangled layer possibly representing a collapsed trichodermium", subcutis of peridium of hyphae 4-15 microns wide, appressed, floccose, pale ochraceous; clamp connections regularly present, (Smith(27))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'from Idaho'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(27) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
107
FAMILY  Hymenogastraceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hymenogaster minimus  Zeller^  Mycologia 33: 197. 1941
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include very small size, spherical fruitbody that is translucent whitish with the dark brown color of the spore mass showing through from the 6-14 labyrinthine cavities within, sterile base apparent as a translucent spot, growth under conifers, and microscopic characters including finely verrucose dark brown spores with a closely applied colorless envelope, basidia 4-spored and according to Zeller(8) also 2-spored^; description from Zeller(8) except where noted; Smith comments, "The spores of this species resemble those of Protoglossum luteum [name in italics] Massee in structure though the size is larger and the peridial trichodermium is not gelatinous. No change in taxonomic status of this species is proposed here for lack of information on which to base an interpretation of the spore features."; Hymenogaster minimus described from OR
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  about 0.2cm across, spherical, "translucent whitish, with the dark-brown color of the spores showing through from the cavities within and more whitish over the septa of the gleba"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  dark brown; made up of several (about 6-14) labyrinthiform cavities, irregular in shape and arrangement
STEM  "sterile base barely apparent as a translucent spot" on lower part of fruitbody; "no columella or main veins apparent"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in coniferous duff
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14-16.3 x 11.5-13 microns, broadly elliptic with a small apiculus, finely verrucose, covered with a closely applied, colorless utricle, spores very dark brown (umber)^; basidia 2-spored and 4-spored, 10-12 x 5-6 microns, clavate, sterigmata very short; peridium about 80 microns thick at the thinnest places when fresh, colorless, a mesh-like network of hyphae that are 7.5-9 microns wide and septate, (Zeller), spores 16-19 x 14-18 microns, nearly round to broadly ovate, russet in KOH, bister in Melzer's reagent, "with a thick inner homogeneous rusty brown (in KOH) wall and an equally thick paler less dense outer wall through which plugs extend to surface giving the surface a punctate to subreticulate appearance, beak absent to only slightly developed, sterigmal attachment inconspicuous"; basidia and brachybasidioles 30-35 x 12-15 microns, basidia 4-spored; cystidia none; subhymenium of inflated elements 8-12 microns in diameter and 2-3 cells deep; tramal plates of hyphae 3-5 microns wide, interwoven, branching, nongelatinous, pale ochraceous, with mostly uninflated hyphal cells; context of peridium of hyphae 3-7 microns wide, compactly interwoven, yellowish in KOH; peridial cutis of inflated cells 20-40 x 12-20 microns in series, often the end-cell clavate, the walls thin, colorless in yellowish in KOH, yellow in Melzer's reagent, no incrustations seen, a few hyphae "can at times be observed over the trichodermial layer but are not regarded as an epicutis"; no laticiferous hyphae seen; clamp connections absent, (Smith(27))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'smallest' or 'very small'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Zeller(8), Smith(27)
108
FAMILY  Hymenogastraceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hymenogaster nigrescens  A.H. Sm.^  Mycologia 58: 117. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical, white, silky-fibrillose fruitbody that stains inky black on handling, the surface staining olive in FeSO4, spore mass that grayish brown or tinged purplish, absent columella, growth under conifers, and microscopic characters including broadly fusoid distinctly beaked spores that are irregularly wrinkled to warty-wrinkled, 4-spored basidia, and prosenchymatous peridium throughout^; rare, northern ID, (Trappe(13)), type collection found in ID
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  surface staining olive in FeSO4
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, "white, drying pallid to brownish but where handled inky black"; silky, dry^, (Smith(4)), 1-2cm across, spherical; white when fresh, "drying pallid to dingy brownish, when handled staining inky black"; silky, dry when fresh, (Smith(27))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "avellaneous to wood-brown (gray-brown) or tinged purplish"^, (Smith(4)), "dark avellaneous to wood brown or more purplish brown, drying dingy pallid except where stained"; "chambers small but distinct", (Smith(27))
STEM  no columella^ (Smith(27))
ODOR  none^ (Smith(27))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in conifer duff, July^, (Smith(27)) 
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 17-22 x 10-13 microns, "broadly fusoid, distinctly beaked", irregularly rugulose [finely wrinkled]^, cuticle of peridium of appressed hyphae, clamp connections absent, (Smith(4)), spores 17-22 x 10-13 microns, "broadly fusoid with a short smooth beak and a distinct sterigmal appendage", "irregularly rugulose (the outer layer) varying to warty-rugulose (lacking longitudinal valleys and ridges)"; near bister in Melzer's reagent "at first but slowly becoming dark bay-brown", russet in KOH; basidia 4-spored, 30-55 x 7.5-9 microns, subcylindric when sporulating, colorless in KOH; cystidia none; subhymenium cellular, cells thin-walled; tramal plate with a mediostratum of cells 4-9 microns in diameter, thin-walled, yellowish in KOH; "context with cells inflated to 8-12 microns in places but no groups of sphaerocysts seen"; peridium with upper cuticular zone of hyphae that are 2-5 microns wide, appressed, "mostly uninflated and yellowish in KOH, no pigment incrustations seen"; clamp connections none, (Smith(27))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'becoming black'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(4), Smith(27), Trappe(13)
109
FAMILY  Hymenogastraceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hymenogaster occidentalis  Zeller & C.W. Dodge^  Ann. Mo. Bot. Gard. 21: 668. 1934
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include small underground grooved-wrinkled fruiting body, surface pale tan flecked with red, spore mass grayish, and microscopic characters including wrinkled-warty spores borne on 2-spored or 4-spored basidia^; rare, western OR to northern CA, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-2cm across, irregular to nearly spherical, smooth to silky, pale tan flecked with red, drying dingy tan color^, (Smith(4)), 1-2cm across, sulcate-rugose [grooved-wrinkled]; pale tan, flecked with small patches of pink or red, drying "pinkish-buff" to "clay-colored"; smooth to silky; "peridium of a byssoid, stupose, or meshy fibrillose texture", (Dodge)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  grayish, drying "snuff-brown"; cavities relatively large, septa brittle, thin, papery^, (Dodge)
STEM  
ODOR  earthy^ (Dodge)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Quercus (oak) and conifers, March to May^, (Smith(4)), scattered through loose moist soil, under Quercus (oak) and Abies (fir), (Dodge), mycorrhizal host in Pacific Northwest Quercus (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 20-25 x 14-18 microns, broadly ovate to nearly elliptic, wrinkled-warty^; cuticle of peridium of interwoven hyphae, clamp connections present but often rare, (Smith(4)), spores 20-26 x 12-15 microns, mostly elliptic, "slightly broad-apiculate, sometimes maturing with a broad rounded tip, pedicel notched, short, surface warted (warts mostly retrorse) and covered by a smooth utricle"; basidia 2-spored or 4-spored, 30-34 x 4-5 microns, cylindric; septa 15-19 microns thick (74 microns including hymenia), prosenchymatous, colorless to yellowish when dry; peridium 50-100 microns thick, colorless, (Dodge), spores 20-25 x 14-18 microns, "broadly ovate to subelliptic, sterigmal appendage absent (base truncate), no appreciable beak present", "outer layer wrinkled-warty, with some tendency to longitudinal furrows", "inner layer about 2 microns thick, deeply colored and homogeneous throughout", spores bister as revived both in Melzer's reagent and in KOH; basidia 2-spored and 4-spored, 9-12 microns wide near sterigmata, "subcylindric and projecting when sporulating", brachybasidioles present, "thin-walled and nearly vesiculose"; cystidia none; subhymenium cellular; tramal plates with central strand of narrow hyphae but often some cells inflated; context of peridium "of numerous inflated thin-walled smooth cells some of which appear to be in pockets"; peridium of interwoven filaments 4-7 microns wide in cuticular zone, the walls yellowish in KOH and some debris adhering; clamp connections present but often rare, (Smith(27))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'western'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Dodge(2) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Smith(4), Smith(27), Trappe(13)
110
FAMILY  Hymenogastraceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hymenogaster olivaceus  Vittad.^  Monogr. Tuberac. 24. 1831;  Hymenogaster decorus  Tul.;  Hymenogaster pallidus  Berk. & Broome;  Hymenogaster calosporus  Tul.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include nearly spherical to irregular fruitbody that is pallid becoming dirty brown or olive-brown, its smooth to innate-fibrillose surface often rupturing deep into the spore mass, the spore mass mottled tawny and white, becoming dirty brown, mild odor and taste, underground growth under hardwoods or conifers, and microscopic characters including large, dark, elliptic spores, with a loose wrinkled covering, young spores oboval-lanceolate with prominent claw-like pedicel, 2-spored basidia, septa of colorless, gelatinous, interwoven hyphae, and peridium of large, thin-walled, varicose hyphae^; description derived from Dodge(2) except where otherwise noted; collections examined from OR, CA, Lithuania, France, Germany, Italy, Russia, Sweden, United Kingdom
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  up to 4cm across, nearly spherical to irregular; pallid, becoming dirty brown, drying "bister" to "fuscous"; smooth to innate-fibrillose, often rupturing deep into the spore-mass^, (Dodge), 0.5-2.5cm across, irregularly subspherical, often flattened, white to pale brown, then olive-brown; "smooth, shiny, thin, soon cracking", (Buczacki)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  mottled tawny and white, becoming dirty brown, drying "snuff-brown" to "bone-brown"; cavities irregular, medium small^, (Dodge), "pale brown, then darker brown with numerous small irregular scattered cavities", (Buczacki)
STEM  
ODOR  faint, mushroomy^, (Buczacki)
TASTE  indistinct^ (Buczacki)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground under hardwoods or conifers, April to January^ (Dodge), underground or at soil surface in organic soil, usually in large groups; usually in hardwood woodland with Fagus (beech), Quercus (oak), and Tilia (lime), rarely with conifers; late summer to fall, (Buczacki)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 19-29 x 12-14 microns when mature, elliptic with rounded ends, dark, "with a loose, much-wrinkled utricle, guttulate with a prominent epispore", (young spores 29-42 x 11-14 microns, oboval-lanceolate with a cylindric or capitate apiculus, prominent claw-like pedicel, smooth, covered with a clear, more or less closely applied utricle, light yellowish brown, guttulate with prominent epispore), (i.e. as the spores mature "they become shorter, the apiculus shrivels and disappears, while the utricle becomes roughly wrinkled and darker as the spore contracts")^; basidia 2-spored, slender, cylindric; septa 20-30 microns thick, colorless, of gelified interwoven hyphae; peridium 75-150 microns thick, "homogeneous, of large, thin-walled, varicose hyphae", (Dodge), spores 30-47 x 13-19 microns, "yellow-brown, elongated spindle-shaped, with sharp point and terminal appendage, smooth, but with persistent wrinkled outer coat", (Buczacki)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'olivaceous'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Dodge(2) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Buczacki(1)*
111
FAMILY  Hymenogastraceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hymenogaster pachydermis  Zeller & C.W. Dodge^  Ann. Mo. bot. Gdn 21: 637. 1934;  Chamonixia pachydermis  (Zeller & C.W. Dodge) G.W. Beaton, Pegler & T.W.K. Young  Kew Bull. 40(3): 584. 1985;  Rossbeevera pachydermis  (Zeller & C.W. Dodge) T. Lebel  [as 'Rosbeeva'], in Lebel, Orihara & Nitaro Maekawa, Fungal Diversity 52(1): 64. 2012 (proposed current name)
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  the outstanding feature is a thick peridium (outer skin) for the genus, about 0.2cm when fresh, other features include greenish yellow color in upper part when fresh (pale yellowish to almost white in lower part), firm light brown spore mass with tiny cavities at first which become larger when old, growth under alder, Eucalyptus, and beech, and microscopic characters including smooth to very finely verrucose spores 10-14 x 5-7.5 microns on 4-spored basidia^; the online Species Fungorum, accessed June 7, 2014, gave the current name as Rossbeevera pachydermis (Zeller & C.W. Dodge) T. Lebel, but MycoBank, accessed on the same date, gave the current name as Chamonixia pachydermis (Zeller & C.W. Dodge) G.W. Beaton, Pegler & T.W.K. Young; collections examined from OR, CA, Australia, New Zealand, (Dodge)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2-4cm across, 2.5-3cm high, oblate spheroidal to chestnut-shaped, firm; greenish-yellowish in upper part to pale yellowish or almost white in lower part when fresh, drying "chamois" to "buckthorn-brown" in upper part and "cartridge-buff" to "chamois" in lower part; "smooth to soft dull innate-fibrillose"; peridium very thick, 0.2cm when fresh, drying 0.04-0.06cm thick
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  firm; light brown, drying "walnut-brown" to "Vandyke brown"; cavities tiny at first becoming larger when old "(even splitting into very large hollows because of scissile septa)"
STEM  sterile base not conspicuous
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under leaves or on the ground under Alnus (alder), Eucalyptus, and Fagus (beech), November to April
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-14 x 5-7.5 microns, elliptic, oval, or oboval, smooth to very finely verrucose, 4-angled to 5-angled in cross-section, light yellowish brown^; basidia 4-spored, 10-14 x 4-5 microns, narrowly clavate; septa colorless, "of large gelified parallel hyphae, scissile with large openings at the angles, 10-20 microns thick"; peridium "dilute yellowish, homogeneous, prosenchymatous, with a surface of large loose hyphae"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'thick-skinned'
SIMILAR  Hymenogaster ruber also has a thick peridium, but is white, changing to pink to red or purple when touched, and spores are smaller with more distinct warts, (Dodge)
SOURCES  Dodge(2) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway)
112
FAMILY  Hymenogastraceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hymenogaster parksii  Zeller & C.W. Dodge^  Ann. Mo. Bot. Gard. 21: 674. 1934
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spongy, nearly spherical to ovoid fruitbody colored dirty white to gray, spore mass grayish to brownish, no columella, growth under oak and other plants, and microscopic characters including broad warty-wrinkled spores with distinct pedicel and beak, on 2-spored and 4-spored basidia^; described from CA, and Smith (4) notes report from OR, also reported commonly from OR to Oregon Truffling Society, and reported from OR by Fogel(8)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-1.5cm across, nearly spherical to ovoid, soft, spongy; dirty white to gray, drying to cinnamon-buff to clay color^, (Smith(4)), 0.5-1.5cm across, nearly spherical, soft, spongy; dirty white to gray, becoming "cinnamon-buff" to "clay-color" on drying; smooth; peridium cottony-stupose, easily torn, (Dodge), small and whitish when fresh (Arora)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  grayish, drying dark vinaceous brown^, (Smith(4)), grayish, drying "Natal brown"; cavities first developing in upper part of fruitbody; septa coarse-stupose, compact, (Dodge), grayish to ocher-brown or cinnamon-brown, (Arora)
STEM  columella not noted^ (Smith(4))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered just under leaves and through the soil about 5cm deep, under Quercus (oak) and Heteromeles arbutifolia (Christmasberry), November to April, (Dodge for California)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 18-25 x 13-17 microns, with distinct pedicel and prominent beak, warty-wrinkled^, peridium of appressed interwoven hyphae, (Smith(4)), mature spores 18.5-26 x 12.2-17 microns, oboval-citriform or elliptic-citriform, verrucose, very dark, young spores 22-24 x 11-14 microns, smooth, clear yellowish, apiculate, pedicellate; basidia 4-spored, cylindric; septa 18-25 microns thick; peridium 35-75 microns thick, colorless, (Dodge), spores 18-25 x 13-17 microns, nearly elliptic, with strong pedicel and prominent beak, near bister in Melzer's reagent, pale fulvous in KOH, inner wall thick (about 2 microns) and homogeneous, rust-colored, outer wall paler, warty-wrinkled, ending short of the prominent, smooth, solid beak; basidia 2-spored and 4-spored, brachybasidioles present between the basidia; tramal plates of interwoven, colorless hyphae; peridium a homogeneous layer of hyphae 3-8 microns wide, appressed-interwoven, ochraceous in KOH, some inflated cells present in midportion; clamp connections "absent (but present on some collections identified as this species by Zeller)", (Smith(27))
NAME ORIGIN  named after H.E. Parks, who found the type
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Dodge(2) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Smith(4), Arora(1)*, Smith(27), Fogel(8)
113
FAMILY  Hymenogastraceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hymenogaster subalpinus  A.H. Sm.^  Mycologia 58: 120. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to nearly spherical fruitbody that is dull white becoming dingy yellow from handling and finally purplish brown, 2) a spore mass that is grayish becoming vinaceous brown, 3) a rudimentary columella, 4) growth under conifers, and 5) large warty-roughened spores, 6) 2-4-spored basidia (mostly 2-spored), 7) cellular structure of the context of the peridium, and 8) a thin epicutis.^ Hymenogaster subalpinus is a common winter species in the Pacific Northwest, (Trappe, M.(3)). It is abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It is found from southern WA to northern CA and northern ID, (Trappe(13)). The type is from ID. It has been reported for OR to Oregon Truffling Society, and for AZ in States(2).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on surface yellowish brown, FeSO4 on surface very weakly olive^, (Smith(27))
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-1.2cm across, spherical to nearly spherical; dull white, becoming dingy to yellow from handling and finally dingy purplish brown; appressed fibrillose, dry; consistency crumbly, (Smith(27)), 0.5-2cm across (States), "dull brownish white to yellowish brown, bruising brown", (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  grayish becoming vinaceous brown^, (Smith(4)), 'when young dark avellaneous ("wood brown"), slowly becoming violaceous brown ("Benzo brown")', gleba is also referred to as 'purple-brown'; chambers small and round, (Smith(27)), soft; "dark brown, much of its color coming from the spores", (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  columella slight (rudimentary) present as whitish streaks in the spore mass, radiating from a basal point or small somewhat truncate sterile area; "with an inconspicuous basal rhizomorph"^, (Smith(27)), with inconspicuous basal rhizomorphs (States)
ODOR  strongly of mushrooms and pungent when old^, (States), unpleasant (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in duff under cedar-hemlock, (Smith(27)), associated with Pinus ponderosus (Ponderosa Pine), and in pine stands mixed with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Quercus gambelii (Gambel Oak), (States), with Pseudotsuga menziesii at low to middle elevations, October to March, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 17-27 x 10-15, ovate above a pedicellate base, with a rudimentary to prominent beak, "warty-roughened with patches and ridges of outer spore-wall material", rusty yellow brown in water and KOH when fresh (a few smooth spores 32 x 9 microns also present), dark rusty brown as revived in KOH^; basidia 2-spored, 30-40 x 10-15 microns, colorless; subhymenium of a cellular type, the cells 8-10 microns in diameter; tramal plates of a narrow strand of colorless thin-walled hyphae 5-10 microns wide; peridium with a thin epicutis of appressed hyphae 3-7 microns wide, "the hyphal cells not much enlarged or not at all, yellow in KOH, granular debris present in the layer (fresh state)"; "tramal body of inflated cells (almost pseudoparenchymatic) at times seeming to be in pockets", thin-walled, smooth, colorless to yellowish in KOH; clamp connections absent, (Smith(27)), spores 16-28(30) x 9-14 microns, elliptic to ovate, coarsely warted and slightly striate; basidia 2-4-spored, mostly 2-spored, "I have not found it to possess the fusoid leptocystidia which Smith (1966) uses as a distinguishing feature in his key. It is appropriate that mention of the cystidia was omitted from the original species diagnosis for they are likely to be sterile basidial elements instead.", (States), spores 20-30 x 14-16 microns, narrowly citriform [lemon-shaped] with a truncate-cupped base, roughened, (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  probably 'subalpine', referring to habitat
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(27) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Smith(4), States(2), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)*
114
FAMILY  Hymenogastraceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hymenogaster sublilacinus  A.H. Sm.^  Mycologia 58: 108. 1966;  Hymenogaster brunnescens  A.H. Sm.;  Hymenogaster diabolus  A.H. Sm.;  Hymenogaster  subcaeruleus  A.H. Sm.;  Hymenogaster subochraceus  A.H. Sm.;  Hymenogaster subolivaceus  A.H. Sm.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a somewhat spherical to irregularly lobed, white fruitbody that is gradually tinged lilac to dingy blue on exposure or bruising, and becomes yellowish, the blue color often disappearing with maturity, 2) a spore mass that is white becoming brown at maturity, 3) columella absent or more often as a sterile basal patch with a few branches, 4) attachment by rhizomorphs scattered over surface, 5) underground growth under mountain conifers, and 6) microscopic characters including small non-beaked warty-wrinkled spores on 4-spored basidia.^ Arora says "This species appears to be the most common conifer-loving Hymenogaster, at least in California. The confusing color changes it undergoes as it ages and dries out has led to the naming of several "new" species (e.g. H. brunnescens, H. diabolus, H. subochraceus) where only one exists." Fogel(2) synonymized H. brunnescens A.H. Sm., H. diabolus A.H. Sm., H. subcaeruleus A.H. Sm., H. subochraceus A.H. Sm., and H. subolivaceus A.H. Sm. with this species. Descriptions derived both from Fogel's wide concept and from the original Smith description are given below. Most Hymenogaster species are related to Hebeloma, but this species is related to Cortinarius and will need a new name, (Trappe(13)). Trappe(13) informally use the name "Protoglossum" for this species, but seems not to recognize the combination Protoglossum aromaticum (Velen.) Vidal. In Vidal(1) the new combination has the same synonyms as Fogel's concept plus Hymenogaster remyi C.W. Dodge & Zeller and Rhizopogonella haasii Sochner. Hymenogaster sublilacinus is common among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). Arora(1) calls it "fairly common in the Sierra Nevada and other mountain ranges of the West in the spring, summer, and early fall". RANGE It is found from WA to southern CA and east to ID, (Trappe(13)). It was described from ID. Fogel(2) examined collections from WA, OR, ID, AZ, CA, CO, MT, NV, UT, and WY. Vidal(1) examined collections from OR, ID, CA, WY, Czech Republic, France, Germany, and Spain.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on peridium yellow slowly turning brown, FeSO4 on peridium negative or slightly olivaceous^, (Fogel)
