OUTER SURFACE  1-4cm across, up to 3.9cm x 2.5cm as dried, spherical to somewhat spherical or ovate to irregularly lobed; white when immature, gradually tinged lilac to dingy blue on exposure to the air or bruising, becoming 'pale yellow' to 'pale orange yellow', drying 'light yellowish brown' to 'dark orange yellow', blue stains "ephemeral, often disappearing with maturity and on drying"; fibrillose; consistency soft, sectioning easily as dried^, (Fogel), 2-5.6cm across, spherical to irregular and variously lobed; peridium thin (about 0.05cm when fresh), separable from spore mass, 2-layered at first, the outer dull lilac, and mycelioid to matted like felt, the inner dingy buffy pallid, when old dingy ochraceous whenever handled, (Smith(27)), 1-3(5.5)cm across, spherical to irregularly lobed (potato-like); "variable in color but typically whitish to lilac or dull bluish when young, becoming yellowish and then orangish and finally brown" when old, "often staining dingy ochraceous when handled (if older) or bluish (if young)"; often fibrillose; peridium often separable rather easily from spore mass, (Arora), 1-7.5cm across, often two or more specimens laterally joined; initially pure white, violaceous or yellow with olivaceous hues, "finally maculated of brown", peridium "thin, fibrillose, not viscid, partially evanescent and showing the chambers", (Vidal)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white, becoming 'light brown' to 'strong brown' with maturity and as dried; locules labyrinthiform, 0.01-0.02cm across, empty^, (Fogel), "cinnamon-brown when mature, rich tawny when dried, of minute chambers, the tramal tissue hyaline-cartilaginous, central part of the gleba often hollowed as in a hollow potato", (Smith(27)), "composed of small or minute chambers that give it a sponge-like appearance"; pallid when very young but brown to cinnamon brown at maturity, (Arora), "loculated, whitish or violaceous when young, later cinnamomeus", chambers minute (0.03-0.2cm),(Vidal)
STEM  attached by rhizomorphs scattered over the surface; "columella absent or more often represented as a sterile basal patch", 0.3-0.7cm x 0.15-0.4cm, with a few radiating, dendroid, sterile veins, colored as peridium^, (Fogel), "with a thickened sterile area at the point of attachment which gives off short branches into the gleba as a branched columella", "columella absent or present as a few rudimentary projections from the sterile base", (Smith(27)), sterile tissue usually present as expansion or thickening of basal peridium, sterile base may give rise to thin short branching columella, (Arora), "sessile or with a diminute sterile base and a white rhizomorph", sterile base small, sometimes with a pseudostipe up to 1.5cm x 0.5cm; columella "reduced, dendroid, white, yellowish in the sterile base", (Vidal)
ODOR  "slight, fungoid, occasionally aromatic (resin or varnish), becoming farinaceous"^, (Fogel), mild to sweetly fragrant (as in Cortinarius foetidus), (Smith(27)), "variable, intense, generally farinaceous, resinaceous or herbaceous, sometimes fruity", (Vidal), "variable (mild, sweetish, farinaceous etc.)", (Arora)
TASTE  mild^ (Smith(27))
EDIBILITY  unknown (Arora)
HABITAT  single to gregarious "in soil or duff under mountain conifers especially fir, spruce, and lodgepole or ponderosa pine"^, (Arora), probably mycorrhizal hosts Abies concolor (White Fir), Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann spruce), Pinus albicaulis (Whitebark Pine), Pinus aristata (Bristlecone Pine), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine); May to August in the Cascades of Oregon, July in the Olympic Mountains of Washington, (Fogel), cespitose about 4 inches deep in duff of Picea engelmannii (Engelmann spruce) in ID (Smith(27)), ripening in spring and summer after snowmelt, March to July in Europe, June to August in North America, "following the altitude and the latitude", (Vidal)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-13(15) x 5-8(9.5) microns including ornamentation and pedicel, elliptic, warty-rugulose, the largest warts near the spore apex, <=0.25-1 micron, not beaked, apical pore lacking, pedicel conic, central, 1-2 x 1-1.5 microns wide at spore base, spores 'brownish orange' in Melzer's reagent, 'strong brown' in KOH^; basidia 4-spored, 16-40 x 4-8 microns, subcylindric to clavate, colorless, with some brown content in KOH, thin-walled, sterigmata conic, 1-4 x 1-2 microns, basidioles "28-36 x 8-12 microns, clavate, thin-walled, readily collapsing"; subhymenium of thin-walled, colorless hyphae with cells inflated to 10 microns in diameter; tramal plates 22-100 microns wide, trama composed of hyphae 3-8 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, cells becoming inflated to 12-15 microns, "clamp connections occasionally present, some hyphae in mediostratum have yellow walls in KOH"; epicutis of peridium 37-173 microns thick, of hyphae 3-11 microns wide, interwoven to periclinal, thin-walled, colorless to yellow, "often obscured by reddish-orange intercellular pigment in Melzer's reagent", subcutis of peridium 40-190 microns thick, confluent with trama, of hyphae 4-8 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, cells becoming inflated to 12-15 microns, nests of thick-walled (1 micron), colorless sphaerocysts 20-25 microns in diameter occasionally present near gleba, (Fogel), spores 11-13 x 6.5-8 microns, elliptic with a prominent sterigmal appendage, "ornamentation in the form of minute flattened to rounded tawny verruculose projections on a thick (1-1.5 microns) inner rusty brown wall, ornamentation often more prominent around the apex of the spore", no apical pore visible, spores tawny red in Melzer's reagent, rich tawny in KOH; basidia 4-spored, 26-37 x 6-8 microns, subcylindric when sporulating, typically colorless in KOH "(some discolored orange-ochraceous), thin-walled, readily collapsing", brachybasidioles 12-20 microns in diameter, forming the framework of the hymenium and basidia projecting beyond them when sporulating, colorless and readily collapsing; cystidia none; tramal plates "with a cellular subhymenium of cells almost as large or even larger than the brachybasidioles", colorless, thin-walled, mediostratum of a few strands of hyphae 5-9 microns wide, colorless to yellowish, "and the cells uninflated and subparallel to interwoven, no incrusting pigment seen"; peridium divided into a thick (about 100 hyphae deep) layer of hyphae 4-10 microns wide, appressed interwoven, with smooth colorless walls "and an interior layer of ochraceous fulvous, (in KOH) hyphae of about the same size (the two layers not always distinguishable), the colored hyphae with very slight pigment incrustations or smooth"; clamp connections present, (Smith(27)), spores 8-13(15) x 5-8(9.5) microns, elliptic, warted-wrinkled, brown under microscope, (Arora), spores 8-12.5(14) x 5-8(9) microns excluding ornamentation and hilar appendix, elliptic or oval, dextrinoid, yellow in water, red-brownish in KOH, warts 0.1-0.2 microns, more developed on apex, up to 0.5 microns; basidia 4-spored, 35-50 x 6-10 microns, basidioles clavate, 17-45 x 8-17 microns, cystidia absent; clamp connections and oleiferous hyphae in all tissues, (Vidal)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Fogel(2) (colors in single quotation marks from Kelly(3)), Smith(27) (also describes the species synonymized by Fogel: H. brunnescens A.H. Sm., H. diabolus A.H. Sm., H. subcaeruleus A.H. Sm., H. subochraceus A.H. Sm., and H. subolivaceus A.H. Sm.), Arora(1), Smith(4), Trappe(13), Vidal(1) (as Protoglossum aromaticum), Desjardin(6)*
115
FAMILY  Hysterangiaceae, Order Hysterangiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hysterangium aureum  Zeller^  Mycologia 33: 201. 1941
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include somewhat spherical surface that becomes depressed-spherical, golden-brownish surface, brownish-olivaceous spore mass with large, somewhat radiating cavities, somewhat branched columella reaching to the center of the fruitbody, growth under Vine Maple and conifers, and microscopic characters including elliptic, colorless basidiospores, septa colorless and composed of gelatinous hyphae, and parenchymatous peridium of polyhedral cells up to 72 microns in diameter, the outer cells golden and the inner cells colorless^; description derived from Zeller(8); described from OR, also reported from OR by (Smith, J.E.(1))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  up to 1.3cm across, somewhat spherical, becoming depressed-spherical, firm; golden-brownish, drying darker; peridium [outer skin] not easily separable
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  brownish-olivaceous; cavities large, somewhat radiating, empty
STEM  columella reaching to center of fruitbody, somewhat branched
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Acer circinatum (Vine Maple) and conifers
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 11-12.5 x 5 microns, elliptic, rounded at both ends, colorless^; septa colorless, about 80 microns thick of gelified hyphae; no distinct layer of hyphae separating gleba and peridium; peridium 325-450 microns thick, parenchymatous, of polyhedral cells up to 72 microns in diameter, outer cells golden, inner cells colorless
NAME ORIGIN  means 'golden', presumably referring to the golden-brownish color of the fruitbody
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Zeller(8), Smith, J.E.(1)
116
FAMILY  Hysterangiaceae, Order Hysterangiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hysterangium coriaceum  R. Hesse^  Hypog. Deutschl. 1: 101. 1891
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a small, spherical, smooth, white fruitbody that becomes flesh-red on handling or in light, 2) a leathery outer covering that is easily separated from the spore mass, 3) a gray to olive-green spore mass, cavities within the spore mass being frequently circular in cross-section, 4) a highly developed light brown columella, and 5) microscopic characters.^  It is abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest, and widespread in North America, but a footnote warns that this is a European name applied to a North American species, (Trappe(13)). RANGE Oregon State University has collections labeled as this species from WA, OR, ID, and MT. The University of Washington has collections labeled as this species from CO and NY. It is illustrated by Desjardin(6) for CA.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-1.5cm across, spherical; "white, becoming flesh-red on handling or in light"; smooth
INNER LAYER  peridium leathery and easily separated from the gleba [spore mass]
INTERIOR  gray to olive-green, "cavities frequently circular in section"; "columella highly developed in the central part of the gleba, light brown"
STEM  columella highly developed
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Betula (birch), Corylus (hazel) and Fagus silvatica (European beech) in Germany, (Zeller), in the Pacific Northwest with a broad spectrum of hosts, (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-12 x 3-4 microns, "slightly appendiculate, slightly brownish in mass with a thick epispore"^; basidia narrowly cylindric, mostly 2-spored; peridium 300-500 microns thick, "with a very thin outer layer of light brown, closely grouped hyphae", next inward "a layer of pseudoparenchyma, thick and violet-colored", "with another layer of thin-celled, almost colorless hyphae next to the gleba"; septa 130-150 microns thick, composed of colorless, gelatinous hyphae
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Trappea darkeri.
SOURCES  Zeller(10), Trappe(13)*, Desjardin(6)*
117
FAMILY  Hysterangiaceae, Order Hysterangiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hysterangium crassirhachis  Zeller & C.W. Dodge^  Ann. Mo. Bot. Gard. 16: 101. 1929
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Hysterangium crassirhachis is characterized by "the brittle peridium, which is easily separable when fresh, and by the tough, rubbery gleba with its large translucent septa which become flinty when dry", (Zeller). Other features include the pinkish color of the fruitbody, the greenish spore mass with cavities radiating from the columella to the peridium, and microscopic characters including smooth fusiform spores on 2-4-spored basidia.^ It is common among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Hysterangium crassirhachis is found from AK south to the Sierra Nevada of CA and east to MT, (Trappe, M.(3)). It is found from BC to southern CA and ID, (Trappe(13)). Collections were examined from OR, CA, (Zeller). It was recorded from OR by Luoma(1), and (Smith, J.E.(1)), and from WA by Colgan(2).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across, white at first, becoming "sea-shell pink" to flesh-colored when fresh, drying "pinkish buff" to "snuff-brown"; peridium easily separable^, (Zeller), "white, bruising pink to brown", (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  peridium is thick, separating easily from spore mass^ (Trappe, M.(3))
INTERIOR  gelatinous; from "grayish olive" to "deep grayish olive" when fresh; "cavities radiating from the columella to the peridium, sometimes simple, appearing as linear openings in sections, but usually labyrinthiform, broken by septa jutting out from the columellar branches on either side, not filled"^, (Zeller), very firm and rubbery; dark olive green, (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  stem in a depression at the base, 0.1-0.2cm in diameter, white, drying somewhat lighter than the rest of the fruitbody, stupose; columella "neutral gray" to slate-gray, "opalescent when fresh, drying white, flinty, thick, terminating in a broad head" at the center of the fruitbody, covering about a third of the median vertical section, from which distinct, tough, percurrent branches radiate^, (Zeller), dendroid columella usually thick, (Trappe, M.(3))
ODOR  "mild to slightly fruity or pungent"^ (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Quercus (oak) and Acer (maple), May^, (Zeller), with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Pinus (pine), Tsuga (hemlock), Picea (spruce), Abies (fir), Larix (larch); year round, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 13-22 x 4-8 microns, fusiform [spindle-shaped], short-appendiculate, smooth, colorless to olivaceous in mass, thick-walled, sometimes with one to many droplets^; basidia 2-4-spored, 30-50 x 6-9 microns, colorless, with short sterigmata; septa from 85-100 up to 200 microns thick, of interwoven, colorless, highly gelatinized hyphae; peridium 400-500 microns thick, duplex, inner and major part parenchymatous, composed of colorless rhomboidal cells, 8-17 microns in diameter, "with an outer rind of smaller, thin pseudoparenchyma of brownish cells about 25 microns thick"; percurrent branches of columella usually at least 300-450 microns thick, composed of interwoven, highly gelatinized, colorless hyphae; stem consisting of hyphae 2-2.5 microns wide, colorless, more or less parallel and anastomosing, (Zeller), spores 11-15 x 4-5.5 microns, elliptic, smooth; no inflated cells in peridium, (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin "crassi-" meaning "thick" and "-rachis" meaning "spine", for the thick columella in the spore mass, (Trappe, M.(1))
SIMILAR  Hysterangium separabile has a spore mass that is darker (but varies with maturity of specimen), and has inflated cells in its peridium, (Trappe, M.(3)).
SOURCES  Zeller(10) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Smith, J.E.(1), Luoma(1), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Colgan(2), Trappe(13)
118
FAMILY  Hysterangiaceae, Order Hysterangiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hysterangium occidentale  Harkn.^  Cal. Acad. Sci. Proc. III. 1: 255. 1899
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a relatively large, spherical to somewhat depressed fruitbody that is dirty white to pallid mouse-gray with surrounding rhizomorphs, 2) a peridium (outer skin) that is easily separable with its outer layer often flaking off, 3) a light pink spore mass with cavities radiating from a columella that penetrates at least to the middle of the fruitbody, 4) growth under oak in spring and early summer, 5) elliptic spores on 2-4-spored basidia, and 6) a two-layered peridium (a filamentous outer layer and a parenchymatous inner layer).^ The description is derived from Zeller(10) except where noted. It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest. RANGE Collections were examined from OR and CA, (Zeller). It is found from western OR to northern CA (Trappe(13)). It occurs from western OR through CA to AZ (Trappe, M.(3)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  6cm x 6cm x 3cm, spherical to somewhat depressed; dirty white to "pallid mouse-gray"; fibrils few, concolorous, conspicuous, free to tightly attached; of firm consistency from abundant rhizomorphic growth in soil, fruitbody tough and rubbery when fresh; peridium separable, outer layer often flaking off^, (Zeller), nearly spherical to irregular; "white to pale brown, bruising brown", (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  easily separable from the spore mass^, (Trappe, M.(3))
INTERIOR  light pink when fresh, becoming "buckthorn-brown" to "raw umber" in alcohol or when dry; cavities empty, radiating from columella^, (Zeller), "pink to pale brownish red", (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  abundant rhizomorphic growth in soil; base not prominent; columella penetrating at least to the middle of the fruitbody, "branched, with a cartilaginous appearance when fresh"
ODOR  when mature, nearly odorless or with pleasant odor of some species of Polyporus^, (Zeller), absent or pleasant (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Quercus (oak), spring and early summer^, (Zeller), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Pinus (pine), and Quercus (oak), at low elevations, April to October, but mostly spring, (Trappe, M.(3)), mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest Quercus and Pinaceae (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-16 x 5-7 microns, elliptic, yellow-brown in mass, cell wall thickened at apex^; basidia 2-4-spored, "linear, filiform, collapsing", sterigmata short and stout; septa 200 microns thick, composed of closely woven, gelatinized, colorless hyphae; peridium duplex, 350-640 microns thick, outer layer 85-300 microns thick, "dark brown, composed of brown hyphae in rhizomorph-like periclinal strands, loosely interwoven", clamp connections frequent, inner layer 260-400 microns thick, parenchymatous, parenchyma not compact, characterized by long hypha-like cells, (Zeller), spores 12-16 x 5-8 microns, (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'western'
SIMILAR  Other common Hysterangium spp. have a thinner peridium and are less reddish in the spore mass, (Trappe, M.(3)).
SOURCES  Zeller(10) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)
119
FAMILY  Hysterangiaceae, Order Hysterangiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hysterangium separabile  Zeller^  Mycologia 33: 203. 1941
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to lobed whitish fruitbody that becomes pinkish on handling or with exposure to light, 2) a peridium (outer skin) separating easily from the firm, rubbery, greenish spore mass, 3) a well developed branching columella, 4) underground growth, and 5) microscopic characters including wrinkled spores and mostly 2-spored basidia.^ It is common among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). It is the most common spring truffle in the western US (Trappe, M.(1)). RANGE It is found from OR to southern CA and AZ, (Trappe(13)). The distribution includes New England states, NY, WY, AZ, OR, CA, Chile, Argentina, and Europe, (Zeller(8)). Oregon State University has collections from WA, OR, AK, CA, and NY. The University of British Columbia has collections from BC.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-3cm across, spherical to somewhat flattened or lobed, "white to pinkish or sometimes buff, often becoming pinkish where bruised or handled"; peridium tends to crack and peel easily from the greenish spore mass^, (Arora), to 3cm across, white slowly becoming pinkish to brown where bruised; peridium readily cracking and separating from spore mass, (Smith), up to 1.5cm across, spherical; white when young becoming "pale ochraceous-buff" or "light ochraceous-salmon" when fresh, becoming "buff-pink" to "onion-skin pink" where bruised, drying "ochraceous tawny" to "mummy-brown"; no fibrils in upper part, but fibrils in lower part variable from terete [round in cross-section] and free to innate or appressed, (Zeller(8)), "white bruising pink to red or rosy brown", separating easily from the spore mass, (Trappe, M.(1))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  olive-brown to greenish; composed of small chambers, "at first firm and tough (cartilaginous), but becoming slimy and stinky (putrid) at maturity" or when old^, (Arora), green to olive green; "cartilaginous becoming mucilaginous at maturity", (Smith), green when fresh, becoming "citrine drab" or "grayish-olive" to "dark greenish-olive" on drying; "cavities polyhedral to irregular, with a tendency to radiate from the columella, small, empty", (Zeller(8)), "dark olive green, very firm and rubbery", (Trappe, M.(1))
STEM  stem absent, "sometimes with mycelial fibres at the base", "columella thin, translucent or whitish, arising from a rudimentary sterile base, often branched" and typically extending about halfway into spore mass^, (Arora), columella prominent, often branched, (Smith), columella usually large and prominent, reaching half way to the top of fruitbody "or often branching near the base", (Zeller), columella narrow, dendroid, (Trappe, M.(1))
ODOR  offensive at maturity^ (Zeller(8)), "mild to faintly fruity or sometimes of iodine", (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  pleasant when young^ (Zeller(8))
EDIBILITY  "Although it has little odor or flavor, its chewy texture provides an interesting additive to omelettes or scrambled eggs", (Trappe, M.(1))
HABITAT  single to gregarious "in humus or soil (usually buried) under both hardwoods and conifers", common late spring through fall^, (Arora), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Abies (fir), and Larix (larch), year round but mostly in spring, (Trappe, M.(1)), gregarious under both conifers and hardwoods, (Smith), underground under conifers and hardwood trees and shrubs, (Zeller), mycorrhizal host in Pacific Northwest Quercus (Trappe(13))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-19 x 6-8 microns, more or less spindle-shaped, smooth within a wrinkled sac, colorless to pale greenish brown under microscope^, (Arora), spores 12-19 x 6-8 microns, spindle-shaped, (Smith), spores 12-19 x 6-8 microns (averaging 15.3 +/- 0.9 microns long), lanceolate, "with a thick epispore which sometimes is slightly roughened" and becomes loosened when old, sometimes papillate at apex, spores olivaceous in mass; basidia 3-4-spored, mostly 3-spored, long, irregularly cylindric, sterigmata usually short, but sometimes becoming 16-18 microns long; septa 85-140 microns thick, composed of hyphae 5-7 microns wide, loosely interwoven, large, thin-walled, finally becoming highly gelatinized; peridium 220-450 microns thick, parenchymatous, cells spherical to polyhedral, varying from 12 to 40 microns in diameter "with a very thin filamentous layer between the parenchyma and gleba, easily separable", (Zeller(8)), spores 11-14 x 4-5 microns, fusoid, smooth, "enclosed in a wrinkled outer skin", (Trappe, M.(1)), inflated cells in peridium, (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin "coriaceum" meaning "leathery" for the tough texture, (Trappe, M.(1))
SIMILAR  Hysterangium crassirhachis has a spore mass that is lighter in color (but varies with maturity of specimen), and its peridium lacks inflated cells, (Trappe, M.(3)). Trappea darkeri is slightly larger (1-5cm), has a columella that extends through the spore mass to the top, often grows above the ground, and has much smaller spores.
SOURCES  Zeller(8) (colors in quotation marks from Ridgway(1)), Smith(4), Arora(1), Zeller(10) (as H. clathroides), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Colgan(2) (as Hysterangium coriaceum), Trappe(13), Siegel(2)*
120
FAMILY  Hysterangiaceae, Order Hysterangiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Hysterangium setchellii  Fischer^  Ber. Schweiz. Bot. Ges. 48: 33. 1938
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include small nearly spherical fruiting body that is finely scurfy with easily separable peridium (outer skin), the interior with broad whitish septa emanating from a scarcely branched columella, the cavities relatively small, elongate, narrow, and radiating, the fruitbody with abundant white mycelium associated, and microscopic characters including fusiform brownish olive basidiospores, and peridium of a compact gelatinous filamentous type^; description is derived from Zeller(8); abundant in the Pacific Northwest, from WA to southern CA, (Trappe(13)), reported for BC and OR to Oregon Truffling Society, by Smith, J.E.(1) and by Luoma(1) from OR, by Zeller(8) from CA, and by Colgan(2) from WA
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-1.5cm across; nearly spherical; brownish in preservative; finely scurfy; peridium easily separable
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  cartilaginous, dull slaty color, with broad milk-white septa that radiate, scarcely branching from the center of the fruitbody to the peridium, "and form an interrupted, more or less thick tramal peridium"; "cavities relatively small, elongate, narrow, radiating"
STEM  fruitbody "from abundantly branched, white mycelium"; columella prominent, white, reaching 1/2 to 2/3 of the way to the top of the fruitbody, scarcely branched except for the large septa
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest trees in Pinaceae (Trappe), in duff under Quercus densifolia (Zeller)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14-19 x 5-6 microns, fusiform, brownish olive^; peridium "110-180 microns thick, of very compact, large gelatinous hyphae, the very thin splitting layer next to the gleba of much finer texture", "The peridium of H. Setchellii [name in italics], though evidently of a fundamental (primary) filamentous type, is so compact it might easily be construed by some as prosenchyma"
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Zeller(8), Smith, J.E.(1), Colgan(2), Luoma(1), Trappe(13)
121
FAMILY  Morchellaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Kalapuya brunnea  M. Trappe, Trappe, and Bonito^  Mycologia 102(5): 1059. 2010;  Leucangium brunneum  nom. prov.
ENGLISH NAMES  Oregon brown truffle
NOTES  Features include 1) an underground fruitbody that is light yellowish brown to orange-brown, reddish brown or brown, with a granular to warty surface, 2) a firm spore mass with grayish pockets separated by white veins, 3) a garlicky-cheesy odor, 4) growth under Douglas-fir, and 5) large, smooth, elliptic spores that contain a large central droplet and many smaller droplets. It often fruits in the same places and times as Leucangium carthusianum, (Trappe, M.(3)). It was originally thought to be a new species of Leucangium, (Trappe, M.(4)). It is common among truffles in northwestern Oregon (Trappe(13)).^ RANGE Kalapuya brunnea is found in the Cascade Range in OR and the Coastal Ranges of OR and northern CA, (Trappe, M.(4)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1.2-6(8)cm x 1-4.5cm, subglobose (nearly spherical) to lobed and furrowed; "light yellowish brown to orange-brown, reddish brown or brown, often with darker patches" or becoming blackish on upper surface when old; rough to granular, "unevenly covered with patches of flat to rounded warts" 0.05-0.3cm wide, "the larger warts often in turn beset with minute warts, polygonal in face view and separated by narrow fissures" when old often rimose-areolate [cracked like dried mud]^, (Trappe, M.(4)), up to 7.5cm across but typically 2.5-5cm across, lumpy; orangish brown; areolate [cracked like dried mud] when mature, granular to warty, (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  peridium up to 0.2cm thick^, (Trappe, M.(4))
INTERIOR  solid, firm; "whitish to yellowish gray, with grayish brown mottling of fertile pockets surrounded by sterile, undifferentiated veins"^, (Trappe, M.(4)), firm; "with gray pockets of spores separated by white veins", (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  "with a subcartilaginous, dendroid, basal attachment that easily breaks off when specimens are removed from soil"^, (Trappe, M.(4))
ODOR  mildly garlicky-cheesy, the odor reminiscent of mature Camembert, (Trappe, M.(4)), can be strongly garlicky, (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  mildly garlicky-cheesy^ (Trappe, M.(4))
EDIBILITY  popular edible (Trappe, M.(3))
HABITAT  underground under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) up to about 50 years old in the top 2-10cm of mineral soil, beneath scant litter layers from near sea level to about 500 m, fruiting October to March but occasionally as early as September and as late as July^, (Trappe, M.(4))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  32-43 x 25-38 microns, elliptic, smooth, containing a large, central droplet "with crowded tiny droplets inside the spore at its ends" and on the sides of the central droplet, spore walls 1-3 microns thick, colorless when young becoming amber to pale olive when mature, non-reactive in Melzer's reagent, strongly staining in cotton blue^; 6-8-spored, 70-110 x 60-100 microns, with a stalk 10-40 x 6-10 microns and having a forked base, walls colorless, when young up to 3 microns thick, thinning to about 1 micron when mature, (Trappe, M.(4))
NAME ORIGIN  means "brown", referring to the brown peridium^, (Trappe, M.(4))
SIMILAR  Leucangium carthusianum is blackish, and has larger spores with only a central droplet.
SOURCES  Trappe, M.(4)*, Trappe, M.(3) (as Leucangium), Trappe(13) (as Leucangium)
122
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Lactarius crassus  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Peirotti^  Index Fungorum 254:1. 2015;  Gastrolactarius crassus  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) J.M. Vidal  Revista Catalana de Micologia 26: 77 (2005) [2004];  Arcangeliella crassa  Singer & A.H. Sm.  Mem. Torr. Bot. Club 21: 74. 1960
ENGLISH NAMES  gastroid milk cap
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Lactarius crassus is a sequestrate Lactarius. Macroscopic features include 1) a pale buff to pinkish buff cap that is bald but unpolished, the cap margin usually reaching the stem but sometimes exposing the spore mass in places, 2) a pale pink-buff spore mass that varies from gill-like to chambered, 3) a poorly developed stem, a 4) peppery taste, and 5) growth beneath the soil under conifers. It is characterized microscopically by a combination of 6) sphaerocysts in the context of the peridium that have thickened, somewhat refractive walls, 7) elliptic, amyloid, reticulate spores, and 8) an undifferentiated peridium.^ Lactarius crassus was known as Gastrolactarius crassus and Arcangeliella crassa. Thiers gives Arcangeliella tenax A.H. Sm. & Wiebe, found in Oregon, as a synonym of this species, but they are listed separately in Trappe(13). L. crassus is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest. RANGE Lactarius crassus is endemic to northern CA according to Castellano(1), but was reported from OR also by Matt Trappe (pers. comm.). Distribution is northern OR to northern CA in the mountains, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  up to 3.5cm across, convex depressed, margin remaining attached to stem or not, reaching the stem in places thus exposing the spore mass (younger specimens); pale pink buff; bald but unpolished^, (Castellano), 2-8cm across, convex when young, becoming flat to shallowly depressed or irregular when old, margin typically remaining attached to stem, but often not quite reaching it in some places, and when old sometimes separating slightly from it; surface pale buff to pinkish-buff, sometimes darkening slightly (to cinnamon-buff) in old age; dry or slightly viscid, smooth, (Arora)
INNER LAYER  peridium up to 0.5cm thick as dried; pale pink-buff within^, (Castellano), thick, crisp, brittle; white to pinkish-buff, (Arora), milk present but often scanty (especially in dry weather)
INTERIOR  spore mass pale pink-buff, varying lamellate to lacunose on same specimen^, (Castellano), spore mass comprised of contorted plates or rudimentary, often chambered gills, pale pinkish-buff to ocher-buff, usually completely enclosed by the cap but occasionally exposed when old, especially near stem (Arora)
STEM  about 1cm x 0.5-0.8cm, becoming hollow in largest specimen, pallid, surface unpolished^, (Castellano), 0.5-2.5cm x 0.5-1.5(2)cm, thick, usually stubby and poorly developed, often off-center, solid or hollow, crisp, brittle, dry, smooth, going through spore mass, whitish or colored like cap (Arora)
ODOR  often unpleasant when old^ (Arora), not distinctive (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  very peppery^ (Arora), somewhat peppery when fresh (Trappe, M.(3))
EDIBILITY  unknown
HABITAT  forms sporocarps June through October beneath the soil surface associated with various Pinaceae species in mixed forests containing Abies concolor, A. magnifica, Pinus contorta, P. jeffreyii, or P. ponderosa from 2000 to 2200 meters elevation^, (Castellano), single to gregarious in duff under conifers and in mixed woods in mountains, (Arora), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Pinus, Abies, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-11 x 6.5-8 microns (not including sterigmal attachment), sterigmal attachment oblique and prominent, with a nearly smooth but well marked plage with an amorphous mass of amyloid material on it, ornamentation in the form of a small-meshed reticulum or broken amyloid reticulum, prominences +/- 0.25 microns high, spore wall slightly thickened and amyloid^, (Castellano), spores 7.5-11 x 5.5-8 microns, elliptic, amyloid ridges, (Arora), spores 8-11 x 6.5-8 microns, elliptic with amyloid ornamentation, (Trappe, M.(3)), spores 7.5-10.6 x 5.5-8.1 microns, elliptic, colorless, "ornamented with a strongly amyloid, complete or partially broken reticulum, with a rather large, conspicuous smooth plage in the hilar region"; basidia 4-spored, 35-47 x 9-15 microns, clavate, thin-walled; cystidia "embedded in the hymenium and often obscure", 35-50 x 8-15 microns, "ventricose to fusoid to subclavate, moderately thick-walled", colorless in KOH and Melzer's reagent; trama of glebal plates interwoven, lacking sphaerocysts, laticiferous hyphae present; cap trama "interwoven, with numerous conspicuous aggregations of sphaerocysts"; epicutis of cap "composed of a narrow, compact layer of closely appressed, more or less repent, interwoven hyphae which sometimes may be subgelatinous"; clamp connections absent, (Thiers)
NAME ORIGIN  'crassus' means 'thick, fat, stout'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Gastrolactarius tenax.
SOURCES  Castellano(1)* (as Arcangeliella crassa), Arora(1) (as Arcangeliella crassa), Smith(4) (as Arcangeliella crassa), Thiers(6) (as Arcangeliella crassa), Singer(10) (as Arcangeliella crassa), Trappe, M.(3)* (as Arcangeliella crassa), Trappe(13) (As Gastrolactarius crassus)
123
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Lactarius lactarioides  (Zeller) P.M. Kirk^  Index Fungorum 278: 1. 2015;  Gastrolactarius lactarioides  (Zeller) J.M. Vidal  Revista Catalana de Micologia 26: 77 (2005) [2004];  Arcangeliella lactarioides  Zeller  Mycologia 39: 282. 1947
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Lactarius lactarioides is a sequestrate Lactarius. Features include an innately fibrillose peridium that does not stain where bruised, the presence of milk on cut tissues, underground growth under conifers, and amyloid verrucose spores.^ Lactarius lactarioides was known as  Gastrolactarius lactarioides and Arcangeliella lactarioides. It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It occurs from southwestern OR to northern CA in mountains, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2.5-3cm across, 1.5-2cm high, somewhat spherical becoming expanded, convex capped, somewhat depressed at disc; pale yellow, drying brown; dry, smooth, innately fibrillose^, (Castellano), 2.5-3cm across, 1.5-2cm high, "resembling a stout agaric button", somewhat spherical becoming expanded, convex, somewhat depressed at top; pale yellowish drying brownish; dry, smooth, innately fibrillose; "peridium thin, especially below or at margins, where it breaks away from base of stem (columella)", (Zeller)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  adnexed, very ventricose, maze-like, exposed below; spore mass white becoming creamy and drying brownish^, (Castellano), spore mass "white, becoming creamy, drying brownish, exposed below, adnexed, very ventricose, cavities labyrinthiform, partially filled with white spores"; "type was dried and no record of the color of the milk was made", (Zeller)
STEM  columella percurrent [going through spore mass], becoming a stem as cap expands, 0.4-0.6cm wide^, (Castellano), columella percurrent, becoming a stem as cap expands, 0.4-0.6cm wide, (Zeller)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground associated with various Pinaceae spp., particularly Abies magnifica and Pinus ponderosa above 1650m elevation, July through November^, (Castellano), in fir woods below timberline (7500 feet), (Zeller), associated with Abies (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  print presumably unobtainable
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-10.5 x 6-6.3 microns, elliptic, verrucose with protuberances of various sizes and somewhat connected by reticulate lines, pedicellate^, (Castellano), spores 8-10.5 x 6-6.3 microns, elliptic, "verrucose with protuberances of various sizes and somewhat connected by reticulate lines", pedicellate; basidia 4-spored, clavate, "with long sterigmata bearing the spores acrogenously", (Zeller)
NAME ORIGIN  probably 'resembling Lactarius'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Castellano(1)* (as Arcangeliella), Smith(4) (as Arcangeliella), Zeller(3) (as Arcangeliella), Trappe(13) (as Gastrolactarius)
124
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Lactarius silviae  Pierotti^  Index Fungorum 254: 1. 2015;  Gastrolactarius camphoratus  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) J.M. Vidal  Revista Catalana de Micologia 26: 77 (2005) [2004];  Arcangeliella camphorata  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Pegler & T.W.K. Young  Trans. Brit. Mycol. Soc. 72: 365. 1979;  Elasmomyces camphoratus  Singer & A.H. Sm.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Lactarius silviae grows under the soil surface, and is characterized by 1) the orange tones of the outer surface and the spore mass, 2) the strong maple-syrup odor, 3) underground growth under conifers, and 4) small, round or nearly round spores on 1-4-spored basidia which at maturity have a strongly amyloid partial to complete reticulum.^ It is a sequestrate Lactarius. The online Species Fungorum and MycoBank, both accessed April 1, 2018, gave the current name as Lactarius silviae Pierotti. It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest, (Trappe(13)). RANGE Lactarius silviae has been found at least in WA and OR (Castellano(1)). It is found from southwestern BC to southwestern OR (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  3-10cm x 0.4-1.7cm, "the base indented around a slight basal protrusion", "the peridium meeting the basal protrusion or detaching" to leave a gap up to 0.5cm exposing underlying locules; orange-red to brown-orange, slowly becoming orange-brown where handled; bald, even to somewhat rugose [wrinkled] or pitted^, (Castellano), tan to rusty-brown, (Arora), 0.6-1.2cm across, nearly spherical to spherical-convoluted; "pale to dark tan or rusty brown"; bald, dull; peridium "distinct, almost papery but not readily separating", (Singer, from dried specimens), light to deep reddish brown (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  milk: white to watery white, unchanging, (Castellano), often absent (Arora)
INTERIOR  spore mass with orange-yellow to orange or brownish orange trama separating locules lined with pale orange yellow spore deposit, "locules tending to be sublamellate-radiating near the base, towards the peridium smaller and rounded"^, (Castellano), chambered; near cinnamon buff as dried, (Smith), near cinnamon-buff, "the chambers empty and more or less elongated approximately vertically", (Singer, from dried specimen)
STEM  ranging from percurrent [going through spore mass] and protruding beyond the base, 0.1-0.2cm broad, to absent and represented as a small basal pad, colored as peridium^, (Castellano), columella colored like peridium, percurrent and unbranched (Singer on the basis of one good section)
ODOR  "when fresh ranging from slight to pronounced, on dried specimens strongly sweet (of maple syrup)"^, (Castellano), strong fragrant, like that of candy caps such as Lactarius fragilis or Lactarius camphoratus (burnt sugar), especially when dry, (Arora), strong and resembling that of Lactarius camphoratus (dried), (Singer), not distinctive despite species name, but sometimes dried fruitbodies with aroma of maple syrup, (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  mild^ (Castellano)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  forms fruiting bodies beneath soil surface associated with various Pinaceae species, particularly Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) from 200 to 950m elevation, March through November^, (Castellano), associated with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Trappe), October to March (Trappe, M.(1), Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-10.5 x 7-10 microns, round to nearly round, measurement excluding the ornamentation of amyloid lines that when young have many short side-branches and often form a partial reticulum up to 0.5 microns tall, "at maturity more strongly amyloid and commonly forming a partial to complete reticulum 0.5-1 micron tall", occasional minute solitary amyloid warts in spaces between lines, sterigmal attachment inconspicuous, about 2 x 1 microns, oblique to axial^; basidia 1-4-spored, 28-36 x 8-9 microns, sterigmata up to 9-12 microns long; cystidia not seen; trama of hyphae (4)8-12 microns wide, loosely interwoven, colorless, thin-walled; subcutis of interwoven, colorless, thin-walled hyphae with scattered greatly inflated cells; peridial epicutis "a compact trichodermium of variously shaped, thin-walled hyphal elements, often with yellow walls, but this soon collapsing to form a more or less amorphous yellow layer over the subcutis", (Castellano), spores 7.5-11(12) x 6.5-8(10) microns, round to nearly round, strongly amyloid ornamentation of fine lines 0.25-0.35 microns wide, "forming a broken network or system of branched and anastomosing lines with some isolated granules, major prominences rare and 0.8-1.0 microns high, most prominences 0.25-0.3 microns high", the wall yellowish transparent in Melzer's reagent, "sterigmal appendage about 2-3 microns long, oblique, not prominent"; basidia 1-spored to 4-spored, 28-36 x 8-9 microns, colorless in KOH, "sterigmata on 2-spored basidia often 9-12 microns long, typically straight and conic", basidioles numerous; cystidia scattered, 32-43 x 9-13 microns, fusoid-ventricose or broadest near the obtuse apex, thin-walled, colorless, content homogeneous or nearly so; tramal plates with a mediostratum of hyphae (4)8-12 microns wide, loosely interwoven, colorless, nongelatinous, with thin walls, lacking incrustations; subhymenium of hyphae about the same width "but with cross walls frequent enough to make the cells nearly isodiametric", laticiferous hyphae 9-12 microns wide also present, "somewhat hyaline, refractive"; sphaerocysts not seen "unless some of the more enlarged subhymenial elements be so interpreted"; peridial epicutis a compactly arranged trichodermium of nongelatinous, colorless to yellowish, thin-walled elements of various shapes: "crooked-filamentous, clavate, fusoid, or simply variously irregular"; peridial context of interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, nongelatinous hyphae "with only an occasional sphaerocyst and these not grouped into nests"; laticiferous hyphae colorless but distinct; clamp connections none, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Castellano(1)* (as Arcangeliella camphorata), Smith(4) (as Arcangeliella camphorata), Arora(1) (as Arcangeliella camphorata), Singer(10) (as Elasmomyces camphoratus), Trappe, M.(1)* (as Arcangeliella camphorata), Trappe, M.(3)* (as Arcangeliella camphorata), Trappe(13)* (as Gastrolactarius camphoratus)
125
FAMILY  Agaricaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Lepiota geophana  Vellinga & T. Lebel^  Mycol. Progr. 12(3): 528. 2012;  Cryptolepiota microspora  Kropp & Albee-Scott  Mycologia 104: 170. 2012
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include small, nearly spherical to ovoid, whitish fruitbodies with thin peridium, gray interior which is loosely labyrinthiform with plate-like layers of fertile tissue, and microscopic characters including thick-walled metachromatic spores on 1-2-spored basidia that have refractive sterigmata^. Description is derived from Kropp(3). Collections were made from ID, CA, and UT.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-1.4cm x 0.4-0.9cm, nearly spherical to ovoid, peridium "whitish, thin and more or less felt-like with adhering soil and some soil particles embedded"
INNER LAYER  peridium thin (0.015-0.0195cm in thickness)
INTERIOR  "gray when fresh, remaining gray or becoming brown when dried, loosely labyrinthiform with plate-like layers of fertile tissue"; fragile when dry
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground; under Pinus contorta in one location and Cercocarpus in another location
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-14.5 x 8.5-14.5 microns, round to oval, [appearing smooth in illustrations], "metachromatic, only a small proportion of spores dextrinoid", spore wall 1-2.5 microns thick^; basidia 1-2 spored, 25-32 x 9-10 microns, broadly clavate with refractive hyaline sterigmata 3-5 x 2 microns; cystidia not seen, "but sterile, clavate, basidium-sized cells that could be either immature basidia or cystidia present in the hymenium"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with small spores' (in comparison to those of C. americana)
SIMILAR  Lepiota geocarpa (= Cryptolepiota americana) has round spores 14-20 microns in diameter, spores walls 2.5-4.5 microns thick, and mucronate cystidia in hymenium - collections were examined from UT. (Kropp(3))  Cystolepiota mengei has broadly elliptic spores 10-16 x 7.5-12.5 microns, "most basidia with four sterigmata but sometimes fewer, these sometimes thick but typically not refractive" and the sterigmata become granular in appearance - collections were examined from CA and UT. (Kropp(3))
SOURCES  Kropp(3) (as Cryptolepiota microspora)
126
FAMILY  Agaricaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Lepiota viridigleba (Castellano) Z.W. Ge, Castellano & M.E. Sm.^  Mycol. Progr. 12(1): 153. 2013;  Amogaster viridiglebus  Castellano  Mycotaxon 55: 186. 1995 (as 'viridigleba')
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a small, nearly spherical or irregular, underground fruitbody, white or pale green from the underlying spore mass, bruising orange to pale red, with a finely tomentose surface, 2) a spore mass with round to irregular, empty locules, 3) a small cartilaginous columella, 4) fruiting in association with Populus, and 5) microscopic characters including large, somewhat irregularly shaped, smooth spores, and the absence of clamp connections.^ The description was derived from Castellano(5) except where specified. It is rare among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It was described from Sierra County CA, and has also been found in Douglas County, OR, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  up to 1.25cm x 0.75cm, nearly spherical to irregular, peridium thin, evanescent [disappearing]; white or pale green from underlying spore mass when fresh, peridium bruising orange to pale red, finely tomentose
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  spore mass with round to irregular, empty locules; pale green when fresh, pale to medium yellow when dried
STEM  columella "small, cartilaginous, dendroid when fresh, inconspicuous when dried"; rhizomorphs absent
ODOR  not distinct
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type hypogeous [underground] under Populus spp.^ (Castellano), found in mixed forests of conifers and Populus (Trappe(13))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-14(15) x 4-6 microns (mean 11.6 x 5.1 microns), elliptic, nearly round or subfusiform [somewhat spindle-shaped], (most if not all spores asymmetric), smooth, apex blunt, base with sterigmal attachment, in KOH spores pale yellow-brown singly, yellow-brown in mass, "in Melzer's reagent some dextrinoid (deep red) others orange brown singly"^; basidia 4-spored, 10-15 x 4-6 microns, clavate, colorless, walls 0.5 microns thick; trama 20-50 microns thick, of thin-walled, colorless, interwoven hyphae, 1-2 microns wide but occasionally inflated to 6 microns wide; peridium 20-30 microns thick, a single layer of loosely interwoven to subpericlinal hyphae 1-2 microns wide, thin-walled, colorless to brown; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  "viridigleba" refers to the green gleba (spore mass)
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon species are macroscopically similar but the gleba of Rhizopogon is not green, and spores are smaller and very rarely dextrinoid.
SOURCES  Castellano(5) (as Amogaster viridigleba), Trappe(13)* (as Amogaster viridigleba)
127
FAMILY  Strophariaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Leratiomyces cucullatus  (Shope & Seaver) Beever & D.-C. Park  Mycotaxon 103: 116. 2008;  Weraroa cucullata  (Seaver & Shope) Thiers & Watling^  Madrono 21: 2. 1973;  Galeropsis cucullata  (Seaver & Shope) Singer;  Bolbitius cucullatus  Seaver & Shope;  Secotium longipes  Zeller
ENGLISH NAMES  gastroid liberty-cap
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include 1) a narrowly conic, dry to slightly viscid cap that is yellow to tawny, 2) a spore mass of brown to reddish brown contorted gills, 3) a slender, yellow to tawny stem, and 4) growth on the ground usually among grasses in wet alpine meadows.^ Leratiomyces cucullatus is widely distributed in the mountains of western North America. Smith(31) described a similar if not identical species from Idaho under the name Weraroa coprophila, which he differentiated by a darkening stem, smoky gray to pale fuscous gills when fresh, and narrow spores. RANGE Leratiomyces cucullatus has been found in OR (R. Sieger, pers. comm. det. Nancy Weber-Smith). Collections were examined from WY and CA, (Thiers(10)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.4-1.5cm broad, 1-4cm high, narrowly conic with pointed apex, margin often splitting when old and retracting slightly from the stem; yellow to yellowish-buff to tawny or yellow-brown; dry to slightly viscid, smooth or fibrillose, often wrinkled; veil absent or evanescent^, (Arora), 0.45-1.5cm wide at base, 0.9-3.5cm high, "not or hardly expanding, typically conic often ending in a long, relatively sharp point which may curl on drying", margin incurved and tightly fitted around stem, joined when young specimens to the stem by a distinct though fleeting veil which leaves flecks that can be seen even in the most mature caps when carefully examined, if expanded retaining a frill of flecks; 'almost "apricot yellow" to "mustard yellow" when young becoming rich "chrome yellow" at the base, finally more "old gold" or "buffy citrine" at the base and "tawny" or near "buckthorn brown" toward the apex'; dry, wrinkled, fibrillose to fibrillose-scaly from remains of a floccose, "mustard yellow" to "ochraceous tawny" veil, (Thiers), narrowly conic; cream buff to ochraceous buff or gray-buff; shiny, sometimes with small brownish scales near margin, (Trudell)
INNER LAYER  soft; yellowish in cap, more buff in stem, particularly at base, and drying bright yellow^, (Thiers)
INTERIOR  spore mass of crisped or contorted gills that may or may not branch to form cavities; brown to reddish-brown^, (Arora), fusing and anastomosing to form elongate compartments; "Verona brown" at first then becoming flushed with "warm sepia", finally "bone brown" except for white or pale yellow margin, (Thiers)
STEM  5-12cm x 0.1-0.4cm, equal or with a small bulb at base, tough; yellow to yellowish-buff to tawny or yellow-brown; dry, smooth or fibrillose^, (Arora), 5-11 x 0.1-0.4cm, equal or slightly swollen at base in larger specimens; "pale ivory yellow" at top and near "Saccardo's umber" to "sepia" downwards, then "ochraceous buff" to "clay color" at the top with a hint of cinnamon yellow but base unchanging; dry with appressed fibrils at top, or fibrillose toward base from veil remnants, (Thiers), "covered with small pallid scales over a brownish background", (Trudell)
ODOR  not unpleasant, mild^, (Thiers)
TASTE  not unpleasant, mild^, (Thiers)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on ground, usually among grasses in wet alpine meadows^, (Arora), gregarious, often in large troops, in boggy or marshy areas; on ground among grasses and sedges, (Thiers)
SPORE DEPOSIT  not obtainable
MICROSCOPIC  spores 11-14(16) x 6-8(10) microns, elliptic, smooth, with germ pore, tawny to brown^, (Arora), spores 11.5-13(14.5) x 6.5-7.5(8) microns, elliptic to slightly almond-shaped, thick-walled, deep honey with a bister tint in water and KOH, prominent though not large apiculus, truncate by a slightly eccentric or apical germ pore; pleurocystidia rare, up to 25 microns long, lageniform and slightly mucronate, mixed with more vesiculose cells up to 15 microns broad, cheilocystidia numerous, forming a distinct fringe on gill, 35-70 x 5-7.5 microns, filamentous-cylindric, colorless or slightly yellowish; cap cuticle filamentous of +/- colored granulose cells 2-3 microns wide and up to 35 microns long; clamp connections infrequent but present
NAME ORIGIN  means 'hooded'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Thiers(10) (as Weraroa, colors in quotes from Ridgway), Arora(1)* (as Weraroa), Smith(31) (as Weraroa, discussing Weraroa coprophila), Trudell(4)* (as Weraroa), Desjardin(6)*
128
FAMILY  Morchellaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Leucangium carthusianum  (Tul.) Paol.^  in Saccardo, Syll. fung. (Abellini) 8: 900. 1889;  Picoa carthusiana  Tul.
ENGLISH NAMES  Oregon black truffle
NOTES  Features include 1) a somewhat spherical to slightly irregular fruitbody that looks like animal dung, 2) greenish to grayish color at maturity, 3) a minutely warted exterior, 4) a spore mass that is whitish becoming grayish green with whitish streaks, sometimes exuding a clear latex that stains white paper pale violet when left overnight, 5) growth in humus or soil in the woods, and 6) microscopic characters including large, smooth, lemon-shaped to spindle-shaped spores and typically 8-spored asci^. It was originally described from France but less frequent there than in the Pacific Northwest, (Trappe, M.(3)). Pacific Northwest collections may actually be a different species from the European one They are common among truffles in the Pacific Northwest, (Trappe(13)). RANGE Leucangium carthusianum is found from southern BC to western OR at low elevations, and also found in southern Europe, (Trappe(13)). There are collections from BC deposited at University of British Columbia. It occurs in WA (M. Beug, pers. comm., Colgan(2)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-4.5(8)cm across, dusky slate violet; minutely papillose^, (Smith), 0.5-4.5(8)cm broad, spherical or nearly spherical to slightly irregular, looks like a piece of animal dung; black to dusky slate-violet; exterior minutely warted, (Arora), brown to black; smooth to rough, (Trudell), charcoal black; warty but sometimes nearly smooth, (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  more or less solid, "grayish green marbled with whitish streaks"^, (Smith), "more or less solid, composed of large pockets of fertile tissue marbled with paler (whitish to buff) sterile veins; fertile tissue whitish to buff when young but becoming grayish-green to greenish-blue in age, sometimes exuding a clear latex when fresh which slowly (overnight) stains white paper pale violet", (Arora), "solid, comprising fertile tissue streaked with paler sterile veins"; fertile tissue "whitish to buff becoming grayish green or greenish blue; sometimes exudes a clear milk which slowly stains white paper light mauve", (Phillips), solid; gray to olive or brownish; "separated into pockets by pallid sterile veins", (Trudell), solid, firm; "gray pockets of spore-bearing tissue separated by white veins", (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  without a mycelial tuft at base^ (Arora)
ODOR  fungoid, pungent, or slightly garlic-like^, (Miller), "strong pungent fruity (often like pineapple)" when mature, (Trudell), pleasant and fruity (most often resembling pineapple) when young, becoming increasingly pungent and earthy when old, (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  "pleasant mild"^ (Miller)
EDIBILITY  good (Phillips)
HABITAT  under Douglas fir, fall and winter, (Smith), single, scattered or in small groups in soil and humus in woods, (Arora), several to many, in soil under conifers or oaks; early spring and summer (Miller), with relatively young Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), often 10-25cm deep in the soil; September to February, (Trappe, M.)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 74-85 x 24-35 microns, spindle-shaped to lemon-shaped, "greenish yellow to honey color, with distinct apiculus at one or both ends"^; asci 8-spored, spherical-ellipsoid, (Smith), spores (56)74-84 x 20-35 microns, lemon-shaped or spindle-shaped, smooth, typically with one giant oil droplet when mature, pallid to greenish yellow becoming brown when mature; asci "typically 8-spored, imbedded in the tissue (not forming a palisade)", (Arora), spores 52-109 x 19-42 microns, olive-colored, apiculate, (Castellano), spores 65-80 x 25-40 microns, fusoid, smooth, (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  means "Carthusian", "for the Carthusian monastery in France where the species was first found", (Trappe, M.(1))
SIMILAR  Kalapuya brunnea (often called Oregon brown truffle), found in young Douglas-fir stands in the Cascade Range in OR and Coastal Ranges of OR and northern CA, has a reddish-brown exterior with a granular texture and a grey marbled interior, a garlicky-cheesy odor, and different spores (smaller with many smaller droplets as well as the central one), (Trappe, M.(4)). Tuber species are similar in  having a solid interior, but in Leucangium carthusianum the spore mass is greenish to grayish when mature, the exterior minutely warted, and the spores are large, smooth, and spindle-shaped, (Arora). Tuber melanosporum, the European black truffle, and Tuber indicum, the Asian black truffle have become established and have completed their life cycle in North American soils, but have not been shown to occur in forests away from truffle farms except for one collection of Tuber indicum in Oregon, (Bonito(2)).
SOURCES  Smith(4) (as Picoa), Arora(1) (as Picoa), Trudell(4)*, Phillips(1)* (as Picoa), Miller(14)*, Castellano(4) (as Picoa), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Colgan(2), NATS(1) (discussing undescribed species), Trappe(13)*, Trappe, M.(4), Bonito(2)
129
FAMILY  Albatrellaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Leucogaster candidus  (Harkn.) Fogel^  Can. J. Bot. 57(16): 1727. 1979;  Leucophleps candida Harkn.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include small, irregular, white fruitbody with surface studded with shallow depressions, white spore mass with cavities filled with branched hyphae bearing spores terminally, the spores round, reticulate, colorless, and enclosed in a gelatinous sheath^; description derived from Zeller(9); infrequent, from western WA to northern CA, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2cm across, irregular; white; "surface studded with shallow depressions"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white; cavities filled with hyphae bearing spores
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  June in California, (Zeller), associated with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8 microns in diameter, round, "reticulate at maturity, enclosed in a gelatinous sheath", colorless^; "cavities filled with branched hyphae which bear spores terminally on the branches"; septa thin; peridium 15-20 microns thick, homogeneous with septa
NAME ORIGIN  means 'shining white'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Zeller(9) (as Leucophlebs candida), Trappe(13)
130
FAMILY  Albatrellaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Leucogaster citrinus  (Harkn.) Zeller & C.W. Dodge^  Ann. Mo. Bot. Gard. 11(4): 398. 1924
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a yellow, somewhat spherical fruitbody, 2) a white interior that has spherical locules 0.05-0.3cm broad, 3) one to several yellow rhizomorphs coming from the base, 4) an association with the roots of conifers, and 5) microscopic characters including nearly round basidiospores with tall spiny-reticulate ornamentation and a lack of inflated cells in the trama.^ It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE The distribution is at least WA, OR, and CA, (Castellano). It occurs from western WA to northern CA and ID, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on peridium (surface) pale brown-pink then brown, FeSO4 on peridium faintly gray^, (Castellano)
OUTER SURFACE  up to 2-4.5cm across, kidney-shaped; pale yellow to dark yellow^, (Castellano), 2cm across, nearly spherical; "citron color, imparting a reddish color to alcohol when immersed" (quotation from Harkness), becoming dirty vinaceous buff when dry, (Zeller), "light yellow to dark yellow", (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "white, trama white, locules spherical", 0.05-0.3cm broad, empty, smaller toward surface of fruitbody^, (Castellano), "ivory yellow" (Ridgway color) when dry; cavities large, spherical, empty, (Zeller), chambered, firm, locules round and 0.1-0.2cm across; white; "exuding a white sticky fluid when freshly cut", (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  with one to several coarse rhizomorphs coming from base, colored as outer surface of fruitbody^, (Castellano)
ODOR  mild but pleasant^, (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  found in association with the roots of Abies concolor (White Fir), A. lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Pinus monticola (Western White Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), from 280 to 2000m elevation, August through November^, (Castellano), under manzanita and laurel, April, (Zeller), with Pseudotsuga, Tsuga, Pinus, Abies, June to November, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-11 x (7)8-9 microns, including spinose-reticulate ornamentation, nearly round, colorless, enclosed in colorless perisporal sac, "ornamentation 1-1.5 microns high, 2-2.5 microns apart, spine base 0.2 microns wide, spore wall 1 micron thick, excluding ornamentation"^; apobasidia 4-spored, 100 x 5-7 microns, clavate, thin-walled, sterigmata absent, basidioles 100-125 x 5 microns, claviform, colorless, thin-walled; trama 60-80 microns thick, of hyphae 2-5 microns wide that are "subparallel, orange, thin-walled, gelatinous"; peridium 60-200 microns thick, of hyphae 2-4 microns wide that are periclinal, compact, and pallid yellow in color, with a red pigment in KOH, (Castellano), spores 7-11 x 7-11 microns, round, pitted or minutely verrucose, surrounded by a gelatinous sheath about 1-2 microns thick, brown in mass, nearly colorless under microscope; basidia 2-4-spored, 16-25 x 2-4 microns, narrowly clavate, colorless, filled with oil globules, sterigmata 5-7 microns long, slender; septa "20-30 microns thick between hymenial layers", composed of very slender, closely woven, colorless hyphae; peridium 140-170 microns thick, "composed of uniform, small, closely woven hyphae", appearing "light chalcedony-yellow" (Ridgway color), homogeneous except for included sand and spherical to irregular pigmented bodies 12-20 microns in diameter, appearing granular, "tawny" to "buckthorn-brown" (Ridgway colors), (Zeller)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to the citron [a lemon-like fruit]', probably in reference to its surface color
SIMILAR  Leucophleps species have spinose (rather than alveolate) spores that are embedded in a gelatinous matrix (rather than enclosed in a colorless perisporal sac separable from the underlying ornamentation ), the latex is scanty from fresh moist specimens when cut (copious in Leucogaster), and the locules are labyrinthiform and 0.03-0.05cm (rather than spherical and 0.05-0.3cm broad), (Fogel(4)).
SOURCES  Castellano(1), Zeller(9), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)*, Fogel(4) (discussing Leucophleps)
131
FAMILY  Albatrellaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Leucogaster microsporus  Fogel nom. prov.^
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a kidney-shaped fruitbody with the base indented, colored white with some yellow stains, drying pale red, 2) a peridium [outer skin] that is rather thick, 3) a white interior white that exudes a sticky white latex when cut, the locules spherical and 0.05-0.1cm across, 4) absent rhizomorphs, 5) growth under Douglas-fir and hemlock, and 6) nearly round spores that are small for the genus (6-10 x 5-6 microns) and enclosed in a colorless perisporal sac, the ornamentation of reticulate spines 0.25-0.5 microns high, with low connecting lines forming 5-6 sided alveoli, 7) 4-spored basidia, and 8) inflated cells in the peridium and trama.^ The description is derived from Castellano(1). It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Leucogaster microsporus nom. prov. is found at least in WA, OR, and CA, (Castellano(1)). It is found from southwestern WA to ID and northern CA, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH pale yellow on peridium, ferrous sulphate in water negative on peridium
OUTER SURFACE  up to 5cm x 4cm, kidney-shaped, base indented with peridial tissue (surface tissue) extending to the center of the fruitbody; white with some yellow stains, drying pale red; bald
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white, drying pale yellow-pink, exuding a sticky white latex when cut; locules spherical, 0.05-0.1cm across, empty in center of fruitbody, filled with spores next to surface
STEM  rhizomorphs absent
ODOR  sweet
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  found in association with roots of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) at 330-1000m elevation, August through November
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-10 x 5-6 microns including ornamentation, nearly round, enclosed in a colorless perisporal sac, "ornamentation of reticulate spines 0.25-0.5 microns high, 2 microns apart, with low connecting lines forming 5-6 sided alveoli"^; apobasidia 4-spored, 30-60 x 6-7 microns, claviform, colorless, thin-walled, sterigmata lacking, basidioles 30-35 x 3-4 microns, claviform, colorless, thin-walled, some encrusted with a colorless crystalline deposit in KOH; trama 60-125 microns thick, composed of hyphae 2-3 microns wide, subparallel, yellow, thin-walled, septate, cells becoming inflated to 10 microns; peridium 100-300 microns thick, composed of hyphae 3-5 microns wide, periclinal, pale yellow, thin-walled, cells becoming inflated to 15 microns, "some oleiferous, yellow, thin-walled hyphae", "outer 60 microns obscured in KOH by yellow, amorphous, pigment balls in Melzer's reagent"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'small-spored'
SIMILAR  Leucophleps species have spinose (rather than alveolate) spores that are embedded in a gelatinous matrix (rather than enclosed in a colorless perisporal sac separable from the underlying ornamentation ), the latex is scanty from fresh moist specimens when cut (copious in Leucogaster), and the locules are labyrinthiform and 0.03-0.05cm (rather than spherical and 0.05-0.3cm broad), (Fogel(4)).
SOURCES  Castellano(1)*, Trappe(13), Fogel(4) (discussing Leucophleps)
132
FAMILY  Albatrellaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Leucogaster odoratus  (Harkn.) Zeller & C.W. Dodge^  Ann. Mo. bot. Gdn 11: 396. 1924
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include light orange fruitbodies that are oblong or irregularly lobed, lacking fibrils and columella, the spore mass white with large, round, empty cavities, and when cut exuding a milky juice^; description derived from Zeller(9) except where noted; rare western OR to northern CA (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  3-4cm across, oblong or irregularly lobed; light orange; fibrils not present
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  cavities large, round, empty; white; exudes a milky juice when freshly cut
STEM  no columella
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) and Quercus (oak), (Trappe), June to July in California (Zeller)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-11 microns in diameter, round to slightly elliptic, "reticulate in gelatinous sheath", colorless^; basidia 20 x 5 microns, with long pedicel and short sterigmata; no paraphyses; peridium thin, about 100 microns thick, "of compactly woven, gelatinized hyphae, homogeneous with the septa"; septa about 75 microns thick, of three layers, the hymenium, subhymenial layers of closely interwoven hyphae, and a middle layer of parallel, gelatinized hyphae; the milky juice may be a dense suspension of spores as no definite latex organs were seen
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with an odor'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Zeller(9), Trappe(13)
133
FAMILY  Albatrellaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Leucogaster rubescens  Zeller & C.W. Dodge^  Ann. Mo. Bot. Gard. 11(4): 395. 1924
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a nearly spherical to irregular fruitbody with a viscid surface that is whitish to pink at first, becoming brick-red to brownish, 2) a spore mass that is cream in color, with about 2 cavities per mm, and filled with a clear gel, and exudes latex when the fresh fruiting body is cut, 3) growth partially or entirely underground, and 4) microscopic characters including round to oblong alveolate-reticulate spores with a gelatinous sheath, borne on 4-spored basidia.^ It is abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Leucogaster rubescens is found from WA to northern CA and ID; in the Rocky Mountains; and in the northeastern US, (Trappe(13)). The type collection is from OR. It is also reported by States(2) for AZ. Trappe, M.(1) says it has been found occasionally in eastern Canada.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-3.5cm across, nearly spherical to irregular; "whitish at first becoming flesh pink, brick red, to brownish"; surface viscid when moist^, (Smith), nearly spherical to irregular; at first whitish to flesh-pink, becoming "brick-red" to "Hessian brown", fibrils the same color or darker; "smooth, uneven, viscid when moist", fibrils innate-appressed; peridium drying brittle and "orange rufous", lined with the outer layer of the spore mass showing white in cross-section, (Zeller), whitish when young, darkening to pink then reddish brown, (Phillips), yellow when young, "becoming brick red, especially when dried"; can be brittle and crumbly when mature, (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  cream color when dried; "cavities about 2 per mm, filled with a clear gel", and exuding latex when fresh fruiting body is cut^, (Smith), drying cream color or "ivory-yellow" when cut after drying; cavities averaging about 2 to the millimeter, spherical to polyhedral, "lined with a clear gelatinous mucus", (Zeller), cream-white with tiny cells 2mm [sic] across filled with clear gel, exuding a latex when cut, (Phillips), firm, locules round and 0.1-0.2cm across; white; "exuding a white sticky fluid when freshly cut", (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  
ODOR  mild but pleasant, when mature may develop a coconut odor^, (Trappe, M.(3)), not distinctive (Phillips)
TASTE  not distinctive^ (Phillips)
EDIBILITY  yes (Phillips)
HABITAT  in duff and humus, spring^, (Smith), mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest trees in Pinaceae (Trappe(13)), in leaf mold under maple (Zeller for type), partly or entirely underground, in soil and leaf litter, April to June, (Phillips), associated with Pinus ponderosus (Ponderosa Pine), (States), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Pinus (pine), Abies (fir), May to December, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-15 microns in diameter, round to oblong, alveolate-reticulate [with broad pits and a network], inamyloid^, (Smith), spores 11-15 x 11-15 microns including gelatinous sheath, spore alone 6-10 x 6-10 microns, round to oblong, echino-reticulate, almost colorless; basidia 4-spored, 15-25 x 8-14 microns, not in a definite hymenium (embedded with spores in clear gelatinous mucus lining the cavities), colorless, pyriform, on pedicels 50-125 microns long, sterigmata 2-4 microns long; septa 35-55 microns thick, colorless, "of thin-walled hyphae, becoming scissile"; "peridium usually 15-35 microns thick, (sometimes 40-60 microns), composed of gelatinized pseudoparenchyma", lined with the fine, colorless hyphae of the outer layer of the gleba, (Zeller), spores 10-15 x 10-13 microns, nearly round to round, "reticulate, enclosed in a smooth, loosely fitting outer skin that at maturity appresses to the spore surface", (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'becoming red'
SIMILAR  Leucophleps species have spinose (rather than alveolate) spores that are embedded in a gelatinous matrix (rather than enclosed in a colorless perisporal sac separable from the underlying ornamentation ), the latex is scanty from fresh moist specimens when cut (copious in Leucogaster), and the locules are labyrinthiform and 0.03-0.05cm (rather than spherical and 0.05-0.3cm broad), (Fogel(4)).
SOURCES  Zeller(9) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Smith(4), Phillips(1)*, Smith, J.E.(1), Luoma(1), States(2), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Colgan(2), Fogel(4) (discussing Leucophleps), Trappe(13), Desjardin(6)*
134
FAMILY  Albatrellaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Leucophleps levispora  (Mattir.) Fogel^  Can. J. Bot. 57(16): 1724. 1979;  Cremeogaster levisporus  Mattir.;  Leucogaster rotundisporus  Fogel & Trappe
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include fruitbody that when dried is spherical to lobed, dark red to almost black, wrinkled and granulose, with interior pallid orange with white tramal plates and labyrinthiform locules 0.03-0.05cm wide, growth underground, and microscopic characters including broadly elliptic spores with fine ornamentation of crowded spines 0.1 micron or less high embedded in a gelatinous matrix, the basidia 4-spored^; description derived from Fogel(4), fresh characters unavailable; reported from OR by J. Smith et al.; rare in the Pacific Northwest, found in western OR, southern CA, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  when dried, up to 3.5cm x 2cm, spherical to irregularly lobed, very dark red, almost black, rugulose [finely wrinkled], granulose
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  when dried, pallid orange with white tramal plates, latex not recorded, locules labyrinthiform, 0.03-0.05cm wide, filled with spores, friable (when dried)
STEM  rhizomorphs not present
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type from California underground under Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa pine), December
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-13(19) x 7-10(14) including ornamentation, broadly elliptic, "ornamentation of crowded spines 0.1 micron or less high embedded in a gelatinous matrix", spores colorless, wall 1-2 microns thick, sterigmal peg central to rarely oblique^; apobasidia 4-spored, 45-50 x +/- 9 microns, clavate-pedunculate, colorless, thin-walled, sterigmata 6 x 1.5 microns, straight, basidioles 45-50 x 8 microns, clavate-pedunculate, colorless, thin-walled; tramal plates 150-188 microns wide, trama of hyphae 2-4 microns wide, subparallel, colorless, cells becoming inflated up to 12 microns; peridium 100-150(260) microns thick, of periclinal, gelatinized, colorless hyphae 4-5 microns wide that by maturity inflate to 20 microns and become more or less isodiametric, "obscured by diffuse, intercellular, orange pigment when mounted in Melzer's reagent"
NAME ORIGIN  means "smooth spored"
SIMILAR  Leucophleps magnata has round spores with taller ornamentation, (Fogel); Leucophleps spinispora has round or nearly round spores, (Fogel); Leucogaster species have alveolate (rather than spinose) spores that are enclosed in a colorless perisporal sac separable from the underlying ornamentation (rather than embedded in a gelatinous matrix), latex is copious from fresh moist specimens when cut (scanty in Leucophleps), and locules are spherical and 0.05-0.3cm broad (rather than labyrinthiform and 0.03-0.05cm), (Fogel)
SOURCES  Fogel(4), Smith, J.E.(1), Trappe(13)
135
FAMILY  Albatrellaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Leucophleps magnata  Harkn.^  Proc. Calif. Acad. Sci. Bot. III. 1: 257-258. 1899;  == Leucogaster magnatus  (Harkn.) Zeller
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a nearly spherical to kidney-shaped or elongate fruitbody that is white with light yellow in depressions becoming pale yellow overall, 2) an interior that is white (when freshly cut showing a transient faint blue tint), the locules labyrinthiform and about 0.05cm broad near the center, 3) scanty sticky latex produced when freshly cut, 4) innate appressed rhizomorphs colored the same as the surface, 5) underground growth under fir and Douglas-fir, and 6) microscopic characters including round spores with ornamentation of slender crowded spines 1-2 microns high embedded in a gelatinous matrix, the basidia 4-spored.^ It is abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Collections were examined from WA, OR, ID, and CA, (Fogel). It is found from WA to northern  CA and east to MT (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on fresh peridium [outer skin] pink, FeSO4 on fresh peridium negative, Melzer's reagent on fresh peridium green, (Fogel)
OUTER SURFACE  up to 3cm across, nearly spherical, kidney-shaped or elongate; white with light yellow in depressions, becoming pallid yellow when old, drying medium brown; rugulose [finely wrinkled]^, (Fogel)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "white, freshly cut surfaces showing a faint blue tint which soon vanishes, drying ochraceous-orange (strongly orange-yellow) or pale yellow"; scanty sticky latex produced on cutting fresh fruitbodies; locules labyrinthiform +/- 0.05cm broad near center of fruitbody, smaller toward periphery, empty in center or filled with spores when mature^, (Fogel)
STEM  rhizomorphs innate appressed, colored as peridium^, (Fogel)
ODOR  on drying astringent, also referred to as acrid^, (Fogel)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground in stands of Abies (fir) and Tsuga (hemlock) "in western Oregon and Washington from June to October", and low-elevation second growth stands of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) "from April to May in western Oregon and December in northern California", specific mycorrhizal associates probably being Pseudotsuga and Abies^, (Fogel)
SPORE DEPOSIT
