MICROSCOPIC  spores (10)15-17(22) microns diameter (including ornamentation), ornamentation 1-2 microns high, embedded in gelatinous matrix^, (Smith), spores (10)15-17(22) microns in diameter including ornamentation, round, "ornamentation of slender, crowded spines 1-2 microns high embedded in a gelatinous matrix", spores light yellow singly in Melzer's reagent and in KOH, "spore wall 1-2 microns thick, with basal pore, sterigmal appendage lacking"; apobasidia 4-spored, 30-50 x 6-12 microns, "clavate to claviform", colorless, thin-walled, content granular in KOH, sterigmata 5-8 x 2 microns, flexuous [wavy], basidioles 30-50 x 6-12 microns, "clavate to claviform", colorless, thin-walled, simple-septate at base; tramal plates (40)60-80 microns wide, trama composed of hyphae 3-5 microns wide, subparallel, colorless, thin-walled, septate, the cells becoming inflated to 7 microns; peridium (80)120-180 microns thick, of hyphae 3-6 microns wide, periclinal, colorless, thin-walled to thick-walled (0.5 micron), obscured by yellow intercellular pigment (in Melzer's reagent), and colorless crystals, some areas staining green in Melzer's reagent, fading in intensity after 10-15 minutes, (Fogel)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin 'magnus' meaning 'large'
SIMILAR  Leucophleps spinispora similarly has a slight to strong acrid odor after drying, has a green surface reaction to Melzer's reagent, and occurs in similar habits, but it has smaller spores with shorter ornamentation (rare collections have spore ornamentation of intermediate height measuring 0.5-0.75 microns high), (Fogel). Leucophleps levispora has broadly elliptic spores with shorter ornamentation, (Fogel). Leucogaster species have alveolate (rather than spinose) spores that are enclosed in a colorless perisporal sac separable from the underlying ornamentation (rather than embedded in a gelatinous matrix), the latex is copious from fresh moist specimens when cut (scanty in Leucophleps), and the locules are spherical and 0.05-0.3cm broad (rather than labyrinthiform and 0.03-0.05cm), (Fogel).
SOURCES  Smith(4), Fogel(4) (colors from Kelly(2)), Zeller(8) (as Leucogaster magnatus), Zeller(9) (as Leucophlebs magnata), Trappe(13)*
136
FAMILY  Albatrellaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Leucophleps spinispora  Fogel^  Can. J. Bot. 57. 1724. 1979;  Leucogaster  levisporus  Zeller non (Mattir.) Fogel & Trappe
ENGLISH NAMES  white jellied false truffle
NOTES  Features include 1) a nearly spherical to irregularly lobed. white fruitbody that becomes grayish, 2) an interior that is white with scanty sticky latex produced when freshly cut, the locules labyrinthiform and about 0.05cm broad near the center, 3) appressed rhizomorphs over the surface, 4) underground growth under fir and Douglas-fir, and 5) microscopic characters including spores that are mostly nearly round to round but occasionally angular, with ornamentation of crowded spines 0.5 micron or less high embedded in a gelatinous matrix, the basidia 4-spored.^ It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Leucophleps spinispora is found from eastern WA to ID, OR, northern CA, AZ, and Mexico, (Trappe(13)). Collections were examined from WA, OR, ID, AK, AZ, CA, CO, and Mexico, and the range also includes UT and NM, (Fogel).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on fresh peridium [outer skin] pink to red, FeSO4 on fresh peridium negative, Melzer's reagent on fresh peridium green^, (Fogel)
OUTER SURFACE  up to 2.5cm across, spherical to irregularly lobed, chalk or milk-white becoming grayish, drying light ochraceous-buff (moderate orange-yellow) with darker brown areas; rugulose [finely wrinkled]; consistency when dried "pith-like but sectioning easily without crumbling unless partially decomposed"^, (Fogel), 1-3cm across, spherical to ovoid or irregularly lobed; white or whitish, often becoming grayish when old; usually wrinkled, (Arora)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white, drying ochraceous-orange (strong orange yellow), tramal plates the same color; scanty sticky latex produced on cutting fresh specimens; locules labyrinthiform, +/- 0.05cm broad, smaller toward periphery of fruitbody, "filled with spores when mature, empty after drying"^, (Fogel), "white, often exuding a white latex when cut", composed of many tiny (less than 0.1cm), "clear, gel-filled chambers (unless old or late to develop)", "sterile veins absent", (Arora)
STEM  rhizomorphs single and basal on young fruitbodies, abundantly appressed over surface when mature^, (Fogel), stem and columella absent; typically covered with rhizomorphs, but when young usually with rhizomorphs only at base, (Arora)
ODOR  "slight to acrid on drying", said to be similar in odor to Leucophleps magnata whose odor is described as astringent^, (Fogel), little odor when fresh, "but dried specimens develop an odor of celery salt", (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  unknown (Arora)
HABITAT  underground in coniferous forests of Picea (spruce), Larix (larch), Abies (fir), and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), June to December, (specific mycorrhizal associate probably Abies or infrequently Pseudotsuga menziesii)^, (Fogel), single to gregarious "in soil or duff (usually buried) under western conifers", (Arora), with Pseudotsuga, Tsuga (hemlock), Pinus (pine), Abies, June to December, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-13 x 10-11microns (including ornamentation), ornamentation to 0.5 microns high, embedded in gelatinous matrix^, (Smith), spores 10-13 x 10-11 microns (including ornamentation), occasionally up to 20 microns in diameter, mostly nearly round to round, occasionally angular, "ornamentation of crowded spines 0.5 micron or less high embedded in a gelatinous matrix", "spore wall plus ornamentation and gelatinous matrix 1-1.5 microns thick", "short sterigmal peg occasionally present", spores in KOH colorless singly and nearly colorless in mass; apobasidia 4-spored, 45-50 x 9-10 microns, clavate, colorless, thin-walled, content granular in KOH when mature, sterigmata 6-8 x 1.5-2.0 microns, straight or flexuous (according to Zeller(1941) up to 22.5 x 2.5 microns), basidioles +/-50 x 10 microns, clavate, colorless in KOH, thin-walled; tramal plates (30)50-90 microns wide, trama composed of hyphae 4-5 microns wide at septa, subparallel, colorless, thin-walled, "the cells becoming inflated to 10 microns to appear nearly pseudoparenchymatous"; peridium 100-200 microns thick drying to 25-50 microns, of interwoven, colorless, thin-walled hyphae 2-4 microns wide near periphery, becoming 10 microns wide toward locules, "obscured by pale yellow, diffuse, intercellular pigment" (in KOH), "some surface hyphae thick-walled and medium gray in Melzer's reagent", (Fogel)
NAME ORIGIN  means "spiny-spored"
SIMILAR  Leucophleps magnata similarly has a slight to strong acrid odor after drying, has a green surface reaction to Melzer's reagent, and occurs in similar habits, but it has larger spores with taller ornamentation (rare collections have spore ornamentation of intermediate height measuring 0.5-0.75 microns high), (Fogel). Leucophleps levispora has broadly elliptic spores, (Fogel). Leucogaster species have alveolate (rather than spinose) spores that are enclosed in a colorless perisporal sac separable from the underlying ornamentation (rather than embedded in a gelatinous matrix), the latex is copious from fresh moist specimens when cut (scanty in Leucophleps), and the locules are spherical and 0.05-0.3cm broad (rather than labyrinthiform and 0.03-0.05cm), (Fogel).
SOURCES  Fogel(4) (colors from Kelly(2)), Smith(4), Arora(1), Luoma(1), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13), Desjardin(6)*
137
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Macowanites lilacinus  A.H. Sm.^  Mycologia 55: 426. 1963;  Russula lilacina  (unpublished combination)
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. The fact that the name was not moved to Russula in Elliott, T.F.(1) could imply doubt that it is an independent species. Features include a dull grayish lilac, slimy-viscid cap with a separable skin, lilac-gray, fragile flesh that stains vinaceous in FeSO4, a free ochraceous spore mass that is gill-like and interveined, a peculiar odor, nearly round spores with amyloid ridges and isolated elements, and 4-spored basidia.^ The description is derived from Smith(24). RANGE The holotype was found in ID.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  flesh and stem dingy vinaceous in FeSO4
OUTER SURFACE  2.8cm broad, convex-depressed; evenly dull grayish lilac; slimy-viscid, bald, smooth at first, irregularly rimose [cracked] when old, shiny when dry and pellicle [cap skin] separable to disc
INNER LAYER  exceedingly fragile, thin; watery lilac-gray, in stem-columella white
INTERIOR  spore mass free from the stem-columella, attached only to underside of peridium, lamellate [gill-like] with the gills very interveined; "pale ochraceous when mature and not staining when injured"
STEM  stem-columella 2cm long, 0.8cm wide, solid, soon hollow; white
ODOR  peculiar
TASTE  mild
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single under spruce and fir
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-10 x 7-9 microns, nearly round to round, 'ornamentation rather scattered and essentially a broken reticulum with lines of fused amyloid granules, "fish bone" lines branching from these, and isolated amyloid particles (the latter numerous), major elements 0.2-0.6 microns high, plage area with more densely arranged and reduced ornamentation', wall inamyloid, "sterigmal attachment inconspicuous"^; basidia 4-spored, 33-40 x 9-14 microns, clavate, broadest below the apex, colorless in KOH, thin-walled; macrocystidia numerous, 50-73 x 9-16 microns, "subfusoid to subclavate and mucronate, thin-walled, content of refractive particles of various types", colorless in KOH; subhymenium cellular, 2-4 cells deep, central part of hymenophoral trama entirely of sphaerocysts, colorless in KOH; peridial trama grading off into heteromerous tissue [with nests of sphaerocysts among filamentous hyphae] immediately under the epicuticular turf; epicutis of peridium a short turf of subgelatinous elements 60-100 microns high and 2-5 microns wide, apical cells not enlarged, pseudocystidia 100 microns or more long and 5-8 microns wide also present, narrowly clavate, "some with the apical cell subfusoid with an acute apex, some with an apical capitellum, content of pseudocystidia refractive-granular in at least some cells of the filament"; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  refers to lilac color
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(24), Trappe(13), Elliott, T.F.(1)
138
FAMILY  Paxillaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Melanogaster 'ambiguus'  (Vittad.) Tul.^  Ann. Sci. Nat. Bot. II. 19: 378. 1843;  Octaviania ambigua  Vittad.;  Melanogaster klotzschii  Corda
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a nearly spherical to ellipsoid fruitbody that is pale olive to olivaceous brown to brown, with a cottony-furfuraceous surface and scanty inconspicuous rhizomorphs, 2) a spore-mass that is black with white to yellowish septa, the cavities large and filled with spores embedded in a gel, 3) growth under hardwoods, and 4) microscopic characters including spores that are smooth, dark brown, and oboval to lemon-shaped, and mostly 4-spored basidia.^ It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). The name might not be correct for the Pacific Northwest - a new name may be needed. RANGE It is found in western WA, western OR and Idaho, and is widespread in Europe, (Trappe(13)). Collections were examined from OR, KY, NY, France, Germany, Italy, United Kingdom, and New Zealand, (Zeller(12)). It has also been found in AZ (States).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-3.5cm across, nearly spherical to ellipsoid; 'pale olive to olivaceous brown when fresh, becoming "cinnamon-brown" to "Prout's brown" on drying'; "surface cottony-furfuraceous, fibrils scanty, inconspicuous"^, (Zeller(12)), 1.5-3cm across, nearly spherical, irregularly lobed, dimpled; warm "buff" then "brown" to "Prout's brown", bruising fuscous; smooth, fibrillose, with dark brown rhizomorphs that lightly cover the surface of the fruitbody, (States), 1-3cm across, more or less spherical to ellipsoid, soft and rubbery in consistency; gray-brown then olive, bruising dark purple-brown; "finely downy, then smooth", (Buczacki)
INNER LAYER  peridium thin^ (Buczacki)
INTERIOR  black with yellowish septa; 'cavities filled with spores embedded in a gel'^, (Zeller(12)), "with distinct white to yellowish tramal veins", chambers up to 0.1cm in diameter, "filled with spores in gelatinous material", black with spore maturation, (States), white, with numerous regularly arranged, dark, small, +/- rounded cavities larger toward base and center, with slimy contents, (Buczacki)
STEM  stem absent, initially attached at base by fine branching rhizomorphs^ (Buczacki)
ODOR  strongly metallic and disagreeable (States), "faint, indefinite, then sweet, then foul, foetid, rotting onions, rubber", (Buczacki)
TASTE  indistinct^ (Buczacki)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under hardwoods, April to October, (Zeller(12)), found once associated with a mixed stand of Pinus ponderosus (Ponderosa Pine) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) beneath a thick layer of duff in September, (States for Arizona), broad spectrum of hosts in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe), at soil surface on organic or sandy soil in woodland, usually with oak or beech, fall, (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (8)12-16(17) x (5.5)6-8(8.5) microns, oboval with more or less acute apex, approaching citriform [lemon-shaped], smooth, dark brown when mature, thick-walled, very often with one droplet^; basidia clavate, disappearing, mostly 4-spored; peridium 300-600 microns thick when fresh, somewhat thinner when dried, colorless within, yellowish brown toward surface, "prosenchymatous, homogeneous, with outer filaments fraying out to form the more or less erect, brown tomentellum at the surface, of large, thick-walled, agglutinated hyphae which often collapse on drying"; tramal tissue "of more slender, smaller-celled prosenchyma", (Zeller(12)), spores 10-15 x 7-9(10) microns, broadly elliptic with subacute apex, base truncate and cupped, spores dark rust brown, guttulate and thick-walled, peridium 500 microns thick composed of hyphae with swollen cells and clamp connections, (States), spores 14-20 x 8-10.5 microns, broadly elliptic then lemon-shaped or spindle-shaped with sharp point, smooth, black, (Buczacki)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'changeable, uncertain, doubtful, of double meaning'
SIMILAR  Melanogaster euryspermus may be distinguished from M. ambiguus "by the large cavities, white septa, the color of the peridium, and more abundant spores", (Zeller(12)). M. euryspermus differs in having a warm, brown, smooth and firm surface, (M. ambiguus having an olivaceous spongy surface), and also differs in the structure of the peridium, and the color, walls, shape, and size of spores, (Zeller(7)).
SOURCES  Zeller(12) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Colgan(2), States(2), Trappe(13), Zeller(7)
139
FAMILY  Paxillaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Melanogaster broomeanus  Berk.^  in Tulasne, Ann. Sci. Nat. Bot. II. 19: 377. 1843 [as 'broomeianus']
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include nearly spherical to irregularly lobed fruitbodies that are ochraceous then dark yellowish brown with a pinkish tint, the surface appressed-tomentose, brown fibrils on lower part, sooty-black gelatinous spore mass with white to cream septa and cavities filled with spores in a gel, odor of coffee grounds, growth under hardwoods, and microscopic characters including smooth spores that are narrowly oblong and truncate^; collections examined from OR, IN, MI, Austria, France, Germany, Italy, Switzerland, United Kingdom, USSR
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2-4cm across, nearly spherical to irregularly lobed, often coalescing when cespitose [clustered]; ochraceous then "Dresden brown" with a flesh tint, becoming blackish where handled, drying "tawny-olive" to "warm sepia"; appressed-tomentose; brown fibrils in lower part^, (Zeller), 0.5-4cm, more or less spherical to top-shaped, "sometimes lobed irregularly, sometimes fusing"; fruitbody "yellow-brown, quickly bruising red-brown or black when handled", peridium "pale yellow-green to yellow, then brown, then red-brown, then purple-black, often cracking", (Buczacki)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  sooty-black, gelified, tramal septa white to creamy, cavities filled with spores in a gel^, (Zeller), "yellow, then reddish, then purple-black", with numerous regularly arranged +/- rounded cavities, (Buczacki)
STEM  brown fibrils in lower part^ (Zeller), stem absent, "sparse rhizomorphs at base", (Buczacki)
ODOR  of coffee grounds (Zeller), "faint, sweet, fruity, pleasant", (Buczacki)
TASTE  indistinct^ (Buczacki)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under hardwoods, July to February^, (Zeller), single or in small to large groups, shallowly underground or at soil surface "on organic soil and among litter in woodland on alkaline sites"; summer to fall, (Buczacki)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (5)6-8.4(11) x (2.5)3.5-4.0(4.5) microns, narrowly oblong, broadly truncate in lower part, light brown^; septa of subgelatinous colorless hyphae; peridium variable in thickness, 50-200 microns (mostly 50-100 microns), "of stupose prosenchyma with large vesiculose cells, yellow-amber to darker toward the exterior, extending as fundamental tissue into the trama", (Zeller), spores 6.5-10 x 3.5-5 microns, narrowly elliptic to cylindric with truncate base, black, slimy, (Buczacki)
NAME ORIGIN  probably after Christopher Edmund Broome, with whom Berkeley co-authored many publications
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Zeller(12) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Buczacki(1)*
140
FAMILY  Paxillaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Melanogaster euryspermus  (Zeller & C.W. Dodge) Zeller^  Mycologia 31: 8. 1939;  Melanogaster ambiguus  var. euryspermus  Zeller & C.W. Dodge  Ann. Mo. Bot. Gard. 22: 373. 1935
ENGLISH NAMES  black veined false truffle
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to irregular fruitbody that is white then yellowish when young, becoming brown, with a smooth surface and a few tightly attached fibrils on the lower part, 2) a gelatinous black large-chambered spore mass with white partitions that dry yellowish, 3) distinctive odor (Rhenish wine, sewer gas, sometimes with a citrous component), and 4) microscopic characters including spores that are smooth, black, and elliptic to lemon-shaped, and 4-spored (or occasionally 2-spored) basidia.^ It is common among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It is found from WA to southern CA, (Trappe(13)). Collections examined from OR and CA, (Zeller(12)). It has also been found in AZ (States(2)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  surface brownish in KOH; septa staining "Artemesia green" in Melzer's reagent^, (States)
OUTER SURFACE  1.5-4(6)cm across, spherical to elongated or lobed; rusty brown to reddish brown, warm brown, or dark brown (but often more yellow when young), "often blackening where bruised"; slightly fibrillose to downy or felty^, (Arora), up to 3.5cm across, spherical to irregular, "snuff-brown" to "bister", not changing with drying, fibrils the same color; smooth, dull, fibrils few, adnate-appressed [tightly attached against surface], not extending halfway up; peridium thick, tough, (Zeller(12)), 1-3cm across, nearly spherical, somewhat lobed; white then "luteous" when young, becoming brown when old, brownish on bruising; slightly viscid when wet, (States)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  with large (up to 0.5cm) "blackish gel-filled chambers separated by whitish to yellow meandering veins"^, (Arora), coal-black with white partitions (drying yellowish); cavities gelatinous, filled with spores when mature, (Zeller(12)), firm; yellowish olive to fuscous black when mature, septa white to light luteous, chambers large and labyrinthiform [maze-like], gelatinizing and filling with spores, (States)
STEM  often with rhizomorphs at base; stem and columella absent^, (Arora), fibrils not distinctly radicate, (Zeller(12)), "with conspicuous basally appressed rhizomorphs" (States)
ODOR  usually strong when old, "sometimes like sewer gas, at other times with a pleasant citrus component"^, (Arora), distinctive odor of Rhenish wine (Zeller(12)), pronounced when mature, and disagreeable (States)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single, widely scattered, or in small groups in duff or soil both under hardwoods and under conifers^, (Arora), in strawberry patch, March to April, (Zeller(12)), beneath litter of Pinus ponderosus (Ponderosa Pine) and in the mineral soil up to 10cm deep, July and September, (States for Arizona), in the Pacific Northwest mycorrhizal with a broad spectrum of hosts, (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores "9-18 x 7-11 microns, lemon-shaped (but with two small prongs at one end), thick-walled, smooth, dark brown"^, (Arora), spores 10-11 x 7.5-9 (usual mature spore 11 x 8.5 microns), elliptic to citriform [lemon-shaped], black; basidia 4-spored, "with long slender (2.5 microns) pedicels of odd lengths, tips pyriform, 5 x 7 microns", sterigmata short, up to 3 microns long; septa variable in thickness, colorless, of small hyphae up to 2.5 microns wide; peridium 320-400 microns thick, "of dark brown hyphae with thin walls, somewhat vesiculose, variable in size, closely stupose", (Zeller(12)), spores range up to 18 microns long and 11 microns wide, (Zeller(7)), spores (9.5)11-16 x (7.5)8-12 microns, elliptic to citriform, "acutely truncate at the base, bluntly apiculate, guttulate in KOH", "sienna" to dark bister; basidia 4-spored or occasionally 2-spored, slowly disappearing, broadly clavate, 18-35 microns wide at apex with short narrow sterigmata; septa composed of hyphae 10-25 microns wide, swollen, filamentous; peridium 800-1000 microns thick but thinner when old, "uniformly composed of compact hyphae that are continuous with glebal tissue", (States)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with wide spores', from 'eurys' = wide (Greek), or 'with widespread spores'
SIMILAR  Melanogaster ambiguus is similar but M. euryspermus may be distinguished from it "by the large cavities, white septa, the color of the peridium, and more abundant spores", (Zeller(12)). M. ambiguus differs in having an olivaceous spongy surface, (M. euryspermus having a warm, brown, smooth and firm surface), and also differs in the structure of the peridium, and color, walls, shape, and size of spores, (Zeller(7)). M. ambiguus has large, elongated spores and a spongy, more olive-colored exterior plus a somewhat metallic odor when old, and is often under Douglas fir.  Melanogaster intermedius has also been reported to the Oregon Truffling Society for OR: it has spores smaller than M. euryspermus. Other species reported to Oregon Truffling Society for OR include Melanogaster vittadinii, Melanogaster tuberiformis, and Melanogaster natsii.
SOURCES  Arora(1), Zeller(7), Zeller(12) (as Melanogaster ambiguus var. euryspermus, colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Zeller(11) (as Melanogaster ambiguus var. eurysperma), States(2) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Colgan(2), Trappe(13)*
141
FAMILY  Paxillaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Melanogaster intermedius  (Berk.) Zeller & C.W. Dodge^  Ann. Mo. bot. Gdn 23: 645. 1936;  Melanogaster ambiguus  var. intermedius  Berk.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include nearly spherical to kidney-shaped, dark reddish brown fruitbody that becomes blackish brown where bruised, the surface tomentulose, with plentiful fibrils at a definite point of attachment, spore mass that is slaty black, slightly lined with septa and the cavities filled with gel, and microscopic characters including dark, smooth, suboval spores in a gel^; infrequent in western OR, northern CA, (Trappe(13)), also in England (Zeller)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2-4.5cm across, nearly spherical to kidney-shaped; very dark reddish brown when fresh, "becoming blackish where bruised"; "surface even to undulating, tomentulose", fibrils plentiful in lower part, "at a definite place of attachment"^, (Zeller), 1-4.5cm across, more or less spherical to kidney-shaped; red-brown, bruising dark brown to black; smooth or finely downy, (Buczacki)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  slaty black, "slightly lined or streaked with thin septa", cavities filled with spores in a gel^, (Zeller), white to pale yellow, then gray-black, with numerous +/- rounded cavities, (Buczacki)
STEM  stem absent, sparse rhizomorphs at base^, (Buczacki)
ODOR  strong, offensive^ (Zeller), strong, unpleasant, foetid, (Buczacki)
TASTE  indistinct^ (Buczacki)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under hardwoods (Zeller), associated with trees in family Pinaceae (Trappe), shallowly underground or at soil surface "on organic soil and among litter in woodland on alkaline sites"; fall, winter, spring, (Buczacki)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 11-13 x 7.4-8 microns, dark, mostly suboval, "obtuse, smooth, very rarely somewhat fusiform, tip subacute"^; cavities filled with spores in a gel; "thin septa, of hyaline (dilute yellowish) gelified hyphae"; peridium 125-160 microns thick, "light yellow to brownish near the exterior", stupose [with tufted or matted filaments], "of hyphae with vesiculose cells, homogeneous, but loosely woven at the surface with some erect hyphae giving the tomentulose character, distinct from the tramal tissue", (Zeller), spores 10-14.5 x 6.5-9 microns, broadly elliptic to short terminal appendage, smooth, brown-black, (Buczacki)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'intermediate'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Melanogaster euryspermus.
SOURCES  Zeller(12), Trappe(13), Buczacki(1)*
142
FAMILY  Paxillaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Melanogaster macrocarpus  Zeller^  Mycologia 31: 9. 1939
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include large snuff brown to tawny olive fruitbody with black gelatinous interior mottled by white septa, odor of spoiled silage or of onions, growth in forest duff under conifers, and microscopic characters including large, broadly obovoid, presumably smooth spores, and 4-spored basidia^; description derived from Zeller(7); Zeller says that this species is doubtless close to Melanogaster microsporus Velen., the type of which was not available, (Zeller(7)) and had earlier described three of the same collections under Melanogaster macrosporus Velen. (Zeller(12)); collections examined from OR
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  up to 12cm x 8cm x 6cm, "snuff brown" or "tawny-olive", drying "russet" to "Mars brown" and darker
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  black, mottled by white septa
STEM  
ODOR  "of spoiled silage or of onions without the tear-producing qualities"
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in forest duff under conifers, especially Tsuga (hemlock), August to October
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-15 x 8-11 microns, broadly obovoid, dark brown^; basidia 4-spored, broadly clavate, colorless, sterigmata 1/5 the length of the spores; septa "about 30-60 microns thick, of gelatinous hyphae and a central plate of prosenchyma"; peridium "about 100-140 microns thick, of a compact prosenchyma which is dark brown at the surface, shading to lighter within", its cells thick-walled, about 7 microns in diameter, "overlying a gelatinous tramal peridium about 50-100 microns thick, which is interrupted by prosenchymatous plates (septa) which have unbroken connection with the peridium and extend into the gleba"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with large fruit', presumably referring to the large size of the fruitbody
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Zeller(7) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Zeller(12) (as Melanogaster macrosporus)
143
FAMILY  Paxillaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Melanogaster 'tuberiformis'  Corda^  in Sturm, Deutschl. Fl. III. 11: 1. 1831
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a somewhat spherical, dark reddish brown to nearly blackish brown fruitbody sparsely covered by separable appressed black rhizomorphs more densely clustered at the base, 2) a blackish spore mass with white or slightly yellowish septa and irregularly shaped chambers filled with spores in a gel, 3) a disagreeable musty or oily-metallic odor, 4) underground growth, and 5) microscopic characters including oboval to pear-shaped spores that are smooth and rich rust-color to dark vinaceous brown, and 2-4-spored basidia.^ It is abundant among truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). The name might not be correct for the Pacific Northwest - a new name may be needed. RANGE It is found from WA to northern CA, ID and MT, (Trappe(13)). Collections were examined from OR, ID, CA, Czechoslovakia, France, and Germany, (Zeller). It has been found in AZ by States(2).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.8-3.5cm across, "variously shaped according to position in soil and litter"; smooth, "sparsely covered by separable black rhizomorphs more densely clustered at the base"^, (States), 1.5-7cm across when fresh, drying 1-2cm in material examined, nearly spherical, bay or reddish-fuscous, drying "Rood's brown" to "Vandyke brown"; fibrils rare, basal, appressed, black, (Zeller), dark brown, becoming nearly blackish brown when fully mature; in wet weather often with dark brown fluid droplets on surface, (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "dark olive" to "fuscous black", firm and resilient at first, gelatinous when old and with contrasting white to "luteous" septa surrounding irregularly shaped chambers, "the chambers filled with spores in a gel", drying hard as compact small spheres or "as a membranous film drawn away from the cavities"^, (States), black with white or slightly yellowish, inconspicuous septa, (Zeller), gelatinous; black with whitish veins when mature, "resembling marbled tar", (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  "sparsely covered by separable black rhizomorphs more densely clustered at the base"^, (States), fibrils rare, basal, appressed, black, (Zeller) 
ODOR  musty and disagreeable, (States), "oily-metallic with a touch of garlic", (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  associated with roots of Pinus ponderosus (Ponderosa Pine), embedded in mineral soil up to 6cm "but occasionally in humus beneath a deep litter layer", spring and fall^, (States), under Pinus (pine), Quercus (oak), Erica, (Zeller), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Pinus, Tsuga (hemlock), Picea (spruce), Abies (fir), year round, (Trappe, M.(3)), in the Pacific Northwest mycorrhizal with a broad spectrum of hosts (Trappe(13))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-14 x 6-10 microns, oboval to pyriform [pear-shaped], smooth, rich rust to dark vinaceous brown^; basidia 2-4-spored, colorless, slowly evanescent [disappearing], terminally clavate, subtended by clamp connections; peridium "composed of tightly compressed hyphae in two layers", the outer of uniform, brown-pigmented hyphae "that descend into a second lightly pigmented layer of mixed hyphal and pseudoparenchymatous cells, this tissue descending into the gleba below", (States), spores 10-11.5 x 5.5-7 microns, oboval, (sometimes pyriform), smooth, very dark brown; basidia evanescent, usually 8-spored; peridium 100-185 microns thick, stupose, amber to darker, (Zeller)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin 'tuber', meaning 'swelling' or 'bulb', and 'forma' meaning 'shape', hence 'bulb-shaped', or 'shaped like a truffle (Tuber)'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  States(2) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Zeller(12) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Smith, J.E.(1), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Colgan(2), Trappe(13)
144
FAMILY  Paxillaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Melanogaster variegatus  (Vittad.) Tul. & C. Tul.^  Fungi hypog.: 92. 1851;  Octaviania variegata  Vittad.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include irregular, rounded, smooth, ocher-ferruginous fruiting bodies with fuscous basal fibrils, spore mass yellowish ashy at first, becoming black, with thin yellow-orange septa, the cavities somewhat pentagonal, and microscopic characters including dark brown, smooth, elliptic spores^, description derived from Zeller(12); common in the Pacific Northwest, found from western WA to southern CA, (Trappe), CA, Italy, Algeria, (Zeller)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  "the size of a hen's egg or fist", drying 2cm across; rounded, irregular; ochraceoferrugineous drying "Verona brown" [Ridgway(1) color]; smooth, fibrils basal, fuscous
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  yellowish ashy at first, becoming black, with thin yellow-orange septa, cavities subpentagonal [somewhat pentagonal]
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Quercus (oak) and Cistus monspeliensis (Montpelier rock rose); August to December, (Zeller), in the Pacific Northwest with a broad spectrum of hosts (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7.5-10 x 5-7.5 microns, elliptic, smooth, very dark brown; basidia evanescent [disappearing]; peridium 100-160 microns thick, stupose [with tufted or matted filaments], amber yellowish, "extending as fundamental tissue into the trama"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'variegated'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Zeller(12), Trappe(13)
145
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Uncertain, Class Uncertain, Phylum Zygomycota
LATIN NAMES  Modicella malleola  (Harkn.) Gerd. & Trappe^  Mycologia Memoir 5: 67. 1974;  == Endogone malleola  Harkn.;  = Endogone torrendii  Bres.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include small white fruitbodies (consisting only of spore-bearing sporangia that are terminal on hyphae), that are spherical to cushion-shaped, smooth to slightly lobed, indented at the base, and hard in consistency, odor of onions, growth above ground on bark or among mosses or underground under moss or litter, and microscopic characters including spores that are nearly round to elliptic, smooth, and colorless^; collections examined from WA, OR, CA, also reported from NE, Europe, and New Zealand, (Gerdemann)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.2-0.5cm across, spherical to nearly spherical or pulvinate [cushion-shaped], "smooth to slightly lobed, indented at base, hard; white, drying to pale, dirty yellow"; peridium absent
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  
STEM  no columella
ODOR  distinctly of onions when fresh (perceptible when kept moist for a while in a closed container)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  above ground on bark or among mosses or underground under moss or litter, in stands of Quercus (oak), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Sequoia, or mixed forests, mostly collected in April and May, but also found in November; mycorrhizal associations unknown, "but often fruiting in the complete absence of endomycorrhizal hosts"
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-17 microns long, nearly round to elliptic "but distinctly subangular from mutual pressure", smooth, colorless, thin-walled, "coherent in clusters when forced out of sporangia"^; sporangia 55-118 x 50-91 microns, spherical to nearly spherical, ellipsoid, or irregular, colorless, thin-walled, terminal on hyphae 8-12 microns wide, compressed tightly together
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin "malleolus" (a small mallet): "Harkness's intent in use of this epithet is unknown, but it possibly refers to the sporangia with attached hyphae, which in his illustration could be thought to appear mallet-like", (Gerdemann)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gerdemann(1)
146
FAMILY  Agaricaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Montagnea arenaria  (DC.) Zeller^  Mycologia 35: 418. 1943
ENGLISH NAMES  gastroid Coprinus
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Montagnea arenaria is at first deeply buried and enclosed in a tough membrane, then expands as the ruptured outer skin forms a volva at the base of the stem. The mature fruiting body has a stem and a cap (all but the cap disc (cap center) soon splitting into spore-bearing plates).^ The online Species Fungorum, accessed December 15, 2015, gave the name as Montagnea arenaria (DC.) Zeller as above, and it would seem that the Latin word 'arenarius' meaning 'sandy' should agree with the ending of the genus named after Montagne, but Zeller called it Montagnea arenarius when combining the name in 1943. The description is derived from Arora(1). RANGE Arora(1) mentions distribution in the arid and semi-arid parts of western North America (from Mexico and TX to CA, OR, and eastern WA). Collections were examined from OR, AZ, NM, Texas, Mexico, Russia, and Algeria, (Zeller). There are collections at the University of British Columbia from BC, AZ, CA, and NM. There are collections at the College of Idaho from ID and Mexico.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-3.5cm across, merely a thin disc-like expansion of the stem, convex becoming flat or depressed, persistent; "white to grayish, buff, or occasionally straw-colored, often with a volval patch or remnants"; smooth, margin often tattered or fringed when old^, (Arora), 1-3.5cm across, merely an expanded disc or the tip of the stem-columella, tapered to a very thin edge, convex then flat to depressed; white or grayish; smooth, "usually with remnants of the volva at the center and sometimes extending nearly to the margin", (Zeller)
INNER LAYER  in stem white when fresh^ (Arora), white in stem (Zeller)
INTERIOR  spore mass exposed at maturity, composed of thin plates that radiate or hang from the margin of the disc-like cap and are entirely free from stem, plates often wavy or curled, up to 3.5(6)cm long, reddish black to blackish when mature; "eventually falling off the cap or disintegrating, but not deliquescing"^, (Arora), lamelloid [gill-like], gills 1-3.5cm long, 0.4-1.2cm deep, entirely free from the main stem-columella, attached to the margin of the disc-like cap, ventricose-rounded below, crowded, black, (Zeller)
STEM  (5)8-30cm x 0.2-1.5(2.5)cm, percurrent [going through cap], "more or less equal or often tapering downward, hollow, tough or almost woody when old and dry (but very light)"; white to buff or sometimes discoloring darker when old; "smooth or longitudinally fibrillose-striate, often splitting or cracking into fibrillose or shaggy scales", volva at base of stem sac-like, "usually buried in soil, loose (often remaining in the ground), two-layered, the outer layer white and ample, the inner composed of tough fibers"; veil absent or rudimentary^, (Arora), stem-columella 8-30cm long, 0.4-2.6cm wide in upper part, usually tapering downward, hollow, becoming almost woody on drying; white or whitish; smooth to striate, often becoming scaly or lacerate [torn]; volva usually double, the outer white, more or less ample, usually covered with adherent sand, "the inner lacerate, of tough fibrous strands", (Zeller)
ODOR  none^ (Miller)
TASTE  unknown^ (Miller)
EDIBILITY  too tough (Arora)
HABITAT  single, scattered or gregarious "in sandy soil, old fields, and other waste places", in arid and semi-arid areas^, (Arora), scattered or gregarious "in sandy places, usually in the open sunlight", (Zeller)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (7.5)12-20(28) x (4.5)6-11(14) microns, elliptic to nearly round, smooth, with germ pore^ capillitium absent, (Arora); spores 12-19 x 6-11.2 microns, elliptic to oboval, dark fuscous, with a more or less colorless germ pore, spores almost sessile, borne acrogenously; basidia 4-spored, 20-28 x 10-14 microns, clavate or pyriform [pear-shaped], somewhat fuscous, "almost square at the distal end with blunt sterigmata at the corners"; gills of light fuscous hyphae, (Zeller), spores given by Smith(4) as 20-28 x 10-14 microns, but this is probably an error for the size of the basidia
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of sand, sandy' (Latin)
SIMILAR  Gyrophragmium californicum is similar but rarer, (known from the San Francisco Bay area in California), and has dark brown to blackish spore-bearing plates that hang from the underside of the disc-like cap rather than from the margin. It also has a loose volva plus a double-layered partial veil that either disappears or forms an annulus (ring). (Arora(1)). A Gyrophragmium species has been reported from Washington state, (Lorelei Norvell, pers. comm.): instead of having spore bearing plates that hang from the edge of the cap, the plates hang from the underside of the cap.
SOURCES  Zeller(6), Arora(1)*, Smith(4)*, Miller(14)*, Desjardin(6)*
147
FAMILY  Albatrellaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Mycolevis siccigleba  A.H. Sm.^  Mycopathol. Mycol. Appl. 26: 391-393. 1965
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to lobed or angular fruitbody that is white becoming yellowish and finally grayish olive, with rhizomorphs scattered over the basal area, 2) a columella that is sometimes present as a bluish streak from a rhizomorph, 3) consistency of the fruitbody making it as light as a piece of styrofoam when fresh and just about as rigid, though somewhat more fragile, 4) a spore mass that is white becoming buff to olivaceous, 5) a fruity to nauseating Inocybe-like odor, 6) growth in duff under conifers, 7) a surface that stains copper green to bluish on the white parts in Melzer's reagent, 8) round to broadly elliptic spores that appear to have spines projecting from a thick inner wall into an outer gelatinous wall, in Melzer's reagent the spines amyloid and a thin amyloid layer covering the outer wall, and 9) 4-spored basidia.^ Electron micrographs show the spore to have "a continuous, thick inner wall from which project irregular spines with tips that flare to form an outer, discontinuous crust", the whole being covered by a continuous, smooth, thin outer wall, (Fogel). It is common among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest RANGE It is found from WA to southern CA and east to MT, (Trappe(13)). Collections were examined from WA, OR, ID, CA, UT, and Mexico, (Fogel).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  surface stains copper green to bluish on white parts in Melzer's reagent, but no reaction of surface to KOH or FeSO4^, (Smith(31))
OUTER SURFACE  1-4cm across, irregular; "white becoming yellowish and finally grayish olive, with scattered rhizomorphs"^, (Smith(4)), 1-4cm across, spherical or nearly so, "at times angular from external pressure, or merely uneven to lobed"; white at first in places, becoming yellowish and when old grayish olive overall; bald "except for a few rhizomorphs appressed over basal area", dirt adhering readily; consistency as light as a piece of styrofoam when fresh and just about as rigid, though somewhat more fragile, (Smith(31)), 1-4cm across, spherical to lobed or angular from external pressure; peridium [outer covering] "white in youth, becoming yellowish in age to grayish olive at maturity, not staining where cut or bruised"; minutely pubescent [downy]; peridium thin, (Fogel)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  very dry, light in weight; white, finally olivaceous^, (Smith(4)), "white when young and very dry in consistency, buff to olivaceous finally, fragile, chambers large and rigid", empty, (Smith(31)), white when young, finally buff to olivaceous when mature; brittle when dried; locules spherical, about 0.025cm in diameter, empty, (Fogel)
STEM  columella a bluish gray streak from a rhizomorph into the spore mass, unbranched, apparently not visible in all fruitbodies; "a few rhizomorphs appressed over basal area", "no well developed basal point of attachment evident"^, (Smith(31)), columella occasionally present, 0.1-0.2cm wide, unbranched, bluish gray, giving rise to a basal rhizomorph; rhizomorphs appressed, basal, colored as surface of fruitbody, (Fogel)
ODOR  subspermatic as in Inocybe (nauseous), (Smith(31)), fruity to nauseous (Fogel)
TASTE  similar to odor but slight, (Smith(31)), similar to odor but less intense (Fogel)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in duff under conifers, late spring to late fall^, (Smith(4)), may be an ectomycorrhizal associate of Abies (fir) spp. and perhaps Picea (spruce) spp., May to November, all but one collection examined were from montane or subalpine coniferous forests, one lowland coastal record, (Fogel)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-14(18) x 9-12(16) microns, round to broadly elliptic, colorless in KOH and violet in Melzer's reagent, spore wall 0.7-1.0 microns thick, 2-layered, "in KOH the ornamentation appearing as spines projecting from an thick inner wall (1-2 microns) into an outer gelatinous wall", "in Melzer's reagent the spines amyloid and a thin amyloid layer covering the outer wall, the ends of the spines appearing as spots on the spore surface"^, spores "with a basal pore at the point of sterigmal attachment" that is surrounded by a broad amyloid collar; basidia 4-spored, 35-40 x 11-15 microns, "clavate to turbinate, loosely arranged in a hymenium", colorless, thin-walled, with content granular in KOH, sterigmata straight, 5-6 x 2 microns at base, brachybasidioles 35-40 x 5-10 microns, clavate, colorless, thin-walled; cystidia none; mediostratum 50-125 microns wide, of hyphae 2-7 microns wide at septa (most cells inflated to 5-20 microns), nongelatinous, thin-walled, colorless in KOH, orange in Melzer's reagent; peridium (30)190-250 microns thick, subcutis of hyphae 3-5 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, epicutis a tangled turf (often collapsed) of hyphae 2.5-5 microns wide, colorless, thin-walled, septate, (Fogel); spores 9-12 x 8-11 (18 x 16) microns, round to nearly round, colorless in KOH, violet in Melzer's reagent, "outermost layer a thin amyloid crust breaking up in places and in some spores seen to separate in flakes, beneath this a thick layer (2 microns thick) traversed by canals opening to the outer surface as spots" and so numerous that the openings "appear as an obscure closely knit reticulum, with a basal pore at place of attachment to sterigma and around this pore a dark violet (amyloid) mass of material spread out in the manner of a broad collar, this mass possibly connected to the thin amyloid crust seen over most spores"; basidia 4-spored, in a loosely arranged hymenium, about 12 microns wide, clavate, colorless and granular in KOH; cystidia none; tramal plates of nongelatinous pseudoparenchyma, colorless in KOH and orange in Melzer's reagent; peridium a tangled turf (often collapsed) of hyphae 2.5-5 microns wide, colorless and clean in KOH, "arising from a subcutis of filamentous-interwoven hyphae", colorless in KOH, both layers dark green in Melzer's reagent (on fresh material), when revived in Melzer's reagent "sordid bluish to bluish green in some areas but color not clearly localized in cells walls in all cases, also much amyloid debris present in the mounts"; clamp connections none, (Smith(31)), spores 8-14(18) x 9-12(16) microns, ornamented with a thin amyloid crust as an outer layer covering at least part of the spore, the thick inner layer traversed by fine canals; clamp connections scattered to abundant on hyphae of peridium, (Smith(4)) 
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with dry gleba [spore mass]'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(31), Fogel(5), Smith(4), Trappe(13)*
148
FAMILY  Boletaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Octaviania cyanescens  Trappe & Castellano^  Mycotaxon 75: 172. 2000 [as Octavianina]
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include nearly spherical to more or less flattened fruitbody that is yellow-white to pale yellow, (in places with scanty dark brown fibrils), developing dark blue stains overnight after collection, spore mass dark gray-brown to brown-black with gray tramal plates separating minute locules, underground growth, and microscopic characters including round dark basidiospores with large conic warts composed of agglutinated spines and forming 4-7 sided polygons at base, in Melzer's reagent the spore wall orange-red and the ornamentation colorless^; description derived from Trappe(2) except where noted; rare in the Pacific Northwest, found OR to northern CA, in mountains, (Trappe(13)); type collection from OR
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1.2-2.5cm across, nearly spherical to +/- flattened; "yellow-white to pale yellow, in places with a scant overlay of dark brown fibrils, overnight after collection developing dark blue stains where bruised"; felty
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  firm, moist; "dark gray-brown to brown-black from the color of the massed spores, with gray tramal plates separating minute, rounded, mostly spore-filled locules"
STEM  rhizomorphs lacking
ODOR  not distinctive
TASTE  not recorded
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  mycorrhizal hosts in the Pacific Northwest Tsuga (hemlock) and trees in Fagaceae, (Trappe(13)), type was underground under and possibly ectomycorrhizal with Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock) at 1900m elevation, September, (Trappe(2))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 13-18(20) microns in diameter (excluding ornamentation), round to occasionally broadly elliptic, ornamentation of somewhat angular cones (3)4-5(7) x 1-6 microns in KOH, 2-4 x 1-6 microns in water, "with occasional interspersed spines and smaller cones, all cones composed of agglutinated spines and forming 4-7 sided polygons at the base, sterigmata often remaining attached as an inconspicuous pedicel", in Melzer's reagent spore wall deep orange-red, ornamentation colorless and only 2-4 microns tall, "heated in cotton blue the spines forming the cones separating and becoming erect, 4-8 x 1.5-3 microns"^; basidia in a hymenium, 30-35 x 11-14 microns, clavate, colorless, thin-walled, sterigmata up to 5-7 x 1.5-2(3) microns; subhymenium of +/- isodiametric cells 5-10 microns in diameter, colorless, thin-walled; trama composed of hyphae 2-4 microns wide at septa, colorless, thin-walled, often inflated to 4-8 microns wide; peridium 150-300 microns thick: subcutis with hyphae 2-6 microns wide at septa, "with pale brown, thin-walled hyphae near the epicutis grading to hyaline near the gleba", commonly inflated to 10-30 microns, epicutis a narrow layer of hyphae 2-7 microns wide at the septa, appressed, pale brown, thin-walled, occasional cells inflated to 5-10 microns; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  means "becoming blue"
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Trappe(2), Castellano(1), Trappe(13)
149
FAMILY  Boletaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Octaviania macrospora  Singer & A.H. Sm.^  Mem. Torrey Bot. Club 21: 9. 1960 [as Octavianina]
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  characterized by thick-walled, inamyloid, short-spiny spores, and a peridial turf of cystidioid elements, other features include fruitbody about 1cm, white and bald, pale spore mass with open chambers, sterile base, growth in association with the roots of Western Hemlock, and microscopic characters including large spores on 1-spored and 2-spored basidia^; type found in OR
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  about 1cm in diameter, white when fresh; bald^, (Singer)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  open chambers, presumably white when fresh^, (Singer)
STEM  sterile base present^ (Singer)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under hemlock, August^, (Singer), found in association with the roots of Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), August, (Castellano)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 17-23 x 12-15 microns, elliptic, ornamented with short spines 1-1.5 microns tall^, cystidia absent, cuticle of peridium a collapsed turf of club-shaped to cystidioid cells, sphaerocysts not observed, (Smith), spores 17-23 x 12-16 microns, broadly elliptic, ornamentation in the form of short spines 1-1.5(2.5) x 0.5 microns, distinct but often touching at their bases, entirely inamyloid (pale yellowish in Melzer's reagent), inner spore wall 1.5-2 microns thick, pale ochraceous in Melzer's reagent, pale buff in KOH, "sterigmal appendage sometimes conspicuous, often slightly irregular in outline"; basidia 1-spored and 2-spored, 29-37 x 10-13 microns, clavate, thin-walled, content granular and ochraceous in KOH; basidioles numerous; cystidia none; subhymenium "appearing cellular in section from the cut ends of hyphal branches, hyphae about the diameter of the base of the basidium, 1-2 cells below the cross wall cutting off the basidium the cells enlarging in age to sphaerocyst proportions"; tramal mediostratum "filamentous, the cells of the filaments scarcely enlarged", walls thin and colorless, no sphaerocysts; peridial context (subcutis) composed of hyphae 3-6 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, subgelatinous (in KOH), "no sphaerocysts or oleiferous hyphae in the layer"; epicutis of peridium "a collapsed turf of clavate to cystidioid cells" 18-27 x 4-8 microns or 20-30 x 3-5 microns if fusoid; clamp connections none, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with large spores'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(4), Castellano(1), Singer(10)
150
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Pachyphloeus austro-oregonensis  J.L. Frank & Trappe^  Mycotaxon 98: 254. 2006;  Pachyphlodes austro-oregonensis  (J.L. Frank & Trappe) Doweld  Index Fungorum 31: 1. 2013 (proposed combination)
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a nearly spherical to irregular, purple-brown fruiting body with warts on the surface, the exterior invaginated into the interior as narrow canals, 2) a pallid to pink inner surface layer, 3) an interior with labyrinthine veins lined by golden yellow hymenia and separated by gray-brown sterile tissue, 4) a white root-like hyphal mass sometimes at the base, 5) growth under leaf litter associated with Oregon White Oak, 6) round spores ornamented with crowded rods, and 7) other microscopic characters.^ This species was recombined in 2013 into Pachyphlodes which has in the past (e.g. Tenth Edition of the Dictionary of the Fungi) been considered a synonym of Pachyphloeus. RANGE It was found in OR in June, but may not have been fully mature.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across, nearly spherical to irregular, purple-brown, verrucose, invaginated into interior "as narrow canals that form thin, verrucose, interior chambers continuous with the outer surface"
INNER LAYER  pallid to pink
INTERIOR  "with labyrinthiform veins lined by golden-yellow hymenia; veins, open or with opposing hymenia pressed together, separated by grey-brown sterile tissue"
STEM  base "sometimes giving rise to a root-like, white, tapering hyphal mass" 1-1.3cm x 0.2-0.3cm
ODOR  mild
TASTE  not recorded
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  below leaf litter in top 2-5cm of mineral soil, associated with Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), fruiting May to June
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (10)12-16(18) microns in diameter including ornamentation, round, ornamented with crowded rods 1-2.5 x 0.5 microns, colorless, spore walls 1-2 microns thick, uniseriate to incompletely biseriate in the asci^; asci 8-spored, "in tight palisades lining the glebal canals", 220-360 x 18-28 microns, cylindric, amyloid, with forked base, occasionally bent; paraphyses equal or extending up to 60 microns beyond asci, 8-13 microns wide with clavate tips, septate; subhymenium 20-50 microns thick, a textura intricata with many isodiametric cells 4-10 microns wide; peridium 500-950 microns thick with 2 layers, inner layer 300-550 microns thick, of colorless cells 4-8 microns wide and of various lengths, "contorted and irregularly arranged as a textura intricata", outer layer a texture angularis 200-400 microns thick of inflated, irregular to isodiametric cells 15-40 microns wide, with light brown walls at surface of fruitbody grading to colorless toward interior
NAME ORIGIN  "austro-" means "southern", and "oregonensis" means "from Oregon", referring to the fact that type "was collected in southern Oregon with the support of Southern Oregon University", and additionally "the interior morphology of folded golden hymenia mirrors the landscape of southern Oregon with its golden dry hills"
SIMILAR  Pachyphloeus citrinus, which fruits under oaks, and Pachyphloeus thysellii, which fruits under Douglas-fir, have elliptic to subglobose asci and solid glebae, (Frank(2)). Pachyphlodes carnea (Harkn.) Doweld or something similar has been reported from the Pacific Northwest (Danny Miller. pers. comm.).
SOURCES  Frank(2), Trappe(13)*
151
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Pachyphloeus citrinus  Berk. & Broome^  in Ann. Mag. nat. Hist. 18: 79. 1846;  Pachyphlodes citrinus  (Berk. & Broome) Doweld  Index Fungorum 31: 1. 2013
ENGLISH NAMES  berry truffle
NOTES  features include fruitbody that is nearly spherical to lobed or tapered in lower part, the surface warted and bright orange to brown or yellow, large round opening at top, basal tuft of mycelium, spore mass solid, whitish to grayish olive or blackish, with paler veins, the hymenium lined channels converging at opening of fruitbody, growth under hardwoods and under conifers, and spores with projections like golf-tees, borne in 8-spored asci^; this species was recombined in 2013 into Pachyphlodes which has in the past (e.g. Tenth Edition of the Dictionary of the Fungi) been considered a synonym of Pachyphloeus; infrequent in the Pacific Northwest, found in western CA at low elevations, eastern United States, (Trappe(13) who note that Pacific Northwest collections of truffles frequently prove to be not exactly the same species as the European equivalents and that a revision of the genus is now underway), recorded from OR, ID, CA, eastern United States, Europe, (Smith), including United Kingdom, (Dennis), throughout most of North America and Europe (Arora), found in United Kingdom (Hawker(1))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-3cm across, more or less spherical to slightly lobed or tapered in lower part, the top often with a depression, circular furrow, or cluster of furrows, fruitbody "firm but not hard"; "color variable, but usually bright to dull orange to brown"; surface "usually divided into polygonal warts"^, (Arora), 1-3cm across, somewhat compressed with a large round apical opening; bright orange to brown; warted, (Smith), up to 1.5cm across, spherical or lobed, with opening at top; yellow, blackening when old; warted, (Dennis)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  more or less solid, composed of sterile veins that often converge toward the top or depression "and form elongated pockets of fertile tissue between them"; whitish when young, becoming grayish to grayish olive "with paler (white to yellowish) veins, and eventually becoming dark olive to blackish with yellow to pale olive veins"^, (Arora), with hymenium-lined channels converging at opening, (Smith), flesh white with yellow and gray veins, drying gray-brown, (Dennis)
STEM  base often with a tuft of mycelium^, (Arora), with basal tuft of mycelium (Smith)
ODOR  when mature, sometimes pungent, according to Herb Saylor "like rotting weeds", after collecting, at other times mild^, (Arora), unpleasant (Dennis)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious in soil under hardwoods and under conifers^, (Arora), in woods (Smith), mycorrhizal hosts in the Pacific Northwest Quercus (oak), Notholithocarpus, (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (11)13-21 microns, round, smooth, and colorless at first, becoming spiny, and when mature the spines enlarging into broader, conic to truncate warts or pegs, when mature each peg usually tipped with a small depression that makes it look like a golf tee, spores usually yellowish when mature^, (Arora), asci typically 8-spored, forming an irregular palisade "along the sterile veins and/ or randomly imbedded in the surrounding tissue", (Arora), spores 13-22 microns with ornamentation of flat-topped golf-tee-like projections about 2 microns high; asci 8-spored, clavate to saccate, (Smith), spores 13-15 x 13-15 microns, round, with numerous low rounded warts, becoming yellowish brown; asci 8-spored, up to 200 x 50 microns, clavate, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to the citron [a lemon-like fruit]', probably in reference to its surface color
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Balsamia magnata and Pachyphloeus austro-oregonensis.
SOURCES  Arora(1)*, Smith(4), Dennis(1), Hawker(1), Trappe(13)
152
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Pachyphloeus thysellii  Colgan & Trappe^  Mycotaxon 90(2): 282. 2004;  Pachyphlodes thysellii  (W. Colgan & Trappe) Doweld  Index Fungorum 31: 1. 2013
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include nearly spherical to irregular fruitbody that is rubbery in texture, with surface "minutely warty, brown to tawny with yellow veins and patches showing among the warts", the spore mass "off-white to yellowish translucent, with white and yellowish alternating veins radiating from a central cavity containing cottony hyphae", absent stem, underground growth beneath Douglas-fir, spores round, colorless, inamyloid, and cyanophilic, with ornamentation of rods, asci 8-spored and inamyloid, and two layered peridium with inner layer of colorless hyphae and outer layer of polygonal brown-walled cells^; this species was recombined in 2013 into Pachyphlodes which has in the past (e.g. Tenth Edition of the Dictionary of the Fungi) been considered a synonym of Pachyphloeus; description derived from Colgan(1); rare, Thurston County WA, (Trappe(13)), type found in WA
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.8-2cm across, nearly spherical to irregular, texture rubbery, when dried it is hard; "minutely warty, brown to tawny with yellow veins and patches showing among the warts"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "off-white to yellowish translucent, with white and yellowish alternating veins radiating from a central cavity containing cottony hyphae"
STEM  
ODOR  mild to slightly onion-like
TASTE  not recorded
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground in 55-65 year-old thinned stands of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) on glacial till, August
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores predominantly round, 12-17 microns in diameter (not including ornamentation), ornamentation of symmetrical rods greater than or equal to 2 x 0.7-1 microns, cyanophilic, spore wall +/- 1 micron thick, colorless in KOH and Melzer's but strongly cyanophilic, episporium colorless, "inconspicuous, adherent to the tips of the ornamentation", "biseriate or clustered in the asci"^; asci 8-spored, ellipsoid, reniform or subspherical, 80-110 x 40-60 microns including short to prominent stem 10-60 x 8-15 microns, colorless, the walls 1 micron thick, inamyloid, weakly cyanophilic; medullary excipulum (gleba) of hyphae 6-10 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, branched; peridium (excipulum) 200-300 microns thick, 2-layered, inner layer (ental excipulum) 40-60 microns thick, with hyphae 6-8 microns wide, tightly interwoven, colorless, with many cells inflated up to 10 microns, walls about 1 micron thick, outer layer (ectal excipulum) 150-250 microns thick, "brown to pale yellow, compactly arranged, of inflated, brown-walled polygonal cells 35-45 microns broad", the walls about 1 micron thick
NAME ORIGIN  named "in honor of the collector of the type specimen, David Thysell, a research botanist in the USDA Forest Service and cooperator on the Forest Ecosystem Project at Fort Lewis"
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Pachyphloeus austro-oregonensis.
SOURCES  Colgan(1), Trappe(13)
153
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Paurocotylis bynumii  (Trappe, Bushnell & Castellano) Healy & M.E. Sm.^  Fungal Biology 121: 278. 2017;  Stephensia bynumii  Trappe, Bushnell & Castellano  Mycotaxon 54: 432
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to convoluted fruitbodies that are covered with brown tomentum, white to cream spore mass that incorporates short, pale pinkish brown to pale brownish orange veins, mild odor and taste, and microscopic characters including round, smooth spores^; description derived from Trappe(12); collections examined from OR, (Trappe(12)), rare, Marion and Clackamas Counties, OR, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-2cm x 1.5-2.3cm, nearly spherical and shallowly furrowed to "much lobed and convoluted"; when young "pale yellowish brown with a scattered brown tomentum", "soon covered with a brown to dark brown tomentum, sometimes cracked to reveal the cream-colored underlying tissues"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  solid; white to cream, "incorporating short, pale pinkish brown to pale brownish orange veins" 0.05-0.1cm broad packed with opposing asci and paraphyses
STEM  none
ODOR  not distinctive
TASTE  not distinctive
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground, a probable mycorrhizal associate with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Corylus cornuta var. californica (California hazel), April through August
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16-18(21) microns wide (in KOH mounts often somewhat larger), round, smooth, colorless, at maturity the wall 0.5 microns thick, spores not staining in cotton blue, colorless to pale yellow in Melzer's reagent^; asci (6-)8-spored, when young "clavate to saccate with uniseriate or biseriate spores", by maturity cylindric with uniseriate spores and 230-250 x 18-25 microns including a long tapering stem 45-60 microns long with a forked base, "one arm of the fork usually longer than the other", inamyloid; paraphyses "about as long as or slightly exceeding the asci", 2-3.5 microns wide, colorless, "septate, sometimes branched, the tips rounded and straight"
NAME ORIGIN  "in honor of Otis Bynum, the collector of the holotype and most of the paratypes", (Trappe)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Trappe(12) (as Stephensia bynumii), Trappe(13) (as Stephensia bynumii), Kumar(1)
154
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Peziza ellipsospora  (Gilkey) Trappe^  Mycotaxon 9(1): 336. 1979;  Hydnotrya ellipsospora  Gilkey  Univ. Calif. Publ. Bot. 6: 307. 1916
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a nearly spherical purplish brown fruitbody that is minutely villose, varying from a simple structure consisting of loose folds to a complicated arrangement of folds and projections separating numerous canals and chambers, and 2) microscopic characters including elliptic papillose spores, and paraphyses not longer than the asci.^ The description is derived from Gilkey(3) except where otherwise specified. It is infrequent among truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It is found in OR and CA (Gilkey(3)). Peziza ellipsospora is found from western OR to southern CA (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-9cm across, nearly spherical; purplish brown; minutely villose [covered with long soft, weak hairs that collapse readily]
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  fruitbody "varying from a simple structure consisting of loose folds casually joined to a compact, complicated arrangement of folds and projections separating numerous canals and chambers"
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under shrubs and trees (Gilkey(3)), Oregon collection under leaves of Quercus (oak) and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), in March, (Zeller(2)), associated with Quercus (Trappe(13))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14 x 10 microns, elliptic, minutely papillose^; asci 8-spored; paraphyses scarcely swollen at tip, not longer than the asci, (Gilkey(3)), spores 14 to (rarely) 19 x 10-16 microns, (Gilkey(2))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with elliptic spores'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Peziza infossa.
SOURCES  Gilkey(3) (as Hydnotrya), Gilkey(2) (as Hydnotrya), Zeller(2) (as Hydnotrya), Trappe(13)*, Desjardin(6)*
155
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Peziza infossa  Fogel & States^  Mycotaxon 88: 155. 2003;  Peziza quercicola  Fogel & States  Mycotaxon 81: 78. 2002 (non Peziza quercicola  Saut. ex Winter 1881)
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include oblong to irregular, whitish fruitbody with yellow patches or bruising yellow, outer layer infolded to form canals and empty chambers that are lined by white to translucent, farinose spore bearing surface, tuft of hyphae at base of fruitbody, unpleasant odor, underground growth under oak, and microscopic characters^; description derived from Fogel(9) except where indicated; found in UT and OR (Trappe, M.(3))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  up to 3cm x 1.3cm x 1.5cm, oblong to turbinate, with irregular symmetry, openings to internal chambers not apparent; white with brilliant yellow patches or bruising brilliant yellow; bald but at 10x farinaceous
INNER LAYER  medullary excipulum white, turning brilliant yellow when sectioned
INTERIOR  multiple empty chambers formed by infolding of wall of fruitbody, lined by farinose, white to translucent spore-bearing surface
STEM  attached by 'prominent basal tuft of hyphae holding a small "button" of soil'
ODOR  "fungoid to strong, sweet, phenolic or dimethyl sulfide-like"^, (Fogel), often phenolic or chemical (Trappe, M.)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground under Quercus turbinella (Shrub Live Oak) and Quercus gambelii (Gambel's Oak) in Utah, May to late June^, (Fogel), with Quercus in woodlands and scrub chaparral; March to July, (Trappe, M.)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 13-17(19) x 10-13 microns, elliptic, verruculose, the warts up to 0.2 microns tall, weakly cyanophilic, spores containing a single large droplet, wall 0.5 microns thick including ornamentation^; asci 8-spored, 156-198 x 13-15 microns, cylindric; paraphyses not abundant, filamentous, capitate, tip 9-10 microns wide, stalk 6-8 microns wide, extending slightly past asci (10 microns); fruitbody walls 550-650 microns thick, "no clear demarcation between ectal excipulum and medullary excipulum", surface sparsely covered with short, blunt, colorless hairs, terminal cell 15-30 x 8 microns; context pseudoparenchymous, cells of hyaline, thin-walled, 5-6 microns broad hyphae swelling to 20-30 x 21-23 microns, (Fogel), spores 13-19 x 10-13 microns, elliptic to oval, finely warty, containing a single oil droplet; asci turn blue in iodine solution, (Trappe, M.)
NAME ORIGIN  means "buried"
SIMILAR  Peziza stuntzii has a solid spore mass and pink flesh, and spores are ornamented with cyanophilic warts and short ridges, (Fogel(9)); Peziza ellipsospora has purplish brown fruitbodies, smaller spores (14 x 10 microns), taller ornamentation (up to 1.0 microns tall), and narrower paraphyses (2-5 microns wide), (Fogel(9))
SOURCES  Fogel(9) (as Peziza quercicola), Trappe, M.(3)*
156
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Peziza stuntzii  Trappe^  Mycotaxon 9(1): 335. 1979
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include irregular furrowed fruitbody that is pink and roughened, solid spore mass pink marbled with brown veins, spicy sausage odor, underground growth, and microscopic characters including elliptic spores with colorless ornamentation of warts and ridges and 8-spored asci that are amyloid in upper part^; type collection found in WA but rare (Smith(4))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  up to 5cm x 3cm, irregular, deeply furrowed; colored flesh pink; peridium scabrous^, (Trappe), up to 5cm x 3cm, tuber-like, irregular in outline; pinkish; roughened, (Smith)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  solid; colored flesh pink, "marbled with brown veins mostly filled with hymenia and often opening to the surface"^, (Trappe), interior of fruiting body complex, with folds of tissue to +/- solid and marbled; pink marbled with brown, (Smith)
STEM  
ODOR  spicy sausage^ (Trappe)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection underground in mixed woods of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), elevation about 550m^, (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-15 x 10-12 microns, ellipsoid, ornamented with warts and ridges up to 0.5 microns high^, asci cylindric 8 spored, indehiscent (even though most Peziza species have dehiscent asci), (Smith), 12-15 x 10-12 microns excluding ornamentation of cyanophilic warts and short ridges +/- 0.5 x 0.5 microns, colorless, uniseriate; asci 8-spored, 230-26 [sic] x 11-16 microns, colorless, "the apical half strongly blue in Melzer's reagent, apices indented or sometimes with a circumferential line, the bases croziered"; paraphyses 3-8 microns wide, with clavate tips; subhymenium of hyphae 6-15 microns wide, tightly interwoven; glebal tissue of hyphae 7-20 microns wide, loosely interwoven, with abundant rounded to subangular cells 10-45 microns in diameter, (Trappe)
NAME ORIGIN  in honor of Dr. Daniel E. Stuntz of the University of Washington
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Peziza infossa.
SOURCES  Trappe(6), Smith(4)
157
FAMILY  Strophariaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Pholiota nubigena  (Harkn.) Redhead^  Index Fungorum 148: 1. 2014;  Nivatogastrium nubigenum  (Harkn.) Singer & A.H. Sm.  Brittonia 11: 224. 1959;  Secotium nubigenum  Harkn.
ENGLISH NAMES  gastroid Pholiota, bubblegum fungus
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include 1) a yellowish brown to white, slightly viscid cap that is smooth or slightly fibrillose, 2) a cinnamon brown spore mass associated with irregularly contorted gills that often form chambers, exposed only when old if at all, 3) a short stout tough stem that is white or stained brownish, 4) flesh in the cap and columella white but in the remainder of the stem rusty brown to yellowish, 5) a fragrant sweet odor, 6) fruiting on rotting conifers, often near melting snow, and 7) microscopic characters including elliptic smooth honey-colored spores, and 4-spored basidia (or some 2-spored).^ It is common in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Pholiota nubigena has been found at least in OR, ID, and CA, (Singer). It has been  found in eastern WA, ID, OR and northern CA in mountains, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  (1)2-8cm across, nearly spherical to convex, "sometimes expanding in age, the center often flattened or slightly depressed", "margin at first incurved and often lobed", remaining attached to stem or sometimes pulling away when old; "ochraceous or tawny to dingy yellowish, buff, or white", usually fading to whitish when old; surface smooth or slightly fibrillose, "slightly viscid when wet, sometimes pitted"^, (Arora), 1-2.4cm across, (fruitbody 1.5-4cm tall), nearly spherical to more or less truncate over disc and the margin abruptly decurved [downcurved], at times angular in outline, rarely umbonate; evenly ochraceous or with streaks or darker areas of tawny, fading to white or whitish when old, (but not truly hygrophanous); bald, smooth, somewhat viscid; peridium not separating from stem-columella, or only rarely breaking away when old and then irregularly, (Singer)
INNER LAYER  rather soft but tough (especially in stem); white in cap and columella (the part of the stem surrounded by the spore mass), usually brown in stem^, (Arora), somewhat watery at first; white when faded, in columella white, in stem becoming rusty brown to almost croceus [yellow], (Singer)
INTERIOR  "spore mass brown to cinnamon-brown when mature, composed of irregularly contorted gills that often form chambers", exposed only when old if at all^, (Arora), "loculate, the chambers vertically elongated and irregular in shape", in old specimens the tramal plates at times irregularly sublamellate [somewhat gill-like] in their orientation; dull cinnamon brown when fresh; not becoming powdery, (Singer), loculate to sublamellate, pale red-brown, (Castellano)
STEM  0.5-2.5cm x 0.5-2cm, "equal or thicker at either end", percurrent [going through spore mass], usually short and stout, tough; white or stained brownish to rust brown; not viscid; veil present as whitish fibrillose tissue that extends from cap margin to stem, often disappearing when old, not forming ring^, (Arora), 0.5-2.5cm x 0.5-1.2cm, "equal to somewhat bulbous, sometimes narrowed into a cylindric columella", solid or rarely hollow, columella percurrent, "at times narrowed upward and then flaring when it joins the peridium, white, attached to the gleba throughout or loosening below and then often leaving a ringhole"; "somewhat matted-fibrillose over the exposed surface, dry and unpolished"; veil white or whitish, arachnoid [webby] and cortina-like, causing the margin of the cap and the top of the stem to be somewhat silky-shining when old, eventually disappearing; white rhizomorphs at base, (Singer)
ODOR  fragrant as in ethyl acetate (Singer), fragrant sweet (Castellano), somewhat like bubblegum or wintergreen (Desjardin)
TASTE  mild^ (Singer)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious or in small clusters on rotting conifers, especially on Abies (fir) and Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), often near melting snow^, (Arora), gregarious to subcespitose [somewhat clustered] on fallen conifer logs and chips, especially of Abies magnifica [California Red Fir] and Pinus contorta [Lodgepole pine], above ground when on chips etc., 1650-2400m, often at the edge of snowbanks, late spring and summer, (Singer), fruits on the surface of rotten logs of Abies above 1300m, May through early October, (Castellano), saprophytic on well-decayed logs (Trappe), from spring into early summer (Trudell)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (3)7-9(12) x (3)5.5-6.5 microns, elliptic, smooth, honey-colored^, (Arora), spores (3)7.5-9(12) x (3)5.5-6.3 microns, elliptic, golden ochraceous to honey color, with a short eccentric sterigmal appendage, germ pore very narrow and apex not truncate, no suprahilar depression or flattening, wall thick; basidia relatively scarce in mature hymenia, 4-spored or some 2-spored, 17-21 x 6-8.2 microns, clavate, sterigmata straight to slightly curved, cylindric to narrowly conic; pseudoparaphyses very numerous, about 16 x 12.5 microns, vesiculose; cystidia 60-100 x 15-25 microns, arising from innermost edge of subhymenium, fusoid-ventricose, the neck long with undulating walls, the apex obtuse to subacute, cystidia honey-yellow to brownish, thick-walled; subhymenium strongly developed (up to 50 microns deep), of inflated to subisodiametric elements 10-25(33) x 8-18.5(25) microns; interior to subhymenium is a layer of somewhat gelatinized hyphae diverging somewhat from mediostratum, its elements up to 15 microns in diameter; mediostratum of regularly arranged nearly colorless to yellowish filamentose hyphae the cells of which are irregularly enlarged; peridium with epicutis 15-50 microns thick, of gelatinous, narrow filamentous, colorless hyphae, cap context of essentially subparallel irregularly enlarged hyphae up to 12 microns wide, walls typically thin but occasional hypha thick-walled, walls colorless but in KOH becoming yellow; veil "of slightly gelatinized hyphae as revived in KOH"; context of stem and columella "of strongly interwoven hyphae but the fundamental arrangement vertical and the cells often enlarged up to 25 microns", hyphae in the columella colorless, those in the lower part of the stem colored, "throughout both structures loosely arranged and with numerous air spaces, not gelatinized"; all hyphae inamyloid; clamp connections present, (Singer), spores inamyloid; basidioles common, about 16 x 12.5 microns, vesiculose, (Castellano)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(11) (as Nivatogastrium nubigenum), Arora(1)* (as Nivatogastrium nubigenum), Castellano(1)* (as Nivatogastrium nubigenum), Smith(4)* (as Nivatogastrium nubigenum), Trudell(4)* (as Nivatogastrium nubigenum), Trappe(13)* (as Nivatogastrium nubigenum), Desjardin(6)* (as Nivatogastrium nubigenum)
158
FAMILY  Agaricaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
