LATIN NAMES  Podaxis pistillaris  (L. ex Pers.) Fr.^  [as 'Podaxon'], Syst. mycol. (Lundae) 3(1): 63. 1829
ENGLISH NAMES  desert shaggy-mane, desert inky-cap, false shaggy-mane, khumbi
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Podaxis pistillaris is similar to Coprinus comatus but has a contorted plated spore mass in place of true gills, and grows in arid areas.^ Some put Podaxis into an order of its own, Podaxales (because of the presence of capillitium), while others consider it a gastroid relative of Coprinus. Khumbi is a name used in India also for Phellorina inquinans, where the two species are the most popular edible commercial mushrooms in the market, (McKnight). It survives its desert habitat by means of thick-walled spores (Lincoff). The description is derived from Arora(1) except where indicated. It is the most prominent desert fungus of the western US, and occurs in warm dry areas on all continents, (Arora). RANGE Distribution is CA to southern ID, south to Mexico, and east to TX, (McKnight). The University of Washington has collections from CA, AZ, NM, TX, and Australia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  cap 2-15cm high, 1-4cm broad, oval to cylindric or sometimes somewhat twisted, the margin usually remaining attached to stem for a long time; "pure white to tan, yellow-brown, or brown"; dry, "typically breaking up to form shaggy fibrils or scales which may eventually peel or wear away to reveal the smooth undersurface", "eventually tearing radially or irregularly"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  spore mass of contorted plates or rudimentary gills, powdery when mature but liquefying slightly under some conditions; "at first white, soon darkening to yellowish, then reddish", and finally reddish brown to dark brown to blackish^, (Arora), when mature, dark brown to black (Smith)
STEM  4-15(26)cm x 0.2-1(1.5)cm, equal in upper part, base usually swollen, extending into spore mass and often through it, "usually long and slender, rather tough and fibrillose to raggedly scaly" (but often smoother when old), "solid or hollow, often twisted striate"; white, or when old often discolored like cap; veil not clearly differentiated from cap and stem tissue^, (Arora)
ODOR  slight^ (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), none (Miller)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  said to be edible when young and white inside, but tough and dusty when old, (Arora), edible when young, widely eaten in northern India, (McKnight)
HABITAT  single or scattered to gregarious or clustered on ground "in deserts, washes, lawns, gardens, irrigated fields, etc." in warm dry areas^, (Arora), spring, also summer and fall after rain, (Lincoff)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (7)10-16(36) x (5)9-15 microns, round to elliptic, pear-shaped, or irregular, smooth, thick-walled, with apical germ pore; capillitium present^, (Arora), spores yellow-brown (Lincoff), "capillitial threads olivaceous to reddish brown in KOH, sparingly septate, rarely branched", often coiled spirally when old, (Smith)
NAME ORIGIN  means "like a pestle" from Greek^, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
SIMILAR  like Coprinus comatus but does not have well-formed gills, does not normally deliquesce, and spore mass is powdery when mature; at least three other Podaxis species with smaller spores occur in the Southwest
SOURCES  Arora(1)*, Lincoff(2)*, Miller(14)*, Smith(4)*, Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)*, McKnight(1)*, AroraPocket*, Desjardin(6)*
159
FAMILY  Gomphaceae, Order Gomphales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Protogautieria lutea  A.H. Sm.^  Mycopath. Mycol. Appl. 32: 393. 1965
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include small size, underground growth, surface pale greenish yellow with broad pits from exposed spore mass, absent peridium, pale greenish yellow spore mass composed of coarse folds to coarsely chambered, rudimentary columella, peculiar odor at first, and microscopic characters including elliptic spores with banded pattern in Melzer's reagent, 4-spored basidia, and cystidia that are vinaceous red in KOH with red incrustations^; description derived from Smith(31) except where indicated; rare, northeastern WA, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  surface with KOH dingy brownish, FeSO4 no reaction
OUTER SURFACE  2cm x 1cm, soft and fleshy in consistency, surface alveolate [with broad pits] from chambers of exposed spore mass (peridium absent), pale bright greenish yellow, dingy brownish from handling
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  of coarse folds to coarsely lacunose; pale bright greenish yellow, (Smith(31)), pale yellow (Smith(4))
STEM  columella rudimentary, dendroid [branching]
ODOR  peculiar but soon vanishing
TASTE  mild
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection single under Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) and Larix (larch), early July
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14-19 x 9-12 microns, elliptic, smooth as seen in KOH, pale cinnamon buff in KOH to colorless if immature, in Melzer's reddish brown and showing darker longitudinal bands of a still darker red-brown color, but no ornamentation visible in wall, wall thick when mature^; basidia 4-spored, in a hymenium, about 35 x 15 microns, clavate; cystidia 100 x 20 microns more or less, "vinaceous red in KOH and with red incrustations", "some vinaceous granules scattered in hymenium"; tramal plates of interwoven colorless hyphae reddish in KOH in places, thin-walled, without incrustations; peridium absent but "exposed ridges of gleba with a palisade of cells reddish to purplish in KOH and with considerable incrusting material on them"; Melzer's reagent "causing entire mount to become dark red-brown"; clamp connections present
NAME ORIGIN  means 'yellow'
SIMILAR  Protogautieria substriata Thiers, described from California, has a black staining reaction on the peridium with KOH, lacks cystidia, peridium is perhaps better developed, and fruitbodies do not strongly resemble Gautieria morchelliformis as reported for P. lutea, (Thiers(4)), when fresh, P. lutea has "much the aspect of Gautieria morchelliformis [name italicized] but the resemblance ends there", (Smith(31))
SOURCES  Smith(31), Smith(4), Trappe(13), Thiers(4) (discussing Protogautieria substriata)
160
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon abietis  A.H. Sm.^  in A.H. Sm. & Zeller: Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 93. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to pear-shaped or irregular fruitbody with a white surface that soon becomes lemon to more ochraceous, bruising pale red at first, the bruised areas quickly turning brown or reddish brown, 2) a white spore mass that becomes dark olive, 3) abundant rhizomorphs on the lower part that converge into one or two coarse basal rhizomorphs, 4) chemical reactions, 5) smooth, truncate spores that are usually subfusoid, 6) 4-spored and 6-spored basidia, and 7) a peridium of interwoven hyphae 4-10 microns wide, with inflated cells up to 15 microns common, and a turf of clavate terminal cells.^ It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Rhizopogon abietis is found from OR to northern CA and ID, (Trappe(13)). It is found in ID and WY (Smith(30)), and OR, CA, PA, TN, and VA, (Miller).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH vinaceous to reddish brown on surface^, (Smith(4)), KOH on peridial surface reddish brown, negative on spore mass; FeSO4 on peridium slowly grayish olive, negative on spore mass, (Miller), FeSO4 somewhat olivaceous on surface, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-4cm across, "white, soon lemon yellow to more ochraceous"^, (Smith(4)), 1-4cm across, spherical, pear-shaped or irregular; surface at first white, soon "tinged lemon-yellow and then more ochraceous and soon spotted or flushed pink to vinaceous where in contact with debris or where injured, ochre-yellow or duller when mature, with reddish brown areas"; at first "cottony and with a basal white rhizomorph as the point of attachment", "at maturity with scattered rhizomorphs over the surface to nearly free of them"; peridium becoming salmon when cut, (Smith(30)), 1.5-4cm across, nearly spherical, ovoid or pear-shaped; peridium white when young or unexposed, pale yellow to light yellow or reddish yellow when old or where exposed, bruising pale red at first, bruised areas quickly turning brown or reddish brown; dry, to slightly tacky when aging, smooth, surface cottony fibrillose when young, then appressed-felty; peridium in cross-section 0.03-0.05cm thick, bruising grayish red; dried peridium light yellow to brown, often with patches of black; rhizomorphs abundant in lower part, "appressed, converging into one or two coarse rhizomorphs at point of attachment", scattered to absent in upper part, colored as peridium, readily bruising dull red, (Miller)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  soft in white stage, cartilaginous when mature; white becoming pale olive and finally dark olive; chambers small^, (Smith(30)), cartilaginous even when young, gelatinizing when old, when dried "hard to bone hard but easy to section"; white at first then grayish yellow, yellowish brown when old, when dried light brown to brown; locules 4-5 per mm at full development, (Miller)
STEM  "with a basal rhizomorph as the point of attachment"^, (Smith(30)), rhizomorphs "converging into one or two coarse rhizomorphs at point of attachment", (Miller)
ODOR  "faint, fungal-fruity when young, distinctly of road tar in age"^, (Miller)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in duff under alpine fir with some spruce present, summer^, (Smith(4)), gregarious in duff under Abies (fir) and Picea (spruce), summer, (Smith(30)), associated with 2-needle and 3-needle pines in southeastern United States, but reported with Tsuga (hemlock), Abies, and Picea from western states, (Miller)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-12 x 3-5 microns^, peridium of appressed, interwoven, thin-walled, nongelatinous hyphae 5-10 microns wide, "with many inflated cells up to 15 microns or more broad", "epicutis typically a turf with elements having clavate terminal cells to 14 microns wide", (Smith(4)), spores 9-12(13) x 3.5-5 microns, with various shapes but usually subfusoid, varying to elliptic, oval, narrowly clavate, or slightly allantoid (in side view), truncate at base with very fine tooth projecting down on either side of it, smooth, colorless in KOH, yellowish in Melzer's reagent; basidia 4-spored and 6-spored, colorless, collapsing readily; paraphyses nearly spherical, "terminal cell ovate to ellipsoid or clavate, thin-walled at first, and becoming thick-walled, having an amorphous central body, all the cells in the hymenial layer finally thick-walled"; subhymenium cellular, the cells when old with thickened walls; tramal hyphae 3-7 microns wide, when mature colorless, gelatinous, refractive in KOH, interwoven, smooth; peridium of appressed-interwoven, thin-walled, nongelatinous hyphae 5-10 microns wide and many enlarged cells in interior up to 15 microns or more in diameter, exterior layer typically a turf with the elements having clavate terminal cells up to 14 microns wide, "this layer collapsing and difficult to revive; sections of dried specimens revived in KOH show a reddish to rusty brown interior zone colored from heavy deposits of pigment in pockets and along the hyphae", and an outer yellowish zone with +/- colorless debris adhering to the hyphal walls, the hyphae 4-15 microns wide; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections rare, (Smith(30)), spores 10.5-13(15.5) x 3.5-5.0(5.5) microns, mostly subfusoid, ranging to elliptic or oval, "basal scar prominent, fine remnants of sterigma projecting slightly beyond a truncate base", narrowly clavate spores, possibly conidia also present, 15-22 x 3-3.5 microns; in KOH, colorless singly, pale olive gray in mass, "in Melzer's reagent, pale yellow singly, grayish olive in mass, mostly with 2 lipid droplets"; basidia "in a distinct hymenium 15-20 x 5-7 microns, mostly thin-walled and soon collapsing, but many with moderately thick walls supporting conidial spores, 2-, 4-, and 6-spored; brachybasidioles 8-20 x 6-10 microns, subglobose, clavate, or obovate, thin-walled in youth, thick-walled, mucilaginous in age, often with amorphous yellow refractive contents in KOH and Melzer's reagent, readily disarticulated in crush mounts"; subhymenium "subcellular but poorly developed", composed of cubic or cylindric and branching hyphae, thin-walled at first, thick-walled and mucilaginous when old; trama of hyphae that are 4-7 microns wide, colorless, moderately refractive in KOH, "cylindric to swollen near septa, loosely interwoven", thin-walled when young and when old, gelatinous, oleiferous hyphae abundant in mediostratum, 3-8 microns wide, "hyaline refractive in KOH, yellowish refractive in Melzer's reagent", cylindric or irregularly swollen and contorted, often branching; peridium 220-260 microns thick, of hyphae 4-10 microns wide, cylindric, loosely interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, large inflated cells up to 15 microns in diameter common, "with a turf of clavate terminal cells, 25-40 x 10-14 microns", cuticle not readily gelatinizing when old, interior part lightly encrusted with yellow to orange yellow amorphous pigment in KOH and in Melzer's reagent, "turf cells free from encrusting material", subcutis absent; clamp connections absent, (Miller)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of true fir [Abies]', referring to the type collection near fir trees
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon rubescens var. rubescens has smaller spores, less inflated cells in the peridium, and usually much smaller paraphyses, (Smith(30)). Rhizopogon ventricosporus also stains pink when bruised but has larger spores, (Castellano). Fresh collections of Rhizopogon vulgaris are similar "in that both species are distinctly yellow, bruise red, and have a tangle of white rhizomorphs near the point of attachment", but in R. abietis spores are longer and wider and often have a knobby crooked apex, (Miller). See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon albiroseus and Rhizopogon roseolus.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Castellano(2)*, Miller, S.L.(1) (colors mostly from Kornerup(3)), Trappe(13)
161
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon albidus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 155. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to angular fruitbody with surface dull white drying dingy pallid, with conspicuous rhizomorphs adhering loosely to surface, spore mass cartilaginous, dry, pallid becoming olive gray to olive brown, growth under conifers, and microscopic characters including smooth oval to oblong spores from 6-8-spored basidia, and peridium of appressed-interwoven hyphae in a single layer, in Melzer's reagent some yellowish-transparent pigment balls forming^; infrequent in the Pacific Northwest, found in southwest OR, central ID, (Trappe(13)), found in OR, ID, and WA, (Trappe, M.(3)), type collection from ID, (Smith(30))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  "with ethanol orange red on cutis, FeSO4 olivaceous"^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, dull white drying dingy pallid; dry, with conspicuous rhizomorphs^, (Smith(4)), 1-3cm across, spherical to subspherical [nearly spherical] or angular-subspherical; dull white overall and drying dingy pallid, not staining a different color when surface injured or when fresh surface cut; dry and silky-fibrillose beneath numerous pallid (whitish) rhizomorphs that are for the most part coarse and adhere to the surface but are easily removed, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "cartilaginous and dry when fresh, firm and sectioning easily when dried"; pallid becoming olive gray to olive brown^, (Smith(4)), spore mass cartilaginous and dry in consistency hen fresh, firm and section easily when dried; pallid then pale grayish, then olive-gray and in the oldest specimen olive-brown, spore mass ochraceous around larval tunnels; chambers minute, (Smith(30)), white when young, becoming brown to olive-brown, (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  
ODOR  not distinctive^ (Smith(4), Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  not distinctive^ (Trappe, M.(3))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under alpine fir and Pinus albicaulis (Whitebark Pine)^, (Smith(4)), under Pinus albicaulis and Abies (spruce), August, (Smith(30)), with Pinus, Abies, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga (hemlock), usually at higher elevations, July to October, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.5-7.5(8.2) x 2.3-2.8 microns^, (Smith(4)), peridium of appressed-interwoven hyphae, enlarged cells present only where hymenial cavities are forming, hyphae 3-12 microns wide, hyaline in KOH, some ochraceous interhyphal debris present as revived in KOH, (Smith(4)), spores (6)6.5-7.5(8.2) x (2.2)2.3-2.8(3) microns, oval to oblong, with base obscurely truncate, smooth, thin-walled, in KOH colorless, in masses along hymenium +/- ochraceous, in Melzer's reagent yellowish or in masses pale rusty brown; basidia 6-8-spored; paraphyses colorless in KOH and yellowish to colorless in Melzer's reagent, thin-walled becoming thick-walled; subhymenium one or two cells below hymenium; tramal plates of hyphae 3-8 microns wide, colorless, subparallel to interwoven; peridium "of appressed-interwoven hyphae in a single layer, enlarged cells only in area where hymenial cavities are forming", hyphae 3-12 microns in diameter, colorless in KOH and yellow in Melzer's reagent, and in the latter medium some yellowish transparent pigment balls form, "incrusting debris present only along surface and possibly of foreign origin, the debris dingy ochraceous to tawny in KOH"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  refers to the white color of the surface
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon pseudoalbus has at most a few inconspicuous rhizomorphs, and unpleasant odor when fresh reminding one of Calvatia fumosa, (Smith(4)), Rhizopogon pseudoalbus in addition has gelatinous spore mass that when dried is hard and crumbly when sectioned, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13), Trappe, M.(3)*
162
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon albiroseus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 91. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to nearly spherical fruitbody that is dull white to brownish or grayish, staining red when bruised but soon returning to white, and staining red with KOH, spore mass that is pallid to deep olive-buff to grayish buffy-brown with small chambers, and in Melzer's reagent spore mass becoming bluish gray, growth under Subalpine Fir, and microscopic characters including smooth, narrowly elliptic spores that are weakly amyloid when immature, 6-8-spored basidia, and peridium of appressed-interwoven clean hyphae (fresh) that become red in KOH, the color fading to colorless^; rare in northern ID (Trappe(13)), type collection from ID (Smith(30))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH red on white surface, FeSO4 no appreciable reaction, spore mass turns darker bluish gray in Melzer's reagent^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, dull white to brownish or grayish at maturity, surface red when injured, stained areas soon fading to white again^, (Smith(4)), 1-3cm across, spherical to nearly spherical or with various shapes from external pressure; white, (rhizomorphs also white), "staining red when bruised but stained areas soon bleaching to white instead of becoming brownish", overall color gradually duller, when old dingy gray and when decaying brownish gray; silky-fibrillose and with appressed rhizomorphs over surface, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  buffy brown^, (Smith(4)), pallid to deep olive-buff to grayish buffy-brown; chambers small, (Smith(30))
STEM  no columella^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under alpine fir^, (Smith(4)), cespitose-gregarious [clustered-gregarious] in a road through Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), 5000 feet elevation, July, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x 2.8-3.3 microns, weakly amyloid when immature^, "peridium of appressed-interwoven hyphae red in KOH, sections clean (not much debris present), some cells short and inflated to 12-15 microns (these are not sphaerocysts)", (Smith(4)), spores 7-8(9) x 2.8-3.3 microns, narrowly elliptic with obscurely truncate base, smooth, weakly amyloid when immature, inamyloid and pale rusty brown when mature, "yellowish in KOH fresh and revived", relatively thin-walled; basidia 6-8-spored, subcylindric in projecting part; paraphyses becoming thick-walled, colorless in KOH and weakly yellowish in Melzer's reagent; subhymenium cellular and +/- 2 cells deep; tramal plates of narrow, colorless, subparallel, somewhat gelatinous hyphae; peridium "of appressed-interwoven clean hyphae (fresh) which become red in KOH", the color fading to colorless, "some cells short and inflated to 12-15 microns, but not sphaerocyst-like, when revived in KOH the outer hyphae pale tawny with some incrusting debris present"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  refers to the white surface that becomes red when bruised
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon rubescens is honey yellow to yellow ocher at maturity (Smith(4)); Rhizopogon roseolus is white when young and soon entirely rose color, (Smith(4)); Rhizopogon abietis becomes yellow, (Smith(4)); Rhizopogon ventricosporus is ocher-yellow, (Smith(4)); Rhizopogon evadens has narrower spores, at least when fresh, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
163
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon alexsmithii  (Trappe) Vizzini & Zotti^  Mycologia 102(4): 974. 2010;  Alpova alexsmithii  Trappe  Beih. Nova Hedwigia 51: 298. 1975
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Rhizopogon alexsmithii is characterized by the combination of a sticky gelatinous spore mass with gel-filled locules separated by white veins, a yellow-brown to dark brown outer surface without pigments that dissolve in KOH, and thin-walled, short, colorless spores borne on basidia. The spore mass is pallid when young and becomes grayish yellowish pink when mature. The outside surface is felty to scabrous and occasionally cracked or wrinkled.^ The description is derived from Trappe(11) except where noted. It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Rhizopogon alexsmithii is found from BC south to the Cascade Mountains of OR, (Trappe(13)). Collections were examined from WA and OR (Trappe(11)). There is a Paul Kroeger collection from BC deposited at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on fresh and dried surface instantly dark brown and soon black; ferrous sulphate in water "dark brown and soon black on fresh specimens, quickly olive on dried specimens"
OUTER SURFACE  0.4-4cm across, the smaller specimens nearly spherical, the larger "flattened to elongate or irregular with lobes and furrows"; peridium 0.02-0.05cm thick, "yellowish brown to dark brown, sometimes staining darker where bruised", "drying dark olive to nearly black"; felty to more or less scabrous [roughened by short projecting rigid scales] and occasionally rimose-rugulose [cracked-wrinkled]
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "firm to crisp, sticky gelatinous, in wet weather exuding sticky fluid from the chambers", chambers 0.03-0.06cm across, rounded, gel-filled, separated by white veins, the contents pallid when young, grayish yellowish pink when mature, and light yellowish brown when dried
STEM  large rhizomorphs appressed on lower side, the same color as peridium, "originating from a basal tuft of hyphae and rhizomorphs"
ODOR  faint, pleasant
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground associated with various Pinaceae spp., particularly Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) and Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock) from 1200m to 3200m elevation, August to December, (Castellano), mycorrhizal with Tsuga (Trappe(11))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-7(8) x 3-4(5) microns, elliptic (or a few subpyriform to obovoid), smooth, in KOH colorless singly, grayish yellow in mass, "in Melzer's reagent pale yellow singly, orange-yellow in mass", thin-walled, strongly cyanophilic when young, acyanophilic at maturity^; basidia 21-29 x 4-5 microns, clavate, "borne among gelatinizing hyphae filling the chambers", colorless, "thin-walled, readily collapsing and by maturity autolysed"; trama hyphae 3-6 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, with cells often inflated up to 12(30) microns, (near the chambers the hyphae highly gelatinized), chambers lined with a palisade of subclavate to irregularly constricted, colorless, thin-walled cells 20-40 x 4-6 microns, some giving rise to short, stout, colorless, thin-walled brachybasidiole cells or basidia but most extending as interwoven, thin-walled, colorless hyphae that fill the chambers; peridial subcutis 174-470 microns thick, "near the epicutis often arranged in an erratic, obscurely radiate palisade (observable only in perfect, thin sections)" of hyphae 8-20 microns wide with brown walls 2-4 microns thick, this layer underlain by interwoven, colorless, thinner-walled hyphae 4-10 microns wide at septa with most cells inflated to 8-30 microns; peridial epicutis erratic in thickness, of tangled hyphae 2-4 microns wide with light yellow-brown walls, occasional versiform end cells 4-8 microns in diameter present, "no pigment diffusing in KOH mounts"; clamp connections absent or rare
NAME ORIGIN  after A.H. Smith, North American mycologist
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Trappe(11) (as Alpova alexsmithii), Castellano(1)* (as Alpova alexsmithii), Trappe(13) (as Alpova alexsmithii)
164
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon alkalivirens  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 48. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to nearly spherical fruitbody with pallid surface that becomes vinaceous brown when old, white to olive-buff spore mass, growth under conifers, chemical reactions including green then black reaction to KOH, and microscopic characters including spores of different shapes and sizes and peridium with giant cells up to 30 microns wide and with thickened walls^; rare, southwestern WA to ID, (Trappe(13)), type found in ID (Smith(30)), also collected in WA, (Smith(28))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH green on fresh surface then blackish, FeSO4 bluish olive on fresh surface^, (Smith(30)), when fresh the spore mass was violet where touched with a drop of Melzer's reagent, peridial surface when touched in KOH changed to pinkish and then olive, and where touched with FeSO4 changed slowly to olive, (Smith(28))
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, pallid, when old colored vinaceous-brown^, (Smith(4)), 1-2.5(3)cm across, spherical to nearly spherical; pallid, gradually darkening and when old or when dried "army brown" to "natal-brown"; dry, "fibrillose and with an overlay of loosely appressed brownish rhizomorphs", (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  firm but sectioning easily when dried, (Smith(4)), white to olive-buff and remaining pallid even when collapsing, (Smith(30))^, fragile when dried and relatively soft, (Smith(28))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under conifers^ (Smith(4))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-18 x 4-8 microns^, "peridium with giant cells up to 30 microns wide and with thickened walls", (Smith(4)), spores of different shapes, 12-18 x 3.5-5 microns "and angular-cylindric or wall merely slightly flexuous to even, base obscurely truncate", 9-12 x 6-8 microns "and ovate to angular ovate, some mitten-shaped and with the thumb either to right or left, some variously triangular or bifid", when mounted in Melzer's reagent bluish but fading out to brownish in half an hour, in KOH colorless when young but pale yellow-brown in the oldest ones, "walls often flexuous but thin (0.25-0.5 microns)"; "Basidia (or conidiophores?) 1-4-spored, soon gelatinizing and collapsing but oval to clavate or subcylindric when young"; paraphyses 8-12 microns wide, clavate, thin-walled; tramal plates of gelatinous, thin-walled, colorless, interwoven hyphae, "no incrustations or enlarged cells noted"; peridium of interwoven hyphae 4-12 microns wide, some giant cells scattered in the layer (cells about 30 microns across) and having thickened colorless walls, also numerous cells up to 20 microns across (inflated but not sphaerocyst-like), "in KOH with floccules of bister pigment between the hyphae and along them", in Melzer's reagent with numerous orange-brown pigment balls; tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30)), large versiform spores in revived material distinctly and persistently amyloid; as revived in KOH, "sections of the peridium are brownish vinaceous, and there is considerable brownish vinaceous debris in the layer", (Smith(28))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'green with alkali', referring to KOH reaction
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon subgelatinosus has darker gelatinous spore mass and smaller spores, and KOH stains some areas of the peridium sections reddish, (Smith(30)); Rhizopogon griseogleba stains vinaceous when handled and turns pinkish lilac with KOH, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Smith(4), Smith(28), Trappe(13)
165
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon anomalus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 32. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include small size, dingy ochraceous surface, spore mass that is grayish brown and bone-like when dried, and growth under conifers, but identified by microscopic characters: amyloid spores and distinctive structure of the tramal plates^; rare in the Pacific Northwest, found in northwest OR to ID and NM, (Trappe(13)), Smith(30) described type from Kauffman's collection from ID
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-2cm wide, spherical to ellipsoid or irregular from pressure; at first dingy ochraceous, drying to cinnamon-brown or darker; dull and unpolished^, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  grayish brown when dried and consistency hard and bone-like; cavities very small and indistinct in dried state^, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  not noted
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under mixed conifers^, (Smith(4))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-7.5(8.5) x 3.5-4.5 microns, elliptic to narrowly elliptic, smooth, in KOH colorless, but dingy brownish ochraceous to cinnamon in masses along hymenium, in Melzer's reagent most pale bluish but some of them dark violet or partly dark violet, wall thin to very slightly thickened, spores "may have an amyloid cap which is thicker than the remainder of the spore wall, and the edge of this cap is very uneven at times and on some spores isolated amyloid granules may occasionally be observed in this area"^; basidia 6-spored or 8-spored as judged by clumps of spores, 20-30 x 5-7 microns, gelatinous, "in KOH often showing an amorphous dull orange-ochraceous content in the form of amorphous masses"; cystidia and paraphyses not studied because of failure to see detail in hymenium; tramal plates "of intricately interwoven hyphae with thin walls gelatinous-refractive, hyaline and homogeneous in FeSO4, but as revived in KOH and in Melzer's sol. (at least near the peridium) with dull orange-brown masses and ropes of amorphous material conspicuous within them, subhymenium of filaments like those of the central strand and with same content, the plates very tough-cartilaginous and not breaking up under pressure", there is no cellular structure to the subhymenium; peridium "a single layer of hyphae, as revived in KOH so much rusty brown amorphous material present in and between the hyphae as to make details indistinct", in Melzer's also dark orange-brown and with some large globules of orange-brown pigment; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections not seen but not excluded, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'anomalous, deviating from the regular rule'
SIMILAR  in Rhizopogon chamaleontinus "few pale blue spores are present, and little material was seen in the interior of the tramal-plate hyphae", (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
166
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon arctyostaphyli  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 35. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to irregular fruitbody with surface that is grayish with yellow tints, peridium that slowly stains red from handling, dull green spore mass, and microscopic characters including amyloid spores from 6-spored and 8-spored basidia (the only Rhizopogon to date that has amyloid spores at maturity and a basically yellow fruitbody, according to Smith(30))^; infrequent in the Pacific Northwest, found in southwestern OR and northern CA, (Trappe(13)); found in Humboldt County in northwest CA
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2-5cm across, grayish with yellow tints, grayish ochraceous dried, peridium slowly staining red from handling^, (Smith(4)), 2-5cm across, spherical to ovoid or somewhat irregular in outline; cinereous to smoke gray with yellowish shading, grayish ochraceous in places when dry, "basic yellow tones... overlaid by the gray", "slowly turning reddish bruised when fresh"; finely fibrillose and with few rhizomorphs, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  dull green, with fine small cavities^, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  none^ (Smith(30))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest Arbutus, Arctostaphylos, (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x 2.8-3.5 microns, amyloid (pale blue over all)^; peridium lacking sphaerocysts, (Smith(4)), spores 7-9 x 2.8-3.5 microns, elliptic to narrowly elliptic, but truncate at base, smooth, in Melzer's reagent pale bluish over all, colorless in KOH singly or ochraceous in groups, thin-walled; basidia 6-spored and 8-spored, 11-15 x 4-6 microns, subcylindric to clavate; paraphyses not distinct - "apparently collapsed like the basidia from partial gelatinization"; tramal plates of colorless gelatinous interwoven hyphae, without clear outlines; peridium of appressed hyphae 3-9 microns wide, branched, thin-walled, near ochraceous tawny, some rusty brown pigment pockets, no sphaerocyst-like cells present; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
167
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon argillaceus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 114. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to irregular fruitbody that is clay-colored (also referred to as dark yellow brown), spore mass dull yellow-brown when mature, exuding colorless drops when cut, absent columella, growth under conifers, dark olive color change in KOH and in FeSO4, and microscopic characters including the "dark brown spores in masses along the hymenium, the thick-walled glassy tramal hyphae, the thick more or less 3-layered peridium with large pockets of sphaerocysts in the central region"^; rare in the Pacific Northwest, found in WA and ID, (Trappe(13)); found at least WA, ID, (Smith(4))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  Smith(30) refers to "the dark olive color-change in both FeSO4 and KOH" among the outstanding features of the species^
OUTER SURFACE  1-4cm across, with numerous white rhizomorphs, clay-colored, as dried bister [dingy yellow-brown] to olive-brown; peridium white when cut and not appreciably discoloring^, (Smith(4)), 1-4cm across, spherical, oval, or more or less irregular; 'dark "cinnamon-buff" to "buckthorn-brown" or "bister" (dark yellow-brown)', when dried the peridium bister to nearly olive-brown; "uneven and with irregular pits and depressions", "with numerous white rhizomorphs over surface but not closely appressed"; peridium thick (up to 0.1cm), "white in section and not discoloring appreciably when cut"; when dried fruitbodies are very hard and difficult to cut or break, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  yellow-brown when mature, exuding colorless droplets when cut^, (Smith(4)), "Dresden brown" (dull yellow brown), moist when cut and exuding colorless drops; chambers minute, (Smith(30))
STEM  columella none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in duff under conifers^ (Smith(4)), gregarious under spruce, (Smith(30) for type from ID)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.5-8 x 2.8-3 microns^, (Smith(4)); hyphae of tramal plates thick-walled as revived in KOH; peridium white in section (fresh) and not appreciably discoloring, hyphae 8-12 microns wide, wall ochraceous in KOH, 2-3 layered, pockets of sphaerocysts present in lower layer (the cells up to 20 microns wide), the layer purplish in places in KOH, (Smith(4)), spores 6.5-8 x 2.8-3 microns, narrowly elliptic, smooth, wall very slightly thickened, spores merely brownish in Melzer's reagent, "but in this medium often showing a false septum", in KOH pale olive singly but near "snuff-brown" (dingy yellow brown) in masses along hymenium; basidia 4-spored and 6-spored, 5-8 microns wide, subcylindric to clavate, colorless and readily collapsing; paraphyses up to 18 microns wide, vesiculose to clavate; cystidia none; subhymenium "cellular but rather indistinct as revived in KOH"; tramal plates of interwoven colorless thick-walled glassy hyphae in KOH, yellowish-transparent in Melzer's reagent; peridial subcutis of two regions, 'one containing pockets of enlarged cells (sphaerocyst-like) surrounded by "connective tissue"', the enlarged cells 20 microns or more in diameter, "and between all hyphae (in KOH) many olive blackish to bluish black deposits of pigment present", the lower region purplish in places in KOH and the hyphae wide and nearly parallel; peridial epicutis 25-50 microns thick, of appressed hyphae 8-12 microns wide, "the walls ochraceous in KOH and somewhat incrusted"; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30)) 
NAME ORIGIN  means 'clay-like', referring to color of surface
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon tsugae similar at least when dried but peridium lacks sphaerocysts, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30) (colors marked in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
168
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon argillascens  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 128. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to ellipsoid or angular fruitbody with surface pale grayish tan, slowly yellow-brown from handling, staining reddish slightly if outer layer is rubbed off but not becoming red from ordinary handling, spore mass dingy yellow-brown, basal cluster of rhizomorphs, gregarious growth under Lodgepole Pine, magenta KOH reaction, olive black FeSO4 reaction, and microscopic characters including smooth, oblong to narrowly elliptic spores from 6-spored to 8-spored basidia, and 2-layered peridium, the inner with inflated cells and staining heavily in KOH, the outer layer of appressed hyphae with walls pale ochraceous in KOH and little interhyphal debris present^; rare in northern ID (Trappe(13)), found eastern WA, northern ID according to Smith(4), type collected from "near Blanchard, Wash. but in Idaho", (Smith(30))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH dark red on surface, FeSO4 quickly olive black on peridium^, (Smith(4)), KOH on peridial surface dark magenta, FeSO4 soon olive-black, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-3.5cm across, "pale grayish tan, slowly yellow-brown from handling", dingy clay color when dried; staining reddish slightly on subcuticular layer^, (Smith(4)), 1-3.5cm across, spherical to ellipsoid or angular from mutual pressure; an even grayish "pinkish-buff", "gradually becoming dingy yellow-brown from handling and dingy clay-colored as dried, staining reddish slightly if outer layer is rubbed off but not becoming red from ordinary handling"; matted-fibrillose; peridium thick, about 0.1cm when fresh, "peridium in section with a reddish inner and a pallid outer layer, outer layer peeling away readily"; attached basally by a cluster of rhizomorphs but lacking appreciable number of rhizomorphs over surface, (Smith(30)) 
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  dingy yellow-brown; firm but when dried sectioning readily (not hard)^, (Smith(4)), when mature dingy yellow-brown, 'and as dried near "buckthorn-brown" or more ochraceous, firm but not hard (sectioning readily)', (Smith(30))
STEM  attached basally by a cluster of rhizomorphs^, (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine)^, (Smith(4)), gregarious under Pinus contorta, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-8 x 2.3-3 microns^, "peridium 2-layered, the inner with inflated cells in poorly defined areas and staining heavily in KOH", "outer layer of appressed hyphae 3-10 microns wide, walls pale ochraceous in KOH and little interhyphal debris present", hyphae of tramal plates thin-walled (under 0.5 microns thick) as revived in KOH, (Smith(4)), spores 6-8 x 2.3-3 microns, oblong to narrowly elliptic (base at most very obscurely truncate), smooth, in Melzer's reagent "yellowish singly to pale tawny in groups and most with a false septum", in KOH nearly colorless singly and ochraceous in masses along the hymenium; basidia 6-spored to 8-spored; paraphyses colorless, thin-walled young, thick-walled with a central colorless amorphous body when old; tramal plates of hyphae 3-6 microns wide, interwoven, gelatinous, colorless, "diverging to a filamentous subhymenium the only isodiametric cells small and at base of hymenial element, nowhere does the trama appear truly bilateral"; peridium "2-layered, lower layer with indistinct areas of inflated cells, and this layer staining heavily in KOH (as dried with many amorphous intercellular masses of dull rusty brown pigment giving thin sections a spotted appearance)", outer layer of hyphae (3)6-10 microns wide, interwoven-appressed, "with pale ochraceous walls (as revived in KOH) and with relatively little intercellular debris"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'becoming clay-like' referring to the color of the surface when the fruitbody is dried
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon separabilis.
SOURCES  Smith(30) (colors directly enclosed in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
169
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon ater  Trappe & Grubisha^  Mycotaxon 93: 345-353. 2005
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Rhizopogon ater is distinctive for its black exterior and spore mass, whether fresh or dry, the color arising from deposits of black, granular crystals in its tissues. When young the outer surface is sordid white to gray under a thin layer of brown hyphae, and often stains pink to vinaceous or brown, by maturity becoming blackish. The inner peridium is sometimes pink. The spore mass is gray to dirty olive, soon becoming black. A columella is rare but there are rhizomorphs at the base.^ The description is derived from Grubisha(3) except where noted. It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Rhizopogon ater is associated with Douglas-fir stands from near sea level to about 600 m elevation in the northern OR Coast Ranges and rarely in the southern WA Cascades, (Grubisha).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  "KOH on fresh, whitish peridium immediately olive, soon black", on fresh or dry spore mass instantly black
OUTER SURFACE  0.7-2cm x 0.9-3.2cm broad, spherical to nearly spherical, when young sordid white to gray under a thin layer of brown hyphae, "often staining pink to vinaceous or brown where cut or bruised, by maturity becoming reddish black to violaceous black or olivaceous black over all, drying dull black to brownish black or blackish olive but often with vinaceous areas"
INNER LAYER  inner peridium sometimes pink
INTERIOR  when young "gray to dirty olive, soon becoming olive black to bluish black or greenish black, when moist and cut open often with a metallic luster, drying dark olive to olive black", (Grubisha), spore mass firm, charcoal gray to nearly black (Trappe, M.)
STEM  columella rare, when present percurrent or inserted into the spore mass only a few mm, "sordid yellow when fresh, staining pink, drying pink"; rhizomorphs "appressed at and emanating from the base singly or in clusters of a few", up to 0.2cm thick at place of attachment, "dark brown and much branched, often breaking off when the specimen is unearthed"
ODOR  "not distinctive or sometimes sweet or onion-like"
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious associated with roots of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir)^, (Grubisha), with Pseudotsuga in moist forests, September to January, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.0-7.0(10.0) x (2.5)3-3.5(4) microns, obtuse to elliptic, smooth, when young with 1-2 droplets and often appearing false septate, colorless to brown in mass in KOH, inamyloid, "in Melzer's reagent brown in mass, sometimes in water or Melzer's reagent with black granules adherent to the surface"^; basidia 13-23 x 7.5-10 microns, clavate to clavate-cylindric; black granules "present in water or Melzer's reagent, scattered in the peridium and glebal trama but profuse in the subhymenium and hymenium, in KOH dissolving into a green pigment"; clamp connections absent; under the microscope in KOH, the spore mass flushes green and the peridial subpellis is red
NAME ORIGIN  means 'black'
SIMILAR  Granules like the ones here are found in other related species but usually only in the peridium and sometimes the immediately adjacent spore mass, (Grubisha).
SOURCES  Grubisha(3), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)
170
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon atroviolaceus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 37. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to pear-shaped fruitbody with a surface that is white staining pink from handling and drying fuscous, 2) a spore mass that is green drying bone-hard, 3) underground to emergent growth under conifers, 4) chemical reactions, 5) dark violet amyloid spores many of which are angular, 6) basidia that are 4-spored, 6-spored, or 8-spored, 7) a filamentose subhymenium, and 8) a peridium of interwoven rhizomorphic strands.^ It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Rhizopogon atroviolaceus is found in western OR and WA to ID (Trappe(13)). It is found in the Siskiyou Mountains and the Cascade Range of OR, east to central and northern ID, (Castellano). It was described from ID, (Smith(30)). 
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH lilac and slowly lilac brown on surface, FeSO4 dull blue on surface^, (Smith(30)), KOH on peridium lilac, soon lilaceous brown to black; Melzer's reagent negative on peridium, purplish black on spore mass, (Castellano)
OUTER SURFACE  1-3.5cm across, "white staining shell pink from handling"^, (Smith(4)), up to 3.5cm thick and 1-2.5cm high, spherical to pear-shaped; "ground color white, becoming shell pink from staining or flushed pink over all and when dried fuscous", rhizomorphs when present brownish avellaneous and staining vinaceous when bruised; surface typically uneven, dry, and fibrillose-silky, at times with appressed rhizomorphs; "peridium in section white when fresh", (Smith(30)), 1.5-3cm across, nearly spherical to pear-shaped or lobed; when young white, "usually slowly staining faintly to moderately pink to vinaceous or violet where bruised or cut", when dried brown-black overall; when young coarsely fibrillose, when mature the surface fibrils brown; "sometimes with scattered, appressed, concolorous rhizomorphs", (Castellano), white when young, "soon becoming brown from a surface layer of brown fibrils, often staining vinaceous where bruised", (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "green and drying bone-hard in mature specimens"^, (Smith(4)), drying very hard in mature specimens (almost like bone); white becoming green when fresh, pale buff when dried; cavities small and irregular, when fresh quickly dark violet with Melzer's reagent, (Smith(30)), soft when young becoming rubbery; white when young becoming gray-olive to green-olive; minutely loculate [chambered], (Castellano)
STEM  columella absent^ (Castellano)
ODOR  fungoid, pleasant^, (Castellano), mild (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  fungoid, pleasant^, (Castellano), mild (Trappe, M.(3))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under pine, spruce and fir mixed, summer and fall^, (Smith(4)), underground to emergent, scattered to grouped, associated with Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga (hemlock), May through December, (Castellano), moderate to high elevations (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-8 x 3-3.6 microns or 7-9 x 3-4 microns, mostly dark violet in Melzer's reagent and many minutely punctate ornamented^, (Smith(4)), spores 6-8 x 3-3.6 microns and elliptic, or 7-9 x 3-4 microns and angular-elongate to angular-elliptic, smooth to minutely punctate-ornamented, colorless in KOH singly and in groups dingy buff (when fresh in KOH some with reddish content, but not when revived), in Melzer's reagent dark violet singly and blackish violet in mass, wall slightly thickened, sterigmal scar inconspicuous; basidia 4-spored, 6-spored, or 8-spored, 17-20 x 5-7 microns, subcylindric or narrowed near top; paraphyses resembling basidioles, 5-8 microns wide, thin-walled, colorless in KOH; tramal plates of interwoven, narrow, colorless, gelatinous-refractive hyphae "branching to a filamentous subhymenium of refractive hyphae, no oleiferous hyphae seen"; peridium a single layer of appressed-interwoven hyphae with colorless nongelatinous walls "but dark brown amorphous masses of pigment present in and along the hyphae to give the layer a dark brown color (revived in KOH)", in Melzer's reagent many of these masses becoming orange-brown globules, some hyphae with inflated cells "but pigment deposits obscure nearly all cell detail"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30)), spores 6-8 x 2-4 microns, elliptic to clavate, (as well as 7-9(10) x 3-4(6) microns, subangular), smooth to punctate-roughened, colorless singly, brown-yellow in mass, distinctly amyloid, the walls somewhat thickened; basidia 4-spored, 6-spored or 8-spored, 17-20 x 5-7 microns, subcylindric, with interspersed brachybasidioles; trama of interwoven colorless hyphae 2-3 microns wide, when mature "with gelatinous-thickened, glassy-appearing walls"; peridium 300-500 microns thick, of interwoven cable-like strands of hyphae with nongelatinous walls "and obscured by pink to orange, red or brown, amorphous pigment masses in KOH, the pigment forming pink to orange-brown globules in Melzer's reagent", (Castellano)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'black-violet'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon subpurpurascens does not become pink, it gives an olive-fuscous reaction with KOH, and the subhymenium is cellular rather than filamentose, (Smith(30)). R. subpurpurascens also has only part of its spores amyloid, (Castellano). Rhizopogon kauffmanii has deep purple pigment globules in Melzer's reagent, (Castellano). R. kauffmanii and Rhizopogon fallax have under 40% of the spores completely dark violet in Melzer's reagent, whereas R. atroviolaceus has over 60% completely dark violet, (Smith(30)). R. fallax has large inflated cells in the peridium, (Castellano).
SOURCES  Smith(30), Castellano(2)*, Smith(4), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)
171
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon aurantiacus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N. Y. bot. Gdn 14(2): 116. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  the most distinctive characters is the orange surface color - when dried the blackened rhizomorphs show against a vinaceous brown surface, other features include dry fibrillose surface with dull brownish rhizomorphs, reactions to KOH and FeSO4, white to honey-yellow spore mass with dry texture and small chambers, absent columella, and microscopic characters^; description derived from Smith(30); type described from ID, (Smith(30)), infrequent in Pacific Northwest, found at least ID, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH turns the surface slowly reddish to reddish brown, FeSO4 turns surface gray to blackish
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across, spherical to subspherical-nodulose; pale orange, drying to vinaceous brown, the surface layer (cutis) separating to reveal small patches of the whitish subcutis, surface not changing when cut or bruised; "dry, with appressed dull brownish rhizomorphs which blacken in drying"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  dry, chambers small but distinct; white to honey yellow
STEM  columella absent
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type gregarious under spruce-fir
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.5-8 x 2.2-2.5 microns, oblong to elliptic, smooth, yellowish in Melzer's reagent, colorless in KOH singly, in groups pale ochraceous revived in KOH, basal truncation very obscure^; basidia cylindric when sporulating, 6-8-spored; paraphyses thin-walled; subhymenium cellular, hyphae of tramal plates narrow (2-4 microns), colorless, "smooth, scarcely gelatinous as revived in KOH"; peridium when fresh "with an outer layer of appressed-interwoven ochraceous-incrusted hyphae", "inner layer red in KOH, no sphaerocysts present", as revived in KOH the whole layer or only the epicutis vinaceous red (pigment both intercellular and intracellular), in Melzer's reagent "the layer full or [?of] orange-red pigment balls", "the hyphae thin-walled, clean of debris"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon ochraceorubens is related and they could be the same species
SOURCES  Smith(30), Trappe(13)
172
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon avellaneitectus  A.H. Sm.^  Journal of the Mitchell Society 84(2): 274. 1968
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to flattened and irregular fruitbody with a pinkish undertone matted loosely with grayish brown fibrils and a few coarse rhizomorphs, labyrinthiform chambers in spore mass which is white to grayish to olive-buff, growth under conifers, and chemical and microscopic characters including smooth, oblong to narrowly subfusoid spores from 4-spored or 6-spored basidia, and peridial epicutis of appressed hyphae pale tan in KOH and with pale fulvous incrustations, with inflated cells also present^; description derived from Smith(28); rare, northeastern WA, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on surface dingy brown, KOH on cross-section of peridium gives red reaction, FeSO4 on surface and on cut surface negative
OUTER SURFACE  1-3.8cm across, spherical to flattened and irregular in outline; "dry and matted loosely with a thin epicutis of grayish avellaneous fibrils", beneath the fibrils an undertone of pinkish, a few coarse rhizomorphs variously distributed over the surface, "peridium in section pallid, becoming distinctly pinkish when cut and redder with the application of KOH"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white to grayish to olive-buff; soft in white stage, cartilaginous when older, chambers labyrinthiform
STEM  columella absent
ODOR  mild to slightly fragrant
TASTE  mild
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered to single along old roads under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), some Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) present in the area
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-7 x 2-2.3 microns, oblong to narrowly subfusoid, smooth, with a false septum, yellowish transparent in KOH and more yellowish in Melzer's reagent^; basidia 4-spored or 6-spored, 7-10 microns wide, versiform, spherical to clavate or subcylindric; basidioles "thin-walled but in oldest specimen thickened up to 1.5 microns and wall not gelatinous"; subhymenium cellular, the cells up to 12 microns across, hyphal walls not gelatinous; tramal plates of hyphae as revived in KOH 3-6 microns wide, (variously inflated and constricted), colorless, interwoven, gelatinous-refractive; peridium "with an epicutis of appressed hyphae pale tan in KOH and with pale fulvous incrustations", hyphae 3-10 microns wide, and many with more inflated cells, "beneath this a region continuing to cavities and with many inflated cells singly or in pockets or as cells in a filament (hence in a row), some cells with walls up to 1 micron thick", with orange-brown pigment balls in Melzer's reagent in the peridium; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with avellaneous covering'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(28), Trappe(13)
173
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon bacillisporus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 148. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a nearly spherical fruitbody with a surface that is pallid, bald, and does not stain, 2) absent rhizomorphs, 3) a olive-buff spore mass that is ochraceous when dried, 4) growth under conifers, 5) smooth, narrow spores from 6-spored and 8-spored basidia, and 6) a single-layered peridium of appressed-interwoven hyphae, ochraceous tawny in KOH with golden ochraceous pigment deposits on the hyphae.^ It is common among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It is found from OR to ID and WY (Trappe(13)). 
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  with FeSO4 olive on dried surface, with KOH pale dingy vinaceous brown^, (Smith(30)) 
OUTER SURFACE  up to 5cm across, pallid fresh, (merely dingy buff as dried), not staining when injured^, (Smith(4)), about 5cm thick, nearly spherical; pallid when collected and scarcely changing (dingy buff) when dried, not staining when injured; bald, lacking rhizomorphs; peridium somewhat separable, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  olive-buff when fresh, ochraceous buff when dried; chambers large, consistency friable and easy to section^, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  alpine, under alpine fir^, (Smith(4)), associated with Pinaceae (Trappe(13))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-6 x 1.7-2 microns, hyaline in KOH^; brachybasidioles remaining thin-walled; peridium a single layer, the hyphae 4-9 microns wide, appressed, "ochraceous tawny, some cells more or less inflated, golden ochraceous pigment deposits present (in KOH) on the hyphae often as droplets", (Smith(4)), spores 5-6 x 1.7-2 microns, rod-shaped, smooth, yellowish in Melzer's reagent, colorless in KOH, thin-walled, basal scar very indistinct; basidia 6-spored and 8-spored, 16-20 x 4.5-6 microns, clavate becoming subcylindric, sterigmata fine and short; paraphyses 5-8 microns wide, clavate, all thin-walled (specimen past maturity); "subhymenium cellular but cell outlines indistinct"; tramal plates of hyphae 3-5 microns wide, of equal width throughout, subparallel, somewhat refractive; peridium a single layer of hyphae 4-9 microns wide (with some cells somewhat enlarged), appressed-interwoven, ochraceous tawny in KOH, "golden-ochraceous pigment deposits present on the hyphae in the layer (often drop-like as revived in KOH)"; all hyphae inamyloid; clamp connections none, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with spores shaped like rod or small stick'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
174
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon brunneicolor  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 106. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to irregular small fruitbody with surface pale yellow to ochraceous buff becoming dark yellow-brown with handling, spore mass dark yellow brown and very hard when fresh, growth under conifers, chemical characters, and microscopic characters including smooth, narrowly elliptic spores from 4-spored, 6-spored, and 8-spored basidia, thick-walled paraphyses with noncolored central body as revived in Melzer's reagent, and duplex peridium with inner layer reacting with KOH and FeSO4^; infrequent in ID, (Trappe(13)), type collection from ID
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 on fresh surface pale gray, KOH on yellow surface cinnamon brown^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-2cm across, pale yellow to ochraceous buff, yellow-brown from handling^, (Smith(4)), 1-2cm across, spherical to nearly spherical or variously irregular; "ochraceous-buff" (pale yellow) or duller overall, where handled slowly dark yellow-brown ("Brussel's brown" or "buckthorn-brown"); "dry to moist but not lubricous or viscid", appressed-fibrillose, no coarser rhizomorphs, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  yellow-brown when fresh and mature, gleba hard and firm-cartilaginous when fresh^, (Smith(4)), dark yellow brown when moist ("Brussel's brown"), very hard when fresh, (Smith(30))
STEM  columella none (Smith(30))
ODOR  none^ (Smith(30))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under conifers, summer^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x 2.8-3.8 microns^; peridium in sections with olive-black layer next to gleba in FeSO4 (the same layer reddish in KOH), "epicutis ochraceous in KOH, hyphae 4-12 microns wide but more distinctly inflated cells also present", (Smith(4)), spores 7-9 x 2.8-3.8 microns, narrowly oval to narrowly elliptic, smooth, yellow in Melzer's reagent and most of them with a false septum, pale yellow in KOH when fresh and when revived and yellow ochraceous in masses along the hymenium, lacking a distinct basal scar; basidia 4-spored, 6-spored, and 8-spored, thin-walled and collapsing readily; paraphyses "mostly with ultimate cell thick-walled and with a small central lumen, at times the whole chain of 3-4 cells with walls thickened", colorless in KOH including lumen, yellowish-transparent in Melzer's reagent and with central body in lumen merely yellowish-transparent; "subhymenium cellular and the cells either thin-walled or walls thickened as described for the paraphyses"; tramal plates of hyphae 3-6 microns wide (and mostly uninflated), colorless, refractive, boldly defined, with smooth walls; peridium in section with an olive-black layer next to the gleba in FeSO4, the same layer reddish in KOH, epicuticular layer of peridium "ochraceous as revived in KOH and with inflated cells in it", most hyphae 4-12 microns wide and thin-walled, lower layer of peridium "as revived in KOH with reddish pigment deposits and a reddish tone pervading the layer"; all tissues inamyloid, orange-brown pigment globules present in the lower layer [presumably of peridium] as seen in Melzer's reagent; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'brown-colored'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon molligleba has spores a little narrower, spore mass is almost sticky when fresh specimens are cut in half, peridium is thin and not obviously duplex, and in Melzer's reagent "sections allowed to stand for an hour did not show any orange-brown pigment globules", (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30) (colors directly in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
175
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon brunneifibrillosus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 79. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include nearly spherical fruitbody with dark cinnamon brown surface, firm spore mass with distinct chambers that is dull sepia when dried, growth under mixed conifers, chemical characters, and microscopic characters including narrow smooth spores from 8-spored basidia, yellow-brown hymenial and subhymenial elements for the most part, and nongelatinous hyphae in the tramal plates^; found eastern slope of Cascades in OR, ID, rare, according to Smith(4), rare, Wasco County, OR, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH darker brown on surface, FeSO4 slowly black on surface^, (Smith(4))
OUTER SURFACE  3cm across, fibrillose, dark cinnamon brown^, (Smith(4)), about 3cm across, nearly spherical; dark cinnamon-brown (+/-"cinnamon-brown" as dried), darker when rubbed (dark russet in these areas finally, as dried); dry and unpolished from a loosely fibrillose layer; "with a basal cluster of rhizomorphs", (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  firm as dried but not hard, in sectioning rather crumbly; dull sepia when dried; chambers distinct^, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single in duff under mixed conifers, (Smith(30) for type), summer and fall, (Smith(4)), mycorrhizal host in Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-8.5 x 2.2-2.5 microns^, paraphyses (brachybasidioles) "8-12 microns wide and with yellow-brown walls (at least in locules near peridium)"; subhymenium not gelatinous; hyphae of tramal plates colorless to slightly yellow-brown, epicutis of peridium with some cells up to 50 microns wide, flagellate hyphal ends rudimentary, (Smith(4)), spores 7-8.5 x 2.2-2.5 microns, oblong, smooth, in KOH ochraceous-transparent singly and dark yellow-brown in groups, in Melzer's reagent yellowish singly and reddish brown in masses, typically with a false septum, "basal truncation present but obscure"; basidia 8-spored, 8-10 microns wide, clavate, with yellow-brown walls both as revived in KOH and as revived in Melzer's reagent, not at all gelatinous; paraphyses 8-12 microns wide, clavate to vesiculose, "thin-walled, walls yellow-brown in KOH and not at all gelatinous, content homogeneous or with a poorly defined amorphous central body"; subhymenium cellular, the cells with colorless to yellow-brown walls, "not at all gelatinous, content similar to that of paraphyses"; peridium with a well developed epicutis of loosely interwoven smooth-walled rusty brown (in KOH) hyphae, "mostly with walls at least somewhat thickened and cells equal to inflated", cells mostly 6-12 microns wide, but some inflated cells up to 50 microns and some narrowed hyphal tips 2-3 microns wide (rudimentary flagellate hyphae); peridial subcutis of hyphae 6-20 microns wide, interwoven, yellowish brown in KOH, reddish cinnamon in Melzer's reagent, some inflated cells in the layer, orange-brown pigment balls present in mounts in Melzer's reagent; no olive seen anywhere in KOH, very little amyloid debris; clamp connections none, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  from 'brunneus' - 'brown', and 'fibrillosus' - 'fibrillose'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
176
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon brunneiniger  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 146. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to ellipsoid fruitbody with surface whitish to dark cinnamon, staining blackish brown from handling, when dried black, shiny, and bald, spore mass white to yellow to olivaceous, basal attachment by 1 to several rhizomorphs, underground growth under conifers, and microscopic characters including smooth narrow spores from 8-spored basidia, and peridium a single layer of closely interwoven hyphae with coagulated blackish content^; found OR, CA according to Castellano(1), rare for OR according to Smith(4), infrequent, western OR to northern CA, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, dark cinnamon when fresh, blackish brown from handling, black and shiny when dried; bald, shiny^, (Smith(4)), 3cm x 2cm x 1cm, or 1-2cm across, spherical to nearly spherical and some ellipsoid; "Mars brown" (dark cinnamon), to "mummy-brown" (blackish brown), blackening completely when dried; "bald and shiny as dried", lacunose at times; according to Trappe's notes peridium whitish with brown patches, turned sepia where bruised in handling, dried black, (Smith(30)), dark red-brown to black-brown (Castellano)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "white then yellow to yellowish olivaceous, when dried hard and near clay color"^, (Smith(4)), firm-cartilaginous, hard when dried; white at first becoming "medal-bronze" to "bronze-citrine" (olivaceous), drying pale sepia to olive-clay color; according to Trappe's notes firm, Marguerite yellow (Maertz & Paul color), (Smith(30)), white at first, becoming olivaceous, drying pale brown to olive; loculate [chambered], (Castellano)
STEM  with a basal attachment by 1 to several rhizomorphs^, (Smith(4)), "with a basal group of rhizomorphs or a single basal rhizomorph" attaching the fruitbody to the substrate; columella not seen in dried material, (Smith(30))
ODOR  not distinctive (Smith(30) from Trappe's notes), mild, "almost fruity" to cheesy, (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Alnus (alder) and Tsuga (hemlock)^ (Smith(30)), found in association with roots of Pinaceae including Abies concolor (White Fir), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), P. monticola (Western White Pine), P. muricata (Bishop Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), and T. mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock), from sea level to 2350m elevation, September and October, (Castellano), April to November, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-6.5(7) x 1.8-2.5 microns^; "peridium a single layer of closely interwoven hyphae with coagulated blackish content (no olive or green color evident in mounts revived in KOH)", (Smith(4)), spores 5-6.5(7) x 1.8-2.3(2.5) microns, cylindric to narrowly oblong, smooth, wall not appreciably thickened, spores in Melzer's reagent "yellowish singly and slightly darker in groups and typically with a false septum", in KOH colorless singly and yellow-brown in groups; basidia 8-spored; paraphyses colorless, becoming thick-walled, amorphous content not darkening in Melzer's reagent; "subhymenium cellular and cells becoming thick-walled like the paraphyses"; tramal plates of interwoven, colorless, gelatinous, smooth, narrow hyphae; peridium a single layer of very closely interwoven hyphae with colorless walls "but much blackish coagulated content as in species giving a green to olive fuscous reaction with KOH but no green visible in mounts revived in KOH", in Melzer's reagent "the pigment rounding into large rusty brown to fuscous-brown pigment balls"; no sphaerocysts seen; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none, (Smith(30)), basidioles colorless, becoming thick-walled, amorphous content amyloid [presumably referring to "paraphyses", which Smith(30) says have amorphous content that does not darken with Melzer's reagent], (Castellano)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'brown-black'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon nitens has differently colored spore mass, different color and color change of the peridium, and lacks pigment balls as revived in Melzer's reagent, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Castellano(1), Smith(4), Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)
177
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon burlinghamii  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N. Y. bot. Gdn 14(2): 121. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include colors of dried material, presence of some rhizomorphs, and the microscopic characters, type collected in CA, (Smith(28)), description derived from Smith(28) examination of dried material; rare in Pacific Northwest, eastern OR to southern CA, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 on dried outer surface no reaction
OUTER SURFACE  2-4cm across, 1-2cm thick, (estimated dimensions fresh from dried material); when dried reddish tawny but paler than in R. ochraceorubens (also lacks the latter's magenta colors when revived in KOH); when dried bald, dull, and unpolished
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "near pale pinkish buff dried and though firm in consistency sectioning very easily"
STEM  "some rhizomorphs present but very inconspicuous on dried specimen"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  associated with members of Pinaceae^ (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x (1.8)2-2.3 microns, rod-shaped to narrowly elliptic, smooth, in Melzer's reagent "mostly yellowish but some groups with a bluish-gray tone indicating a very weak amyloid reaction in places", in KOH colorless individually and faintly ochraceous in groups, spores thin-walled, base scarcely truncate from basal scar^; basidia 6-spored, 5-7 microns in diameter, colorless, thin-walled, sterigmata very short; paraphyses "resembling basidioles, remaining thin-walled but a few with a small refractive granule"; subhymenium cellular; tramal plates "of interwoven subgelatinous hyphae of variable diameter as revived in KOH"; peridium in interwoven single layer of appressed hyphae 3-8 microns wide "and many with cinnamon to yellowish amorphous content as revived in KOH", no amyloid granules seen in Melzer's reagent and no enlarged spherocyst-like cells observed, some hyphal cells irregular in diameter and up to 12 microns broad, peridium in sections revived in KOH fulvous at first but clearing and nearly colorless at least in places; clamp connections absent; all tissues nonamyloid
NAME ORIGIN  after the collector G.S. Burlingham
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(28), Trappe(13)

FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon butyraceus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N. Y. bot. Gdn 14(2): 130. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to irregular, ocher-yellow fruitbody that was wet and slightly sticky when collected, slowly staining vinaceous on handling, with scattered rhizomorphs, the interior moist and spongy with minute chambers, pale buff when young becoming dark olive when old, and microscopic characters including filamentous-branched subhymenium and peculiar staining reaction when mounted in KOH and in Melzer's reagent^; description derived from Smith(30); type described from ID, (Smith(30)), rare in Pacific Northwest, with distribution southern WA, ID, and southern CA, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 on fresh surface dark olive; KOH on surface dull vinaceous
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, spherical to irregular from mutual pressure; rich ocher-yellow over all, "slowly staining dingy vinaceous on handling"; "wet and shiny when collected"; a few scattered rhizomorphs over surface and dirt adhering to surface as though surface were subviscid
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  with minute chambers, moist and spongy, firm when dry but not bone-like in consistency; pale olive-buff when young, dark olive when old
STEM  
ODOR  none
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type in duff near Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Smith), associated with Pseudotsuga and Pinus (pine), (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-8.5 x 2-2.5 microns, narrowly oblong, colorless individually "and barely tinted yellowish in masses along the hymenium", yellowish in Melzer's reagent, no basal scar visible^; basidia 6-spored and 8-spored; paraphyses thin-walled, terminal cells subspherical to ellipsoid, 2-3 septate in lower part, colorless in KOH; cystidia none; tramal plates of colorless refractive hyphae 3-5 microns wide, "loosely arranged and much-branched, giving rise to a ramose subhymenium which in turn gives rise to the hymenial palisade composed mostly of septate elements"; peridium of appressed-interwoven, nongelatinous hyphae 4-12 microns wide, the cells short in the broadest hyphae, as revived in KOH vinaceous red down to a narrow colorless zone above the glebal chambers, some cells up to 18 microns wide present; amorphous masses of reddish pigment numerous; in Melzer's reagent "with the upper half pale yellow and the lower half red, the red fading as orange-red pigment globules form in this layer"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to butter' (Latin)
SIMILAR  compare with Rhizopogon vulgaris. See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon cusickiensis.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Trappe(13)
179
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon canadensis  K.A. Harrison & A.H. Sm.^  Can. J. Bot. 46: 885. 1968
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include somewhat spherical fruitbody that has surface whitish with cinnamon-buff areas, thin transparent peridium, spore mass that has a watery juice when fresh, growth under conifers, chemical characters, and microscopic characters including smooth fusoid spores, and subhymenium of giant cells 12-30 microns in diameter^; type found in BC (Harrison)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on fresh peridium yellowish then reddish, (Smith(4)), KOH reddish on surface (Harrison)
OUTER SURFACE  up to 1.5cm across, "whitish with cinnamon-buff areas" and as dried cinnamon-buff overall, "with an obscure overlay of fine rhizomorphs; peridium thin and transparent"^, (Smith), up to 1.5cm across, spherical to irregularly spherical; "whitish with cinnamon buff areas and when dried more or less dingy cinnamon buff over all"; "with an obscure overlay of fine rhizomorphs in some", "the peridium thin and transparent, allowing the outline of the locules to show", (Harrison)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  with a watery juice when fresh, as dried cinnamon-buff and sectioning readily (not hard)^, (Smith), "of round discrete-appearing locules (as seen on a section of dried basidiocarp), reminding one of a mass of individual tubes cut transversely, the tramal plate tissue very weak, with a watery juice when fresh, when dry firm but sectioning easily, as dried pallid to tinged cinnamon buff", (Harrison)
STEM  columella absent^ (Harrison)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under conifers, (Smith), type collected in August, (Harrison)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-12 x 3.8-5 microns, groups of spores colorless in KOH^, "subhymenium of inflated cells 12-30 microns wide", (Smith(4)), spores 9-12 x 3.8-5 microns, fusoid, smooth, yellowish to orange-buff in Melzer's, colorless in KOH, walls thin (to 0.25 microns), no apical differentiation, some with a tendency to form a false septum; basidia not clearly seen, spores seen in groups of 4; cystidia none; subhymenium "a pseudoparenchymatous layer of giant cells 12-30 microns diameter", tramal plate proper of filaments 3-12 microns wide, the hyphae thin-walled and delicate; numerous globules present in mounts made in KOH and Melzer's reagent; peridium "a layer of thin-walled hyphae or some with slightly thickened walls, compactly interwoven and with some hyphae of various diameters, reddish revived in KOH and with some reddish intercellular debris", in some sections an epicutis (?) of narrow hyphae 2-4 microns wide "with thin to thickened walls and these lemon yellow in KOH and a few seen with clamps"; "tramal body of more or less enlarged hyphae, cells thin-walled and smooth in KOH", (Harrison)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'from Canada'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Harrison(2), Smith(4)
