FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon chamaleontinus  A.H. Sm.^  Journal of the Mitchell Society 84(2): 276. 1968
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to irregular fruitbody with white surface that stains vinaceous to fuscous and has no yellow tones, pallid spore mass, growth in association with roots of Douglas-fir and Sugar Pine, olive black KOH reaction on surface and quick FeSO4 change to black, and microscopic characters including an unusual amyloid pattern of the spores, and candelabra-type branching of hymenium^; found OR (Castellano(1)), ID (Smith(4)), rare in Pacific Northwest, found in northern ID, southwestern OR, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on surface olive then black, FeSO4 on surface quickly black^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-2cm across, spherical to irregular; "white when young, darkening to fuscous black in drying", "when handled staining fuscous to vinaceous fuscous"; when young with numerous appressed fibrils and rhizomorphs but when old or when dried nearly bald^, (Smith(28))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  chambers minute, consistency cartilaginous when fresh, very hard when dry; "pallid, becoming wood brown and avellaneous as dried"^, (Smith(28))
STEM  columella absent^ (Smith(28))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  found in association with roots of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and scattered Pinus lambertiana (Sugar Pine) at 1100m elevation in Oregon, has fruited in June and September^, (Castellano), under conifers (Smith(4)), mycorrhizal host in Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-9 x 3-4.5(5) microns, elongate, drop-shaped to subelliptic or at times somewhat irregular, wall slightly thickened, spores in outer locules amyloid, those in interior inamyloid^, (Castellano), spores 6-9 x 3-4.5(5) microns, spores from interior chamber inamyloid, spores from chambers near the peridium strongly amyloid, "hyphae of subhymenium with candelabra-type branching", "hyphae of peridium 5-12 microns wide", (Smith(4)), spores variable, 6-9 x 3-4.5(5) microns, "elongate-drop-shaped to subelliptic or at times somewhat irregular", when fresh the spores in the outer cavities (near peridium) violet black in Melzer's reagent but those in the interior dingy ochraceous to colorless, in revived material the same is true except the spores in the outer cavities are dark violet and those in interior cinnamon buff in Melzer's reagent (when strongly amyloid, the reaction can include all or part of the spore), spore wall slightly thickened; basidia 4-spored, 6-spored, (not many clearly seen), up to 9 microns wide at top, clavate, length variable; basidioles apparently not becoming thick-walled; subhymenium of subgelatinous hyphae, branching candelabra-like (not filamentose interwoven or cellular), hyphae colorless in KOH or Melzer's reagent, content in places rarely showing amyloid strands; hyphae of tramal plates 4-7 microns wide, gelatinous and interwoven; hyphae of peridium 5-12 microns wide, some near the cavities vinaceous red in KOH when revived, this color at times extending to hyphae of the outer tramal plates, dark dull orange-brown pigment balls or bodies numerous in Melzer's reagent, much debris in layer in both KOH and Melzer's reagent; clamp connections none, (Smith(28))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'like a chamaeleon'
SIMILAR  "R. chamaleontinus appears distinct from R. anomalus in that few pale blue spores are present, and little material was seen in the interior of the tramal-plate hyphae", (Smith(28), Latin names in italics)
SOURCES  Smith(28), Castellano(1), Smith(4), Smith(30), Trappe(13)
181
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon cinerascens  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 148. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to ovate fruitbody with surface white becoming pinkish gray, or becoming slowly brownish from handling, peridium separable in flakes, cut peridium staining red, spore mass olive buff, growth under conifers, rose-red KOH reaction on surface, and microscopic characters including smooth, oblong spores from 4-6-spored basidia and thick peridium with patches of cinnamon pigment in outer layer in KOH and some groups of enlarged cells in inner peridial layer^; found in ID according to Smith(4), infrequent, western OR, northern ID, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH rose-red on surface, FeSO4 no reaction^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across, slowly brownish from handling, white at first, becoming pinkish gray and drying cinereous (in silica gel); dull, bald, dry; peridium readily separable in flakes, cut peridium staining red^, (Smith(4)), 1-2.5cm across, spherical to nearly spherical or ovate; "dull white and slowly brownish when handled but becoming cinereous on drying (in silica gel)"; dull, bald, dry; cut peridium staining red, "peridium readily separable in sheets or flakes"; no obvious rhizomorphs visible, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  consistency rather dry; olive buff when mature^, (Smith(4)), consistency rather dry; white at first, olive-buff when mature; cavities "both large and labyrinthiform and empty to fairly well filled with spores", (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under conifers, summer^, (Smith(4)), in duff under mixed conifers, July, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-6 x 2-2.3 microns, dull brownish in groups in KOH^, "peridium thick, epicuticular zone in KOH with patches of cinnamon pigment", lower zone nearly colorless "and with some groups of enlarged cells (the layer rather clean)", (Smith(4)), spores 5-6 x 2-2.3 microns, oblong, smooth, not truncate, yellowish to yellowish brown in groups in Melzer's reagent, colorless singly and dull brownish along the hymenium in KOH; basidia 4-6-spored, 12-15 x 4-8 microns, neck cylindric; paraphyses 10-15 x 4-8 microns, "ellipsoid to clavate, mostly thin-walled (some with thickened walls)", central area not colored with Melzer's reagent; subhymenium cellular but cells small and about 2 deep; tramal plates of hyphae 2-4 microns wide, colorless, smooth, and gelatinous; peridium "thick, as revived in KOH the epicuticular zone containing amorphous bodies or patches of pigment dull cinnamon in KOH", beneath this the hyphae colorless and some patches of inflated cells present (the layer clean); all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'becoming ashy'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon evadens is brown rather than gray when dried, stains readily on the surface when the fresh fruitbody is injured, and has slightly larger spores, (Smith(30)). See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon evadens var. evadens.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)

FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon cinnamomeus  K.A. Harrison & A.H. Sm.^  Can. J. Bot. 46: 886. 1968
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to nearly spherical fruitbody with surface cinnamon becoming dark brown then blackish, spore mass that is dark brown, growth under conifers, chemical characters including cut peridium staining red with KOH, and microscopic characters including elliptic to narrowly ovoid spores from 4-spored and 6-spored basidia and peridium of appressed interwoven hyphae that is reddish in KOH^; described from BC
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  cut peridium when fresh staining red with KOH, soon dark olive-fuscous with FeSO4^, (Smith(4)), KOH staining cut peridium red, FeSO4 slowly becoming dark olive-fuscous, (Harrison)
OUTER SURFACE  1-2cm across, cinnamon when fresh, soon darker brown where touched and finally blackish^, (Smith(4)), 1-2cm across, spherical to nearly spherical; "cinnamon when fresh and uninjured, soon turning dark brown to finally blackish", when dried dark brown tinged garnet-reddish in places; "with a basal rhizomorph in some and a few superficial to ingrown rhizomorphs over surface"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  dark brown and tough but sectioning easily when dried^, (Smith), tough, cavities large for genus, sectioning easily (not bone hard); very dark brown, when dried olivaceous, (Harrison)
STEM  with a basal rhizomorph in some; columella absent^, (Harrison)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered under mixed conifers, July^, (Harrison)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x 3-4 microns, yellowish singly in KOH^; subhymenial hyphae filamentous, peridium of appressed interwoven hyphae (3)4-10(14) microns wide, the layer reddish in KOH, (Smith), spores 7-9 x 3-4 microns, elliptic to narrowly ovoid, smooth, "base obscurely truncate in some (not at all so in most)", in Melzer's reagent ochraceous-cinnamon, in KOH yellowish singly but cinnamon in masses, wall up to 0.25 microns thick; basidia 4-spored and 6-spored, 7-10 microns wide, clavate, sterigmata 1-1.5 microns long; cystidia 12-18 microns in widest part, clavate, colorless, thin-walled, "empty"; brachybasidioles oval to elliptic "with a refractive central body which merely stains yellowish in KOH, usually in the form of a terminal cell of a 2- to 3-celled filament with all the cells having the same features as the end cell"; subhymenium "of filamentous highly refractive hyphae as branches from tramal plate hyphae"; tramal plates with hyphae 2-4 microns wide, that are refractive-gelatinous, smooth, and colorless in KOH; peridium of hyphae (3)4-10(14) microns wide, appressed-interwoven, "some cells inflated, walls thin but often with adhering debris, the layer (including the debris) reddish to reddish cinnamon in KOH"; clamp connections none, (Harrison)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'cinnamon-colored'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Harrison(2), Smith(4)
183
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon clavitisporus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 52. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to nearly spherical fruitbody that has a pallid to vinaceous buff surface with a thin coating of cinnamon-brown fibrils, spore mass white to olive gray to dull olivaceous, growth under conifers especially Ponderosa Pine, chemical characters including both olive and vinaceous stains on surface with KOH, and microscopic characters including smooth, clavate to cylindric or angular spores and peridial epicutis of dark brown hyphae (in KOH) with flagellate hyphal cells present^; found OR, ID, (Smith(30)), infrequent, western OR to ID, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on dried surface turns it both olive (interior of peridium next to gleba) and vinaceous (outer epicuticular region), FeSO4 on dried surface olive-black^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across, "covered with a thin coating of cinnamon-brown fibrils and these easily pulling away from the subcutis which dries dingy vinaceous-fuscous"^, (Smith(4)), 1-2.5cm thick, spherical to nearly spherical; "covered by a thin cinnamon-brown fibrillose epicutis which easily pulls apart or wears away to expose the pallid to vinaceous-buff ground color, when dried the ground color distinctly vinaceous where not covered by the cinnamon-brown epicutis"; dry, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  consistency when dried firm but sectioning easily; "white to olive gray to dull olivaceous, grayish buff as dried"; chambers small^, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under conifers, mostly Pinus ponderosus (Ponderosa Pine)^, (Smith(4)), in duff under conifers, July in Idaho and November in Oregon, (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal host in Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 11-18 x 5-9 microns^, "epicutis of peridium of dark brown hyphae (in KOH) and flagellate hyphal cells present", (Smith(4)), spores "basically clavate to cylindric but many obscurely to distinctly angular, 18 X 5 microns; 12-16 X 6-9 microns or angular-ovate and 11-15 X 6-8 microns", smooth, pale ochraceous in Melzer's reagent, colorless to ochraceous singly in KOH, darker ochraceous in groups in KOH, wall thin to slightly thickened, "some medial wall thickenings present but few showing any false septum", basal scar distinct; basidia (2 seen) 36-40 x 7-9 microns, 3 microns at base, clavate, colorless; paraphyses 7-11 microns wide, thick-walled, the central amorphous body not colored in Melzer's reagent, "often 2-3 cells in a chain all thick-walled"; subhymenium cellular; tramal plates of narrow colorless refractive-gelatinous hyphae; peridium with an epicutis of loosely woven dark brown hyphae with flagellate cells in the layer, "the context of dull rusty brown hyphae and pigment deposits and next to the gleba often strongly blue-green (all in KOH)"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  refers to clavate shape of spores
SIMILAR  readily distinguished from Rhizopogon variabilisporus and Rhizopogon griseogleba by paraphyses, (Smith(30)); R. subclavitisporus has red to garnet brown reaction to KOH, has less well developed epicutis, and the series of colors presented by the gleba is different, (Smith(30)); Rhizopogon ventricosporus lacks differentiated epicutis of brown-walled hyphae, (Smith(30)); Rhizopogon semitectus has smaller spores, the subhymenium is a palisade, and it lacks flagellate cells in the epicuticular layer, (Smith(28))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Smith(28), Trappe(13)
184
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon colossus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 85. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to irregular fruitbody with a dry, fibrillose surface that is pallid, darkening to wood brown or dull cinnamon brown, 2) a spore mass that is pallid then olivaceous, 3) clustered-gregarious growth under Pinus contorta, 4) smooth, narrow spores from 6-spored and 8-spored basidia, and 5) a poorly developed epicuticular layer of the peridium with thick-walled hyphae, knee-joint-like cells, and spherical cells. Its status as an independent species is disputed.^ Molecular evidence has been presented to support the contention that R. colossus var. colossus (or at least two paratypes that were studied) is a synonym (along with R. parksii holotype and R. hawkerae paratype) of R. villosulus A.H. Sm. (Martin, M.P.(2)); on the other hand, other molecular evidence suggests that R. colossus (holotype), R. villosulus (a different collection), R. hawkerae (same paratype), and R. villescens (non-type) are close and could be a single species that shows variation, whereas two non-type collections of R. parksii were more distant, (Grubisha(2)). The description is for var. colossus: in var. nigromaculatus fresh fruiting bodies turn black when handled, although the dried fruitbodies are indistinguishable. Rhizopogon colossus is not included in the Trappe(13) list of (true and false) truffles of the Pacific Northwest. RANGE Collections were examined from WA, OR, ID, CA, for var. colossus, and WA for var. nigromaculatus, (Smith(30)). Var. nigromaculatus was found in NM(Harrison(2)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1.5-9cm across, "pallid and gradually darkening to wood brown to dull cinnamon-brown, no color change on handling (possibly slightly more brownish)", wood brown when dried; fibrillose^, (Smith(4)), 1.5-6(9)cm across, spherical to compressed or irregular from external pressure; "pallid when young (not truly white) gradually darkening to dark wood-brown to dull cinnamon-brown when properly dried (otherwise tending to blacken)", no color change on handling - or merely more brownish; dry, fibrillose, some rhizomorphs present, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "pallid then olivaceous to dark olive, drying ochraceous"^, (Smith(4)), pallid becoming olivaceous to dark olive but drying dingy ochraceous to Isabella-tan, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  none or when old disagreeable^ (Smith(30))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  cespitose-gregarious [clustered-gregarious] under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine)^, (Smith(4)), type cespitose-gregarious in an old corral under Pinus contorta, (Smith(30)), confirmed ectomycorrhizal association with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Molina & Trappe (1994) as mentioned in Martin, M.P.(2))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-7.5 x 2.2-2.7(3) microns^, "epicutis poorly developed, of brown hyphae and hyphal segments (in KOH)", knee-joint-like cells and spherical cells up to 40 microns wide present, flagellate hyphal ends rare, epicuticular hyphae mostly thick-walled, (Smith(4)), spores 6-7.5 x 2.2-2.7(3) microns, oblong to elliptic, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish singly and more so in groups, in KOH colorless to yellowish singly and more ochraceous in masses along the hymenium, "thin-walled, mostly lacking a false septum and sterigmal scar not conspicuous"; basidia 6-spored and 8-spored, 16-25 x 7-9 microns, clavate or nearly so, colorless in KOH, thin-walled; paraphyses 15-30 x 7-12 microns, nearly spherical to elliptic, colorless, thin-walled; subhymenium ramose [branched], "subgelatinous, cellular only at base of hymenial elements"; tramal plates of "refractive-gelatinous hyphae subparallel to interwoven, smooth and thin-walled"; peridium 2-layered, "the outer layer poorly developed and consisting of a thin coating of smooth thick-walled more or less cinnamon brown-walled cells and hyphal segments", the cells versiform: elongate, knee-joint-like, ovate, angular, or spherical to subspherical and up to 40 microns wide, "walls thin or up to 2 microns thick, flagellate hyphae rare, in some mounts nearly all the hyphae cylindric", the inner layer (context) composed of colorless hyphae "either coated with brown incrusting pigment or this material in pockets or both, the amorphous pigment and debris usually green to olive in KOH and this color often most noticeable near the outermost locules, the context-layer brown in KOH or pink showing faintly, enlarged cells scattered in context as well as in epicutis", large colorless oleiferous hyphae usually readily demonstrated, in Melzer's reagent "the context layer showing numerous brown to orange-brown globules, amyloid particles or granules scattered along some hyphae"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none, (Smith(30)), in a specimen judged to be Rhizopogon colossus var. nigromaculatus, there was a copious amount of dark violet debris along some of the hyphae just below the epicutis, which showed in water as well as in Melzer's reagent (but not in KOH), suggesting that the designation of such particles and granules in Smith(30) as amyloid is incorrect, (Harrison(2))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'a large statue' from 'kolossos' (Greek) 
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon hawkerae stains red quickly from handling, shows this color in sections revived in KOH, and has a better developed epicutis of the peridium, (Smith(30)). Rhizopogon ponderosus is similar but has spores 9-12 x 3.5-4.5 microns, (Smith(30)). See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon separabilis.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Harrison(2), Martin, M.P.(2), Grubisha(2), Trappe(13)
185
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon columbianus  K.A. Harrison & A.H. Sm.^  Can. J. Bot. 46: 887. 1968
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include nearly spherical fruitbody with surface pallid becoming dingy brown without any red staining when handled, spore mass that is dark vinaceous-brown when fresh, growth under conifers, chemical characters, and microscopic characters including smooth, truncate spores, and peridium of appressed hyphae^; found in BC (Smith(4))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  slightly vinaceous on surface with KOH, with FeSO4 no reaction on surface^, (Harrison)
OUTER SURFACE  "about 2cm, pallid becoming dingy brown, then with a slight cinnamon tint"^, (Smith), up to about 2cm by 1.4cm, nearly spherical, slightly compressed; pallid when young but soon with dingy streaks over surface and gradually dingy brown with slight vinaceous tint, not changing color markedly on handling; "dry and unpolished, lacking conspicuous rhizomorphs", (Harrison)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  when fresh dark vinaceous-brown, when dried hard and olive-brown^, (Smith), firm, hard, hard when dried; when mature deep vinaceous brown, when dried more olivaceous brown, (Harrison)
STEM  columella absent^ (Harrison)
ODOR  not distinctive^ (Harrison)
TASTE  not distinctive^ (Harrison)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  collection under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), summer^, (Smith), under Larix (larch), Pseudotsuga menziesii, and Pinus ponderosa, July, (Harrison)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.5-8 x 3-3.8 microns, truncate, pale cinnamon in KOH^; "peridium of appressed hyphae 4-9 microns wide, cells short to long but none greatly inflated", "epicutis merely of appressed hyphae", (Smith), spores 6.5-8 x 3-3.8 microns, oval to elliptic (truncate at base), smooth, in Melzer's reagent and in KOH groups are pale tawny to cinnamon (not dextrinoid), wall thin (to 0.25 microns); basidia "becoming thick-walled as do the basidioles"; subhymenium "cellular, the cells also finally with thickened walls"; tramal plates of narrow, interwoven, refractive-gelatinous hyphae; peridium of hyphae 4-9 microns wide, appressed, short to long but none greatly inflated, some brownish debris in the layer and some hyphae with incrustations but not with distinct color revived in KOH, epicutis "merely of appressed hyphae, not distinct as a layer", in Melzer's reagent no pigment globules present and no distinct color reaction; clamp connections none but pseudoclamps rarely present, (Harrison)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'from Columbia', likely referring to British Columbia
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Harrison(2), Smith(4)
186
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon cusickiensis  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N. Y. bot. Gdn 14(2): 137. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  important features are yellow ocher colors and narrow elongated hymenial elements (Smith(30)), other features include small size, pink staining of surface when bruised, scanty basal rhizomorphs, white spore mass that becomes honey color, small maze-like chambers in spore mass, and absent columella^; type found in WA
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  outer surface slightly reddish with KOH and olivaceous with FeSO4
OUTER SURFACE  1.5-2cm across, spherical to versiform [various shapes] and angular from external pressure, "ocher yellow" (Ridgway(1) color) when fresh, "staining pink slowly when bruised"; "when dried dull ochraceous to yellow-brown"; "rhizomorphs few and mostly basal"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "rather hard when dried", chambers small, labyrinthiform [maze-like]; "white becoming more honey color than olive"
STEM  columella absent
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), July 2
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9(10) x 2.2-2.8(3) microns, "narrowly elliptic or tapered slightly at both extremities, at maturity some with a slight suprahilar depression on one side causing spores to appear slightly inequilateral in one view", smooth, colorless to yellowish in Melzer's reagent and also in KOH^; basidia 6-spored to 8-spored, 14-17 x 4-5 microns, narrowly clavate; paraphyses 10-16 x 4-6 microns, "narrowly ovate (the end-cell) to narrowly clavate, thin-walled"; subhymenium "of branched filaments about the diameter of the base of the hymenial element" (2-5 microns wide), gelatinizing; hyphae of tramal plates "soon gelatinous, narrow, branched and interwoven, smooth, hyaline in KOH"; peridium "of interwoven hyphae, no epicutis differentiated", the hyphae 3-8(12) microns wide, "some knots of inflated cells present, as revived in KOH the region next to the gleba with rusty cinnamon intercellular and intracellular pigment masses", in Melzer's reagent "these deposits forming orange-brown pigment balls"; all hyphae inamyloid and no amyloid granules notes; clamp connections none
NAME ORIGIN  means 'from Cusick (Washington)' where type was found
SIMILAR  distinguished from Rhizopogon butyraceus, Rhizopogon deceptivus, Rhizopogon udus, and Rhizopogon vulgaris by the hymenial elements, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30)
187
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon cylindrisporus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 129. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a nearly spherical fruitbody which has an ochraceous surface that bruises reddish, 2) a peridium separable in patches, 3) a spore mass that is olivaceous drying olive buff to yellow brown, 4) fairly numerous rhizomorphs, 5) a dark red-brown KOH reaction on the outer surface, 6) cylindric spores from 2-spored and 4-spored basidia, and 7) the outer layer of the rhizomorphs and the context of the peridium magenta in KOH.^ It is rare among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Rhizopogon cylindrisporus is found in ID, (Trappe(13)). The type was found in ID (Smith(30)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on the dried surface a darker red-brown than the dried surface, FeSO4 no reaction on dried surface^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  3-5cm across, "ochraceous over all, rhizomorphs fairly numerous", many rhizomorphs incorporated in peridium, peridium separable in patches^, (Smith(4)), 3-5cm across, nearly spherical and irregular in outline; "ochraceous overall but becoming reddish where bruised and these places drying reddish, the remainder drying very dingy ochraceous"; rhizomorphs fairly numerous; "peridium somewhat separable leaving distinct pallid yellowish spots where it falls off", (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  olivaceous, when dry olive buff to yellow brown^, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type in duff, October^, (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal hosts in the Pacific Northwest trees in Pinaceae (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-13 x 2-2.5 microns, cylindric to slightly allantoid [curved], in Melzer's reagent colorless or nearly so singly and yellowish in groups, in KOH nearly colorless singly and pale ochraceous in groups, "basal scar indistinct, walls smooth and thin, some with a false septum"^; basidia 2-spored and 4-spored, 6-7 microns wide, clavate; paraphyses "clavate to ellipsoid, becoming thick-walled"; subhymenium cellular; tramal plates composed of interwoven, colorless, gelatinous hyphae; peridium with the outer layer of the rhizomorphs and the context of the peridium magenta in KOH; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with cylindric spores'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon ochraceorubens has a similar peridium and peridial KOH reactions but the spores are different, (Smith(30)).
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
188
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon deceptivus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 134. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to angular fruitbody with surface white then cream or yellower, (bruising slowly reddish), finally dingy ochraceous, cottony when young, spore mass pallid olive-buff becoming dark sepia, and cheesy drying bone hard, usual attachment to substrate by a basal rhizomorph, growth under conifers, chemical characters, and microscopic characters including smooth, oval to narrowly elliptic spores^; rare, central ID, (Trappe(13)), collections examined from ID (Smith(30))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 "on fresh peridium dark olive-brown along the inner layer of the cut section, KOH pale dingy vinaceous along the inner layer of the cut peridium"^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  0.8-2cm across, white and then cream color or yellower to ochraceous; cottony, dry-fibrillose^, (Smith(4)), 0.8-2cm across, spherical to nearly spherical, or angular from mutual pressure; white when young, slowly changing to cream or yellower, finally dingy ochraceous, slowly reddish when bruised; cottony when young, the fibrils matted down when old; peridium white in section but soon stained pinkish
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  cheesy when fresh, bone hard when dry; dark sepia^, (Smith(4)), soft and cheesy when old but drying to the consistency of bone; pallid olive-buff becoming dark sepia; chambers minute, 3-4 per mm, (Smith(30))
STEM  columella lacking; usually attached to substrate by a rhizomorph^, (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious in duff under conifers, summer^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-7.5 x 2.6-3 microns^; "epicutis of fresh peridium a weak trichodermium", the hyphae 4-9 microns wide, the layer vinaceous brown when revived in KOH, peridium lacking groups of inflated cells in the interior zone but individual cells may be inflated (for this group in key), "some cells barrel-shaped and about 15 microns broad", (Smith(4)), spores 6-7.5 x 2.6-3 microns, oval to narrowly elliptic, smooth, in Melzer's reagent pale yellow singly and orange-ochraceous in masses of spores along the hymenium (inamyloid at all stages), in KOH yellowish when fresh and along the hymenium when revived, basal scar not distinct; basidia 5-6 microns broad when sporulating, colorless, thin-walled, collapsing; paraphyses 8-11 microns wide, up to 20 microns long, subspherical to ellipsoid, thin-walled when young, many thick-walled ones with a central body but this not staining in Melzer's reagent; subhymenium "cellular and the cells at times with thickened walls as in the paraphyses"; tramal plates when mature gelatinous in KOH, composed of hyphae 3-6 microns wide, colorless, smooth, subparallel to interwoven, with walls slightly thickened; peridial epicutis of hyphae 4-9 microns wide, interwoven to suberect (suggesting weak trichodermial arrangement), as revived in KOH the entire layer vinaceous brown "from copious pigment masses readily separated from the hyphae under pressure", some of the cells barrel-shaped and about 15 microns in diameter (enlarged), no evidence of trichodermial structure visible on revived material; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'deceptive'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon luteolus is close but its peridium does not stain red on injury and spores are larger, (Smith(30)). See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon cusickiensis.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
189
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon defectus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N. Y. bot. Gdn 14(2): 131. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include dingy ochraceous fruitbody that is soon red when bruised, rubbery olive-pallid spore mass with small chambers, staining yellow around worm holes, short unbranched columella that stains red, rhizomorphs only in a basal patch, and microscopic characters^; found at least in ID (Smith(30))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH no reaction and FeSO4 faintly olivaceous slowly [probably on surface of fruiting body]
OUTER SURFACE  up to 3.6cm across, spherical to irregular; "dingy ochraceous, soon red when bruised, finally brownish, when dried dingy ochraceous with vinaceous areas"; bald and "free of rhizomorphs except for a basal patch somewhat rooting in the soil"
INNER LAYER  peridium 0.05cm thick when fresh, "pallid when cut but soon reddish"
INTERIOR  rubbery when fresh, firm but easy to section after drying (almost crumbly in places); chambers very small; "olive-pallid and staining yellow around worm holes"
STEM  columella short (0.8cm) and unbranched, staining red when cut and dull vinaceous red when dried, connected to a rhizomorph
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single under conifers
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.5-8 x 2.2-2.7 microns, oblong to narrowly elliptic, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish, as revived in KOH pale yellowish brown in groups, no false septum present^; basidia 4-spored to 6-spored, possibly 8-spored, 10-13 x 4-5 microns, clavate to elongate, colorless in KOH; paraphyses 12-16 x 6-9 microns, thin-walled; tramal plates of subgelatinous, narrow, subparallel to interwoven, colorless hyphae and occasionally a hypha about 15 microns wide also present - apparently laticiferous - "branching to the inconspicuous but cellular subhymenium about 2 cells deep"; peridium of hyphae 4-9(15) microns wide, appressed-interwoven, clean, (fresh in KOH), scattered large (+/- 15 microns wide) oleiferous hyphae present, lacking distinct groups of inflated (sphaerocyst-like) cells but many hyphae with slightly inflated cells, "as revived in KOH the epicuticular layer ochraceous and hyphae with some debris between them, inner layer dark red to red-brown revived in KOH and color caused by large pockets and amorphous masses of pigment both intracellular and intercellular"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  "This species differs from R. vulgaris in becoming vinaceous pink in some areas as dried, in the presence in some basidiocarps at least, of a columella, lack of a KOH color change of fresh peridium and only a very weak to lacking FeSO4 reaction." (Smith(30), Latin name in italics and 4 as subscript)
SOURCES  Smith(30)
190
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon ellenae  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 43. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to irregular fruitbody with a surface that is white and smooth to minutely hairy, developing brownish or pinky-gray or blackish areas when old, and staining grayish to reddish when handled, 2) conspicuous rhizomorphs, 3) a spore mass that is whitish then dark olive-brown, 4) growth under conifers especially pine, 5) chemical characters including a muddy brown KOH reaction on the surface, and 6) microscopic characters including subfusoid, weakly but evenly amyloid spores from 6-spored and 8-spored basidia. The combination of a reddish reaction when handled and (weakly) amyloid spores is distinctive when present.^ The chlorophyll-lacking plant Sarcodes sanguinea (snow plant) forms mycorrhizae specifically with Rhizopogon ellenae, which is ectomycorrhizal on the roots of neighboring trees, (Trappe(13)). It is abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest. RANGE Collections were examined from WA, OR, ID, and UT, (Smith(30)). It is found from western WA to northern CA and ID (Trappe(13)). It is also found in CA (Arora).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH stains surface muddy vinaceous brown, FeSO4 stains surface olive^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-6cm across, white, "when handled slowly becoming avellaneous to fuscous"^, (Smith(4)), 1-9cm across, ovoid, elongate or roundish and sometimes flattened; white, then developing pinky-gray or purplish smoky-gray tones when old or with handling; "smooth or minutely hairy with a few strands of mycelium", (Phillips), 1-6cm across, spherical to flattened or somewhat irregular in outline; white when young and to late maturity, "when handled slowly staining avellaneous to vinaceous fuscous, when dried the surface near fuscous"; "dry, appressed-fibrillose and this overlaid by conspicuous white rhizomorphs arising from basal area and extending up the sides", (Smith(30)), 1-9cm across, white when young, but developing dingy pinkish gray to purplish lilac to fuscous (dark purple-gray or smoky) tones when old or after handling, (Arora), peridium thin, white when young, "becoming light brown from a surface layer of brown fibrils and staining vinaceous to light yellowish brown where bruised; usually with abundant rhizomorphs appressed over the surface", (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white to pallid then dark bister [dark dingy yellow-brown], drying olive-brown^, (Smith(4)), white when young; minutely chambered, (Phillips), chambers small at first, when old large in large specimens; "pallid becoming dark bister and when dried buffy-brown (dark olive-brown)", (Smith(30)), firm and white when young, becoming gray to olive-gray when old, (Arora), white when young, soon yellowish brown to dark brown, (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  no columella^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  none^ (Smith(30))
TASTE  mild^ (Trappe, M.(3))
EDIBILITY  unknown (Phillips)
HABITAT  under mixed conifers^, (Smith(4)), scattered or in groups or clusters in soil or needle duff under conifers, particularly pine, September to November, (Phillips), scattered in duff under conifers, late summer and fall, (Smith(30)), often breaking through the ground, (Arora), with Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Abies (fir), and Arbutus (madrone), year-round, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x 3-4 microns, walls distinctly but weakly amyloid at maturity^, "subhymenium of inflated cells broader than the basidioles; hyphae of peridium 4-8 microns wide, local groups of short cells up to 14 microns wide also present", (Smith(4)), spores 7-9 x 3-4 microns, elliptic to oblong, smooth, weakly amyloid, (Phillips), spores 7-9 x 3-3.8 microns, subfusoid, smooth, in Melzer's reagent weakly but distinctly greenish blue, in KOH near cinnamon buff in groups, wall slightly thickened, no obvious basal scar; basidia 6-spored, 8-spored, 15-20 x 5-7 microns, subcylindric and readily collapsing; paraphyses present only as basidioles, thin-walled, colorless, readily collapsing; cystidia none; "subhymenium of inflated cells broader than the basidioles (2 often arising from a single basal cell)"; tramal plates hyphae 3-5 microns wide, distinctly interwoven, nongelatinous, colorless, with enlargements up to 8-12 microns at times but not forming sphaerocysts, colorless in Melzer's reagent; peridium consisting of a single layer, composed of hyphae 4-8 microns wide, appressed interwoven, with more or less vinaceous brown walls as revived in KOH, "some debris adhering to walls and dark brown pigment masses numerous", in Melzer's reagent these masses becoming dull orange-brown and subglobular, "local areas of short hyphal cells up to 14 microns across present, but these not true sphaerocysts", large crooked laticiferous hyphae also present, yellow in Melzer's reagent; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30)), spores 6-9 x 2.5-4 microns, (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  in honor of Ellen Trueblood of Nampa, Idaho, who found the type
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon kauffmanii has more variable spores and lacks the greatly enlarged cells of the tramal plates, (Smith(30)). Rhizopogon idahoensis is described as having spores 2.3-3 microns wide by A.H. Smith, but some regard R. idahoensis as a synonym and its spore width falls within the range given by Trappe, M.(3). Rhizopogon rubescens also has a white surface but it becomes yellowish (and takes on a reddish-brown color when bruised). Rhizopogon ochraceorubens, Rhizopogon occidentalis, Rhizopogon evadens, and Rhizopogon vulgaris may turn a shade of reddish when handled or become a shade of reddish, but all have narrower spores. See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon fallax, Rhizopogon pedicellus, and Rhizopogon vinicolor.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Phillips(1)*, Arora(1)*, Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)
191
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon ellipsosporus  Trappe, Castellano, & Amar.^  Mycotaxon 75: 173. 2000
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Rhizopogon ellipsosporus is characterized within Rhizopogon by its short broad spores. Features include a nearly spherical fruitbody that is brown with scattered appressed rhizomorphs of the same color, a spore mass that is solid, rubbery, and pale yellow-brown, absent columella, underground growth in association with roots of Douglas-fir, and microscopic characters (including smooth, elliptic to obovoid or occasionally angular spores, and a peridium of appressed-interwoven hyphae with abundant extracellular amorphous yellow-brown pigment in KOH).^ It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Rhizopogon ellipsosporus is found in western OR, (Trappe(13)). It is endemic to OR according to Castellano(1).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  up to 2.4cm long and 1.5cm wide, nearly spherical; brown with scattered appressed rhizomorphs colored as surface^, (Castellano)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  solid, rubbery, with rounded locules 0.01-0.04cm wide, pale yellow brown, the color a combination of the white to brown trama and the pale brown-yellow spore masses filling the locules^, (Trappe(2))
STEM  columella absent^ (Castellano)
ODOR  not recorded^ (Trappe(2))
TASTE  not recorded^ (Trappe(2))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  associated with roots of Pseudotsuga menziesii, (Douglas-fir) and scattered Pinus lambertiana (Sugar Pine) at 850m elevation^, (Castellano)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (4)4.5-6 x 3-4 microns, elliptic to obovoid or occasionally irregular, smooth, inamyloid^, cyanophilic, thin-walled, sterigmal attachment +/- 1 microns broad, in KOH colorless singly and brown-yellow in mass, with a single large droplet; basidia 12-24 x 4-10 microns, clavate, thin-walled, with interspersed brachybasidioles; subhymenium filamentous; peridium 120-160 microns thick, of appressed-interwoven, colorless to pale yellow, thin-walled hyphae 3-4 microns wide, many cells inflated to 4-6 microns, with abundant extracellular deposits of amorphous yellow-brown pigment in KOH which is orange-brown in Melzer's; clamp connections absent, (Trappe(2))
NAME ORIGIN  refers to "ellipsoid" shape of spores, in reference to the relatively broad spores compared to other Rhizopogon species
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon oregonensis A.H. Smith differs in having peridial hyphae 4-10(15) microns in diameter and a subhymenium of isodiametric cells, (Trappe(2)). Rhizopogon exiguus Zeller has more broadly truncate spores that average 7-8 x 5-5.5 microns, (Trappe(2)).
SOURCES  Castellano(1), Trappe(2), Trappe(13)
192
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon evadens  A.H. Sm.  var. evadens^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 151. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a more or less spherical, often lobed fruitbody with a surface that is snow white soon discoloring to whitish to grayish vinaceous or pinkish buff or olive buff, bruising reddish vinaceous, 2) a spore mass with small chambers that is white becoming olive buff to dark olive, 3) a metallic-disagreeable odor when old, 4) growth under 2-needle and 3-needle pines and Douglas-fir, 5) a FeSO4 reaction on surface that is distinctly olive, KOH quickly pinkish to red, 6) narrowly oblong spores, and 7) a peridium with a poorly differentiated epicutis intergrading into a subcutis of broader hyphae, both layers or only the epicutis with ochraceous to ochraceous tawny pigment encrusted on the hyphal walls. "This is a distinctive species in that the peridium gives a red reaction in KOH but the sections revived in KOH show none of the vinaceous tints or vinaceous to vinaceous-brown debris in the layer which usually accompanies this character in other species" (Smith(30)).^ Var. evadens is abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Rhizopogon evadens var. evadens is found in WA, OR, northern CA, ID, and eastern North America, (Trappe(13)). Var. evadens collections were examined from ID, OR, NS, (Smith(30)). Var. evadens collections were examined from OR, ID, MS, NC, OH, TN, and VA, (Miller). R. evadens is common in ID and reported from BC, WY, NM, and NS, (Smith(4), perhaps including both varieties).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 on surface slowly distinctly olive (on dried specimens slowly dark olive), KOH quickly pinkish to red^, (Smith(30)), FeSO4 on peridium slowly olive, negative on spore mass; KOH on peridium reddish brown, on young spore mass often pinkish white, (Miller)
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, "often plicate-folded, appressed silky, snow white soon discolored to grayish vinaceous to pinkish buff or olive buff", reddens with bruising^, (Smith(4)), 1-2.5(3)cm across, spherical to nearly spherical, often pleated-folded or wrinkled; "snow white when young and fresh but soon merely whitish to grayish vinaceous to pinkish-buff and remaining so to old age when it is more or less olive-buff"; unpolished becoming bald and appressed-silky (under a lens); "peridium somewhat separable, very few rhizomorphs present, flushed reddish from handling", the surface is also said to be "vinaceous in places where injured", (Smith(30)), 1-5cm across, nearly spherical to elongate-flattened, often irregularly lobed and folded; white to yellowish white when young or unexposed, often pale yellow to yellowish brown in patches, finally grayish orange, the white surface bruising grayish magenta, older or exposed surface discoloring to grayish red or reddish brown where handled, (when dried pale orange to light orange in lower part and in depressions, brown to dark brown elsewhere); "dry, smooth, subtomentose at first", then appressed-felty, often scurfy, when old silky; peridium easily separable from spore mass, in cross-section 0.05-0.1cm thick, "thickest near base, white, immediately flushing greyish red"; rhizomorphs abundant, appressed, coalescing into a single large rhizomorphic attachment in lower part, tapering to fine, scant fibrils in upper part, colored as surface of fruitbody at first then brown where handled, when dried dark brown and inconspicuous, (Miller)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white when young, olive buff to dark olive when mature^, (Smith(4)), "white becoming olive-buff to darker olivaceous; chambers small", (Smith(30)), soft, cake-like when young, then tough, cartilaginous when old, when dried hard in consistency but easy to section; white when young, then grayish yellow, "maturing centripetally with pale coloration proximal to the peridium", young or mature spore mass often bruising pale red to dull red, when dried spore mass pale yellow to light yellow; loculate [chambered], 4-5 per mm when young up to 2-3 per mm when mature, (Miller)
STEM  rhizomorphs abundant, appressed, coalescing into a single large rhizomorphic attachment in lower part, (Miller), very few rhizomorphs present (Smith(30))
ODOR  when old often acid to somewhat metallic-disagreeable, (Smith(30)), not distinctive to acidic disagreeable when old, (Miller)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  mostly under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), summer and fall, (Smith(30)), associated with 2-needle and 3-needle pines, including in the west P. ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), P. contorta (Lodgepole Pine), and P. lambertiana (Sugar Pine), and also Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), this variety fruiting in spring, summer and fall, but mostly from October to December^, (Miller), grows with Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Pinus albicaulis (Whitebark Pine), (Smith(4), probably for both varieties)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-8 x 2-2.3 microns^, "peridium with a poorly differentiated epicutis of appressed hyphae intergrading with a zone of broader, almost cellular, hyphae, at least the epicutis with ochraceous to ochraceous tawny pigment incrustations", (Smith(4)), spores 6-8 x 2-2.3 microns, narrowly oblong, smooth, inamyloid (pale yellowish singly and in groups in Melzer's reagent), in KOH colorless singly but yellowish in groups; basal scar inconspicuous; basidia 4-spored, 6-spored, and 8-spored, 16-22(26) x 5-6 microns, subclavate, colorless, thin-walled, soon collapsing; paraphyses like basidioles or wider, 15-20 x 6-12 microns, colorless, thin-walled; subhymenium "cellular from inflated cells of the lower part of the hymenial elements", tramal plates composed of hyphae 2.5-6 microns wide, interwoven, refractive-gelatinous, and colorless in KOH; peridium basically 1-layered but a poorly differentiated epicutis of appressed hyphae 3-6 microns wide can be made out, this intergrading into a subcutis of hyphae 8-20 microns wide, "and often almost cellular in sections (from viewing cut ends), both layers or only the epicutis with ochraceous to ochraceous tawny pigment encrusted on the walls, or lower layer almost devoid of pigment", the hyphal walls thin but not gelatinous; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30)), spores (5.5)6.0-8.0 x 2.5-3.0(3.5) microns, narrowly oblong to oval, often curved in side view, in Melzer's reagent pale yellow singly, olive yellow in mass, mostly with 2 lipid droplets, in KOH colorless to pale yellow singly, pale yellowish gray in mass, basal scar present but not prominent; basidia borne in a distinct hymenium, 4-spored, 6-spored, or 8-spored, 15-26 x 5-6 microns, narrowly clavate, thin-walled, soon collapsing, brachybasidioles 8-25 x 6-15 microns, nearly spherical, clavate or obovate, thin-walled to moderately thick-walled when young, thick-walled, mucilaginous when old, readily disarticulated in crush mounts; subhymenium poorly developed, composed of hyphae that are colorless, "thin-walled, cubical, elongated or branching cylindrical"; trama composed of hyphae that are 3-8 microns wide, loosely interwoven, colorless, cylindric to slightly swollen, refractive in KOH, thin-walled when young, highly gelatinous when old, oleiferous hyphae common in mediostratum, 4-13 microns wide, "hyaline refractive in KOH, yellow refractive in Melzer's reagent", cylindric or irregularly swollen and contorted, branching; peridium 200-320 microns thick, peridial epicutis composed of hyphae 3-5 microns wide, tightly appressed, parallel, thin-walled, gelatinous, "heavily encrusted with dull yellow to orange yellow amorphous pigment in KOH, bright yellow orange in Melzer's reagent", peridial subcutis "present but not well differentiated from epicutis", of hyphae 5-25 microns wide, cylindric, thin-walled, nongelatinous, "with abundant hyphal strands appearing in cross-section as nests of sphaerocysts", oleiferous hyphae abundant, 5-12 microns wide, "hyaline refractive in KOH, yellow refractive in Melzer's reagent", cylindric or irregularly swollen and contorted, "branching, lightly encrusted with dull yellow pigment or free from encrusting material"; clamp connections absent, (Miller)
NAME ORIGIN  from "evadens", Latin for "escaping", "going out", possibly because fruitbodies of this fungus are frequently erumpent, (Miller)
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon rubescens has an intermediate yellow stage in the color of the surface, and spores are wider, (Smith(30)). R. rubescens has a fresh mature peridium that is pale yellow, bruising red, when old mottled with large areas of brown or dark brown, and spores 7-10.5 x (2.5)3-3.5(4.5) microns, whereas R. evadens var. evadens has a fresh peridium that is white, yellowish brown to grayish orange, bruising instantly magenta, and spores (5.5)6-8 x 2.5-3(3.5), (Miller). Rhizopogon vulgaris has a distinctly yellow surface and typically bruises more slowly, (Miller). Rhizopogon cinerascens is gray rather than brown when dried, does not stain readily on the surface when the fresh fruitbody is injured, and has slightly smaller spores, (Smith(30)). Rhizopogon masoniae differs from Rhizopogon evadens in the former's copious development of rhizomorphs and in the distribution and type of pigment in the peridium, (Smith(30)).
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Miller, S.L.(1) (colors mostly from Kornerup(3)), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)
193
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon evadens  A.H. Sm.  var. subalpinus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 153. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  "The small narrow spores, yellow-brown pigmentation of the peridial layer, the yellow and then red reaction of the fresh peridium when injured, and the inflated cells in the lower region of the peridium are distinctive. The color change separates it at once from R. evadens var. evadens.", (Smith(30), Latin names italicized). Other features include a white initial color of the spherical to irregular fruitbody, a small-chambered spore mass that is white becoming olivaceous, absence of a columella, growth under conifers, a dark red KOH reaction on the surface and olive FeSO4 reaction, and microscopic characters including smooth, narrowly oblong spores.^ Var. subalpinus is common among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Rhizopogon evadens var. subalpinus is found in the OR Cascade Mountains and central ID in the mountains, (Trappe(13)). Three collections were examined from ID (Smith(30)), (note that over 160 collections of var. evadens were examined). It is known from WA, OR, ID, and CA, (Castellano).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on surface dark red, FeSO4 distinctly olive^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, spherical, nearly spherical or irregular; white when fresh, when handled staining ochraceous then reddish, when old near "natal-brown" (specimens that have remained uninjured are merely dingy pallid), when dried merely dark "wood-brown"; when fresh dry, "fibrillose under a lens (but not the soft cottony type)"; peridium somewhat separable, when cut at first pallid but soon reddish; appressed rhizomorphs over surface^, (Smith(30)), 1-3cm across, white when fresh, staining ochraceous then red, when old yellow-brown, (Castellano)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white becoming pale and then darker olivaceous; chambers small^, (Smith(30))
STEM  columella absent^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  none^ (Smith(30))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Pinus albicaulis (Whitebark Pine), (Smith(30)), usually found in association with roots of Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock) or Abies spp. (fir) from 1250m to 2350m elevation, August through October, (Castellano)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.5-7.5 x 2 microns, narrowly oblong, smooth^, in Melzer's reagent yellowish singly and in groups, in KOH colorless individually and in groups, spores thin-walled, basal scar inconspicuous; basidia 6-8-spored, subcylindric, colorless, thin-walled; paraphyses 6-12 microns, nearly spherical to ovoid, all thin-walled and nonrefractive; cystidia none; subhymenium cellular and the lower (inner) cells refractive; tramal plates composed of hyphae that are colorless, smooth, refractive, and gelatinous, as revived in KOH; peridium composed of hyphae that are 4-12 microns wide, appressed-interwoven, many scattered inflated cells present, 'pinkish next to gleba on fresh sections mounted in KOH, when sections of dried material are revived in KOH the layer is evenly about "snuff brown" and amorphous pigment deposits numerous'; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30)), basidioles 6-12 microns wide, nearly spherical to ovoid, thin-walled; many scattered inflated cells present in lower (inner) part of peridium, (Castellano)
NAME ORIGIN  from "evadens", Latin for "escaping", "going out", possibly because fruitbodies of this fungus are frequently erumpent, (Miller, S.L.), "subalpinus" means "subalpine" (on higher mountain slopes just below timberline)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Castellano(1)*, Miller, S.L.(1), Trappe(13)
194
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon exiguus  Zeller^  Mycologia 31: 2. 1939
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a surface that is white with ochraceous mottling becoming brown, 2) rhizomorphs mostly in the lower part, 3) a spore mass that is white then brown, 4) a farinaceous odor, 5) underground growth, 6) smooth, broadly oval, truncate spores that are rich rusty cinnamon in KOH, 7) long 4-spored basidia, and 8) a bright rusty cinnamon peridium in KOH.^ It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Rhizopogon exiguus is found in western WA and OR (Trappe(13)). It is endemic to WA and OR (Castellano).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.2-1cm across, "white with ochraceous mottling, becoming pale date brown"^, (Smith), 0.2-1cm across, round to nearly round, lobed in large specimens; white with ochraceous mottling, becoming brown; fibrils scanty in upper part, rhizomorphic in lower part, (Castellano), 0.2-1cm across, spherical or nearly so, lobed in large specimens, consistency soft and spongy; white with ochraceous mottling, becoming snuff-brown; smooth, fibrils scanty in upper part, rhizomorphic in lower part, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white then brown; loculate [chambered]^, (Castellano), cavities small, rounded, partly filled with spores; white then brown, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  farinaceous^ (Smith(30), Castellano)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in heavy duff under hemlock, (Smith(30)), found in association with roots of Pseudotsuga menziesii and Tsuga heterophylla at 950m elevation, (Castellano)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-8 microns long^; "basidia with 4 prominent sterigmata often with pale cinnamon walls in KOH"; "peridium a single layer of compactly interwoven hyphae bright rusty cinnamon in KOH", (Smith(4)), spores 7-8 x 5-5.5 microns, oval to elliptic, base truncate from broad basal scar, inamyloid, smooth, wall slightly thickened, yellow singly, red-brown in mass; basidia 20-40 x 6-7.5 microns, narrowly clavate, walls may be thickened slightly as well as colored pale cinnamon in KOH; basidioles 14-20 x 7-10 microns, colorless, thin-walled, nongelatinous; clamp connections absent, (Castellano), spores 7-8 x 5-5.5 microns, oval to elliptic and base truncate from broad basal scar, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish to rusty yellowish, when revived in KOH yellowish singly and rusty cinnamon in mass, wall slightly thickened; basidia 4-spored, 20-40 x 6-7.5 microns, "narrowly clavate, walls often slightly thickened and refractive", "sterigmata distinct and walls may be thickened slightly as well as colored pale cinnamon (revived in KOH)"; paraphyses 14-20 x 7-10 microns, colorless, thin-walled, nongelatinous; cystidia not seen; tramal plates of colorless refractive hyphae, "not obviously gelatinous, subparallel to interwoven"; subhymenium of branched filaments; peridium "a single layer of compactly interwoven hyphae in mass bright rusty cinnamon in KOH, at the exterior with loosely interwoven hyphae yellowish in KOH but not forming a distinct epicutis, hyphae thin-walled or walls very slightly thickened"; clamp connections absent; all tissues inamyloid, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'small, short, poor, scanty'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon ellipsosporus.
SOURCES  Castellano(1)*, Smith(30), Smith(4), Zeller(7), Trappe(13)
195
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon fallax  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 39. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to irregular fruitbody with white surface that becomes wood-brown to vinaceous brown, with fibrils and rhizomorphs that eventually stain wood-brown, firm spore mass (with small irregular chambers) that is pallid becoming dull olivaceous, surface that stains olive with FeSO4 and vinaceous-fuscous to black with KOH, and microscopic characters including weakly amyloid, smooth, elliptic to oblong or oval spores from 4-6-8-spored basidia, and conspicuous enlarged hyphal cells in the peridium^; description derived from Smith(30); infrequent in the Pacific Northwest, found in ID, WY, (Trappe(13)), specimens examined from ID and WY
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  fresh surface stains vinaceous to inky-black with KOH, fresh surface stains olive to dark olive with FeSO4
OUTER SURFACE  1-6.5cm thick, spherical, nearly spherical, or irregular in outline; white, gradually becoming wood-brown to darker vinaceous brown overall and drying fuscous-brown; "more or less covered with fine fibrils and over these occur rhizomorphs both of which eventually stain wood-brown"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  very firm, chambers small and of irregular shape; pallid becoming dull olivaceous
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Pinus contorta, August and September
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-7.5 x 2.6-3 (8-10 x 3-3.5 microns) in same fruitbody, in some 7-10 x 2-2.5 microns, elliptic to narrowly oblong, varying to oval, smooth, weakly but distinctly amyloid (greenish blue) at times a few in a mount dark violet in Melzer's reagent, yellowish in KOH individually, in masses in KOH cinnamon-buff, wall finally becoming slightly thickened, basal scar inconspicuous^; basidia 4-spored, 6-spored, 8-spored, readily collapsing; paraphyses septate with terminal cells 15-20 x 7-9 microns, ovate to subclavate, colorless in KOH, thin-walled; cystidia none; tramal plates of hyphae 2-8 microns wide, colorless, highly refractive, and interwoven; subhymenium cellular and not gelatinous; peridium about 1000 microns thick fresh, "pallid in section but in KOH the outer region soon olivaceous and the inner one pinkish", the inner region containing enlarged cells up to 20 microns across or these also present to a lesser degree in outer layer, when revived in KOH the outer layer brown and pigment deposits numerous, the inner layer vinaceous brown, in Melzer's reagent with numerous orange-brown globules; clamp connections none; all tissues inamyloid
NAME ORIGIN  means 'false'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon ellenae has spores more consistently subfusoid, and the hyphae of its tramal plates frequently have greatly enlarged hyphal cells (a feature rare in Rhizopogon), (Smith). See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon atroviolaceus.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Trappe(13)
196
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon flavofibrillosus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 118. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Rhizopogon flavofibrillosus is characterized by 1) the yellow peridium that stains dull purple-red in KOH and 2) smooth spores that are narrowly elliptic to nearly oblong. Other features include 3) a spherical to irregular fruitbody, pallid when young but soon overlaid with pale brown-yellow fibrils and rhizomorphs, at maturity becoming green-yellow in some areas and rose tinged in others, 4) a chambered spore mass that is whitish becoming pale olivaceous, 5) attachment by a basal cluster of rhizomorphs, 6) absent columella, 7) growth in association with the roots of conifers from 950 to 2350 m elevation, 8) a pale olivaceous surface reaction to FeSO4, 9) mostly 6-spored basidia, and 10) fresh peridial epicutis as a trichodermium of short branched hyphae with subclavate end cells 26-40 x 5-9 microns, and subcutis of interwoven hyphae reddish as revived in KOH.^ It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It is found from southwestern OR to northern CA, ID and MT, (Trappe(13)). The type collection is from ID.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 staining fruitbody pale olivaceous slowly, "KOH on fresh peridium dull purplish red"^, (Smith(4)), KOH on fresh peridium dull purple-red, FSW slowly pale olivaceous, (Castellano)
OUTER SURFACE  3-5.5cm across, "pallid with straw-yellow fibrils at first, at maturity greenish yellow with rose colored areas"^, (Smith(4)), 3-5.5cm across, spherical to depressed-subspherical or irregular; "pallid when very young but soon overlaid with pale brown-yellow fibrils and rhizomorphs, at maturity variously colored, green-yellow over some areas and rose tinted over others but remaining pallid in the most protected places", virgate [radially streaked] from appressed fibrils, (Castellano), 3-5.5cm across, spherical to depressed-subspherical or irregular, the largest one 5.5cm wide and 2.2cm deep; 'pallid when young but soon overlaid with "straw-yellow" fibrils and rhizomorphs, at maturity variously colored, greenish yellow over some areas and rose tinted over others but remaining pallid in most protected places', when dried the fruitbodies dingy Isabella-color [dingy pale yellow brown]; virgate from appressed fibrils; dry, uneven, (Smith(30), color in double quotation marks from Ridgway)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  whitish becoming pale olivaceous; chambers becoming large when fruitbody old (up to 0.05cm)^, (Smith(30))
STEM  "attached by a basal cluster of rhizomorphs which extend up toward the surface" of the fruitbody; no columella^, (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), July, (Smith(4)), associated with roots of various conifers from 950m to 2350m elevation, July through November, (Castellano)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5.5-6.5(7) x 2.5-2.8 microns, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled, colorless in KOH^; basidia 6-spored, 16-20 x 6-7 microns, colorless, thin-walled, basidioles resembling basidia; clamp connections absent, (Castellano), spores 5.5-6.5(7) x 2.5-2.8 microns, narrowly elliptic to nearly oblong, smooth, very weakly yellowish in Melzer's reagent, colorless in KOH, walls very slightly thickened, spores "with a faint basal truncation from the sterigmal scar"; basidia mostly 6-spored, 16-20 x 6-7 microns, colorless, thin-walled, collapsing readily, basidioles resembling basidia, thin-walled; cystidia none; subhymenium narrow, usually the basal cell of a hymenial element and the short branch from the tramal hypha; tramal plates composed of hyphae 2-4 microns wide, subparallel to interwoven in arrangement, colorless, refractive, appearing nongelatinous in fresh material; peridium "at first with an epicutis in the form of a trichodermium of short branched hyphae" with end cells 26-40 x 5-9 microns and subcylindric to clavate, colorless and thin-walled, trichodermium apparently soon collapses because not demonstrable on dried material; peridial subcutis "of appressed parallel to interwoven hyphae reddish in KOH from a dissolved pigment, some incrusting pigment present on surface or near it"; "scattered groups of enlarged cells present (indicating cut hyphal ends of groups of hyphae at right angles to the general direction of the remainder of the hyphae)"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30)), "peridium with an epicutis at first a trichodermium of short branched hyphae" with end cells 26-40 x 5-9 microns, subclavate, thin-walled; peridial subcutis "of interwoven hyphae reddish in KOH as revived (from a dissolved pigment), scattered groups (cut ends of rhizomorphs) of larger cells present", hyphae of tramal plates thin-walled (under 0.5 microns thick) as revived in KOH, (Smith(4))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'yellow-fibrillose'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Castellano(1)*, Trappe(13)
197
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon florencianus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 72. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include pallid surface that becomes dingy yellow brown and stains yellow brown with handling, wet appearance when mature, growth in duff in fir-spruce zone, chemical characters including rusty brown reaction with KOH and microscopic characters including smooth oblong spores from 8-spored basidia and hyphae of peridial epicutis often with flagellate hyphal ends^; rare, in ID, (Trappe(13)), found central Idaho (Smith(4))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on fresh surface rusty-brown, FeSO4 olive-black^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-4cm across, "pallid at first, soon dingy yellow-brown", staining bister [dingy yellow-brown] from handling; wet in appearance when mature^, (Smith(4)), 1-4cm across, spherical to nearly spherical or oval; pallid when fresh but soon with an overlay of dingy yellow brown fibrils, staining bister from handling and this color overall when old but on drying becoming nearer cinnamon brown; "wet in appearance when mature (but dug from duff scarcely moist), with some rhizomorphs over basal area", (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "with large chambers (very distinct under 3x lens)", "when dried hard but not bone-like"; "dull ochraceous brown becoming dark yellow-brown but drying a pale dingy cinnamon"^, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in duff in Abies-Picea (fir-spruce) zone^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x 2.3-2.6 microns^, "cells of subhymenium and of some tramal hyphae readily disarticulating"; "hyphae of epicutis often with flagellate hyphal ends", (Smith(4)), spores 7-9 x 2.3-2.6 microns, oblong, basal scar inconspicuous, smooth, in KOH nearly colorless singly but dingy ochraceous in groups, in Melzer's reagent not much change in color; basidia 8-spored; paraphyses "very soon becoming thick-walled and the changing finally including the subhymenium and some of the tramal hyphae, the elements readily disarticulating", cells of hymenial layer 6-12 microns wide; peridium "of a loosely woven epicutis of thick-walled yellow-brown hyphae (fresh), rusty brown in KOH" and 4-9(12) microns wide, "no inflated giant cells found but flagellate hyphae often numerous", subcutis of colorless hyphae with inflated cells mostly colorless in KOH or greenish and with deposits of bluish-green pigment; clamp connections none; in Melzer's reagent the hymenium and subcutis with much amyloid debris but no amyloid hyphae, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  refers to Florence, Oregon, where type was found
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)

FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon fragmentatus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 56. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include duplex peridium when fresh with brick-colored to dark brown outer layer and white inner layer, rusty brown dried spore-mass, caramel odor, growth under conifers, and microscopic characters including smooth, truncate, elliptic to oval spores that are dingy violaceous in Melzer's reagent and pale cinnamon in KOH, 8-spored basidia, and enlarged cells of the tramal plate hyphae^; description derived from Smith(30); rare, Klickitat County, WA, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  about 3cm across, ovate; peridium duplex when fresh with the outer layer lateritious to dark brown and the inner layer white; surface with only inconspicuous rhizomorphs
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  small chambers, soft when fresh; rusty brown when dried
STEM  
ODOR  strongly of caramel when fresh
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under conifers
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-8 x 3-3.7 microns, elliptic to oval, truncate at base, smooth, dingy violaceous in Melzer's reagent, pale cinnamon in KOH, thin-walled, basal scar distinct^; basidia 8-spored, 14-20 x 5-8 microns; paraphyses all thin-walled and resembling basidioles; subhymenium and tramal plates "of very thin-walled nongelatinous hyphae with cells often 20-40 microns thick and readily disarticulating", some filaments with irregularly enlarged cells 6-15 microns across also present, "tramal plates crumbly when sectioned, hyphal arrangement basically interwoven, the cells weakly outlined as revived in KOH", some hyphae as revived in Melzer's reagent containing colorless granular particles; peridium of hyphae 4-15 microns wide, appressed-interwoven, cylindric, heavily incrusted with rusty brown pigment in KOH, in Melzer's reagent forming large orange-brown pigment balls but all hyphae still remaining granular incrusted, no layering visible in revived mounts; clamp connections none; all tissues inamyloid: some amyloid debris present but possibly extraneous
NAME ORIGIN  means 'fragmented'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Trappe(13)

FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon fragrans  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 71. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include more or less spherical fruitbody with cinnamon brown surface that dries russet or darker, spore mass that is very dark brown, pungent-fragrant odor, olive-black reaction to both KOH and FeSO4, and microscopic characters including smooth narrowly oblong spores, and "extreme development of the mucilaginous wall thickening, extending to the subhymenium and tramal hyphae", and coiled to crooked hyphae as well as flagellum-like hyphae in the peridial epicutis^; rare, central ID, (Trappe(13)), found central Idaho according to Smith(4), ID and probably OR, (Smith(30)); Paul Kroeger collection from BC deposited at University of British Columbia
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  olive black reaction in both KOH and FeSO4, the latter distinct on both fresh and dried material, (this is probably on the surface although this is not specifically stated)^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1.8cm across, cinnamon-brown when fresh, drying russet or darker; subtomentose [more or less tomentose], epicutis chipping off^, (Smith(4)), about 1.8cm across, spherical or nearly so; dull cinnamon brown when fresh, drying russet or darker (description also refers to the russet-brown color of the peridium as a distinctive feature), the epicutis separating into patches to expose the pallid subcutis; dry and unpolished to subtomentose, no rhizomorphs present, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  chambers small to medium; dark cinnamon-brown when mature^, (Smith(30))
STEM  columella lacking^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  pungent-fragrant when fresh^, (Smith(4))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under spruce and fir^, (Smith(4)), in duff under conifers (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.5-8 x 2-2.8 microns^; 'epicutis of crooked dark brown (in KOH) hyphae 4-15 microns wide, "knee-joint" cells present, flagellate hyphal ends also present', (Smith(4)), spores 6.5-8 x 2.2-2.8 microns, narrowly oblong, no obvious basal scar but sometimes with false septum, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish, in KOH faintly yellowish singly and pale dingy brown in mass; basidia soon collapsed and not reviving; hymenium "made up of thick-walled paraphyses with the cells in chains 1-4 cells long", the central body remaining yellowish in Melzer's reagent, the cells versiform [of various forms] (some lengths of hyphae even developing thickened walls), 6-12 microns wide, the terminal cells 10-25 x 7-12 microns; tramal plates with colorless highly refractive loosely interwoven hyphae 4-10 microns wide, cells enlarged in places at times; subhymenium "cellular and cells often thick-walled (as part of the chains of cells forming the paraphyses)"; peridium 2-layered: 1) epicutis of hyphae 4-15 microns wide, coiled to crooked, dark brown in KOH, walls up to 1.5 microns thick, many with "knee-joint-like" shapes, "these elements forming an obscure tangled turf which collapses or becomes rubbed off", flagellum-like hyphae tapering to an acute almost colorless apex also present, 2) "inner layer of appressed thin-walled hyphae green in KOH and FeSO4", mostly 4-8 microns wide "and many of these hyphae developing wall thickenings comparable to those of the hymenial elements, amyloid granules present but often rare in the peridial context or along hymenium"; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'fragrant'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon villosulus has lighter colored spore mass
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
200
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon fuscorubens  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 120. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Rhizopogon fuscorubens is easily recognized by the abundant, conspicuous dark brown to black rhizomorphs against a pale surface color in younger fruitbodies, the red to reddish brown surface in older or slightly dried fruitbodies, and the smooth, narrow spores. Other features include a white spore mass that becomes yellowish then light brown, development under deep litter of 2-needle and 3-needle pines, and chemical and microscopic characters.^ It is common among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Rhizopogon fuscorubens is found in coastal OR and northern CA, MT, and eastern North America, (Trappe(13)). The type is from OR (Smith(30)). It was examined from OR, MS, VA, (Miller). A specimen from SC was used in study (Grubisha(2)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 on peridial surface negative to slowly gray, negative on spore mass; KOH on peridial surface reddish brown, negative on spore mass^, (Miller), FeSO4 on ochraceous areas of dried peridium staining olive (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-5cm across, nearly spherical, ovate or turbinate [top-shaped]; white at first then pale yellow, grayish orange, brownish orange, reddish brown, or brown when old or when exposed, not bruising readily when injured (also stated to be "grayish orange, brownish orange, or reddish brown at full development, occasionally bruising red"); "dry, smooth, subtomentose in youth, felted below, unpolished above with age"; in cross-section peridium 0.03-0.05cm thick, yellowish white to reddish white; rhizomorphs abundant, circumscribing entire fruitbody in reticulate pattern, "fine to large, mostly appressed", colored as surface at first and inconspicuous, readily staining brown, dark brown, or black when old or when handled, contrasting sharply with lighter surface color; when dried peridium pale yellow to light brown with abundant brownish red, reddish brown, or black mottling^, (Miller), 1-3cm across, dried fruiting body with a lemon buff ground color overlaid by blackish rhizomorphs, (Smith(4) for dried state), 1-3cm across, spherical to nearly spherical; "surface covered with a network of rhizomorphs as in R. occidentalis [name italicized] only in drying becoming black causing surface to be black or with lemon buff areas showing between, upper area ochraceous with fuscous streaks", this also explained as follows: "Dried peridium with lemon-buff ground color overlaid by blackish rhizomorphs", (Smith(30) for dried state), "dingy white and staining red where handled when young, darkening to grayish red, grayish brown, or grayish olive" when old, the surface netted from the young stage with black rhizomorphs, (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  firm fleshy, then spongy-cartilaginous; white when young, then dull yellow, grayish yellow, finally light brown when old, often mottled with light zones, when dried yellowish white to grayish yellow; chambers 3-4 per mm at full development^, (Miller), firm when dried but cutting easily; pale ochraceous when dried, olivaceous when old, when dried with slightly pallid spots, (Smith(30) for dried state)
STEM  rhizomorphs "mostly appressed, some free converging below into a tangled network of loosely hanging strands or singly large rhizomorphic attachment"^, (Miller)
ODOR  absent to faintly metallic^ (Miller), musty (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  mild^ (Trappe, M.(3))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground or erumpent in forests, usually under a deep litter layer, associated with 2-needle and 3-needle pines, October to December^, (Miller), unknown (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal in the Pacific Northwest with Pinus (pine), (Trappe), with Pinus, usually on sandy soils, July to February, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (6)7.0-9.5 x 2.5-3.0 microns, oblong to narrowly elliptic^, in Melzer's reagent colorless singly, bright orange yellow in mass, mostly with 1-3 false septa, in KOH colorless singly, pale grayish yellow in mass, "basal scar present but not prominent"; basidia borne in distinct hymenium, 15-20 x 5-8 microns, clavate, thin-walled, soon collapsing, mostly 8-spored, brachybasidioles 10-25 x 6-15 microns, subspherical, clavate or obovate, thin-walled when young, moderately thick-walled or thick-walled, mucilaginous when old; subhymenium "poorly developed, subcellular at base of some hymenial elements, 1-3 cells deep", cells 6-10 microns in diameter, subspherical, cubic or elongated, branching, colorless, moderately thick-walled when old;
