trama of hyphae that are 4-7(10) microns wide, cylindric to slightly swollen, loosely interwoven, colorless, refractive in KOH; peridium 150-250 microns thick: peridial subcutis thin, cells mostly anticlinal, 10-15 x 5-8 microns, "oblong to elongated or swollen, thin-walled", projecting into outermost chambers, not encrusted; peridial epicutis of hyphae 3-8 microns wide, tightly interwoven to appressed, colorless, walls thin to moderately thickened; rhizomorphs and hyphal strands abundant, 5-15 cells thick, 15-60 microns in diameter, subparallel in tangential section, spherical in cross-section, gelatinized when old, "heavily encrusted with dark brownish red amorphous pigment in KOH, pigment readily liquefying into large compound reddish brown pigment globules in Melzer's reagent", (Miller), spores 7-7.5 x 2.5-3 microns, "peridium of rhizomorphs interwoven with much-branched hyphae, as revived in KOH magenta to fuscous-red, the hyphae 4-12 microns wide, no sphaerocysts present", (Smith(4) for dried state), spores 6-7.5 x 2.5-3 microns, oblong to narrowly elliptic, smooth, yellow in Melzer's reagent, colorless to yellowish in KOH, base obscurely truncate; basidia 8-spored, 12-15 x 5-7 microns, narrowly clavate; paraphyses 12-15 x 6-11 microns, subvesiculose, thin-walled; subhymenium cellular, the cells colorless and thin-walled; tramal plates "of nongelatinous hyphae subparallel to interwoven, some cells enlarged to 9-15 microns"; peridium "of rhizomorphs and interwoven much-branched hyphae, as revived in KOH dark magenta to fuscous-red including rhizomorphs", with plate-like incrustations of pigment to nearly smooth, hyphae 4-12 microns wide, cylindric, no sphaerocysts present, in Melzer's reagent "large orange-brown pigment globules present"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30) for dried state)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin meaning "dark brown and reddening", "referring to the abundant dark brown rhizomorphs, and the reddish brown color often found in the peridium of older and dried basidiocarps"^, (Miller)
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon brunneofibrillosus has narrower spores, and rhizomorphs are not distinctively colored as revived in KOH, (Smith(30)). Rhizopogon ochraceorubens has a peridium that dries red, whereas R. fuscorubens has a peridium that dries yellow and rhizomorphs that dry black, (Smith(30)). See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon monticola and Rhizopogon willamettensis.
SOURCES  Miller, S.L.(1) (colors mostly from Kornerup(3)), Smith(30), Smith(4), Grubisha(2), Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)
201
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon griseogleba  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 52. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include more or less spherical fruitbody with surface nearly bald and gray brown, staining vinaceous where bruised, grayish brown spore mass, chemical characters including pinkish lilac reaction on fresh surface and microscopic characters including spores of variable shape, and peridium a thick layer with copious fuscous-brown pigment masses in hyphae and between them, and groups of enlarged cells in inner peridium^; found ID (Smith(30))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  "KOH on fresh peridium red to vinaceous (no olive tints present on fresh or on revived sections)", "FeSO4 on peridium dark olive"^, (Smith(4)), KOH stains surface pinkish lilac, FeSO4 stains surface dark olive, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-1.5cm across, pale to dark wood brown, fresh surface staining vinaceous where bruised; dry, nearly bald, with scattered rhizomorphs^, (Smith(4)), 1-1.5cm thick, spherical to nearly spherical, outline uneven; pale to dark wood-brown and staining vinaceous when handled; dry, nearly bald "but under a lens matted-fibrillose and this overlaid with scattered rhizomorphs"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  consistency hard and bone-like; grayish brown, drying drab^, (Smith(4)), consistency hard and bone-like when dried, cavities very small; color grayish wood-brown when fresh, pale drab when dried, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  none^ (Smith(30))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  dug from ashes of an old campfire, under Picea (spruce)^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores of various shapes and variable in size, 12-18 x 6-12 microns, "possibly many of them conidia"^, (Smith(4)), spores of various shapes: 18 x 5 microns and narrowly fusoid, 12-15 x 6-9 microns and clavate to obcordate, 10-14 x 9-12 microns and angular-subglobose, 9-12 microns and triangular, 14-18 x 3-5 microns and flexuous-cylindric, Rhodophyllus-like (angular-rectangular), etc., inamyloid (yellowish), in KOH ochraceous-tawny, wall slightly thickened and brittle, with many broken spores, basal scar distinct but not conspicuous; basidia not clear in revived mounts, 'many "spores" seen to be the apical cell of a filamentous projection into the hymenium'; paraphyses - none clearly defined; tramal plates of colorless gelatinous hyphae refractive in KOH, some oleiferous hyphae present in the layer; peridium a thick layer of hyphae 4-12 microns wide, "with copious fuscous-brown pigment masses in the hyphae and between them", groups of enlarged cells present near the spore mass; clamp connections absent; all tissues inamyloid, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with gray spore mass'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon alkalivirens does not stain vinaceous when handled and KOH makes the surface green then black, (Smith(30)); Rhizopogon variabilisporus has the same patterns of variation in shape but spore mass is pallid becoming dark yellow brown when cut, slowly darkening to olive-brown, (Smith(30)); Rhizopogon clavitisporus readily distinguished by paraphyses, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4)
202
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon griseovinaceus  A.H. Sm.^  Journal of the Mitchell Society 84(2): 276. 1968
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include nearly spherical to flattened fruitbody with tan surface that dries vinaceous gray and is minutely areolate (cracked like dried mud), spore mass that is olive buff as dried and very soft and crumbles easily, and microscopic characters including smooth, narrowly elliptic to oblong spores and peridium with trichodermial type of epicutis^; rare, Lane County OR, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 slowly blackens dried surface^ (Smith(28))
OUTER SURFACE  2-3.5cm across, tan when fresh, vinaceous-gray when dried; dry, minutely areolate [cracked like dried mud]^, (Smith(4)), 2-3.5cm across, nearly spherical to flattened; tan when fresh, when dried a medium vinaceous gray; dry, minutely areolate [cracked like dried mud], lacking obvious rhizomorphs, (Smith(28))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  very soft and friable (crumbles easily), cavities labyrinthiform; olive buff when dried^, (Smith(28))
STEM  columella lacking^ (Smith(28))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under conifers^ (Smith(4)), mycorrhizal in the Pacific Northwest with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-7.5 x 2-2.5 microns, narrowly elliptic to oblong, smooth, yellowish in Melzer's reagent when dried, colorless in KOH, thin-walled, not truncate^; basidia 7-9 microns wide, of various lengths up to 25 microns long, 6-7 spores seen (possibly 8-spored); basidioles thin-walled; subhymenium a nongelatinous cellular layer 1-2 cells deep, thin-walled, colorless, content not distinctive; tramal plates of thin-walled non-gelatinous hyphae 3-8 microns wide (or some cells inflated and wider); peridium with trichodermial type of epicutis that has the elements forming small areolae or appressed to the surface, the hyphal cells 9-15(20) microns across, often short (under 50 microns), the terminal cells elliptic to cystidioid, greenish in KOH but fading to yellowish on standing, with dark olive rod-like particles in and between the cells in places, the subcutis of appressed hyphae at first, and also greenish in KOH when revived, tramal body of thin-walled hyphae closely interwoven with some red pigment in the layer as revived in KOH, but this fading in 15 minutes, inflated cells seen but no large pockets of sphaerocysts present, in Melzer's reagent the epicuticular hyphae nearly colorless but with dingy incrustations and a few broken pieces of hyphae partly amyloid, dark violet rods also present between the hyphae but these are possibly the same as the olive particles seen in KOH, tramal body with numerous orange-brown pigment balls in the layer as revived in Melzer's reagent; no amyloid hyphae seen in the interior of the peridium; clamp connections absent, (Smith(28)), spores 6-7.5 x 2.2-2.5 microns, yellowish in Melzer's reagent when mature, "epicutis of peridium of hyphae 9-15 (20) microns wide, the cells often short, walls greenish in KOH at first", "epicutis of peridium a turf (trichodermium)" that collapses when old, (Smith(4))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'gray-vinaceous'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon semireticulatus lacks the trichodermial type of epicutis, and spores are longer and broader, (Smith(28))
SOURCES  Smith(4), Smith(28), Trappe(13)
203
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon hawkerae  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 83. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to irregular fruitbody with a surface that has wood brown fibrils over a whitish ground color, and changes to bright pink where injured, 2) a spore mass that is white when young, becoming olive, 3) growth in very rotten wood, 4) an olive reaction of the peridial surface to KOH and FeSO4, and 5) microscopic characters including narrowly elliptic spores from 4-6-spored basidia, rare to scattered cystidia, and peridial epicutis with versiform cells 2-11 microns wide, many seta-like cells (flagellate hyphal ends).^ Molecular evidence has been presented to support the contention that Rhizopogon hawkerae (or at least a paratype and other collections identified as this species) is a synonym (along with R. parksii and paratypes of R. colossus var. colossus) of R. villosulus A.H. Sm. (Martin, M.P.(2)); on the other hand, other molecular evidence suggests that R. villosulus (different collection), R. colossus (holotype), R. hawkerae (same paratype), and R. villescens (non-type) are close and could be a single species that shows variation, whereas two non-type collections of R. parksii were more distant, (Grubisha(2)). Rhizopogon hawkerae is abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It is found from southern BC to northern CA and ID, (Trappe(13)). It has been reported to the North American Truffling Society for OR and for Sproat Lake in BC. It was reported from OR by J. Smith et al. A specimen from WA was used in study (Grubisha(2)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 on peridium dark olive, KOH quickly pale olive^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-4cm across, "wood brown to vinaceous-fuscous over a whitish ground color, changing to bright pink where injured"; dry^, (Smith(4)), 1-4cm across, spherical, ovoid, or irregular from mutual pressure; wood-brown to vinaceous-fuscous, when fresh the wood brown fibrils overlying a whitish ground color, soon bright pink where injured, when dried dingy vinaceous except for the brown fibrils (and the pallid buff spore mass); dry, (Smith(30)), smudgy white when young, "bruising pinkish to red or reddish brown", "later becoming brown with red tints and black bruises", (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "pallid becoming olive-buff" and finally nearly fuscous when old; "chambers empty, small and irregular"^, (Smith(30)), white when young, darkening to olive, (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  columella none^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  mild or slightly spicy^ (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  mild^ (Trappe, M.(3))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection in a very rotten log, August^, (Smith(30)), associated with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir); year-round, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.5-8 x 2.2-2.8 microns^, cystidia 26-30 x 8-10 microns, "projecting 10-15 microns beyond the basidia"; "epicutis of hyphae with versiform cells 2-11 microns wide", "many setalike cells present, flagellate hyphal ends also present", (Smith(4)), spores 6.5-8 x 2.2-2.8 microns, narrowly elliptic to suboblong, in Melzer's reagent weakly yellow, in KOH colorless singly and in masses along hymenium, no basal truncation seen; basidia 4-6-spored, 20-23 x 4-5 microns, "clavate, thin-walled, readily collapsing"; paraphyses "resembling basidioles, none seen with thickened walls, in KOH many with minute highly refractive globules"; cystidia rare to scattered, 26-30 x 8-10 microns, projecting 10-15 microns beyond hymenium, fusoid-ventricose, colorless, thin-walled; tramal plates of somewhat interwoven, narrow, refractive, colorless hyphae (revived in KOH), nongelatinous in water mounts when fresh; peridial subcutis of colorless appressed-interwoven hyphae, bluish in places in KOH (fresh) and with amyloid granules as revived in Melzer's reagent, 2-11 microns wide, no pockets of enlarged cells present, "as revived in KOH dingy vinaceous and with darker brown pigment pockets abundant"; peridial epicutis of hyphae with dark brown walls in KOH and water, "and the walls thickened (1-2 microns), smooth to rarely incrusted, the cells versiform, 2-11 microns diam", "many seta-like elements present in or projecting from the layer and tapered to a whiplike flexuous nearly hyaline apex about 1 micron in diam; the bases 3-6 microns in diam (the so-called flagellate hyphal ends)"; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30)), peridial subcutis has a characteristic red layer revived in KOH (use 25X objective), although this fades after about 5 years of dried storage to pale pink and may disappear entirely after 7-10 years, (NATS)
NAME ORIGIN  after Lilian Hawker who found the type
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon subareolatus and Rhizopogon villosulus are similar Douglas-fir associated species that also have woven brown walled hyphae in the peridium revived in KOH: R. subareolatus has slightly smaller spores 6-7 x 2-2.3 microns, and no flagellate hyphae and R. villosulus lacks a red layer in the subcutis as revived in KOH (may be orange-brown). Beside those two, other species associated with Douglas-fir that have woven brown hyphae in the peridium revived in KOH include Rhizopogon parksii (spores 4.5-6.5 x 2.3-3 microns), Rhizopogon villescens (spores 7-10 x 3-4 microns), Rhizopogon zelleri (spores 9-12 x 3.5-4 microns), (these three like R. hawkerae with at least some flagellate hyphae), Rhizopogon vinicolor (spores 5.5-8 x 3-4.5 microns), and Rhizopogon subclavatisporus (spores 8-13 x 4.5-7 microns and thicker on one end), (NATS). Rhizopogon mutabilis A.H. Sm., found in ID, may be this species. See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon colossus and Rhizopogon subclavitisporus.
SOURCES  Smith(30) (as R. hawkeri, incorrect because Lilian Hawker is a woman), Smith(4), Smith, J.E.(1), NATS(1) (Trappe, M., accessed April 6, 2005), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Grubisha(2), Martin, M.P.(2), Trappe(13)
204
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon hysterangioides  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 50. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include underground growth, nodular surface white but yellowish in depressions, lack of rhizomorphs, dry firm spore mass, chemical characters including yellowish to pinkish surface reaction to KOH and microscopic characters including Hysterangium-like spores, and peridium of compactly interwoven hyphae^; rare in the Pacific Northwest, found northern CA to ID and CO, (Trappe(13)), found ID according to Smith(4), reported for OR to Oregon Truffling Association
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH yellowish then reddish on fresh peridium, FeSO4 slowly pale bluish on peridium, (Smith(4))^, KOH slowly dingy yellowish to pinkish on surface, FeSO4 slowly pale bluish to pale bluish olive on surface, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm, nodulose to irregular; "dull white, yellowish in the depressions"; dry; no rhizomorphs present^, (Smith(4)), 1-3cm across, spherical-nodular to very irregular; "dull white or in some the depressions pale yellowish"; dry, no rhizomorphs present, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  consistency firm-cartilaginous; white, drying pale pinkish buff^, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in duff under spruce and fir^, (Smith(4)), in duff under conifers (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 11-14 x 4.5-6.5 microns, groups of spores colorless in KOH, spores yellowish in Melzer's^; basidia clavate to subspherical above a wavy pedicel; cystidia none; "peridium of compactly interwoven hyphae 3-8 microns wide, no sphaerocysts present", (Smith(4)), spores 11-14 x 4.5-6.5 microns, subfusoid to elliptic, with a droplet, smooth, yellowish in Melzer's reagent, colorless in KOH; basidia 4-spored, clavate above a wavy pedicel or tip subglobose; cystidia none; peridium of compactly interwoven colorless hyphae 3-8 microns wide or some cells variously enlarged but not sphaerocysts, when revived in KOH flushed reddish near surface (where debris present) but colorless in interior, yellowish in Melzer's reagent; clamp connections none; many oil drops present in KOH and Melzer's mounts, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'like Hysterangium' in reference to the spores
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
205
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon idahoensis  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N. Y. bot. Gdn 14(2): 43. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features distinguishing from close relatives are color pattern of white to wood-brown and finally drying near fuscous, conspicuous rhizomorphs over surface, spores that are narrowly oblong, amyloid, lacking truncate basal scar, and in mass along the hymenium pale cinnamon color of spores as opposed to ochraceous, (Smith(30), but note that the description refers to "an inconspicuous network of rhizomorphs"), other features include surface staining slowly when injured to dingy lilac-vinaceous, in KOH staining purplish to vinaceous-fuscous or bluish black, and in FeSO4 greenish to inky black^; description derived from Smith(30); found at least in ID, (Smith(30)), common in the Pacific Northwest, distribution southwestern OR to northern CA and ID, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH staining surface purplish to vinaceous-fuscous or bluish black; FeSO4 staining surface greenish to inky black
OUTER SURFACE  1-6cm across, spherical, compressed or irregular; white; dry, "unpolished to woolly or fibrillose and with an inconspicuous network of rhizomorphs, slowly becoming wood-brown", in drying becoming "hair brown" (Ridgway(1)) to "fuscous" (Ridgway(1) [blackish]), "when injured slowly staining dingy lilac-vinaceous, collections partly dried in situ not always staining"
INNER LAYER  peridium 0.05-0.1cm thick when fresh, whitish in section
INTERIOR  chambers small to medium-large; white, slowly olivaceous to olive-gray
STEM  columella absent
ODOR  none
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in duff under conifers in ID, July and August
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (6.5)7-9 x 2.3-3 microns, oblong, or in side view slightly curved, pale greenish blue in Melzer's reagent, colorless in KOH, when revived in KOH aggregations along hymenium pale cinnamon buff^; basidia 4-spored, 6-spored, and 8-spored, 10-17 x 4-6(7) microns, colorless, thin-walled, readily collapsing; paraphyses 6-10 x 5-9 microns (the terminal cells), thin-walled, colorless; cystidia none; subhymenium cellular (including lower part of hymenium); tramal plates of interwoven, colorless, smooth hyphae "nongelatinous in KOH on young material and refractive-gelatinous in older specimens"; peridium in section in KOH vinaceous in places, the hyphae 3-9 microns wide, "mostly cylindric and with much incrusting debris as particles or amorphous material", "revived in KOH the hyphal walls near avellaneous to darker brown, smooth", 0.2-0.3 microns thick, in Melzer's reagent many orange-brown globules present in the layer, no groups of enlarged cells present; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none
NAME ORIGIN  means 'from Idaho', where type was found
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon subcaerulescens is close, but immature specimens of R. subcaerulescens stain bluish with FeSO4 (compared with olive to inky-black for R. idahoensis), and vinaceous with KOH (compared with olive for R. idahoensis), and in addition spores are weakly amyloid (bluish green tint) only in some immature spores, whereas in R. idahoensis spores are still amyloid when the pigmentation has progressed to the cinnamon-buff stage, (Smith(30)); compare also with Rhizopogon ellenae which is described as having spores 3-3.8 microns wide. See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon pedicellus.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Trappe(13)
206
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon inquinatus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 66. 1966.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include more or less spherical fruitbody with surface whitish to pallid buff, staining reddish then black with handling, olive spore mass that becomes olive-brown to blackish when cut, growth in association with conifer roots, chemical characters, and microscopic characters including smooth, truncate, elliptic to oval spores from 4-6-spored basidia, and large amyloid globules in the peridium^; rare, western OR to northern ID, (Trappe(13)), found OR according to Castellano, ID according to Smith(30)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 olive to blackish on peridium, (Smith(4)), KOH red then fuscous-black, (Castellano)^, "KOH on white surface reddish then fuscous-black, FeSO4 olivaceous but finally blackish", (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  about 2cm across, "whitish to pallid buff", peridium "where handled slowly staining inky-fuscous but with an intervening red stage"^, (Smith(4)), about 2cm, in diameter, spherical to nearly spherical; white at first, on exposure to air pale tan and where handled slowly staining inky-fuscous but with an intervening red stage; appressed-fibrillose, (Castellano), about 2cm across, spherical to nearly spherical, "whitish at first, on exposure to air pallid buff and where handled slowly staining inky-fuscous but with an intervening reddish stage"; dry and appressed fibrillose when fresh, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "olive, when cut olive-brown to blackish"^, (Smith(4)), olive, when cut soon olive-brown to black but when dried dark olivaceous, loculate [chambered] to labyrinth-like, (Castellano), rubbery in consistency, chambers labyrinthiform; olive when mature, "when cut soon becoming olive-brown to blackish but when dried brownish olivaceous", (Smith(30))
STEM  columella absent^, (Smith(30), Castellano)
ODOR  none^ (Smith(30), Castellano)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under cedar and hemlock, (Smith), found in association with roots of Pinus jeffreyi, Pseudotsuga menziesii and Tsuga heterophylla from 500 to 1400m elevation, (Castellano for Oregon), in duff in cedar-hemlock association, (Smith(30) for Idaho)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.5-7.5(8) x 3-3.5 microns, yellowish in KOH singly^; "peridium of appressed hyphae 3-5 microns wide, lacking greatly inflated cells", amyloid globules in Melzer's reagent (fresh or revived) often large (up to 30 microns wide), (Smith(4)), spores 6.5-7.5(8) x 3-3.5 microns, elliptic to oval and with a distinct cap-like truncation at base, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled, in KOH dingy yellow singly, red-brown in mass; basidia 4- to 6-spored, basidioles 6-9 microns, colorless, thin-walled, subgelatinous; clamp connections absent, (Castellano), spores 6.5-7.5(8) x 3-3.5 microns, elliptic to oval and with a distinct cup-like truncation at base, smooth, in Melzer's reagent dull yellowish singly and dull rusty brown in groups, in KOH dingy yellowish singly and dull cinnamon in masses, walls only slightly thickened; basidia "4- and 6-spored (possibly all 8-spored)"; paraphyses 6-9 microns wide, colorless, thin-walled, subgelatinous; tramal plates of hyphae 3-5 microns wide, gelatinous, branched, interwoven; subhymenium "of gelatinous-filamentous branches extending to a weak cellular region below hymenium"; peridium of loosely interwoven colorless thin-walled hyphae 3-5 microns wide, "smooth and the layer clean (as seen in KOH fresh), as revived in KOH with dark cinnamon granules of amorphous pigment", in Melzer's reagent (both fresh and dried) with dark violet globules up to 30 microns or more across free in the layer, no sphaerocysts or large inflated cells present; clamp connections none; all tissues inamyloid, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'stained, befouled'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Castellano(1), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
207
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon isabellinus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N. Y. bot. Gdn 14(2): 114. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include unchanging Isabella-color (a yellow-brown) of both surface and appressed rhizomorphs, dull olive spore-mass, weak KOH and FeSO4 reactions, absent columella, and microscopic characters^; description derived from Smith(30); described from OR, (Smith(30)), rare in Pacific Northwest, distribution western OR to ID, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  surface with KOH slightly more yellow-brown; surface with FeSO4 slightly more olivaceous
OUTER SURFACE  2-3cm across, spherical or nearly so; dry, fibrillose; coating on appressed rhizomorphs Isabella-color [a yellow-brown color in Ridgeway(1)] when fresh and practically unchanging when dried in silica gel, rhizomorphs not conspicuous because they are the same color as the surface, not staining red when bruised
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  firm but not hard; dull olive drying olive-gray
STEM  columella absent
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type brought to a mushroom show from near Portland Oregon
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5.5-7 x 2.3-3 microns, elliptic to oblong, smooth, colorless to yellowish in KOH, yellowish in Melzer's reagent and often with a false septum^; at least some basidia 6-spored; paraphyses colorless in KOH and yellowish in Melzer's reagent, "becoming thick-walled but central body not staining"; "subhymenium cellular and the cells becoming thick-walled like the paraphyses"; tramal plates of interwoven, colorless, highly refractive, somewhat gelatinous, narrow hyphae with walls of many at least somewhat thickened when old; peridium "of appressed-interwoven hyphae olive-yellow in KOH, the layer clean, inflated cells present here and there throughout the layer or in groups", in Melzer's reagent merely more yellowish "and with scattered yellow pigment balls in the mount"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none
NAME ORIGIN  refers to the Isabella-color of the surface
SIMILAR  related to Rhizopogon ochraceorubens and may be a synonym of that species, but according to Smith(30), "differs markedly in color (Isabella-color) and in the KOH reactions of the peridium as well as lack of pigment deposits in the latter"
SOURCES  Smith(30), Trappe(13)
208
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon kauffmanii  A.H. Sm. & Zeller^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 38. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to angular, appressed-fibrillose fruitbody with surface white turning slowly dark gray from handling, with a few coarse rhizomorphs that are mostly basal, columella absent or a false one present, growth in duff under conifers, rapid deep blue reaction to FeSO4, and microscopic characters including smooth spores of variable shape that are amyloid, amyloid in upper part, or inamyloid, 8-spored basidia, and peridium in Melzer's reagent showing some globules with amyloid content and some amyloid segments of hyphae^; rare, found in ID, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  "with FeSO4 quickly deep blue"^, (Smith(4)), KOH on surface vinaceous and finally vinaceous fuscous (no olive tone present); FeSO4 on surface quickly deep blue, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1.5-6cm across, "white, slowly fuscous from handling"^, (Smith(4)), 1.5-6cm across, spherical, nearly spherical, ovoid, or angular from external pressure; white, "when handled often developing bluish gray areas but mostly slowly becoming fuscous to vinaceous-fuscous"; dry and appressed-fibrillose, with a few coarse rhizomorphs mostly basal, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  when fresh the consistency hard and cartilaginous, bone-like when dried; white to olive buff (not darker when liquefying), when dried dingy pale ochraceous-clay color; cavities very minute^, (Smith(30))
STEM  columella absent or a false one present^, (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in duff under conifers^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-10 x 3.5-5 microns^; in mounts of peridium in Melzer's reagent "some globules with amyloid content are present, some hyphal segments of peridial hyphae with thickened strongly amyloid segments also present", (Smith(4)), spores 7-10 x 3.5-5 microns, variable in size and shape, elliptic, nearly round, angular-round (about 8 x 6 microns), or ovoid (6.5-8 x 3-4 microns), many somewhat angular and many more or less collapsed, smooth or very faintly marbled near edge of amyloid cap (when one is present), many dark violet in Melzer's reagent over all or only in upper quarter to three quarters, some inamyloid and some weakly amyloid spores also present, "wall finally becoming somewhat thickened"; basidia 8-spored, subgelatinous; paraphyses present but gelatinous, outlines not distinct as revived in KOH, but as seen in Melzer's reagent 6-10 microns wide and clavate; tramal plates of gelatinous intricately interwoven hyphae 2-5 microns wide, colorless, smooth, and loosely interwoven; subhymenium "filamentous and elements highly refractive in KOH"; peridium a thick single layer of hyphae 4-12 microns wide, laticifers scattered in this layer, "hyphae with heavy dark brown pigment deposits in and over them, and pigment also in large amorphous masses", some hyphae "with strongly amyloid masses or globules of the content present and many orange-brown pigment balls present in crushed mounts, amyloid granules often present also and some hyphae with thickened amyloid (dark violet) walls in short segments also present"; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  after Calvin Henry Kauffman, 1869-1931, professor of botany Michigan
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon subpurpurascens has olivaceous reaction of peridium to KOH (instead of vinaceous to vinaceous-fuscous), and in Melzer's has only orange-brown pigment balls (R. kauffmanii has dark violet ones as well), (Smith(30)). See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon atroviolaceus and Rhizopogon ellenae.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
209
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon libocedri  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N. Y. bot. Gdn 14(2): 117. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to irregular, grayish tan fruitbody with dry surface and many fibrils radiating from a basal point, the interior with empty chambers of variable size, growth under the surface associated with conifers, dark green to inky black staining reaction in FeSO4, and microscopic characters^; described from Del Norte County in CA, (Smith(28)), rare in western OR and northern CA (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH staining dried outer surface darker brown; FeSO4 staining dried fruiting body dark green to inky black
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across; spherical to obovate or somewhat irregular; grayish tan when fresh, drying dingy cinnamon to near pinkish buff; dry 
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  chambered, about concolorous with the outer surface as dried (dingy pinkish buff), "chambers empty and variable as to size (dried specimens)"
STEM  "with many fibrils radiating from a basal point"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type in duff under Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-cedar), (Smith), associated with Pinaceae (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5.5-6 x 2.2-2.5 microns, oblong to elliptic, with truncated basal scar, smooth, slowly dextrinoid (at least in groups), colorless in KOH, thin-walled^; basidia 4-spored, 6-spored, 8-spored, 5-7 microns wide, colorless, thin-walled; paraphyses "thin-walled, resembling basidioles, the outlines as revived in KOH indistinct but walls not gelatinous"; "subhymenium very indistinct, not more than a single layer of isodiametric cells present"; tramal plates of colorless, thin-walled, gelatinous-refractive hyphae more or less interwoven; peridium thin, of appressed hyphae 4-10 microns wide, "with thin walls but in sections the layer ochraceous tawny, little or no debris or pigment incrustations on the walls, no sphaerocysts in the layer", yellow oleiferous hyphae present (as observed both in KOH and in Melzer's reagent); clamp connections none; all tissues nonamyloid
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Libocedrus' referring to the Incense-cedar under which the type was found
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(28), Trappe(13)
210
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon luteoalboides  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 140. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include more or less spherical fruitbody with surface yellow, staining pinkish where handled but stain soon fading, cut peridium staining ochraceous to pinkish ochraceous, spore mass grayish to grayish brown with small chambers, absent columella, growth under conifers, pinkish reaction on surface with KOH, and microscopic characters including smooth, oblong to subfusoid spores from 6-8-spored basidia, and peridium consisting of interwoven hyphae with some groups of inflated cells and with some oleiferous hyphae^; rare, found central ID, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH pinkish on fresh cutis, FeSO4 dull brown^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, wax yellow to ocher yellow, "staining pinkish where handled but stain soon fading", duller when dried; cut peridium staining ochraceous to pinkish ochraceous^, (Smith(4)), 1-3cm across, spherical or nearly so; wax yellow to ocher yellow (but more buff colored when dried), "staining pinkish when handled or bruised but stained part soon fading"; very few rhizomorphs present; cut peridium ochraceous to pinkish ochraceous, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  gray (avellaneous) when fresh and mature, dingy ochraceous when dried; not staining when cut^, (Smith(4)), cartilaginous; a grayish cinnamon-buff to avellaneous but pale dingy ochraceous when dried; chambers fine, (Smith(30))
STEM  columella none^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under alpine pines and fir and spruce, summer^, (Smith(4)), type collection underground under Pinus albicaulis (Whitebark Pine), Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), and Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), August, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x 2.4-3 microns^, peridium "of a layer of ochraceous interwoven hyphae 4-12 microns wide as an epicutis" (epicutis not a trichodermium), "a rusty brown lower layer (as revived in KOH) of hyphae 8-18 microns wide, and some inflated cells present in it as well as oleiferous hyphae 8-14 microns wide", (Smith(4)), spores 7-9 x 2.4-3 microns, oblong to subfusoid, in Melzer's reagent yellowish, pale tawny in masses, some with a false septum, in KOH yellowish singly, dingy yellow-brown in masses, basal truncation scarcely evident; basidia 6-8-spored; paraphyses 8-12 microns wide, clavate to ellipsoid, "mostly thin-walled, slowly becoming thick-walled", colorless in KOH; tramal plates composed of filaments 2-4 microns wide, subgelatinous and colorless in KOH, thin-walled; peridium composed "of a layer of ochraceous interwoven hyphae 4-12 microns diam as an epicutis and a rusty brown (revived in KOH) layer of hyphae 8-18 microns diam, some of the enlarged cells in groups, oleiferous hyphae 8-14 microns diam also present"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'like [Rhizopogon] luteoalbus'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon luteoalbus is similar, but R. luteoalboides "has brighter more persistent colors, a pinkish KOH reaction which soon fades, and a dull brown FeSO4 reaction, and when fresh a differently colored gleba", (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
211
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon luteoalbus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 109. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to irregular fruitbody with surface pale yellow fading to whitish, unchanging when bruised, bald under scattered rhizomorphs, spore mass that is dingy ochraceous to finally olive brown, with small chambers, growth under Lodgepole Pine, chemical characters, and microscopic characters including smooth subfusoid to oblong spores from 4-spored and 8-spored basidia, subhymenium of filamentous elements, and 2-layered peridium (outer layer pale yellow to colorless, inner layer rusty brown)^; rare, found in ID, (Trappe(13)), collections examined from ID (Smith(30))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  "dried peridium staining olivaceous when FeSO4 is applied, KOH staining the dried surface brownish and ethanol staining it vinaceous"^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, pale yellow fading to whitish when old, bald beneath scattered rhizomorphs, not changing color when bruised^, (Smith(4)), 1-3cm across, spherical to oval or irregular; pale yellow when fresh, gradually fading to grayish white or when old dingy Isabella-color [pale yellowish brown] as the color of the spore mass shows through, not changing color when bruised; appearing bald beneath a few scattered rhizomorphs, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  dingy ochraceous to finally olive-brown; chambers small; when mature and dried, crumbly to section^, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), summer and early fall, (Smith(4))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 (10) x 2.8-3.5 microns^; subhymenial elements filamentous; peridium 2-layered as revived in KOH, outer layer pale sulphur to colorless, "inner layer rusty brown, lacking inflated cells or sphaerocysts", (Smith(4)), spores 7-9(10) x 2.8-3.5 microns, subfusoid to oblong, smooth, pale yellow in Melzer's reagent, colorless to yellow in KOH, thin-walled, basal scar small but distinct; basidia 4-spored and 8-spored, colorless, collapsing readily; paraphyses thin-walled at first, becoming thick-walled but content not coloring in Melzer's reagent; "entire hymenial hyphae becoming thick-walled, and in age often including the subhymenial elements"; subhymenium "filamentous to the basal cells of the hymenial layer"; tramal plates of interwoven, colorless, refractive, gelatinous, smooth hyphae; inner peridial layer "rusty brown in KOH from incrusting debris and intercellular deposits", outer peridial layer (epicutis) composed of hyphae that are interwoven, pale sulphur to colorless, walls smooth to faintly roughened, no inflated cells (sphaerocyst-like) seen in either layer; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'yellow-white'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon luteolus has surface that deepens in color with age instead of fading to whitish, and dried specimens are bone hard, (Smith(30)). See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon luteoalboides.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
212
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon luteoloides  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 126. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to angular fruitbody with wet-appearing surface yellow ocher, quickly staining yellow-brown from handling at maturity, pallid brownish spore mass that becomes darker brown when mature and is soft and wet when fresh but bone hard when dried, growth under Whitebark Pine, red surface reaction with KOH, and microscopic characters including smooth oval to oblong spores and peridium with an epicutis of loosely interwoven hyphae^; rare, central ID, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  surface of fruiting body red in KOH when fresh, FeSO4 no reaction on fresh peridium^, (Smith(4)), KOH on surface red, FeSO4 no reaction, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, yellow ocher when fresh, quickly staining yellow-brown when mature (dull cinnamon when dried)^, (Smith(4)), 1-3cm across, spherical, ellipsoid, or angular from external pressure, often compressed; yellow-ocher when fresh, "quickly staining yellow-brown from handling" and when dry the bruised areas dull cinnamon with unbruised areas dull ocher; wet in appearance, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  soft and becoming wet in consistency when mature, "but drying bone-hard and crumbly when one tries to section it"; pallid brownish when young, then "Dresden-brown" [dark yellowish brown] to "argus-brown" when mature; dull cinnamon when dried^, (Smith(30))
STEM  columella absent^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection under Pinus albicaulis (Whitebark Pine)^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x 2.5-3 microns^, "peridium with an epicutis of hyphae 4-12 microns wide, the cells often inflated, the layer pale ochraceous in KOH; the lower layer rusty brown in KOH, most cells somewhat inflated", hyphae of tramal plates thin-walled (under 0.5 microns thick) as revived in KOH, (Smith(4)), spores 7-9 x 2.7-3 microns, oval to narrowly elliptic or oblong, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellow singly and pale rusty brown in masses, in KOH yellowish singly, yellow-brown in masses, thin-walled, basal scar scarcely visible; basidia none seen sporulating; paraphyses 7-11 microns wide, oval to elliptic, soon thick-walled with a central amorphous body not colored in Melzer's reagent; "subhymenium of thick-walled cells connecting to paraphyses as a chain of such elements (cellular type)"; peridial inner layer rusty brown "from amorphous pigment as revived in KOH and hyphal cells mostly at least somewhat inflated", peridial outer layer as revived in KOH composed of hyphae that are 4-12 microns wide, often enlarged, the hyphae loosely interwoven, pale ochraceous, thin-walled, with some granular intercellular material present; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'like [Rhizopogon] luteolus'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
213
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon luteolus  Fr. & Nordholm^  Symb. Gast. 1: 5. 1817
ENGLISH NAMES  yellow false truffle
NOTES  features include spherical to irregular fibrillose fruitbody with surface yellow ocher to golden tawny, copious rhizomorphs that are often tawny at first, spore mass that is white becoming olivaceous at maturity, and microscopic characters including smooth, narrowly oblong spores measuring 7-9(10) x 2.5-3.5 microns, from 4-spored and 6-spored basidia, and 1-layered peridium of appressed hyphae that are bright ochraceous when fresh in KOH but vinaceous as revived in KOH^; the spores of the type from Sweden have slightly different spore size at 6-8 x 2.8-3.5 microns; collections examined from ID, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom, (Smith(30)), occurs in United Kingdom (Hawker(2))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 and KOH producing no color change on fresh surface or slowly slightly brownish^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-4cm across, yellow-ocher to golden tawny; dry, fibrillose; rhizomorphs often tawny at first and copious over peridium when fresh^, (Smith(4)), up to 4cm across, spherical to compressed and irregular; when fresh and uninjured yellow-ocher "but soon deepening to golden-yellow or golden-tawny, the rhizomorphs often tawny at first"; dry and fibrillose and covered overall by appressed rhizomorphs, (Smith(30)), 1-3cm across, irregularly spherical, "white to deep olive-yellow, then olive-brown, not turning red or black"; matte, "smooth but with irregular lumps and hollows", +/- covered with fine pale brown fibers, (Buczacki)
INNER LAYER  peridium "rather coarse, thick, tough", cracking on aging^, (Buczacki)
INTERIOR  olivaceous at maturity and bone hard when dried^ (Smith(4)), white (all specimens young), olivaceous when mature according to European authors; chambered with very minute cavities, (Smith(30)), "pale yellow to olive-brown, with irregularly shaped cavities", 0.02-0.1cm, (Buczacki)
STEM  columella none^ (Smith(30)), absent (Buczacki)
ODOR  unpleasant, indefinite^, (Buczacki)
TASTE  mild^ (Buczacki)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single in duff under fir, summer^, (Smith(30)), underground or at soil surface with pine, often among litter; usually in small to large groups; late summer to fall, (Buczacki)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-10 x 2.5-3.5(4) microns^, peridium 1-layered, "of appressed hyphae 5-12 microns wide, vinaceous as revived in KOH, slowly fading to fulvous", inflated cells present (both scattered and in pockets), (Smith(4)), spores 7-9(10) x 2.5-3.5(4) microns, narrowly oblong, smooth, yellowish in Melzer's reagent, colorless in KOH, wall slightly thickened; basidia 4-spored and 6-spored, 16-20 x 6-7 microns, colorless, thin-walled; paraphyses 7-9 microns wide, subspherical to ellipsoid "and only a few seen with mucilaginous inner-wall thickenings"; cystidia none; subhymenium "cellular from the basal and near basal cells of the hymenial elements"; tramal plates of hyphae that are somewhat interwoven, colorless, refractive, and smooth; peridium of hyphae that are appressed, with "walls bright ochraceous in KOH fresh (vinaceous-red as revived in KOH but slowly fading to fulvous), much debris in the layer and this material ochraceous when fresh and reddish brown revived in KOH", the hyphae 5-12 microns in diameter "with pockets of larger cells present or these cells more or less scattered throughout the layer", in Melzer's reagent many orange-brown globules present; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none, (Smith(30)), spores 5.5-7.5 x 2.5-3 microns, elongated elliptic, smooth, pale olive-brown, (Buczacki)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin "lute-" meaning yellow and "-olus", a diminutive suffix, meaning "yellowish", the fruitbody color, (Trappe, M.(1))
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon luteoalbus has a surface that fades to whitish instead of deepening in color when old, and dried specimens are crumbly rather than bone hard, (Smith(30)); Rhizopogon occidentalis has narrower spores (2)2.3-2.6(3) microns wide, inner peridium is yellowish to colorless and clear of amorphous debris (cinnamon if rhizomorph layer included) revived in KOH, and the peridium lacks orange-brown globules in Melzer's reagent, (Smith(30)). See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon deceptivus.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Courtecuisse(1)* (as R. obtextus), Hawker(2), Trappe, M.(1), Buczacki(1)*
214
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon luteorubescens  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 92. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to irregular fruitbody with a white surface that becomes pale bright yellow, slightly staining reddish to reddish brown when injured but with little discoloration on dried fruitbodies, 2) a white spore mass that becomes pallid yellowish to ochraceous (lemon-yellow where injured), 3) a dark olivaceous reaction of the peridium to FeSO4, and 4) microscopic characters including smooth, subfusoid to elliptic spores from 6-spored and 8-spored basidia, and clavate paraphyses.^ The online Species Fungorum, accessed May 23, 2016, gives this as a synonym of Rhizopogon roseolus (Corda) Th. Fr. The description is derived from Smith(30). It is rare among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It has been found in ID, (Trappe(13)). The type collection is from ID.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  peridium "reddish in KOH, and in FeSO4 rather dark olivaceous"
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, spherical to irregular; white at first, becoming pale bright yellow (near "Baryta yellow" Ridgway) and almost the same color when dried, "staining reddish to reddish brown slightly when injured" but very little discoloration showing on dried fruitbodies; dry, appressed-fibrillose; "no appreciable number of rhizomorphs"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  very soft (immature specimens); "white becoming pallid yellowish to ochraceous" (where injured or worm-eaten lemon yellow)
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in duff under conifers, July and August
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-8 x 3-3.5 microns, subfusoid to elliptic, smooth, yellowish in Melzer's reagent, colorless to yellowish in KOH, basal scar indistinct^; basidia 6-spored and 8-spored, 16-25 x 7-8 microns, colorless, readily collapsing; paraphyses 15-30 x 8-12 microns, clavate, thin-walled when young but (in at least some) thick-walled when old, content homogeneous; subhymenium cellular; tramal plates composed of hyphae 3-6 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, "only slightly refractive as seen in KOH"; outer peridial layer composed of hyphae 4-12 microns wide, colorless to yellowish (in KOH), smooth-walled, floccose, the layer "clean", no sphaerocysts noted; inner peridial layer "pale tawny from incrusting pigment between and on the hyphae", the hyphae 4-10 microns wide with some enlarged ones present; oleiferous hyphae fairly numerous, yellow in KOH; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none
NAME ORIGIN  means 'yellow becoming red'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Trappe(13)
215
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon lutescens  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 62. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to irregular fruitbody with surface pallid then flushed buff and finally dingy ochraceous over some areas and dingy vinaceous over others, spore mass that is pallid when young and soon yellow when cut, gregarious growth in a rotten conifer log, chemical characters including change of surface to black with FeSO4, and microscopic characters including smooth, truncate, elliptic to oval spores^; rare, southwestern BC to ID, (Trappe(13)), found ID, (Smith(30))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on fresh surface dingy purplish or, where the color has changed to ochraceous, a rusty brown, FeSO4 on fresh surface slowly black^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across, some with basal attachment, pallid at first, soon flushed buff, finally dingy ochraceous over some areas^, (Smith(4)), 1-2.5cm across, spherical to variously irregular; "when fresh dingy pallid but soon flushed cadmium-buff and finally becoming dingy vinaceous over some areas and dingy ochraceous elsewhere", drying vinaceous; dry and with few rhizomorphs, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  pallid when young, soon cadmium yellow when cut^, (Smith(4)), chambers large for genus; pallid when fresh but soon changing to cadmium when cut, drying a dingy olive-brown, (Smith(30))
STEM  some fruitbodies apparently with a basal attachment; columella lacking^, (Smith(30))
ODOR  none^ (Smith(30))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious in a rotten conifer log (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-10 x 4.5-6(6.5) microns, elliptic to oval and truncate at the sterigmal attachment from a broad scar, smooth, pale ochraceous in Melzer's reagent, pale ochraceous in KOH singly and near orange-ochraceous in mass in KOH, wall slightly thickened (0.33 microns), with an "oil drop" as revived in KOH but this disappearing in Melzer's reagent^; basidia 30-40 x 8-10 microns, cylindric, thin-walled, soon collapsing; cystidia none; paraphyses "of the ellipsoid to oval type and arising from an inflated cell 16-25 x 8-13 microns"; subhymenial layer "not truly distinct but hymenial layer 2-3 cells deep from chains of inflated cells"; tramal plates of subgelatinous narrow (3-8 microns wide) thin-walled smooth hyphae (in KOH and Melzer's reagent), "budding off hymenial elements laterally, often enlarged at point of branching"; peridium a layer of interwoven hyphae 2-6 microns wide, (fresh), colorless, with some incrusting debris, no enlarged (swollen) cells present, "the hyphae of the context dingy rusty to vinaceous in KOH and with considerable debris present", "the layer very tough and difficult to separate the component hyphae"; clamp connections none; all tissues inamyloid, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'becoming yellow'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
216
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon masoniae  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 154. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include nearly spherical to ellipsoid or pear-shaped fruitbody with surface dull white, staining red when bruised or peridium cut, numerous coarse rhizomorphs, spore mass white then pale olive, distinct rudimentary columella seemingly present in some fruitbodies, negative reactions on the surface to KOH and FeSO4, and microscopic characters including smooth, oblong spores from mostly 6-spored basidia, and peridium indistinctly 2-layered, with intracellular pigment bodies that are vinaceous brown in fresh specimens in KOH and rusty brown in revived specimens in KOH, and having enlarged cells in inner peridium^; rare, Clackamas County OR, (Trappe(13)), type collection found in OR (Smith(30))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  neither KOH nor FeSO4 causing color change on fresh specimens^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  2-4cm across, covered by numerous coarse rhizomorphs, surface staining red when bruised, clay color when dried^, (Smith(4)), 2-4cm across and up to 3.5cm high, ellipsoid, pear-shaped, or nearly spherical; dull white, staining red when bruised or when peridium cut, "when dried a dingy clay-color"; "covered by numerous coarse rhizomorphs extending up from the base and branching, the rhizomorphs loose at the base" but closely appressed in upper part and then surface somewhat reticulate in places from branching of the main rhizomorphs, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  when dried firm but not hard; white becoming pale olive; chambers labyrinthiform and up to 0.1cm or more long^, (Smith(30))
STEM  rudimentary columella present and distinct in some fruitbodies (but some artifact is suspected here)^, (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga (hemlock) in mixed conifer-hardwood area^, (Smith(4)), type collection on humus, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-7 x 2-2.3 microns, oblong, smooth, colorless in Melzer's reagent fresh and revived, colorless in KOH fresh and revived, with 1-2 oil droplets^; basidia cylindric, mostly 6-spored; paraphyses colorless in KOH, thin-walled; subhymenium "cellular, 2-4 cells deep and cell walls not gelatinous"; central strand of tramal plates composed of hyphae 2-4 microns wide, subparallel, colorless, gelatinous to subgelatinous; peridium "with a separate outer layer, sections of fresh material showing many vinaceous-brown (rusty brown as revived in KOH) intra-cellular pigment deposits, enlarged cells present in lower layer (the two layers not clearly differentiated anatomically), the entire peridium of appressed-interwoven hyphae"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30)), "peridium indistinctly 2-layered, enlarged cells present in the lower layer", "vinaceous brown intracellular pigment bodies present (sections of fresh specimens in KOH), these bodies rusty brown in KOH on revived material", (Smith(4))
NAME ORIGIN  names after Miss Marjorie Mason of the Oregon Mycological Society, the collector of the type
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon masoniae differs from Rhizopogon evadens in the former's copious development of rhizomorphs and in the distribution and type of pigment in the peridium, (Smith(30)). See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon evadens var. evadens.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
217
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon milleri  A.H. Sm.^  Mycopath. et Mycol. App. 26: 389. 1965
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to angular fruitbody with a surface that is whitish becoming cinnamon buff, 2) a spore mass that is cinnamon, and 3) microscopic characters including some of the spores being partly dark violet in Melzer's reagent, and a vinaceous red reaction of the subcutis to KOH.^ It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It is found from western OR to ID, (Trappe(13)). The type is from ID.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH dark vinaceous red on fresh peridium, FeSO4 dark olive^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across, whitish becoming cinnamon buff and drying this color^, (Smith(4)), 1-2.5cm across, spherical to oval or somewhat angular; whitish at first but discoloring to cinnamon buff; dry and appressed fibrillose, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "cartilaginous when fresh, hard as a rock when carefully dried, chambers very minute"; pale cinnamon when young, cinnamon when mature, but when dried "near pale sepia (a yellow brown)"^, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under larch and pine^ (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.5-8.5 (9.2) x 3-4 microns, in Melzer's reagent "some spores dark violet over part (half) of the spore and paler elsewhere"^; "peridium with subcutis red in KOH", (Smith(4)), spores 6.5-8.5(9.2) x 3-4 microns, "elliptic, oblong, oval, subglobose or obscurely angular", in Melzer's "some dark violet in upper half, upper three fourths, or on some spores only in spots in the wall", in KOH dingy yellow-brown in groups, nearly colorless singly, wall distinctly thickened; hymenium gelatinous (both basidia and paraphyses) as revived in KOH; tramal plates of colorless gelatinous smooth interwoven hyphae; subhymenium of gelatinous filaments; peridium with outer region of pigment-filled and incrusted hyphae with some areas olive as revived in KOH, subcutis vinaceous red in KOH, in Melzer's large orange to brown pigment balls forming; clamp connections none, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  after O.K. Miller, who found the type
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
218
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon molallaensis  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 80. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include irregular fruitbody with pallid surface that becomes ivory and becomes decorated with olivaceous to umber scales and patches, rhizomorphs sparse, appressed, and colored as surface, olive brown spore mass, Swiss cheese odor, and microscopic characters including smooth oblong to narrowly elliptic spores, variously shaped paraphyses that become thick-walled, subhymenial cells also becoming thick-walled, and peridial epicutis when well developed of interwoven thin-walled to thick-walled hyphae^; rare, Clackamas and Polk Counties OR, (Trappe(13)), type collection found in OR (Smith(30))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  surface with KOH reddish brown becoming blackish, with FeSO4 faintly grayish^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  2.5-4.5cm across, pallid becoming ivory, when dried grayish brown; appressed-fibrillose, becoming decorated with olivaceous to umber squamules [fine scales] and patches^, Smith(4), about 4.5cm x 4cm x 2.5cm, "compressed, in outline more or less irregular"; pallid becoming ivory; "becoming decorated with olivaceous to umber squamules and patches"; dry, appressed-fibrillose; rhizomorphs sparse, appressed, colored as surface or darker, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  firm, when dried not hard as bone; soon olive-brown, and drying olivaceous^, Smith(30) 
STEM  
ODOR  pleasant, of Swiss cheese^, (Smith(30))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection gregarious under grass near roots of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), 60m elevation, November^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5.5-7 x 2.4-3 microns^, "epicutis of hyphae with some cells thick-walled, no flagellate hyphal ends seen", Smith(4), spores 5.5-7 x 2.4-3 microns, oblong to narrowly elliptic, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish and with a false septum, in KOH yellowish singly, yellowish tan in groups, no obvious basal truncation; basidia not revived well; paraphyses up to 12 microns wide, "clavate, oval or versiform (some mitten-shaped)", very soon becoming thick-walled, inclusion colorless in Melzer's reagent to merely yellowish; subhymenium cellular, the cells soon thick-walled; central strand of tramal plates of hyphae 2-7 microns wide, gelatinous-interwoven, colorless, "the width often indistinct because of gelatinization"; some hyphae in tramal plates becoming thick-walled; peridial subcutis composed of interwoven hyphae yellowish to colorless "with copious cinnamon incrusting pigment and coagulated cell-content (revived in KOH)", in Melzer's reagent 'with orange pigment balls and some "amyloid" debris'; peridial epicutis "forming slowly, often visible as segments of hyphae in which the walls have become thickened and are fulvous as revived in KOH", in well developed epicutis the layer of tawny interwoven thick-walled to thin-walled hyphae "with some inflation of the cells or the latter equal", "but no sphaerocysts or flagellate hyphae seen"; "no olive reaction to KOH seen on hyphae of peridium or on tramal and hymenial elements next to peridium"; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  after Molalla in Clackamas County, Oregon, where type was found
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
219
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon molligleba  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 107. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to angular fruitbody with dry appressed-fibrillose surface ocher-yellow, yellow-brown from handling, a few rhizomorphs present over basal part, spore mass soft and almost sticky and dark yellow-brown, growth under conifers, and microscopic characters including narrowly elliptic smooth spores from 6-8-spored basidia, and peridium of appressed-interwoven hyphae with rusty brown debris as revived in KOH^; rare, central ID, (Trappe(13)), type collection from ID
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  "surface merely brownish with KOH (fresh), FeSO4 scarcely olivaceous (but if ethanol is added to the spot the color changes quickly to dark olive)"^, (Smith(30)), "FeSO4 plus ethanol quickly dark olive on fresh surface", (Smith(4))
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across, "ocher-yellow, yellow-brown from handling or this color overall finally", when dried near cinnamon-brown in places^, (Smith(4)), 1-2.5cm across, spherical to angular-spherical or angular-ellipsoid; "ochre-yellow" (Ridgway color) becoming yellow-brown from handling and finally this color overall, when dried some areas near cinnamon-brown, others remaining dingy ochraceous; dry, appressed-fibrillose; "peridium very thin and when sectioned merely ochraceous changing to dull yellow-brown"; "with a few rhizomorphs present over basal part", (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "dark yellow-brown, with a cheese-like consistency in dried mature specimens", "soft and almost sticky when fresh"^, (Smith(4)), "soft and moist (almost sticky when cut)", when dried, the young specimens firm, the older ones cheesy; dark yellow-brown ("Dresden brown" Ridgway color) when mature, (Smith(30))
STEM  "a few rhizomorphs present over the basal part but no basal attachment evident"; columella none^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious under Pinus albicaulis (Whitebark Pine) and Abies (fir), August^, (Smith(30)), under alpine fir and white-bark pine, (Smith(4))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7.5-9 x 2.8-3.3 microns^; subhymenium cellular; "peridium of appressed-interwoven hyphae, with rusty brown debris as revived in KOH, some hyphae up to 15 microns wide but groups of sphaerocysts are lacking", (Smith(4)), spores 7.7-9 x 2.8-3.3 microns, oblong to narrowly elliptic, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish singly and merely yellow-brown in groups, a false septum usually present, in KOH colorless singly, yellowish in groups (revived in KOH); basidia 6-8-spored; paraphyses "ellipsoid to clavate and all thick-walled with a small central inclusion"; subhymenium "cellular and the cells with walls thickened as in the paraphyses"; hyphae of tramal plates 2-5 microns wide, filamentous, interwoven, thin-walled to thick-walled; peridium "of appressed-interwoven hyphae, as revived in KOH with some intercellular debris in epicuticular region, much rusty brown pigment intra-cellular in inner region, some hyphae inflated to 15 microns but no groups of sphaerocysts seen"; all tissues inamyloid but some dark violet particles present in Melzer's reagent; clamp connections none, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with soft spore mass'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon brunneicolor has spores a little wider, gleba not sticky when fresh, peridium duplex, and shows orange-brown pigment globules, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
220
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon monticola  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N. Y. bot. Gdn 14(2): 122. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include white underground fruitbody that becomes slowly yellowish to ochraceous with dingy lilaceous to reddish stains but does not stain reddish when injured, appressed rhizomorphs that are yellowish to clay-color, finely chambered spore-mass that is grayish olive, absent columella, surface reacting red in KOH and slowly olivaceous gray in FeSO4, and microscopic characters^; description derived from Smith(30); type found in ID (Smith(30)), rare in Pacific Northwest, distribution southwestern OR, central ID, NM, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  with KOH the surface carmine-red, with FeSO4 the surface olivaceous gray slowly
OUTER SURFACE  2-5cm across, spherical to somewhat spherical, compressed, or angular from mutual pressure, white when young, "slowly yellowish to ochraceous, mostly with dingy lilaceous to reddish stains at time of collection but not staining these colors when injured", "when dried dingy yellowish with vinaceous areas"; when young matted-fibrillose; "more or less covered with yellowish to clay-color appressed rhizomorphs"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  chambers minute, cartilaginous; grayish olive
STEM  columella none
ODOR  none
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type underground under Abies (fir) and Picea (spruce), August
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-8.5 x 2.5-3 microns, "smooth, oblong to obscurely fusoid, lacking a basal truncation", in Melzer's reagent yellowish to pale tawny, in KOH yellowish singly and dingy yellow-brown in masses^; basidia not described; paraphyses 6-9 microns wide, oblong to ellipsoid, thick-walled, with a central mass merely yellowish in Melzer's reagent; tramal plates of interwoven hyphae 2-6 microns wide, thin-walled, colorless in KOH and subgelatinous; peridium "a thin layer of appressed-interwoven hyphae as an epicutis", this layer clean and colorless to yellowish in KOH; "subcutis as revived in KOH dull red and with amorphous pigment in the layer" (appearing clean when fresh), "many hyphal cells inflated but no sphaerocysts in groups evident"; all tissue inamyloid; clamp connections none
NAME ORIGIN  means 'living in mountains'
SIMILAR  compare Rhizopogon fuscorubens
SOURCES  Smith(30), Trappe(13)
221
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon nitens  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 147. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include more or less spherical fruitbody with surface pallid when fresh but drying blackish, spore mass white drying pale tan or wood-brown, attachment by a basal rhizomorph, spore mass that becomes gray brown, and microscopic characters including smooth spores 5-6(7) x 2 microns, paraphyses that become thick-walled, and peridium with heavy incrustations of pigment-debris obscuring detail, the pigment also intracellular, slowing becoming dark olive to olive-brown in KOH, and in Melzer's reagent the layer orange-brown but without pigment balls^; data on fresh fruitbodies not available; infrequent, southwestern WA to northwestern OR, (Trappe(13)), type collection found in WA (Smith(30))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  from dried material there is an indication that the KOH reaction on fresh surface may be positive (olive)^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across, pallid fresh but dark gray as dried; possibly subviscid (when fresh), bald; attached by basal rhizomorphs^, (Smith(4)), 1-2.5cm across, spherical to nearly spherical; pallid when fresh, drying fuscous-black; when dried wrinkled and bald, somewhat shining as if it had been subviscid when fresh, (Smith(30) with data on fresh material lacking)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "white, becoming pale tan where dried but varying to wood-brown"; lacunose [chambered]^, (Smith(30) with data on fresh material lacking)
STEM  attached by basal rhizomorphs^, (Smith(4)), attached by "a basal rhizomorphs [sic]" (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under conifers^, (Smith(4)), type collection gregarious under moss, September, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-6(7) x 2 microns, colorless in KOH^; brachybasidioles becoming thick-walled; "peridium with heavy incrustations of pigment debris obscuring hyphal detail as mounted in KOH, some pigment intracellular", in Melzer's reagent the peridium "orange-brown in color but pigment globules not formed", (Smith(4)), spores 5-6(7) x 2 microns, smooth, yellowish in Melzer's reagent (often with a false septum), colorless in KOH, thin-walled; basidia clavate; paraphyses 13-20 x 7-12 microns, clavate, colorless in KOH, with internal wall thickening occurring before the gleba becomes colored; subhymenium "more or less filamentous-interwoven, many of the hyphae with thickened walls"; hyphae of tramal plates subparallel, colorless, "somewhat gelatinous and some with slightly thickened walls, oleiferous hyphae present"; peridium "with heavy incrustations of pigment-debris obscuring hyphal detail, the pigment also within the cells, slowly becoming dark olive to olive-brown in KOH", in Melzer's reagent the layer orange-brown but pigment balls not forming; clamp connections absent as far as observed, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'shining'
SIMILAR  differs from Rhizopogon brunneiniger "in the color of the spore mass, the color and color change of the peridium", and in that R. nitens lacks pigment balls as revived in Melzer's reagent, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
222
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon obscurus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 149. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to angular bald fruitbody with surface dull white, slowly staining red from handling or bruising, spore mass white slowly becoming pale olivaceous, with minute chambers, rhizomorphs few and attachment usually basal, gregarious growth under Lodgepole Pine, in KOH the surface quickly pink to vinaceous and the spore mass pinkish, in FeSO4 the surface slowly pale olive and the spore mass greenish, and microscopic characters including smooth, subfusoid to oblong spores, 4-6 spored basidia, peridium containing oleiferous hyphae and (as revived in KOH) plate-like crystals, and in inner peridial layer nests of sphaerocysts^; rare, northwestern OR, northern CA, ID, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  in KOH peridial surface quickly pink to vinaceous, in FeSO4 slowly pale olive; spore mass pinkish in KOH, greenish in FeSO4^, (Smith(30)), KOH on surface staining it pink, FeSO4 on fresh specimens slowly pale olive, (Smith(4))
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across, spherical or angular from mutual pressure; dull white, slowly staining red on bruising; bald; "rhizomorphs very few and attachment usually basal"^, (Smith(30)), 1 x 2.5cm, slowly red from handling; bald, (Smith(4))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white slowly becoming pale olivaceous; chambers minute^, (Smith(30)) 
STEM  "rhizomorphs very few and attachment usually basal"^ (Smith(30)) 
ODOR  none^ (Smith(30))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), July^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-10 x 2.5-3 microns, narrowly subfusoid to oblong (usually tapered at both ends), smooth^, in Melzer's reagent nearly colorless singly, yellowish in groups, in KOH colorless singly and in masses along hymenium, thin-walled, basal scar indistinct; basidia 4-6 spored, 14-20 x 6-8 microns, clavate; paraphyses "resembling immature basidia, thin-walled"; cystidia none; subhymenium of inflated, nonrefractive, thin-walled cells; tramal plates composed of hyphae 2-6 microns wide, colorless, smooth, refractive-gelatinous, more or less interwoven; peridium "with an epicutis of nongelatinous hyphae 4-12 microns in diam, and those near surface with ochraceous incrustations as seen in KOH both fresh and revived; nests of enlarged cells present in subcutis and this region in fresh material having a diffuse reddish pigment as observed in mounts in KOH, sections revived in KOH are hyaline in lower region, scattered ochraceous oleiferous hyphae present, many large hyaline plate-like crystals scattered in the layer (as revived in KOH)"; all parts inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30)), "peridium with an epicutis of hyphae 4-12 microns wide, near surface with ochraceous incrustations (in KOH) both in fresh and revived material, groups of enlarged cells present in subcutis and this region hyaline in KOH as revived, scattered ochraceous oleiferous hyphae present, many large plate-like crystals in the layer as revived in KOH", (Smith(4))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'dark' (Latin)
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon proximus has fuscous FeSO4 reaction on surface, lacks nests of sphaerocysts in peridium, and lacks plate-like crystals in peridial mounts revived in KOH, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
223
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon occidentalis  Zeller & C.W. Dodge^  Ann. Missouri Bot. Gard. 5: 14. 1918
ENGLISH NAMES  western Rhizopogon, western pogie
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to irregular fruitbody with a surface that is whitish becoming lemon yellow, usually staining slowly yellow to orange or reddish brown on handling (reddish only when surface actually cut), 2) loose brown rhizomorphs that stand out distinctly on dried fruitbodies against the white to yellow surface, 3) a spore mass that is pallid becoming grayish olivaceous or olive, 4) growth under conifers, 5) smooth, oblong, inamyloid spores, 6) basidia that are mostly 6-spored and 8-spored, and 7) a peridium that is one-layered, composed of appressed hyphae with oleiferous hyphae and inflated cells that are not in groups.^ It is abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). This is one of three Rhizopogon species mentioned as common for the Pacific Northwest, with R. parksii and R. ellenae, (Ammirati). RANGE Rhizopogon occidentalis is found in WA, OR, northern CA, and ID, (Trappe(13)). It is known from OR, ID, CA, (Smith(30) who examined collections also from WA but comments that at least one of them has spores about 9 x 3 microns and may be a large spored variety of the species). There is a Paul Kroeger collection from BC deposited at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 on dried peridium olive (Smith(30)), KOH on peridium lilac to red (for this group in key) (Smith(4))
OUTER SURFACE  1-6cm across, whitish at first, near lemon yellow when mature, "surface staining yellow to orange or reddish-brown slowly on handling", staining red when cut, and "as dried covered with brown rhizomorphs"^, (Smith(4)), 1-5cm across, "irregularly potato-shaped or pear-shaped; whitish at first, then lemon yellow in age, bruising orange or reddish brown; minutely hairy with loose cordlike brownish rhizomorphs", (Phillips), 1.3-8cm across, "white when young, becoming bright yellow with greenish tint, often developing some brownish to reddish areas but not rapidly staining when injured or cut"; "coated with small fibrils and more conspicuous buff to brownish or reddish brown chord-like strands", (Ammirati), 1-6cm across, spherical to irregular, ovoid, pear-shaped, etc.; surface color "whitish at first, slowly becoming yellow (finally nearly lemon-yellow)", "staining yellow to orange or reddish brown slowly on handling", (not all collections showing this change readily), staining red when cut, when dried the retaining the color of the fresh surface (whitish to pale lemon-yellow); "dry and fibrillose beneath a conspicuous coating of buff to tawny-brown rhizomorphs, and these standing out distinctly on the dried specimens", "the rhizomorph layer drying to a cinnamon-tan"; (Smith(30)), "yellowish white to yellow, often with orange to red areas, with yellow to orange rhizomorphs appressed to form a network over the entire surface, sometimes reddening slightly where bruised or cut", (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  olive drying cinnamon buff^, (Smith(4)), minutely chambered; pale yellow-orange, drying cinnamon buff, (Phillips), firm; pallid to pale greenish gray, (Ammirati), consistency "when dried rather brittle and crumbly"; "pallid becoming grayish olivaceous to olive and drying to a cinnamon-buff"; chambers large, in older specimens 0.05-0.01cm, (Smith(30)), white to gray or yellow, becoming some shade of olive or brown; at maturity dry or somewhat powdery, (Trudell), "white to gray to pale tan to olive to brown, depending on level of maturity", (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  
ODOR  none or slight (Smith(30)), sourdough (Phillips)
TASTE  sweetish^ (Arora)
EDIBILITY  no (Phillips), edible (Arora)
HABITAT  under mixed conifers^ (Smith(4)), single or scattered in sandy soil under mixed conifers, (Phillips), totally or partially underground, single or in groups, often in sandy soil, under conifers, especially Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), in fall, seems to be most common in coastal region, (Ammirati), with 2-needle and 3-needle pines "in the mountains and, especially, the pine woodlands on coastal dunes", (Trudell), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pinus (pine), (Trappe), September to March, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT
