MICROSCOPIC  spores 5.5-7 x (2)2.3-2.6(3) microns^, "peridium one-layered, of appressed hyphae 3-8 microns wide, oleiferous hyphae present, also inflated hyphal cells 10-20 microns but not in groups", (Smith(4)), spores 5.5-7 x 2.3-2.6 microns, elliptic, smooth, (Phillips), 5.5-7 x (2)2.3-2.6(3) microns, oblong, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish singly, yellowish tan in groups, in KOH yellowish to colorless singly and deeper ochraceous to dingy cinnamon-buff in masses, often with 2 oil drops; basidia mostly 6-spored and 8-spored, 14-20 x 7-9 microns, clavate, colorless, thin-walled; paraphyses "like the basidioles but in age developing thickened walls but central body not dextrinoid"; subhymenium "more or less cellular and 1-3 cells deep, not gelatinous in KOH"; tramal plates composed of hyphae 2.5-6 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, smooth, finally gelatinous-refractive; peridium "one-layered, of appressed hyphae 3-8 microns broad, if the rhizomorph-layer is included the content and/or walls are both more or less cinnamon, beneath this the hyphae with yellow to hyaline walls (revived in KOH)", (revived peridium essentially clean in subcutis but near surface there may be more amorphous debris); oleiferous hyphae present as well as enlarged hyphal cells in some of the fundamental hyphae (10-20 microns in diameter); all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30)), spores "smooth, thin-walled, and often elongated to spindle-shaped", (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'western'
SIMILAR  Species in the Rhizopogon rubescens group start white and turn yellow with maturity but turn dark brown instead of staying yellow: they also tend to turn reddish with bruising rather than yellow to orange to reddish brown, (Smith(30)). Rhizopogon luteolus differs in having distinctly wider (2.5-3.5 microns) spores, and in Melzer's reagent its peridium shows many orange-brown globules, but in KOH it is vinaceous red at first slowly fading to reddish brown, and there is much amorphous debris in the layer, (Smith(30)). See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon ellenae and Rhizopogon vinicolor.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Phillips(1)*, Lincoff(2)*, Ammirati(1)*, Trudell(4)*, Arora(1), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13), Desjardin(6)*, Siegel(2)*
224
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon ochraceisporus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N. Y. bot. Gdn 14(2): 62. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  well marked by ochraceous surface, change in KOH to rusty brown, dark cinnamon color of mature spore mass, strong dark olive reaction of spore mass to FeSO4, and relatively deep spore pigmentation, (Smith(30)), other features include dark olive reaction of FeSO4 on surface, covering of inconspicuous rhizomorphs, small chambers in spore mass, and other microscopic details^; description is derived from Smith(30); Kretzer(1) regard this species as a synonym of Rhizopogon vinicolor based on morphological similarity to that species and to R. diabolicus (for which they have molecular evidence that it should be considered a synonym of R. vinicolor); description derived from Smith(30); Rhizopogon ochraceisporus described from WA, OR, ID, (Smith(30)), common in Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  "KOH instantly dark rusty brown on the peridium, dark olive on dried specimens at times"; FeSO4 on peridial surface slowly dark olive; FeSO4 on fresh spore mass dark olive
OUTER SURFACE  2-3.5cm across, spherical, flattened, or irregular, some lobed; when fresh pale ochraceous, soon ochraceous tawny to rusty brown from handling; unpolished, "surface more or less covered by inconspicuous rhizomorphs"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "chambers small, consistency tough but moderately brittle when dry and not difficult to section"; rusty cinnamon-brown [also referred to as dark cinnamon when mature]
STEM  
ODOR  none or slight
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under fir, in duff, summer and fall, (WA and ID)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x 3.8-4.5 microns, oval, "ochraceous in KOH fresh, and brownish-ochraceous in masses along the hymenium as revived in KOH", in Melzer's reagent "yellowish singly and pale rusty brown in masses", "smooth, wall slightly thickened, with a distinct basal truncation as seen under oil immersion"^; basidia 4-spored, 6-spored, 14-20 x 4-6 microns, subcylindric, thin-walled and readily collapsing; paraphyses 12-19 x 9-12 microns, clavate to ellipsoid, thin-walled and colorless in KOH; cystidia none; "subhymenium scarcely more than 2 cells deep and not as refractive in KOH as the hyphae of the central strand"; tramal plates of subparallel to interwoven hyphae 2-4 microns wide, colorless, smooth, and gelatinous both in water mounts of fresh material and as revived in KOH; peridium "of appressed interwoven hyphae yellow in KOH, fresh and with much adhering debris", 4-12 microns wide, much branched, "fascicles of short branched crooked hyphae present forming a poorly differentiated epicutis of irregular extent, the peridium essentially a single layer"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with ochraceous spores'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Kretzer(1), Trappe(13)
225
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon ochraceobrunnescens  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 125. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical fruitbody with moist matted-fibrillose surface colored ocher yellow, staining dingy brown from handling, without conspicuous rhizomorphs, cut surface of peridium saffron yellow, spore mass grayish olive, chemical characters, and microscopic characters including smooth spores 6.5-7.5 x 2.5-3 microns and 2-layered peridium that has inner layer red in KOH and in Melzer's reagent has orange-brown pigment balls and violet-black globules^; rare, northern CA, northern ID, (Trappe(13)), found ID (rare) according to Smith(4)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH dingy reddish brown on surface, FeSO4 brownish^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  about 1.5cm across, ocher yellow, staining brown from handling^, (Smith(4)), about 1.5cm across, spherical; ocher-yellow, "becoming dingy brown where handled", "when dried dull ochraceous except for the areas that were stained brown"; moist, matted-fibrillose, "lacking any appreciable rhizomorphs"; "the cut peridium dingy saffron-yellow in section", peridium not separable, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  cartilaginous when fresh and hard when dry; "when mature grayish olive"; chambers distinct to naked eye^, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection single in conifer duff, July, (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pinus (pine), (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.5-7.5 x 2.5-3 microns^, "peridium 2-layered, the epicutis of hyphae 4-10 microns wide and ochraceous in KOH, subcutis (inner layer) red in KOH, interhyphal material rusty brown", hyphae of tramal plates thin-walled (under 0.5 microns thick) as revived in KOH, (Smith(4)), spores 6.5-7.5 x 2.5-3 microns, oblong to elliptic or subventricose, smooth, yellowish in Melzer's reagent, often with a false septum, colorless to yellowish in KOH, not truncate; basidia collapsed; paraphyses "thick-walled including the basal cells of the hymenium", central content colorless to yellowish in Melzer's reagent; tramal plates of hyphae 3-6 microns wide, filamentose, colorless, "branching divergently to the cellular layer beneath the hymenium"; "Peridium two-layered in sections, the outer ochraceous in KOH, the hyphae 4-10 microns diam, thin-walled, smooth. The inner layer red in KOH and with intercellular pigment pockets rusty brown, the hyphae in the upper layer merely yellowish hyaline, in Melzer's sol. with many orange-brown pigment balls and some large as well as small globules dark violet black." (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'ochraceous becoming brown'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
226
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon ochraceorubens  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 124. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a variously shaped fruitbody with a pale yellow to ochraceous or reddish brown surface, often mottled with red or reddish brown, sometimes reddening or turning fulvous with bruising, usually with conspicuous brown to reddish brown rhizomorphs that are intergrown with the surface, 2) a peridium that tends to slough off in patches, 3) a chambered spore mass that is whitish becoming olive to olive brown, 4) chemical characters, and 5) microscopic characters including smooth, narrowly oblong spores, 6-spored and 8-spored basidia, and a peridium with hyphal incrustations and interhyphal debris that both become magenta in KOH.^ It is abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). It is common in the Pacific Northwest (Smith(4)). RANGE It is found from WA to southern CA, ID and CO, (Trappe(13)). It is found in BC, WA, OR, ID, NM, and WY, (Smith(4)). It has also been found in AZ (States(2)) and Mexico (in States(2)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 on surface greenish to dark olive (rarely scarcely reacting), "KOH slowly tawny to reddish-brown or no reaction (reaction usually slow)"^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  2-8cm across, golden yellow to tawny or ochraceous when young, overlaid with brown rhizomorphs, russet when old, sometimes staining fulvous with injury, when dried "and in contact with naphthalene (in herbarium) vinaceous red to vinaceous brown"^, (Smith(4)), 2-8cm across, spherical, nearly spherical, ellipsoid, lobed, flattened, or irregular; pale lemon-yellow to yellow-ocher to golden yellow to tawny yellowish or finally cinnamon to russet, "sometimes unchanging when bruised but usually tending to stain tawny to fulvous from handling", when dried vinaceous-red to vinaceous-brown; usually covered with a network of rhizomorphs that are conspicuous at first but less so when old "(as the surface becomes the same color as the rhizomorphs)"; peridium sometimes showing a tendency to flake off, especially when dried, exposing pale ochraceous areas, peridium is basically thin but rhizomorphs become interwoven so that it is rather thick in some areas, (Smith(30)), 2-8cm across, "yellow to tawny or ochraceous when young", but usually overlaid with brown to reddish brown rhizomorphs, "often mottled with red or reddish brown areas" (especially when old), "sometimes reddening somewhat when bruised or discoloring brown to rusty brown", (Arora), white and quickly passing through pale luteous stage, then tawny yellowish and finally cinnamon brown, (States), bright yellow when young "with yellow rhizomorphs appressed to form a network over the entire surface, the outer rhizomorphs and peridium soon darkening to red or reddish brown"; often fruits in clusters, (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "consistency when dried somewhat friable and easy to section"; "white becoming olivaceous to olive-brown" but near cinnamon-buff when dried; chambers moderately large^, (Smith(30)), "firm or spongy becoming tough as it dries"; pallid to grayish becoming olive or olive-brown when old; minutely chambered, (Arora), chambers 2-4 per mm, (States), white at first, becoming tan, when mature olive to olive-brown or brown, (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  columella absent (Arora), free dark brown rhizomorphs at base (States)
ODOR  none at first, when old acid to acid metallic at times^, (Smith(30)), faint and unpleasant (States), mild (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  mild^ (Trappe, M.(3))
EDIBILITY  unknown (Arora)
HABITAT  single to clustered in duff under pine, mostly under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), summer and fall^, (Smith(30)), single to clustered under Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), usually found shallowly embedded in mineral soil under deep duff, (States for AZ, but notes a report by Hosford under Ponderosa Pine in the Cascades of the Pacific Northwest), with 2-needled to 3-needled pines in mountain forests, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-8 x (1.7)2-2.5(3) microns^; subhymenium cellular; hyphae of tramal plates thin-walled (under 0.5 microns thick) as revived in KOH; "peridium of rhizomorphs incorporated in a layer of appressed hyphae", hyphal incrustations and interhyphal debris vinaceous red (magenta) in KOH, "some cells inflated to 20 microns but no pockets of sphaerocysts seen, ground hyphae (excluding those of the rhizomorphs) 3-10 microns wide", (Smith(4)), spores 6-8 x (1.7)2-2.5(3) microns, narrowly oblong, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish-transparent to ochraceous and none seen with a false septum, in KOH colorless when young, yellowish at maturity, spores thin-walled, basal scar small and indistinct; basidia 6-spored and 8-spored, 12-20 x 5-7 microns, "ellipsoid to slightly clavate, thin-walled, collapsing", colorless or in chambers near peridium occasionally somewhat vinaceous in KOH; paraphyses resembling basidioles, thin-walled, colorless, collapsing; cystidia none; subhymenium "very indistinct and refractive, cellular layer consisting of basal cells of the hymenial elements"; tramal plates composed of hyphae that are subparallel to interwoven, gelatinous-refractive, smooth, thin-walled; peridium "of appressed-interwoven hyphae and rhizomorphs, the fundamental peridial hyphae usually dark vinaceous-red as revived in KOH from pigment deposits and wall incrustations, the rhizomorphs basically ochraceous in KOH but in some sections entirely vinaceous-red, or in others some red and some merely ochraceous (where there are no pigment pockets, some only red around the periphery)", "no sphaerocysts present but occasional inflated cells up to 15-20 microns present on some hyphae, hyphae mostly 3-10 microns diam and cells uninflated and thin-walled"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30)), spores 5.5-8.0 x 2.0-2.8 microns, oblong to elliptic, with two droplets, (States)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'ochraceous becoming red'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon vulgaris may become reddish and favors pines, but there are few rhizomorphs and when revived, the peridial structure is obscured by abundant reddish to orangish-brown pigmented debris (NATS). Rhizopogon fuscorubens has a peridium that dries yellow and rhizomorphs that dry black whereas R. ochraceorubens has a peridium that dries red, (Smith(30)). Rhizopogon rubescens, Rhizopogon ellenae, and Rhizopogon vinicolor may become or bruise reddish, but have wider spores. Rhizopogon alpestris A.H. Sm. and R. arenicola A.H. Sm. may be this species. See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon aurantiacus, Rhizopogon cylindrisporus, Rhizopogon isabellinus, and Rhizopogon sublateritius.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Arora(1)*, States(2), NATS(1) (Trappe, M., accessed April 6, 2005), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)*
227
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon ochroleucoides  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N. Y. bot. Gdn 14(2): 95. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include whitish fruitbody that is soon weakly yellow, when injured reddish tan on young specimens but dingy vinaceous on old ones, surface appressed matted-fibrillose to almost bald, almost free of rhizomorphs except for a basal patch (attached by these), spore-mass whitish then olive-buff then dark yellow brown, KOH reaction on surface dull vinaceous red, FeSO4 reaction on surface olivaceous, and microscopic characters^; infrequent in Pacific Northwest, distribution WA and ID, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 on fresh surface olivaceous, in KOH dull vinaceous red
OUTER SURFACE  1-5cm across, spherical or somewhat spherical or angular from mutual pressure; whitish when young, soon weakly yellow, when injured reddish tan on young specimens but dingy vinaceous on old ones; surface appressed matted-fibrillose to almost bald, almost free of rhizomorphs except for a basal patch (attached by these)
INNER LAYER  "peridium when cut slowly reddish on young specimens and croceus on old ones" [croceus is saffron-color]
INTERIOR  soft-cartilaginous when fresh and mature but bone-hard when dried; whitish then olive-buff, then dingy ochraceous, and at maturity dark yellow-brown
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious under conifers, summer and fall
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7.5-9(10.2) x 2.8-3.3 microns, oblong to subfusoid, smooth, in KOH yellowish singly and pale yellow-brown in groups, in Melzer's reagent yellow to yellow-brown, false septum often present^; basidia 8-spored, clavate; paraphyses soon thick-walled, content not coloring in Melzer's reagent; subhymenium cellular, the cells often thick-walled when old; tramal plates of interwoven hyphae 2-4 microns wide, subgelatinous, smooth; peridium "with an inner layer dark cinnamon in KOH form amorphous pigment, some cells quite enlarged" (15 microns or more), "outer layer yellowish in KOH, and with much less debris and amorphous pigment", in Melzer's reagent "many amyloid granules present and pigment balls not forming or very rare"; all hyphae inamyloid; clamp connections none
NAME ORIGIN  means 'like [Rhizopogon] ochroleucus'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon ochroleucoides is close to R. ochroleucus "but has wider and slightly longer spores, a gleba which is soon dark yellow-brown, the peridium in places retains a strong vinaceous red tinge as dried, and there characteristically is a cluster of rhizomorphs at the base", (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Trappe(13)
228
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon ochroleucus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 132. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to nearly spherical fruitbody with surface pallid, slowly becoming yellow, staining pink slightly when injured, lacking conspicuous rhizomorphs, spore mass olivaceous, growth under conifers, chemical characters, and microscopic characters including smooth, narrowly elliptic to oblong basidiospores, paraphyses with thickened walls, and inner layer of peridium fulvous from incrusting pigment^; rare, southwestern OR, ID, (Trappe(13)), found OR, ID, (Smith(30))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  "FeSO4 no reaction on fresh peridium, olivaceous on dried peridium and with KOH dull rusty brown"^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  2-6cm across, "pallid, slowly yellow, drying ocher buff, staining pink slightly when injured"^, (Smith(4)), 2-6cm across, spherical to nearly spherical; pallid when young, slowly becoming yellow and drying pale dull ocher-buff, staining pinkish slightly when fresh, when old not becoming generally reddish brown; appressed-fibrillose; lacking conspicuous rhizomorphs, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  moderately hard when dried; olivaceous fresh, dingy olivaceous when dried or nearly pale ochraceous tawny in places; large chambers^, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in duff in a campground, and under conifers, late summer and fall, (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal host in Pacific Northwest Pinus (pine), (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-8 x 2.3-3 microns^, peridium 1-layered, of appressed-interwoven hyphae 8-15 microns but with pockets of larger cells in lower peridium near the spore mass, "yellow near the surface and fulvous in the interior of the layer", (Smith(4)), spores 6-8 x 2.3-3 microns, narrowly elliptic to oblong, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish singly and in masses, in KOH yellowish singly, more ochraceous in masses, basal scar inconspicuous; basidia none found with spores attached, but spores in groups of six; paraphyses 6-9 microns broad, clavate to ovoid or ellipsoid, wall with conspicuous internal thickening and an amorphous central body not coloring in KOH or in Melzer's reagent; tramal plates of interwoven, colorless, refractive gelatinous hyphae "branching to form a filamentous to cellular hymenium"; peridium "a thick single layer of appressed-interwoven hyphae yellowish in KOH and an inner region pale fulvous to dark fulvous from incrusting pigment, pockets of enlarged cells present in the lower zone, and the entire peridium composed of ground hyphae 8-15 microns in diam with the cells often at least somewhat inflated, in the upper zone the walls free or nearly so from incrusting pigment"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'ocher-white'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon ochroleucoides is close to R. ochroleucus "but has wider and slightly longer spores, a gleba which is soon dark yellow-brown, the peridium in places retains a strong vinaceous red tinge as dried, and there characteristically is a cluster of rhizomorphs at the base", (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
229
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon odoratus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 150. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include underground growth, white surface discoloring on handling to red and then slowly to brown, whitish spore mass that becomes dark olive when mature, sweetly fragrant odor, slow red KOH reaction on surface, and microscopic characters including smooth, oblong spores, 6-8-spored basidia, and peridium of colorless non-incrusted hyphae^; found northeastern WA (Smith(4))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on fresh surface staining it slowly red, FeSO4 no reaction^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  2-6cm across, "with loosely appressed rhizomorphs, red stains developing from handling and slowly discoloring to brown"^, (Smith(4)), 2-6cm long or wide and 2-4cm thick, "flattened and irregular in outline"; "dead white and drying whitish except for adhering dirt, when handled slowly staining red and stains slowly discoloring to brown", peridium thick, 0.1cm thick fresh, but not readily separable, "white when cut but slowly staining red"; "closely appressed-fibrillose when young and fresh", dry, "with loosely appressed whitish rhizomorphs over lower half", (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  dark olive when mature^, (Smith(4)), "whitish with a flush of tan when young but at maturity dark olive to olive-fuscous"; chambers distinct, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  sweetly fragrant^ (Smith(4)), sweetly fragrant on cut fresh specimens (like that of drying Suillus subolivaceus), (Smith(30))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type under Pinus ponderosus (Ponderosa Pine), October^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.5-7.5 x 2-2.5 microns^, peridium of colorless non-incrusted hyphae (in KOH or in Melzer's reagent), no greatly inflated cells seen, (Smith(4)), spores 6.5-7.5 x 2-2.5 microns, "oblong, smooth, base in many with a fairly distinct truncation", in Melzer's reagent yellow to yellow-brown and with a false septum, in KOH colorless to yellowish singly and dingy yellow-brown in groups; basidia 6-8-spored, 6-7 microns wide, clavate; paraphyses thin-walled; tramal plates of hyphae 2-5 microns wide, colorless, smooth, gelatinous, somewhat interwoven; subhymenium cellular, the cells thin-walled; peridium a thick layer of colorless hyphae with no incrusting pigment (as revived in KOH and Melzer's reagent), "a few surface hyphae with somewhat brownish walls as revived in KOH, no nests of sphaerocysts seen but some groups (cut ends of hyphae) seen, entire layer clean as revived in KOH"; clamp connections absent; all hyphae inamyloid, (Smith(30)) 
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with an odor'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4)
230
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon olivaceofuscus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 66. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to ovoid fruitbody with surface white becoming dingy tan and often developing reddish to pinkish area, olive spore mass that stains dark gray when cut in mature stage, odor that is pungent when old, growth under conifers, KOH on surface in young specimens red to reddish brown or purplish brown, in older discolored ones dark brown to blackish, FeSO4 on surface olive-black, and microscopic characters including elliptic to oval spores from 6-8-spored basidia, and 1-layered peridium of appressed hyphae, ochraceous tawny or paler in KOH and without inflated cells^; infrequent, western OR to northern ID, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on surface causing a dark garnet brown to purplish stain (on old fruitbodies merely dark brown), another part of description states KOH reaction variable and depending on age of fruitbody: in young specimens red to reddish brown, in older discolored ones dark brown to blackish; FeSO4 olive-black, reaction quick and reliable^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-3.5cm across, white becoming pale tan then progressing to clay color [dingy tan color], "often with reddish areas, slowly staining reddish brown to reddish from handling on immature stages"^, (Smith(4)), 1-3.5cm across, spherical to ellipsoid or ovoid, outline often showing indentations; youngest specimens white, becoming dingy pale buff, "then nearly clay color and often developing reddish to pinkish areas but not staining readily when bruised, usually finally staining reddish to brown or not staining at all", dull brown when old and when dried mostly dull vinaceous red; moist, appressed-fibrillose, few rhizomorphs, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  in mature specimens staining dark gray when specimen is cut open^, (Smith(4)), "chambers labyrinthiform and moderately large (1 mm. +) sectioning easily when in dried state"; pallid when young, soon dull olive, finally when mature blackish brown, usually staining fuscous when mature fruitbodies are sectioned, but when dried dark yellow brown; in another part of the description it is stated that the spore mass is the color of a green olive at maturity, but when cut becomes fuscous to blackish brown and dries a dark yellow-brown, (Smith(30))
STEM  columella none^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  pungent when old^ (Smith(30))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under mixed conifers (spruce, fir, white pine)^, July and August, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.5-7.5 x 3.3-4 microns, pale cinnamon in KOH^, "peridium a single layer of appressed hyphae 3-9 microns wide, ochraceous-tawny or paler in KOH (as revived), no inflated cells observed", mounts in Melzer's (fresh or dried) not showing amyloid globules, (Smith(4)), spores 6.5-7.5 x 3.3-4 microns, elliptic to oval, base slightly truncate-cupped on some, smooth, revived in KOH pale cinnamon, in Melzer's reagent slightly darker; basidia 6-8-spored; paraphyses thin-walled; tramal plates "of gelatinous narrow interwoven to somewhat divergent hyphae"; subhymenium mostly filamentose but some +/- isodiametric cells at base of basidia; "some oleiferous hyphae present"; peridium a single layer of hyphae 3-9 microns wide, appressed-interwoven, ochraceous tawny or paler revived in KOH, "some incrusting debris present" (and blackish granules present in places in both KOH and Melzer's reagent); no inflated cells seen; no clamp connections present, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  'means olivaceous-fuscous'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon vinicolor differs in FeSO4 reaction and change of color of spore mass when cut (spore mass not as distinctly olive and does not change when cut); Rhizopogon parvulus has different spores (Smith(30)); in the dried state, Rhizopogon diabolicus has bright rusty cinnamon spores mass and the peridium is less red, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
231
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon olivaceoluteus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 126. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to nearly spherical fruitbody that is greenish yellow, and soon dull brown where handled, matted fibrillose and wet to touch, cartilaginous dingy yellow brown spore mass with minute chambers, growth in duff under fir, chemical characters, and microscopic characters including smooth oblong spores, and peridium of appressed interwoven hyphae 4-10 microns wide with some enlarged cells up to 15 microns and intercellular violet-black granules (and amorphous masses) in both KOH and Melzer's reagent^; rare, in ID, (Trappe(13)), type collection found in ID (Smith(30))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  surface dull yellow brown with KOH, olive-brown with FeSO4^, (Smith(30)), surface of fruiting body staining yellow-brown to dull cinnamon with KOH, (Smith(4))
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across, dull greenish yellow, soon dull brown where handled; "wet to the touch and matted-fibrillose"; without conspicuous rhizomorphs^, (Smith(4)), 1-2.5cm across, spherical to nearly spherical, dull greenish yellow when fresh, exposed surface soon dull brown where handled; matted fibrillose when fresh, wet to the touch and in drying much debris adhering to surface, rhizomorphs fine and closely appressed over the surface, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  cartilaginous, hard as bone when dried, chambers minute; dingy yellow-brown when fresh, drying dull cinnamon^, (Smith(30))
STEM  columella absent^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under alpine fir^, (Smith(4)), in conifer duff under Abies (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x 2.6-3 microns^; hyphae of tramal plates thin-walled (under 0.5 microns thick) as revived in KOH; "peridium of appressed interwoven hyphae 4-10 microns wide, some enlarged cells up to 15 microns but no nests of sphaerocysts seen", (Smith(4)), spores 7-9 x 2.6-3 microns, oblong (capsule-like), smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish singly and pale tawny in groups, in KOH yellowish singly and yellow-brown in groups, base obscurely truncate; basidia none found sporulating; paraphyses all thick-walled when mature, central body not staining in Melzer's reagent; subhymenium "cellular and most cells thick-walled"; tramal plates of hyphae 3-6 microns wide, interwoven, gelatinous, colorless, smooth; peridium "of appressed-interwoven hyphae, much amorphous pigment (dull cinnamon revived in KOH) in and between the hyphae", some enlarged hyphal cells present (up to 15 microns) but most hyphae 4-10 microns wide, no nests of sphaerocysts seen, in both KOH and Melzer's reagent violet-black granules and amorphous masses seen (intercellular); all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'olivaceous-yellow'
SIMILAR  "This species is close to R. subcitrinus [name italicized] and may be only a form of it, but the peridium does not stain red at first, it is greenish yellow when uninjured, there are copious amounts of pigment in the layer in sections revived in KOH, and the gleba dries dull cinnamon." (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
232
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon olivaceotinctus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 28. 1966;  Alpova olivaceotinctus  (A.H. Sm.) Trappe
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Rhizopogon olivaceotinctus is characterized by the combination of a sticky gelatinous spore mass with gel-filled locules, a yellow-brown peridium, and basidiospores that measure (6)8-10(12) x 3-4(5) microns, (Castellano). The spore mass is mottled yellow-brown with white streaks and exudes a latex when cut. There is an association with Abies (true fir).^ The species was included in the genus Alpova for many years but in 2001, Grubisha(1) presented molecular evidence that it is not close to the other Alpova species and should be returned to Rhizopogon. It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Rhizopogon olivaceotinctus is found from southwestern OR to southern CA, (Trappe(13)). It is found in southern OR and northern CA (Castellano).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1.5-2.5 x 2-4.5cm, spherical to lobed and irregular or elongated; peridium reviving to 0.02-0.03cm thick, "yellow brown, when dried tinged olive over dull brown"; rhizomorphs scattered^, (Castellano), 2-4.5cm across, 1.5-2.5cm deep, spherical to lobed and irregular, or elongated; "when fresh yellow-brown, when dried tinged olive over a dull brown ground color"; "faintly fibrillose over all and with scattered rhizomorphs at first", (Smith)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  spore mass exuding a latex when fresh; when dried the locules filled and separated by pallid veins, the locule contents yellow-brown^, (Castellano), exuding a latex when cut, "mottled with whitish streaks, the cavities near the peridium drying filled solid with spores, those in the mid-portion with a sulphur tinge as dried and showing powdery spores in unfilled cavities", (Smith)
STEM  
ODOR  not recorded^ (Smith)
TASTE  not recorded^ (Smith)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground, associated with various Abies (fir) species, Arbutus menziesii (Arbutus), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Quercus kelloggii (California Black Oak), (Castellano), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Abies (fir), (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (6)8-10(12) x 3-4(5) microns, "elliptic to oblong, a few subangular to subfusoid or irregular", smooth, "in KOH pale green singly, yellow-gray in mass, in Melzer's reagent pale brown-yellow singly, yellow brown in mass", the walls slightly thickened when mature^; basidia "borne among tangled, gelatinized hyphae along the locule walls but not in a palisade and, less abundantly, among gelatinizing and indistinct at early stages of development [sic]"; trama of interwoven, colorless, thin-walled hyphae 2-20 microns wide with some slightly inflated cells, "diverging to tightly interwoven, highly gelatinized cells" from the tips of which grow very indistinct, thin-walled, interwoven, colorless hyphae that fill the locules but soon autolyse, "the palisade also autolysing about the time that spores begin to form"; peridial subcutis of interwoven, colorless hyphae 2-10 microns wide with scattered, somewhat inflated cells, the walls 0.5-1.5(2) microns wide; peridial epicutis about 25 microns thick, of appressed, interwoven hyphae 2-5 microns wide with scattered inflated cells, "the walls yellow and thin to somewhat thickened, the contents brown-yellow and diffusing into the fluid of KOH mounts"; clamp connections absent, (Castellano), spores 8-10(12) x 3-4(5) microns, somewhat elliptic, some obscurely angular, many oblong, a few subfusoid, smooth, wall thickened slightly, basal scar inconspicuous, in KOH greenish transparent singly and slightly more yellowish in groups, in Melzer's reagent pale yellowish singly and pale brownish in groups; basidia soon gelatinous and indistinct, but forming a hymenium; paraphyses soon gelatinous; tramal plates "of hyaline interwoven at first nongelatinous hyphae"; peridium "with a distinct epicutis of lemon-yellow cells with pigment in the walls (revived in KOH), the hyphae appressed and many enlarged cells present", subcutis a colorless almost pseudoparenchymatic layer; clamp connections absent, all tissues inamyloid, (Smith)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'tinged olivaceous'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Castellano(1)* (as Alpova olivaceotinctus), Smith(30), Grubisha(1), Trappe(11) (as Alpova olivaceotinctus), Trappe(13)
233
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon oregonensis  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 103. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include dried surface that is dull dark ochraceous tawny to dingy pale cinnamon brown, numerous rhizomorphs, dried spore mass that is pinkish buff when young and umber brown when old, neither FeSO4 nor KOH reacting distinctively on dried peridium, and microscopic characters including spores 4.8-5.6(6) x 2.8-3.5 microns, 6-spored and 8-spored basidia, and single-layered peridium with the hyphae 4-10 microns wide, some inflated cells up to 15 microns wide present, in KOH with yellow-brown pigment in the cell sap^; fresh characters of the species are not known; rare, southwestern OR and northern CA, (Trappe(13)), type collection found in OR
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  neither FeSO4 nor KOH reacting distinctively on dried peridium^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  2-7cm across, ochraceous tawny to cinnamon brown, pale cinnamon brown when dried^, (Smith(4)), 2-7cm across, spherical to pyriform [pear-shaped] or ovoid; with numerous rhizomorphs (almost netted when fresh); when dried surface and rhizomorphs the same color: a dull dark ochraceous tawny to dingy pale cinnamon-brown; when dried "the peridium chipping off in small areas leaving pallid yellowish spots", (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  pinkish buff when dried (young) but near umber brown (old), most likely olivaceous when fresh; when dried fragile and readily sectioned, mature spore mass almost crumbly^, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection in duff under conifers, November^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-5.6 x 2.8-3.5 microns, peridium 1-layered, "the hyphae 4-10 microns wide, some inflated cells up to 15 microns wide present, in KOH with yellow-brown pigment in the cell sap"^, (Smith(4)), spores 4.8-5.6(6) x 2.8-3.5 microns, elliptic to oval, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish, in KOH colorless singly and usually with a colorless highly refractive droplet or body, scarcely ochraceous in groups, spores thin-walled, sterigmal scar inconspicuous; "Basidia clavate. Basidia 6- and 8-spored, 4.5-6 microns diam, 16-18(-26) microns long and subcylindric, hyaline, thin-walled, readily collapsing"; paraphyses 12-18 x 6-8 microns, "clavate to oval, thin-walled, with very minute refractive granules in some"; subhymenium cellular; hyphae of tramal plates interwoven, irregular, colorless in KOH, slightly refractive; peridium as single layer of hyphae interwoven, nongelatinous, 4-10 microns wide, some inflated irregularly and 15 microns more in diameter, "in KOH with a yellow-brown pigment in the cell sap and much debris in the layer but hyphal outlines remarkably clear"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'from Oregon'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon ellipsosporus.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
234
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon oswaldii  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 107. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include large fruitbody of various shapes, with surface dark brown in upper part, honey yellow near base, greenish where covered by debris, covered by heavy white tomentum when young, olive spore mass that has rather small, angular chambers and oozes a viscous liquid when cut, earthy then pungent-disagreeable odor, and microscopic characters including smooth subfusoid to oblong spores, 4-spored and 6-spored basidia, and 2-layered peridium with outer layer dingy ochraceous and inner layer fuscous brown (from numerous pigment granules and incrustations on the hyphae)^; rare, western OR and WA, (Trappe(13)), found WA, OR, and rare according to Smith(4)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2-5.5cm across, "date brown (rather dark), honey yellow around the base, where covered by debris olive-green to greenish brown, when dried blackish brown"; "when young covered by a heavy white tomentum"^, (Smith(4)), 2-8.5cm across, 2-5.5cm high, spherical, nearly spherical, compressed or turbinate [top-shaped], "often creased or furrowed, surface more or less nodulose"; 'over upper part near "raw umber" with some areas darker, around the base near honey-yellow, where covered by debris olive-green to greenish brown', when dried near "mummy brown" [blackish brown] but dingy yellowish areas showing in places; "when fresh and young covered by a heavy white conspicuous tomentum"; "basal rhizomorphs prominent, elsewhere covered by a network of fine brownish fibrils", (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  blackish brown and bone hard when dried, "olive when fresh and mature, oozing a viscous liquid when cut"^, (Smith(4)), firm, "oozing a gelatinous liquid when cut, hard when dried"; "mummy-brown" when dried, apparently olive when young and fresh; "cavities mostly open and rather small, angular"
STEM  
ODOR  earthy then pungent-disagreeable, finally offensive, somewhat like spoiled garlic^, (Smith(30))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  cespitose-gregarious in sandy soil under mixed conifers, fall^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7.5-9 x 3-3.6 microns^; "peridium separable from gleba and 2-layered, the white outer layer (on young specimens) dingy ochraceous in KOH, lower layer fuscous-brown in KOH, hyphae 4-11 microns wide, no greatly inflated cells present", (Smith(4)), spores 7.5-9 x 3-3.6 microns, "subfusoid to oblong, many obscurely angular, smooth", in Melzer's reagent pale snuff-brown or in masses darker, often showing a false septum, (in some mounts immature spores appear weakly amyloid), in KOH greenish-transparent singly, in masses pale "snuff-brown"; basidia clavate and 5-8 microns wide, when sporulating developing a long neck 9-15 x 3-4.5 microns, 4-spored and 6-spored, spores sessile or nearly so, basidia thin-walled, nongelatinous; paraphyses not distinct from basidioles, thin-walled, nongelatinous; subhymenium of branched gelatinous hyphae; tramal plates of hyphae 3-5 microns wide, closely packed, crooked, very interwoven, gelatinous; peridium 2-layered, the inner layer "fuscous in KOH from numerous pigment granules and incrustations on the hyphae" which are 4-11 microns wide, "equal in width to slightly inflated at either end or in the middle", appressed-interwoven, thin-walled, individually colorless as revived in KOH, nongelatinous, without clamp connections; the outer peridial layer dingy ochraceous as revived in KOH, with appressed-interwoven hyphae but no pigment granules; all tissues inamyloid, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  after Oswald, collector of the type
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon sipei has similar appearance when dried but has different spores, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30) (individual colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
235
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon pachyspora  Hosford^  Beih. Nova Hedwigia 51: 166. 1975
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include small size, nearly spherical, lobed fruitbodies, the surface brownish orange turning dark reddish brown where deeply bruised, drying brownish with vinaceous stains, and tomentose with single basal rhizomorph, the interior dark olive with yellowish margins and veins, growth in summer under conifers, and microscopic characters: spores 7.5-9(10) x 4.5-6.5(7) microns, with thick walls 1-1.5(2) microns thick, some irregularly shaped spores, thick-walled brachybasidioles with walls up to 2 microns thick, and a somewhat differentiated epicutis containing numerous flagellate cells^; description derived from Hosford(1); rare, western WA, (Trappe(13)), described from WA
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH quickly reddish brown on fresh surface; FeSO4 greenish fuscous to black on surface; KOH dark brown to fuscous on gleba [spore mass], FeSO4 dark olive to fuscous on gleba
OUTER SURFACE  1-1.5cm wide, nearly spherical and lobed, surface brownish orange, "turning dark reddish brown where deeply bruised, drying brownish with vinaceous stains", thin and cracking, exposing golden brown ground color of interior, surface "tomentose with a single appressed, basal, concolorous rhizomorph"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  dark olive, "with lighter (yellowish) margins and venations; texture firm-cartilaginous, drying hard but easy to section; cavities minute and difficult to see with the unaided eye"
STEM  
ODOR  none recorded
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to scattered, under moss-covered humus, in association with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), July and August
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7.5-9(10) x 4.5-6.5(7) microns, ovoid to nearly round, "triangular to variously shaped, often with lateral protrusions", wall greatly thickened, 1-1.5(2) microns thick, pale yellow singly and golden (orange) brown in masses in both KOH and Melzer's reagent^, central droplets as seen in Congo red and Phloxine, "basal scar conspicuous and broadly truncate, under oil immersion with short lateral projections on each side of basal scar"; basidia 21-34 x 6-8 microns, "clavate, thin-walled, collapsing at maturity", brachybasidioles 12-18 x 6-10 microns, clavate, developing thick gelatinous walls up to 2 microns thick, colorless in KOH but with yellow contents in Melzer's reagent; trama "broad, hyphae interwoven and gelatinous-refractive in KOH"; subhymenium "filamentous, cells at the base of brachybasidioles developing thickened walls" with yellowish contents in Melzer's reagent; context hyphae "refractive and largely obscured by pale cinnamon brown masses of intercellular pigment as observed in KOH", in Melzer's reagent context yellow, with abundant orange brown pigment globules; peridium "with an epicuticular zone of loose, branching, cinnamon brown hyphae" mostly 5-10 microns wide, often with thickened walls up to 2 microns thick, many originating in the context from swollen bases or from cells 15-25 microns in diameter and ending at surface as narrow, flagellate cells, 1-3 microns in diameter, in Melzer's reagent epicuticular hyphae orange brown; all tissues inamyloid; sphaerocysts not observed; clamp connections not seen
NAME ORIGIN  means 'thick-spored'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon vinicolor is similar on the basis of general appearance, and bruising and macrochemical reactions, but spores are different, (Hosford)
SOURCES  Hosford(1), Trappe(13)
236
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon parksii  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 76. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  dark pogie
NOTES  Features include 1) a nearly spherical to irregular fruitbody with a surface that has an overlay of dark fibrils but is pallid becoming dark brown, 2) a pinkish layer (exposed by separation of the outer layer) that soon stains blue and finally umber, (the bruising reaction also described as pink to violet), 3) an olive spore mass, 4) an inky fuscous KOH reaction on the fresh surface of the fruitbody, 5) a slowly dark olive FeSO4 reaction on the fresh surface, 6) growth in duff under Douglas-fir and Sitka spruce, and 7) microscopic characters including relatively short spores, a peridium with flagellate hyphal ends, and a peridial subcutis that is a thick layer reddish in KOH on revived material.^ Molecular evidence has been presented to support the contention that R. parksii (the holotype) is a synonym (along with a R. hawkerae paratype and R. colossus var. colossus paratypes) of R. villosulus A.H. Sm. (Martin, M.P.(2)). On the other hand, other molecular evidence suggests that R. villosulus (a different collection), R. colossus (the holotype), R. hawkerae (the same paratype), and R. villescens (non-type) are close and could be a single species that shows variation, whereas two non-type collections of R. parksii were more distant, (Grubisha(2)). Rhizopogon parksii is abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Rhizopogon parksii, using the Smith & Zeller(1966) concept, is found in WA, OR, and CA and is the most abundant Rhizopogon in the Sitka spruce zone along the coast, (Smith(4)). R. parksii occurs from southwestern BC to northern CA and ID, (Trappe(13) who list also Rhizopogon villosulus, R. villescens, and R. hawkerae, but not R. colossus). R. parksii is known from hundreds of locations in BC, western WA, western OR, and northern CA, (Castellano(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on fresh surface inky fuscous, FeSO4 slowly dark olive^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  up to 1-4cm across, nearly spherical to irregular and lobed; when young white, "staining pink to violet where bruised", when old developing a covering of dark hyphae, when mature dark gray to dark olive with brown to brown-black areas overlying dingy white; felty^, (Castellano), " 1-3cm, pallid with overlay of dark fibrils, becoming dull brown, unpolished to loosely appressed-fibrillose, the outer layer separating to expose the pinkish ground color (which soon stains blue and finally umber), as dried showing vinaceous-brown areas between the fuscous patches", (Smith(4)), 1-3cm across, spherical to oblong or irregular; "pallid with dark fibrils over it, becoming dull brown; unpolished to loosely appressed-fibrillose, the outer layer separating to expose a pinkish ground color, but this soon turning to blue and finally umber (blackish) on exposure to air, when handled staining bluish (dull indigo) and then blackish, when dried bluish fuscous with dingy vinaceous brown areas often showing between the fuscous patches", (Smith(30)), pallid to brown or pinkish, but stains dingy purple to bluish-black on surface when bruised or when old, (Arora), smudgy white when young, when mature gray to brown, when young staining slightly pink when cut or bruised, later sometimes staining gray or violet, (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white when young, soon becoming gray to olive, when mature dark olive-gray to dark olive^, (Castellano), chambers small, empty, firm but not bone-like in consistency; dull tan (pale wood-brown when dried), (Smith(30)), white when young, when mature gray to grayish olive, "sometimes with vinaceous to purple stained areas", (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  
ODOR  fungoid to pungent^ (Castellano), mild to slightly garlicky or of spicy sausage, (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  not distinctive^ (Castellano), mild to slightly garlicky or of spicy sausage, (Trappe, M.(3))
EDIBILITY  no (Phillips)
HABITAT  common particularly under Douglas-fir and Sitka spruce along the west coast^ (Smith(4)), August through December, usually found in small or large groups in duff in Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) forests (Castellano), associated with Pseudotsuga, August to December, (Trappe, M.(3)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Trappe(13))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-7 x 2.5-3 microns, elliptic to oval, smooth, colorless, thin-walled^; basidia 14-16 x 4-6 microns; trama of interwoven hyphae with walls that become gelatinous-thickened when mature; subhymenium cellular; peridium "with an epicutis of brown, loosely interwoven hyphae with thin to somewhat thickened walls, flagellate hyphal ends often common, in water or Melzer's reagent with scattered to abundant black granules than dissolve in KOH to form a green fluid", subcutis a relatively thick layer of interwoven, colorless, thin-walled hyphae, "the layer pink to red in KOH and often with red to orange amorphous debris", (Castellano), spores 5.5-6.5 x 2.3-3 microns, subelliptic, "subhymenium cellular, the cell walls gelatinous at maturity; peridium with flagellate hyphal ends; subcutis a thick layer reddish in KOH on revived material ", (Smith(4)), spores 5.5-7 x 2.3-3 microns, elliptic to ovoid, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish singly and in groups, in KOH colorless singly but pale snuff-brown in masses, with a false septum in Melzer's and in KOH, basal scar very inconspicuous; basidia 14-16 x 4-6 microns, readily collapsing; paraphyses "with end cell 14-20 x 6-12 microns, ovate, elliptic or elongate, thin-walled at first, becoming thick-walled, amorphous central inclusion not coloring in KOH, in the thick-walled stage easily breaking at the septa", thick-walled paraphyses lacking in specimens in which gleba is still white; amyloid particles appear in the hymenium in some collections; tramal plates of colorless refractive gelatinous interwoven hyphae; subhymenium "cellular and the cells with refractive-gelatinous walls but most not developing thickenings"; peridium "duplex, outer layer a loosely interwoven weft of hyphae with dull cinnamon-brown walls, sparingly to frequently branched, walls thin to thickened and smooth, flagellate hyphae ends fairly numerous, some amorphous pigment greenish in KOH along the base of this layer", subcutis "a thick (about 100 microns) layer of interwoven hyphae strongly reddish as revived in KOH" and with numerous large laticiferous hyphae colorless in KOH and yellow in Melzer's reagent (up to 20 microns wide), also in Melzer's reagent "much blackish green to blackish violet debris present on the hyphae of this layer, in KOH the zone beneath this layer including the young locules dark green, the red pigment as seen in KOH is in intercellular pockets and masses of pigment aggregated along the hyphae"; clamp connections absent; all tissues inamyloid, but some hyphal fragments amyloid, (Smith(30)), spores 4.5-6.5 x 2.3-3 microns (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  named after H.E. Parks, who collected the type
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon umbrinoviolascens shows no violaceous colors when dried, and no pinkish tones, and spore size is 6-7.5 x 2-2.5 microns, (Smith(30)). Other species associated with Douglas-fir that have woven brown hyphae in the peridium revived in KOH include Rhizopogon hawkerae (spores 6.5-8 x 2.2-2.8 microns), Rhizopogon villescens (spores 7-10 x 3-4 microns), Rhizopogon villosulus (spores 6-8 x 2.2.5 microns), Rhizopogon zelleri (spores 9-12 x 3.5-4 microns), (these four like R. parksii with at least some flagellate hyphae), Rhizopogon subareolatus (spores 6-7 x 2-2.3 microns), Rhizopogon vinicolor (spores 5.5-8 x 3-4.5 microns), and Rhizopogon subclavatisporus (spores 8-13 x 4.5-7 microns and thicker on one end), (Trappe, M.). See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon subclavitisporus.
SOURCES  Castellano(1)*, Smith(30), Smith(4), Phillips(1)*, Arora(1), NATS(1) (Trappe, M., accessed April 6, 2005), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Martin, M.P.(2), Grubisha(2), Trappe(13), Siegel(2)*
237
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon parvulus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 64. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include small size, underground growth, surface whitish color staining and becoming lilaceous to purplish, interior spore mass white then yellowish and when old fulvous, reddish KOH and olivaceous FeSO4 reaction on surface of fruitbody, and microscopic characters including smooth, elliptic to oval spores, and peridium with central area dull magenta as revived in KOH^; R. parvulus differs from R. vinicolor primarily in that is has slightly larger and often irregularly shaped spores; a paratype of R. parvulus was compared by molecular methods with R. vinicolor and found to be close if not identical to it, (Kretzer(1)); Rhizopogon parvulus type from ID (Smith(30)), but rare (Kretzer(1)), rare, northern ID, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  red on application of KOH, olivaceous with FeSO4^, (Smith(4)), KOH reddish on cutis (surface), FeSO4 olivaceous, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  0.7-1.4cm across, surface whitish, "when handled staining lilaceous to purplish" and soon this color overall^, (Smith(4)), 0.7-1.4cm across, spherical or nearly so; "whitish when young but staining lilaceous to purplish and soon entirely so colored, drying dull vinaceous", "oldest fruitbody dull clay-color and drying reddish"; dry, unpolished, lacking conspicuous rhizomorphs, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white then yellowish and when old fulvous, dried gleba sectioning readily^, (Smith(4)), "white soon yellowish and in oldest one dull fulvous, (the tramal plates blackened in drying in oldest one)"; consistency when dried "firm but not hard, sectioning easily", (Smith(30))
STEM  columella absent^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Larix (larch)^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores typically 8-10 x 4-5 microns, elliptic to oval, smooth, in Melzer's reagent ochraceous singly, but reddish fulvous in masses, in KOH ochraceous singly but dull rusty brown in masses, base distinctly to obscurely truncate, many (in some mounts) angular-round to variously angular or bifurcate at apex, 7-9 x 5-8 microns^; paraphyses thin-walled, inflated; subhymenium filamentous, with an enlarged cell at base of basidium; tramal plates of narrow gelatinous colorless hyphae; peridium "as revived in KOH with a central strand or upper half (in section) with heavy dull magenta to fulvous pigment deposits, some granular pigment deposits in epicuticular region, lower part consisting of appressed radially arranged hyphae with thin walls rather intricately interwoven"; clamp connections none; all parts inamyloid, (Smith(30)), "spores in groups in KOH dull rusty brown; peridium with central area dull magenta as revived in KOH, no greatly inflated cells noted", (Smith(4))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'little'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon subcinnamomeus has different colors and color changes of the fresh fruitbody, a wet tacky surface when mature, and spore mass hard as a bone when dried, (Smith(30)); Rhizopogon vinicolor and Rhizopogon olivaceofuscus have different spores, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Kretzer(1), Trappe(13)
238
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon pedicellus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N. Y. bot. Gdn 14(2): 41. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a white fruitbody that stains slowly pinkish when handled, 2) a white spore mass that becomes vinaceous when cut and becomes olive-green as it matures, 3) a fruitbody surface that is vinaceous fuscous with KOH and olivaceous with FeSO4, and 4) microscopic characters including spores that are amyloid but not dark violet.^ It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Rhizopogon pedicellus occurs from western OR to eastern WA and ID (Trappe(13)). It was described from ID (Smith(30)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH stains surface vinaceous fuscous; FeSO4 stains surface olivaceous, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  about 1.5cm across, spherical but outline irregular; white, "slowly staining pinkish where handled and when dried dark vinaceous-fuscous"; unpolished to fibrillose^, (Smith), white, slowly staining pinkish when handled; fibrillose, (Trappe, M.)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  minute chambers, "cutting easily when dried (in young condition)"; white, "when fresh the cut surface slowly vinaceous"^, (Smith), white when young, becoming olive-green, (Trappe, M.)
STEM  
ODOR  not distinctive^ (Trappe, M.)
TASTE  not distinctive^ (Trappe, M.)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  with Pinus (pine), Abies (fir), and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), often at higher elevations; June to November^, (Trappe, M.), in duff under Pinus, August, (Smith)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5.5-6.5(7) x 2-2.5 microns, smooth, oblong, distinctly amyloid but not dark violet in Melzer's reagent, colorless in KOH, basal scar inconspicuous^; basidia mostly 8-spored, 12-16 x 4-6 microns, colorless, collapsing; paraphyses "thin-walled (all young) resembling basidioles"; subhymenium cellular; tramal plates of interwoven, thin-walled, colorless, refractive hyphae as revived in KOH; peridium "a single layer of appressed interwoven hyphae so filled with deposits of fuscous pigment in and between the cells as to obscure all details"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none, (Smith), spores 5.5-7 x 2-2.5 microns, "bacilliform, smooth, colorless singly but grayish brown in mass, slightly gray to violet in iodine solution", (Trappe, M.)
NAME ORIGIN  'pedicellus' is Latin for 'small stalk' but reason for name is obscure
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon ellenae and Rhizopogon idahoensis are readily distinguished by their different spore characters (Smith(30)).
SOURCES  Smith(30), Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)
239
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon ponderosus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N. Y. bot. Gdn 14(2): 75. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include large size, pallid fruitbody that becomes wood-brown, the surface layer matted-fibrillose, spore mass with large cavities that is pallid becoming olive-buff to olive, KOH reaction on surface green, FeSO4 reaction olive-black, and microscopic characters^; description here derived from Smith(30); described from material collected in OR and CA, (Smith(30)), rare in the Pacific Northwest, distribution western OR to southern CA, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH stains dried surface olive to dark green; FeSO4 stains dried surface olive-black
OUTER SURFACE  3-8cm across, spherical to irregular; pallid becoming wood-brown, dark wood-brown when dried; dry and matted fibrillose, the fibrillose layer tending to rub off when fruitbody old
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "cavities large in dried material"; "pallid becoming olive-buff to olive, when dried pale dull cinnamon"
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in duff under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine) and Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), October and November, (Smith), mycorrhizal with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-12 x 3.5-4.5 microns, "basically oblong but varying to ellipsoid, subclavate or with a slight medial constriction, most having a false septum", yellowish in Melzer's reagent, colorless in KOH singly and dingy cinnamon-buff in groups^; basidia 2-spored, 4-spored, and 6-spored, 15-23 x 7-10 microns, narrowly clavate, ellipsoid, or subfusoid; "subhymenium cellular but indistinct because of refractive-gelatinous cell walls"; tramal plates of colorless, refractive, gelatinous hyphae "interwoven and cells often enlarged somewhat"; peridium with a thin epicutis of dark brown walled hyphae 3-16 microns wide, the walls thin up to 2 microns thick, "smooth, or incrusted, the cells versiform to cylindric (but no thorns projecting from them and very few with bumps), flagellate hyphal cells present"; the inner layer (peridial context) green to olive in places in KOH, the hyphae mostly colorless "but so much dull rusty brown amorphous pigment in the layer as to obscure the color of the hyphal walls, also some brown-walled hyphae occurring in the layer, this layer rather easily separating from the young glebal chambers, no oleiferous hyphae observed"; all tissues inamyloid but amyloid granules scattered along some hyphae; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  means 'heavy'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon zelleri is smaller, is more cinnamon colored when dried, has little or no pigment deposits in the peridial context, and in the material examined, the peridium was not separable, (Smith(30)); Rhizopogon colossus is similar but has spores 6-7.5 x 2.2-2.7(3) microns, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Trappe(13)
240
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon proximus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 150. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to pear-shaped, matted-fibrillose fruitbodies, the surface dull white, slowly brownish on exposed areas, staining red if injured, spore mass white to grayish (immature) and not staining when cut, with fine chambers, growth under conifers, red KOH reaction on surface, bluish black FeSO4 reaction on surface, and microscopic characters including oblong to slightly curved or somewhat fusoid spores, 6-spored basidia, and peridial layer with laticifers but no sphaerocysts, the layer dingy cinnamon as revived in KOH with some fine particles of amorphous pigment^; found eastern WA according to Smith(4), rare, northern ID, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on cutis red, FeSO4 bluish black on fresh peridium^, (Smith(4)), KOH on cutis red, FeSO4 "fuscous" (Ridgway color), very little olive evident, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  2-2.8cm across, spherical to pear-shaped; "dull white, slowly brownish on exposed areas, staining red when injured and a strong red tinge pervading the pallid superficial layer in dried specimens"; "dry, appressed-fibrillose (matted down like felt)"; "peridium thin, white when cut but soon turning red"^, (Smith(30)), 2-3cm across, "slowly brownish on exposed areas, staining red if injured"; matted-fibrillose, (Smith(4))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  firm but sectioning readily when dried; "white to grayish (all somewhat immature)", not staining when cut; chambers very fine^, (Smith(30))
STEM  columella none^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  none^ (Smith(30))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection under Larix (larch) and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), October^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-10 x 2.2-2.4 microns^, oblong to suballantoid [curved] or subfusoid, in Melzer's reagent yellowish to transparent-yellowish singly, slightly more yellowish in masses, in KOH colorless singly, yellowish in masses, thin-walled, no basal scar evident; basidia "6-spored, clavate, thin-walled"; paraphyses 8-12 microns wide, ovoid to clavate, colorless, thin-walled; subhymenium cellular; tramal plates composed of hyphae 3-6 microns wide, subparallel-interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, scarcely gelatinous; throughout tramal plates and hymenium (as revived in KOH) many minute colorless drops or granules apparently both intercellular and intracellular; peridium "of appressed interwoven filaments 3-9 microns diam, mostly of equal diameter, large laticifers (8-12 microns) also present, no groups of sphaerocysts seen, dingy cinnamon as revived in KOH with some fine particles of amorphous pigment, many fine granules also present and adhering to cells"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30)), "peridium of appressed-interwoven hyphae 3-9 microns wide, laticifers 8-12 microns wide also present, no groups of sphaerocysts seen", "layer dingy cinnamon in KOH as revived, pigment particles present and often very fine", (Smith(4))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'closest' or 'very close' (Latin)
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon obscurus has slowly pale olive reaction of peridium to FeSO4, nests of sphaerocysts in peridium, and plate-like crystals in the peridium of mounts revived in KOH, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
241
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon pseudoaffinis  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 138. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to irregular fruitbody with surface snow white slowly becoming yellowish and where injured purplish red, peridium separable at maturity, usually with basal cluster of rhizomorphs, spore mass soft and white, slowly becoming olive-buff or olive-yellowish, and more cartilaginous, growth under fir-spruce, chemical characters, and microscopic characters including oblong spores that sometimes have a faint amyloid reaction, 6-spored and 8-spored basidia, and peridium with groups of sphaerocysts and with a colored layer that is vinaceous to rusty brown in KOH^; rare, ID, (Trappe(13)), uncommon in ID (Smith(4))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 slowly pale olivaceous on white surface, with KOH dingy vinaceous^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-4cm across, snow white, "becoming yellowish and where injured purplish red"; cottony, dry-fibrillose; "usually with a basal cluster of rhizomorphs"^, (Smith(4)), 1-4cm across, spherical, nearly spherical, or irregular; at first snow white, slowly becoming yellowish and where injured purplish red; at first cottony; "attached by a more or less basal cluster of white rhizomorphs, rhizomorphs also appressed to surface in various places", especially creases and depressions; peridium separable when mature, peridium about 0.1cm thick when young, 0.05cm when old, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  soft, becoming rigid-cartilaginous; white, slowly becoming olive-buff or olive-yellowish; chambers small to medium-large (up to 0.05cm when old)^, (Smith(30))
STEM  "usually attached by a more or less basal cluster of white rhizomorphs"; no columella^, (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in clusters in the debris under Abies (fir) and Picea (spruce), summer^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.5-8 x 2.5-3 microns^; subhymenium cellular; peridium soft at first, the hyphae 4-11(20) microns wide, "groups of inflated cells present with a colored zone in KOH which is vinaceous in fresh specimens and rusty brown as revived", (Smith(4)), spores 6.5-8 x 2.5-3 microns, oblong, yellowish in Melzer's reagent, "but in 2-5% of cases where spores were attached a faint greenish blue tint is present indicating a possible weak amyloid reaction", inamyloid when mature, in KOH colorless singly but yellowish in groups along hymenium; basidia 6-spored and 8-spored, 14-18 x 6-7 microns, colorless, thin-walled, collapsing; paraphyses basidioid and thin-walled; cystidia none; subhymenium cellular, nongelatinous, and all cells thin-walled; tramal plates of hyphae that are subparallel, colorless, thin-walled, and smooth, nongelatinous in white stage of gleba but "glassy" in old specimens as revived in KOH; peridium 1-layered, composed of hyphae 4-11(20) microns wide, parallel-interwoven, appressed, loosely arranged at first and more compactly arranged when old, and groups of inflated cells present near gleba and some barrel-shaped cells up to 18 microns present in the colored layer "which is vinaceous in KOH both when fresh and revived but fades to rusty brown on standing"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)

FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon pseudoalbus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 155. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include more or less spherical fruitbody with matted-fibrillose surface colored dull white, unchanging with injury, at most a few inconspicuous rhizomorphs, spore mass gelatinous and olive brown, with very small chambers, unpleasant odor, KOH pink on fresh surface and FeSO4 olive, and microscopic characters including smooth, more or less oblong spores and peridium of appressed-interwoven hyphae 5-12 microns wide, lacking sphaerocysts and interhyphal debris^; this species is described as R. pseudoalbus A.H. Sm., but is treated as R. pseudoalbidus A.H. Sm. in Smith(4); rare, southwestern OR, central ID, (Trappe(13)), type collection from ID, (Smith(30))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH pink in fresh surface, FeSO4 olive^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, dull white; "at most with a few inconspicuous rhizomorphs"^, (Smith(4)), 1-2.5cm across, spherical to nearly spherical; dull white both when young and when old and drying pallid, no appreciable color change when injured, but when peridium cut a slight reddish tinge was evident; "dry, dull and matted-fibrillose but with only a few inconspicuous rhizomorphs", (Smith(30)) 
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  drying to a hard consistency but crumbly when being sectioned; soon decidedly gelatinous and olive-brown; with exceedingly small chambers^, (Smith(30)), "gelatinous and olive-brown when fresh, drying hard", (Smith(4))
STEM  columella none^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  unpleasant (like Calvatia fumosa)^, (Smith(4))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection under spruce-fir, August^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-7 x 2-2.2 microns^; "peridium of appressed-interwoven hyphae 5-12 microns wide, lacking sphaerocysts and interhyphal debris", (Smith(4)), spores 6-7 x 2-2.2 microns, mostly oblong to suboblong, smooth, in Melzer's reagent dingy ochraceous to colorless singly, dark yellow-brown to dull cinnamon in masses, typically with a false septum, in KOH colorless singly, near "buckthorn brown" (Ridgway color) in masses; hymenium and tramal plates "so gelatinous that little detail is visible in mounts of revived material", in Melzer's reagent the paraphyses in the chambers next to the gleba clavate and thin-walled and the tramal hyphae narrow, colorless, and smooth; peridium a clean layer (in KOH or in Melzer's reagent) of hyphae that are 5-12 microns wide, appressed-interwoven, yellowish brown (in KOH), lacking any groups of sphaerocysts, in Melzer's reagent with a few yellowish to colorless pigment balls; all hyphae inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon albidus has conspicuous rhizomorphs, cartilaginous dry spore mass when fresh, and mild odor
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4) (as R. pseudoalbidus), Trappe(13)
243
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon pseudoroseolus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N. Y. bot. Gdn 14(2): 89. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include white appressed-fibrillose fruitbodies that become flushed vinaceous without an intervening yellow stage and when dried have a speckled appearance due to sloughing of some of the surface layer, white spore mass with small chambers, FeSO4 reaction olive-blackish on surface, KOH reaction bright rose on surface, and microscopic characters including relatively large spores^; description derived from Smith(30); found in ID, MI, (Smith(30)), rare in Pacific Northwest, distribution southwestern WA to ID, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 on surface olive-blackish but no reaction on spore mass; "in KOH instantly bright rose color on surface anywhere"
OUTER SURFACE  1-1.5cm across, spherical to irregular; white at first, slowly becoming flushed vinaceous overall with no yellow intermediate stage, "when dried dark vinaceous-red but with pallid spots where the epicutis sloughs off"; appressed fibrillose at first; basal rhizomorphs only
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  chambers small; white
STEM  columella not present
ODOR  none
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in duff under Pinus (pine), Abies (fir) and Picea (spruce), spring and summer
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-10 x 3.5-4 microns (9-11 x 5 microns), subfusoid to narrowly elliptic, yellowish in Melzer's reagent, colorless in KOH singly but yellowish in groups along hymenium, smooth, thin-walled, basal scar distinct^; basidia 4-spored, 6-spored, 14-20 x 5-7 microns, thin-walled, colorless in KOH; paraphyses 16-20 x 8-12 microns, thin-walled, colorless but with 1-2 colorless refractive globules in the interior; cystidia none; "subhymenium cellular and with the same refractive granules as found in hyphae of the central strand"; tramal plates of colorless, nongelatinous, scarcely refractive, thin-walled, smooth, subparallel hyphae with highly refractive globules in the interior; peridium a loosely interwoven layer of hyphae 5-15 microns wide, "much incrusting pigment and debris in the layer and as revived in KOH dark vinaceous", in Melzer's reagent "having many large droplets of orange-brown pigment"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none
NAME ORIGIN  means 'false [Rhizopogon] roseolus'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon roseolus has spores 6.5-8 x 2.8-3.2 microns and FeSO4 has no reaction on fresh surface, (Smith(30)); Rhizopogon rubescens also starts white but turns yellowish before bruising reddish brown on the surface, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Trappe(13)
244
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon pseudovillosulus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 77. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include small size, more or less spherical fruitbody with fibrillose surface that is cinnamon-brown when fresh, (the outermost layer readily rubbing off to reveal pallid areas that soon stain bluish fuscous), olive brown spore mass, prompt olive reaction to KOH or FeSO4, and microscopic characters including smooth, oblong spores from 8-spored basidia, and peridial epicutis containing "knee-joint" cells and also flagellate hyphal ends^; infrequent, WA to southern OR and ID, (Trappe(13)), found central ID and northward, (Smith(4)), ID, OR, (Smith(30))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH instantly olive to dark olive on surface, FeSO4 instantly olive^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  0.9-1.6cm across, cinnamon-brown when fresh; dry, fibrillose^, (Smith(4)), 0.9-1.6cm across, spherical to nearly spherical; "near cinnamon-brown when collected because of the epicutis, epicutis readily separable when rubbed and subcutis then showing as pallid areas which soon stain to a bluish-fuscous (no red anywhere)"; dry and appressed-fibrillose when fresh, "very few rhizomorphs present and these loosely attached", (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  olive brown^ (Smith(4)), "chambers distinct only under a lens, when fresh the consistency moist and cartilaginous"; color "olive-brown", (Smith(30))
STEM  columella absent^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under spruce and fir with some larch present, (Smith(4)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)^, in duff under conifers (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.5-8.5 x 2-2.5 microns^, 'hyphae of epicutis containing many "knee-joint" cells and also flagellate hyphal ends', (Smith(4)), spores 6.5-8.5 x 2-2.5 microns, oblong, smooth, in Melzer's reagent dingy yellowish singly and dingy yellowish brown in groups, in KOH dingy yellowish singly and dull yellowish brown in masses, thin-walled, lacking a distinct basal truncation; basidia 8-spored; paraphyses and subhymenial cells "all thick-walled and readily disarticulating with pressure on the cover glass"; tramal plates of refractive hyphae colorless and smooth in KOH, content homogeneous, subgelatinous; peridium "with an epicutis of loosely interwoven hyphae with bister (in KOH) slightly thickened walls, the hyphae 4-10 microns diam, and with many cells knee-joint like or taking other odd shapes and up to 15 microns diam, flagellate cells also present", subcutis of mostly colorless interwoven hyphae often green in KOH (no red anywhere) "and hymenium next to peridium also often green and with deposits of green to blue-green amorphous pigment"; clamp connections none; many of the hyphae with intracellular dark violet granules as seen in Melzer's reagent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'false [Rhizopogon] pseudovillosulus'
SIMILAR  close to Rhizopogon villosulus but stains bluish fuscous on fresh subcutis and lacks any red tints in KOH either fresh or dried, (Smith(30)). See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon reae and Rhizopogon rudus.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
245
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon quercicola  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 81. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include cinnamon-brown surface with its outer layer sloughing off when dried to reveal a vinaceous red inner surface layer, cinnamon-buff spore mass that is dry, soft, and fragile, with cavities distinct to the naked eye, rhizomorph single and basal when present, underground growth under Chinquapin Oak, and microscopic characters including small narrow spores from 8-spored basidia, and peridial epicutis with some cells up to 40 microns wide^; rare, Clackamas and Wasco Counties, OR, (Trappe(13)), type found in OR (Smith(30))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2-3cm across, spherical, nearly spherical, or spherical-nodulose; dull cinnamon-brown, when dried the cinnamon-brown outer layer of the epicutis tending to slough off in patches exposing the vinaceous inner peridial layer (the inner layer also referred to as vinaceous red); "no rhizomorphs visible except for a single basal one" (in one fruitbody)^, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  very dry, soft, fragile, (when dried); near cinnamon-buff; "cavities distinct to the naked eye"^, (Smith(30)), soft and readily sectioned (when dried), near cinnamon buff when dried, (Smith(4))
STEM  single basal rhizomorph (in one fruitbody)^, (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY
