HABITAT  type collection in duff under Quercus muehlenbergii (Chinquapin Oak), October, (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-5.7 x 2-2.2 microns^; brachybasidioles thin-walled, vesiculose to clavate; hyphae of tramal plates 3-6 microns wide, nongelatinous; "subhymenium cellular; hyphae of epicutis with some cells up to 40 microns wide", (Smith(4)), spores 5.5-7 x 2-2.2 microns, oblong or nearly so, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish singly and pale tawny in masses, in KOH nearly colorless singly and yellow-brown in groups, thin-walled, no basal truncation seen; basidia 8-spored; paraphyses 10-15 x 7-9 microns, "vesiculose to clavate, thin-walled, soon collapsing"; subhymenium "cellular but often one cell deep"; hyphae of tramal plates 3-6 microns wide, subparallel, nongelatinous; peridial subcutis "reddish cinnamon in KOH, of closely interwoven hyphae, intercellular pigment incrustations present", in Melzer's reagent with cinnamon pigment balls, "no sphaerocysts seen in subcutis"; peridial epicutis of hyphae 4-12 microns wide (or variously inflated up to 40 microns, the inflated cells intercalary), loosely interwoven, cinnamon-brown in KOH, thin-walled to thick-walled, walls smooth or nearly smooth; all hyphae inamyloid; clamp connections none, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'living with oak'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
246
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon reae  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N. Y. bot. Gdn 14(2): 104. 1966 [as 'reaii']
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include pinkish white fruiting body that blackens at least when it dries, the surface covered with numerous rhizomorphs, whitish spore-mass that becomes olive-brown, rather strong odor, and microscopic characters^; the St. Louis Code 60C1a specifies that names ending in -a such as Rea add an -e, not an -ii to the name; description derived from Smith(30); type from CA, (Smith(30)), rare in the Pacific Northwest, distribution southwestern OR to southern CA, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 on dried surface olivaceous but soon fading and not leaving a stain; KOH on dried surface not leaving a permanent stain
OUTER SURFACE  1.5-3cm across, spherical or somewhat spherical or somewhat irregular; 'pale tan ("cinnamon-buff"), gradually blackening and bister to sepia or blackish as dried'; appressed-fibrillose; "more or less covered with numerous black rhizomorphs", (Smith(30) - [It is unclear whether any of these colors are based on the fresh collection - Rea's field notes are also quoted, "There were soft and felt as if they might be viscid but we are not sure of this . . . They had a rather strong odor." "Plant irregularly globular, rooting at base, deeply cracked and fissured on under side, pinkish-white covered with dirt and fibrillose scales which are raised and dark in the center. Gleba white, turning brown in spots."] )
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  chambered, "consistency when dried almost crumbly but sectioning easily"; whitish at first, becoming olive-brown
STEM  rooting at base according to Rea
ODOR  rather strong according to Rea
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type cespitose, superficial, on ground under oak
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-7.5 x 3-3.5 microns, elliptic, colorless to yellowish in KOH, in Melzer's reagent darker yellowish, "smooth, walls scarcely thickened, basal scar indistinct (base rounded)"^; basidia clavate, 6-8 microns wide, thin-walled and collapsing; "subhymenium of enlarged cells highly refractive in KOH"; tramal plates of subparallel hyphae, colorless, with "thin to slightly thickened (mucilaginous) walls"; peridium a thick, single layer of appressed-interwoven hyphae 4-11 microns wide, "but as revived in KOH with much amorphous material in the interior as well as incrusted on the walls, the pigment yellow-brown (in masses dark sepia), some inflated cells present but no groups of sphaerocysts located"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none
NAME ORIGIN  after the collectors of the type, Paul and Marion Rea
SIMILAR  compare with Rhizopogon pseudovillosulus
SOURCES  Smith(30) (color individually in double quotation marks from Ridgway(1)), Trappe(13)
247
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon rogersii  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 74. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include matted fibrillose surface that wears away to expose pallid layer, staining red when injured, chemical characters including dark olive reaction to KOH, and microscopic characters including spores 8-10 x 2.8-3.6(4) microns from 4-spored to 6-spored basidia, enlarged cells and flagellate hyphal ends in the epicutis of the peridium, greenish pigment in lower peridium where it adjoins the spore mass, and amyloid granules in peridium^; infrequent, southwestern WA and OR, (Trappe(13)), found eastern OR according to Smith(4), OR, ID, (Smith(30)), WA (Colgan(2))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 on epicutis olive-black on dried specimens, KOH stains surface dark olive^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across, "matted fibrillose, the fibrillose layer easily wearing away to expose pallid inner layer", staining red when injured (on fresh specimens)^, (Smith(4)), 1-2.5cm across, spherical or nearly so and when dried irregular in outline; apparently red when injured, but scarcely any vinaceous tinge on dried specimens; dry, "matted-fibrillose from the loosely interwoven epicutis, this easily worn away to expose portions of a pallid layer" (on the dried fruitbody), (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  firm but not hard when dried; white when young, becoming olivaceous^, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe), not given in Smith(30)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-10 x 2.8-3.6(4) microns^, "epicutis of peridium with some enlarged cells up to 20 microns wide and flagellate hyphal ends present, in KOH much dark green pigment in the area bordering the spore mass", (Smith(4)), spores 8-10 x 2.8-3.6(4) microns, elliptic to oblong or ovate, some obscurely fusoid, obscurely truncate from basal scar, in Melzer's reagent yellowish, in KOH colorless to yellowish singly and more ochraceous in groups, walls thin to slightly thickened; basidia 4-spored to 6-spored, 6-8 microns wide, clavate, when sporulating subcylindric, readily collapsing; paraphyses 7-12 microns wide, clavate to ellipsoid, thin-walled, readily collapsing; tramal plates of hyphae 3-8 microns wide, subparallel to interwoven, in KOH colorless and refractive; subhymenium "cellular to filamentose-branched, often poorly delimited"; peridium consisting of an epicutis of loosely interwoven hyphae with rusty brown walls and an inner layer of paler compactly arranged colorless to yellowish hyphae, epicutis of hyphae (2)3-10(12) microns wide, and some swollen cells in the layer up to 20 microns wide but their shape variable from subvesiculose to nearly cylindric, walls of some hyphae 3 microns or more thick, all hyphae in layer smooth, flagellate hyphae down to 1.5-2 microns near apex present in the layer, subcutis (or context) of cylindric to inflated hyphae (but no groups of sphaerocysts seen), the walls thin, the layer ochraceous tawny as revived in KOH but much dark green pigment in area where it borders on spore mass, "some amorphous material in the layer between hyphae or more or less encrusted on them", in Melzer's reagent "some hyphae with adhering granules and irregular particles of amyloid material (resembling iron filings adhering to a magnet)"; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  after D. P. Rogers, who collected the type
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon zelleri does not stain red and has slightly larger spores (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Colgan(2), Trappe(13)
248
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon roseolus  Corda sensu A.H. Sm.^
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) small size, 2) a spherical to irregular fruitbody with a surface that is white becoming rose (no yellow stage), the rose reaction intensified by KOH, 3) a spore mass that is white becoming olive, 4) absent columella, and 5) microscopic characters including narrowly elliptic spores from 6-spored basidia, and a peridium of appressed hyphae, in KOH the entire layer diffused with rose pigment.^ It is abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It is found from southern BC to northern California and the Rocky Mountains, (Trappe(13) who probably, like Trappe, M.(3) but unlike Smith, include Rhizopogon rubescens as a synonym). It is found in ID and also reported from BC and MI, according to Smith(4).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  "FeSO4 no reaction on peridium or gleba; KOH intensifies the rose color"^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-2cm across, "white when young, soon entirely rose color", (Smith(4)), 1-2cm across, spherical, flattened, or irregular; dingy rose color overall except in depressions where faintly buff-tinged; "unpolished and with scattered appressed rhizomorphs", (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "white when young, slowly becoming olive"^, (Smith(30))
STEM  columella absent^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in duff under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), July^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.5-8 x 2.8-3.2 microns^, "peridium of appressed hyphae 4-10 microns wide, in KOH the entire layer diffused with rose pigment, as revived vinaceous brown", (Smith(4)), spores 6.5-8 x 2.8-3.2 microns, narrowly elliptic to oblong, in Melzer's reagent yellowish individually and in groups, often falsely septate, in KOH colorless individually and in groups along the hymenium, thin-walled, "basal scar present but indistinct"; basidia 6-spored, 12-18 x 5-7 microns, subcylindric to clavate, colorless, thin-walled, and readily collapsing; paraphyses 10-20 x 6-11 microns, subspherical to ovoid or ellipsoid, "thin-walled, lacking a refractive body or granule"; cystidia none; subhymenium cellular; tramal plates of hyphae forming the central strand that are subparallel, colorless, thin-walled, smooth, nongelatinous, "lacking refractive globules or masses"; peridium of hyphae 4-10 microns wide, appressed, nongelatinous, "with incrustations and pigment deposits near the surface, the whole layer diffused with rose pigment (sections of fresh material mounted in KOH), no nests of enlarged cells seen", "as revived in KOH the layer vinaceous-brown and with much debris and incrusting material present"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  refers to rose color
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon rubescens is honey yellow to yellow ocher at maturity (Smith(4)), but is regarded as a synonym of R. roseolus by multiple authors. Rhizopogon albiroseus has a surface that is dull white to brownish at maturity (Smith(4)). Rhizopogon abietis becomes yellow (Smith(4)). Rhizopogon ventricosporus is ocher-yellow (Smith(4)). Rhizopogon pseudoroseolus has larger, subfusoid spores and gives a strong reaction in FeSO4, (Smith(30)).
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13), Trappe, M.(3)
249
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon rubescens  (Tul.) Tul.^  Giorn. Bot. Ital. 2: 58. 1844
ENGLISH NAMES  blushing false truffle
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to angular fruitbody that is white becoming yellowish and taking on reddish brown color when bruised, the surface cottony-fibrillose to felt-like or areolate [cracked like dried mud], 2) rhizomorphs on the surface, 3) a white spore mass that becomes olive brown, 4) chemical characters, and 5) microscopic characters including minutely punctate spores from 4-spored, 6-spored, and 8-spored basidia, and peridial hyphae heavily incrusted with amorphous reddish brown intracellular and intercellular pigment.^ |S.L. Miller distinguishes Rhizopogon rubescens from similar species in the southeastern United States with yellowish color and reddish bruising reaction (including R. abietis and R. vulgaris) by accepting only collections with "a pale yellow fresh peridium that is soon mottled with large patches of red or reddish brown, and becomes areolate in age", (Miller, S.L.(1)). |The online Species Fungorum, accessed May 23, 2016, gave this name as a synonym of Rhizopogon roseolus (Corda) Th. Fr.; Svrcek also regarded R. rubescens as a synonym of R. roseolus, (as do Trappe, M.(3), and presumably Trappe(13) who do not list R. rubescens while calling R. roseolus abundant in the Pacific Northwest). |But Smith & Zeller do not accept the synonymy because there is no mention in Corda's description of yellow colors in the description of R. roseolus, (Smith(30)). |Smith(30) describes three additional varieties whose spores are seldom over 3.5 microns wide: 1) var. pallidimaculatus (from ID, MI) has a dried spore mass showing pale yellowish streaks and spots, and fresh specimens have a fragrant odor, 2) var. ochraceus (from ID) not with the characters given for var. pallidimaculatus, spores capsule-shaped, 7-9 x 3-3.5 microns, and 3) var. rileyi (from ID) not with the characters given for var. pallidimaculatus, spores oblong to subfusoid, 6.5-8 x 2.5-3 microns. |Rhizopogon rubescens is known from across the North American continent and is probably the commonest Rhizopogon in North America, (Smith(4)). It is "often very abundant in lodgepole pine forests of our Rocky Mountains in late July and August, but known across the continent", (Smith(30)). |RANGE Collections were examined from PQ, MI, TN, VA, and France, (Miller, S.L.). Collections were examined from WA, ID, NS, PQ, AL, MI, NJ, NY, UT, VT, and WY, (Smith(30) for var. rubescens). It was reported for OR to the Oregon Truffling Association but not commonly.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 on fresh surface staining the surface greenish to olive - often slowly; "KOH causing a vinaceous red to red-brown color change"^, (Smith(30)), FeSO4 on peridial surface negative, or very slowly olive-brown, negative on spore mass; KOH on peridial surface reddish brown, in time dark brown, negative on spore mass, (Miller, S.L.)
OUTER SURFACE  1-6cm across, "when young white and cottony fibrillose, soon becoming sparsely covered with rhizomorphs, at maturity appressed fibrillose and honey yellow to yellow ochre, exposed areas reddish brown, staining pink to vinaceous red where injured"^, (Smith(4)), 1.5-6cm across, generally a lumpy potato shape; at first white, but surfaces above the ground take on a greenish olive color when old, distinctly reddening when handled, (Phillips), 1-6cm across when fresh, spherical, nearly spherical, pear-shaped, or angular from mutual pressure; when young white, becoming yellowish, eventually near honey yellow to yellow-ocher, "injured or exposed areas reddish brown and when injured the surface staining vinaceous red (pink on white basidiocarps)"; when young cottony-fibrillose overall, soon sparsely covered with rhizomorphs, eventually appressed-fibrillose, (Smith(30)), 1-3cm across, nearly spherical, ovoid, turbinate [top-shaped], or elongate-flattened, furrowed to the base; white when young, then yellowish white to pale yellow, grayish yellow or pale orange, when old mottled with brown or dark brown, young fruitbodies bruising grayish red or brownish red, older fruitbodies bruising grayish red; smooth, dry, cottony-fibrillose when young, then felty, finally appressed-felty in lower part and areolate [cracked like dried mud] in upper part; peridium in cross-section 0.05-0.1cm thick, grayish red; rhizomorphs abundant when young, prominent in lower part and on the sides, innate-appressed, white or pale yellow, bruising grayish red then dark brown, (Miller, S.L.)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  fragile and easily sectioned when dry, white and soft at first then dark olive brown, and may be gelatinous as it matures^, (Smith(4)), "white at first, then olive-buff as it matures, staining reddish when cut; finely granular", (Phillips), at first soft, becoming more cartilaginous, at maturity rather gelatinous, when dried unchanged in color, waxy, easy to section; at first white, becoming olive-buff, at maturity dark olive-brown, "when dried (old specimens) olive-tawny to olive-buff (on less mature ones)"; cavities large, 0.025-0.075cm at maturity, rarely slightly speckled as seen on sectioned fruitbodies, (Smith(30)), soft, cake-like when mature, then tough, cartilaginous, when old gelatinous and flabby; white at first, then grayish yellow to olive brown, "often mottled with lighter colors or maturing centrifugally with lighter colored tissue near the peridium"; locules 1-3 per mm, irregularly shaped, empty when mature, (Miller, S.L.)
STEM  attached by 1-2 large, cylindric or flattened rhizomorphs^, (Miller, S.L.)
ODOR  mild to disagreeable when old, (Smith(4)), slight (Phillips), none or when old at times disagreeable, like rotten cabbage, (Smith(30)), slight, sweet-fungal when young, when old strong and distinctly of road tar, (Miller, S.L.)
TASTE  slight^ (Phillips)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to cespitose under conifers especially 2-needle pine, summer and fall^, (Smith(4)), under conifers, especially pine, July to November, (Phillips), single to cespitose [clustered] under conifers, especially 2-needle pines but not limited to this group or the genus Pinus, summer and fall, (Smith(30)), underground, erumpent, or fully exposed in soil in well developed forested areas, associated with 2-needle and 3-needle pines, October to December, (Miller, S.L., for southeastern US)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-10 x 3.2-4 microns^; peridium of colorless to pale yellow hyphae "over a vinaceous brown zone with considerable debris on and between the hyphae (as seen in KOH)", (Smith(4)), |spores 6-10 x 2.5-4.5 microns, fusoid to subfusoid, (Phillips), |spores 8-10 x 3.2-4.2 microns, (some ID and WY collections placed here have spores mostly 7-8.5 x 3.3-4 microns), subfusoid to ovate, or oblong, in Melzer's reagent colorless to yellowish, in KOH nearly colorless or colorless singly for young fruitbodies, pale ochraceous singly for old fruitbodies, basal scar present but not conspicuous, spore walls slightly thickened at maturity; basidia 4-spored, 6-spored, and 8-spored as seen on revived material but mostly 8-spored, 5-7 microns wide, clavate to cylindric, colorless, soon collapsing; paraphyses 10-28 x 7-12 microns, "clavate, ovate to ellipsoid, thin-walled at first but becoming thick-walled from a mucilaginous internal deposit, eventually leaving only a small lumen filled by amorphous material", not coloring in Melzer's reagent, "the basal cells and even the subhymenial elements finally becoming thick-walled"; [cystidia not mentioned in description for this variety but occasional in var. pallidimaculatus, rare in var. rileyi]; subhymenium cellular; tramal plates composed of hyphae 3-8 microns wide, "at first floccose but becoming gelatinous, interwoven, smooth"; peridial epicutis "distinct in revived sections but not in fresh material", composed of hyphae 4-12 microns wide, appressed, colorless to pale yellow, "with the cells of various lengths from isodiametric to over 10 times as long as broad (filamentose), pigment deposits or wall incrustations absent to inconspicuous (not cluttering up the layer), the hyphal walls thin and not refractive or gelatinous"; inner layer as revived "vinaceous-brown to fulvous as seen in KOH because of much amorphous debris between and on the hyphae", the hyphae equal in diameter for the most part and 5-12 microns wide, but inflated cells up to 20 microns occurring at times, "oleiferous hyphae absent to rare and usually ochraceous in KOH"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none, (Smith(30)), |spores 7.0-10.5 x (2.5)3.0-3.5(4.5) microns, subfusoid, ovate or broadly elliptic, smooth or minutely punctate, in Melzer's reagent colorless to yellowish singly and in mass, mostly with 2-3 lipid droplets, in KOH colorless to yellowish singly and in mass, basal scar distinct but not prominent; basidia borne in a distinct hymenium, mostly 4-spored but 6-spored and 8-spored basidia also common, 15-35 x 5-7 microns, clavate, thick-walled at first, soon collapsing, brachybasidioles 10-30 x 6-12 microns, subspherical, clavate, obovate or ellipsoid, thin-walled when young, thick-walled, mucilaginous when old, easily disarticulated in crush mounts, "basidia, brachybasidioles, and spores often encrusted or filled with amorphous pigment in locules near the peridium"; subhymenium cellular, 2-4(5) cells deep, cells 5-8 microns in diameter, nearly spherical to elongated, colorless, thick-walled when old; trama of hyphae that are 2-8(10) microns wide, loosely interwoven, colorless, highly refractive, cylindric to slightly swollen, thin-walled when young, mucilaginous when old; peridium 240-450 microns thick, peridial subcutis comprises the outer part of locules near the cutis, zone thin, cells anticlinal, 10-20 x 5-9 microns in diameter, oblong, oblong-elliptic or swollen, mostly thin-walled, projecting into outermost locules, often encrusted with reddish brown pigment, peridial epicutis of hyphae that are 2-5(10) microns wide, loosely interwoven, cylindric to slightly inflated, and thin-walled or moderately thick-walled, hyphal strands frequent, innate-appressed or scattered throughout, 2-4(8) cells thick, 10-30 microns in diameter, hyphae parallel in tangential section, "spherical in cross-section, resembling nests of sphaerocysts", epicutis gelatinized when old, heavily incrusted with amorphous intracellular and intercellular pigment "that is reddish brown to dark brown in KOH, rich reddish brown in Melzer's reagent, and readily liquefies into small or large pigment globules"; clamp connections absent, (Miller, S.L.)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'becoming red'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon roseolus and Rhizopogon albiroseus lack yellow at all times in development, (Smith(4)) (but multiple authors consider R. rubescens a synonym of R. roseolus). Rhizopogon abietis has larger spores, more inflated cells in the peridium, and usually much larger paraphyses, (Smith(30)). Rhizopogon ventricosporus has larger spores, (Smith(30)). Rhizopogon vulgaris gives a strong FeSO4 reaction, has narrower spores 5.5-8 x 2-2.6 microns, lacks cystidia, and has thin-walled paraphyses, (Smith(30)). Rhizopogon subcitrinus is smaller and when dried has a bone-hard consistency, (Smith(30)). Rhizopogon occidentalis does not become red (unless cut) or dark brown, but tends to retain the bright yellow surface color, and when bruised may turn yellow to orange to reddish brown, (Smith(30)). Rhizopogon vinicolor is associated with Douglas-fir, has brown woven hyphae in the peridium, and has tramal hyphae with an ice-like or glass-like appearance, (Trappe, M.). Rhizopogon evadens var. evadens has a fresh peridium that is white, yellowish brown to grayish orange, bruising instantly magenta, and spores (5.5)6-8 x 2.5-3(3.5) as opposed to a fresh mature peridium that is pale yellow, bruising red, when old mottled with large areas of brown or dark brown, and spores 7-10.5 x (2.5)3-3.5(4.5) microns for R. rubescens, (Miller, S.L.). R. evadens and Rhizopogon ochraceorubens bruise reddish, but have narrower spores. Rhizopogon ellenae is white when young and to late maturity, when handled slowly staining avellaneous to vinaceous fuscous. See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon pseudoroseolus.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Phillips(1)*, Miller, S.L.(1) (colors mostly from Kornerup(3)), Miller(14)*, Arora(1), NATS(1) (Trappe, M., accessed April 6, 2005), Trappe(13) (referring to R. roseolus), Trappe, M.(3) (referring to R. roseolus)
250
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon rudus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N. Y. bot. Gdn 14(2): 34. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include pallid to dingy snuff-brown fruitbody that becomes cinnamon from handling, the subcutis staining bluish fuscous when the epicutis is removed, and the peridium grayish when cut, spore mass deep olive-buff with russet stains, absent columella, KOH and FeSO4 both with olive reaction on the outer surface, and microscopic characters^; description derived from Smith(30); type from ID (Smith(30)), rare in the Pacific Northwest, distribution OR, ID, NM, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  surface olive in KOH, peridium in section green in KOH; surface olive in FeSO4
OUTER SURFACE  up to 5cm across, variously shaped; "pallid at first but epicutis soon dingy snuff-brown", becoming dull cinnamon from handling (no red stains), when epicutis is removed the subcutis staining bluish fuscous; "loosely matted-fibrillose causing much dirt to adhere", "epicutis minutely areolate where protected from the dirt"
INNER LAYER  peridium grayish when cut
INTERIOR  dry, spongy; "deep olive buff with russet stains and near peridium in some places dingy rusty yellow"
STEM  columella absent
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type under ground in an old logging road near Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-7.5 x 2.2-2.5 microns, "oblong, smooth, no distinct basal scar", in Melzer's reagent "yellowish singly and in groups weakly tawny", in KOH nearly colorless singly "and in groups merely more dingy greenish-hyaline to brownish"^; basidia clavate (none seen sporulating); paraphyses "becoming thick-walled and with an amorphous central body not staining in Melzer's sol."; subhymenium "cellular and with cells beneath the basidia also tending to become thick-walled"; hyphae of tramal plates 2-5 microns wide, gelatinous, colorless, smooth, more or less interwoven; subcutis of peridium "of hyphae closely interwoven, dull cinnamon in KOH and with darker cinnamon pigment deposits both intracellular and intercellular", some giant inflated cells 25-75 microns across scattered through peridium next to the gleba, "with olive pockets as revived in KOH"; peridium "with a thin (1-3 hyphae deep and lacking over some areas) epicutis, the hyphae thin-walled or some thick-walled, dull fulvous in KOH and also with particles of incrusting pigment", many of the cells inflated to 15-20 microns across and irregular in shape, "(end-cells clavate but with irregularities, knee-joint-like, etc.)", when cylindric 4-12 microns wide; all tissues inamyloid, "with amyloid particles present in the peridial layer", no pigment balls present in Melzer's reagent; clamp connections none
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon subareolatus 1) lacks the giant cells in the peridium, 2) lacks the copious incrustations in the lower layer of the peridium as revived in KOH, and 3) has a much better developed epicutis, (Smith(30)); compare also Rhizopogon pseudovillosulus
SOURCES  Smith(30), Trappe(13)
251
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon salebrosus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 37. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to ovoid or angular fruitbody having a surface that is yellow-brown to cinnamon-brown with an overlay of vinaceous-brown rhizomorphs, 2) an spore mass with small chambers that is olive-gray becoming cinnamon-brown, 3) growth in humus under conifers, 4) chemical characters including an olive-green color change of surface to KOH, and 5) microscopic characters including smooth spores that are oblong to subfusoid or some boomerang-shaped, and weakly amyloid when young (inamyloid when mature), 8-spored basidia, and a peridium of subgelatinous hyphae with olive-fuscous pigment in pockets and along the hyphae, inflated cells present in the interior region.^ The chlorophyll-lacking plant Pterospora andromedea (pine drops) forms mycorrhizae with R. salebrosus which is ectomycorrhizal with nearby trees, (Trappe(13)). It is abundant among truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It is found from western OR to WA and ID, (Trappe(13)). Rhizopogon salebrosus was described from ID (Smith(30)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on cutis olive-green darkening to olive-black but on cut surface of peridium vinaceous, 'FeSO4 dark olive on cutis and cut peridium'^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, "yellow-brown to cinnamon-brown with an overlay of vinaceous-brown rhizomorphs"^, (Smith(4)), 1-3cm across, spherical to ovoid or ellipsoid or angular from external pressure; 'ground color about "snuff-brown" to "cinnamon-brown" and appressed fibrillose (dull cinnamon-brown)'; "rough with an over-layer of coarse darker rhizomorphs as dried dark cinnamon-brown to slightly more vinaceous"; cut peridium white and unchanging, (Smith(30)), peridium "thick, fibrous-felty"; "white at first, becoming brownish from an overlay of brown fibrils", (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  very hard-cartilaginous when fresh, hard when dry; olive-gray becoming cinnamon-brown; chambers so small as to be barely visible under 6x handlens, dark fuscous in Melzer's reagent when fresh^, (Smith(30)), white at first, when mature brown to olive-brown, (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  
ODOR  mild^ (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  mild^ (Trappe, M.(3))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in humus under fir and pine^, (Smith(30)), with Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Abies (fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Picea (spruce), year-round, (Trappe, M.(3)), associated with Pinaceae (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9(10) x 2.8-3.5(4) microns, "weakly amyloid when young, inamyloid when mature"^, inflated cells present in peridium as cut ends of cells, (Smith(4)), spores 7-9(10) x 2.8-3.5(4) microns, oblong to subfusoid or some boomerang-shaped, smooth, colorless singly in KOH, in mass pale bister, weakly amyloid (pale bluish when young and when older and browner appearing pale bister in mass), thin-walled; basidia 8-spored, cylindric when producing spores; paraphyses colorless, clavate, gelatinous, when old collapsing; tramal plates of gelatinous colorless hyphae interwoven and with no pigment incrustation; "subhymenium a cellular layer about 2 cells deep from filaments diverging from tramal strand"; peridium of subgelatinous hyphae 5-12 microns wide and with subgelatinous walls in KOH, "much olive-fuscous pigment in pockets and along the hyphae, inflated cells present in interior region", in Melzer's reagent with orange-brown pigment balls to bister or nearly violet-brown; clamp connections absent; all tissues inamyloid, (Smith(30)), spores 6-10 x 2.5-3.5 microns, (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'rough, uneven'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon subcaerulescens.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)
252
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon semireticulatus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 33. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include fruitbodies that are circular in outline, having dull whitish surface with violaceous umber stains and an overlay of numerous rhizomorphs, spore mass that is pallid becoming grayish brown, growth under conifers, chemical characters including bright vinaceous red peridium in KOH when sections revived in KOH, and microscopic characters including subfusoid spores from 8-spored basidia, and sections of fresh or recently dried material bright vinaceous-red in KOH from intercellular and intracellular pigment^; infrequent, WA and OR east to CO, (Trappe(13)), found eastern WA according to Smith(4), specimen from OR used in study (Grubisha(2))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on peridium vinaceous then fuscous brown, FeSO4 dark olive brown^, (Smith(30)), with FeSO4 on surface dark olive-brown, (Smith(4))
OUTER SURFACE  4-6.5cm across, fresh fruiting bodies "with violaceous-umber stains on a dull white ground color"; with an overlay of numerous distinct rhizomorphs^, (Smith(4)), 4-6.5cm across, 2.8-3.5cm deep, circular in outline; dull white when young and fresh, the rhizomorphs brownish, slowly spotting dull violaceous umber from handling and when dried whitish with dark umber areas and an overlay of brown rhizomorphs fairly conspicuous; "surface dry, appressed fibrillose and this layer with an overlay of rhizomorphs to give a somewhat reticulate appearance", (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "pallid becoming grayish brown"^, (Smith(4)), pallid to "wood brown", blackish with Melzer's reagent when fresh, "and when fresh dry in consistency, the chambers labyrinthiform and medium sized (visible to naked eye)", (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Larix (larch), (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal hosts in the Pacific Northwest Abies (fir), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga, (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x 2.6-3.2 microns^, "very weakly amyloid to inamyloid as they reach maturity", "sections of fresh or recently dried material bright vinaceous-red in KOH", (Smith(4)), spores 7-9(10) x 2.6-3.2 microns, mostly subfusoid, yellow to colorless singly in KOH, dingy yellowish in groups, in Melzer's reagent "dingy yellow-brown in groups with some suggestions of an amyloid reaction"; basidia 8-spored, narrowly clavate; paraphyses resembling basidia (if distinct); tramal plates "of interwoven gelatinous hyphae, near peridium often with vinaceous red content"; "subhymenium of diverging filaments with short cells often red in KOH in areas near peridium"; peridium of appressed interwoven hyphae 4-12 microns wide, "the layer bright vinaceous red in KOH from amorphous intracellular and intercellular pigment", some groups of inflated cells present and about 15 microns wide, but not true sphaerocysts; clamp connections absent; all tissues inamyloid, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'half-reticulate'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon griseovinaceus has a trichodermial type of epicutis, which is strongly olive when revived in KOH, and spores are shorter and narrower, (Smith(28))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Smith(28), Grubisha(2), Trappe(13)
253
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon semitectus  A.H. Sm.^  Journal of the Mitchell Society 84(2): 279. 1968
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include more or less spherical fruitbody with white surface and fine rhizomorphs, surface fibrils gradually cinnamon-brown, where handled staining vinaceous-brown, spore mass that is white then gray then cinnamon-brown, growth under conifers, chemical characters, and microscopic characters including smooth, somewhat oblong to irregular spores, 4-spored cystidia, and peridium with some cells inflated 15-20 microns in diameter in its outer layer, and pigment balls that are dull brownish orange in Melzer's reagent^; infrequent, OR and northern ID in mountains, (Trappe(13)), found northern ID (Smith(4))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH greenish fuscous on surface but reddish near the cavities, FeSO4 olive fuscous on surface^, (Smith(28)) 
OUTER SURFACE  2-2.5cm across, white, "surface fibrils gradually cinnamon-brown, where handled staining vinaceous-brown"; with fine rhizomorphs^, (Smith(4)), spores 2-2.5cm across, spherical or nearly so; "ground color white, covered with fine rhizomorphs, slowly developing an epicutis of colored hyphae causing it to be cinnamon brown and matted fibrillose, slowly staining dark vinaceous brown from handling", (Smith(28))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  cartilaginous and rubbery, hard when dry; white then gray, when old cinnamon-brown^, (Smith(28))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under cedar and hemlock (Smith(4)), under a cedar shake (Smith(28))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-12 x 3-4.5 microns, suboblong, some irregular or with one or two protuberances, smooth, dingy cinnamon buff in Melzer's reagent revived or fresh, or in KOH, thin-walled^; basidia 4-spored, 20-30 x 5-7.5 microns, spores sessile; basidioles remaining thin-walled; subhymenium of hyphae 2-4 microns wide, and in a palisade ending in the hymenium, not gelatinous and only somewhat refractive; tramal plates of gelatinous hyphae 3-5 microns wide that are only somewhat refractive to highly refractive; peridium when mature with an epicutis of hyphae 4-15 microns wide, the cells short to long, many inflated to 15-20 microns finally, the short cells keg-shaped to fusoid or clavate, their walls yellow ocher in KOH when fresh and greenish when revived, with copious granules and debris adhering, walls 0.5-0.8 microns thick and colorless in KOH when revived in the thick-walled cells, pigment balls dull brownish orange in Melzer's reagent, "inner layer of hyphae reddish in KOH and with some inflated cells"; clamp connections absent, (Smith(28))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'half-covered'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon clavitisporus has larger spores, a cellular subhymenium, and flagellate cells in the epicuticular layer of the peridium, (Smith(28))
SOURCES  Smith(4), Smith(28), Trappe(13)
254
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon separabilis  Zeller^  Mycologia 31(1): 3. 1939
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include whitish to pale yellow fruitbody that stains rusty brown and with the surface layer flaking off, spore mass with small empty cavities white becoming buffy-citrine, absent columella, and microscopic characters^; description derived from Smith(30); type found in OR, (Smith(30)), rare in the Pacific Northwest, distribution OR, Cascade Mountains, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1.5-4cm across, spherical to nearly spherical or irregular; white to cartridge buff [a pale yellow] with vinaceous pink spots, becoming pale yellow, changing to russet where bruised [also said to stain rusty brown], drying dingy cinnamon to dingy vinaceous brown (not fuscous); separable (the peridium flakes off), "rather smooth, sparsely covered with inconspicuous fibrils"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  cavities small and empty; white becoming buffy-citrine and drying Isabella color [a yellow brown]
STEM  columella none
ODOR  "resembling that of raw potatoes to somewhat farinaceous"
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type found in summer and fall under Pinus contorta in OR
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.5-8 x 2.5-3 microns, narrowly elliptic to subfusoid, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish singly and deeper yellow in groups, in KOH colorless singly but yellowish in groups, basal scar distinct under oil immersion^; basidia 4-spored and 6-spored, 9-15 x 4-6 microns, cylindric, soon collapsed; paraphyses 6-12 microns wide, with interior wall-thickening but no central body staining in Melzer's reagent; tramal plates "of gelatinous refractive interwoven hyphae giving rise to a cellular nongelatinous subhymenium"; peridium "as revived in KOH fulvous in the outer zone", nearly colorless next to the gleba and there having many cells enlarged up to 20 microns or more causing a weak connection to the gleba, hyphae in the highly colored zone 3-7 microns wide, "pigment in pockets and on the hyphal walls"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none
NAME ORIGIN  means 'separable', probably referring to the separable peridium layer
SIMILAR  "In R. argillascens the heavy pigment deposits are in the zone next to the gleba, not in the epicuticular zone as in R. separabilis, and in the latter the inner zone does not stain red when the fresh peridium is cut. However, the two are close enough to justify further critical study of their differences as indicated to date", (Smith(30), Latin names in italics), compare also with Rhizopogon colossus
SOURCES  Smith(30), Trappe(13)
255
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon sepelibilis  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 87. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include dark fuscous surface when dried, spore mass that is pallid buff when dried, and microscopic characters including narrowly elliptic smooth spores from 6-spored basidia, a copious amount of green pigment in sections revived in KOH, and large inflated cells in the peridial epicutis^; data on characters when fresh is lacking in Smith(30); rare in WA (Trappe(13)), type collection found in Mt. Rainier Nat. Park in WA (Smith(30))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-5cm across, spherical, when dried "evenly dark fuscous, no pattern or rhizomorphs evident"^, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  pallid buff when dried, consistency firm but not bone hard, chambers small^, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir)^, (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-7.5 x 2-2.5 microns^, epicutis of ochraceous (in KOH) hyphae with only slightly thickened walls, "the cells versiform and often cystidial (and 10-15 microns wide), greatly inflated cells up to 25 microns wide present, flagellate hyphal ends also present", (Smith(4)), spores 6-7.5 x 2-2.5 microns, oblong to narrowly elliptic, smooth, yellowish-transparent in Melzer's reagent, colorless in KOH, thin-walled, basal scar indistinct; basidia 6-spored (spores seen in groups), 12-18 x 6-9 microns, clavate, thin-walled; paraphyses "thin-walled, resembling basidioles"; subhymenium "with diverging filaments to the cellular area beneath the hymenial cells"; tramal plates of colorless, "somewhat refractive elements slightly gelatinous in KOH"; peridial epicutis "of ochraceous (in KOH) hyphal cells with only slightly thickened walls", the cells versiform - all sorts of irregular shapes, "with obtuse protrusions, irregular inflations, and often appearing to have abortive clamps or the beginnings of the development of the clamp hypha, the hyphal ends often cystidial and 10-15 microns diam, most hyphae 6-9 microns diam but greatly inflated cells up to 25 microns also present, some broadly clavate (15 microns) hyphal ends also present" as well as narrow flagellate hyphae +/- 2 microns in diameter "and occasional thick-walled hyphal segments with yellow-brown walls"; peridial inner layer "of thin-walled hyphae, the cells often very broad (20 microns) but not always inflated, many green pockets as revived in KOH, and layer blackish olive when first revived in KOH", cells often with yellowish brown pigment but fading out when old, in Melzer's reagent with amyloid particles or granules often conspicuous; clamp connections not observed with certainty, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin 'sepelibilis', 'that can be buried, that can be concealed'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
256
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon sipei  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 119. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to lobed fruitbody with surface pallid to dingy tan becoming blackish brown, lacking conspicuous rhizomorphs, spore mass dingy tan when dried, and microscopic characters including smooth cylindric to oblong spores from 6-spored to 8-spored basidia, large oleiferous hyphae in tramal plates, and peridium that is a single layer with greatly inflated cells in inner region and more filamentose toward exterior but cell outlines obscured by yellow-brown amorphous pigment^; rare in OR (Trappe(13)), found western OR according to Smith(4), type collection from OR
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  no green or olive anywhere when revived in KOH^ (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  3-9cm across, "pallid to dingy tan becoming blackish brown"^, (Smith(4)), 3-9cm across, spherical to nearly spherical or lobed; 'colors when fresh not known but as ascertained from dried material pallid to dingy tan becoming "bister" to "mummy-brown" in drying'; bald to unpolished; apparently without conspicuous rhizomorphs, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  dingy tan when dried^ (Smith(4)), dingy ochraceous-brown when dried (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir)^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-7.5 x 1.8-2.2 microns^; basal scar distinct; hyphae of tramal plates thin-walled (under 0.5 microns thick) as revived in KOH, large oleiferous hyphae present in the tramal plates; peridium a single thick layer of somewhat pseudoparenchymatous cells, with dense masses of interhyphal pigment yellowish brown in KOH, (Smith(4)), spores 6-7.5 x 1.8-2.2 microns, cylindric to oblong, smooth, yellowish to colorless in Melzer's reagent, colorless in KOH singly but pale ochraceous in groups, spores thin-walled, basal scar distinct; basidia 6-spored to 8-spored, clavate, colorless, thin-walled, readily collapsing, elongated at time of sporulation; paraphyses 8-11 microns wide, resembling basidioles, thin-walled when old; subhymenium "distinctly cellular, the walls sharply defined as seen in KOH"; tramal plates composed of hyphae 4-8 microns wide, interwoven to subparallel in arrangement, colorless, refractive, "not truly gelatinous as revived in KOH", "large oleiferous hyphae seen in the trama"; peridium "a single layer of hyphae with greatly inflated cells (almost pseudoparenchymatous in sections) in the lower region and more filamentose toward the exterior but the cell outlines all but obscured by masses of yellowish brown amorphous pigment filling most of the cells"; all tissues inamyloid "but amyloid masses scattered widely in the peridial layer and some pieces of hyphae having an amyloid content"; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  after Frank P. Sipe who collected the type
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon oswaldii has similar appearance when dried but has different spores, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
257
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon smithii  Hosford^  Beih. Nova Hedwigia 51: 164. 1975
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Rhizopogon smithii is recognized by 1) a nearly spherical to ovoid fruitbody that is pallid, quickly turning bright red with exposure or handling, the red stains changing to dingy brown, 2) a spore mass that is white becoming olive and sometimes staining ochraceous, with small chambers, 3) underground growth in sandy soil associated primarily with Pinus contorta, and 4) KOH and ethanol both giving a red reaction on fresh fruitbody surface, and FeSO4 reacting olive green to bluish green on the fresh surface.^ Hosford comments that a spotty but distinct yellow stage develops in the surface: the feature may be absent or overlooked, since the yellow phase is apparently transitory or, when present, often confined to small depressions or creases, (Hosford). The description is derived from Hosford(1). It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Rhizopogon smithii is found in western OR and northern CA, (Trappe(13)). Collections were examined from OR and CA, (Hosford(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH quickly bright red on fresh surface, ethanol quickly vivid orange-red on fresh surface, FeSO4 olive-green to bluish green on fresh surface; KOH slowly pale pink on gleba [spore mass], FeSO4 plus ethanol on gleba: "slowly bluish gray on white areas or dark olive in darker areas", ethanol on gleba no reaction
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across, nearly spherical to ovoid; "pallid with yellow hues usually developing at least in surface depressions, quickly turning bright pink upon handling or cutting, then changing to dingy brown within an hour", drying pale brown to dark brown; rhizomorphs sparse, appressed, light brown
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "white when young, becoming olive; ochraceous stains developing around damaged tissue", yellow brown when dried; chambers small, dry, cheesy in consistency when fresh, "hard when dried, but easy to section"
STEM  stem and columella absent
ODOR  not distinctive
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious, underground to partially exposed in sandy soil, especially in dune areas; associated with Pinus (pine), particularly Pinus contorta; fruiting in fall
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-7 x 2.3-2.5 microns, narrowly oblong, colorless singly in both KOH and Melzer's reagent, in masses dingy yellow in KOH and bright yellow and pseudoseptate in Melzer's reagent^; basidia colorless in KOH, thin-walled, collapsing at maturity, brachybasidioles 12-15 x 6-8 microns, "becoming thick-walled and gelatinous at maturity, subcylindric to clavate"; trama "with narrow central strand composed of thin-walled subparallel to diverging hyphae"; subhymenium "cellular, 2-3 cells deep, cells becoming thick-walled and gelatinous at maturity"; peridium of hyphae 3-8 microns wide as mounted fresh in KOH, interwoven, colorless, "with copious orange-red intercellular pigment throughout, but especially in epicuticular layer when reimbibed in KOH, hyphae in epicuticular layer yellow-brown, context hyaline and free of debris", in Melzer's reagent, "some orange brown pigment globules forming in mounts of fresh tissue"; all tissues inamyloid; no sphaerocysts noted, but some hyphal cells inflated up to 12 microns wide, especially near gleba; yellow laticiferous hyphae present; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  in honor of Dr. Alexander H. Smith "who has contributed so much to the taxonomy and knowledge of Rhizopogon" (Hosford, generic name italicized)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hosford(1), Trappe(13)
258
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon sordidus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 127. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to irregular, matted-fibrillose fruitbody with the surface yellow-ocher but soon dingy brown from handling, mostly lacking rhizomorphs, 2) a peridium with its inner layer staining red when cut, 3) a spore mass that is white becoming dingy yellowish to olive yellowish and finally dingy yellow-brown, 4) growth under pine, 5) KOH on surface pinkish cinnamon and soon fading, and 6) microscopic characters including smooth oblong spores from 4-spored, 6-spored, or 8-spored basidia, and a peridium with pockets of inflated cells and an inner layer with a heavy concentration of yellow-brown pigment and debris.^ It is rare among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Rhizopogon sordidus occurs in northern ID (Trappe(13)). It is found in eastern WA and adjacent ID according to Smith(4).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on surface pinkish cinnamon and soon fading, FeSO4 no distinct reaction^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-3.5cm across, yellow-ocher fresh, soon dingy brown from handling, dark dingy brown as dried; very few rhizomorphs evident; peridium when cut with inner layer staining red^, (Smith(4)), 1-3.5cm across, spherical, ellipsoid, or irregular from pressure; when fresh dingy but rich ocher-yellow, "slowly becoming dingy brown from handling and when dried a dull sordid brown, no white stage observed"; dry, matted-fibrillose, "mostly lacking any appressed or loosely enveloping rhizomorphs"; peridium thick, 2-layered, the outer layer somewhat separable, inner layer pallid but "pinkish cinnamon" or redder when cut, (Smith(30), color in double quotation marks from Ridgway)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white becoming dingy yellowish to olive yellowish and finally near "buckthorn-brown"; chambered, (Smith(30), color in double quotation marks from Ridgway), finally dingy yellow-brown, not hard to section when dry, (Smith(4))
STEM  columella absent^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine)^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.5-7.5 x 2.2-2.5 microns^; "pockets of inflated cells present in peridium, peridium with an epicutis of appressed-interwoven hyphae 3-8 microns wide, inner layer with heavy concentration of yellow-brown pigment and debris", hyphae of tramal plates thin-walled (under 0.5 microns thick) as revived in KOH, (Smith(4)), spores 6.5-7.5 x 2.2-2.5 microns, oblong, smooth, merely yellowish in Melzer's reagent (many with a false septum), colorless or nearly so in KOH, not truncate; basidia 4-spored, 6-spored, or 8-spored, 4-6 microns wide, cylindric, colorless; paraphyses soon thick-walled; subhymenium cellular, 1-2 cells deep; hyphae of tramal plates interwoven, colorless, and gelatinous; peridial subcutis "containing a heavy concentration of yellow-brown pigment and debris (intercellular) and with pockets of enlarged to inflated cells"; peridial epicutis composed of appressed, interwoven, colorless hyphae "with very little incrusting pigment fresh but a considerable amount in dried material revived in KOH, hyphae filamentose", 3-5(8) microns in diameter; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin 'sordidus' meaning 'dirty', probably referring to the sordid or dingy color of handled or dried fruitbodies
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
259
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon subareolatus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 81. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include pallid surface that becomes dingy vinaceous and areolate [cracked like dried mud] or warted, and often dries with a cinnamon undertone, olivaceous spore mass with small chambers that dries dull ochraceous, growth under Douglas-fir, dark olive reaction of dried surface to FeSO4, vinaceous to black reaction of surface to KOH, and microscopic characters including narrowly oblong smooth spores from 6-spored and 8-spored basidia, and peridial epicutis a collapsed trichodermium with end-cells 8-15 microns wide and clavate to cystidioid^; abundant in the Pacific Northwest, found southwestern BC to northern CA and east to CO, (Trappe(13)), type collection from OR (Smith(30)); reported from WA by Colgan(2), Paul Kroeger collection from BC deposited at University of British Columbia
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  surface "with FeSO4 dark olive, in KOH inky black in old ones, when young staining vinaceous"^, (Smith(4)), "dark olive in FeSO4 (on dried peridium), in KOH inky black on old specimen, vinaceous on young ones, with olive areas in the subcutis as revived in KOH", (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-6cm across, pallid at first, "becoming dingy vinaceous and as dried dark dingy yellow-brown (rarely with bluish dark gray areas)"; dry and unpolished, becoming areolate [cracked like dried mud]^, (Smith(4)), 1-6cm across, spherical to nearly spherical; "pallid at first and becoming dingy vinaceous, when dried with dark dingy yellow-brown or rarely with bluish fuscous areas, often with an obscure ochraceous under tone", (J. Trappe's collections placed here "were white, slowly becoming umber brown"); dry and unpolished, the surface "becoming separated into minute areolae or small warts", (Smith(30)), "Thin, dark reddish brown to grayish brown surface underlain by a whitish, pink-staining layer", "prominent dark brown rhizomorphs at base and sides", (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  olivaceous drying ochraceous^, (Smith(4)), "when dried firm and easy to section"; "pallid to olivaceous, drying dull ochraceous"; chambers small, (Smith(30)), olive brown to brown (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  
ODOR  none, but in J. Trappe's collections placed here "apparently also distinctive but variable, according to Trappe resembling fresh frankfurters, fermenting molasses, or merely pungent-fruity"^, (Smith(30)), mild to garlicky-pungent (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  mild to garlicky-pungent (Trappe, M.(3))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection in duff under pine, during fall rainy season^, (Smith(30)), associated with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir); fruiting year-round, (Trappe, M.(3)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Trappe(13))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-7 x 2-2.3 microns^, end cells of epicuticular hyphae "8-15 microns wide and clavate to cystidioid", "flagellate hyphal ends absent", (Smith(4)), spores 6-7 x 2-2.3 microns, narrowly oblong, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish-transparent singly, deeper yellowish in masses, in KOH colorless singly, dingy yellow-brown in groups, basal scar indistinct; basidia 6-spored and 8-spored, clavate, colorless, readily collapsing; paraphyses 5-10(12) microns wide, colorless in KOH, thin-walled to having wall slightly thickened when old; "subhymenium inconspicuous, of narrow basal cells at bottom of hymenium"; tramal plates "of refractive interwoven hyphae lacking colored contents and wall incrustations"; peridial inner layer of smooth to incrusted, colorless to brown hyphae "with much of the area green in KOH, amorphous dark brown to fuscous pigment pockets and incrustations copious throughout the layer", no sphaerocysts seen but some cells up to 20 microns in diameter, "oleiferous hyphae not uncommon"; peridial epicutis "in the form of a collapsed trichodermium of hyphae with rusty yellow-brown walls in KOH", the cells 8-15 microns in diameter and short, "the end-cells clavate to cystidioid, walls smooth to encrusted, no flagellate hyphal cells observed, areas of dark green in the layer as revived in KOH"; all hyphae inamyloid but amyloid particles scattered along some hyphae; clamp connections none, (Smith(30)), peridial subcutis has a characteristic red layer revived in KOH (use 25X objective), although this fades after about 5 years of dried storage to pale pink and may disappear entirely after 7-10 years, (NATS)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon hawkerae and Rhizopogon villosulus are similar Douglas-fir associated species that also have woven brown walled hyphae in the peridium revived in KOH: the former has spores 6.5-8 x 2.2-2.8 microns and occasional to abundant flagellate hyphae, and the latter lacks a red layer in the subcutis revived in KOH (may be orangish brown), whereas R. subareolatus has spores 6-7 x 2-2.3 microns, no flagellate hyphae, and subcutis with a red layer revived in KOH, (NATS), beside those two, other species associated with Douglas-fir that have woven brown hyphae in the peridium revived in KOH include Rhizopogon parksii, Rhizopogon villescens, Rhizopogon zelleri, (all with at least some flagellate hyphae), Rhizopogon vinicolor (spores 5.5-8 x 3-4.5 microns), and Rhizopogon subclavatisporus (spores 8-13 x 4.5-7 microns and thicker on one end), (NATS). See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon rudus and Rhizopogon subclavitisporus.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Colgan(2), NATS(1) (Trappe, M., accessed April 6, 2005), Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)
260
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon subbadius  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N. Y. bot. Gdn 14(2): 41.1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include white fruitbody overlaid with drab fibrils and rhizomorphs that are white around base and fawn over the upper part, the peridium pallid in section but staining slowly to brownish-vinaceous, the spore mass white becoming olive-gray, and microscopic characters^; description derived from Smith(30); found in ID, WY, (Smith(30)), infrequent in the Pacific Northwest, distribution western OR to ID and WY, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH causing a dingy vinaceous stain on surface of dried material; FeSO4 not producing color change on surface of dried material
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across, spherical to ovoid or pear-shaped; "white overlaid with drab matted-down fibrils, more or less covered with rhizomorphs that are white around the base and fawn color (vinaceous brown) over the upper part"
INNER LAYER  "pallid in section but staining slowly to brownish-vinaceous"
INTERIOR  spongy when fresh; white, becoming olive-gray
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type in duff under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-12(14) x 3.5-4.5(5) microns, "subfusoid to elliptic or oblong, some concave on dorsal line in medial section, very thin-walled and readily collapsing", in Melzer's reagent yellowish to buff in groups but "but some staining a faint greenish tone as if weakly amyloid when immature", in KOH colorless singly but dingy buff in groups^; basidia and paraphyses "nongelatinous (could not be sure that spores were born on basidia; they may be borne on conidiophores)"; tramal plates "of gelatinous highly refractive hyphae interwoven in central strand and extending out (branching) to form subhymenium"; peridium one-layered, hyphae colorless, thin-walled "and many containing dark brown pigment masses", "the layer mostly dull vinaceous brown in KOH", many of the cells up to 15-25 microns in diameter but no sphaerocysts present; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon subgelatinosus is similar but R. subbadius "appears distinct not only because of the different KOH reaction on the fresh peridium, but because the hyphae of the peridium have thinner walls and sphaerocysts were not present in pockets", (Smith(30)); Rhizopogon subcaerulescens is close but R. subbadius "has distinctly larger spores which are so thin-walled that they do not revive readily in Melzer's sol.", (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Trappe(13)
261
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon subcaerulescens  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N. Y. bot. Gdn 14(2): 44. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include whitish color becoming overlaid with cinnamon brown fibrils, fine-chambered spore-mass that is avellaneous to wood brown fresh and slightly darker as dried, absent columella, important chemical and bruising reactions, and microscopic characters^; Smith(30) describe this species as the most difficult of species of Rhizopogon to identify - the species is confusing because 1) the white appearance of the surface is completely changed by the later overlay of brown fibrils, 2) the reaction of the spores to iodine may vary with age, 3) the KOH and FeSO4 reactions vary, and 4) it apparently has several varieties; in var. viridescens described from a collection in ID there is a bright green reaction in FeSO4 instead of a bluish one; in var. subpannosus described from collections in ID and WA the fresh peridium in white stage is merely slightly vinaceous bruised (instead of often flushed bluish to purplish after handling), and the spore mass is dark cinnamon-brown to bister when mature (in var. subcaerulescens the spore mass is avellaneous to wood brown when fresh); description derived from Smith(30) for var. subcaerulescens which is found in WA, OR, ID, (Smith(30)); R. subcaerulescens abundant in Pacific Northwest, distribution WA to northern CA and east to the Rocky Mountains, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  surface dark olive in KOH, bluish in FeSO4; spore mass bluish green in FeSO4
OUTER SURFACE  1-4cm across, spherical, nearly spherical or irregular; olivaceous white, overlaid with numerous fine cinnamon brown fibrils, "unchanging when injured or slowly flushed bluish fuscous as dried"; dry, fibrillose
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  chambers 2-3 per millimeter; avellaneous to wood brown when fresh and slightly darker when dried
STEM  columella absent
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in duff under conifers, summer
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x 2.8-3.2 microns, "oblong to subfusoid, walls slightly thickened"; in KOH colorless singly, colorless to slightly tinged cinnamon along hymenium, in Melzer's reagent 'yellowish hyaline individually but in masses along hymenium pale "buckthorn-brown" and in places the groups of young ones having a bluish green tint indicating a possible weak amyloid reaction on immature spores'^; basidia 6-spored, 8-spored, 12-16 x 5-6 microns, colorless, thin-walled, basidioles thin-walled; cystidia none; "subhymenium of short broad cells only subgelatinous as revived in KOH"; tramal plates of gelatinous, highly reactive hyphae "subparallel but diverging to subhymenium", the walls colorless and lacking incrustation; peridium of appressed hyphae 4-9 microns wide, the inner zone with pigment granules in colorless hyphae "and a diffuse rose color pervading mounts of fresh material in KOH", "outer zone or layer with yellowish walls in KOH fresh", when revived in KOH no differential visible and cells somewhat "glassy", pigment pockets extending through the entire peridium and the entire layer dingy cinnamon, in Melzer's reagent the layer flushed vinaceous and orange-brown pigment globules (intercellular) abundant; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon idahoensis is close, but immature specimens of R. subcaerulescens var. subcaerulescens stain bluish with FeSO4 (compared with olive to inky-black for R. idahoensis), and vinaceous with KOH (compared with olive for R. idahoensis), and in addition spores are weakly amyloid (bluish green tint) only in some immature spores, whereas in R. idahoensis spores are still amyloid when the pigmentation has progressed to the cinnamon-buff stage, (Smith(30)); Rhizopogon subbadius is close but "has distinctly larger spores which are so thin-walled that they do not revive readily in Melzer's sol.", (Smith(30)); compare also Rhizopogon salebrosus
SOURCES  Smith(30) (color individually in double quotation marks from Ridgway(1)), Trappe(13)
262
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon subcinnamomeus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 63. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to ellipsoid fruitbody with surface wet when fresh and pale grayish tan becoming dull dark brown, staining dingy brown with handling, spore mass that is pallid to saffron becoming dark rusty brown, growth under conifers, chemical characters, and microscopic characters including truncate spores from 6-8-spored basidia, and peridium with a loosely tangled outer layer of hyphae with dark cinnamon pigment incrustations^; rare, western OR to northern ID, (Trappe(13)), found ID, (Smith(30))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH dark garnet red on fresh undamaged surface, FeSO4 olive-black on surface and on spore-mass^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across, "pale grayish tan, finally near cinnamon-brown", "peridial surface wet when fresh and soon dingy brown from handling"^, (Smith(4)), 1-2.5cm across, spherical to ellipsoid, grayish "pale pinkish buff" when fresh and young, "soon becoming dingy brown from handling as the epicutis becomes matted down", finally dull dark brown; appearing unpolished but when mature wet to the touch (not viscid), (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  pallid to croceus (saffron-colored) to dark rusty brown finally; "hard as bone when dried and not easily sectioned"^, (Smith(4)), chambers small, consistency hard like bone when dried; pallid when young becoming pale croceus, finally dark rusty brown, (Smith(30))
STEM  columella absent^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious under conifers^ (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-10 x 4-5(6.5) microns, "truncate at base, groups in KOH strongly cinnamon-colored"^; "peridium of a loosely tangled outer layer of hyphae 3-5 microns wide having dark cinnamon pigment incrustations", "subcutis (and central region) clean, red in KOH, no nests of sphaerocysts observed", (Smith(4)), spores 7-10 x 4-5(6.5) microns, "oval to elliptic, some obscurely to distinctly angular, some angular-subglobose or bifid at apex, base obviously truncate", smooth, in Melzer's reagent strongly cinnamon in groups, when revived in KOH pale ochraceous to pale cinnamon singly, strongly cinnamon in groups, (fresh spores darker in Melzer's reagent than in KOH), walls somewhat thickened; basidia 6-8-spored; paraphyses thin-walled to thick-walled; subhymenium cellular with some cells thick-walled, 2-3(4) cells deep; tramal plates of hyphae 2-4 microns wide that are interwoven, colorless, and gelatinous; peridium consisting of a loosely tangled outer layer of narrow (3-5 microns wide) hyphae with pigment incrustations (dark cinnamon as revived in KOH), subcutis of wider hyphae "forming a clean layer red in KOH fresh", "no nests of sphaerocysts seen", as revived in Melzer's reagent with small oil drops and pigment granules in the layer; clamp connections absent; all tissues inamyloid, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'near [Rhizopogon] cinnamomeus'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon parvulus has different colors and color changes of the fresh fruitbody, and lacks the characters of wet tacky surface when mature and bone-hard consistency when dried, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
263
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon subcitrinus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 133. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include more or less spherical, appressed-fibrillose fruitbody with surface dull ocher yellow, slightly pink with injury, apparently without a white stage and without obvious rhizomorphs, olive spore mass with minute chambers, brownish reaction of surface with KOH or FeSO4, and microscopic characters including smooth spores from mostly 6-spored basidia, thick-walled cells that develop in the hymenium, and peridium dull rusty brown revived in KOH with many cells short and irregular and also enlarged at the septa^; rare in ID (Trappe(13)), found ID according to Smith(4)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 pale dingy brownish (no olive tone) on fresh surface, KOH slowly dingy brown on surface but finally rusty brown^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  0.8-1.5cm across, more or less spherical; dull ocher-yellow staining pink slightly when injured, drying olive-buff; dry, appressed-fibrillose; no obvious rhizomorphs^, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  bone hard when dried; pale olive when young, darker olive when old; chambers minute^, (Smith(30))
STEM  columella absent^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in groups in duff under conifers^, (Smith(30)), under Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), (Smith(4))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7.5-9 x 2.5-3 microns^; "peridium of hyphae 3-9 microns wide, the layer dull rusty brown in KOH, many cells short and irregular and also enlarged at the septa", "peridium not showing pockets of enlarged cells", (Smith(4)), spores 7.5-9 x 2.5-3 microns, "smooth, thin-walled, hyaline in KOH or groups pale ochraceous, yellowish in Melzer's sol., often with internal local wall thickenings and many appearing as if secondarily septate, wall only very slightly thickened", basidia mostly 6-spored, hymenium mostly of chains of inflated cells 14-25 x 8-15 microns, colorless, thin-walled at first but when old some developing an interior wall thickening; subhymenium not truly present (represented by the basal cells of the structural elements of the hymenium); tramal plates composed of hyphae 3-4 microns wide (revived in KOH), branched, colorless, subgelatinous, and thin-walled, no oleiferous elements seen; peridium composed of hyphae (3)4-9 microns wide, interwoven, colorless (yellowish in Melzer's reagent), "when revived in KOH the layer dull rusty brown, many of the hyphal cells short and of irregular shape and also enlarged at the septa, some incrusting debris present, no sphaerocysts noted"; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon olivaceoluteus "is close to R. subcitrinus and may be only a form of it, but the peridium does not stain red at first, it is greenish yellow when uninjured, there are copious amounts of pigment in the layer in sections revived in KOH, and the gleba dries dull cinnamon." (Smith(30)); Rhizopogon rubescens is larger and when dried is fragile and easily sectioned, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
264
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon subclavitisporus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 53. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to ellipsoid fruitbody with surface whitish then rose-purplish and finally brownish, spore mass that is saffron-colored at first then olivaceous, then rusty brown at maturity, growth under conifers, red to garnet KOH reaction on surface, and microscopic characters including ovate to clavate spores with truncate base, 6-8-spored basidia, and peridium with scattered giant cells to 40 microns in diameter, and with flagellate hyphal ends^; rare, northwestern OR to northern ID, (Trappe(13)), found ID (Smith(30)), reported from OR by J. Smith et al.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH red on young specimens, garnet brown on old ones^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-2cm across, "whitish then rose-purplish and finally dingy clay color", (dull vinaceous when dried); dry and fibrillose^, (Smith(4)), 1-2cm across, spherical to ellipsoid; "whitish when young, soon rose purplish and finally darkening to brownish", dingy clay color when old but when dried dull vinaceous; dry and fibrillose, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "pale croceus when young, soon olivaceous and at maturity dull rusty brown"^, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in duff under mixed conifers, (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-13 x 4.5-7 microns, reddish-cinnamon in Melzer's reagent, "base truncate and cupped", "becoming thick-walled"^, "brachybasidioles with ochraceous walls in KOH", "epicutis with giant cells to 40 microns scattered in it (their walls 2-3 microns thick), some epicuticular hyphae fulvous in KOH and ochraceous flagellate hyphal ends also present", (Smith(4)), spores "9-13 x 4.5-7 microns, ovate, ventricose-ovate, to clavate, with a truncate base having a distinct cup"; smooth, in Melzer's reagent reddish cinnamon, in KOH pale yellow-cinnamon to cinnamon, becoming thick-walled; basidia 6-8-spored, becoming cylindric; paraphyses "clavate to fusoid (cystidium-like), soon thick-walled and walls ochraceous in KOH", central body not coloring in Melzer's reagent, basal cells also with thick colored wall; tramal plates of hyphae 3-7 microns wide, gelatinous, colorless, interwoven, thin-walled; subhymenium "gelatinous, filaments extending to the basal cells of paraphyses and basidia"; peridium "of interwoven hyphae with ochraceous walls and some adhering debris in epicuticular region, in subcutis with heavy masses of reddish to cinnamon pigment, giant cells scattered in epicuticular region and some fulvous hyphae (in KOH) with walls 2-3 microns thick (but not forming a layer)", some colorless to pale ochraceous flagellated hyphae also present, no olive reaction with KOH, hyphae of epicutis mostly 4-9 microns wide with inflated cells to 18 microns (giant cells to 40 microns); clamp connections none; amyloid debris present but all hyphae with inamyloid walls, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'near [Rhizopogon] clavitisporus'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon clavitisporus has blue-green reaction to KOH, has better developed epicutis, and the series of colors presented by the gleba is different, (Smith(30)); Rhizopogon ventricosporus lacks differentiated epicutis of brown-walled hyphae, (Smith(30)); other species associated with Douglas-fir that have woven brown hyphae in the peridium revived in KOH include Rhizopogon parksii (spores 4.5-6.5 x 2.3-3 microns), Rhizopogon hawkerae (spores 6.5-8 x 2.2-2.8 microns), Rhizopogon villescens (spores 7-10 x 3-4 microns), Rhizopogon villosulus (spores 6-8 x 2.2.5 microns), Rhizopogon zelleri (spores 9-12 x 3.5-4 microns), (these five with at least some flagellate hyphae), Rhizopogon subareolatus (spores 6-7 x 2-2.3 microns), and Rhizopogon vinicolor (spores 5.5-8 x 3-4.5 microns) (Trappe, M.) 
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Smith, J.E.(1), NATS(1) (Trappe, M., accessed April 6, 2005), Trappe(13)
265
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon subcroceus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 133. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to angular fruitbody with surface apricot colored, fine rhizomorphs darker, not staining where injured but cut peridium staining apricot salmon, spore mass pallid becoming olive and finally dark olive-brown, absent columella, growth under pine, KOH reaction on surface of fresh fruitbody magenta, and microscopic characters including oblong to narrowly oval spores, 4-spored and 6-spored basidia, paraphyses with 1-2 refractive globules (revived in KOH), and peridium with very little interhyphal debris or pigment^; rare in ID, (Trappe(13)), found ID, (Smith(4)), AZ (States)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 on fresh surface pale olive but dark olive in revived sections, in KOH magenta; sections of spore mass revived in FeSO4 slowly becoming dark olive^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-3cm across, apricot color when fresh, sectioned peridium staining apricot salmon; "rhizomorphs fine and darker in color than the fibrillose surface"^, (Smith(4)), 0.5-3cm across, spherical, nearly spherical, or angular from pressure; "evenly apricot-buff except for the darker rhizomorphs, surface not staining when injured" (but when fresh peridium sectioned it changes to apricot-salmon); dry, marked by lines from fine rhizomorphs, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "pallid becoming olive and finally dark olive-brown", when dried dull olive (and easily sectioned though not crumbly); chambers small and irregular^, (Smith(30))
STEM  columella absent^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  none^ (Smith(30))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious under pine, July^, (Smith(30)), singly or in clusters, in humus layer beneath litter of pinyon pine, (States for AZ)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (5.5)6-7(8.5) x 2-2.7 microns^; brachybasidioles with 1-2 highly refractive globules revived in KOH; peridium of hyphae 3-5(10) microns wide, colorless to ochraceous in KOH fresh, "some cells in lower zone 15 microns or more broad (note the cut ends of some hyphae are the same width), with very little interhyphal debris or pigment as revived in KOH", (Smith(4)), spores (5.5)6-7(8.5) x 2-2.7 microns, oblong to narrowly oval, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish singly but dextrinoid in groups, in KOH yellowish singly but pinkish-buff to cinnamon-buff in masses along hymenium, wall thickened to thin and in Melzer's reagent at times with a false septum, base of spore truncate but inconspicuously; basidia 4-spored and 6-spored, 6-7 microns wide, colorless, readily collapsing; paraphyses 15-22 x 7-11 microns, mostly subclavate, colorless "with slightly thickened walls but in the interior one or two highly refractive globules present (amorphous bodies) as revived in KOH", the amorphous bodies merely yellowish in Melzer's reagent; tramal plates composed of hyphae 2.5-5 microns wide, subparallel, colorless, smooth, gelatinous-refractive (not gelatinous-refractive when young), some inflated cells up to 10 microns in diameter that are barrel-shaped or versiform; peridium composed of hyphae 3-5(10) microns wide, appressed-interwoven, "some with incrusted walls but very little debris or pigment in sections revived in KOH, hyaline to ochraceous in KOH fresh, interior or lower layer a layer of cells up to 15 microns or more broad, interwoven and magenta in KOH fresh (hyaline as revived in KOH)"; clamp connections none, (Smith(30)), spores 6.6-8.5 x 2.5-3 microns (States)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to the color 'subcroceus' (somewhat saffron-colored) of the fruitbody
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), States(2), Trappe(13)
266
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon subgelatinosus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 42. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES
