NOTES  features include spherical to irregular fruitbody with surface white with fibrils that become gray-brown or vinaceous brown, spore mass that becomes gelatinized, growth under conifers, chemical characters including dark olive KOH reaction of fresh peridium, and microscopic characters including long spores that are dingy yellow-brown in Melzer's reagent, 6-8-spored basidia, hymenium soon entirely gelatinized, and broad subgelatinous hyphae in the peridium^; infrequent, western OR to northern CA and ID, (Trappe(13)), found in ID, (Smith(30)), specimen from OR used in study (Grubisha(2))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 olive on the fresh surface, KOH dark olive on fresh surface^, both reactions blue to olive black in one collection, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  0.8-3cm across, white, the fibrils becoming wood brown [gray-brown]^, (Smith(4)), 0.8-3cm across, spherical to nearly spherical or somewhat irregular; white; moist but fibrillose, the fibrils becoming wood-brown in places where there was pressure, very few rhizomorphs, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  rather hard when fresh and bone-like when dried; white slowly turning dark olive to olive-brown, drying grayish olive-buff; chambers very fine^, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  none^ (Smith(30))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious under mixed conifers (pine, spruce, fir)^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (8)9-12 x (2.5)3-4 microns, inamyloid^; hymenium soon becoming entirely gelatinized; "hyphae of peridium mostly with thickened translucent walls in KOH", (Smith(4)), spores (8)9-12 x (2.5)3-4 microns, subcylindric, elliptic to subfusoid (in some fruitbodies, many misshapen spores, even resembling boomerangs), smooth, 'yellowish olive in KOH fresh, dingy cinnamon-buff in masses along the hymenium as revived, with a greenish tint in Melzer's sol. fresh but as revived near "snuff-brown" (yellow-brown) in masses along the hymenium', walls thin to very slightly thickened, lacking a basal scar; basidia 6-spored, 8-spored, gelatinous in KOH and outlines not clear; basidioles also gelatinous; cystidia not seen; tramal plates of hyphae 3-8 microns wide, colorless, interwoven, gelatinous, glassy, lacking incrustations, typically flexuous [wavy], and diverging to subhymenium; subhymenium cellular but cell walls glassy as are the hyphae of the central strand; peridium about 1000 microns thick, white in section, unchanging when cut, but in KOH with magenta areas in the interior, with pockets of enlarged cells scattered through the layer and also along the surface, nearly all cell walls thickened and glassy as revived in KOH, vinaceous buff with brown pigment deposits numerous and these in Melzer's reagent becoming orange-brown globules; clamp connections absent; all tissues inamyloid, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'near [Rhizopogon] gelatinosus'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon subbadius "appears distinct not only because of the different KOH reaction on the fresh peridium, but because the hyphae of the peridium have thinner walls and sphaerocysts were not present in pockets", (Smith(30)); Rhizopogon alkalivirens has spore mass that does not become as gelatinous or as dark, spores are larger, and it lacks the reddish areas in the sections of the peridium, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Grubisha(2), Trappe(13)
267
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon sublateritius  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N. Y. bot. Gdn 14(2): 121. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include white fruitbody with yellowish areas at times but slowly becoming flushed pale brick red in places, overlaid by a netted coating of rhizomorphs, white spore mass with small chambers that becomes pale olive-gray, absent columella, and microscopic characters^; description derived from Smith(30); type found in ID (Smith(30)); rare in Pacific Northwest, distribution northern CA to northern ID, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on surface slowly ferruginous when young but negative in the type collection; FeSO4 on surface very slightly olive yellowish when young but negative in the type collection
OUTER SURFACE  1-6.5cm across, spherical to spherical-angular or angular-ovate; "white with yellowish areas at times but slowly becoming flushed pale lateritious in places or almost over all, not changing on bruising and lacking distinctly yellow colors when fresh"; "dry and unpolished beneath a coating of coarse to often loosely appressed rhizomorphs often forming a wide meshed reticulum and at the base often in a cluster at place of attachment"
INNER LAYER  peridium very thin and unchanging when cut
INTERIOR  "dry in consistency when fresh, chambers very small"; "white becoming pale olive-gray"
STEM  columella absent
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type in arcs under Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5.5-7.5(8) x 2-2.3 microns, oblong to elliptic, in Melzer's reagent colorless to yellowish singly, cinnamon-buff in masses, in KOH colorless singly, pale dingy cinnamon-buff in masses, "typically with two large oil droplets as seen revived in KOH"^; basidia "cylindric to clavate when sporulating, mostly 6-spored"; paraphyses colorless in KOH, thin-walled at first, slowly becoming somewhat thick-walled; "subhymenium filamentous and diverging from central strand and ending in enlarged cells at base of basidium"; tramal plates of interwoven, narrow, gelatinous, colorless hyphae as revived in KOH; peridium of interwoven-appressed, mostly colorless hyphae 4-10 microns wide with some groups of enlarged cells up to 18 microns in diameter, in epicuticular region the walls tawny to brick-red both in KOH and Melzer's reagent, "at least over most areas and some incrusting debris present, but interior region almost lacking debris (clean) and unpigmented"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon ochraceorubens has a different color pattern and there is distinct color change in drying, whereas with R. sublateritius there is scarcely any color change in drying, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Trappe(13)
268
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon subolivascens  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 104. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include ovoid, dry, appressed-fibrillose fruitbody about 1.5cm across, dull rusty ochraceous when fresh, staining olive where handled, when dried dingy vinaceous brown, spore mass dark olive when mature and the same color but hard as bone when dried, the cavities minute, growth under conifers, KOH reaction on fresh peridial surface dingy vinaceous, FeSO4 slowly dark olive but fading, and no reaction on dried specimens, and microscopic characters including spores 7-8.5 x 3.5-4 microns, ovate to angular-ovate, smooth, and truncate at base, 4-spored, 6-spored, and 8-spored basidia, paraphyses 7-12 microns wide, and peridium a single layer of hyphae^; rare, central ID, (Trappe(13)), type collection from ID (Smith(30))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on fresh peridial surface dingy vinaceous, FeSO4 slowly dark olive but fading, no reaction on dried specimens^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  about 1.5cm across, ovoid; "dull rusty ochraceous when fresh, staining olive where handled", when dried dingy vinaceous brown; dry, appressed-fibrillose^, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  hard as bone when dried; dark olive when mature^ (Smith(4)), hard when dried; dark olive and retaining this color when dried; cavities minute, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  none^ (Smith(30))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection in duff under conifers, July^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-8.5 x 3.5-4 microns, ochraceous in KOH, in Melzer's reagent rusty red (where collected along hymenium)^; "peridium of hyphae 4-10 microns wide, no sphaerocysts seen", (Smith(4)), 7-8.5 x 3.5-4 microns, ovate to angular-ovate, smooth, truncate at base from a slight sterigmal scar (no distinct teeth seen in optical section), in Melzer's reagent ochraceous singly, rusty red in mass along hymenium, in KOH ochraceous; basidia 4-spored, 6-spored, and 8-spored, clavate, colorless, collapsing; paraphyses 7-12 microns wide, thin-walled, context homogeneous; subhymenium cellular; tramal plates composed of hyphae 3-5 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, refractive, gelatinous; peridium a single layer of hyphae 4-10 microns wide, "but with so much dingy vinaceous debris in the layer as to obscure all details"; no sphaerocysts seen; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
269
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon subpurpurascens  A.H. Sm.^  Mich. Botanist 3: 17. 1964
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a rubbery, spherical to irregularly compressed fruiting body, the surface white overlaid with fibrils, slowly staining brownish and finally purplish red, 2) a white to brown spore mass with minute cavities, 3) growth under conifers, 4) "pistol grip" spores that are slightly laterally prominent, 5) a variation in amyloid reaction of spores which may be all dark violet, partly dark violet or apparently inamyloid, 6) 6-spored and 8-spored basidia, and 7) a 1-layered peridium that has many hyphae with yellowish incrustations on the walls, with a purplish vinaceous color between the hyphae, in Melzer's reagent the peridium showing many large dark orange-brown pigment balls.^ It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Rhizopogon subpurpurascens is found from western OR to ID and WY, (Trappe(13)). It is found in WA, OR, and ID, (Trappe, M.(3)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH stains surface slowly olive-fuscous, FeSO4 stains surface bluish to olive^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-4cm across, white; overlaid with fibrils; consistency of fresh fruitbody distinctly rubbery^, (Smith(4)), 1-4cm across, spherical to irregularly compressed; white, (overlaid by vinaceous buff to avellaneous fibrils), when handled slowly staining brownish and finally dull purplish red (no yellow stage), when dried dark purplish fuscous; dry, felty-fibrillose and with appressed rhizomorphs overall, (Smith(30)), "whitish to brown and composed of interwoven fibrils, staining brownish to dull purplish with handling", (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  cavities minute; olivaceous^, (Smith(30)), white when young, later becoming brown, (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  
ODOR  mild^ (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  mild^ (Trappe, M.(3))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Pinus contorta (lodgepole pine) and Abies lasiocarpa (alpine fir)^, July and August, (Smith(30)), with Pinus, Abies, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), July to December, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores variable, mostly under 3.5 microns wide, 'some with a "pistol grip" from the manner in which the apiculus is attached'^, peridium composed of hyphae 4-10 microns wide, (Smith(4)), spores 7-8.5(9) x 3-3.5 microns, narrowly oval to oblong, broadest part toward apex in some, many irregular in shape, some 10-11 x 2-2.5 microns and curved, some with a lateral protuberance (pistol-grip type), smooth under ordinary magnification, but faintly mottled under oil immersion, many spores dark violet in Melzer's reagent, and some of these dark violet only over the upper part or half, in many the deposition of amyloid material seen to be on the line separating the endosporium from the exosporium, many spores apparently remaining inamyloid, spores in KOH colorless singly but yellowish in masses along the hymenium, wall thickened slightly; basidia 6-spored and 8-spored, 5-7 microns wide; paraphyses 12-20 x 8-12 microns, ovoid to subglobose, all thin-walled, "the walls very indistinct in KOH, with 1-3 isodiametric cells below to give a cellular subhymenium"; cystidia none; tramal plates "of gelatinous interwoven hyphae diverging to subhymenium" and enlarged at the septa to 8-10 microns wide, thin-walled, colorless, and smooth; peridium a single layer of hyphae 4-10 microns wide, appressed, more or less cylindric, colorless, thin-walled, smooth or many with yellowish incrustations on the walls, with a purplish vinaceous color between the hyphae, in Melzer's reagent peridium shows many large dark orange-brown pigment balls and bodies of different shapes often with granular but not amyloid content; clamp connections absent; all tissues inamyloid, (Smith(30)), 25-75% of the surface of individual spores strongly purple in iodine solution (colorless when young, more amyloid as they mature and finally 100% darkened in Melzer's reagent), (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon kauffmanii stains vinaceous to vinaceous fuscous on the surface, and has some hyphae of the peridium with darkly amyloid contents (some dark violet pigment balls present), (Smith(30)). See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon atroviolaceus.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)
270
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon subradicatus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 117. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include large spherical to irregular fruitbody with yellow surface, and an overlying network of rhizomorphs, spore mass grayish olive to olive brown when mature and stained ochraceous around larval channels, definite basal attachment by short somewhat rooting projection ending in a cluster of rhizomorphs, chemical characters, and microscopic characters including smooth, elliptic to oblong spores, 6-spored to 8-spored basidia, and peridium of appressed interwoven hyphae 3-10 microns wide, with inflated cells 20-40 microns in diameter scattered through the layer^; type collection from WA, (Smith(30)), found in eastern WA (Smith(4))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on surface dingy yellowish then yellow-brown, FeSO4 no reaction to slightly olive-yellowish, cut peridium with application of KOH slowly dingy reddish brown next to spore mass; KOH and FeSO4 both no reaction on spore mass^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  3-9cm across, "ground color lemon yellow to dingy sulphur, fading to cinnamon buff, not staining where injured"; "typically with basal short rooting group of rhizomorphs", rhizomorphs yellowish to cinnamon buff, when old clay color^, (Smith(4)), 3-9cm across and 2-6cm deep, spherical, depressed-spherical, flattened, pear-shaped, or variously irregular; "ground color dull lemon-yellow to dingy sulphur where exposed to light, long remaining whitish where covered by soil, finally fading to dingy cinnamon-buff over portions exposed to light, not staining where injured (bruised areas merely becoming dingy slowly)", "cut surface of peridium not staining"; dry, fibrillose, "over this a network of appressed rhizomorphs dull cinnamon-buff in color to darker clay-color, extending upward from a definite short root-like point of attachment", (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  staining ochraceous around worm holes, grayish olive to olive brown when mature; dry^, (Smith(4)), dry, spongy; "pallid to grayish to olive-buff to grayish olive or finally olive-brown (when liquified)", staining ochraceous around damaged areas (larval tunnels etc.); chambers small to medium (+/- 0.1cm) and labyrinthiform, (Smith(30))
STEM  "typically with a basal short rooting group of rhizomorphs"^, (Smith(4)), no columella, but basal attachment in the form of a short subradicating [somewhat rooting] projection ending in a cluster of rhizomorphs, (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection under Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine)^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5.5-6.5 x 2-2.5 microns, elliptic to oblong, often with false septum, smooth, colorless to yellowish in Melzer's reagent and in KOH, wall not appreciably thickened^; basidia 6-spored to 8-spored, cylindric; paraphyses thin-walled, yellowish-transparent in KOH; subhymenium cellular to subfilamentose; tramal central strand of narrow, subparallel, colorless hyphae; peridium of hyphae 3-10 microns wide, appressed interwoven, pale ochraceous (in KOH), with greatly inflated cells 20-40 microns in diameter scattered throughout the layer, in Melzer's reagent merely ochraceous-tawny and with some "amyloid" granules, "some granular debris in epicuticular region"; all hyphae inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30)), "peridium of appressed interwoven hyphae 3-10 microns wide", inflated cells up to 40 microns present, hyphae of tramal plates thin-walled (under 0.5 microns thick) as revived in KOH, (Smith(4))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'somewhat rooted'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4)
271
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon subsalmonius  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 142. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to irregular fruitbody with the surface pale rose to peach pink to salmon pink or pinkish ochraceous or whitish, typically with scattered salmon buff to dingy vinaceous buff rhizomorphs over the surface, 2) a minutely chambered spore mass that is pallid to olive and when old dark yellow brown, 3) chemical reactions to KOH on the surface, 4) smooth, oblong spores from 6-spored and 8-spored basidia, and 5) a 1-layered peridium of appressed interwoven hyphae, with the walls ochraceous in KOH and with some amorphous pigment present in the epicuticular region.^ This is a collective species with several varieties based on the color of injured areas and the reactions of the peridium to KOH: a) var. subsalmonius has no bruising color change on the surface and KOH gives a pinkish lilac reaction on the parts of the fresh surface tinged pink or salmon (the great majority of collections in ID fitting this variety), b) var. griseolilacinus does not stain pinkish when injured, but KOH gives a pale lilac-gray reaction on the surface, c) var. roseitinctus does not stain pinkish with handling and has no KOH reaction on the fresh peridium, d) var. similis stains pinkish (vinaceous) with handling, it has pockets of inflated cells in the peridium, and many spores are dextrinoid, and e) var. persicinus stains pinkish (vinaceous) from handling, but lacks pockets of inflated cells in the peridium. The Smith(4) description used below is for R. subsalmonius, and the Smith(30) description used below is for R. salmonius var. subsalmonius. Rhizopogon subsalmonius is common among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Rhizopogon subsalmonius is found from WA to northern California, ID and AZ, (Trappe(13)). It is known from BC, WA, OR, ID, and WY according to Smith(4), but the varieties were described from ID in Smith(30).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH staining the pink fresh surface pinkish lilac but usually no reaction on white or buff areas (for var. subsalmonius, see above for other varieties); fresh surface in FeSO4 slowly pale olivaceous but dried surface soon olive-black^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-6cm across, "pale to bright peach pink to salmon pink or white, often fading to whitish, at times pinkish ochraceous"; appressed-fibrillose, dry; typically with scattered salmon buff to dingy vinaceous buff rhizomorphs over the surface^, (Smith(4)), 1-6cm across, spherical to nearly spherical or irregular, often angular from mutual pressure; pale rose to peach-red to pale salmon color when young, but soon fading to salmon-buff to pale buff or whitish, when old often whitish to olivaceous where exposed and pinkish on underground parts; appressed-fibrillose, dry, unpolished; "typically with scattered salmon-buff rhizomorphs over the surface", "the rhizomorphs remaining with some pinkish tones even if the surface is whitish to pale buff or olivaceous"; peridium not changing color when cut or bruised or staining very lightly, (Smith(30)), pale peach pink to light salmon when young, "later yellowish salmon to brownish salmon", "with salmon-colored rhizomorphs appressed here and there on the peridium, thin and easily rubbed off", (Trappe, M.(3)) 
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  firm-cartilaginous when fresh, "sectioning easily when dry"; "pallid to olivaceous to dark olive", dark yellow brown when old; chambers minute, empty^, (Smith(30)), dark olive to dark yellow brown at maturity; "sectioning easily when dry", (Smith(4)), white when young, "becoming olive green and finally dark yellowish brown", (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  columella none^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  mild^ (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  mild^ (Trappe, M.(3))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in spruce-fir zone in the mountains of Idaho after heavy rains in August, (Smith(4)), with Abies "at moderate to high elevations, often abundant with subalpine fir at timberline", March to September, (Trappe, M.(3)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Abies (fir), (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (5.5)6-8 x 2-2.5 microns^; "peridium a thin layer of appressed interwoven hyphae, walls of hyphae ochraceous in KOH", (Smith(4)), spores (5.5)6-8 x 2-2.5 microns, oblong, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish singly or in groups more yellowish, in KOH colorless singly but pinkish buff in masses along the hymenium, basal scar indistinct; basidia 6-spored and 8-spored, 6-7 microns wide, thin-walled, readily collapsing; paraphyses 16-20 x 8-12 microns or more wide, "thin-walled, or rarely developing wall thickenings", colorless in KOH; subhymenium cellular, 2-3 cells deep; tramal plates composed of hyphae 2-6 microns wide that are colorless, refractive-gelatinous, subparallel in a central strand, walls thin to slightly thickened; peridium "thin, single-layered, of appressed interwoven hyphae, the cells at first 2-6 microns wide but at maturity 10-20 microns wide in single cells, with some amorphous pigment present in the epicuticular region and the walls ochraceous in KOH"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  from 'subsalmonius', meaning somewhat salmon in color, referring to one of the colors of the surface
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)
272
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon truncatus  Linder^  Rhodora 26: 196-197. 1924;  Rhizopogon cokeri  A.H. Sm.  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 58. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Rhizopogon truncatus differs from all other members of the genus with its bright yellow surface and strikingly truncate spores (Castellano). Features include 1) a spherical to ovoid fruitbody with the surface bright yellow and unchanging with injury, 2) a spore mass that is pale yellow in most collections, becoming darker, 3) underground to emergent habit under pine and other conifers, 4) negative reactions to FeSO4 and KOH, and 5) microscopic characters including smooth, truncate spores that are inamyloid or sometimes dextrinoid, and 6-spored or 8-spored basidia.^ It is common among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Rhizopogon truncatus is found from western OR to northern CA, and eastern North America, (Trappe(13)). It is found in OR and ID, (Smith(30) as R. cokeri), and NH and NS, (Smith(30) as R. truncatus). It is found in OR, NS, NH, CA, and NC, (Miller).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 no reaction on peridial surface and glebal surface, KOH no reaction on peridial surface and glebal surface^, (Miller), Melzer's reagent no reaction on peridium or gleba, (Castellano)
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, spherical to nearly spherical or ovoid; "yellow to vivid yellow at all stages, becoming gray-yellow to olive-yellow where bruised", "when dried dull yellow to yellow"; with scattered, appressed rhizomorphs colored as the surface of the fruitbody^, (Castellano), 0.5-3cm across, spherical, nearly spherical, or ovoid; yellow to vivid yellow even when young, grayish yellow or olive yellow where handled, not bruising, when dried yellow but often mottled with olive yellow or deep orange; dry, granulose to pulverulent [powdery], unpolished where handled; peridium 0.03-0.05cm thick, yellow in cross-section; rhizomorphs "sparse, inconspicuous, fine, reticulating above, 1-3 large strands appressed below, concolorous with peridial surface", (Miller), bright yellow with yellow rhizomorphs (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  dark yellow-brown; minutely loculate [chambered]^, (Castellano), soft, cake-like in consistency when young, firm when old; yellowish white to pale yellow at first (and in most actual collections), then grayish yellow, dark olive brown or yellowish brown, finally dark yellowish brown, unchanged when dried; "locules small, 4-6 per mm, irregularly shaped, empty at maturity", (Miller), dark brown (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  columella lacking (Castellano), associated with mats of bright yellow mycelium (Trappe, M.(3))
ODOR  slightly oily or not distinctive^ (Castellano), slightly oily or not distinctive (Miller)
TASTE  slightly oily or not distinctive^ (Castellano)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground to emergent, scattered to grouped associated with Pinaceae spp. especially Pinus spp. (pine), April through November^, (Castellano), underground or imbedded in well rotted conifer logs, or woody debris; on west coast associated with Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Abies spp. (fir), (Miller), moderate elevations to subalpine forests, year-round, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (5.5)7-9(11) x 3-5 microns, elliptic-truncate to oblong-truncate, inamyloid but sometimes dextrinoid, colorless to yellow-brown singly, yellow-brown in mass, walls up to 0.75 microns thick, "sterigmal attachment conspicuous and up to 2 microns broad"^, (Castellano), spores (5.5)7.0-9.0(11) x 3.0-5.0 microns, oblong, oblong-elliptic, cylindric, or elliptic, often irregularly allantoid [curved], reniform [kidney-shaped], subangular, or bilobed, smooth truncate, in Melzer's reagent immature spores colorless to strongly dextrinoid singly and in mass, mature spores pale yellowish brown to slightly dextrinoid in mass, (in KOH colorless to pale yellow singly, yellow-brown in mass), basal scar and sterigmal remains prominent, walls thickened at maturity, spores mostly with 1-2 lipid droplets; basidia borne in hymenial layer, 6-spored or 8-spored, 11-14 x 4.5-5.5 microns, clavate, colorless, thick-walled at first, then autolysing, brachybasidioles 7-10 x 6-8 microns, subspherical to obovate, thick-walled, gelatinizing at maturity; glebal trama composed of hyphae 2-5 microns wide, cylindric to swollen, colorless, thin-walled when young, mucilaginous, refractive when old, "subparallel in the mediostratum, interwoven and gelatinized adjacent to the hymenium", "scattered oleiferous hyphae present in the mediostratum", 5-10(15) microns wide, "refractive or yellowish refractive in KOH and Melzer's reagent"; peridium 100-220 microns thick, composed of hyphae 4-7 microns wide, uniformly cylindric to occasionally swollen, branching, anastomosing, thin-walled, end-cells 3-40 x 4-6 microns, "blunted or rounded at the tip, protruding or intertwined", peridium pale yellow in KOH, the pigment diffusing into the fluid (dissolving only slightly less readily in water), "bright yellow in Melzer's reagent, the pigment lightly encrusting the hyphae, not diffusing into the fluid", subcutis lacking; clamp connections absent, but short, stubby branches resembling false clamps common, (Miller)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin "truncatus", meaning "cut off", referring to the truncate prominent basal scar on the spores^, (Miller)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Miller, S.L.(1) (colors mostly from Kornerup(3)), Castellano(2)*, Smith(4) (as R. cokeri), Smith(30) (as R. truncatus and as R. cokeri), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)
273
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon tsugae  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 59. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include dried appearance rough and unpolished and under a lens reticulate, with color "cinnamon brown" to "Mars brown", spore mass when dried hard with small cavities and colored cinnamon brown, growth under hemlock, and microscopic characters including mostly subfusoid spores from 4-spored and 6-spored basidia, and peridium of appressed hyphae with incrusting amorphous material, sections olive-brownish when first revived in KOH, in Melzer's reagent orange-brown but lacking pigment balls, many hyphae with an orange-brown content of amorphous material but walls colorless^; description derived from Smith(30); rare, northwestern OR, (Trappe(13)), type from OR
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-2cm broad, spherical or nearly so; when dried "cinnamon brown" to "Mars brown" (colors probably from Ridgway); when dried rough and unpolished and under a lens faintly reticulate
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  when dried cinnamon-brown and hard (almost bone-like) with very small cavities
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under hemlock (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe(13))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-9.5(10) x 2.8-3.4 microns, mostly subfusoid varying to narrowly ovoid, a fair number obscurely angular, smooth, yellowish to yellowish brown in Melzer's reagent, ochraceous singly in KOH but near snuff-brown in groups, walls thickened slightly, basal scar mostly indistinct^; basidia at least some 6-spored, more of them 4-spored, gelatinous when old, more or less cylindric when sporulating and spores sessile; paraphyses "not distinct from basidioles and all thin-walled, finally gelatinizing"; tramal plates of intricately interwoven colorless gelatinous hyphae 3-7 microns wide but width irregular in some; "subhymenium gelatinous-filamentose, the outlines of the hyphae in the tramal plates indistinct because of the gelatinization"; peridium of appressed hyphae 3-8 microns wide, with slightly thickened walls, "almost cemented together from incrusting amorphous material, sections olive-brownish first revived in KOH but fading out to dingy yellow-brown", in Melzer's reagent orange-brown but lacking pigment balls, many hyphae with an orange-brown content of amorphous material but walls colorless; clamp connections absent; all tissues inamyloid 
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Tsuga', referring to habitat
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon argillaceus indistinguishable when dried but has sphaerocysts in lower layer of peridium, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Trappe(13)
274
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon udus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 131. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to irregular fruitbody with surface rich ocher yellow and lubricous, inner layer of peridium staining red when cut, spore mass olive brown, fragrant odor, chemical characters, and microscopic characters including smooth oblong to narrowly oval spores, thick-walled paraphyses, and peridium of appressed hyphae 8-12 microns wide but some cells up to 23 microns wide, walls yellowish in KOH, and some hyphae of the layer with internal or incrusting pigments^; rare in ID (Trappe(13)), found in ID (Smith(4))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  surface red-brown in KOH, FeSO4 not causing a color change on peridium^, (Smith(4)), KOH on surface (epicutis) red then rusty brown, FeSO4 no reaction, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, rich ocher yellow, inner layer of peridium staining red when cut; lubricous^, (Smith(4)), 1-3cm across, spherical to irregular; "rich ocher-yellow overall, inner layer of peridium staining red when bruised but surface showing a red-brown stain", "peridium when cut soon orange-cinnamon to reddish orange in the inner zone"; "the surface often very uneven, with a lubricous to wet feeling (dug from dry duff), no rhizomorphs present", (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "watery cartilaginous (hard as bone when dried), chambers very minute (3-4 per mm)"; olive to olive-brown^, (Smith(30))
STEM  columella absent^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  fragrant when fresh^ (Smith(30))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Picea (spruce) and Pinus (pine)^, (Smith(4)), in dry duff under Picea and Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), summer, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-8 x 2.5-3 microns^, "peridium of appressed hyphae 8-12 microns wide but some cells up to 23 microns wide, walls yellowish in KOH, incrusting material along the hyphae of the inner layer", (Smith(4)), spores 7-8 x 2.5-3 microns, oblong to narrowly oval, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish singly to pale tawny in groups, usually with a false septum, in KOH colorless to yellowish, base not distinctly truncate; basidia none found well enough revived to study; paraphyses and subhymenial cells all thick-walled, central content not staining in Melzer's reagent, thick-walled paraphyses readily separating into units of 2-4 cells under pressure; peridium of appressed-interwoven hyphae with variously enlarged cells up to 23 microns (mostly 8-12 microns wide), walls yellowish in KOH and Melzer's reagent, "sections of fresh material in KOH showing an inner red layer and the outer zone yellow, some granular incrusting pigment present along the hyphae but the inner region containing cells with dark rusty brown interior pigment deposits (in KOH)", in Melzer's reagent with large orange-brown pigment balls in this region; clamp connections absent; all tissues inamyloid, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'damp'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon cusickiensis.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
275
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon umbrinoviolascens  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 78. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include variously shaped fruitbody with violaceous brown surface, staining dark violaceous when injured, olive buff mature spore mass, growth under conifers underground or almost underground, and microscopic characters including smooth, oblong to narrowly elliptic spores, 6-8-spored basidia, and peridial epicutis with many inflated-versiform cells and with flagellate hyphal ends^; rare in Pacific Northwest, found eastern WA and ID, (Trappe(13)), found eastern WA and northern ID, (Smith(4))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on cut surface olive (no red anywhere), FeSO4 dark olive^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, violaceous-brown, "lacking any reddish stains or tints"; dry, unpolished^, (Smith(4)), 1-3cm long and 1-2cm thick, variously shaped (even subfusiform); when fresh brownish violaceous to violaceous-drab, where injured staining dark violaceous, with an overlay of wood-brown fibrils and when dried gray-brown or darker (no violet or red showing), olive spore mass showing where cracked when fresh, peridium when cut dull violaceous to bluish drab; dry, unpolished, rhizomorphs practically lacking, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  olive buff when mature^, (Smith(4)), chambers large and labyrinthiform; pallid to olive buff, (Smith(30))
STEM  columella lacking^, (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) and Larix (larch), summer and fall^, (Smith(4)), in duff hypogeous to subhypogeous under conifers, (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga, (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-7.5 x 2-2.5 microns^, hyphae of epicutis of peridium composed of cells 9-15 microns wide, "many inflated-versiform cells present, flagellate hyphal ends present", (Smith(4)), spores 6-7.5 x 2-2.5 microns, oblong to narrowly elliptic, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish singly and slightly more yellowish brown in groups, in KOH dingy transparent singly, dingy brownish in groups, thin-walled, lacking obvious basal truncation; basidia 6-8-spored; paraphyses 6-9 microns wide, clavate to ovoid, thin-walled; tramal plates of colorless, thin-walled, gelatinous, refractive, interwoven to subparallel hyphae, content homogeneous; subhymenium "cellular, the cells thin-walled"; peridium "with an epicutis of loosely interwoven hyphae with bister walls (in KOH) and many cells inflated-versiform and 9-15 microns diam, the walls thickened and little or no incrusting pigment on surface, flagellate end-cells present"; subcutis "of narrow interwoven non-gelatinous hyphae with some pigment incrustation (near epicutis) and near glebal chambers olive in KOH (including adjacent spores and hymenium in many cases)"; clamp connections absent; some amyloid debris present in mounts revived in Melzer's reagent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'umbrinous (brown) becoming violet'
SIMILAR  R. umbrinoviolascens shows no violaceous colors when dried, while Rhizopogon parksii when dried is bluish fuscous with dingy vinaceous brown areas often showing between the fuscous patches, and spore sizes are different, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
276
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon variabilisporus  A.H. Sm.^  Mich. Botanist 3: 18. 1964
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to angular fruitbody having surface rough and whitish with fibrils soon vinaceous brown, attachment by a cluster of basal rhizomorphs, pallid spore mass that changed to yellow brown when cut, growth under conifers, and microscopic characters including spores of variable form, the peridium with inflated cells scattered or in groups, its filamentous tissue reddish in KOH and the epicuticular hyphae colorless to pale bister in KOH^; rare in the Pacific Northwest, found southwestern OR to northern CA and Idaho, (Trappe(13)), found ID (rare) according to Smith(4)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2-4cm across, "whitish with the fibrils soon dingy vinaceous-brown, drying blackish brown", "peridium not staining red when injured"; rough, fibrillose^, (Smith(4)), 2-4cm across, spherical to ovoid or angular from external pressure; "whitish, but the fibrils soon dingy vinaceous brown, and much dirt adhering to the surface, when dried blackish brown"; rough and fibrillose, (Smith(30)) 
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  pallid when young but changing to dark yellow-brown when cut, colored as peridium in old fruiting bodies^, (Smith(4)), chambers minute and nearly empty; 'pallid becoming "bister" (dark yellow brown) when cut, slowly darkening to olive-brown, in old specimens about concolorous with the peridium in the dried state', (Smith(30))
STEM  usually attached by a cluster of basal rhizomorphs^, columella none or rudimentary, (Smith(30))
ODOR  none^ (Smith(30))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to single in duff under Picea (spruce) and Abies (fir), July and August^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-20 x 5-8 microns, varied in form^, subhymenium cellular; "peridium with inflated cells scattered or in groups, the filamentous tissue reddish in KOH", epicuticular hyphae colorless in KOH, (Smith(4)), spores various shapes, 20 x 5 microns and subcylindric, 14 x 7.5 microns and ovoid, 12 x 8 microns and obcordate, 14-16 x 7-8 microns and clavate, 18 x 6 microns and allantoid, or 12 x 6 microns and angular-ovate (sizes being the averages for each type), also in above patterns some may show constrictions or protuberances or be merely somewhat angular in outline, yellow-brown in Melzer's reagent, but with a thin colorless apparently mucilaginous sheath, dull brownish singly in KOH, pale bister in masses in KOH, basal scar obscure; basidia (?) 15-30 x (6)8-12 microns and 1-spored (?could be conidiophores), 6-spored, spores sessile, basidial walls often somewhat thickened but not colored, shape varying from clavate to cylindric or irregular in outline; paraphyses not distinguishable from basidioles; cystidia none; tramal plates of interwoven highly refractive elements; subhymenium cellular; peridium up to 1000 microns thick when fresh, "pallid when cut and not discoloring readily but becoming dark brown in drying", "context of peridium of enlarged cells scattered and in pockets and their walls mostly slightly thickened, the ground tissue of filamentose hyphae which are vinaceous as revived in KOH and are heavily encrusted with debris", "epicutis not differentiated from context but numerous hyphal tips project and these heavily incrusted but the walls not appreciably colored (fresh material in H2O mounts)", as revived in KOH the walls of these hyphae and those near surface colorless to pale bister; clamp connections none; all tissues inamyloid, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with variable spores'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon griseogleba has the same variable patterns of spore shape but fresh spore mass is grayish wood-brown, (Smith(30)); Rhizopogon clavitisporus readily distinguished by paraphyses, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
277
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon ventricosporus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 100. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to irregular fruitbody with ocher-yellow, appressed-fibrillose surface, staining irregularly reddish when bruised, but the peridium saffron-yellow when cut, spore mass grayish becoming honey-yellow and with tunnel walls rusty ochraceous, growth under conifers, and microscopic characters including both broadly ovate and fusoid-ventricose spores, paraphyses that are chains of 2-4 cells, and peridium with a surface layer of loosely interwoven hyphae reddish cinnamon in KOH and groups of inflated cells next to spore mass^; R. ventricosporus is named for the fusoid-ventricose spores that occur along with smaller broadly ovate spores, but "it is very doubtful if the cystidium-like spores are actually basidiospores. The question is whether or not both conidia and basidiospores are produced on the same hymenium.", (Smith(30)); rare, northern CA and ID, (Trappe(13)), type collection from ID
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, ocher-yellow; appressed-fibrillose^, (Smith(4)), 1-3cm across, spherical to irregular; ocher-yellow with occasional red areas "but only staining red slowly in bruising and not always changing" (different in different areas of the same fruitbody); dry, appressed-fibrillose; "peridium near saffron-yellow when cut"; "drying with an ochraceous ground color and a dull rose flush pervading large areas"; rhizomorphs inconspicuous, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  grayish becoming honey-yellow^, (Smith(4)), "grayish to honey-yellow, where eaten by larvae the tunnel walls rusty ochraceous, drying dingy buff", (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection gregarious under Picea (spruce) and Pinus albicaulis (White-bark Pine), August^, (Smith(30))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-13 x 6-8 microns^; "outer part of peridium of interwoven hyphae 4-8 microns wide, some cells to 12 microns or more wide, groups of inflated cells present next to the gleba", (Smith(4)), spores variable in shape, the basic shape broadly ovate and 9-13 x 6-8 microns, the most common variation fusoid-ventricose and 13-22 x 4-7 x 3-5 microns "(ventricose near point of attachment and neck elongated from original spore-apex)", rarely subcylindric and up to 22 x 4 microns, rarely nearly round or obscurely angular, inamyloid (pale ochraceous brown), in KOH ochraceous, thin-walled; basidia not seen; paraphyses a chain of 2-4 enlarged cells, the uppermost 1-2 becoming thick-walled and spherical to ovate (7-11 microns in diameter); subhymenium filamentous, colorless, gelatinous; hyphae of tramal plates 3-6 microns wide, becoming gelatinous, becoming thick-walled when old at least in part; peridium "with a surface layer of loosely interwoven hyphae reddish cinnamon in KOH from both coagulated intracellular pigment masses and encrusting pigment", hyphae 4-8 microns wide, "some hyphae with inflated cells up to 12 microns or more"; inner layer of peridium with "more compactly arranged and interwoven hyphae", "and next to gleba with groups of enlarged cells (rudiments of glebal chambers)"; all hyphae inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with spores that are ventricose (wider in middle)'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon clavitisporus and Rhizopogon subclavitisporus have a differentiated epicutis of brown-walled hyphae, (Smith(30)). See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon abietis, Rhizopogon albiroseus, Rhizopogon roseolus, and Rhizopogon rubescens.
SOURCES  Smith(30) (as R. ventricisporus), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
278
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon vesiculosus  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N. Y. bot. Gdn 14(2): 65. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include white underground fruitbody that becomes pale dingy saffron, staining red from handing, and is finally reddish brown, spores mass that is white then pale yellow then blackish brown, absent columella, and microscopic characters^; description derived from Smith(30) except where noted; described from ID, (Smith(30)), common in the Pacific Northwest, distribution WA, OR, and ID, (Trappe(13)). It occurs in British Columbia as well, at least in the form of ectomycorrhizal connections.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on surface red; FeSO4 on surface fuscous
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across, spherical to oblong, some irregular; "white when young, becoming pale dingy saffron, staining red from handling and finally dull reddish to reddish brown" and about this color when dried; dry, soft to touch, matted-fibrillose; rhizomorphs few and scattered
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "firm but not hard, dried specimens easy to section"; white when young, soon pale yellow, and when mature blackish brown, mature spore-mass when mature and dried near "Dresden-brown" (a Ridgway(1) color that is a dark yellowish brown)
STEM  columella none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe), type under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), (Smith)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-6.5 x 3.2-3.6 microns, ovate-truncate, smooth, colorless to yellowish in KOH, slightly more yellowish in Melzer's reagent^; basidia 6-spored, cylindric; paraphyses becoming thick-walled, content colorless to dull ochraceous in Melzer's reagent; "subhymenium of filaments diverging to hymenial cells"; tramal plates of gelatinous, narrow, colorless, interwoven hyphae; peridium reddish in KOH when fresh, rusty brown when revived, of interwoven hyphae 5-10 microns wide, the hyphal walls thin, scattered through the epicutis are yellow-brown (fresh) inflated cells up to 50 microns across, these collapsing on drying, rusty brown to ochraceous pigment and debris present in peridium as revived in KOH (intercellular and intracellular); all tissues inamyloid but some amyloid (?) particles between hyphae of peridium; clamp connections none
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon vinicolor has longer, slightly narrower spores, lacks inflated cells in the epicutis, and the spore-mass is never as blackish-brown when fresh, (Smith(30))
SOURCES  Smith(30), Trappe(13)
279
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon villescens  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 74. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to angular fruitbody with dark yellow fibrillose surface, dull blue staining with bruising, spore mass that is dull violet around worm holes, growth under conifers, chemical characters including bluish black reaction of subcutis surface to KOH, and microscopic characters including relatively large spores, 6-spored to 8-spored basidia, and blackish violet debris under the microscopic in KOH and in Melzer's reagent^; some molecular evidence suggests that R. villescens (not using the holotype), R. villosulus (not the holotype), R. colossus (holotype), and R. hawkerae (paratype), are close and could be a single species that shows variation, (Grubisha(2)), but other molecular evidence about these other species does not correspond exactly (Martin, M.P.(2)); infrequent in the Pacific Northwest, found WA to southwestern OR and ID, (Trappe(13)), Rhizopogon villescens found in northern ID, (Smith(4)), reported from OR by Smith, J.E.(1)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH bluish-black on subcutis, FeSO4 dull olivaceous; spore mass green in KOH but quickly fading^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm thick, dark yellow-brown when fresh, subcutis of peridium staining dull blue on bruising when fresh; fibrillose^, (Smith(4)), 1-2.5cm across, spherical to elliptic or angular; with a thin epicutis of dark yellow brown interwoven fibrils (appearing grayish snuff-brown when dried), "beneath this a layer of pallid fibrils which stain dull blue on bruising and when dried is dingy vinaceous", when dried fruitbodies are reddish beneath the overlay of dull yellow-brown fibrils, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  chambers medium sized; olivaceous, around the worm holes dull violet^, (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under fir and pine in northern Idaho, July^, Smith(4), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-10(11) x 3-3.8 microns^, peridial epicutis with flagellate hyphal ends, (Smith(4)), spores 7-10(11) x 3-3.8(4) microns, subelliptic to oblong, with distinct basal truncation, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish singly, yellowish brown in groups, in KOH colorless singly, yellowish in groups, thin-walled; basidia 6-spored to 8-spored, clavate; paraphyses thin-walled; subhymenium cellular, tramal plates of hyphae 3-6 microns wide, somewhat interwoven, colorless, subgelatinous; peridium with epicutis of loosely interwoven hyphae 3-7 microns wide, with dull cinnamon walls, some with cinnamon incrustations, 'many greatly elongated flagellate hyphae present, some inflated cells found, with violet black granules and amorphous masses present in KOH; in Melzer's sol. hyphal walls dull fulvous, numerous "amyloid" granules and masses present and at broken hyphal ends a short part of the wall dark violet'; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  other species associated with Douglas-fir that have woven brown hyphae in the peridium revived in KOH include Rhizopogon parksii (spores 4.5-6.5 x 2.3-3 microns), Rhizopogon hawkerae (spores 6.5-8 x 2.2-2.8 microns), Rhizopogon villosulus (spores 6-8 x 2.2.5 microns), Rhizopogon zelleri (spores 9-12 x 3.5-4 microns), (these four like R. villescens with at least some flagellate hyphae), Rhizopogon subareolatus (spores 6-7 x 2-2.3 microns), Rhizopogon vinicolor (spores 5.5-8 x 3-4.5 microns), and Rhizopogon subclavatisporus (spores 8-13 x 4.5-7 microns and thicker on one end), (Trappe, M.) . See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon subclavitisporus.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Grubisha(2), Smith, J.E.(1), Martin, M.P.(2), NATS(1) (Trappe, M., accessed April 6, 2005), Trappe(13)
280
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon villosulus  Zeller^  Mycologia 33: 196. 1941
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a nearly spherical fruitbody with a dark brown surface that is slightly villose, 2) a light brown spore mass with small, maze-like chambers, 3) a large rhizomorph from which it arises, 4) absent columella, 5) growth in duff under conifers, 6) an olive reaction on the fresh peridium with KOH or FeSO4, 7) oblong spores on basidia that are 6-spored, 8-spored, or more rarely 4-spored, 8) septate paraphyses with mucilaginous thickenings, and 9) a peridial epicutis of loosely interwoven hyphae with cinnamon-brown walls.^ Molecular evidence has been presented to support the contention that the Smith and Zeller species R. colossus var. colossus (2 paratypes studied), R. hawkerae (paratype studied), and R. parksii (holotype studied) are synonyms of this species, (Martin, M.P.(2)); on the other hand, other molecular evidence suggests that R. villosulus (different collection), R. colossus (holotype), R. hawkerae (same paratype), and R. villescens (non-type) are close and could be a single species that shows variation, whereas two non-type collections of R. parksii were more distant, (Grubisha(2)). Rhizopogon villosulus using the Smith & Zeller(1966) concept is not rare in the Pacific Northwest according to Smith(4), "Not rare in Idaho but it is one of the most difficult to collect since the basidiocarps are often about the size of rabbit pellets and the same color as the soil", (Smith(30)). It is abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Rhizopogon villosulus is found in the Rocky Mountains, southern BC to northern CA, Mexico, (Trappe(13)). It was described from OR by Zeller. Collections were examined from OR, ID, and CA, (Smith(30)). A specimen from WA used in study (Grubisha(2)). It was introduced into Europe, Australia, and New Zealand on Douglas-fir seedlings, (Trappe, M.(3)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  "in KOH olive on fresh peridium, FeSO4 olive"^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  0.8-2.5cm across, bister brown [dark yellow-brown] when fresh and about the same when dried; arising from a rhizomorph, slightly villose [with long soft hairs]^, (Smith(4)), 0.8-2.5cm across, nearly spherical; "brown (bister) when fresh, changing but little in drying often", not staining where bruised; soft, slightly villose, becoming areolate [cracked like dried mud] "due to rupture of the peridial epicutis, also the latter easily removed by abrasion" (epicutis tends to be worn away exposing the pallid subcutis but the peridium as such not readily separable), (Smith(30)), up to 1.5cm across, nearly spherical; "surface soft, slightly villose, brown (bister) when fresh, changing little when dried, often becoming areolate due to the rupture of the outer peridium", (Zeller), "dark brown and felty over an underlying whitish layer, not staining", (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "light brown drying buffy brown (dingy avellaneous in the type); cavities small and labyrinthiform"^, (Smith(30)), "light brown, drying buffy brown; cavities small, labyrinthiform", (Zeller), white when young, dark olive-brown when mature, (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  fruitbody arising from a large rhizomorph; columella absent^, (Smith(30)), from a large rhizomorph (Zeller)
ODOR  when mature "of spicy, garlicky sausage"^ (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  mild^ (Trappe, M.(3))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Picea (spruce) and Abies (fir) and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), June to September^, (Smith(4)), in duff under conifers, June to September, (Smith(30)), associated with Douglas-fir, fruiting year-round, (Trappe, M.(3)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe(13))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-8 x 2-2.5 microns^, brachybasidioles soon thick-walled, "epicutis of loosely interwoven hyphae with cinnamon-brown walls, very few flagellate hyphal ends present", (Smith(4)), spores 6-8 x 2-2.5 microns, oblong or nearly so, in Melzer's reagent colorless individually and pale reddish brown in aggregations, in KOH colorless or nearly so singly, dingy ochraceous to dingy pinkish buff in masses, basal scar inconspicuous; basidia 6-spored, 8-spored, more rarely 4-spored, 15-20 x 4.5-6 microns, "subcylindric, readily collapsing"; paraphyses "septate, terminal cell ovate, obovate to clavate", 15-25 x 7-12 microns, "mostly with mucilaginous thickenings both in the terminal cell and those (2-3) beneath it, the paraphyses readily disarticulating at the septa and then found floating separately in the mount", the amorphous central body not coloring in Melzer's reagent; subhymenium "cellular and the cells thickened as indicated above as well as separating at the septa readily under pressure"; tramal plates of "highly refractive gelatinous hyphae more or less interwoven"; inner peridial layer (subcutis) of interwoven hyphae colorless in KOH "but with dull brown pigment pockets present and in places in KOH becoming dark green, red pigmentation observed in the layer on some collections, no pockets of distinctly inflated cells present", amyloid particles present on sections of peridium revived in Melzer's reagent; peridial epicutis of hyphae that are loosely interwoven, brown-walled (near cinnamon-brown), smooth, "often with thickened walls, the hyphae branched and often enlarged near the septa, some with short branches but these not thorn-like, very few flagellate hyphae seen, greatly inflated dark brown cells present and often abundant"; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30)), spores 6-7.5 x 2.2-2.7 microns, narrowly elliptic, slightly colored; basidia 2-spored and 4-spored, 14-25 x 3-5 microns, exceeding the paraphyses, narrowly clavate, sterigmata about 1-1.5 microns long; paraphyses 12-20 x 8-10 microns, "obovate to oblong, highly gelatinized"; septa "narrow, of highly gelatinized hyphae"; peridium "very thin, 32-60 microns thick, when dry, duplex", the inner layer composed of compactly woven, colorless hyphae, the outer layer of hyphae 4-7 microns wide, loose, brown, some somewhat erect, "this layer sometimes rupturing and exposing the inner layer", (Zeller)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to the villous surface of the fruitbody
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon hawkerae and Rhizopogon subareolatus are similar Douglas-fir associated species with woven brown hyphae in peridium as revived in KOH, but they both have a red layer in the subcutis revived in KOH (may be orangish brown in R. villosulus), (NATS). Beside those two, other species associated with Douglas-fir that have woven brown hyphae in the peridium revived in KOH include Rhizopogon parksii (spores 4.5-6.5 x 2.3-3 microns), Rhizopogon villescens (spores 7-10 x 3-4 microns), Rhizopogon zelleri (spores 9-12 x 3.5-4 microns), (these three like R. villosulus with at least some flagellate hyphae), Rhizopogon vinicolor (spores 5.5-8 x 3-4.5 microns), and Rhizopogon subclavatisporus (spores 8-13 x 4.5-7 microns and thicker on one end), (NATS). See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon fragrans, Rhizopogon pseudovillosulus, and Rhizopogon subclavitisporus.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Zeller(8), NATS(1) (Trappe, M., accessed April 6, 2005), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Martin, M.P.(2), Grubisha(2), Trappe(13)
281
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon vinicolor  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 67. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to angular fruitbody with an appressed-fibrillose surface that barring injury is white then yellow for a short time then vinaceous-red, but the surface normally soon staining pink from injury, 2) a small-chambered spore mass that is white to dingy ochraceous becoming olive to dark olive-brown, 3) growth under Douglas-fir, and 4) chemical and microscopic characters including smooth, truncate spores from 4-spored and 6-spored basidia, and a peridium that is dull vinaceous as revived in KOH.^ A molecular study of R. vinicolor, R. ochraceisporus, R. diabolicus, R. vesiculosus, and R. parvulus concluded the first three names were synonyms [falling under the name R. vinicolor], that R. parvulus was close if not identical, and that a closely related but distinct biological species designated R. vesiculosus sensu Kretzer et al included R. vesiculosus A.H. Sm. from Idaho, a paratype of R. diabolicus from Idaho, 3 paratype collections of R. vinicolor from Idaho, and a R. vinicolor collection from Oregon. (R. vesiculosus sensu Kretzer et al. differed from R. vesiculosus A.H. Sm. in having a wider range of spores lengths - (5)6-9(10) vs. 6-6.5 microns, and in being found under Douglas-fir rather than Lodgepole Pine. See SIMILAR for the differences between R. vinicolor sensu Kretzer et al. and R. vesiculosus sensu Kretzer et al.). It is very abundant in the Pacific Northwest, predominantly in spring. (Kretzer(1)). Rhizopogon vinicolor is abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE The Rhizopogon vinicolor type was found in ID (Smith(30)). It was reported to North American Truffling Society for BC and frequently for OR. It was reported by Luoma(1) and Fogel(8) for OR. 2 paratypes of R. diabolicus A.H. Sm. from WA were subsumed under R. vinicolor sensu Kretzer et al., documenting the presence of R. vinicolor in Washington. It is found through much of the range of Douglas-fir in North America and introduced to Europe, Australia, and New Zealand on Douglas-fir seedlings on plantations, (Trappe, M.(1)). It is found from southwestern BC to northern CA, CO, (Trappe(13) who maintain separately Rhizopogon ochraceisporus A.H. Sm. as common in Washington, Oregon, and Idaho, under Pseudotsuga, and Rhizopogon diabolicus A.H. Sm. as rare in central Idaho under Pinaceae).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on surface gives purplish stain fading to vinaceous; FeSO4 on surface slightly olive-brown or no reaction^, (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, "white then vinaceous-red"; dry, appressed fibrillose^, (Smith(4)), 1-3cm across, spherical to nearly spherical, ovoid, or angular from external pressures; "white at first and soon staining pink, finally becoming vinaceous-red over all, if basidiocarps develop without injury the color pattern is white, then yellow for a short time and then entirely vinaceous-red, when dried dull vinaceous over all or a little yellow showing on some basidiocarps in depressed areas", (in another part of the description, it is said that young fruitbodies soon become dull rose to lilac-rose color); dry, appressed-fibrillose, rhizomorphs lacking or only a few present, (Smith(30)), at first "white with tinges of yellow and staining pink to vinaceous when exposed or bruised, by maturity dark vinaceous brown and darkening where bruised", (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  becoming dark olive-brown^, (Smith(4)), chambers small and nearly filled with spores; white to dingy ochraceous becoming olive to dark olive-brown, (Smith(30)), light yellow when young, "by maturity dark cinnamon brown to dark olive and rubbery", (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  
ODOR  none (Smith(30)), slightly fruity (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  mild^ (Trappe, M.(3))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under conifers, especially Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir)^, (Smith(4)), in groups or single in duff under Pseudotsuga, July and August, (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga, (Trappe(13)), fruiting year-round (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (5.5)6-7(8) x 3-4(4.5) microns, 2 basal projections [truncate]^, subhymenium cellular; "peridium with a thin layer of interwoven fibrils", "interior hyphae reddish in KOH, in the epicutis the hyphal walls cinnamon-buff in KOH", (Smith(4)), spores (5.5)6.5-8.5(9) x 3-4(4.5) microns in English description, (5.5)6-7(8) x 3-4(4.5) microns in Latin description, elliptic to oval with truncate base, under oil immersion a slight tooth projects on each side of the scar to produce an incipient cup-like base, smooth, yellowish in Melzer's reagent and KOH, wall somewhat thickened; basidia 4-spored and 6-spored, 5-8 microns wide, clavate, readily collapsing; paraphyses 15-30 x 6-12 microns, clavate to elliptic or subcylindric, becoming thick-walled when old, lacking distinctive content; tramal plates when mature of hyphae 3-6 microns wide, colorless, interwoven, refractive-gelatinous; subhymenium cellular; peridium of appressed-interwoven hyphae 3-8(12) microns wide, the cells mostly equal in width but some enlarged, no pockets of sphaerocysts present, as revived in KOH the whole layer dull vinaceous, "pigment in masses between the hyphae (obscuring almost all detail in the layer)"; clamp connections absent; all tissues inamyloid, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'wine-colored'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon vesiculosus sensu Kretzer et al. differs from R. vinicolor sensu Kretzer most usefully in the colors of the fresh peridium (surface) and gleba (spore mass): 'Both species begin with a white peridium that bruises pinkish-red (Smith's "vinaceous"), but only R. vinicolor sensu Kretzer et al develops vivid yellow patches during early maturity. At maturity, both species are light yellowish brown (Smith's "ochraceous") and turn various shades of brown from handling, the shades typically reflecting the color of the mature gleba underneath (see below). In R. vinicolor sensu Kretzer et al, the gleba develops from white when immature through pale yellow and pale greenish yellow-brown, to dark greenish brown (Smith's "olive brown") or brown or more rarely reddish brown (Smith's "rusty cinnamon" or "russet"). On the other hand, the gleba of R. vesiculosus sensu Kretzer et al appears to develop from white to greenish brown (a stage that apparently is short and was not noted in the type description) to dark blackish-brown (dominant stage).', (Kretzer(1), Latin names italicized). Rhizopogon olivaceofuscus differs in its FeSO4 reaction and the change of color of the spore mass when cut. Rhizopogon parvulus has different spores (Smith(30)). In the dried state, Rhizopogon diabolicus has a bright rusty cinnamon spores mass and the peridium is less red, (Smith(30)). Other species associated with Douglas-fir that have woven brown hyphae in the peridium revived in KOH include R. parksii (spores 4.5-6.5 x 2.3-3 microns), Rhizopogon hawkerae (spores 6.5-8 x 2.2-2.8 microns), Rhizopogon villescens (spores 7-10 x 3-4 microns), Rhizopogon villosulus (spores 6-8 x 2.2.5 microns), Rhizopogon zelleri (spores 9-12 x 3.5-4 microns), (these five with at least some flagellate hyphae), Rhizopogon subareolatus (spores 6-7 x 2-2.3 microns), and Rhizopogon subclavatisporus (spores 8-13 x 4.5-7 microns and thicker on one end), (NATS). Rhizopogon rubescens is associated with pines, and the peridium has clear woven hyphae when revived in KOH, (NATS). Rhizopogon ellenae has spores 6-9 x 2.5-4 microns, and peridium when revived is thin (about 100 microns thick), shiny, and composed of woven hyphae but often with embedded debris, (NATS). Rhizopogon occidentalis, Rhizopogon ochraceorubens, Rhizopogon vulgaris, and Rhizopogon evadens may all become or bruise a shade of reddish but spores are narrower, (NATS). Rhizopogon gilkeyae A.H. Sm. and Rhizopogon subalpinus A.H. Sm. may be this species. See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon pachyspora and Rhizopogon subclavitisporus.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Kretzer(1), Luoma(1), Fogel(8), NATS(1) (Trappe, M., accessed April 6, 2005), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)
282
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon viridis  Zeller & C.W. Dodge^  Ann. Missouri Bot. Gard. 5: 5. 1918
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include small size, more or less spherical fruitbody with olivaceous surface, olive to dark olive spore mass with minute cavities, absent columella, growth under pine, and microscopic characters including smooth spores, 6-spored to 8-spored basidia, cellular subhymenium with cells developing mucilaginous wall thickenings, and epicutis a tangled turf of thin-walled hyphae^; rare in northern ID (Trappe(13)), found northern ID according to Smith(4)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  appears to be chemically inactive^ (Smith(30))
OUTER SURFACE  1-2cm across, olivaceous when fresh, becoming olivaceous-black, when dried very dark brown^, (Smith(4)), 1-2cm across, nearly spherical to spherical, "not shrinking appreciably in drying"; "citrine-drab" to "olivaceous-black" when fresh, drying very dark brown, according to Zeller and Dodge somewhat mottled due to partial sloughing of darker outer layer, the darker places squarrose, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  olive to deep olive drying dark olive, eventually in type near "olive-brown"; cavities minute, empty^, (Smith(30)), deep olive to olive-brown (as dried), (Smith(4))
STEM  no columella^ (Smith(30))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection in duff under pine^, (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.5-8 x 2-2.5 microns^, "subhymenium cellular but cells developing mucilaginous wall thickenings; hyphae of epicutis in a tangled turf, thin-walled, no flagellate hyphal ends observed", (Smith(4)), spores 6.5-8 x 2-2.5 microns, oblong, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish, in KOH nearly colorless individually, yellowish brown in masses, basal scar conspicuous; basidia 6-spored to 8-spored (spores in groups), 12-18 x 6-7 microns, subcylindric, colorless, thin-walled, and readily collapsing; paraphyses 9-20 x 7-11 microns, "apical cell ovate to elliptic or clavate, becoming thick-walled" but the amorphous central body not coloring in Melzer's reagent; "subhymenium cellular and the cells tending to develop mucilaginous thickenings but the hyphae not breaking up under pressure into the individual cells"; peridium a double layer, the upper "with numerous dark brown hyphae (cinnamon-brown in KOH) arranged in a tangled turf but not reviving readily in KOH, the cells mostly remaining collapsed (thin-walled) and no flagellate hyphae seen", lower layer of hyphae 5-15 microns wide, intricately interwoven, no larger cells grouped into pockets; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'green'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(30) (individual colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Smith(4), Trappe(13)
283
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon vulgaris  (Vittad.) M. Lange^  Dansk. Bot. Ark. Bd. 16, nr. 1, p.56. 1956
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Distinctive characters are the basic pale yellow color when fresh, a rapid dark blackish green reaction of the dried surface and spore mass to FeSO4, a red reaction of the dried surface to KOH which soon fades to rusty brown, narrow spores, and a lack of thick-walled hymenial elements, (Smith(30)). A more complete list of features is 1) a spherical to lobed fruitbody with the surface cream to yellowish and finally yellowish tan to olive brown, bruising pink to red-brown, 2) whitish brownish rhizomorphs that when young bruise pinkish, 3) a basal cluster of rhizomorphs, 4) a spore mass that is cartilaginous, pallid to yellowish then olive gray to olive-brown or yellow-brown, 5) a rapid dark blackish green reaction of the dried surface and spore mass to FeSO4, 6) a red reaction of the dried surface to KOH which soon fades to rusty brown, 7) underground growth under conifers, 8) smooth spores that are narrowly subfusoid or elliptic or oblong, 9) 4-spored and 8-spored basidia, 10) a lack of thick-walled hymenial elements, 11) a peridial epicutis that is a turf of spherical to ovoid, thin-walled, inflated cells, and 12) a peridial subcutis with oleiferous hyphae and orange brown to reddish brown pigment.^ It is abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Collections were examined from OR, AR, CA, FL, MA, MS, TN, and VA, (Miller). Collections were examined from BC (although paraphyses were thick-walled), ID, NS, and TN, (Smith(30) saying that they are tentatively assigned here). It is found in ID (rare) according to Smith(4). It was reported from WA by Colgan(2). Besides being found in the Pacific Northwest, it is widespread in the United States and Europe, (Trappe(13)). It is found in the United Kingdom (Hawker(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  for dried collections, surface and spore mass quickly dark blackish green in FeSO4, surface red in KOH but the red soon fading to rusty brown^, (Smith(30)), FeSO4 on white peridium dull grey to blackish grey, negative on older surface, negative on spore mass, KOH on white surface reddish white, on yellow or olive areas brown, KOH negative on spore mass, (Miller)
OUTER SURFACE  up to 4cm across, cream to ochraceous and often yellowish brown where exposed; rhizomorphs brownish; basal cluster of rhizomorphs^, (Smith(4)), 1.5-5cm across, spherical to slightly lobate; "at first white, then yellowish tinged with reddish, finally greenish brown"; with mycelial threads, thin and branching, appressed; peridium not detachable, (Lincoff), up to 4cm across, spherical, ovate, or somewhat flattened, when large may be lobed; cream when young, "becoming yellowish tan with slight olivaceous flush (parts exposed to daylight darker brown), turning pink where bruised"; "minutely felty-fibrillose, often cracked"; "rhizomorphs inconspicuous and few on upper side", forming 1-3 rootlets in lower part, brownish, (Smith(30)), 1-4cm across, nearly spherical, ellipsoid, flattened, or irregularly lobed, frequently compound; white when young and unexposed, then yellowish white, pastel yellow, finally grayish yellow to olive brown, the white surface bruising reddish white, older or exposed surface bruising brownish red to violet brown; dry, smooth, cottony-fibrillose when young, then felty, shiny, metallic in upper part when old after prolonged exposure, when dried grayish yellow, often with patches of brighter yellow; rhizomorphs "abundant near basal attachment, coarse, free hanging, profusely branched, rarely appressed over upper surface", white bruising reddish white when young, when old white to yellowish white, often with no bruising reaction, when dried yellowish brown, appressed, conspicuous near base; peridium in cross-section 0.05-0.15cm thick, "thickest near basal attachment, flushing dull red", (Miller), pale cream when young and staining red where cut or bruised; when mature dull yellow to yellowish brown; lacking rhizomorphs on sides and top, (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "pallid then olive gray"; cartilaginous when fresh, sectioning readily when dried^, (Smith(4)), soft; white at first, becoming greenish and finally olive-brown; with narrow maze-like chambers, (Lincoff), pallid almost to maturity; chambers empty; deliquescent when mature, (Smith(30)), soft, cake-like at first, then tough, cartilaginous, when old gelatinous; white to yellowish white or pale yellow when young, then olive yellow, finally olive brown to yellowish brown, "often mottled light to dark because of erratic maturation", young specimens with pale spore mass occasionally bruising pinkish white, when dried grayish yellow to yellowish brown, (Miller), white when young, light olive by maturity, (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  basal cluster of rhizomorphs^ (Smith(4)), rhizomorphs forming 1-3 rootlets in lower part, (Smith(30)), rhizomorphs abundant near basal attachment, (Miller)
ODOR  slight (Smith(4)), slightly acid and fruity then acrid and penetrating (Lincoff), faint, like Scleroderma, or in some mature specimens strong and offensive, (Smith(30)), similar to the commercial mushroom when fresh, when old strongly of road tar, (Miller)
TASTE  initially sweet (Lincoff), mild (Trappe, M.(3))
EDIBILITY  edible when immature, but too difficult to identify accurately (Lincoff for Europe)
HABITAT  under mixed conifers^ (Smith(4)), underground under conifers, often gregarious (Lincoff), "occurring primarily on disturbed, eroded, or less than optimal sites", associated with a variety of conifers, (in the western United States including Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), P. contorta (Lodgepole Pine), P. monticola (Western White Pine), Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain hemlock), and Abies amabilis (Pacific Silver Fir)), July to December, (Miller), with Pinus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Abies, and other conifers "in young to mature stands from sea level to subalpine", year-round, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5.5-8 x 2-2.6 microns, many subfusoid^; "peridium of appressed hyphae, no pockets of vesiculose cells seen, in KOH finally fulvous near the surface" and nearly colorless toward the spore mass, with copious pigment in peridium as revived in KOH, (Smith(4)), spores 5-8 x 2-3 microns, elliptic, smooth, whitish, (Lincoff), spores 5.5-8 x 2-2.6 microns, narrowly subfusoid to elliptic varying to oblong, smooth, in Melzer's reagent yellowish singly and in groups, in KOH colorless singly and yellowish in groups, with inconspicuous basal scar; basidia 4-spored and 8-spored, 14-17 x 4-5 microns, "subcylindric, readily collapsing"; paraphyses 10-18 x 4-10 microns, subspherical to clavate or vesiculose and thin-walled; cystidia none; "subhymenium poorly developed and individual cells indistinct in revived material"; tramal plates "with gelatinous highly refractive hyphae more or less interwoven"; peridium of "appressed-interwoven hyphae at first red in KOH but soon fading out to fulvous and with orange-brown pigment globules in upper region (in Melzer's sol.), no pockets of vesiculose cells noted", the part next to the gleba finally nearly colorless; all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections none, (Smith(30)), spores 7.5-9.5(10.5) x 2.5-3.0 microns, subcylindric, oblong to narrowly subfusoid, often slightly curved in side view, in Melzer's reagent pale yellow singly, dull olive yellow in mass, mostly with 2-3 lipid droplets, in KOH pale yellow singly, dull yellowish gray in mass, basal scar present but not prominent; basidia borne in a distinct hymenium, 12-18 x 4-5 microns, subcylindric to narrowly clavate, "thin-walled and soon collapsing, mostly 8-spored", brachybasidioles 10-20 x 6-10 microns, subspherical, clavate, or obovate, thin-walled when young, thick-walled, mucilaginous when old, not readily disarticulated in crush mounts; subhymenium poorly developed, composed of branching, colorless, thin-walled or thick-walled, cylindric or cubic hyphae; trama of hyphae that are 4-7 microns wide, colorless, highly refractive in KOH, cylindric to slightly swollen, thin-walled when young, mucilaginous when old, oleiferous hyphae present in mediostratum, 6-12 microns wide, hyaline refractive to deep yellow in KOH and in Melzer's reagent, "cylindric or irregularly swollen and contorted"; peridium 300-360 microns thick, peridial subcutis a layer of hyphae that are 6-14 microns wide, cylindric, appressed, interwoven, and thin-walled, oleiferous hyphae abundant, 8-20 microns wide, dark yellowish brown in KOH and in Melzer's reagent, cylindric or irregularly swollen and contorted, occasionally branching, slightly gelatinized when old, "lightly encrusted with amorphous pigment that is orange brown to reddish brown in KOH, orange brown in Melzer's reagent, readily liquefying into large, compound orange brown pigment globules", peridial epicutis a turf of spherical to ovoid, thin-walled, inflated cells; clamp connections absent, (Miller)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'common'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon abietis is similar to fresh collections of R. vulgaris "in that both species are distinctly yellow, bruise red, and have a tangle of white rhizomorphs near the point of attachment", but in R. abietis spores are longer and wider and often have a knobby crooked apex, (Miller). Rhizopogon rubescens has wider spores, the FeSO4 reaction is weaker, paraphyses tend to become thick-walled, and cystidia may be present, (Smith(30)). Rhizopogon evadens lacks the distinctly yellow surface, and typically will bruise much faster and turns more magenta when young and fresh, (Miller). Rhizopogon defectus becomes vinaceous pink in some areas as dried, has a columella (in some basidiocarps at least), lacks a KOH color change of the fresh peridium, and has only a very weak to lacking FeSO4 reaction, (Smith(30)). Rhizopogon cusickiensis differs in the hymenial elements, (Smith(30)). See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon butyraceus, Rhizopogon ellenae, Rhizopogon evadens var. evadens, Rhizopogon ochraceorubens, and Rhizopogon vinicolor.
