SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Lincoff(1)*, Miller, S.L.(1) (colors mostly from Kornerup(3)), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Colgan(2), Hawker(1), Trappe(13)
284
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon willamettensis  H.V. Sm. & A.H. Sm.^  How to know the non-gilled fleshy fungi: 348. 1973;  == Rhizopogon brunneofibrillosus  A.H. Sm.  Journal of the Mitchell Society 84(2): 275. 1968
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include more or less spherical fruitbody with dark dull brown rhizomorphs over dingy ochraceous ground color when fresh, the spore mass olive-buff with 2-4 chambers per mm, and chemical and microscopic characters, including intense brick red reaction to KOH (as contrasted with relatively little coloration when revived in KOH), small narrow spores and nongelatinous hymenium of the candelabra type^; the online Species Fungorum previously gave the name Rhizopogon brunneofibrillosus as a homotypic synonym for Rhizopogon willamettensis, but when accessed on December 16, 2014 gave the latter as the current name; this species R. brunneofibrillosus is not the same as R. brunneifibrillosus A.H. Sm. which is likely the reason for the new name; found in OR
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH intensely brick red on fresh surface, going quickly to dark red brown (dark bay brown), FeSO4 slowly dark olive-brown
OUTER SURFACE  5cm across, spherical or nearly so; "with conspicuous coating of brown (near cinnamon brown) rhizomorphs over a dingy ochraceous ground color that slowly changes to cinnamon buff by late maturity, not changing color when handled"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  chambers large, 2-4 per mm, consistency friable when dried; olive-buff and retaining an olive tone when dried
STEM  columella lacking
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  from a mixed collection brought to Annual Mushroom Show of Oregon Mycological Society from somewhere in the Willamette River Valley
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-6.5 x 2-2.2 microns, oblong to narrowly elliptic, smooth, in Melzer's reagent pale dingy ochraceous (and most with a false septum), in KOH nearly colorless singly but ochraceous buff in groups, thin-walled^; basidia 12-25 x 7-12 microns; basidioles resembling basidia and thin-walled (wall up to 0.5 micron thick); "hymenium with candelabra type of branching and hence the subhymenium not sharply distinct from the hymenium", the hyphae 5-9 microns wide and nongelatinous; tramal plates of nongelatinous hyphae 4-12 microns wide, (the cells often enlarged but the structure of the plate obviously filamentous), hyphal walls 0.2-0.5 microns thick, smooth, and colorless; peridium with embedded rhizomorphs, of appressed hyphae 5-12 microns wide, "hyphal cells often somewhat inflated but no sphaerocysts seen either singly or in groups, encrusting material present on walls and dingy vinaceous brown as revived in KOH, pigment pockets (probably massive incrustations) similarly colored (no red or olive coloration in material revived in KOH)"; in Melzer's reagent "with scattered dull orange-brown pigment bodies (globules or variously shaped bodies)"; clamp connections none
NAME ORIGIN  from 'brunneus' - 'brown', and 'fibrillosus' - 'fibrillose'
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon fuscorubens has wider spores and rhizomorphs are distinctively colored (to fuscous-red or magenta) as revived in KOH, (Smith(28))
SOURCES  Smith(28) (as R. brunneofibrillosus)
285
FAMILY  Rhizopogonaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Rhizopogon zelleri  A.H. Sm.^  Mem. N.Y. Bot. Gard. 14: 75. 1966
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include more or less spherical fruitbody with creased scurfy surface that is wood-brown when fresh, grayish tan dried spore mass, growth in duff under conifers, and microscopic characters including smooth spores, and peridial epicutis of interwoven brown-walled hyphae, some flagellate hyphae present^; much larger fruitbodies up to 8cm may be this species; infrequent in the Pacific Northwest, found western OR to ID and the Rocky Mountains, (Trappe(13)), found OR, ID according to Smith(4), specimen from NM used in study (Grubisha(2))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.8-1.5cm across, wood brown but when dried cinnamon-brown (paler where epicutis has been removed); unpolished, scurfy^, (Smith(4)), 0.8-1.5cm across, spherical to nearly spherical and more or less creased and uneven; about "wood-brown" when fresh (never any red tints), when dried near cinnamon-brown except for paler areas where epicutis has been removed; dry, dull, appearing scurfy, (Smith(30))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "firm but not hard as dried"; "cinnamon-buff to (when mature) avellaneous"^, (Smith(4)), chambered, firm when dried but sectioning readily (neither bone-like or crumbly); when dried near "cinnamon-buff" to "avellaneous" (a grayish tan), (Smith(30))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in duff under conifers April in Oregon, July and August in Idaho^, (Smith(4)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-12 x 3.5-4 microns^; subhymenium "of branched filaments gelatinous in KOH", peridial epicutis "thin, flagellate hyphal ends present but no thornlike projections seen", (Smith(4)), spores 9-12 x 3.5-4 microns, "suboblong to oblong-angular or many with a slight medial constriction, some subclavate, a fair number obscurely angular in outline, truncate from the sterigmal scar", smooth, in KOH pale ochraceous singly, near cinnamon-buff in groups, in Melzer's reagent more ochraceous but not dextrinoid; basidia "6-spored (as far as observed)", 5-7 microns wide, spores sessile or nearly so; paraphyses "of septate filaments with apical cell basidiole-like", thin-walled; cystidia none; tramal plates of smooth, colorless, "gelatinous-refractive hyphae subparallel to interwoven"; subhymenium "of filamentose elements refractive-gelatinous in KOH"; peridium "composed of a loosely interwoven thin epicutis of dull brown-walled hyphae" 3-8 microns wide, "the walls 1-1.5 microns thick, some hyphae lumpy but none seen with thorn-like projections, flagellate hyphae present", inner layer of hyphae 4-10 microns wide, compactly interwoven and colorless, "no sphaerocysts seen, much bright green to olive-green pigment diffused in region next to glebal cavities, no truly reddish areas observed"; clamp connections absent; all tissues inamyloid, "but scattered amyloid granules present on some hyphae", (Smith(30))
NAME ORIGIN  "dedicated to Dr. S.M. Zeller, whose work in the Pacific Northwest did much to advance our knowledge of this group of fungi"
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon rogersii presumably stains red on injury and has slightly smaller spores, (Smith(30)); other species associated with Douglas-fir that have woven brown hyphae in the peridium revived in KOH include Rhizopogon parksii (spores 4.5-6.5 x 2.3-3 microns), Rhizopogon hawkerae (spores 6.5-8 x 2.2-2.8 microns), Rhizopogon villescens (spores 7-10 x 3-4 microns), Rhizopogon villosulus (spores 6-8 x 2.2.5 microns), (these four like R. zelleri with at least some flagellate hyphae), Rhizopogon subareolatus (spores 6-7 x 2-2.3 microns), Rhizopogon vinicolor (spores 5.5-8 x 3-4.5 microns), and Rhizopogon subclavatisporus (spores 8-13 x 4.5-7 microns and thicker on one end), (Trappe, M.) . See also SIMILAR section of Rhizopogon ponderosus and Rhizopogon subclavitisporus.
SOURCES  Smith(30), Smith(4), Grubisha(2), NATS(1) (Trappe, M., accessed April 6, 2005), Trappe(13)
286
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Roesleria subterranea  (Weinm.) Redhead^  Can. J. Bot. 62(12): 2516 (1985) [1984];  == Pilacre subterranea  Weinm.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) tiny fruitbodies growing on roots of commercial grapes, the fruitbodies consisting of a spherical, light gray, powdery spore mass and a slender, light yellow, smooth stem, and 2) microscopic characters.^ The description here is derived from that of Dennis(1) for Roesleria pallida, this description being one specified by Redhead(65) for Roesleria subterranea in making the new combination. RANGE Collections of Roesleria subterranea were examined from BC, France (slide only), and Germany, (Redhead).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  head breaking down into a spherical, light gray, powdery spore mass scarcely 0.1cm across
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  
STEM  slender; light yellow; smooth
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on roots of commercial grapes (Redhead), single on bark, (Dennis)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-6 x 4-5 microns, broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless to light greenish gray, uniseriate in the ascus^; asci 8-spored, up to 55 x 10 microns, cylindric, soon vanishing; slender hyphae among the asci "have been called paraphyses but there is no compact hymenium"; stem consisting of hyphae about 3-4 microns wide, compact, parallel, thin-walled, the hyphae becoming loose and radiating in the head, (Dennis), spores have pale isabelline wall pigmentation; a septum divides the spores across their broadest plane but is only visible in lateral views (liquid mounts most often show the polar view because of the orientation of the slightly compressed sides against the slide surface); spores of Roesleria are described as roughened (at least under scanning electron microscope), (Redhead)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'underground'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Dennis(1) (as Roesleria pallida), Redhead(65)
287
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Uncertain, Class Uncertain, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Roeslerina microspora  Redhead^  Can. J. Bot. 62(12): 2515. (1985) [1984]
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include tiny fruitbodies growing on small diameter roots, the colorless fruitbodies consisting of a dry, powdery, fertile head and a bald stem, and microscopic characters^; collections examined from BC, WV, (Redhead)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  colorless fruitbodies with a dry, powdery, fertile head and a stem
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  
STEM  0.03-0.08cm x 0.006-0.01cm, narrowly tapered upwards, round in cross-section, bald
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground on small diameter roots
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 2.5-3 microns, nearly round to lens-shaped, appearing smooth under light microscope but roughened under scanning electron microscope, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled, 1-celled, usually uniseriate in the ascus^; asci normally clustered on a common subhymenial cell, 8-spored, 19-22 x 3-3.5 microns, cylindric, "undifferentiated apically, evanescent", "occasionally formed in chains of 2, or as intercalary units at the bases of the capillitium hyphae"; capillitium hyphae interspersed among the asci, projecting well above the intact asci, 50-100 x 3.5-4 microns, contorted, colorless, thin-walled, septate; stem composed of filaments to only slightly inflated cells, 3-5.5 microns in diameter, with smooth, slightly to notably thickened walls (up to 0.5 microns), "somewhat incrusted in the apical region"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with small spores'
SIMILAR  Roeslerina radicella has larger fruitbodies, spores, and asci, and may have different habitat on the smaller primary rootlets 0.05-0.1cm thick, versus the larger perennial rootlets 0.5-1cm thick for R. microspora, (Redhead)
SOURCES  Redhead(65)
288
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Uncertain, Class Uncertain, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Roeslerina radicella  Redhead^  Can. J. Bot. 62(12): 2515. (1985) [1984]
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include tiny fruitbodies growing on fine rootlets, the colorless fruitbodies consisting of a dry, powdery, fertile head and a bald stem, and microscopic characters^; collections examined from BC (Redhead)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  colorless fruitbodies with a dry, powdery, fertile head and a stem
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  
STEM  0.03-0.25cm x 0.0045-0.009cm, narrowly tapered upward, round in cross-section, bald
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground on fine rootlets
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9.5 x 5.5-6 microns, nearly round to broadly elliptic, appearing smooth under light microscope but roughened under scanning electron microscope, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled, 1-celled, usually uniseriate in the ascus^; asci normally clustered on a common cell, 8-spored, 31-53 x 6.3-7 microns, cylindric, "undifferentiated apically, evanescent", occasionally formed in short 1-celled to 3-celled chains that disarticulate easily, or in intercalary fashion as basal cells to the capillitium hyphae; capillitium hyphae "interspersed among the asci, projecting well above the intact asci", 100-230 x 4.5-5 microns, contorted, colorless, thin-walled, septate, occasionally branched at the bases, and occasionally slightly swollen in upper part; stem composed of slightly inflated cells, 3.5-7(9) microns in diameter, with smooth, slightly thickened walls forming textura porrecta tissue
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Roeslerina microspora has smaller fruitbodies, spores, and asci, and may have different habitat on larger perennial rootlets 0.5-1cm thick versus the smaller primary rootlets 0.05-0.1cm thick for R. radicella, (Redhead)
SOURCES  Redhead(65)

FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula acerba  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 231. 2018;  == Macowanites acris  Singer & A.H. Sm.  Mem. Torrey Bot. Club 21: 86. 1960
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include 1) a dull grayish vinaceous, convex-depressed, dry cap, 2) firm hard flesh, 3) a pale tan spore mass that appears somewhat gill-like from underneath, but is chambered internally, 4) a short bulbous white stem stained faintly ochraceous at the base, 5) a peppery taste, and 6) microscopic characters including broadly elliptic spores usually with low ornamentation of cones and warts joined by fine lines or in series, 4-spored (more rarely 2-spored) basidia, hymenial macrocystidia, a well differentiated hymenopodium, and an outer layer of peridium with a hypodermial layer and the epicuticular layer a turf containing dermatopseudocystidia and septate primordial hyphae.^ The description is derived from Singer(10). When Macowanites acris was moved to Russula a new species epithet was chosen because of the prior name Russula acris Steinhaus, Hedwigia 27: 51: 1888. RANGE The type collection is from ID.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 with flesh of cap pallid to slightly dingy
OUTER SURFACE  5cm across, convex-depressed, with decurved [downcurved] margin; dull grayish vinaceous ("Benzo brown"); dry, unpolished, creased
INNER LAYER  firm and hard in cap, firm and hard in stem
INTERIOR  1.5cm thick at deepest part, hard, firm; pale tan ("pinkish-buff"); as seen from underneath, obscurely gill-like, but loculate [chambered] "because of the development of cross walls and veins" toward the upper part of the fruitbody, attached at apex of stem-columella
STEM  3cm x 2cm at top, bulbous and 1cm wide at base, solid; white, stained faintly ochraceous at base; unpolished
ODOR  
TASTE  acrid [peppery]
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single under Picea [spruce]
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-11.7 x 7-9.7 microns, broadly elliptic, ornamentation projecting 0.3-0.8(1) micron, mostly about 0.5-0.6 microns, on "smaller spores (from 4-spored basidia) of cones and warts with occasional linear thin connections or tail-like extensions, or warts in series forming short chains", on larger spores mostly almost smooth to smooth (if smooth then amyloid), spore wall rather deep ochraceous in ammonia, sterigmal appendage eccentric, oblique^; hymenium continuous, basidia 4-spored (more rarely 2-spored), 45-66 x 11-13 microns, clavate, colorless revived in dilute bases, sterigmata 6-8 microns long, curved or straight (mostly curved); macrocystidia abundant, 70-100 x 6-13 microns, projecting, fusoid, in KOH nearly colorless, in dilute bases often only densely granular; subhymenium "of mostly subisodiametric small elements intermixed with some short-cylindric or irregular elements extending towards the base of the basidia, characteristically of the subcellular type", hymenopodium consisting of hyphae 2-3 microns wide, filamentose, somewhat interwoven, extending generally in the direction of the tramal plates; tramal mediostratum heteromerous, sphaerocysts prominent; outer layers of peridium well differentiated, consisting of an inner hypodermial layer and a clearly delimited epicuticular layer, the hypodermial layer similar in aspect to the homologous layer in typical acrid [peppery] Russulas ("pink but bleaching quickly in ammonia" and consisting of repent filamentous nongelatinous hyphae), epicuticular layer composed of loosely arranged hyphal ends 15-40 x 2-3 microns, somewhat gelatinized and in a turf-like arrangement, "the elements irregular in outline or forked", and interspersed with these are hypha-like dermatopseudocystidia 35-50 x 4-5 microns, also present are septate primordial hyphae with broadly rounded apices "as well as other elements intermediate between primordial hyphae and dermatopseudocystidia"; hyphae of all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent in all tissues
NAME ORIGIN  means "bitter" (Elliott, T.F.(1))
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Macowanites acris) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Trappe(13) (as Macowanites acris), Elliott, T.F.(1)
290
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula albidigleba  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 231. 2018;  Macowanites albidigleba  Singer & A.H. Sm.  Mem. Torrey Bot. Club 21: 85. 1960
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include 1) a convex cap that is pallid becoming pale dull rose-color, 2) a spore mass that is white, somewhat gill-like where exposed between cap margin and stem but with small irregular chambers in the interior, 3) flesh that is firm and white, 4) a stem that is firm and white, 5) a broadly percurrent columella, 6) a taste that is slowly slightly peppery, 7) a pinkish reaction of FeSO4 on flesh of cap and stem, and 8) microscopic characters including nearly round to broadly elliptic spores with an ornamentation of short ridges often connected by fine lines, and some unconnected warts, basidia that are 2-spored or 4-spored, macrocystidia in the hymenium, a poorly differentiated hymenopodium, and a peridial epicutis that is a turf with dermatopseudocystidia.^ The description is derived from Singer(10). RANGE The type was found in ID.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 on context of peridium and stem pinkish
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, convex, not expanding, with rounded margin, spore mass exposed between margin and stem; pallid at first, slowly becoming pale dull rose-color (near "vinaceous tawny"); "dry, moist but not viscid under moderately humid conditions", unpolished when mature, uneven
INNER LAYER  firm and white in cap, firm and white in stem
INTERIOR  white until old and then merely "pale pinkish buff" in the interior (elsewhere color given as white to cream); appearing obscurely gill-like over the exposed part, "lacunose inside and with very small irregular chambers"
STEM  about 1cm x 0.8-1cm, firm, subequal, white, columella very broadly percurrent [going through to cap surface] and spore mass attached to it only near the apex
ODOR  none
TASTE  mild at first, finally tardily slightly acrid [slowly slightly peppery]
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection closely gregarious under Abies grandis (Grand Fir), July
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7.5-11 x 7.5-9.7 microns, nearly round to broadly elliptic, ornamentation "rather variable, projecting 0.3-0.8 microns, the majority with ornamentation in the form of irregular short ridges and crests often fused or connected by fine lines, some unconnected warts and smaller amyloid particles also present in an irregular pattern, at times almost forming a broken reticulum", pale yellowish in dilute bases, sterigmal appendage oblique and eccentric^; basidia 2-spored or 4-spored, 35-54 x 13.5-15.8 microns; macrocystidia 40-72 x 12-18.5 microns, "varying from fusoid to clavate and sometimes with a mucro"; subhymenium "narrow, subcellular to cellular, with elements about as broad as the base of the basidium", "hymenopodium poorly developed (1-2 hyphae broad)"; tramal mediostratum "heteromerous, with large and medium sized sphaerocysts abundant"; peridial context "similar in structure to the mediostratum of the tramal plates"; peridial epicutis of dermatopseudocystidia 40-70 x 5-12 microns, with loose contents, sometimes septate, rounded to obtuse at apex, located among the elements of a turf of irregular, often branched, colorless hyphal ends with homogeneous content "and all loosely arranged in a subgelatinous layer"; all hyphae inamyloid; clamp connections none
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with white gleba'
SIMILAR  Russula subloculata is similar but Russula albidigleba differs in having a paler peridium when young, a much paler gleba [spore mass], a slowly slightly peppery taste, and a poorly differentiated hymenopodium, (Singer).
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Macowanites albidiglebus) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Trappe(13) (as Macowanites albidiglebus), Elliott, T.F.(1)
291
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula alleinstanleyae  T.F. Elliott & Trappe^  Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 232. 2018;  == Macowanites citrinus  Singer & A.H. Sm.  Mem. Torrey Bot. Club 21: 82. 1960
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include a slightly viscid cap that is lemon yellow over disc, when old grayish along the margin, a chambered spore mass that is buff becoming pale grayish where exposed, a short white stem, growth under Lodgepole Pine, chemical characters including a gray reaction of FeSO4 on stem flesh, and microscopic characters including elliptic to nearly round spores with amyloid ornamentation in the form of a broken reticulum, and 4-spored basidia (more rarely 2-spored).^  When Macowanites citrinus was moved to Russula, a different species epithet was chosen because of the prior name Russula citrina Gillet, Revue Mycol., (Toulouse) 3(no.11): 5 (1881).  Gymnomyces citrinus (Harkn.) Trappe, T. Lebel & Castellano, Mycotaxon 81: 199. 2002, is also different, being a synonym of Russula harknessii Trappe & T.F. Elliott. RANGE The holotype was found in ID.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 gray on stem context, (Smith), FeSO4 on cap flesh no reaction, with spore mass soon grayish, with stem flesh soon gray, (Singer)
OUTER SURFACE  2-4cm across, convex, margin incurved and in places touching the stem-columella; lemon yellow over the disc, when old grayish along the margin; slightly viscid, skin often cracking into irregular plates^, (Smith), 2-4cm across, "convex, usually remaining so" but rarely expanding to broadly convex, leaving spore mass exposed below, margin incurved and in places touching the stem-columella, acute or subacute; "white with a lemon yellow to greenish yellow disc", when old watery gray along the margin; slightly viscid, smooth, when old the surface cracking into irregular plates, exposing the thin white flesh or even penetrating to the spore mass; peridium thin, fragile, (Singer)
INNER LAYER  white in cap, columella, and stem^, (Singer)
INTERIOR  spore mass "buff becoming pale grayish where exposed"; chambered^, (Smith), "cartridge buff when freshly cut but gradually becoming pale grayish when such surfaces remain exposed"; "chambered with irregular elongate cavities, gill outlines barely visible", (Singer)
STEM  1-1.5cm x 0.8-1.1cm, spore mass attached at top; white; unpolished; veil lacking^, (Singer)
ODOR  faintly pungent^ (Singer)
TASTE  mild^ (Singer)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type gregarious under Pinus contortus (Lodgepole Pine), July^, (Singer)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-12 x 8-10 microns, ornamentation to 1.5 microns high; cystidia rare, 48-64 x 9-11 microns, mucronate^, (Smith), spores mostly 9-11(14) x 8-10(12) microns, elliptic to nearly round, amyloid ornamentation projecting (0.5)1-1.3 microns, "typically in the form of a broken reticulum", spores stramineous in KOH, "with oblique eccentrically attached sterigmal appendage, rarely more symmetrical"; basidia 4-spored or more rarely 2-spored, 31-36 x 11-14 microns, "sterigmata apical, half-sickle-shaped or more rarely either long-conic and straight, or irregular"; pseudocystidia rare, 48-64 x 9-11 microns, "mucronate at tip in most, with oily-refractive contents (apparently not typical macrocystidia)", "some oleiferous hyphae may enter the lower portion of the hymenium but do not form cystidiform terminal members"; subhymenium "consisting of some elongate branched hyphae but typically of subisodiametric elements, hence cellular, thin to medium width", "hymenopodium generally indistinct at maturity, when present consisting of elongated filamentous elements"; tramal mediostratum varying, according to thickness of tramal plates, from extremely thin "to very thick particularly where tramal plates connect, and in these thicker places the tissue is heteromerous", in fact the sphaerocysts are so abundant that in some sections the tissue appears cellular; peridial epicutis well developed but scarcely differentiated into outer and inner layer, "consisting of a turf of filaments with some oleiferous hyphae intermingled", the filaments 3-6 microns wide and many with numerous (2-4) cross walls, "the cells usually irregular in shape, the filaments often breaking up at the septa, and the cells becoming free", dermatopseudocystidia aseptate to septate, the latter type often with homogeneous contents, "the aseptate ones rounded or narrowed to an obtuse tip, with granular or banded content", both types about 70 x 6-6.6 microns, epicuticular elements of the center of the fruitbody with a bright yellow pigment permeating the preparation; context of cap, columella and stem heteromerous; all hyphae inamyloid; clamp connections absent in all hyphae, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  "In honor of mycologist and educator Allein Stanley for her more than 40 years of dedicated service to the North American Mycological Association." (Elliott, T.F.(1))
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Russula lymanensis and Russula iodiolens.
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Macowanites citrinus), Smith(4) (as Macowanites citrinus), Trappe(13) (as Macowanites citrinus), Elliott, T.F.(1)
292
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula aromatica  Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 234. 2018;  == Gymnomyces fragrans  (A.H. Sm.) Trappe, T. Lebel, & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 199. 2002;  == Martellia fragrans  A.H. Sm.  Mycologia 55: 437. 1963
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  unusual features are the styrofoam-like consistency of the fresh spore mass, the vanilla-like odor when fresh, and the nongelatinous tramal hyphae, other features include nearly spherical, dry, bald, unpolished fruitbody that is pallid becoming pale cinnamon brown, absence of basal attachment, absence of adhering rhizomorphs, absent columella, round to nearly round spores with ornamentation of separate rods and spines that are somewhat connected, 4-spored basidia, and epicutis of peridium with a turf of dermatocystidia^; when the species was moved to Russula, a new species epithet was required because of the prior name Russula fragrans Romagn. (1954); Russula aromatica was described from ID (Smith(24)); rare, central ID, (Trappe(13)), also found OR, CA, (Castellano(1), who give different hosts)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on peridial surface russet, FeSO4 on surface no reaction^, (Smith(24)), KOH on peridial surface red (Castellano)
OUTER SURFACE  1-4.5cm across, spherical or nearly so; "pallid, slowly becoming cinnamon brown"; dry, bald, unpolished^, (Smith(4)), 1-4.5cm across, spherical or nearly so; pallid when young, by maturity pale cinnamon brown; dry, bald "but unpolished and usually with much dirt adhering", (Smith(24))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "pallid to whitish, staining cinnamon"; "dry and firm (like styrofoam)"^, (Smith), dry and firm (like styrofoam); pallid to whitish when young, staining cinnamon around larval tunnels or flushed cinnamon when old (finally dark russet); cavities large and irregular (readily evident without the aid of a hand lens), (Smith(24))
STEM  columella absent^ (Smith(4)), no basal attachment, no adhering rhizomorphs, no columella, (Smith(24))
ODOR  vanilla-like when fresh; dried collections have a fragrant odor resembling that of some species of Hydnellum^, (Smith(24))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  found in association with roots of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) or Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock) from 1500m to 2500m, June through November, (Castellano), type collection under alpine fir in August, (Smith(4))^, single to gregarious under Abies (fir), August, (Smith(24)), under Abies (Trappe(13))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-11 x 7.5-10 microns, ornamented with isolated rods and spines to 0.7-1.5(2) microns high^; "cystidia rare, filamentose and usually embedded in the hymenium, cuticle of peridium a turf of cystidia 18-27 x 4-8 microns, many brown to ochraceous in KOH", (Smith(4)), spores 8-11 x 7.5-10 microns, round to nearly round, ornamentation "as separate rods and spines 0.7-1.5(2) microns high, some fused into small groups or lines", plage area ornamented the same as the rest of the surface, wall inamyloid and slightly thickened, sterigmal appendage inconspicuous; basidia 4-spored, 23-38 x 8-11 microns, clavate, thin-walled, colorless in KOH, sterigmata very fine; cystidia in hymenium "rare to scattered, filamentose with crooked apices, content homogeneous or nearly so (pseudocystidia)"; subhymenium 1-3 cells deep, the "cells" 4-8 microns in diameter, "and mostly representing cut ends of hyphae because of the intricately interwoven nature of the layer", "central strand entirely of filamentose hyphae 3-8 microns wide, and not gelatinous (though slightly refractive in KOH), lacking sphaerocysts"; epicutis of peridium of dermatocystidia 18-27 x 4-8 microns, "bluntly fusoid, and many brown to ochraceous in KOH, the layer almost obliterated in old specimens"; peridial context "ochraceous to rusty brown in KOH, of interwoven filaments, no sphaerocysts seen", (Smith(24))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with an aroma'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Russula nondistincta.
SOURCES  Smith(24) (as Martellia fragrans), Smith(4) (as Martellia fragrans), Castellano(1) (as Martellia fragrans), Trappe(13) (Gymnomyces fragrans), Elliott, T.F.(1)
293
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula castellanoi  Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 236. 2018;  == Macowanites mollis  Singer & A.H. Sm.  Mem. Torrey Bot. Club 21: 79. 1960;  == Elasmomyces mollis  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Pegler & T.W.K. Young
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category; Russula castellanoi is characterized by 1) a white peridium, 2) a much reduced stem that dries alutaceous [light tan], 3) soft flesh, 4) extremely narrow elements of the spore ornamentation, and 5) its peridial structure, (Castellano). Features include 1) a fruitbody that is depressed-spherical to depressed with a cap, the cap whitish and lubricous, 2) a spore mass that is white to buff, 3) a short stem, 4) large nearly round spores with amyloid ornamentation in the form of small spines fused in groups of 2 or 3 or unconnected, and 5) 1-spored to 2-spored basidia, (Singer).^ It is rare (Trappe(13)). RANGE Russula castellanoi is known from 2 sites in WA and OR, (Castellano). It is found from southwestern WA to northwestern OR, (Trappe(13)). There are two collections by S. Redhead from British Columbia at the University of British Columbia (1972 and 1973).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, depressed-spherical to depressed with a cap; white, drying cinnamon-buff to alutaceous; soft, lubricous or moist; cap surface extending to stem or leaving a narrow to wide and irregular "ringhole" exposing the spore mass^, (Singer), 1.3-3cm across, depressed-spherical to depressed with a cap, white, drying cinnamon tan; lubricous, (Castellano), 1-3cm across, white, drying cinnamon buff to alutaceous; soft to touch, lubricous, (Smith)
INNER LAYER  flesh of cap soft^ (Singer)
INTERIOR  spore mass soft, white to buff, drying slightly paler than cap surface^, (Singer), spore mass white to tan, (Castellano)
STEM  stem-columella present but greatly reduced, stem part 0.4-0.6cm x 0.2-0.3cm, white, columella percurrent [extending to cap surface] or nearly so^, (Singer)
ODOR  none^ (Singer)
TASTE  not recorded^ (Singer)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  found in association with roots of Abies grandis (Grand Fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) above 1000 meters elevation, July and September^, (Castellano), under mixed conifers and hardwoods, September, (Singer)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-15 microns, round, or 11-14(16) x 9.5-13 microns and nearly round to elliptic, "ornamentation in the form of small spines unconnected or fused in groups of 2-3, 0.6-1 micron high" and +/- 0.25 micron broad at base, "completely covered with amylaceous material", sterigmal appendage inconspicuous, plage area ornamented as rest of surface, "spore wall thin to slightly thickened"^; basidia 1-spored to 2-spored, 24-33 x 10-13 microns, clavate, colorless, readily collapsing; basidioles numerous; cystidia rare to scattered, 38-56 x 5-8 microns, "filamentose-acuminate to narrowly clavate-mucronate, with a small amount of refractive content variously distributed (as seen in KOH)"; pseudoparaphyses none; subhymenium of vesiculose elements that when mature are 10-18 microns in diameter and form a layer 2-3 cells deep; mediostratum of tramal plates at first (near margin of cap) filamentose but when mature greatly enlarged cells scattered through it; cap cuticle complex, with a basal cellular layer, the cells 8-15 microns in diameter "over and from which there is a turf of dermatopseudocystidia mixed with branched filaments of fundamental hyphae and this layer somewhat gelatinous in KOH", the turf elements versiform (clavate, contorted, fusoid, capitate-pedicellate, etc.) but generally under 30 microns long (dermatopseudocystidia may be longer); oleiferous hyphae none; clamp connections absent, (Singer), peridial subcutis "a turf of dermatopseudocystidia mixed with somewhat gelatinized, branched hyphae, the turf elements versiform-clavate, contorted, fusoid, capitate-pedicellate, etc., but generally under 30 microns long", (Castellano), spores 11-16 x 9-13 microns, round or nearly round, spore ornamentation amyloid and 0.4-0.8 microns high; cap cuticle "a basal cellular zone giving rise to a somewhat gelatinous turf of versiform elements", (Smith)
NAME ORIGIN  "In honor of Dr. Michael (Caz) Castellano for his career-long fascination with and research on sequestrate fungi" (Elliott, T.F.(1))
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Macowanites mollis), Castellano(1)* (as Macowanites mollis), Smith(4) (as Elasmomyces mollis), Trappe(13) (as Macowanites mollis), Elliott, T.F.(1)
294
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula chlorineolens  Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 232. 2018;  == Macowanites chlorinosmus  A.H. Sm. & Trappe  Mycologia 55: 423. 1963
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Russula chlorineolens is characterized by the chlorine odor and the distorted gills that become deep ochraceous. Other features include an ivory to ochraceous, subviscid cap, a short, white, unchanging stem, an unpleasant taste, an association with spruce and hemlock, spores with amyloid warts, 4-spored basidia, numerous thin-walled cystidia, and a subgelatinous epicutis of the peridium with its elements forming a distinct layer.^ The description is derived from Smith(24) except where noted. It is infrequent among sequestrate species in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). When this species was moved from Macowanites to Russula, a new species epithet was chosen because of the earlier name Russula chlorinosma  Burl. Mycologia 16:22. 1924. RANGE Russula chlorineolens was described from OR, and is also found at least in WA, (Castellano(1)). It is found in coastal OR, CA and AK, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2.5-5.5cm across, convex to broadly convex-depressed; "ivory to pallid yellow over marginal area, disc buff to more dingy ochraceous"; "at least subviscid when wet but soon dry", cap skin when old splitting irregularly or merely somewhat rimose [cracked], separable to center
INNER LAYER  thin, whitish, in stem white
INTERIOR  "adnate to apex of stem, up to 2cm deep in widest part", sublamellate [somewhat gill-like], to labyrinthiform [maze-like]; 'pale ochraceous when young ("E" of Crawshay), becoming orange ochraceous in age ("F")'
STEM  stem-columella 1-3cm x 0.6-0.9cm, "equal or nearly so, solid, fragile"; "white to pallid, unchanging on injury", pallid when dried
ODOR  of chlorine, "faint in the youngest specimens, strong in old ones and becoming objectionable"
TASTE  very unpleasant, somewhat chlorinaceous but not acrid [not peppery]
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  found in association with roots of Sitka spruce (Picea sitchensis) and western hemlock (Tsuga heterophylla) below 200m elevation^, (Castellano), scattered to gregarious under spruce and hemlock, (Smith(24))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-9.5 x 6.5-7.5 microns, broadly elliptic to nearly round, ornamented with small strongly amyloid warts 0.3-0.5(0.8) microns high, "closely gregarious or united into small groups but no semblance of a reticulum present, typically with an amorphous amyloid jacket around base of sterigmal appendage, plage area ornamented", wall inamyloid^; basidia 4-spored, 23-30 x 9-12 microns, clavate, colorless in KOH; cystidia "abundant and voluminous, 50-65 x 10-15 microns, subclavate-mucronate, cylindric mucronate, or narrowly clavate, with a slight amount of refringent content, walls very thin and cystidia collapsing by late maturity and then hard to demonstrate in KOH mounts"; hymenophoral trama with a cellular subhymenium, the cells 6-12 microns in diameter, "this area grading imperceptibly into the central area which is composed of inflated cells and appears to be entirely pseudoparenchymatous in sections revived in KOH"; context of peridium "of heteromerous tissue, the sphaerocysts thin-walled"; subcutis of peridium "appressed-interwoven hyphae with scattered greatly inflated isolated cells along the base of the epicuticular turf"; epicutis of peridium "a compact subgelatinous (revived in KOH) trichodermium of versiform elements adhering tenaciously together to form a layer with outlines of individual cells often not too clear, the component elements of the hyphae with variously enlarged cells (up to 20 microns broad) and clavate, cylindric, or fusoid end-cells showing clearly, dermatopseudocystidia scattered to rare"; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  means 'smelling of chlorine'
SIMILAR  Russula vilgalysii [as Macowanites fulvescens] has larger spores (Smith(24))
SOURCES  Smith(24) (as Macowanites chlorinosmus), Castellano(1)* (as Macowanites chlorinosmus), Smith(4) (as Macowanites chlorinosmus), Trappe(13)* (as Macowanites chlorinosmus), Elliott, T.F.(1)
295
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula dodgei  Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 233. 2018;  == Gymnomyces cremeus  (Zeller & C.W. Dodge) Trappe, T. Lebel, & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 199. 2002;  == Martellia cremea  (Zeller & C.W. Dodge) Singer & A.H. Sm.;  == Arcangeliella cremea  Zeller & C.W. Dodge
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include irregularly shaped fruitbody that is light buff to cinnamon-buff and marbled, firm cinnamon-buff spore-mass, percurrent creamy white columella, and microscopic characters including round to broadly ellipsoid spores ornamented with closely set isolated spines and warts up to 2 microns high, the tips often amyloid, basidia 2-spored and 4-spored, ventricose-mucronate cystidia, and peridial cuticle of interwoven hyphae^; when this species was moved from Gymnomyces to Russula, a new species epithet was required because of the prior name Russula cremea (Murrill) Singer Lilloa 22: 711. 1951; rare, western OR, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1cm x 2cm x 2cm, irregular in shape, drying subreniform [somewhat kidney-shaped]; light buff to cinnamon-buff, marbled^, (Singer) 
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  firm, cinnamon buff^, (Singer)
STEM  columella percurrent [going through spore mass], creamy white^, (Singer)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection in duff under oaks, March^, (Singer)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-12 (14) x 9-12 microns, round to broadly elliptic, "ornamented with closely set isolated spines and warts up to 2 microns high, the tips often amyloid"^; "cystidia 35-46 x 12-17 microns, ventricose-mucronate; cuticle of peridium of interwoven hyphae", (Smith), spores 10-12(14) x 9-12 microns (excluding ornamentation), round to broadly elliptic, strongly amyloid ornamentation of isolated spines closely set and generally of two sizes, 1) 1.2-2 microns high and 1.5-2 microns wide at base, conic, and 2) smaller warts or particles 0.5-1 microns wide and about as high, "no connecting lines seen, the tips of the spines often with an amyloid plug", over the plage area "usually a few fine amyloid lines present and connected to form a partial reticulum and the warts and spines on that area greatly reduced in size", "the ornamentation easily broken off and littering the mount"; basidia 2-spored and 4-spored, 26-33 x 8-12 microns, clavate, colorless, thin-walled, sterigmata 6-8 x 1.5 microns, conic and narrow; pseudoparaphyses 10-16 microns in diameter, subelliptic, thin-walled; cystidia scattered, 35-46 x 12-17 microns, ventricose-mucronate, rarely with refractive, amorphous content (but when present not the same type as in chrysocystidia), mostly remaining collapsed; subhymenium of sphaerocyst-like cells; hyphae of tramal plates interwoven, colorless; peridium with a thick (about 100 microns) outer filamentous epicutis of hyphae 3-5 microns wide, colorless, interwoven, not incrusted, inner layer heteromerous [with nests of sphaerocysts among filamentous hyphae]; clamp connections none; oleiferous hyphae rare to scattered, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  "In honor of C.W. Dodge, who collaborated with S.M. Zeller in describing numerous new species of sequestrate fungi, including this taxon", (Elliott(1))
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Martellia cremea), Smith(4) (as Martellia cremea), Trappe(13) (as Gymnomyces cremea), Elliott, T.F.(1)
296
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula ellipsospora  (Zeller) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 233. 2018;  Gymnomyces ellipsosporus  (Zeller) Trappe, T. Lebel, & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 199. 2002;  Martellia ellipsospora  (Zeller) Singer & A.H. Sm.;  Hydnangium ellipsosporum  Zeller
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include white to pale ochraceous buff, nearly spherical fruitbody that is smooth but the outer layer flaking off when old at times, spore mass with medium sized cavities, cream color (becoming ochraceous buff), sterile base and columella absent, but occasionally large white rhizomorphs adhering to surface, growth under conifers, and microscopic characters including 1) large spores with heterogeneous ornamentation both as to amyloid reaction and shape and size of the ornamentation, the basidia mostly 1-spored, rarely 2-spored, and 2) lack of sphaerocysts^; found at least in OR, (Singer), AZ (States), infrequent, western OR, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-2cm tall, 1-1.3cm broad, nearly spherical, usually taller than broad; white to pale ochraceous buff; smooth but outer layer flaking off when old at times; "occasionally with large white rhizomorphs adhering to surface"^, (Singer), 0.5-2.5cm across, (States)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  cream becoming ochraceous buff; cavities medium size, empty^, (Smith), chambers small but visible (States)
STEM  no sterile base, no columella^, (Singer)
ODOR  faint and mushroom-like^ (States)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under conifers, June to August, type under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir)^, (Singer), associated with Pinus ponderosus (Ponderosa Pine), (States)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15-20(23) x 12-15 microns, ornamentation of warts, short ridges, and spines to 2.5(3) microns high^; cuticle of peridium of compactly woven hyphae, (Smith), spores 15-20(23) x 12-15(16) microns, broadly elliptic, ornamentation of irregular warts, short ridges and spines and 1.8-2.5(3) x 0.4-1 microns, "strongly amyloid or amylaceous material denser over the elements of the ornamentation in some places than in others and usually darkest at or near the apex, sometimes strongly amyloid on one side of a wart and not on the other, the long narrow elements often bent or crooked", many fine lines and granules of amylaceous material present and connecting the major elements of the ornamentation, spore wall thin, nearly colorless in Melzer's reagent, ochraceous in dilute KOH, "sterigmal appendage prominent in some of the smaller spores, usually inconspicuous in larger ones", "plage area covered with amyloid ornamentation in the form of lines and granules"; basidia mostly 1-spored, rarely 2-spored, 30-42 x 11-15 microns, broadly clavate, colorless in KOH, thin-walled, those with a sterigma resembling mucronate cystidia, basidioles clavate to ellipsoid; pseudoparaphyses resembling inflated basidioles; cystidia none; subhymenium cellular, cells sphaerocyst-like and when old quite inflated (10-20 microns); tramal mediostratum a narrow band of filaments 4-7 microns wide (of equal or nearly equal diameter throughout), interwoven, colorless, branched; peridial epicutis a layer of hyphae 3-6 microns wide, compactly interwoven, the walls thin to slightly thickened but not gelatinous; peridial context (subcutis) of hyphae 5-8 microns wide, more loosely interwoven, colorless, no sphaerocysts seen; clamp connections none, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to ellipsoid spores
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Martellia ellipsospora), Smith(4) (as Martellia ellipsospora), States(2) (as Martellia ellipsospora), Trappe(13) (as Gymnomyces ellipsosporus), Elliott, T.F.(1)

FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula extramaculata Trappe & T.F. Elliott, in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 235 (2018);  Cystangium maculatum  (Singer & A.H. Sm.)  Trappe, T. Lebel, & Castellano^  Mycotaxon 81: 197. 2002;  Martellia maculata  Singer & A.H. Sm.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  characterized by large spiny spores with unique amyloid reaction, 2-spored and 4-spored basidia, lack of cystidia, and cellular peridial epicutis, other features include small pallid fruitbody that is pallid with brown stains in places and that has a surface with broad pits, spore mass also pallid with brown stains in places, absent columella, and underground growth in association with conifers^; when the species was moved to Russula, a new species epithet was required because of the prior name Russula maculata Quel.; found in WA, OR, according to Castellano(1), common, western WA and OR, (Trappe(13)), CA (Smith)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-2cm across, spherical; pallid; uneven to alveolate [with broad pits]^, (Smith), 1-2cm across, spherical; pallid with brown stains in places; surface uneven to alveolate, (Singer)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  pallid, soon stained brown^, (Smith), pallid but with brown stains in places, (Singer)
STEM  no sterile base, no columella, (Singer)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  found in association with the roots of various Pinaceae spp. from sea level to high elevation, September through November^, (Castellano), under Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-cedar), (Singer)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  "spores 10-15 x 8.5-11 microns, ornamentation predominantly of isolated spines to 1 micron high, amyloid only at the tip or one side near the tips of the spines"^; "cuticle of peridium cellular", (Smith), spores 10-15 x 8.5-11 microns, nearly round to elliptic, ornamentation of spines up to 1 micron high and 0.5 microns broad "which are amyloid only at the tip or on one side near the tip, smaller amyloid granules also present on the spore surface but for the most part all elements unconnected", spores pale orange to orange buff in Melzer's reagent, nearer cinnamon-buff in KOH, wall about 1-1.5 microns thick. sterigmal appendage inconspicuous; "plage area not different from remainder of surface"; basidia 2-spored and 4-spored, 20-24 x 10-12 microns, clavate, yellowish in KOH, basidioles numerous, content yellowish in KOH; cystidia absent; subhymenium gelatinous, colorless in KOH, the cells badly collapsed but short and more or less isodiametric; tramal mediostratum subgelatinous, hyphae only slightly inflated, colorless in KOH, thin-walled, no sphaerocysts; peridial context (subcutis) of interwoven, colorless, subgelatinous hyphae, no sphaerocysts present; peridial epicutis an epithelium several cells deep, the walls colorless to yellow, smooth, nongelatinous; clamp connections absent, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  'maculatum' means 'with spots', probably referring to the spotty amyloid reaction of the spore ornamentation; 'extra-' is used to distinguish the species name from Russula maculata Quel.
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Martellia maculata), Smith(4) (as Martellia maculata), Castellano(1) (as Martellia maculata), Trappe(13) (as Cystangium maculatum)
298
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula ferruginascens  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 233. 2018;  Gymnomyces ferruginascens  Singer & A.H. Sm.  Mem. Torrey Bot. Club 21: 54-55. 1960
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to irregular fruitbody that is dull white becoming rusty brown especially from handling, spores mass that is white at first, rusty brown by maturity, chemical characters, and microscopic characters including elliptic to nearly round spores with amyloid spines and warts some of which are unconnected but others fused into groups or connected by fine lines, basidia 2-spored and 4-spored, (very rarely 1-spored or 3-spored)^; found at least ID (Smith), CA (Thiers(4)), infrequent northern ID (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  peridium "staining olivaceous in FeSO4, quickly rusty brown in KOH", (Smith), "FeSO4 pale olivaceous on the gleba", "KOH quickly rusty brown on peridium", (Singer) 
OUTER SURFACE  (0.7)1-5cm across, dull white when young, becoming rusty brown especially from handling^, (Smith), (0.7)1-5cm across, spherical to ellipsoid or irregular; dull white when young, gradually rusty brown especially from handling; dry, unpolished, (Singer)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white at first, rusty brown by maturity^, (Smith), 'white at first, becoming pallid and by maturity "tawny" to "russet" (rusty brown)'; loculate [chambered], chambers empty, (Singer) 
STEM  columella absent; "attached at base but only by a tubercle of mycelium"^, (Singer)
ODOR  "faintly disagreeable in large collections"^ (Singer)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  spruce-fir forests in ID, summer^, (Smith), single to scattered under Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce) and Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), (Singer)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-16(18) x 9-12(15) microns, elliptic to nearly round, ornamentation 1-1.5 microns high^; basidia colorless as revived in KOH; cystidia rare, up to 7.5 microns broad, embedded in hymenium; sphaerocysts not observed in context of peridium; cuticle of peridium a +/- persistent turf, (Smith), spores 12-16(18) x 9-12(15) microns (excluding ornamentation), elliptic to nearly round, "ornamented with amyloid spines and warts some of which are unconnected but others fused into groups or connected by fine lines, the prominent elements 1-1.5 microns high", "sterigmal appendage straight or oblique, attached centrally"; basidia and basidioles forming a continuous hymenium, 35-60 x 10-14 microns, 2-spored and 4-spored, (very rarely 1-spored or 3-spored), clavate, rarely ventricose in mid-portion, colorless, thin-walled, readily collapsing, "sterigmata mostly slightly curved"; pseudocystidia very rare, imbedded in hymenium, up to 7.5 microns wide, tibiiform; subhymenium "strongly developed, cellular and with frequent large sphaerocysts", colorless in well dried material or where unstained by natural color changes; tramal mediostratum regular, "consisting of filamentose hyphae somewhat interwoven but extending in the direction of the tramal plates, not or at most only slightly gelatinized, rather loosely arranged at juncture of tramal plates and sphaerocysts evident in these areas"; inner peridial layer of colorless to brownish filaments, "tangential-repent, scarcely gelatinized, with thin to slightly thickened walls and narrow protoplasmic content"; peridial epicutis a palisade of versiform elements, cylindric, subulate, ampullaceous, or clavate, with tips varying from acute to broadly rounded, colorless but becoming brown inside and out, "with thin to thick (1.2 microns) wall, the elements of the palisade eventually decumbent"; all hyphae inamyloid; clamp connections none, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'becoming ferruginous (rusty brown)'
SIMILAR  Russula similaris (as Gymnomyces fallax) is practically the same in field characters, but differs microscopically, (Singer); Russula taetra (as Gymnomyces foetens) has a pungent odor reminiscent of Russula foetens when fresh, and lacks the true sphaerocysts in pockets in the tramal plates, (Singer)
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Gymnomyces ferruginascens) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Smith(4) (as Gymnomyces ferruginascens), Thiers(4) (as Gymnomyces ferruginascens), Trappe(13) (as Gymnomyces ferruginascens) , Elliott, T.F.(1)
299
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula fulvispora  (A.H. Sm.) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 234. 2018;  Gymnomyces fulvisporus  (A.H. Sm.) Trappe, T. Lebel, & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 199. 2002;  Martellia fulvispora  A.H. Sm.  Mycologia 55: 438. 1963
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  the diagnostic combination of features of this species consists of the strong odor of slightly burnt sugar, the pronounced color change from white to rusty brown on the surface, in the spore mass, and even in the spores (colorless from white side of fruiting body and rusty tan from colored part), the thick walls of the spores, "the prominent but rather littered-up spore ornamentation, the sphaerocysts in the peridial context, and the narrow epicuticular turf of dermatocystidia"^, (Smith(24)); rare, central ID, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on peridium quickly russet^, (Smith(4)), KOH on peridial surface quickly a darker rusty brown, FeSO4 no reaction, (Smith(24))
OUTER SURFACE  1.5-3cm across, spherical to irregular; white but soon stained cinnamon brown; dry, pubescent^, (Smith(4)), 1.5-3cm across, spherical to irregular; "at first white, but rather soon becoming cinnamon brown to russet"; dry and unpolished to minutely pubescent [downy], uneven, (Smith(24))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white then dark rusty brown^, (Smith(4)), white at first, soon dark rusty brown, (Smith(24)), "irregular chambers small to medium large", (Smith(24))
STEM  columella weak, dendroid [branching]^, (Smith(4)), columella dendroid, weak, arising from a slightly developed sterile base, (Smith(24))
ODOR  strong, of burnt sugar^, (Smith(4)), "strong odor of slightly burnt sugar", (Smith(24))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in duff in spruce-fir forest, summer^, (Smith(4)), single or gregarious under conifers, August, (Smith(24))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-12 x 8-10 microns, ornamented with isolated spines and short ridges^; cystidia inconspicuous, embedded; cuticle of peridium "a turf of cystidia 18-27 x 3-6 microns, rusty brown as revived in KOH", sphaerocysts present in inner part of peridium, (Smith(4)), spores 9-12 x 8-10 microns, round to nearly round, "ornamentation in the form of isolated spines or these grouped into rows or short crooked lines, but not enough fusion of elements to form a broken reticulum, many smaller isolated amyloid particles littering the spore surface", plage area ornamented, wall about 1 micron thick and inamyloid, "sterigmal appendage not prominent (about 1-1.5 microns wide)"; basidia mostly 2-spored, 28-37 x 10-12 microns, clavate, "tan to pale rusty brown in KOH"; hymenial cystidia "very inconspicuous, resembling basidia in size and shape but apex drawn to an obtuse projection", pale tan like the basidia; filamentous pseudocystidia very rare; subhymenium cellular by virtue of the fact that the base of the basidium is usually divided into 2-4 cells approximately isodiametric "and finally inflating to a greater size than the base of the basidium"; central strand of hymenophoral trama of colorless to pale tan hyphae 'with slightly thickened walls as seen in KOH and as revived somewhat "glassy" in appearance, no sphaerocysts present'; epicutis of peridium a turf of dermatocystidia 18-27 x 3-6 microns with dermatopseudocystidia mixed in, "interior to this is a thick subcutis of narrow (2-6 microns) compactly interwoven hyphae with slightly thickened walls, occasional large sphaerocysts scattered in this layer and these more numerous in the looser tissue beneath it, some large rusty brown hyphae also present in the subcutis, the epicutis rusty brown in KOH as revived and the tissue beneath paler tan", but on standing in KOH becoming nearly colorless; clamp connections absent, (Smith(24))
NAME ORIGIN  refers to the color of the spores as fulvous
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(24) (as Martellia fulvispora), Smith(4) (as Martellia fulvispora), Trappe(13) (as Gymnomyces fulvisporus), Elliott, T.F.(1)
300
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula fuscoviolacea  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 234. 2018;  Macowanites fuscoviolaceus  Singer & A.H. Sm.  Mem. Torrey Bot. Club 21: 87. 1960
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include 1) a convex cap that is dull fuscous-violet and viscid, 2) white brittle flesh in the cap, 3) a spore mass that is white with tawny-stained larval channels, somewhat gill-like where almost to entirely exposed on lower surface, but maze-like in the interior, 4) a white stem stained rusty, 5) a mild taste, and 6) microscopic characters including nearly round spores with variable ornamentation (with connecting lines not forming a complete network, warts often arranged in crowded rows or even fused together to form ridges), basidia 4-spored, very rarely 2-spored, and peridial epicutis a turf of long, sparsely branched hyphae.^ The description is derived from Singer(10). RANGE The holotype collection was found in ID.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 slowly pinkish buff on flesh of peridium
OUTER SURFACE  3cm across, convex, with lobed or irregular more or less blunt margin; "violaceous in buttons, soon becoming fuscous-violet on disc, marginal zone dull violaceous with pallid areas", bald, viscid, uneven
INNER LAYER  in cap brittle, white; in stem white
INTERIOR  lower surface of spore mass almost or entirely exposed, scarcely lamellate [gill-like] on exposed surfaces, in interior labyrinthiform [maze-like] with small, narrow cavities, free from stem-columella; milk-white except for tawny stains around larval channels
STEM  2cm x 1.2cm thick at top, solid; white, stained rusty around base and larval channels; columella percurrent [going through spore mass]
ODOR  
TASTE  mild
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection single under Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), July
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9.7 x 6-8.3 microns, nearly round to very short elliptic, ornamentation "projecting 0.3-0.7 microns, rather variable, connecting lines not forming a complete network, warts often arranged in crowded rows or even fused together to form ridges", spores yellowish in dilute bases, sterigmal appendage about 3 microns long and oblique^; hymenium continuous, basidia 4-spored, very rarely 2-spored, 34-51 x 11.5-15 microns, clavate, sterigmata most often half-sickle-shaped "but sometimes coarse and irregular or straight"; macrocystidia 40-65 x 9-16 microns, clavate, fusoid, or ventricose, more rarely cylindric, obtuse to broadly rounded in upper part, "with rather loose to dense banded contents, rarely without any content"; subhymenium "consisting of subisodiametric to short-cylindric very small hyphal cells", hymenopodium not consistently present, hyphae 2-3.5 microns wide, filamentous, longitudinally arranged; tramal mediostratum strongly heteromerous [with nests of sphaerocysts among filamentous hyphae] "except in the thinner connective tramal plates where sphaerocysts are rather scattered"; trama of cap and stem heteromerous; hypodermium absent; outermost layer of cap about 100 microns thick, formed by a turf of hyphae 2.5-4 microns wide, about 100 microns long, sparsely branched, imbedded in a gelatinous mass (in KOH), "terminal cells of some filaments cystidioid, numerous dermatopseudocystidia present"; surface layer of stem with moderate number of dermatopseudocystidia similar to those on cap; hyphae inamyloid; clamp connections none
NAME ORIGIN  means 'fuscous violaceous', referring to the cap color
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Macowanites fuscoviolaceus), Trappe(13) (as Macowanites fuscoviolaceus), Elliott, T.F.(1)
301
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula gilkeyae  (Zeller & C.W. Dodge) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 234. 2018;  Gymnomyces gilkeyae  (Zeller & C.W. Dodge) Trappe, T. Lebel, & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 199. 2002;  Martellia gilkeyae  (Zeller & C.W. Dodge) Singer & A.H. Sm.  Mem. Torrey Bot. Club 21: 32. 1960;  Hydnangium gilkeyae  Zeller & C.W. Dodge
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) an oblong to nearly spherical fruitbody that is buff with brownish stains, the surface bald with a network of innate veins, 2) a spore mass with medium-sized cavities, colored white to creamy when fresh, 3) absent sterile base, 4) absent columella, 5) underground growth under California hazel, 6) nearly round spores with simple to forked spines or truncated cones 3.5-5 microns high, 7) 1-spored basidia, and 8) a peridial cuticle that is a loose tangled turf of narrow clavate to subcylindric hyphal tips.^ It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It is found in northwestern OR, (Trappe(13)). The type collection was from OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  3-4.5cm across, oblong to nearly spherical; buff with brownish stains, pale tawny when dried; brittle, bald, when old with veins forming a reticulum [network]^, (Smith(4)), 4.5cm x 3cm x 3cm, oblong to nearly spherical, brittle; buff with brownish stains, pale tawny when dried; bald, with innate reticulate veins, wrinkles more pronounced when dried, (Singer)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white to creamy, drying creamy pinkish buff^, (Smith), white becoming slightly creamy when fresh, drying "pinkish-buff" to "warm-buff"; "cavities open and medium-sized", (Singer)
STEM  no sterile base, no columella^, (Singer)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground under Corylus californicus (California Hazel), April and May^, (Singer), mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest are trees in Pinaceae (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-16 x 12-15 microns, ornamented with simple to forked spines or truncated cones 3.5-5 microns high^; cuticle of peridium a loose tangled turf of narrow clavate to subcylindric hyphal tips, (Smith), spores 12-16 x 12-15 microns excluding spines, "ornamented with prominent simple to forked spines or truncated cones 3.5-5 microns high and 1-2.5 microns broad at base, ornamentation amyloid (denser at apex and around base in many spines), the elements varying greatly in size and not fused at the bases (in fact seldom connected)", "sterigmal appendage collapsed and inconspicuous", plage area not distinctive; hymenium continuous, basidia 1-spored, 30-37 x 10-14 microns, clavate, thin-walled, colorless in KOH, basidioles numerous; cystidia none but basidia on which a sterigma is developing resemble mucronate leptocystidia; rarely a pseudocystidia-like filament seen; subhymenium composed of hyphae 3-6 microns wide, densely ramose-interwoven [branched-interwoven], no sphaerocysts; tramal mediostratum of hyphae 2-4 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, nongelatinous, no sphaerocysts; peridial context (subcutis) of loosely interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, smooth, nongelatinous hyphae, sphaerocysts absent, oleiferous hyphae very rare; peridial epicutis "a loose tangled turf of narrow (2-4 microns) clavate to subcylindric hyphal end-cells 12-30 microns long and mostly pale ochraceous and with granular content, much debris adhering in this layer"; clamp connections absent, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  after Helen Gilkey, collector of the type
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Martellia gilkeyae, colors individually in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Smith(4) (as Martellia gilkeyae), Trappe(13) (as Gymnomyces gilkeyae), Elliott, T.F.(1)
302
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula hunsuckeri  T.F. Elliott & Trappe^  Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 237. 2018;  == Macowanites nauseosus  A.H. Sm.  Mycologia 55: 428. 1963
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Russula hunsuckeri is distinct from other sequestrate Russulas by a disagreeable taste, a vinaceous FeSO4 reaction on the cortex of the stem, nonreticulate spores, a peridium that has a strongly gelatinous ixotrichodermium with the terminal elements scarcely enlarged or actually narrowed, and pronounced development of sphaerocysts in the hymenophoral trama and the peridial context, the last feature being responsible for the almost crumbly flesh consistency. Other features include a dull reddish vinaceous, bald cap that is viscid to subviscid at first but soon dry, a somewhat gill-like spore mass that is pinkish buff to more ochraceous, a white, naked stem-columella that does not stain when handled, and broadly elliptic spores with strongly amyloid ornamentation, mostly as small blunt spines, separate or in groups or short rows, borne on 4-spored basidia.^ The description is derived from Smith(24). When the species was moved from Macowanites to Russula a new species epithet was required because of the prior name Russula nauseosa (Pers.) Fr.(1838). RANGE The holotype was found in ID.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 causes stem cortex to become somewhat vinaceous
OUTER SURFACE  1.8-2.3cm broad, convex; dull reddish vinaceous ("brownish vinaceous"), darker over disc than margin; bald, viscid to subviscid, soon dry
INNER LAYER  exceedingly fragile (almost crumbly); white, in stem pallid with cortex of stem pinkish-buff
INTERIOR  spore mass sublamellate [somewhat gill-like], adnexed to apex of columella; pinkish buff to more ochraceous
STEM  stem-columella 1-1.5cm x 0.4-0.7cm, white, not staining where handled; dry, naked
ODOR  slight and not distinctive
TASTE  nauseous and disagreeable
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type gregarious under fir (Smith), mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest in Pinaceae (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-13 x 7-9 microns, broadly elliptic, "ornamentation strongly amyloid, mostly as small blunt spines separate or in groups or short rows, and if the latter then fused into lumpy lines at times, no true reticulum present, ornamentation 0.5-1.2 microns high, plage area with reduced ornamentation and diffusely amyloid, often with a mass of strongly amyloid material at base of sterigmal appendage on the plage area", wall inamyloid^; basidia 4-spored, 30-40 x 9-13 microns, clavate but broadest below apex, colorless in KOH; macrocystidia scattered, 43-65 x 10-15 microns, 'subfusoid-mucronate to more or less clavate or clavate-mucronate, not projecting prominently, content with some refractive particles but typically appearing "empty", thin-walled, readily collapsing, originating in subhymenium'; subhymenium cellular, 2-3 cells deep, "central area entirely of enlarged cells" (up to 30 microns in diameter); epicutis of peridium "a gelatinous trichodermium of branched hyphae 80-120 microns long", 3-5 microns wide at tips (narrowed), "many pseudocystidia in the layer also (hyphae with golden ochraceous pigment in KOH), some with refractive content in some but not in all of the cells, a few hyphae developing a sphaerocyst at the apex but these usually imbedded in the layer"; subcutis of peridium "a thin layer of appressed-interwoven hyphae less gelatinous than the elements of the trichodermium"; peridial context almost entirely of sphaerocysts, clamp connections none
NAME ORIGIN  "In honor of naturalist, mycologist, botanist, and philosopher Dr. Robert Hunsucker", (Elliott, T.F.(1))
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(24) (as Macowanites nauseosus) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Trappe(13) (as Macowanites nauseosus), Elliott, T.F.(1)
303
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula idahoensis  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 234. 2018;  Cystangium idahoensis  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Trappe, T. Lebel & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 197. 2002;  Martellia idahoensis  Singer & A.H. Sm.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to irregular fruitbody with surface that is white becoming pale yellowish brown in places, and uneven or with ridges radiating from the base, the outermost peridial layer separable and thin, spore mass with minute irregular chambers and colored white becoming pale cinnamon buff when old, a poorly developed branching columella, growth under duff in spruce-fir forests, and microscopic characters including round to broadly elliptic spores with amyloid ornamentation of isolated warts and short ridges, (1)-, 2-, 3-, and 4-spored basidia, hymenial cystidia, and peridial epicutis a trichodermium of elements with enlarged cells, the end-cells clavate^; found in ID, and common at the type location, (Singer), infrequent, western OR to ID, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH and FeSO4 not showing any color reaction in or on the peridium or spore mass (Singer)
OUTER SURFACE  0.8-5cm across, spherical to irregular; "white becoming pale yellowish brown in places"; "surface ribbed to wrinkled or uneven"; "outer layer of peridium separable"^, (Smith), 0.8-4(5)cm across, spherical-depressed, spherical, or irregular; white when young, "finally with a pale alutaceous tone in some areas", rarely overall, drying pallid; "uneven to ribbed with irregular ridges and grooves", more or less distinctly radiating from the base of the fruitbody, at first merely wrinkled, with little or no dirt adhering; peridium two-layered, the outer separable and thin (little more than 0.05cm thick when dried), (Singer)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white becoming pale cinnamon buff when old; dry^, (Smith), dry in consistency when cut; white, when old pale cinnamon buff; chambers minute, irregular, empty, (Singer)
STEM  columella poorly developed, dendroid [branching]^, (Smith), columella poorly developed, dendroid, when fresh "observable as a few white lines of sterile tissue extending out from a small basal tubercle of sterile tissue" or a thickened basal part of the interior layer of the peridium, (Singer)
ODOR  none^ (Singer)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious "in duff in spruce-fir forests", summer^, (Smith), single to gregarious, beneath the duff under Picea engelmannii (Engelmann spruce) and Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), (Singer), mycorrhizal host Abies (fir) (Trappe(13))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-13 x 9-11.5 microns, ornamentation of isolated warts and short ridges, prominences 1-1.5(2) microns high^, cystidia 40-50 x 9-10 microns; "cuticle of peridium a trichodermium of elements with enlarged cells, the end cells clavate", (Smith), spores 10-13 x 9-11.5 microns, round to broadly elliptic, ornamentation echinate [spiny] to verrucose, the prominences 1-1.5(2) microns high, elements unconnected or anastomosing to form compound warts that are also more or less unconnected to each other, "very few anastomosing lines or ridges, amylaceous material denser at apex of the spines and warts", "sterigmal appendage very inconspicuous, straight or oblique, attached at geometric base of spore"; basidia (1)-, 2-, 3-, and 4-spored, 29-45 x 11-16 microns, clavate, colorless, "sterigmata 5-8 microns long, narrowly conic, erect or slightly oblique, straight or nearly so, apical"; macrocystidia "arising from deeper in the tramal tissue than the basidia", scattered, 40-50 x 9-10 microns, "with banded to granular pale yellowish content", "clavate to subcylindric, obtuse", leptocystidia (?) rare, 30-37 x 12-15 microns, "clavate-mucronate and with weakly refractive amorphous interior mass as revived in KOH", a second type (76-90 x 9-14 microns) narrowly clavate, found when fresh but not demonstrated when dried, their content colorless and homogeneous and the wall very slightly thickened; balloon-shaped pseudoparaphyses found here and there in hymenium; subhymenium "broad, cellular, of large and small sphaerocysts"; tramal mediostratum relatively narrow, of filamentous, subparallel to slightly interwoven, colorless hyphae extending in the direction of the tramal plates, laticiferous hyphae rare (best seen when fruitbody immature), crooked, and brown in KOH; peridial epicutis over 200 microns thick "consisting of a staggard [?staggered] palisade of hyphae with enlarged cells and ending in clavate end-cells, or these showing irregular proliferations, rarely with narrow or branched elements in the palisade", "interior to this layer is a layer of repent filamentose hyphae more or less interwoven and with pockets of slightly inflated cells (rudimentary sphaerocysts)", not gelatinized; all hyphae inamyloid; clamp connections none, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'from Idaho'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Martellia idahoensis), Smith(4) (as Martellia idahoensis), Trappe(13) (as Cystangium idahoensis), Elliott, T.F.(1)
304
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula iodiolens  (A.H. Sm. & V.L. Wells) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 235 (2018);  Macowanites iodiolens  A.H. Sm. & D.E. Wells  Mycologia 55: 425. 1963
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include 1) a nearly spherical to convex-depressed, pale ochraceous cap with the surface dry to moist, 2) a cap margin that is incurved to almost reach the stem-columella, 3) white unchanging brittle flesh, 4) distorted gill-like structures that are adnate to free and unchanging ochraceous in color, 5) a percurrent stem-columella paler than the cap, 6) a faint odor of iodoform, and 7) microscopic characters including spores with an amyloid ornamentation of blunt rods. It could be the same as Macowanites chlorinosmus.^ The description is derived from Smith(24). It is rare among sequestrate species in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Russula iodiolens was described from OR. There are collections labeled as this species from WA at the University of Washington and from OR at Oregon State University.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2.5-3.5cm across, nearly spherical to broadly convex-depressed; pale ochraceous, disc at times tan with a pinkish cast or tinged pinkish lilac; "dry to moist, unpolished to pruinose or finely appressed tomentose", "smooth or at margin somewhat ribbed", "disc in some becoming finely areolately cracked", margin often incurved but free, sometimes reaching stem-columella but usually 0.2-0.4cm distant exposing interior (spore mass), surface layer separable
INNER LAYER  flesh moderately thick (0.4-0.7cm) at disc, tapered to margin; rather crisp and fragile; white, unchanging; in stem white
INTERIOR  varying from adnate to free from stem-columella, sublamellate [somewhat gill-like], not oriented vertically, about 1cm broad, brittle; ochraceous (darker than peridium), unchanging when injured
STEM  stem-columella percurrent, 1.5-2cm long, 0.5-0.8cm wide at top, extending 0.5-1cm below peridial margin, nearly equal; brittle, stuffed; pallid to yellowish (paler than outer surface of cap); dry, unpolished to somewhat pruinose, longitudinally rivulose [with river-like lines]
ODOR  "faint but distinctly of iodiform (fragrant)"
TASTE  mild
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type single to gregarious, above ground to somewhat buried, under Tsuga (hemlock) and Abies (fir)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-11 x 8-9.5 microns, elliptic to nearly round, inamyloid; wall thin to slightly thickened, ornamentation of blunt rods mostly unconnected and 0.5-1(1.5-2) microns high, "the largest spores with the longest ornamentation, rods coated heavily with the amylaceous material"^; "plage area ornamented as over remainder of spore surface" except for amorphous amylaceous material surrounding base of sterigmal appendage in some; basidia 4-spored, 26-37 x 11-14, clavate, colorless in KOH; pseudocystidia 'of contorted filamentose elements as well as some "macrocystidia"' 45-60 x 8-13 microns, "these usually enlarged at the level of the tips of the basidia" and then narrowed to a drawn-out needle-like projection to the pointed apex, content refractive; hymenophoral trama "with central strand of filamentose hyphae and sphaerocysts, oleiferous hyphae rare"; subhymenium narrow, of cells 9-20 microns in diameter, the layer 2-3 cells deep, not gelatinous; peridial trama heteromerous, the sphaerocysts thin-walled; subcutis of peridium of appressed-interwoven, colorless, thin-walled hyphae 2-9 microns in diameter; epicutis "a turf of clavate to flagellated pseudocystidia (with refractive glandular content)", up to 50 x 3.7-7.5 microns, "many pedicellate-clavate cells also present and these varying to capitate", enlarged part 8-15 microns wide, total length 20-35(45) microns, "many filamentose to versiform elements also present in the turf, the walls of some of the elements thickened slightly and more refractive in KOH"; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  means 'smelling like iodine'
SIMILAR  Macowanites alleinstanleyae [as Macowanites citrinus] is somewhat similar but "differs sharply in the features of the spore ornamentation and the details of the peridial epicutis" (Smith(24)).
SOURCES  Smith(24) (as Macowanites iodiolens), Trappe(13) (as Macowanites iodiolens), Elliott, T.F.(1)
305
