FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula lymanensis  (Cazares & Trappe) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 235. 2018;  Cystangium lymanensis  (Cazares & Trappe) Trappe, T. Lebel & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 197. 2002;  Macowanites lymanensis  Cazares & Trappe  Mycotaxon 42: 335. 1991
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Distinctive features are microscopic: the relatively large spores with ornamentation 1-2 microns tall, consisting of individual rods or warts often connected in lines or forming a partial reticulum, 2- or 4-spored basidia, the thin peridial epicutis of appressed hyphae, and the total absence of cystidia. Macroscopic features include a pale dull yellow cap, a pale orangish yellow loculate spore mass, a white stem-columella of variable size, and a yeasty odor.^ The description is derived from Cazares(1) except where indicated. It is rare among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It has been found in Chelan County, WA, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  7-23cm x 1.2-3.6cm in diameter, nearly round to top-shaped, lobed or depressed at center, peridium pale dull yellow with brown stains on disc, grading to white towards the margin, bald, recurved and often attached to stem but sometimes separated to reveal the basal locules
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  spore mass pale orangish yellow or slightly yellower, loculate [chambered], locules 0.03-0.1cm broad
STEM  stem-columella barely projecting or prominent, white, percurrent [going through spore mass] or truncated; rhizomorphs not present
ODOR  strongly yeasty with a slight wine essence
TASTE  mild
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type was single to gregarious or tufted in the compacted soil of a campsite (Cazares), associated with the roots of Abies amabilis and A. lasiocarpa at 1700m elevation, (Castellano)
SPORE DEPOSIT  not obtainable
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-13(17) x 7-12(14) microns, excluding ornamentation, round to nearly round, symmetrical, the wall and ornamentation amyloid, ornamentation 1-2 microns tall, consisting of rods or warts, separate or often connected by lines, occasionally forming a partial reticulum^; basidia 2- or 4-spored, 28-45 x 11-17 microns, thin-walled, clavate, colorless in KOH, pale yellow in Melzer's; pleurocystidia and cheilocystidia absent; epicutis of peridium 20-70 microns thick, composed of appressed, thin-walled hyphae 2-5 microns in diameter at septa, with most cells inflated up to 10-20 microns in diameter, light yellow in KOH and Melzer's, subcutis composed of thin-walled, colorless, inflated cells and sphaerocysts 10-40 microns in diameter; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  in reference to Lyman Lake, near which the holotype was collected
SIMILAR  Russula alleinstanleyae is similar in the size of the spores and the color of the peridium, but has a peridial epicutis comprised of a turf of filaments as opposed to the epicutis of appressed hyphae of Russula lymanensis.
SOURCES  Cazares(1) (as Macowanites lymanensis), Castellano(1)* (as Macowanites lymanensis), Trappe(13) (as Cystangium lymanensis), Elliott, T.F.(1)
306
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula marshallorum  T.F. Elliott & Trappe^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 240. 2018;  == Cystangium vesiculosum  (Singer & A.H. Sm.)  Trappe, T. Lebel, & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 198. 2002;  == Martellia vesiculosa  Singer & A.H. Sm.  Mem. Torrey Bot. Club 21: 29. 1960
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a white spherical fruitbody with a cream-colored spore-mass that has small irregular chambers, 2) the absence of a sterile base or columella, 3) growth under conifers, and 4) microscopic characters including evenly amyloid ornamentation of isolated rods and warts that tend to slough off in revived material, mostly 2-spored basidia, and a peridial epicutis with vesiculose cells.^ It is common among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). When this species was moved from Cystangium (and Martellia) to Russula, a new species epithet was required because the name Russula vesiculosa was used for Gymnomyces vesiculosus Coker and Couch (1928). RANGE The type collection is from OR. It occurs from northern CA to WA and ID from the Pacific Coast to middle elevations in the mountains, (Trappe, M.(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-2cm white (gray as preserved) and unchanging^, (Smith), 1-2cm across, spherical, pure white, (gray as preserved in fluid), (Singer), white to pale cream; smooth, (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  creamy and unchanging (gray as preserved in fluid); chambers small and irregular^, (Singer), white to pale cream (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  no sterile base, no columella^, (Singer)
ODOR  mild^ (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-cedar), October^, (Singer), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Picea (spruce), Abies (fir), Pinus (pine); March, June to November, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-14 x 8-11 microns, ornamentation amyloid over all, predominantly of isolated rods and warts up to 1.3 microns high^; cells of peridial cuticle 18-50 microns broad, (Smith), spores 10-14 x 8-11 microns, elliptic to nearly round, amyloid ornamentation "of separate rods and warts up to 1.3 microns high, these closely grouped in some areas but not fused", falling off very easily, hence bald spores in most mounts, wall about 1 micron thick, pale yellow in Melzer's reagent, "sterigmal appendage short and inconspicuous", "plage area not distinctive except for slightly more irregular ornamentation"; basidia (mostly 2-spored), 23-28 x 9-12 microns, short-clavate, colorless, thin-walled, readily collapsing, basidioles numerous; cystidia none; subhymenium "cellular" in structure, the cells enlarging to about 15 microns in diameter (sphaerocyst-like); tramal mediostratum of filaments 3-7 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, subgelatinous, no sphaerocysts present; peridial context (subcutis) of hyphae 3-5 microns wide, intricately interwoven, uninflated, nongelatinous, no sphaerocysts present; peridial epicutis an epithelium of large inflated cells (18-52 microns in diameter) with yellowish, nongelatinous, smooth walls; oleiferous hyphae none; clamp connections none, (Singer), spores 10-14 x 8-11 microns, with strongly amyloid spines 1-2 microns long, (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  "In honor of Australian truffle-growing Marshall family for their strong support of Australasian truffle research and conservation" (Elliott, T.F.(1))
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Martellia vesiculosa), Smith(4) (as Martellia vesiculosa), Trappe, M.(1)* (as Cystangium vesiculosum), Trappe, M.(3)* (as Cystangium vesiculosum), Trappe(13)* (as Cystangium vesiculosum), Elliott, T.F.(1)
307
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula mattsmithii  Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 232. 2018;  == Gymnomyces compactus  Singer & A.H. Sm.  Mem. Torrey Bot. Club 21: 53. 1960
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to irregular fruitbody that is white with brownish spots, with uneven to wrinkled surface, spore mass with small cavities, colored white but stained brown in places, absent sterile base, absent columella, and microscopic characters including broadly elliptic spores with amyloid ornamentation in the form of warts closely arranged in lines or fused into groups (without long ridges or unbroken lines), 4-spored basidia, and epicutis in the form of a distinct trichodermium^; when this species was moved from Gymnomyces to Russula, a new species epithet was required because of the prior name Russula compacta Frost (1879); description derived from Singer(10); rare in western OR (Trappe(13)), type collection from OR
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-2cm across, spherical to irregular; white with brownish spots; uneven to wrinkled
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white, stained brown in places; cavities small and partly empty
STEM  no sterile base or columella
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-14 x 9-12 microns, broadly elliptic, heavily amyloid ornamentation "in the form of warts closely arranged in lines or fused into groups of various shapes but not long ridges or unbroken lines present, prominences about 1 micron high, very faint fine lines or streaks on spore wall also present but these scarcely visible under oil", spore wall about 0.5 microns thick and yellowish-transparent in Melzer's reagent, sterigmal appendage inconspicuous, plage area not distinctive^; basidia 4-spored, 26-33 x 9-12 microns, wall thin and colorless, content colorless and protoplasmic (material preserved in liquid), sterigmata short (up to 6 microns), fine, and straight, basidioles numerous; pseudoparaphyses none; cystidia none; subhymenium cellular, the cells enlarging to sphaerocysts, thin-walled, colorless in KOH; tramal mediostratum "of interwoven hyphae with some sphaerocysts mixed in especially at junction points", filamentose hyphae with somewhat enlarged hyphal cells with thin, smooth, colorless walls; peridial epicutis "a thin decumbent turf of dermatocystidia" 18-30 x 4-7 microns, "mostly narrowly fusoid to clavate (layer evident in young specimens)" and with thin colorless walls; peridial context (when old the entire peridium) of hyphae 4-7 microns wide, interwoven and filamentous, with walls that are subgelatinous, smooth, and colorless, near subhymenium scattered sphaerocysts occur; oleiferous hyphae none; clamp connections none
NAME ORIGIN  "In honor of Dr Matt Smith for his extensive research on taxonomy and ecology of sequestrate fungi" (Elliott, T.F.(1))
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Gymnomyces compactus), Trappe(13) (as Gymnomyces compactus), Elliott, T.F.(1)
308
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula medlockii  (Trappe & Castellano) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 236. 2018;  Cystangium medlockii  (Trappe & Castellano) Trappe, T. Lebel & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 197. 2002;  Martellia medlockii  Trappe & Castellano  Mycologia 78: 918-919. 1986
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  distinguished from other stemless Russula species by the combination of "relatively small, ellipsoid spores with rather low and strongly amyloid ornamentation, peridial epicutis with many inflated cells, subcutis with nested sphaerocysts, and glebal trama with scattered inflated cells but no true sphaerocysts"^; description derived from Trappe(1); type found in OR
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-3.2cm across, somewhat spherical with indented base; white with pale yellow or yellowish brown areas; smooth
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  pale orange yellow^ (color from Kelly(3))
STEM  with a white basal pad and sometimes a small columella
ODOR  faintly chlorinaceous
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type underground under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), elevation 170m, in the laboratory forms ectomycorrhizae with Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-12 x 7-10 microns excluding ornamentation, elliptic to round, symmetrical, apparently statismosporic, ornamentation rods and warts 0.2-0.7 x 0.2-0.7 microns, these mostly single but occasionally 2-4(5) merged into short rows, "most rods and warts partially to entirely black in Melzer's reagent, occasionally nonreactive or only weakly reactive", spores colorless, with single large droplet, spore wall at maturity 0.5-1.0 micron thick, colorless in KOH, olivaceous gray in Melzer's reagent^, sterigmatal attachment straight, 1-2 x 1-1.5 microns, colorless in KOH, in Melzer's reagent ranging from colorless to "having a basal olivaceous gray jacket with or without a large, rounded, black deposit on one side"; basidia 2-4-spored, 14-17 x 6-9 microns, clavate to subcylindric, colorless, thin-walled, brachybasidioles similar but ranging to 12 microns wide; cystidia lacking; subhymenium of 1-2 layers of +/- isodiametric cells 5-12 microns in diameter; trama of subparallel hyphae 1.5-4 microns wide at septa, some cells inflated up to 8 microns, "true sphaerocysts lacking but inflated cells present, especially at junctures of tramal plates"; peridium 100-210 microns thick, of interwoven hyphae 5-10 microns wide at septa, most cells inflated up to 30 microns, "with single or nested sphaerocysts scattered throughout", walls thin and colorless to pale yellow; context of basal pad and columella heteromerous, of hyphae 3-10 microns wide, the cells not inflated, the walls thin and colorless, "with single or nested sphaerocysts scattered throughout"
NAME ORIGIN  after Bill Medlock, who collected the type
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Trappe(1) (as Cystangium medlockii), Trappe(3) (as Cystangium medlockii), Kelly(3)
309
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula monticola  (Harkn.) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 236. 2018;  Gymnomyces monticola  (Harkn.) Trappe, T. Lebel & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 200. 2002;  Martellia monticola  (Harkn.) Singer & A.H. Sm.;  Hydnangium monticola  (Harkn.) Zeller;  Octaviania monticola  Harkness
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  recognized in the field by the way that the two outer layers of the peridium split open, other features include whitish spherical to irregular fruitbody, whitish spore mass, usually a branching columella, often a basal thickening, and microscopic characters including nearly round to round spores with an amyloid broken reticulum, 2-spored or 4-spored basidia, and peridial epicutis a lax turf^; infrequent, southwestern WA to northern CA in mountains, (Trappe(13)), collected in ID (Singer)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-3.5cm across, spherical to irregular; white becoming pinkish buff when old; bald^, (Smith), 1-3.5cm across, spherical to nearly spherical, irregular at times; white (but dingy from adhering dirt), at times pinkish buff when old; "outer layer readily separable and often peeled back", exposed inner layer soon rimose [wrinkled], often exposing spore mass, (Singer)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white when young, becoming pale cinnamon when old^, (Smith), when young, becoming "pale pinkish-buff" or slightly paler than "light pinkish cinnamon"; loculate [chambered], the chambers small, (Singer, colors in quotation marks from Ridgway)
STEM  columella dendroid [branching], sometimes arising from pulvinate [cushion-shaped] sterile base^, (Smith), "columella a white strip of sterile tissue which branches laterally and is percurrent in some specimens and in others almost lacking, base often with a conspicuous fleshy thickening", (Singer)
ODOR  mild^ (Singer)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), August^, (Singer), mycorrhizal hosts in the Pacific Northwest are trees in Pinaceae, (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-12.5 x 9.5-12 microns, "ornamentation in the form of a broken reticulum with the prominences 0.5-1.1 microns high"^; cuticle of peridium a lax turf, the terminal cells 24-41 x 4.5-8.5 microns, (Smith), spores 10-12.5 x 9.5-12 microns, nearly round to round, "ornamentation in the form of a heavily amyloid broken reticulum with the prominences 0.5-1.1 microns high, rarely with numerous short irregular ridges only partly connected and with isolated warts also present", spores colorless to very pale yellowish in dilute bases, "apiculus small and inconspicuous, either straight or oblique"; basidia 2-spored or 4-spored, 26-40 x 7.5-12 microns, clavate, colorless, thin-walled, and readily collapsing, sterigmata mostly straight, vertical or less often oblique; cystidia none; subhymenium "broad, consisting of isodiametric cells some enlarge to resemble sphaerocysts, filaments rarely present"; tramal mediostratum "narrow, consisting of filamentous hyphae relatively frequently septate and somewhat interwoven, lacking sphaerocysts except where tramal plates merge with peridial inner layer", lactiferous hyphae none, oleiferous hyphae occasional; peridium 3-layered: 1) epicuticular layer "mainly of hyphal ends and cystidioid terminal elements not forming a palisade but irregularly ascending and often tangled, the terminal cells cylindric", 24-41 x 4.8-8.5 microns, "ampullaceous, subcapitate, clavate, fusoid, etc., apices obtuse to subacute, walls thin to slightly thickened", 2) intermediate layer "of tangentially repent filamentous hyphae rarely with slightly swollen cells" (up to 10 microns in diameter), usually 2-4.5 microns wide, colorless, "subparallel to interwoven, not gelatinized, when peridium splits this layer often adheres to the epicuticular layer", 3) inner layer of colorless heteromerous tissue, sphaerocysts large and abundant; all hyphae inamyloid; clamp connections absent, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'living in mountains'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Martellia monticola), Smith(4) (as Martellia monticola), Trappe(13) (as Gymnomyces monticola), Elliott, T.F.(1)
310
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula nancyweberae  Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 238. 2018;  == Macowanites pseudoemeticus  A.H. Sm.  Mycologia 55: 431. 1963
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include a deep red, subviscid cap, fragile white flesh, a somewhat gill-like to chambered spore mass that is pallid becoming pale pinkish buff, a short white stem-columella that stains "pinkish buff" in FeSO4, a mild odor and taste, and round or nearly round spores borne on 2-spored and 4-spored basidia.^ The description is derived from Smith(24). When the species was moved from Macowanites to Russula, a new species epithet was required because of the prior name Russula pseudoemetica Secr. ex Singer (1926). RANGE The holotype was found in ID.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  stem-columella "pinkish-buff" in FeSO4
OUTER SURFACE  2-3.5cm across, broadly convex; deep red over all or with pallid patches; apparently subviscid when wet, bald, often splitting along margin or nearly to disc
INNER LAYER  thin, fragile; white
INTERIOR  sublamellate [somewhat gill-like], the gills crowded, thickish, fused to form chambers; pallid becoming pale pinkish buff (not truly yellow), at maturity spore mass exposed in the manner of a Russula
STEM  stem-columella 1-2cm x 0.5-1cm, short, solid, fragile; white
ODOR  mild
TASTE  not distinctive
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type gregarious under spruce
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-9(10) x 7-8(9) microns, nearly round to round, "ornamentation in the form of a broken reticulum of branched nodulose lines and scattered isolated particles, the prominent elements 0.3-0.5 microns high, plage area with reduced ornamentation and often diffusely amyloid over a very small area", spore wall inamyloid, sterigmal appendage inconspicuous^; basidia 2-spored and 4-spored, 30-38 x 9-12 microns, clavate, colorless in KOH, sterigmata straight to slightly curved; macrocystidia 40-65(70) x 9-16 microns, "subclavate-mucronate and usually with at least some refractive content, thin-walled, readily collapsing, some merely subfusoid to clavate"; subhymenium cellular, 2-4 cells deep and continuing into the trama which is of sphaerocysts up to 30 microns in diameter, colorless in KOH; peridial trama "mostly of enlarged cells but a filamentous subcuticular zone present giving rise to epicutis"; epicutis of peridium a turf of greatly elongated pseudocystidia (60-200 x 4-7 microns) with refractive content, mostly decumbent when old, turf proper of gelatinous hyphal elements 40-60 x 2.5-6 microns, "often branched, apical cells not appreciably enlarged (in fact some almost aciculate in upper part)"; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  "In honor of Dr. Nancy Weber, for her extensive research on taxonomy of epigeous Ascomycetes, especially the genus Morchella", (Elliott, T.F.(1) with Morchella italicized)
SIMILAR  Russula subloculata is similar but R. nancyweberae has smaller spores and a paler duller spore mass, (Smith).
SOURCES  Smith(24) (as Macowanites pseudoemeticus) (color in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Trappe(13) (as Macowanites pseudoemeticus), Elliott, T.F.(1)
311
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula nondistincta  (Trappe & Castellano) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 237. 2018;  Gymnomyces nondistincta  Trappe & Castellano  Mycotaxon 75: 166. 2000
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  "The distinctive feature of this species is its lack of distinctive features." (Trappe(2)), features include somewhat spherical cream-colored smooth fruitbody that slowly turns pale red-brown where handled, pale brown-yellow spore mass, with rounded locules 0.2-0.5 millimeters in diameter lined by pale yellow spores, and microscopic characters including round spores with amyloid rods and spines, on 1-4-spored basidia^; description derived from Trappe(2); rare, OR to northern CA in mountains, (Trappe(13)), type found in OR
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  5cm x 4cm, somewhat spherical, the base indented; cream, slowly turning pale red-brown where handled; smooth
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  pale brown-yellow; with rounded locules 0.02-0.05cm in diameter lined by pale yellow spores
STEM  columella lacking
ODOR  of wine
TASTE  not recorded
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type found under Abies amabilis (Pacific Silver Fir) and Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock) at 1800m elevation, September
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9(11) x 7-9(11) microns, round, ornamentation in the form of strongly amyloid rods and spines (0.5)1-1.5(2) x 0.5-1 microns, these often merged in twos and threes to form short lines, "in places the spore surface with minute amyloid granules", spores colorless to pale yellow in KOH, walls gray in Melzer's reagent^; sterigmal appendage inconspicuous, +/- 1 x 0.5 microns; basidia 1-4-spored, 15-30 x 10-15 microns, clavate, sterigmata +/- 6 x 1 microns; cystidia absent; subhymenium of hyphae 2-5 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, with occasional cells inflated to 7-12 microns; trama of hyphae 2-5 microns wide, subparallel-interwoven, colorless, thin-walled; peridium 100-150 microns thick: epicutis of peridium 25-50 microns thick, of hyphae 2-4 microns wide, appressed, thin-walled, cell contents yellow-brown, subcutis 75-125 microns thick, of hyphae 2-4 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, thin-walled; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  Latin "nondistincta" (not distinctive), "in reference to the lack of distinctive features of this species"^, (Trappe)
SIMILAR  of the former Gymnomyces species with small round spores, Russula subochracea and Russula aromatica both have a peridial epicutis of dermatocystidia, (Trappe); Russula taetra has spore ornamentation and peridial epicutis similar to that of R. nondistincta but "has cystidia and a subhymenium of enlarged, isodiametric cells", (Trappe)
SOURCES  Trappe(2) (as Gymnomyces nondistincta), Castellano(1) (as Gymnomyces nondistincta), Trappe(13) (as Gymnomyces nondistincta), Elliott, T.F.(1)
312
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula odorifera  Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 237. 2018;  == Macowanites odoratus  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Trappe, T. Lebel & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 202. 2002;  == Elasmomyces odoratus  Singer & A.H. Sm.  Mem. Torrey Bot. Club 21: 57. 1960
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include a small whitish unpolished cap, the cap surface not reaching the stem consistently, a chambered pallid spore mass that becomes pinkish-cinnamon, a stem-columella greatly reduced in proportion to the size of the cap, the columella not always percurrent, an ethyl acetate odor, habitat on humus under conifers and hardwoods, and microscopic characters including elliptic spores with amyloid ornamentation of rods or spines (in irregular ridges or lines not connected to each other except by very fine lines), basidia that are 1-spored and 2-spored, and a cap cuticle that is a cutis of ochraceous hyphae.^ When the species was moved from Macowanites to Russula a new species epithet was required because of the prior name Russula odorata Romagn.(1950). RANGE Macowanites odorifera has been found at least in WA.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-2cm across, depressed-convex; whitish; unpolished; peridium not reaching the stem consistently^, (Singer)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "pallid becoming pinkish cinnamon as spores mature"; chambered^, (Singer)
STEM  stem-columella greatly reduced in proportion to size of cap and columella not always percurrent [not always going through to cap surface]^, (Singer)
ODOR  of fresh specimens strongly of ethyl acetate (fragrant)^, (Smith), strong of ethyl acetate (Singer)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on humus under conifers and hardwoods, July^, (Singer)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15-20 x 12-15 microns (including ornamentation), elliptic, pale cinnamon buff in KOH, strongly amyloid ornamentation in the form of rods or spines 1.5-2.3 microns long, thickness variable, generally amyloid overall but darker at apex or darker on one side, "elements occurring in irregular ridges or lines not connected to each other except by very fine lines", isolated warts and ridges often with tails, "no true appearance of even a broken reticulum, spore wall thin and pale yellowish in Melzer's reagent where exposed", sterigmal appendage inconspicuous^; basidia 1-spored and 2-spored, 30-35 x 10-14 microns, "clavate, readily collapsing", basidioles "numerous, with protoplasmic content"; cystidia none but 1-spored basidia without a spore resemble cystidia; subhymenium of vesiculose cells 12-20 microns in diameter, 1-2 cells deep; tramal mediostratum "of filamentose-interwoven hyphae, no sphaerocysts"; peridial context (subcutis) of interwoven filaments, colorless to yellowish, no sphaerocysts; peridial epicutis of hyphae 3-5 microns wide, interwoven, ochraceous, appressed or at the surface with some ascending hyphal ends; oleiferous hyphae none; clamp connections none, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'bearing an odor'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Elasmomyces odoratus), Smith(4) (as Elasmomyces odoratus), Trappe(13) (as Macowanites odoratus), Elliott, T.F.(1)
313
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula olida  (A.H. Sm.) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 237 (2018);  Macowanites olidus  A.H. Sm.  Mycologia 55: 429. 1963
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include a glutinous, cinnamon cap, a light yellow-brown spore mass that has distorted gills and cavities, an odor of cherry pits similar to Russula laurocerasi, and microscopic characters, including nearly round to elliptic spores with a strongly amyloid ornamentation of unconnected granules and of lines with short branches, borne on 4-spored basidia.^ The description is derived from Smith(24). RANGE The holotype was found in ID.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 on stem faintly pinkish (pallid vinaceous)
OUTER SURFACE  3.5-4.5cm broad, convex-depressed, margin curved in against spore mass (hence spore mass exposed around stem-columella); "pinkish cinnamon" over all or darker and tinged with olive over disc; glutinous, shining when dry, bald, pellicle (cap skin) not separable to any degree, rather rubbery when handled (due to thick epicutis of peridium)
INNER LAYER  thin, fragile; white
INTERIOR  spore mass lamellate [gilled] to lacunose [with cavities], attached to top of columella and peridium, apparently never enclosed by the peridium being intergrown with the stem-columella; soon "ochraceous buff" or brighter yellow
STEM  stem-columella 2-3cm x 0.8-1.1cm, solid; white, not staining when handled; unpolished
ODOR  aromatic, of cherry pits, reminding one of Russula laurocerasi
TASTE  mild
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type under mixed conifers
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-11.5 x 7-8.5 microns, nearly round to elliptic, "ornamentation strongly amyloid, 0.5-0.8 microns high, in the form of lines with short branches or these forming a partial reticulum but mostly of fairly numerous unconnected granules", spore wall inamyloid, "plage area with reduced ornamentation but in many spores with a dark amyloid spot at the base of the sterigmal appendage"^; basidia 4-spored, 30-40 x 9-12 microns, broadest below the apex, colorless in KOH; macrocystidia 40-60 x 10-16 microns, "clavate mucronate, scattered, slightly projecting, with a content of scattered refractive particles", thin-walled and readily collapsing; hymenophoral trama almost entirely of sphaerocysts including the subhymenium, colorless in KOH; peridial trama of heteromerous tissue [with nests of sphaerocysts among filamentous hyphae]; peridial epicutis "a turf of gelatinous hyphae and pseudocystidia 100-150 microns deep", the end cells of the turf elements clavate to cystidioid and 7-12 microns wide, or hyphal tips undifferentiated and 3-5 microns wide, colorless in KOH, some with refractive contents, epicutis arising from a layer of hyphae 2.5-7 microns wide, interwoven, gelatinous; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with an odor'
SIMILAR  Russula subloculata has a similar spore ornamentation, but the odor of R. olida when fresh and the cinnamon color of the cap surface distinguish it from that species, (Smith).
SOURCES  Smith(24)  (as Macowanites olidus) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Trappe(13) (as Macowanites olidus), Elliott, T.F.(1)
314
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula oregonensis  (Zeller) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 237. 2018;  Cystangium oregonense  (Zeller)  Trappe, T. Lebel, & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 198. 2002;  Martellia oregonensis  (Zeller) Singer & A.H. Sm.;  Hydnangium oregonense  Zeller
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include white depressed-spherical fruiting body that stains brownish, spore mass with small cavities that is colored white becoming pink then brownish vinaceous, absence of sterile base and columella, fruiting under duff in spring, and microscopic characters including large spores with very large spines irregularly coated with amyloid material, 1-spored basidia, cellular epicutis of peridium with small dermatocystidia, and absence of sphaerocysts in the context of the peridium^; infrequent, western OR, ID, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-2cm across, white, staining brownish; smooth^, (Smith), 1-2cm across, depressed-spherical; white, becoming marbled with light and dark brownish spots; smooth, (Singer)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white becoming flesh-pink, then brownish vinaceous; cavities small^, (Singer)
STEM  no sterile base, no columella^, (Singer)
ODOR  farinaceous^ (Singer)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in duff and mixed woods and under Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-cedar), Oregon, March to June^, (Smith), under duff in mixed woods (Singer), mycorrhizal with Pinaceae (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15-18 x 10-15 microns, ornamentation of spines 4-7 microns high, irregularly amyloid^; hymenial cystidia 42-54 x 7-11 microns, fusoid; cuticle of peridium a cellular zone 3-6 cells deep, the cells 8-20 microns broad, small cystidia project from the layer, (Smith), spores 15-18 x 10-15 microns excluding ornamentation, elliptic to round, ornamentation of spines 4-7 x 1.5-2.5 microns amyloid in some manner, either with a thin amylaceous coating overall, with a more heavily amylaceous jacket over lower half and apex nearly colorless, or upper part even or more irregularly coated with amylaceous material than lower part, "elements closely spaced (but not fused) to somewhat separated", "plage area and sterigmal appendage not distinct"; basidia 1-spored, (30)35-46(54) x 10-13 microns, clavate, yellowish-transparent, thin-walled, basidioles clavate, thin-walled; cystidia scattered to rare, 42-54 x 7-11 microns, fusoid, colorless, thin-walled; subhymenium of inflated cells (sphaerocysts), 2-3 cells deep; tramal mediostratum composed of hyphae 3-6 microns wide, interwoven, filamentose, colorless, thin-walled, lacking sphaerocysts; "a few subparallel strands forming a rudimentary hymenopodium on each side of mediostratum"; peridial context (subcutis) composed of hyphae 3-5 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, cells scarcely inflated, no sphaerocysts or inflated cells present; peridial epicutis a cellular zone 3-6 cells deep, the elements 8-20 microns wide and with thin, smooth, colorless walls, from the surface of this layer project numerous small dermatocystidia 15-22 x 4-8 microns, some fusoid-ventricose, some clavate, and all with colorless walls, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'from Oregon'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Martellia oregonensis), Smith(4) (as Martellia oregonensis), Trappe(13) (as Cystangium oregonense), Elliott, T.F.(1)
315
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula orsonmilleri  Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 239. 2018;  == Gymnomyces subalpinus  (A.H. Sm.) Trappe, T. Lebel & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 201. 2002;  == Martellia subalpina  A.H. Sm.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to irregular, bald, unpolished, dull white fruitbody that soon becomes yellowish to cinnamon buff, 2) a white spore mass with small irregular chambers that becomes pale tan and finally stains dull brown, 3) a strong basal rhizomorph, 4) a rudimentary columella, 5) growth under fir, and 6) microscopic characters including round spores with amyloid broken reticulum, on usually 2-spored basidia.^ When this species was moved to Russula, a new species epithet was required because of the prior name Russula subalpina  O.K. Mill. 1982. Russula orsonmilleri is rare among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Gymnomyces subalpinus was described from ID (Smith(24)). It has been found in central ID, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  neither KOH nor FeSO4 caution color change on peridial surface^, (Smith(24))
OUTER SURFACE  1-3.5cm diameter, nearly spherical to irregular; dull white to yellowish to cinnamon buff; unpolished; peridium not readily separating into 2 layers^, (Smith(4)), 1-3.5cm across, spherical to compressed or irregular, or pear-shaped; dull white at first, soon "yellowish to pinkish buff and finally dingy cinnamon buff to tan (staining slowly over entire surface)"; bald but unpolished, (Smith(24))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white becoming pale tan, finally with dull brown stains^, (Smith(4)), "white becoming pale pinkish buff and finally with dull brown stains"; "chambers small, irregular, empty", (Smith(24))
STEM  fruitbody with a strong basal rhizomorph; columella rudimentary, dendroid [branching]^, (Smith(4)), "with a strong basal rhizomorph attached at base"; "columella rudimentary, white, dendroid, often only traces present", (Smith(24))
ODOR  none^ (Smith(24))
TASTE  slight^ (Smith(24))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under alpine fir, August^, (Smith(4)), type collection in duff under Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), August, (Smith(24))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-10(11) x 7.5-10(11) microns, ornamented with broken reticulum, the prominences 0.2-0.4 microns high^; cuticle of peridium a poorly formed turf arising from a zone of interwoven hyphae, (Smith(4)), spores 8-10(11) x 7.5-10(11) microns, round to nearly round, ornamentation closely arranged, strongly amyloid, with prominences 0.2-0.4 microns high in the form of a broken reticulum, wall inamyloid but almost obscured, plage area not differentiated, sterigmal appendage narrow (about 1 micron in diameter); basidia 2-spored (rarely 4-spored), 24-36 x 9-11 microns, clavate, colorless in KOH, thin-walled; cystidia none; subhymenium "of more or less isodiametric cells 2-3 deep"; hymenophoral trama of hyphae 6-10 microns wide, interwoven, colorless in KOH, thin-walled, filamentose, "no sphaerocysts seen in layer and no distinct system of oleiferous or laticiferous hyphae seen"; epicutis of peridium "a poorly formed turf of terminal cells" 20-36 x 5-9 microns, "some subcylindric, others fusoid-ventricose to clavate", all thin-walled, smooth and colorless in KOH, many pseudocystidial hyphal ends also in the layer, the layer almost obliterated when old, the turf layer arising from a thick layer (about 100 microns thick) of hyphae 2-7 microns wide, compactly interwoven, nongelatinous, colorless (in KOH), the pockets of sphaerocysts scattered under this layer, all parts colorless in KOH and "no system of oleiferous or laticiferous hyphae seen other than the epicuticular cells with their refractive content (pseudocystidia)"; clamp connections none, (Smith(24))
NAME ORIGIN  "In honor of Dr. Orson K. Miller Jr. for his wide ranging contributions to taxonomy of North American fungi, including sequestrate and subalpine species", (Elliott, T.F.(1))
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(24) (as Martellia subalpina), Smith(4) (as Martellia subalpina), Trappe(13) (as Gymnomyces subalpinus), Elliott, T.F.(1)
316
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula parksii  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 237 (2018);  Gymnomyces parksii  Singer & A.H. Sm.  Mem. Torrey bot. Club 21(3): 55. 1960
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include white unchanging underground fruitbody with a hollow stem-like sterile base, growth under oak, and microscopic characters including nearly round to broadly elliptic spores with a prominent apiculus, ornamented with prominent spines amyloid in outer part and amyloid lines and particles, 2-spored and 4-spored basidia, and peridium with an epicutis in the form of a trichoderm^; description derived from Singer(10); rare in northern ID, (Trappe(13)), type from CA (Singer) 
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-1.5cm across (estimated); white, unchanging 
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  
STEM  "with a hollow stipe-like base which does not penetrate the gleba but in places the gleba is exposed in the area between the margin of the peridium and the sterile base"
ODOR  none
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type in California in heavy clay soil under Quercus (oak)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-11 x 7-9 microns, nearly round to broadly elliptic, with a prominent pointed sterigmal appendage 3-4 microns long (not included in the overall measurement), ornamented with prominent spines 2-2.5 microns long that are "amyloid only near the apex or over upper half", "and strongly amyloid lines and particles forming almost a broken reticulum at times" and about 0.5 microns high^; basidia 2-spored and 4-spored, 33-44 x 9-11 microns, clavate; cystidia rare, about 50 x 11 microns, subfusoid, thin-walled, lacking distinctive content; pseudoparaphyses none; subhymenium cellular; mediostratum of tramal plates mostly filamentous-interwoven but spherocytes present as plates approach peridium; peridium "with an epicutis in the form of a compact (almost indistinct) trichodermium" of septate hyphae 6-11 microns wide, interior to this a layer of mostly filamentose hyphae but some spherocysts also, laticiferous hyphae rare; clamp connections none demonstrated
NAME ORIGIN  after Harold E. Parks, who collected many hypogeous fungi in California
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Gymnomyces parksii), Trappe(13) (as Gymnomyces parksii), Elliott, T.F.(1)
317
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula piniamans  Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 238 (2018);  == Macowanites pinicola  A.H. Sm.  Mycologia 55: 430. 1963
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include a pallid to buff, viscid cap, thin fragile flesh, a somewhat gill-like to lacunose, pale yellowish spore mass attached at the top of the white stem-columella, fulvous stains around the stem base where handled, a mild odor and taste, and round spores with rather widely spaced bands of ornamentation, borne on 2-spored and 4-spored basidia.^ The description is derived from Smith(24). When the species was moved to Russula from Macowanites, a new species epithet was required because of the prior name Russula pinicola Murrill (1943). RANGE The holotype was found in ID.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 gives vinaceous buff (pinkish gray) reaction
OUTER SURFACE  2-4cm across, convex; pallid over all at first, slowly becoming pale toast-color ("pinkish buff"), 'some with reddish reflections or finally some with a slight olive tinge'; "viscid when wet, smooth but soon splitting irregularly into variously shaped plates", bald
INNER LAYER  thin, fragile; white
INTERIOR  spore mass attached at top of stem-columella, otherwise free of it, sublamellate [somewhat gill-like] to lacunose [with cavities], a broad expanse always exposed around stem-columella; "warm buff" (distinctly yellow)
STEM  1-3cm x 1-1.5cm, white, fulvous around base where handled; naked
ODOR  not distinctive
TASTE  mild
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type gregarious under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-11.5 x 9-11.5 microns, round to nearly round, "ornamentation in form of a wide-meshed partial reticulum of nodulose lines or chains of amyloid particles, the coarser elements 0.5-0.8(1) micron high, isolated particles also present", "plage area indistinct, the ornamentation reduced but lines still evident, some amorphous amyloid material around the base of the inconspicuous sterigmal appendage", wall inamyloid and somewhat thickened^; basidia 2-spored and 4-spored, 28-36 x 10-14 microns, clavate, broadest below apex, colorless in KOH; macrocystidia very rare, 32-44 x 10-16 microns, "ventricose mucronate, with an amorphous mass of refractive material in lower mid-portion"; subhymenium "cellular and 2-4 cells deep, central area of hymenophoral trama of sphaerocysts about twice the size of those in the subhymenium, colorless in KOH"; peridial trama "with pockets of sphaerocysts surrounded by filamentose hyphae (heteromerous)"; subcutis of peridium "a thin layer of nongelatinous appressed-interwoven hyphae with some enlarged cells in the layer"; epicutis of peridium "a gelatinous trichoderm of branched hyphae" 50-80(100) x 3-6 microns, "end-cells not particularly enlarged", no significant number of pseudocystidia in epicutis; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  means "friend of pine" (Elliott, T.F.(1))
SIMILAR  Russula subloculata is similar but R. piniamans differs in developing fulvous stains on the stem, in the vinaceous-gray FeSO4 reaction, and the rare macrocystidia which lack yellow contents in KOH, but the sharpest difference is in spore ornamentation: in R. piniamans the elements are spaced far apart giving an open effect, (Smith). Russula subrosacea and Russula vilgalysii have yellow laticiferous hyphae in the peridial context, and different spores, (Smith). 
SOURCES  Smith(24) (individual colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway) (as Macowanites pinicola), Trappe(13) (as Macowanites pinicola), Elliott, T.F.(1)
318
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula rogersii  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 238. 2018;  Gymnomyces rogersii  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Trappe, T. Lebel & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 200. 2002;  Octavianina rogersii  Singer & A.H. Sm.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include nearly spherical to irregular fruitbody with white surface, peridium sometimes breaking up to expose the spore mass which is pale tan when dried, columella rudimentary to absent, and microscopic characters including nearly round spores with prominent spines, 1-spored basidia, scattered hymenial cystidia, and peridial cuticle of appressed interwoven hyphae, and scattered sphaerocysts^; rare, western OR, (Trappe(13)), type found in OR
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across, nearly spherical to irregular, white when fresh, unpolished, peridium sometimes breaking up to expose the spore mass^, (Smith), 1-2.5cm across, spherical to nearly spherical, flattened or quite irregular; white when fresh, drying whitish to pale buff; unpolished when dried; peridium continuous or at times breaking into a number of lobes and spore mass exposed in upper part (not at base in specimens examined), (Singer)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  pale tan when dried^, (Smith), of minute chambers and drying nearly "cinnamon-buff" (Ridgway color), not of a gelatinous consistency, (Singer)
STEM  columella rudimentary to absent^ (Smith), columella "as seen in dried material rudimentary to lacking, when present consisting merely of thin short lines of sterile tissue and not percurrent"; stem absent, (Singer)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  collection under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) in May^, (Singer)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14-19 microns in diameter, ornamented with rods and spines 1.5-3 microns high^, cystidia scattered, 60-80 x 7-11 microns, cuticle of peridium of appressed interwoven hyphae, scattered sphaerocysts present, (Smith), spores 14-19 microns, nearly round, ornamentation in the form of distinct rods and spines 1.5-3 x 0.6-1 microns, closely arranged but not separate, typically pale yellow in Melzer's reagent (spores from dried specimens) "but a few seen with a distinct small bluish spot in upper half or at apex (for taxonomic purposes non-amyloid)", no distinct plage area showing, spore wall about 2 microns thick and pale orange-yellow in Melzer's reagent, "sterigmal appendage absent to very inconspicuous and its walls thin and parallel (hyphal-like)"; basidia 1-spored, 42-56 x 10-15 microns, clavate, thin-walled, colorless; basidioles numerous, 30-38 x 9-11 microns; pseudoparaphyses "present as broadly inflated basidioles (10-15 microns broad)", thin-walled, colorless, readily collapsing; cystidia scattered, 60-80 x 7-11 microns, narrowly clavate to narrowly fusoid, some with refringent rods and granules in the interior, arising from oleiferous hyphae, thin-walled, colorless in KOH; subhymenium "of slightly enlarged to sphaerocyst-like cells", colorless, thin-walled; "mediostratum of filamentose hyphae with some oleiferous hyphae and some scattered sphaerocysts", all colorless in KOH; epicutis of peridium continuous with context and composed of hyphae 2-4 microns wide, appressed-interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, smooth; context "mostly of interwoven filamentous hyphae but some sphaerocysts present near subhymenium"; clamp connections absent, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  after the collector of the type, D.P. Rogers
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(4) (as Octavianina rogersii), Singer(10) (as Octavianina rogersii), Trappe(13) (as Gymnomyces rogersii), Elliott, T.F.(1)
319
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula rolfalexii  (Trappe, T. Lebel & Castellano) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 238. 2018;  Gymnomyces rolfalexii  Trappe, T. Lebel & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 201. 2002;  == Martellia parksii  Singer & A.H. Sm.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical fruitbody that is dull cinnamon brown and uneven to wrinkled, spore mass dull cinnamon brown with minute chambers, sterile base absent, columella absent, and microscopic characters including elliptic to nearly round spores with amyloid ornamentation of warts and rods single or in groups, and peridial epicutis a turf of minute, clavate to filamentous cells^; Martellia parksii had to be renamed when transferred into Gymnomyces because of the prior description of a different species Gymnomyces parksii; common, western OR, (Trappe(13)), type collection found in OR
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  about 1cm across, spherical; near dull cinnamon brown as dried; uneven^, (Smith), about 1cm across, spherical; near dull cinnamon brown; "uneven to wrinkled and unpolished (when dried out)"; consistency rubbery-tough (preserved in liquid), (Singer)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  dull cinnamon brown; chambers minute^, (Singer)
STEM  no sterile base, no columella^, (Singer)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest are trees in Pinaceae, (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-14(18) x 9-12(14) microns, ornamented with short rods and warts up to 1 micron high^; "cuticle of peridium a turf of minute, clavate to filamentous cells", (Smith), spores 10-14(18) x 9-12(14) microns, not including sterigmal appendage, elliptic to nearly round, amyloid ornamentation "in the form of warts and rods single or in groups but not fused to form distinct lines or ridges, prominences 0.5-1.0 microns high and more heavily amyloid at apex than at base", spore wall about 1 micron thick, yellowish in Melzer's reagent, pale buff in KOH, sterigmal appendage 2-3 microns, with basal amyloid jacket, place area not distinct; basidia 2-spored (only a few with sterigmata seen), 22-28 x 10-13 microns, "broadly clavate, thin-walled, readily collapsing"; pseudoparaphyses resembling broad basidioles; cystidia none seen; subhymenium cellular, the cells 6-10 microns in diameter; tramal mediostratum of interwoven, colorless, gelatinous hyphae, mostly 2.5-6 microns wide, no sphaerocysts and no oleiferous hyphae; peridial context (subcutis) composed of hyphae 1.5-4 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, and gelatinous, no sphaerocysts, no oleiferous hyphae; peridial epicutis "a turf of minute cells, clavate to filamentous, encrusted with much amorphous material", the clavate cells 4-8 x 3-6 microns and the filaments 4-12 x 1.5-3 microns, various intergrading types also; clamp connections none, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  after Rolf Singer and Alexander H. Smith, who described Martellia parksii
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Martellia parksii), Smith(4) (as Martellia parksii), Trappe(13) (as Gymnomyces rolfalexii), Elliott, T.F.(1)
320
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula setigera  (Zeller) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 239. 2018;  Gymnomyces setiger  (Zeller) Trappe, T. Lebel & Castellano [as 'setigerus']  Mycotaxon 81: 201. 2002;  Martellia setigera  (Zeller & C.W. Dodge) Singer & A.H. Sm.;  Hydnangium setigerum  Zeller
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include nearly spherical fruitbody that is white to light brown, spore mass with small irregular cavities, colored creamy white becoming light brown, attachment by a single rhizomorph, and microscopic characters including low amyloid ornamentation in the form of isolated warts and ridges, 1-spored, 2-spored, and 4-spored basidia, fusoid cystidia, and peridial epicutis a trichodermium with dermatocystidia that are clavate, subfusoid, seta-like, or contorted-filamentose^; rare, northeastern WA and western OR, (Trappe(13)), type collection found in OR
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-1.5cm across, nearly spherical; white to light brown; unpolished to plush-like^, (Singer)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  creamy white, becoming light brown; cavities small, irregular^, (Singer)
STEM  no columella or sterile base, fruiting body attached by a single rhizomorph^, (Singer)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection under moss in dense coniferous woods, March^, (Singer)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-10(11) microns, round, "ornamentation in the form of a broken reticulum with scattered isolated warts and ridges, prominences about 0.25 microns high"^; cystidia numerous, 34-52 x 7-11 microns, fusoid, apex acute; cuticle of peridium a trichodermium, (Smith), spores 8-10(11) microns, round, "ornamentation in the form of irregular knotty ridges connected to from a broken reticulum and in addition with both small warts and granules with tails, or very fine lines connecting to coarser elements, the prominences about 0.25 microns high (very low), all elements of ornamentation strongly amyloid", spore wall pale yellowish in Melzer's reagent, nearly colorless as revived in KOH, wall about 0.5-0.75 microns thick; sterigmal appendage about 2.5 x 2 microns with an amyloid jacket around base, plage area not differently marked from the remainder of the surface; basidia 1-spored, 2-spored, and 4-spored according to Zeller, 30-42 x 10-12 microns, clavate, yellowish as revived in KOH, basidioles numerous; pseudoparaphyses scattered, 36-40 x 15-20 microns, resembling giant basidia; cystidia numerous, 34-52 x 7-11 microns, "basically fusoid but near apex usually with a series of constrictions, apices acute", colorless, content protoplasmic, often seen to connect to oleiferous hyphae, filamentous "pseudocystidia" 30-40 x 3-5 microns with acute apices also present; subhymenium of hyphae 4-8 microns wide, diverging, 2-3-septate and when old the cells becoming sphaerocyst-like (up to 15 microns); tramal mediostratum of hyphae 4-8 microns wide, filamentose, interwoven, colorless, "and at junction points some cells barrel-like and up to 12-15 microns broad but no true sphaerocysts present", oleiferous hyphae scattered; peridial epicutis a trichodermium of thin-walled yellowish to colorless hyphae with numerous cross-walls "and the cells of irregular shape making the layer difficult to interpret", proliferated at the tips into versiform dermatocystidia (10)15-30 x (3)5-8(10) microns, "clavate, subfusoid, seta-like or contorted-filamentose", if seta-like the cell walls thickened slightly but colorless in KOH; clamp connections none; oleiferous hyphae present, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'bearing setae' referring to the seta-like dermatocystidia in the epicutis of the peridium
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Martellia setigera, examined preserved in liquid), Smith(4) (as Martellia setigera), Trappe(13) (as Gymnomyces  setigerus), Elliott, T.F.(1)
321
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula shafferi  Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 232. 2018;  == Gymnomyces brunnescens  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Trappe, T. Lebel, & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 199. 2002;  == Martellia brunnescens  Singer & A.H. Sm.  Mem. Torrey Bot. Club 21(3): 37. 1961
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a somewhat spherical but often bumpy or pitted fruitbody that is white and develops ocher brown to rusty brown stains when old or with handling, 2) a spore mass that is white discoloring brown, 3) absent sterile base, 4) absent columella, 5) an odor that is often sweet, at least in old fruitbodies, and 6) amyloid spores with isolated to grouped but unconnected spines and warts of only moderate height, 7) basidia that are 4-spored and 2-spored, and 8) a peridial epicutis that is a turf of seta-like dermatocystidia.^ It is infrequent among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest. When Gymnomyces brunnescens was moved to Russula, a new species epithet was required because of the prior name Russula brunnescens Murrill Lloydia 8: 264. 1946 (1945). RANGE The type collection is from OR (Singer). It is found from southwestern BC to northern CA (Trappe(13)). Trappe, M.(1) says it is one of the more common hypogeous fungi in the Douglas-fir forests of western WA, western OR, and northern CA.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across, uneven to tuberculate or alveolate; white, when old brownish as if stained; bald^, (Smith(4)), 1-3cm across, spherical to oval or irregularly knobby (potato-like); "white when young, developing ochre-brown to rusty-brown or brown stains in age or after handling, usually entirely brownish in old age; smooth or pitted", (Arora), 1-2.5cm across, spherical or nearly so; white, older specimens brownish as if stained; bald, surface uneven to tuberculate and in some specimens finally alveolate, (Singer)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white staining brown; chambers small^, (Singer), small chambers, crisp when young; white discoloring brown to rusty brown when cut (often slowly) and becoming ocher-brown to brown when mature, (Arora)
STEM  no sterile base, columella absent^, (Singer)
ODOR  "often sweet (somewhat reminiscent of vanilla)", at least when old^, (Arora), not distinctive (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single, scattered, or in groups "in soil or in humus (buried) in woods", favoring conifers, collections found in mixed woods and under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), April, July, and October^, (Arora), under conifers, May, (Smith(4)), with Pseudotsuga menziesii, July to December, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-11 x 8-9 microns, ornamentation of +/- isolated short spines and warts to 1.3 microns high^; "cuticle of peridium a turf of seta-like cystidia" 22-36 x 3-7 microns, "the walls thickened and yellowish in KOH", context of peridium of colorless gelatinized hyphae, (Smith(4)), 8-11 x 8-9 microns, "broadly elliptic to round, with strongly amyloid warts and spines", colorless; cystidia absent; walls of tissue between the chambers "lacking sphaerocysts in their central layers", (Arora), spores 8-11 x 8-9 microns, broadly elliptic to nearly round, "ornamentation in the form of short spines and warts in groups or evenly distributed but mostly unconnected, the prominences 0.8-1.3 microns high, generally strongly amyloid, especially at apex of the spines", sterigmal appendage inconspicuous, "plage area not distinctive or merely with less prominent ornamentation"; basidia 4-spored and 2-spored, 26-34 x 10-12 microns, "clavate, thin-walled, content protoplasmic", basidioles numerous; cystidia none; subhymenium "appearing cellular because the hyphae diverging from the mediostratum are cut up by cross walls to produce more or less isodiametric cells"; tramal mediostratum of hyphae 3-5 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, gelatinous, no sphaerocysts, no oleiferous hyphae; peridial epicutis a turf of seta-like dermatocystidia 22-36 x 3-7 microns, fusoid, wall thin to thickened and yellowish transparent in KOH, often with patches of amorphous incrustation around them; peridial context (subcutis) of hyphae 2-4 microns, interwoven, colorless, smooth, gelatinous; no sphaerocysts or oleiferous hyphae present; clamp connections absent, (Singer), spores 8-12 x 8-10 microns, round, with amyloid spines +/- 1 micron tall (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  "To honor Dr. Robert Shaffer for his important contributions to knowledge of North American Russulae" (Elliott, T.F.(1), with 'Russulae' italicized)
SIMILAR  Russula subochracea (as Martellia subochracea) has larger round spores and no odor, (Smith(24)). R. subochracea (as Gymnomyces subochraceus) is very similar and may be the same species (NATS). See also SIMILAR section of Russula similaris.
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Martellia brunnescens, based on specimen in alcohol), Smith(4) (as Martellia brunnescens), Arora(1) (as Martellia brunnescens), Trappe, M.(1)* (as Gymnomyces brunnescens), Trappe, M.(3)* (as Gymnomyces brunnescens), Smith(24) (as Martellia brunnescens), Trappe(13)* (as Gymnomyces brunnescens), NATS(1) (as Gymnomyces brunnescens), Elliott, T.F.(1)
322
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula similaris  Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 233. 2018;  == Gymnomyces fallax  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Trappe, T. Lebel, & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 199. 2002;  == Martellia fallax  Singer & A.H. Sm.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include white fruitbody that turns rusty brown in spots, spore mass very pale yellow-cream to nearly white, growth under hardwoods, and microscopic characters including nearly round to round spores with low warts and spines that are amyloid (smaller ones) or partly amyloid (larger ones), basidia 2-spored mostly, rarely 4-spored, and hymenial cystidia that are colorless in KOH or with refractive yellowish content as in chrysocystidia^; when this species was moved from Gymnomyces to Russula, a new species epithet was required because of the prior name Russula fallax (Schaef.) Fr. (1874); a common western species (Arora), infrequent in the Pacific Northwest, found in western OR to southern CA, (Trappe(13)), type collection from CA
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-2cm across, white, turning rusty brown in spots^, (Singer)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  very pale yellow-cream to nearly white^ (Singer)
STEM  
ODOR  earthy (Singer), like Russula fragrantissima (Arora)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in soil under Quercus agrifolia (California Live Oak), (Singer), under hardwoods (Arora)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-12 x 8-10 microns, nearly round to round, pale ochraceous to colorless in KOH, "ornamentation in the form of warts and spines 0.5-0.8 microns high and almost as broad, with amyloid material covering the smaller elements but on the larger ones covering only the apex or one side of the wart below the apex", spore wall up to about 1 micron thick and yellowish-transparent in Melzer's reagent, sterigmal appendage 2-3 microns long, 1-1.8 microns thick and inamyloid, "plage area ornamented but the particles there less amyloid and smaller than elsewhere on the spore"^; basidia 2-spored mostly, rarely 4-spored, 36-44 x 9-11 microns, "thin-walled, readily collapsing, many with yellow content in KOH", sterigmata straight and conic; pseudoparaphyses 10-14 microns broad, ellipsoid; cystidia 38-50 x 12-17 microns, ventricose-mucronate or apex obtuse, thin-walled, colorless in KOH "or with refractive content as in chrysocystidia"; tramal plates of hyphae 4-9 microns wide, uninflated, filamentous, interwoven, somewhat transparent in KOH, subgelatinous, with slightly thickened walls, no sphaerocysts; subhymenium of similar hyphae but the cells shorter; peridial context (subcutis) of interwoven filaments, no sphaerocysts; peridial epicutis of interwoven hyphae colorless to yellowish in KOH, walls thickened and glassy in KOH, surface with scattered dermatocystidia or these present as fascicles, the cystidia 20-30(40) x 4-8 microns, subfusoid, colorless, and with walls slightly thickened; laticiferous hyphae absent; clamp connections absent, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  'similaris' means 'similar'
SIMILAR  Russula ferruginascens (as Gymnomyces ferruginascens) is practically the same in field characters, but differs microscopically, (Singer); Russula shafferi (as Martellia brunnescens) lacks hymenial cystidia (Arora)
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Martellia fallax), Arora(1) (as Martellia fallax), Trappe(13) (as Gymnomyces fallax), Elliott, T.F.(1)
323
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula stewartii  Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 236. 2018;  == Gymnomyces monosporus  E.L. Stewart & Trappe  Mycotaxon 2(2): 209. 1975
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  the distinctive feature is the large spores for the genus on 1-spored basidia, other features include nearly spherical to irregular fruitbody with persistent covering that is white but stains pink to grayish red where bruised, spore mass that is pale yellow at first, becoming dingy orange-yellow, absent columella but one to several sterile veins radiating from base, fragrant odor, growth underground, and microscopic characters including spores with ornamentation of colorless rods and spines^; when this species was moved from Gymnomyces to Russula, a new species epithet was required because of the name Russula monospora (Boud. & Pat.) Trappe & T.F. Elliott based on Hydnangium monosporum Boud. & Pat. (1888); description derived from Stewart(1); rare, western OR, (Trappe(13)), described from OR
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  peridial surface not reacting to 5% KOH, 5% FeSO4, or Melzer's reagent
OUTER SURFACE  0.9-3.5cm x 0.9-2.5cm fresh, 0.7-2.9cm x 0.7-1.9cm dried, nearly spherical to irregular, "depressed at the base"; white, staining pink to grayish red where bruised, drying light brown; "felty-smooth to alveolate (depressed over glebal chambers)"; peridium thin, persistent
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  pale yellow when young, becoming light orange yellow and, when mature, dingy orange yellow, drying light yellowish brown; chambers 0.02-0.05cm in diameter, rotund
STEM  columella lacking but one to several narrow sterile veins radiating from base
ODOR  fragrant
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type underground in old roadbed in woods of 20 to 30 year old Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), July
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15-21 x 12-18 microns excluding ornamentation, nearly round to broadly elliptic, ornamentation of colorless rods and spines 1.5-3(4) x 0.5-1 microns, "occasionally with light to heavy amyloid deposits near the base as dots or collars (the amount of amyloid deposits varying markedly from spore to spore)", strongly cyanophilic in cotton blue - lactic acid, walls 1.5-2(3) microns thick, pale yellow in KOH, dull yellow in Melzer's reagent, cyanophilic in cotton-blue - lactic acid, sterigmal appendage 2-4 x 2-3 microns, "inconspicuous, often with a basal amyloid collar"^; basidia 1-spored, 30-35 x 11-16 microns, "thin-walled, broadly clavate, with a single, prominent sterigma, mostly with granular content in KOH", brachybasidioles 25-35 x 14-19 microns, thin-walled, contents clear in KOH; cystidia scattered, 35-47 x 7-12 microns, extending 12-25 microns beyond other hymenial elements, "obtuse-ventricose, thin-walled, with granular content in KOH"; subhymenium "of 1-3 tiers of sphaerocyst-like cells mostly 9-25 x 6-15 microns"; tramal mediostratum of hyphae 2-5 microns wide, subparallel, with scattered single to clustered sphaerocysts; peridium 150-300 microns thick, of hyphae 2-3(4) microns wide, interwoven, colorless, with sphaerocysts scattered in tissue adjacent to gleba; clamp connections not seen
NAME ORIGIN  "In honor of Dr Elwin L. Stewart, mycologist and plant pathologist, for his contributions to taxonomy of sequestrate fungi", (Elliott, T.F.(1))
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Stewart(1) (as Gymnomyces monosporus) (colors from Kelly(3)), Trappe(13) (as Gymnomyces monosporus), Elliott, T.F.(1)
324
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula stricklandiorum  T.F. Elliott & Trappe^  Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 235. 2018 [as 'stricklandorum'];  == Macowanites luteolus  A.H. Sm. & Trappe  Mycologia 55: 427. 1963
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include a fruitbody with cream to dull pale yellowish color of the cap, spore mass, and stem, the cap slightly viscid, the spore mass of half-formed gills attached only at top of stem, and the short dry stem hoary when fresh. The odor is mild and the taste peppery or like raw potatoes. It fruits just under or on ground under conifers. Microscopic characters include round or nearly round spores with amyloid ornamentation of small rods and granules arranged in short rows, 2-spored and 4-spored basidia, and short elements in the peridial epicutis.^ It is common among sequestrate species in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). When Macowanites luteolus was moved to Russula a new species epithet was chosen to avoid confusion with the name Russula luteola (Harkn.) Trappe and T.F. Elliott which is based on Hydnangium luteolum Harkn. (previously combined as Gymnomyces luteolus (Harkn.) Trappe et al.) RANGE Russula stricklandiorum was described from OR (Smith(24)), and is found in CA (Thiers(4)), and WA (Phillips). It has been recorded from western OR to AK (Trappe, M.(1)). There are collections from BC by O. Ceska at the University of British Columbia and from WA at the University of Washington and Oregon State University.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH giving no reaction with flesh; FeSO4 giving no reaction with flesh^, (Smith)
OUTER SURFACE  2-4cm across, "uneven, lumpy button mushroom-shaped with a smooth surface, white to creamy buff, drying yellowish, slightly viscid at first"^, (Phillips), 1-3cm across, "broadly convex and not expanding", margin curved in but not reaching the stem-columella; evenly pale cream but gradually becoming darker and duller over the disc, rather dingy yellowish when dried, (color of cap is also referred to as dull pale yellowish); "viscid at first but soon dry and unpolished", (Smith), pale yellow; often cracking, (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  pallid^ (Smith)
INTERIOR  spore mass "creamy spongelike mass of half-formed gills"^, (Phillips), lamellate [gill-like] to lacunose [with cavities], attached only at apex of stem-columella; cream-buff (as the cap margin), not staining when cut, (also referred to as dull pale yellowish), (Smith), pale orange yellow; "with vestigial stem extending all the way through the middle to the top, forming a prominent, white columella", (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  1-2cm x 0.5-1cm, short and stubby; whitish or creamy like the cap^, (Phillips), stem-columella 1-1.5cm x 0.4-0.7cm at top, nearly equal; buffy-pallid when fresh, unchanging where bruised (also referred to as dull pale yellowish); dry, when fresh hoary, (Smith)
ODOR  mild^, (Phillips), slight and not distinct (Smith)
TASTE  like raw potatoes (Phillips), slowly but distinctly acrid [peppery], (Smith)^, acrid (Arora), mild, (Trappe, M.(3))
EDIBILITY  unknown (Phillips)
HABITAT  "just under or on the surface of ground under conifers", September to October^, (Phillips), under Tsuga (hemlock) and Picea (spruce), (Smith), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga, Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), year-round, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7.9-9.4 x 7-8.5 microns, round or nearly round, amyloid warts^, (Phillips), spores "7-9 X 6.5-7.5 (10-12 X 8-10 microns)", nearly round to broadly elliptic, "ornamentation in the form of small rods to granules, scattered or closely arranged in short rows" (not reticulate), major elements 0.3-0.7 microns high, "plage area ornamented and typically a large amorphous drop of strongly amyloid material at base of the prominent sterigmal appendage", wall inamyloid; basidia 2-spored and 4-spored, 28-36 x 9-12 microns, colorless in KOH, thin-walled; macrocystidia numerous, 46-62 x 10-16 microns, "narrowly clavate-mucronate to narrowly ellipsoid-pedicellate", the apex with a short projection, "thin-walled, with some refractive content of various shapes, readily collapsing"; subhymenium cellular, 2-4 cells deep, central strand of hymenophoral trama with numerous sphaerocysts, all parts colorless in KOH; subcutis of peridium a thick layer of hyphae 5-10 microns wide, interwoven, with scattered enlarged cells, grading into the peridial context of heteromerous tissue [with nests of sphaerocysts among filamentous hyphae]; epicutis of peridium a turf of subgelatinous elements with terminal cells 4-6 microns wide, "the end cells narrowly clavate to somewhat cystidioid, some narrow elongated pseudocystidial hyphae extending throughout the layer and decumbent on surface, these with granular content in some of the component cells" and colorless in KOH; clamp connections absent, (Smith), spores 7-12 x 6.5-10 microns, round to nearly round, with amyloid spines, (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  "in honor of Bob and Babs Strickland for their support of the natural sciences and contributions to conservation" (Elliott, T.F.(1))
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Smith(24) (as Macowanites luteolus), Phillips(1)* (as Macowanites luteolus), Arora(1) (as Macowanites luteolus), Trappe, M.(1)* (as Macowanites luteolus), Trappe, M.(3)* (as Macowanites luteolus), Thiers(4) (as Macowanites luteolus), Trappe(13) (as Macowanites luteolus), Elliott, T.F.(1)
325
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula subabietis  Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 231. 2018;  == Gymnomyces abietis  Trappe & Castellano  Mycotaxon 75: 161. 2000
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) an underground fruitbody that is white and downy when young, soon becoming smooth with the upper surface pale yellow (sometimes with rose to orange-brown areas), 2) an interior that is white when young becoming pale orange yellow from spores lining the labyrinthine locules, 3) occasional sterile white veins or a white columnar to branching columella, 4) a small basal pad of sterile tissue, 5) growth under fir, and 6) microscopic characters including round to broadly elliptic spores with amyloid rods and lines, and 1-4-spored basidia.^ When Gymnomyces abietis was moved to Russula, a new species epithet was chosen to avoid confusion with Russula abietum (J. Blum) Bon 1983. The description is derived from Trappe(2) except where noted. It is common among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest. RANGE Collections were examined from WA, OR, ID, and CA, (Trappe(2)). Distribution is WA to ID and northern CA in mountains, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-4cm x 0.6-2.8cm, the base indented, radially rugose [wrinkled]; peridium readily separable, when young "thin, white, pubescent, soon becoming smooth and the sides and upper surface dull, pale yellow, sometimes blushed rose to orange-brown areas, not staining where bruised or slowly becoming slightly brown, often rupturing to expose glebal locules as the basidioma expands"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white when young, soon pale orange-yellow from spores lining the labyrinthine locules 0.05-0.3cm x 0.01-0.05cm; dry; occasional, narrow, white, sterile veins
STEM  "with a white, small to prominent, basal pad of sterile tissue and occasional, narrow, white, sterile veins or a narrow, columnar to dendroid, white columella" up to 0.6cm x 0.05-0.3cm; "with soil attached near basal mycelium"
ODOR  not distinctive
TASTE  not distinctive
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground, under Abies amabilis, A. concolor, A. grandis, A. lasiocarpa, A. magnifica, A. procera and possibly Tsuga mertensiana, July through October, (Trappe(2)), above 1000m elevation (Castellano), August to December (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-10(14) x (7)7.5-9.5(11) microns, round to nearly round or broadly elliptic, ornamented when young "by unevenly amyloid rods and inamyloid lines 0.5 x 0.2-0.5 microns, the rods sometimes loosely joined in short rows", by maturity the rods strongly and evenly amyloid, (0.3)1(1.5) x 0.3-1.0 microns, "often joined to form short, thick lines" or connected by narrow, low, amyloid lines on the spore surface to form a partial to nearly complete reticulum, "sterigmal appendage with a strongly amyloid, basal collar or a large, amyloid deposit on one side"^; basidia 1-4-spored, 23-29(40) x (6)8-13(15) microns, clavate, sterigmata +/- 5 x 1 microns; cystidia absent; trama composed of hyphae 2-5 microns wide, subparallel, colorless, thin-walled, "at tramal junctions with occasional to many isolate cells inflated up to 25 microns and with occasional nests of sphaerocysts"; "basal pad of columella with abundant sphaerocysts"; peridium 100-200 microns thick: epicutis "a loose to tightly packed trichodermium of obtuse-cylindric to clavate or occasionally versiform", colorless, thin-walled end cells (2)3-5 microns wide, when old this collapsing to appear appressed-interwoven, subcutis of hyphae 2-5 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, "with scattered cells inflated up to 10 microns and occasional nests of sphaerocysts where subcutis and tramal intersections merge"
NAME ORIGIN  means "almost of the fir" (Elliott, T.F.(1))
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Trappe(2) (as Gymnomyces abietis), Castellano(1)* (as Gymnomyces abietis), Trappe, M.(1)* (as Gymnomyces abietis), Trappe, M.(3)* (as Gymnomyces abietis), Trappe(13) (as Gymnomyces abietis), Elliott, T.F.(1)
326
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula subfulva  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 239. 2018;  Gymnomyces subfulvus  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Trappe, T. Lebel & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 201. 2002;  Martellia subfulva  Singer & A.H. Sm.  Mem. Torrey Bot. Club 21: 35. 1960
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to irregular bald fruitbody that is pale rusty brown preserved in fluid, spore mass dull cinnamon preserved in fluid, with very fine chambers, point of attachment present but columella absent, and microscopic characters including in nearly round to round spores ornamented with amyloid rods and spines to 1.5 microns high, mostly 2-spored basidia, peridial epicutis a turf of clavate to fusoid cells, their content ochraceous as revived in KOH, sphaerocysts absent from peridium but subhymenium a layer of large sphaerocysts 2-4 cells deep^; description derived from Singer(10); common, southwestern BC to northern CA, (Trappe(13)), type collection from OR
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.8-1.5cm across, more or less spherical to irregular; pale rusty brown as preserved in fluid, dull brown when dried; bald but with some adhering debris^, (Singer)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  dull cinnamon as preserved in fluid, dark cinnamon when dried; with very fine chambers^, (Singer)
STEM  sterile base indistinct in preserved material but a definite point of attachment present, columella absent^, (Singer)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in conifer duff, June^, (Singer)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-12 x 8-11 microns, ornamented with rods and spines to 1.5 microns high^, cuticle of peridium a turf of clavate to fusoid cells, their content ochraceous as revived in KOH, sphaerocysts absent from peridium, (Smith), spores 9-12 x 8-11 microns, nearly spherical to spherical, pale cinnamon in KOH, wall yellowish in Melzer's reagent, amyloid ornamentation in the form of rods and spines 0.75-1.5 microns and 0.3-0.7 microns thick, more strongly amyloid at apex than at base, irregular in outline from above, "or 2-3 fused into an irregular formation but no sign of a reticulum (the individual groups unconnected but some elements showing fine tails)", "sterigmal appendage inconspicuous and with a basal amyloid jacket"; hymenium pale cinnamon-yellowish in KOH; basidia 2-spored mostly, 23-28 x 10-12 microns, "clavate, content pale yellowish cinnamon in KOH (preserved material)", "thin-walled and soon collapsing", basidioles scattered; pseudoparaphyses scattered, 10-15 microns in diameter, almost spherical at times; cystidia none; subhymenium a layer of large sphaerocysts 2-4 cells deep; tramal mediostratum a narrow layer of filamentose elements colorless in KOH and nongelatinous, only moderately interwoven; peridial context (subcutis) ochraceous in KOH, of interwoven narrow hyphae, context near subhymenium nearly colorless but hyphae also narrow and interwoven, sphaerocysts none and oleiferous hyphae none; peridial epicutis "a turf ending in clavate to fusoid cells with ochraceous content, and smaller cylindric to pointed cells with slightly thickened walls", (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'nearly fulvous', color in Latin description is "pallide fulvis"
SIMILAR
