SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Martellia subfulva), Smith(4) (as Martellia subfulva), Trappe(13) (as Gymnomyces subfulvus), Elliott, T.F.(1)
327
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula subloculata  Trappe, T. Lebel & Castellano^  Mycotaxon 81: 204. 2002;  == Macowanites americanus  Singer & A.H. Sm.
ENGLISH NAMES  gastroid Russula, false brittlegill, American false Russula
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include 1) a viscid cap with variable color: pale olive yellow, pale olive, pink, lilac, lilac-purple, purplish red, blue, or even whitish, or often mixtures of these, 2) a spore mass consisting irregular or distorted gills that are whitish at first but become ochraceous, 3) a stout, equal, brittle stem, 4) a mild odor and taste, 5) growth under conifers (buried or above ground), 6) nearly round spores with amyloid ridges and warts forming at most a broken reticulum, 7) basidia that are mostly 4-spored, rarely 1-spored, 2-spored, or 3-spored, 8) hymenial pseudocystidia, and 9) a cap cuticle that is at first a palisade of pseudocystidia, these becoming decumbent and tangled when old.^ Russula subloculata is commoner in North America than any of the species of Macowanites (Smith), from which genus it was moved in 2002. RANGE It has been found in the Pacific Northwest and northern Rocky Mountains, (Smith). Specifically it has been recorded for ID (Singer) and CA (Thiers(4)). There are collections from BC at the University of British Columbia, collections from WA, AK, and CA at the University of Washington, collections from OR and MT at Oregon State University, and collections from ID at New York Botanical Garden and the College of Idaho (all as Macowanites americanus).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-5cm across, "convex or irregularly lobed but often expanding" when old to flat or even centrally depressed, margin not typically joined to stem but often touching it when young; "color variable: lilac, purplish, vinaceous, olive, blue, yellow, or even whitish, or often mixtures thereof"; "viscid when wet, smooth or often breaking up into scales (especially at center)"^, (Arora), 1-5cm across, hemispheric or convex-flattened to irregular, more rarely almost flat from the start, eventually often expanding to flat with decurved [downcurved] margin, often eccentric, margin acute or sometimes blunt; color variable, pale olive-yellow, pale olive, pink, lilac, lilac-purple, purplish red, blue, sometimes with one color and other times showing various colors in a single group of fruitbodies, often with mixed colors in a single cap, whitish at times when covered by duff; bald, viscid at first, smooth, soon cracking into large flakes (at times so deeply as to expose the spore mass), (Singer), "yellow, olive vinaceous, purplish, or lilac in varying proportions", (Smith)
INNER LAYER  brittle, crisp; white^, (Arora), thin at margin, becoming thicker toward disc where it is 0.1-0.4cm thick, "moderately firm at first, becoming very fragile", (Singer)
INTERIOR  spore mass "consisting of irregular or distorted, often veined or even chambered gills", usually attached to stem; whitish at first but soon becoming ocher to dull yellow-orange^, (Arora), thickness variable, very broad at the cap margin, "or evenly narrow to the columella, or strongly ventricose and then deeply sinuate", or concave below and then adnate to subdecurrent; very fragile, "apparently always at least partly exposed", basically sublamellate [somewhat gill-like] and attached to top of stem-columella, "but very convolute and intervenose", almost alveolate in many fruitbodies, and often some bands of the spore mass extending from the margin of the cap to the stem-columella and decurrent there, "lamellar plates radiating but not regularly so", often bent or forking at various levels and not vertically oriented, "forming some completely closed winding chambers and a majority of broad chambers open toward the lower surface"; at first white, soon more or less deeply ochraceous ("ochraceous buff" Ridgway color) from spores, (Singer), white at first but soon pale to rich ochraceous, (Smith)
STEM  1-3cm x 0.3-1.5cm, "more or less equal, firm, brittle", percurrent [going through spore mass]; white; smooth^, (Arora), 1-3cm x 0.4-1.2cm, usually shorter than the width of the fruitbody, equal or nearly so, solid, soon becoming stuffed and finally partly hollow, percurrent to the thickest part of the peridium [cap]; white; bald, uneven; no basal mycelial tomentum, (Singer)
ODOR  none^ (Singer)
TASTE  mild^ (Singer)
EDIBILITY  said to be edible, but be sure of identification, (Arora)
HABITAT  single to gregarious or clustered "in duff under conifers (sometimes buried)", especially under Picea (spruce), Abies (fir), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), and Pinus (pine), mainly in summer and fall^, (Arora), July to November (Lincoff), underground to above ground on and in deep conifer duff, often in large groups, near and under stands of Abies, Picea, and Pseudotsuga, July to August in Idaho, (Singer)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8.5-13.5 x 8-12 microns, elliptic to round, amyloid warts and ridges^, (Arora), spores 8.7-13.2 x 8.2-11.8 microns, short-elliptic to nearly round, strongly amyloid ornamentation "of warts and short spines connected into (often straight) chains or lines by a sometimes interrupted network of fine lines and occasional short ridges", "projecting 0.5-0.8 microns or rarely up to 1.2 microns", spores distinctly yellowish, "sterigmal appendage eccentrically to subcentrally attached and almost oblique, very rarely almost straight", "plage area with a dark amyloid area of amorphous material which extends to the sterigmal appendage and forms a thin short jacket around its base or up to one fourth to one third the distance toward its apex"; hymenium continuous, basidia mostly 4-spored, rarely 1-spored, 2-spored, or 3-spored, 23-46 x 7-13.5 microns, mostly 23-38 x 10-13 microns, clavate, colorless, sterigmata straight to curved and usually conic; pseudoparaphyses about 22 x 18 microns, thin-walled; pseudocystidia numerous in young specimens (but more scattered when mature), 40-90 x 7-11.5 microns, "ventricose, broadest in the lower, central, or upper third, or rarely ampullaceous with obtusely rounded or more rarely acute attenuated tip, originating in the lower portion of the subhymenium or the outer portion of the mediostratum", content yellow in KOH "and visible as granular to banded loosely distributed material"; subhymenium "well developed, of small cellular or somewhat irregular elements", colorless, "intermixed with hyphous cystidial pedicels" [hyphous presumably meaning hypha-like], hymenopodium poorly differentiated, mostly inconspicuous and sometimes absent; tramal mediostratum "varying from regular to obscurely bilateral" (toward subhymenium often diverging slightly), its elements mostly very strongly inflated, or typically heteromerous [with nests of sphaerocysts among filamentose hyphae]; peridial trama and that of stem and columella typically heteromerous; beneath the peridial epicutis there is a hypodermium similar to that of other Russulas, "consisting of repent filamentous hyphae but differing in containing scattered sphaerocysts"; peridial epicutis "at first consisting of strongly projecting pseudocystidia arranged in a palisade, the elements gradually becoming more decumbent and tangled, subgelatinous as revived in KOH", many primordial hyphae and ordinary filamentous hyphae also present in older fruitbodies (these often dominant), dermatopseudocystidia 25-85 x 4-8 microns, cylindric to clavate, some colorless fusoid dermatocystidia without distinctive content or incrustation also present; hyphae in all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent from all tissue, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'somewhat loculate'
SIMILAR  Macowanites albidigleba has a paler peridium when young, a much paler gleba [spore mass], a slowly slightly peppery taste, and a poorly differentiated hymenopodium, (Singer). Other Macowanites species differ in color, have strong odors, have bitter taste, or differ in spore size, (Lincoff). See also SIMILAR section of Macowanites olidus, Macowanites pinicola, Macowanites pseudoemeticus, and Macowanites subolivaceus.
SOURCES  Arora(1) (as Macowanites americanus), Singer(10) (as Macowanites americanus), Lincoff(2)* (as Macowanites americanus), Miller(14)* (as Macowanites americanus), McKnight(1)* (as Macowanites americanus), Smith(4)* (as Macowanites americanus), Thiers(4) (as Macowanites americanus)
328
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula subochracea  (A.H. Sm.) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 240. 2018;  Gymnomyces subochraceus  (A.H. Sm.) Trappe, T. Lebel & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 201. 2002;  Martellia subochracea  A.H. Sm.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include depressed-spherical to irregular dry fruitbody that is white, slowly becoming cinnamon buff to tawny, spore mass white with irregular minute chambers, slowly flushing cinnamon near peridium, absent columella, and microscopic characters including round spores 7-9(10) microns, with amyloid spines and rods 0.8-1.2 microns high, basidia 2-spored and 4-spored^; described from ID (Smith(24)); common, WA to northern CA and ID, (Trappe(13)), reported for OR to Oregon Truffling Society, J. Smith et al. reported from OR; Paul Kroeger collection from BC deposited at University of British Columbia (as Martellia subochracea)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH on peridium dark tawny, FeSO4 no change^, (Smith(4)), KOH on surface dark tawny, FeSO4 no change, (Smith(24))
OUTER SURFACE  1-4cm across, depressed-spherical to irregular; white slowly flushed cinnamon buff to tawny; dry and unpolished^, (Smith(4)), 1-4cm across, depressed - near spherical or more irregular; white, slowly becoming cinnamon buff and finally tawny; dry, unpolished; "no appressed rhizomorphs visible", (Smith(24))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white, slowly flushed dingy cinnamon^, (Smith(4)), white, "slowly becoming flushed dingy cinnamon near peridium"; with irregular minute chambers, (Smith(24))
STEM  columella absent^, (Smith(4)), "basal attachment present but not pronounced, tapered to a puckered base", "no appressed rhizomorphs visible"; columella absent, (Smith(24))
ODOR  none^ (Smith(24))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection in duff under Abies (fir) in ID, August^, (Smith(24)), mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 (10) microns, round, ornamentation of spines and rods to 1.2 microns high, these isolated or joined by low ridges to form a broken reticulum^; cystidia not observed; cuticle of peridium a weak turf of cystidia 20-36 x 3-7 microns, (Smith(4)), spores 7-9(10) x 7-9(10) microns, round, "amyloid ornamentation in the form of rods and spines 0.8-1.2 microns high", mostly isolated but on some "grouped into rows or fused into short nodulose lines forming a broken reticulum", spore wall inamyloid, plage not differentiated, sterigmal appendage inconspicuous; basidia 2-spored and 4-spored, 27-36 x 10-13 microns, clavate, colorless in KOH, with oily content; cystidia none; subhymenium "cellular and cells greatly enlarged at times to 10-20 microns", central strand of hymenophoral trama of filamentose, interwoven, nongelatinous, colorless hyphae (in KOH), no oleiferous hyphae seen; epicutis of peridium "a weak turf of dermatocystidia 20-36 x 3-7 microns, narrowly fusoid to almost aciculate", colorless to ochraceous in KOH and subcutis ochraceous in KOH; peridial trama colorless to ochraceous in KOH and of tightly interwoven, colorless, nongelatinous to subgelatinous hyphae (revived in KOH); clamp connections absent, (Smith(24))
NAME ORIGIN  'subochraceum' is one of the colors in the Latin description used to describe the peridium
SIMILAR  Gymnomyces brunnescens has larger spores and odor is often sweet, (Smith(24)), Gymnomyces brunnescens is very similar and may be the same species (NATS). See also SIMILAR section of Gymnomyces nondistincta.
SOURCES  Smith(24) (as Martellia subochracea), Smith(4) (as Martellia subochracea), Smith, J.E.(1) (as Gymnomyces subochraceus), NATS(1) (as Gymnomyces subochraceus), Trappe(13) (as Gymnomyces subochraceus), Elliott, T.F.(1)
329
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula subolivacea  (A.H. Sm.) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 240. 2018;  Macowanites subolivaceus  A.H. Sm.  Mycologia 55: 432. 1963
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include a viscid, whitish cap that is soon flushed with olive to grayish olive or yellowish, a somewhat gill-like spore mass that is white becoming yellowish, a thick white stem-columella, a mild odor and taste, growth under conifers, and microscopic characters including round to nearly round spores ornamented with ridges and warts forming the appearance of a badly broken reticulum, basidia that are 4-spored (rarely 2-spored), subclavate hymenial cystidia, and a cap cuticle that is a gelatinous to subgelatinous turf.^ RANGE The holotype was found in ID (Smith(24)). It also occurs in CA (Thiers(4)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 no reaction on cap flesh but vinaceous buff in stem^, (Smith(24))
OUTER SURFACE  2-6cm across, "milk-white when young, soon flushed with olive to grayish olive or yellowish"; viscid, bald^, (Smith(4)), 2-6cm across, convex, the margin connivent to the stem-columella (but not attached) and lobed to very irregular; milk-white when young, but soon flushed with "olive", "olive-yellow" or "grayish olive"; glutinous when fresh, bald, surface cracking into irregular pieces when old, (Smith(24))
INNER LAYER  thin, white, very fragile^, (Smith(24))
INTERIOR  sublamellate [somewhat gill-like]; milk-white becoming yellowish^, (Smith(4)), sublamellate "and anastomosing to produce cavities or pockets", "adnate to apex of columella or practically free (actually seceding and free in many specimens), well exposed by partial expansion of peridium"; milk-white, slowly becoming "ochraceous buff", (Smith(24))
STEM  2-4cm x 1-2cm, stem-columella thick, white^, (Smith(4)), 2-4cm x 1-2cm, fragile; white; bald, naked, (Smith(24))
ODOR  not distinctive^ (Smith(24))
TASTE  mild^ (Smith(24))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type gregarious under spruce, (Smith(24)), under pines and firs in CA, (Thiers(4))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x 7-9 microns, ornamented with ridges and warts not forming a distinct reticulum^, (Smith(4)), spores 7-9 x 7-9 microns, round to nearly round; 'ornamentation of isolated particles, short nodulose crooked lines, some fine "fish bone" lines, and the whole so arranged as to approach in appearance a badly broken up reticulum, major elements 0.4-0.8 microns high, plage area ornamented and often an amorphous mass of amyloid material at base of the inconspicuous sterigmal appendage', wall inamyloid; basidia 4-spored (rarely 2-spored), 28-36 x 10-14 microns, colorless in KOH, thin-walled; macrocystidia 38-52 x 10-14 microns, "subclavate with obtuse to rounded apices, thin-walled", colorless in KOH, "with some refractive particles of various types"; subhymenium cellular, the layer 2-5 cells deep, "entire central portion of hymenophoral trama of greatly inflated cells", thin-walled and colorless in KOH; subcutis of peridium "of appressed interwoven hyphae grading into the heteromerous peridial trama" [trama with nests of sphaerocysts among filamentous hyphae]; epicutis of peridium "a turf of gelatinous branched hyphae and elongated pseudocystidia, the gelatinous elements 3-6 microns wide in the terminal cell, but the 3rd to 4th cell back from the tip often short and enlarged to 6-11 microns", pseudocystidia 60-200 microns long, 3-11 microns wide at apex, "filamentous to clavate", "often decumbent over the gelatinous turf"; clamp connections none, (Smith(24))
NAME ORIGIN  refers to the subolivaceous color of the mature cap
SIMILAR  Russula subloculata tends to be smaller, the color of the cap is different (R. subolivacea consistently pallid to olive), the spore mass is deeper in color (in R. subolivacea paler and only slowly becoming yellowish), and Russula subloculata has larger spores, (Smith(24)).
SOURCES  Smith(24) (as Macowanites subolivaceus) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Smith(4) (as Macowanites subolivaceus), Thiers(4) (as Macowanites subolivaceus), Trappe(13) (as Macowanites subolivaceus), Elliott, T.F.(1)
330
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula subrosacea  (A.H. Sm.) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 240. 2018;  Macowanites subrosaceus  A.H. Sm.  Mycologia 55: 433. 1963
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include 1) a pale dingy rose, subviscid cap that becomes areolate-squamulose with ochraceous stains over the scales and along the margin, 2) a "warm buff" to "ochraceous buff" spore mass that is gill-like with cross veins to produce cavities, 3) a short white stem-columella that stains ochraceous at the base, 4) a mild taste, and 5) microscopic characters including nearly round to broadly elliptic spores with an amyloid ornamentation of granules isolated or in rows or nodulose lines, and short, fat 2-spored and 4-spored basidia.^ The description is derived from Smith(24) except where noted. RANGE The holotype was found in ID (Smith). It also occurs in CA (Thiers).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  no reaction of cap flesh to FeSO4 or KOH
OUTER SURFACE  3.5cm across, convex, "partly expanded to unexpanded"; pale dingy rose with ochraceous stains over the squamules [fine scales] and along the margin; subviscid when moist but soon dry, becoming areolate-squamulose [with cracked mud pattern to finely scaly]
INNER LAYER  thin, fragile; whitish
INTERIOR  spore mass adnate to top of columella but free otherwise, lamellate [gill-like] with cross veins to produce cavities; "warm buff" to "ochraceous buff", not staining when injured
STEM  2cm long, 0.8cm wide, short, white, stained ochraceous at base; unpolished
ODOR  
TASTE  mild
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to scattered under spruce and fir (Smith), under lodgepole pine in CA, (Thiers(4))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-12 x 8-10 microns, nearly round to broadly elliptic, "ornamentation heavily amyloid and consisting of granules isolated and in rows or nodulose lines not united into a reticulum, prominences 0.2-0.5 microns high", "plage area ornamented, usually a dark mass of amorphous amyloid material at base of the sterigmal appendage", spore wall inamyloid^; basidia 2-spored and 4-spored, 30-40 x 15-20 microns (fat and short), clavate, colorless in KOH; macrocystidia scattered, 36-58 x 9-15 microns, "fusoid to clavate-mucronate, with various types of refractive content", colorless in KOH, pseudocystidia 20-35 x 5-8 microns and with bright ochraceous content in KOH; subhymenium cellular, 2-4 microns deep, colorless in KOH, "central strand of hymenophoral trama entirely of large sphaerocysts", colorless in KOH, 'some golden ochraceous "oleiferous" hyphae present'; peridial context 'of heteromerous tissue with rusty brown to ochraceous "oleiferous" hyphae present as revived in KOH'; epicutis of peridium of hyphae 2-4 microns wide, interwoven subgelatinous, ochraceous in KOH, "the endcells not enlarged, at times a short indistinct turf formed by the ends of the elements being ascending to upright and often dark ochraceous to rusty brown in masses", epicuticular and subcuticular regions not sharply differentiated; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  refers to the subrosaceous (somewhat rose-colored) cap
SIMILAR  Russula vilgalysii is similar but R. subrosacea has a dingy rose-colored peridium, exceptionally short fat basidia, a yellow rather than cinnamon-buff spore mass, and a different organization of the peridial epicutis, (Smith). Russula vinicolor has prominent macrocystidia with obtuse to rounded apices, a milk-white spore mass, and higher spore ornamentation, (Smith). Russula piniamans has round spores with rather widely spaced bands of ornamentation and lacks the yellow laticiferous hyphae in the peridial context, (Smith).
SOURCES  Smith(24) (as Macowanites subrosaceus) (colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Thiers(4) (as Macowanites subrosaceus) , Trappe(13) (as Macowanites subrosaceus), Elliott, T.F.(1)
331
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula taetra  Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 234. 2018;  == Gymnomyces foetens  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Trappe, T. Lebel, & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 199. 2002;  == Martellia foetens  Singer & A.H. Smith  Mem. Torrey Bot. Club 21: 36-37. 1960
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include more or less spherical, dull tawny fruitbody that is bald and smooth without rhizomorphs, spore mass pallid at first, staining dull cinnamon around larval tunnels, columella and stem both absent, pungent odor when fresh like Russula foetens, and microscopic characters including round to nearly round spores ornamented with amyloid warts and spines, mostly 4-spored basidia, rare to scattered cystidia, and peridium of repent interwoven hyphae^; when the species was moved to Russula a new epithet was required because of the prior Russula foetens Pers.(1796); type collection from ID (Singer(10)), rare, southwestern WA (Trappe(13)), reported for OR to Oregon Truffling Society
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  KOH causing a yellow stain in fresh spore mass (but not dried), "the pigment dissolving in the medium when mounted on a slide"
OUTER SURFACE  about 3cm across, irregular in outline but roughly spherical; dull tawny drying cinnamon brown; bald, smooth, without rhizomorphs^, (Singer)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  pallid at first, staining dull cinnamon around larval tunnels; loculate [chambered], dry^, (Singer)
STEM  columella and stem absent (no definite point of attachment)^, (Singer)
ODOR  when fresh pungent, reminiscent of Russula foetens^, (Singer), disagreeable, resembling that of Russula foetens (Smith)
TASTE  slightly disagreeable^ (Singer)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), August, (Singer)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-11 x 7-9 microns, round to nearly round, "ornamented with warts and spines sometimes connected to form short ridges, prominences to 1-1.5 microns high"^; cystidia rare to scattered, 30-40 x 3.5-8.2 microns; "cuticle of peridium of repent interwoven hyphae, dark fulvous brown in KOH", (Smith), spores 8-11 x 7-9 microns, round to nearly round, heavily amyloid ornamentation projecting 1-1.5 microns (rarely 2 microns), spinules 1-1.5 microns broad at base, consisting of warts and spinules "closely spaced and some connected to form chains, others fused into an irregular grouping of ridges or crests but the groups essentially unconnected to other groups", spore wall typically less than 1 micron thick, in dilute KOH pale to dingy ochraceous, sterigmal appendage often oblique, relatively inconspicuous (2-3 microns long); basidia 4-spored or occasionally 1-spored, 2-spored, or 3-spored, 27-42 x (6.5)8-12 microns, clavate or nearly so, sterigmata more often straight than curved, vertical to oblique; macrocystidia rare to scattered, 30-40 x 3.5-8.2 microns, "variable in shape, cylindric, clavate, fusoid-ventricose or dumbbell-shaped, smooth and thin-walled", with banded or granular contents or some colorless throughout, yellow, "not conspicuously connected with conducting elements (but occasional oleiferous hyphae present in subhymenium or trama)"; subhymenium a moderately thick layer of subisodiametric cells 8-15 microns in diameter, which at times may enlarge to the size and shape of sphaerocysts (20 microns); tramal mediostratum of hyphae 3-6 microns wide, uninflated, extending in the direction of the tramal plate, interwoven, not or only slightly gelatinizing in 2.5% KOH; peridium about 150 microns, "consisting or a rather uniform layer of tangentially arranged filamentous hyphae which are repent (extending parallel with surface of peridium) but are strongly interwoven, near the surface often strongly colored fulvous brown and with occasional hyphae or cystidioid terminal cells ascending somewhat", "the hyphae slightly gelatinous revived in KOH, inamyloid and without clamp connections", (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  "taetra" means "foul, offensive" (Elliott, T.F.(1))
SIMILAR  Russula ferruginascens (as Gymnomyces ferruginascens) lacks the odor of R. taetra (as Gymnomyces foetens), and has true sphaerocysts in pockets in the tramal plates, (Singer). See also SIMILAR section of Russula nondistincta.
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Martellia foetens), Smith(4) (as Martellia foetans), Trappe(13) (as Gymnomyces foetens), Elliott, T.F.(1)
332
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula unicalifornica  Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 232. 2018;  == Gymnomyces cinnamomeus  Singer & A.H. Sm.  Mem. Torrey bot. Club 21(3): 51. 1960
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include more or less spherical, cinnamon-brown, bald fruitbody with chambered, pale cinnamon brown spore mass, lack of columella or definite point of attachment, underground growth under oak, and microscopic characters including more or less round spores with amyloid ornamentation of spines, warts, and ridges, and basidia that are ochraceous tawny when revived in KOH^; when this species was moved from Gymnomyces to Russula, a new species epithet was required because of the prior name Russula cinnamomea Banning (1881); description derived from Singer(10); rare in western OR and northern CA, (Trappe)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across (dried), spherical to nearly spherical; cinnamon-brown; bald
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  chambered; pale cinnamon-brown
STEM  no columella showing; point of attachment not definite
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type from California underground under Quercus agrifolia (Coast Live Oak)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-12 microns in diameter not including the sterigmal appendage; round to nearly round, ornamentation amyloid and consisting of short spines up to 1 micron high and warts, "the amyloid reaction limited mostly to the upper half of the spines and warts, some weakly amyloid ridges and connecting lines also present and often forming half crests or half circles", varying "from true broad cones to crests or half-circles" and some spores predominantly showing the latter, sterigmal appendage oblique and projecting about 3 microns, pointed^; basidia 4-spored, 38-55 x 10-13 microns, clavate, ochraceous to tawny as revived in KOH; cystidia not seen; pseudoparaphyses present, clavate to vesiculose; subhymenium cellular, cells about the same diameter as base of basidium; mediostratum of tramal plate heteromerous and some oleiferous hyphae present; peridium with a thick outer layer of interwoven filaments, 3-10 microns wide, subgelatinous, colorless, spherocysts "present in a thin poorly defined inner layer"; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  contraction of 'University of California', the site of the type collection, (Elliott(1))
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Gymnomyces cinnamomeus), Trappe(13) (as Gymnomyces cinnamomeus), Elliott, T.F.(1)
333
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula variabilispora  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^, in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 240. 2018;  Cystangium variabilisporum  (Singer & A.H. Sm.)  Trappe, T. Lebel, & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 198. 2002;  Martellia variabilispora  (Zeller) Singer & A.H. Sm.  Mem. Torrey bot. Club 21(3): 27 (1961) [1960]
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include white nearly spherical fruitbodies, with spore mass white at first, no sterile base or columella and microscopic characters including broadly elliptic to nearly round spores with amyloid or partly amyloid ornamentation in the form of warts, spines, ridges, crescents, or irregular knotty lines, 1-spored basidia, and peridium epicutis a cellular zone 4-6 cells deep, giving rise to club-shaped end cells at the surface^, found at least OR
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1.5cm across (dried), nearly spherical; pure white, drying alutaceous^, (Singer)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  white at first, drying cinnamon buff; center of fruitbody hollow^, (Singer) 
STEM  no sterile base, no columella^, (Singer)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under conifers, October^, (Singer)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 11-14 x 9.5-12 microns, ornamentation a mixture of ridges, warts and spines, 0.7-1.5 microns high^; cuticle of peridium a cellular zone 4-6 cells deep, giving rise to club-shaped end cells at the surface, (Smith), spores 11-14 x 9.5-12 microns, broadly elliptic to nearly round, "ornamentation strongly amyloid, or on larger elements strongly amyloid only at the tip, prominences 0.7-1.5 microns high, in the form of warts and small spines", the elements isolated to grouped into ridges, crescents, or irregular knotty short lines, "all types usually present on a single spore", "very closely arranged but the pale yellowish spore wall visible between elements or groups of elements", "sterigmal appendage inconspicuous or up to 2.5 microns long, usually with an amyloid basal jacket", "plage area not distinctive"; basidia 1-spored, 24-32 x 9-11 microns, clavate, thin-walled, colorless in KOH, basidioles numerous; pseudoparaphyses 10-15 microns wide, "clavate, scarcely distinct from basidioles"; cystidia not observed "but basidia with sterigmata beginning to form remind one of mucronate leptocystidia"; subhymenium cellular and when old the cells enlarged and sphaerocyst-like, colorless, thin-walled; tramal mediostratum of interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, smooth filaments, not gelatinous in KOH, no sphaerocysts and no oleiferous hyphae present; peridial context (subcutis) of filaments 3-5 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, nongelatinous, and lacking incrustations, no sphaerocysts and no oleiferous hyphae; peridial epicutis a cellular layer 4-6 cells deep of colorless, "smooth-walled hyphal cells, some clavate end-cells projecting from surface"; clamp connections none, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with variable spores' 
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Martellia variabilisporum), Smith(4) (as Martellia variabilispora), Elliott, T.F.(1)
334
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula vilgalysii  Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 234. 2018;  == Macowanites fulvescens  Singer & A.H. Sm.  Mem. Torrey Bot. Club 21: 84. 1960
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include 1) a whitish cap with areolate cracks that become pale dingy tan to tawny, 2) an enclosed spore mass that is pale buff, with irregular cavities more or less radiating from the columella, 3) stem absent in type collection, 4) mild odor and taste, 5) growth under spruce and fir, and 6) microscopic characters including elliptic spores with ornamentation in the form of a partial or broken reticulum connecting low cones, 2-spored and 4-spored basidia, and a cap cuticle that is a turf of pseudocystidia and hyphal ends, with contents ochraceous as revived in KOH.^ When Macowanites fulvescens was moved to Russula, a new species epithet was chosen because of the prior name Russula fulvescens Burl. (1915). RANGE The holotype was collected in ID. Paul Kroeger collection from BC deposited at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2-3cm across, whitish; smooth becoming areolate [cracked like dried mud], the areolae becoming clay-color to tawny^, (Smith(4)), 2-3cm across, spherical; surface at first continuous and whitish, later breaking up into areolate patches that stain clay color to tawny exposing the white flesh underneath, (Singer)
INNER LAYER  flesh of cap thin, white^, (Singer)
INTERIOR  spore mass pale buff; chambered, enclosed in peridium [outer skin]^, (Smith(4)), about 1cm thick at thickest point, "attached all along the columella down to the base where the lower edge of the peridium is intergrown with the tissue of the columella", the spore mass not exposed at any time, "consisting of cavities more or less radiating from the columella toward the peridium" but chambers irregular in shape; slightly paler than "cinnamon-buff" (buff-colored)
STEM  columella not continued into a stem in some specimens, 0.4cm wide^, (Smith(4)), columella 0.4cm wide, in the type collection not continued into a stem (but stem might be expected in other collections), percurrent [going through spore mass], whitish, becoming cinnamon-buff when cut, (Singer)
ODOR  not distinctive^ (Singer)
TASTE  not distinctive^ (Singer)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Picea (spruce) and Abies (fir), summer^, (Smith(4)), under Picea and Abies, August, (Singer)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9.5-15.2 x 7-11.8 microns, elliptic, ornamentation in form of broken to partial reticulum^; hymenial pseudocystidia 63-110 x 13-18 microns; leptocystidia 48-64 x 18-24 microns; cap cuticle "a turf of pseudocystidia and hyphal ends, contents ochraceous as revived in KOH", (Smith(4)), spores 9.5-15.2 x 7-11.8 microns, broadly elliptic, "ornamentation projecting 0.2-0.8 microns, mostly 0.4-0.5 microns, of low almost wart-like cones which are more or less crowded into shorter or longer chains or short crests, and are usually connected by very fine amyloid lines or tail-like extensions to form a partial or broken reticulum", spores pale yellow in dilute bases; sterigmal appendage eccentric and oblique, "plage area ornamented and often showing a diffuse amyloid spot or area"; hymenium continuous, basidia 2-spored and 4-spored, 35-50 x 11-16 microns, clavate or ventricose, "sterigmata variable, straight or half-sickle-shaped"; pseudoparaphyses rather numerous, vesiculose; pseudocystidia rather numerous, 63-110 x 13-18 microns, "mostly clavate-mucronate or apex merely obtuse to subacute"; leptocystidia 48-64 x 18-24 microns, with protoplasmic content, clavate-mucronate, thin-walled, readily collapsing (perhaps only an empty variant of the pseudocystidia); subhymenium "broad, consisting of small and large sphaerocysts and a few elongated narrow elements", hymenopodium "poorly developed, intermittent, filamentous"; tramal mediostratum heteromerous [with nests of sphaerocysts among filamentous hyphae]; peridial trama heteromerous; peridial epicutis "consisting of a differentiated turf of dermatopseudocystidia and hyphal ends which are often irregular in outline or forked, not gelatinized, not originating from a hypodermal layer", tending to become fulvous; hyphae inamyloid; clamp connections none, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  "In honor of Dr. Rytas Vilgalys for his research and teaching of all aspects of mycology." (Elliott, T.F.(1))
SIMILAR  Russula chlorineolens [as Macowanites chlorinosmus] has a faint to strong odor of chlorine and smaller spores, (Smith(24)). Russula piniamans [as Macowanites pinicola] has round spores with rather widely spaced bands of ornamentation and lacks yellow laticiferous hyphae in the peridial context, (Smith(24)). Russula subrosacea [as Macowanites subrosaceus] has a dingy rose colored peridium, short fat basidia, a yellow rather than cinnamon buff spore mass, and a different peridial epicutis, (Smith(24)).
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Macowanites fulvescens) (color in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Smith(4) (as Macowanites fulvescens), Smith(24) (as Macowanites fulvescens), Trappe(13) (as Macowanites fulvescens), Elliott, T.F.(1)
335
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula vinicolor  (A.H. Sm.) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 240. 2018;  Macowanites vinicolor  A.H. Sm.  Mycologia 55: 434. 1963
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include a viscid cap that is dingy vinaceous red, white flesh, a somewhat gill-like to chambered white spore mass that stains slowly cinnamon-buff when injured, a white stem-columella that stains rusty where injured, a mild odor and taste, and microscopic characters including elliptic to nearly round spores with amyloid ornamentation in the form of a broken reticulum or separate granules and crests, 4-spored (rarely 2-spored) basidia, and prominent hymenial cystidia.^ The description is derived from Smith(24). RANGE The holotype was found in ID.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, broadly convex to flat; "dingy vinaceous red over disc, paler vinaceous along margin, in some a slight olive shade pervading the disc, with ochraceous stains along margin where in contact with debris"; viscid, bald
INNER LAYER  white
INTERIOR  spore mass attached to top of columella, sublamellate [somewhat gill-like] to lacunose [chambered]; white, where injured slowly stained cinnamon-buff
STEM  1-1.5cm x 0.8-1.2cm, equal; "white, staining rusty where injured"
ODOR  none
TASTE  mild
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single under conifers
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-13 x 7.5-10 microns, elliptic to nearly round, "ornamentation in the form of short branched lines to make a more or less broken reticulum", or of separate granules and cristae [crests], "many of the granules closely arranged in rows or fused to form lumpy lines, prominences 0.3-0.8 microns high", "plage area with closely packed ornamentation giving a diffusely amyloid effect", sterigmal appendage inconspicuous, wall inamyloid^; basidia 4-spored, rarely 2-spored, 28-37 x 9-13 microns, clavate, colorless in KOH, thin-walled; macrocystidia abundant and projecting prominently, 56-80 x 10-17 microns, "mostly subfusoid to clavate with obtuse apices (none with a mucro seen), content refringent with amorphous material variously distributed", colorless in KOH, "thin-walled and readily collapsing"; subhymenium cellular, 2-3 cells deep, colorless in KOH, central strand of hymenophoral trama with sphaerocysts, "but some filamentous hyphae also present"; peridial trama heteromerous [with nests of sphaerocysts among filamentous hyphae]; subcutis a thick layer of interwoven, nongelatinous, filamentous hyphae; epicutis of peridium a turf 40-60 microns deep, of hyphae 3-6 microns wide, colorless, "and end-cells not appreciably differentiated, with a gelatinous layer 25-50 microns deep above this, which is penetrated by long pseudocystidia" with refringent granular content, pseudocystidial hyphae up to 200 microns long, and 4-8 microns wide, narrowly clavate at apex; no yellow laticiferous hyphae seen in KOH mounts; clamp connections absent
NAME ORIGIN  means 'wine-colored'
SIMILAR  Russula subrosacea is similar but R. vinicolor differs in having prominent macrocystidia with obtuse to rounded apices, a milk-white spore mass, and higher spore ornamentation, (Smith).
SOURCES  Smith(24) (as Macowanites vinicolor), Trappe(13) (as Macowanites vinicolor), Elliott, T.F.(1)
336
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Russula zelleriana  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Trappe & T.F. Elliott^  in Elliott & Trappe, Fungal Systematics and Evolution 1: 241. 2018;  Macowanites zellerianus  (Singer & A.H. Sm.)  Trappe, T. Lebel & Castellano  Mycotaxon 81: 203. 2002;  Elasmomyces zellerianus  Singer & A.H. Sm.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled category. Features include a yellowish white. pruinose cap with a light ochraceous chambered spore mass, a short stem, and microscopic characters including large nearly round spores with amyloid ornamentation, 2-spored basidia, and a cap cuticle that is a turf of versiform elements arising from a zone of periclinal hyphae.^ The description is derived from Singer(10). RANGE Russula zellerianus has been found at least WA and probably OR (Singer).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1.5-2.5cm across, depressed-spherical, with undulate [wavy] margin; yellowish white; pruinose; peridium 0.02cm thick^, (Singer)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  light ochraceous, drying tawny-olive to wood-brown; with large empty chambers and thin (0.01cm) tramal plates^, (Singer)
STEM  stem-columella short, thick in stem part, percurrent in columella part [going through to cap surface]^, (Singer)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  emergent under conifers, October^ (Singer)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 13-16.2 x 12.6-14 microns, nearly round, spore ornamentation 1-2 microns high^; cap cuticle a turf of versiform elements arising from a zone of periclinal hyphae, (Smith), spores 13-16.2 x 12.6-14 microns, nearly round, many yellowish and many colorless (in KOH), amyloid ornamentation long-spinose "with isolated spines 1.5-2.5 microns, completely covered with amylaceous material, sterigmal appendage oblique"; basidia 2-spored, 31-38 x 12-15 microns, clavate, colorless, sterigmata almost half-sickle-shaped in most basidia; cystidia not seen with certainty; subhymenium very extensive and mainly cellular, consisting of a thick layer of large sphaerocysts and a few elongated hyphal elements, colorless; tramal mediostratum relatively narrow, slightly gelatinized, somewhat regular in arrangement, "consisting of filamentous elements or occasionally very slightly enlarged hyphal elements but sphaerocysts not seen"; peridial trama "consisting of hyphae extending in all directions with some air spaces between (loosely woven), slightly gelatinous", colorless, "covered by an epicutis-like outer layer that is very thin and consists of hyphal ends which are usually periclinal in their arrangement and their terminal members are sometimes cystidioid, these dermatocystidia versiform" (cylindric-capitate, ampullaceous etc.), dermatopseudocystidia of the macrocystidium type also in the epicutis, about 54 x 9 microns, "with some loosely banded contents, long-clavate", primordial hyphae also present, granularly incrusted; laticifers none seen; oleiferous vessels not very prominent; hyphae of all tissues inamyloid; clamp connections absent from all tissues, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  referring to Zeller who identified the type incorrectly as Elasmomyces mattirolanus
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Elasmomyces zellerianus), Smith(4) (as Elasmomyces zellerianus), Trappe(13) (as Macowanites zellerianus), Elliott, T.F.(1)
337
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Sarcosphaera coronaria  (Jacq. ex Cooke) Boud.^  Icones Mycologicae (Paris): pl. 302. 1893;  Sarcosphaera crassa  (Santi) Pouzar;  Sarcosphaera eximia  (Durieu & Lev.) Maire;  Sarcosphaera dargelasii  (Gachel) Nannf.
ENGLISH NAMES  violet star cup, pink crown, crown fungus
NOTES  Also listed in Cups category. Features include 1) hollow spherical fruitbodies developing at or below ground level, 2) the outer layer splitting from above into 6-10 rays, revealing the interior that is whitish to grayish then pinkish to purplish, 3) the exterior whitish roughened and dirt-encrusted, and 4) sometimes a short stem-like base.^ RANGE Sarcosphaera coronaria is found at least in BC, WA, OR, ID, and also AB, AZ, CA, CO, NM, UT, (Larson). It also occurs in MI, NY, (Lincoff(2)), Switzerland (Breitenbach), United Kingdom (Dennis), Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen). See a note on p.17 Pfister(5) concerning the authority.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  at first a spherical to flattened or lobed ball 3-10cm across, usually with soft spot or slight depression at top, the wall splitting downward from this spot to form pointed segments or rays (usually 6-10) that open up part way to form deep cup, 5-20cm across; whitish to creamy; scurfy or rough, usually dirt-incrusted^, (Arora), 3-10(20)cm across, when young forming a hollow ball, embedded in ground, then opening at top to form a rounded hole with margin that later splits to form star-shape; whitish to gray-white, (Breitenbach), grayish white with violaceous tinge, (Hansen)
INNER LAYER  rather thick but brittle; whitish^, (Arora)
INTERIOR  inner (upper) surface "usually whitish to grayish at first, but becoming grayish-pink to pinkish, lilac, purple, or purple-brown in age", smooth or breaking into fine scales^, (Arora), inner surface pale violet when young, then violet to brown-violet, smooth, (Breitenbach)
STEM  usually but not always present as a short thick narrowed base up to 3cm long^, (Arora), without stem (Breitenbach)
ODOR  none in particular^ (Lincoff(1))
TASTE  none in particular^ (Lincoff(1))
EDIBILITY  not recommended: a few people are adversely affected by it, (Arora), edible cooked, but indigestible for some, poisonous raw, (Lincoff(1))
HABITAT  single to gregarious in clusters of 2-5, developing at or below ground level, but usually exposed or partly exposed when mature, common under western conifers, found in spring but also summer and fall^, (Arora), single or clustered in hardwood and coniferous forest, park grounds, path borders, ground, street gravel, needle litter, (Breitenbach), February to July, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores "14-22 x 7-9 microns, elliptic with blunt or truncate ends, smooth or very slightly roughened, with 1-3 (usually 2) oil droplets"^, (Arora), spores 13.5-18 x 7-8.5 microns, broadly elliptic with blunt ends, smooth, colorless, with 2 oil droplets; asci 8-spored, 300-360 x 10-13 microns, positive reaction to iodine; paraphyses cylindric, septate, some forked at base, tips with slight clavate widening to 5-6(7) microns, (Breitenbach), spores 15-22 x 7-9 microns, smooth to minutely verrucose, (Castellano), spores 15-16.5 x 8-10 microns, verruculose under oil immersion; asci cylindric, (Hansen), spores 13-15 x 7-8 microns, broadly elliptic with rather abruptly truncated ends, colorless, with 2 oil drops; asci about 300-360 x 12-13 microns, stained blue at tip by iodine; paraphyses septate constricted at septa, often once or twice branched in upper part, "the apical cell up to 7 microns wide, with brownish sap", (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to a crown'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Arora(1)* (as Sarcosphaera crassa), Breitenbach(1)* (as Sarcosphaera crassa), Castellano(2)*, Phillips(1)* (as Sarcosphaera crassa), Ammirati(1)* (as Sarcosphaera crassa), Lincoff(2)* (as Sarcosphaera crassa), Lincoff(1)* (as Sarcosphaera crassa), Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)* (as Sarcosphaera crassa), Courtecuisse(1)* (as Sarcosphaera crassa), McKnight(1)* (as Sarcosphaera crassa), Dennis(1) (as Sarcosphaera crassa), Hansen, L.(1), Larsen(1), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Pfister(5)
338
FAMILY  Geastraceae, Order Geastrales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Schenella pityophilus  (Malencon & Riousset) Estrada & Lado^  Mycologia 97(1): 147. 2005;  Pyrenogaster pityophilus  Malencon & Riousset  Bull. Soc. mycol. Fr. 93. 1977
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include a fruitbody that is spherical or nearly so, white then pinkish when exposed, felty on the surface, with three layers in cross-section: a central capitate columella, a radiating brown pattern of peridioles that contain the spores, and a thick, lighter-colored peridium.^ It is common among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Schenella pityophilus is found in southwestern OR and northern CO, Mexico, and France, (Trappe(13)). It is found from southwest OR and CA to Mexico, and also in France, (Trappe, M.).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1.8-2.5cm across, spherical to ellipsoid; white then pinkish when exposed; surface dry, cottony, felted with a layer of separable membranous mycelium, with concolorous or yellowish rhizomorphs; exoperidium double, white or pink, filamentous-leathery on the surface (cortex), fleshy-cellular deeper (endostratum), 0.12-0.15cm thick, white or pinkish in section, (Malencon), spherical to nearly spherical; bruising pink; surface felty, (Trappe, M(1)., who illustrate the fruitbody with a cross-section showing about 40% of the radius is capitate columella, 40% gleba, and 20% peridium)
INNER LAYER  endoperidium also double soft, membranous, cream-ocher or light clay color, somewhat adnate [attached] or easily separable at maturity; dehiscence irregular, apical, may be star-like, (Malencon)
INTERIOR  "with a central, capitate columella from which radiate brown, elongated peridioles that contain the spores; the peridioles are easily teased apart", (Trappe, M.(1)), pseudocolumella basal, robust, white, rounded, dispersing ('diffluente') at maturity, arising from an invagination of the peridium; gleba divided into 150-200 peridioles that are hard, black, conic or narrowly pyramidal, 0.3cm x 0.15cm, radiating around the top of the pseudocolumella, empty then filled with spores and disintegrating when old, (Malencon)
STEM  
ODOR  mild (Trappe, M.(1))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground, buried in dead needle litter, in sandy soil, under Pinus (pine), March to May, (Malencon), with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Pinus (pine), and Quercus (oak) "in dry, lowland forests and woodlands", December to June, (Trappe, M.(1)), probably saprotrophic (Trappe(13))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-8 x 4-7 microns, finely warty, brown, (Trappe, M.(1)), spores 5-7 x 5 microns, round or broadly elliptic, verrucose with large, rounded or flattened warts, spores colorless or pale ocher then dark brown, black in mass, and powdery at maturity^; basidia 2-8-spored (most often 3-5-spored), 35-40 x 3-4 microns, cylindric, proliferating for the most part into thread-like epibasidia 1-1.5 microns wide, and reaching 150 microns long; capillitium particular to each peridiole, of subhymenial origin, of long brown filaments 1500-2000 x 2-6 microns, straight or sinuous, smooth, moderately thick-walled (1 micron), showing rare perforations here and there, not branching or septate, but generally spurred or appendiculate at the base, (Malencon)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Compare with Geatrum spp. formerly in Radiigera and with Schenella simplex.
SOURCES  Malencon(1) (in French, as Pyrenogaster), Trappe, M.(1) (as Pyrenogaster)*, Trappe, M.(3) (as Pyrenogaster)*, Trappe(13)*
339
FAMILY  Geastraceae, Order Geastrales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Schenella simplex  T. Macbr.^  Mycologia 3(1): 39. 1911;  Pyrenogaster atrogleba  (Zeller) L.S. Dominguez & Castellano  Mycologia 88(5)  866. 1996;  Radiigera atrogleba  Zeller
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to slightly flattened or depressed fruiting body often imbedded in white rhizomorphs, the rough outer surface whitish to grayish, often developing buff, pinkish, vinaceous, or brownish tints when old, 2) a peridium with a thin outer separable mycelial part and a thicker (0.3-0.5cm) inner part that is microscopically multilayered, 3) a spore mass that is white and soft, becoming sticky and blackish with a radial pattern, and finally black-powdery, 4) a conspicuous rounded columella in the middle of the spore mass, 5) clustered growth in soil or duff in woods (especially along roads in woods), and 6) microscopic characters including elliptic spores 5.6-7 x 4.2-5.5 microns, filiform 6-8-spored basidia, and specific peridial and glebal structures.^ Schenella simplex was originally thought to be a slime mold, but the name received priority when Radiigera atrogleba, described as a truffle, was later found to be the same species. In Schenella, dispersal by animals eating the fungus is supplemented by the development of spore-containing peridioles (radial sections of the spore mass) coated with a sticky substance, and in at least one species of the genus this enables parts of the spore mass to stick to the animal. It is abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Schenella simplex is found from BC to northern CA, ID, and CO, (Trappe(13)). Collections were examined from BC, WA, OR, ID, CA, CO, and UT, and it is also known from MT and Mexico, (Dominguez).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2.5-5cm broad, spherical to slightly flattened or depressed, "often imbedded in white mycelial threads (rhizomorphs)", peridium (skin) 3-layered, outer surface "tough and felty or fibrous-cottony, rough, white to grayish", often developing buff, pinkish, vinaceous, or brownish tints when old, "usually separating readily from the two inner layers"; inner two layers "closely adhering to each other, whitish to rosy or pinkish when fresh (but may turn olive or buff when bruised)", 0.3-0.5cm thick, "white when sectioned (or with a greenish tinge)"^, (Arora), 1-4cm across, spherical to nearly spherical; felty to cottony with adherent soil debris, outermost layer 0.02-0.05cm thick, yellow white to light yellow brown with some light pink hues, the layer underneath often exposed at maturity; endoperidium to 0.42cm thick, two-layered, the inner layer of 2 intergrading strata, tough, hard when dried, waxy to cartilaginous when rehydrated, (Dominguez), endoperidium of two layers, the outer about 0.1cm thick, the inner 0.3-0.4cm thick, (Smith(15) quoting Zeller)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "white, fleshy, and rather soft at first, becoming gooey or inky and blackish, and eventually powdery (and blackish)", (Arora), black at maturity, capillitium attached between peridium and columella, radial pattern apparent, (Dominguez)
STEM  "absent, but the basal portion of the peridium usually thickened slightly and giving rise to a prominent columella which is nearly round, cushion-shaped, or narrowed at base and enlarged (rounded) at the apex; columella usually 0.8cm thick or more at widest portion, usually penetrating the spore mass at least halfway (never percurrent); white or tinged gray, sometimes disintegrating in old age"^, (Arora), columella present (Dominguez)
ODOR  often rather unpleasant in the inky stage (Arora), metallic, resembling that of actual ink, (Smith(15) quoting Gruber)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  unknown (Arora), not edible (Smith(15))
HABITAT  single "or more often in groups or large, mycelium-incrusted clusters in soil or duff in woods and along old roads through the woods, usually buried or only partially exposed", mainly with conifers in summer or fall^, (Arora), usually gregarious, under conifers, May to November, most often August through October, (Dominguez), in closely connected, almost ingrown, clusters of 15-30, deep in the soil with only a few visible, (Smith(15) quoting Gruber), probably saprotrophic (Trappe(13))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5.5-6.5 microns, round, minutely warted, deep brown under microscope^; interior "composed of plate-like bundles of hyphae which radiate from the columella to the peridium", (Arora), spores 5.6-7.0 x 4.2-5.5 microns, elliptic to rarely round in front and side view, round in polar view, finely verrucose, basal scar present, with apiculus; basidia 6-8-spored, to 28 x 1.5-2.5 microns, tubulose to filiform, with epibasidial part bearing short sterigmata (1 micron); gleba with long radiating locules when immature that form well-developed to poorly developed peridioles (radial sections containing spores and capillitial threads) at maturity; trama plate hyphae up to 1.5-2 microns wide, thin-walled; capillitium shiny, dark reddish brown, smooth, up to 7 microns diameter, attached to peridium and columella, persisting as tubes at maturity; columella of hyphae 2-5 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, "thin-walled, septate, clamped"; peridium 2-layered, to 4200 microns thick, a thin mycelial layer and a pseudoparenchymal layer, itself with 2 intergrading strata (and the thin outermost stratum itself with 2 zones): 1) the mycelial outer layer of the peridium is 175-200 microns thick, composed of hyphae 0.5-1 microns wide, entangled, flexuous [wavy], nonseptate, nonbranching, colorless, intermingled with soil debris, 2) the outer pseudoparenchymatous stratum is 42-100 microns thick, with an outer zone plectenchymatic lacking structure at maturity and inner zone of hyphae 2-4 microns wide, colorless, thin-walled, clamped, not reacting with cotton blue in lactic acid, and intermingled with conductive hyphae that are 2 microns wide, and react positively with cotton blue in lactic acid, the inner pseudoparenchymatous stratum is 2000-4200 microns thick, composed of thin-walled, colorless, inflated cells up to 60 microns in diameter, near the gleba the cells compressed and appearing almost flat, (a third stratum also sometimes present, "dark brown, undifferentiated, to 15 microns thick near the peridium, with attached capillitial threads"), (Dominguez), basidia 4-many spored (Smith(15) quoting Zeller)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with black gleba', 'gleba' refers to the spores and supporting structures and comes from Latin for 'clod, lump'
SIMILAR  Geastrum taylorii is smaller with a smoother brownish to drab exterior, and a paler brown spore mass. Geastrum fuscogleba has an olive-brown to brown mature spore mass and spiny spores. Compare also with Geastrum bushnellii and Schenella pityophilus.
SOURCES  Dominguez(1) (as Pyrenogaster atrogleba), Arora(1)* (as Radiigera atrogleba), Smith(15) (as Radiigera atrogleba), Smith(4) (as Radiigera atrogleba), Trappe(13)
340
FAMILY  Sclerodermataceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Scleroderma hypogaeum  Zeller^  Mycologia 14(4): 193. 1922;  Scleroderma arenicola  Zeller
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Also listed in Puffballs category with other Scleroderma species. Features include 1) the size and ornamentation of the spores (an important differentiating character), 2) underground or somewhat underground growth, 3) shape spherical to somewhat pear-shaped, at times with irregular lobules, 4) color whitish to yellowish or yellowish brown, staining with injury iodine yellow or dark reddish, 5) surface smooth or lightly cracked at top, with poorly defined scales, 6) flesh up to 0.3cm when dried, staining reddish like surface, 7) dehiscence [opening] not observed much, opening by irregular tearing at top, also deliquescing, 8) spore mass white becoming olive-gray, blackish violet, or dark purple-chocolate, with inconspicuous whitish to yellowish threads, 9) somewhat downward projecting base with white rhizomorphs, 10) rubbery to farinaceous odor and taste, and 11) growth in coniferous woods, occasionally in sand, or under lawn sod.^ Guzman includes S. arenicola Zeller as a synonym but notes that S. arenicola Zeller sensu Smith 1951 is S. michiganense (Guzman) Guzman. It is common among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest. RANGE Scleroderma hypogaeum is found from southern WA to southern CA, (Trappe(13)). Collections were examined from BC, WA, OR, ID, CA, CO, MT, and Mexico, (Guzman).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  (1)2-4(6)cm across, spherical to somewhat pear-shaped, at times irregularly lobulate; surface whitish to yellowish or yellowish brown, staining frequently and irregularly iodine yellow or dark reddish; peridium [covering] smooth or lightly cracked in the apical part, with poorly defined scales; flesh of peridium 0.1-0.3cm thick when dried, corky when fresh to woody and profusely alveolate (like the medulla of bone) when dried, whitish to yellowish brown, yellowish in the base, staining reddish like the surface when injured; dehiscence little observed, happening by an irregular tearing of the apical part of the fruitbody^, (Guzman), (1)2-4(6)cm across; dark yellow; smooth; peridium 0.4cm thick, opens by irregular pore at top, (Ramsey), 1-7cm, nearly spherical to irregular, "firm but pithy when young", deliquescent when old, "light buff to pale ochraceous-buff or even avellaneous, becoming bay to almost black when beginning to deliquesce", bald or with innate-appressed fibrils; peridium reaching 0.3cm thick, compact, colorless, (Zeller)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  when young fleshy, alveolate and white, when mature powdery and olive-gray, blackish violet, or dark purple-chocolate; with filaments that are whitish or yellowish and not very conspicuous^, (Guzman), violet with yellow threads (Ramsey), at first white, then yellowish, turning purplish umber when mature (drying black where cut), (Zeller)
STEM  sessile or with a short and poorly defined rhizomorphic prolongation^, (Guzman), base ranges from sessile to occasionally extended, (Ramsey), mycelium "of white rhizomorphs attached to the somewhat downward projecting sterile base", (Zeller)
ODOR  when fresh strongly rubbery, but when dried mild or sometimes disagreeable, (Guzman), farinaceous when young, but becoming strongly alkaline when deliquescing, (Zeller)
TASTE  when fresh strongly rubbery, but when dried mild or sometimes disagreeable, (Guzman), farinaceous when young (Zeller)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  hypogeous or subhypogeous [underground or somewhat underground], occasionally in sand, growing gregariously, in coniferous woods^, (Guzman), gregarious in conifer woods only, (Ramsey), in clay soil under lawn sod (Zeller), mycorrhizal hosts in the Pacific Northwest trees in Pinaceae (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (15)18-23(25.5) x (15)18-23(25.5) microns including spines, strongly spiny and reticulate, the spines curved or with T-shape, ornamentation 1.5-4 microns high, reddish brown in Melzer's reagent, yellowish brown or dark brown in KOH; when immature the spores are smooth, oval, 8-16 microns in diameter and brown^, (Guzman), spores 11-25 x 11-25 microns, average 14 microns, nearly round, alveolate-reticulate, dark purplish umber; basidia 10-13 x 8-10 microns, pyriform to subglobose, colorless, usually 4-spored, (Zeller), spores 17-20, with spines less than 1 microns long, (Sims)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'underground'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Guzman(3), Zeller(2), Ramsey(3), Sims(1), Trappe(13)*
341
FAMILY  Sclerogastraceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Sclerogaster pacificus  Zeller & C.W. Dodge^  Ann. Mo. Bot. Gard. 22: 370. 1935
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include nearly spherical, dirty white fruitbody with peridium that tends to disappear, spore mass that is firm and finally friable, colored ochraceous buff, the cavities polyhedral and filled with spores, sterile base present but columella not seen, and microscopic characters including round spores 7-8 microns in diameter with very large verrucae, 9-10 per great circle^; rare, southern BC, coastal OR, (Trappe(13)), collection examined from OR (Zeller)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.8-1cm across (dried), nearly spherical; dirty white; peridium evanescent [disappearing]^, (Dodge)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  firm, finally friable; ochraceous buff; "cavities polyhedral, filled with spores"^, (Dodge)
STEM  sterile base present; columella not seen^, (Dodge)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-8 microns, round, with very large verrucae, 9-10 per great circle^; basidia clavate, soon collapsing and evanescent; "septa of loosely woven, slender hyphae in a gel, thin, 20-30 microns thick"; peridium about 100 microns thick, pseudoparenchymatous, cells up to 200 x 30 microns, very thin-walled, (Dodge)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to the Pacific Ocean
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Dodge(1), Zeller(11), Trappe(13)
342
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Sedecula pulvinata  Zeller^  Mycologia 33: 213. 1941
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Sedecula pulvinata is characterized by 1) a cushion-shaped fruitbody, 2) a black, chambered spore mass with white to gray trama, the spore mass powdery at maturity, 3) coarse, black cord-like rhizoids extending from the spore mass in the basal region, 4) growth in association with roots of conifers above 2000m altitude, and 5) microscopic characters including large, brown, ellipsoid to irregular spores and 2-spored basidia.^ Trappe, M.(5) present evidence that it belongs in the family Coniophoraceae. It is rare among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Sedecula pulvinata is found in ID, northern CA, and CO, (Trappe(13)). It is found also in AZ (States).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  up to 6cm across and up to 4cm tall, pulvinate [cushion-shaped]; white to gray; "smooth to granular with adherent soil"; peridium tough, leathery, 0.2-0.3cm thick in upper part, thin and almost evanescent in lower part, "margin of thicker peridium usually somewhat rolled under so as sometimes to elevate the basal or under side"^, (Castellano), 2-6cm across, 1-3cm high, pulvinate; white to grayish; smooth to granular; peridium tough, leathery, 0.2-0.3cm thick in upper part, thin and almost evanescent [disappearing] in lower part, "margin of thicker peridium usually somewhat rolled under so as sometimes to elevate the basal or under side having the thinner peridial cover", (Zeller), 4-9cm across, "usually ovoid to ellipsoid to pulvinate"; "whitish to pale olive-buff, sometimes with slight yellowish tints when young and fresh", darkening to gray or blackish when old, "not changing color when bruised or exposed"; dry, dull, somewhat bald when young, often appearing tomentose to fibrillose when old, characteristically appearing lacunose and pitted or split when old; peridium 0.2-0.3cm thick, (Thiers)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  coarsely loculate [chambered], black except for the white to gray trama becoming powdery at maturity, locules labyrinthine, 0.1-1.2 x 0.1-0.3cm, lined with powdery spores^, (Castellano), "black except for the whitish partitions (plates), becoming powdery at maturity"; "larger partitions of the gleba (plates) extend centripetally to unequal depths toward the base and center from the peridium with which they have unbroken connection and the same structure", (Zeller), black becoming somewhat powdery when mature; cord-like cartilaginous veins ramifying throughout and remaining intact during all stages, veins compactly and closely interwoven in upper part becoming loosely interwoven to free in the basal part "and extending beyond the peridium as coarse rhizoids", (Thiers), if spore mass exposed in moist soil, it will become gelatinous rather than powdery, (States)
STEM  coarse, black cord-like rhizoids extending from the spore mass in the basal region^ (Thiers)
ODOR  mild^ (Castellano), unpleasant and strong when old and moist (Thiers)
TASTE  mild^ (Castellano), not distinctive (Thiers)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  found in association with roots of Abies concolor (White Fir), Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Abies magnifica (California Red Fir), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), and Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine) above 2000m elevation, June through September^, (Castellano), under duff of Abies magnifica shastensis (Shasta Red Fir) at 2140m elevation, September, (Zeller), mycorrhizal hosts in the Pacific Northwest trees in Pinaceae (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 23-26 x 13-16.2 microns, ovoid to somewhat elliptic or irregular, usually very short-pedicellate, in KOH dark brown, inamyloid^; basidia 2-spored, narrow-clavate, sterigmata about as long as the spores, slender, peridium composed of large cells with strongly gelatinized walls, (Castellano), spores 23-26 x 13-16.2 microns, oval to somewhat elliptic or irregular, dark brown (black in mass), usually very short-pedicellate; basidia 2-spored, narrow-clavate; peridium "composed of whitish parenchyma of large cells with heavily gelatinized walls", (Zeller), spores (22)25.5-28.5 x (12)13.3-14.3 microns, oval to elliptic to occasionally nearly round to citriform [lemon-shaped], smooth, brown in Melzer's reagent and in KOH, walls 1-2 microns thick, with germ pore at apex, colorless apiculus present; basidia 2-spored, colorless in KOH; glebal trama colorless in KOH, interwoven; cystidia absent; peridium a compact trichodermium composed of hyphae 5-7 microns wide, tangled interwoven, repent, colorless in KOH, smooth, thin-walled; clamp connections absent, (Thiers), spores 20-27 x 11-15 microns (States), (18)2326(27) x (12)1316(20) microns, (Trappe, M.(5))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pulvinate' (cushion-shaped)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Castellano(1), Zeller(8), Thiers(4), States(2), Trappe(13), Desjardin(6)*, Trappe, M.(5)
343
FAMILY  Bolbitiaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Setchelliogaster tenuipes  (Setch.) Pouzar^  Ceska Mykologie 12: 34. 1958
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include convex to spherical cap that is yellowish brown to reddish brown, somewhat gill-like chambered ochraceous spore mass, thin, striate, appressed-fibrillose stem-columella colored similarly to cap, webby superior veil that disappears, growth under eucalyptus, oak, etc., and microscopic characters including large ochraceous spores with tawny dots or lines, and (1-)2-(3-)spored basidia^; collections examined from OR, CA, (Singer)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-2cm broad, 0.5-3cm high, convex to +/- cylindric or spherical; hazel to chestnut brown when mature; dry to moist, margin when young attached to stem-columella by white veil fragments, usually breaking free when old^, (Smith), 1-3cm x 1-3cm, nearly spherical or broadly ovoid, subumbonate, at base more or less truncate; yellow brown, deep brown (according to Setchell), or red-brown ("Morocco red" Ridgway color according to Zeller); bald, not viscid; peridium up to 0.1cm thick in upper part, rather thick at the point of confluence with the columella, membranous in lower part, usually separating from the stem-columella to expose a narrow ring of spore mass, (Singer)
INNER LAYER  fleshy^ (Singer)
INTERIOR  somewhat gill-like, ochraceous tawny to hazel^, (Smith), ochraceous; decurrent on the apex of the stem-columella but for the most part separating or free from the latter; variable in structure, loculate [chambered] with the chambers very regular in shape and position, the chambers becoming extended in gill-like fashion near the exposed lower part, or in other specimens generally with a gill-like structure especially visible in longitudinal sections, and then consisting of anastomosing plates, but not in a regular manner; chambers sinuous or equal or completely irregular, (Singer)
STEM  0.5-2cm x 0.3-0.4cm stem-columella, appressed-fibrillose^, (Smith), stem variable in length, reaching 2cm long, equal or narrowing slightly downward, 0.2-0.3cm wide, "relatively thin, often bent or flattened", solid, striate; more or less colored as cap; columella continuous with stem, percurrent [going through spore mass] and widened into the upper part of the peridium, sometimes slightly narrowed before reaching the junction, lower part to over half the lower length free from the spore mass; veil superior, arachnoid [webby], transverse, scant, evanescent [disappearing] after maturity is reached, (Singer)
ODOR  none^ (Singer)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious in soil, under or near Eucalyptus (Cupressus or Quercus often present)^, (Smith), subhypogeous [almost underground] on earth and humus under Eucalyptus globulus, Quercus sp. etc., in California during the rainy season (November until April), in Oregon also in June, (Singer)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15-17.6 x 9-11.2 microns, obovoid to subelliptic, roughened, germ pore typically present^, (Smith), spores 14.5-19 x 9.5-12.5 microns, elliptic to suboval, with dots or elongated irregular lines that may be fused to form an imperfect inconspicuous reticulation appearing tawny on a paler background, spores deep rusty ochraceous in KOH, germ pore absent to clearly visible, a plug-like tawny-cinnamon body or even 2-5 of these may be present at the apex, spore wall 1-1.2 microns with complex structure (perisporium conspicuous and pale ochraceous-tawny, exosporium heterogeneous, consisting of a continuous wall through which extend minute canals plugged by a resinous golden tawny substance, under mechanical pressure the combined perisporium and exosporium tending to separate from the underlying episporium, episporium tawny and appearing as a thin line, endosporium thick and paler in color than episporium); basidia (1-)2-(3-)spored, 30-40 x 7-10 microns, colorless, with a median constriction, sterigmata straight or very slightly curved, basidia "rarely seen to form a large area of hymenium but rather intermixed with very numerous pseudoparaphyses"; pseudoparaphyses "normally vesiculose and not projecting beyond the general level of the hymenium", colorless, sometimes gigantic (cystidia?), about 32 x 16 microns, generally 20-22 x 13 microns; true cystidia or pseudocystidia not seen; subhymenium well developed, nearly colorless to colorless, "consisting of small irregular elements, some of them isodiametric, forming a distinct if not very thick layer", hymenophoral trama consisting of brownish to brownish-transparent hyphae "of very variable diameter, some of them actually subisodiametric" (e.g. 4-28 microns in diameter), "thin-walled or nearly so, some elements incrusted by deep rusty pigment, generally regular but chains of broad inflated elements alternating with strands of filamentous narrow hyphae, making the trama slightly intermixed"; peridial tissue thin, "inner layer much like the hymenophoral trama, not gelatinous", its hyphae 5-27 microns wide, "outer layer thick, its elements rusty brown from incrusting pigment", an epithelium or pseudoparenchyma consisting of sphaerocysts in chains or isolated, and few filamentous hyphae ending up (as a terminal member) in a sphaerocyst (sphaerocysts 8-28(50) x 8-22 microns); hyphae of all tissues with clamp connections, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with thin stem'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(12), Smith(4)
344
FAMILY  Trappeaceae, Order Hysterangiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Trappea darkeri  (Zeller) Castellano^  Mycotaxon 38: 3. 1990;  == Hysterangium darkeri  Zeller
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a spherical to irregularly lobed fruitbody that is white becoming buff to pale orange or yellowish brown when bruised, 2) a zone of white sterile chambers underlying the peridium, 3) a spore mass that is gelatinous and olive toned with minute chambers, 4) rhizomorphs emerging from the bottom of a branching columella, 5) an unpleasant odor suggesting stinkhorns or gasoline, 6) underground or above ground growth, 7) chemical reactions, and 8) microscopic characters including elliptic to oblong spores, (4)6(8)-spored basidia, a peridium 35-100(200) microns thick and disappearing, and a layer of sterile locules just inside the peridium.^ The description is derived from Castellano(3) where not otherwise noted. It is common among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Trappea darkeri is found in eastern WA, ID, OR to southern CA and east to SD, (Trappe(13)). Collections were examined from WA, OR, ID, AB, AK, AZ, CA, CO, MT, SD, UT, Spain, and India, (Castellano).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 negative on peridium, "Melzer's reagent pale brown with a pale yellow margin", "KOH pale yellow to golden"; KOH on spore mass olive gray to dark brown
OUTER SURFACE  1-6cm across, spherical to nearly spherical to irregularly lobed; "white at first, becoming buff to pale orange or yellowish brown when bruised, drying buff to orangish brown"; bald to finely pubescent, later polished^, (Castellano), rubbery; "white but staining yellow to orange or brown where bruised", (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  peridium in cross section thin with an underlying zone of white sterile chambers^, (Trappe, M.(3))
INTERIOR  gelatinous, "olive to olive brown to bright olive green"; locules empty, spherical to irregular, minute; numerous persistent sterile locules contained in a gelatinized layer up to 0.1-0.2cm thick just inside the true peridium^, (Castellano), fertile chambers olive to bright olive-green or olive-brown, (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  distinct columella, up to 0.8cm thick near base, typically dendroid (branching) and reaching to two thirds of fruiting body, occasionally subpercurrent, gray to translucent bluish gray; rhizomorphs 2cm or more x 0.1cm at point of attachment, emerging from base of columella, white, single or clustered and branching^, (Castellano), columella translucent, dendroid, (Trappe, M.(3))
ODOR  unpleasant, suggesting stinkhorns or gasoline^, (Castellano, Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  hypogeous or epigeous [buried or partly buried], single to scattered, under conifers usually at elevations 1000-3100m; in western North America May through November^, (Castellano), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Pinus (pine), Abies (fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Picea (spruce), and Quercus (oak) at moderate to high elevations, April to November, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 4-5(5.5) x 2-3(3.5) microns, elliptic to oblong, smooth, sessile or occasionally with short pedicel, with slightly tapered to truncate point of attachment, walls less than 0.5 microns thick, in KOH colorless to pale green singly, olive green in mass, in Melzer's colorless singly, pale olive in mass^; basidia (4)6(8)-spored, (11)17-28(30) x 3-7 microns, irregularly cylindric to clavate, thin-walled, colorless, clamp connections present at base; cystidia none; subhymenium of hyphae 3-4 microns wide, closely interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, sometimes inflated up to 15 microns; locules empty, spherical to irregular, 100-300(600) x 20-60 microns, sterile locules "persistent, numerous, contained in a gelatinized layer (up to 1-2 mm thick) adjacent to the true peridium, lined with large pyriform to subclavate cells, 15-26 x 7-10 microns, with clamp connections present at base, stuffed with hyaline, clamped, thin-walled hyphae"; trama variable in thickness, of hyphae 2-6 microns wide, closely interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, capitate, in a gelatinous matrix, sometimes inflated up to 17 microns, contiguous with the layer of sterile locules, clamp connections common on noninflated hyphae; peridium 35-100 (200) microns thick, mostly of interwoven to subpericlinal, relatively compact, colorless to yellowish brown, thin-walled hyphae 2-4 microns wide, with scattered crystalline particles and occasional areas with thin-walled, colorless, inflated cells 10-15(25) microns in diameter
NAME ORIGIN  named for the collector of the type, G.D. Darker
SIMILAR  Trappea phillipsii stains pink where bruised instead of brown, and has a persistent and thicker true peridium and narrower spores, (Castellano). Hysterangium coriaceum is typically somewhat smaller (0.5-3cm), has a columella that typically reaches halfway through the fruitbody, generally develops underground, and has larger spores. See also SIMILAR section of Hysterangium separabile.
SOURCES  Castellano(3), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)*, Desjardin(6)*
345
FAMILY  Trappeaceae, Order Hysterangiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Trappea phillipsii  (Harkn.) Castellano^  Mycotaxon 38: 7. 1990;  == Hysterangium phillipsii  Harkn.
ENGLISH NAMES
