NOTES  features include spherical to irregular fruitbody usually on or in rotten wood, surface white becoming bright pink to pale pinkish brown when bruised, spore mass gelatinous and green with minute locules, rhizomorphs attached at base, columella branching, unpleasant gasoline odor, FeSO4 reaction on surface of fruitbody greenish blue-gray, and microscopic characters including oblong smooth spores, 6(8)-spored basidia, a layer of sterile locules just inside the peridium, and peridium 100-350 microns thick^; DNA analysis indicates that this species should be in a different family (Trappe(13)); description derived from Castellano(3); infrequent in the Pacific Northwest, found eastern OR to southern CA and NV, (Trappe(13)), found OR, also CA, NV, Castellano(3)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  FeSO4 on peridium greenish blue-gray
OUTER SURFACE  1-4cm across, nearly spherical to irregular; white at first but quickly staining bright pink to pale pinkish brown when bruised
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  soft-gelatinous; dark green to bright green; locules minute, empty
STEM  base indented; columella distinct, translucent, dendroid branching at middle of fruitbody; rhizomorphs "white when fresh, staining pink when bruised, numerous, branched, attached at base", about 0.1cm thick
ODOR  unpleasant, of gasoline
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in California, usually single on or in rotten wood, presumptively mycorrhizal with conifers and possibly Quercus spp. at elevations 600-2400m, January to September
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 3-6 x 1-2(2.5) microns, oblong, smooth, subsessile, in KOH colorless singly, pale green in mass, in Melzer's colorless singly, pale olive in mass^; basidia 6(8)-spored, 10-20 x 2-5 microns, cylindric, sterigmata inconspicuous; cystidia absent; subhymenium of hyphae 2-4 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, with some cells inflated up to 9 x 6 microns; trama 30-50 microns thick, of hyphae 1-3 microns wide in a gelatinous matrix, the hyphae interwoven, colorless, and thin-walled; sterile locules "contained in a gelatinized layer (up to 500 microns thick) adjacent to the true peridium, persistent, few to abundant, sometimes contiguous with the peridium, lined with large subclavate cells, 15-26 x 7-10 microns", stuffed with colorless thin-walled hyphae; peridium 100-350 microns thick, composed of hyphae 3-5 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, near the surface the hyphae inflated up to 25 microns; clamp connections common on noninflated hyphae of peridium, present on cells lining sterile locules, and on hyphae inside sterile locules
NAME ORIGIN  named for the collector, C.L. Phillips
SIMILAR  Trappea darkeri stains brown to yellowish brown instead of pink when bruised, has a thinner peridium which disappears, and has wider spores, (Castellano)
SOURCES  Castellano(3), Trappe(13)
346
FAMILY  Suillaceae, Order Boletales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Truncocolumella citrina  Zeller^  Mycologia 31: 6. 1939
ENGLISH NAMES  stalked yellow Trunc, citrine false truffle
NOTES  Truncocolumella citrina is characterized by 1) a spherical to irregular fruitbody that is yellowish to olive, dry, and smooth or sometimes cracking, 2) a small-chambered spore mass that is firm to gelatinous, and yellow-brown to olive-gray, 3) a yellow columella that is stump-like to branched, often forming a short thick stem, 4) growth in duff or slightly projecting, under Douglas-fir, and 5) microscopic details including elliptic, smooth spores from 4-spored basidia.^ Smith described the var. separabilis, distinguished by the tendency of the spore mass to separate from the stem-columella and from the plate-like branches of the columella, the distinct tubular nature of the spore mass, and the rather strong pseudoamyloid reaction of the spores in Melzer's reagent, and noted also an interwoven arrangement of the hyphae of the tramal plates. Truncocolumella citrina is abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Truncocolumella citrina is found from BC to northern CA to the Rocky Mountains, (Trappe(13)). Collections of Truncocolumella citrina var. citrina were examined from WA, OR, ID, and CA, and it is said to occur "throughout the Pacific Northwest, late summer and fall, often rather common", (Smith(29)). There are collections from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre and the University of British Columbia, and collections at Oregon State University from BC, WA, OR, ID, CA, and MT.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2-5(7)cm broad, 1.5-5cm high, "irregularly rounded to oval, bulblike, lobed, or kidney-shaped"; sometimes whitish when very young but soon becoming yellow to ocher, greenish yellow, or grayish olive; "smooth or sometimes cracking to form a few scales or patches"^, (Arora), 2-5(7)cm broad, 1.5-5cm high, "whitish when immature and not exposed to light", becoming yellow ocher to olive-fuscous at maturity, (Smith(4)), 2-3cm across, 1.5-4cm high, obovate, subellipsoid, spherical, depressed-spherical to kidney-shaped or heart-shaped; pale greenish yellow darkening to olive-fuscous when old, ("immature stages sometimes whitish" before exposure to light), drying pale yellow to dull greenish yellow, or, where bruised, "old gold" (Ridgway color); typically unpolished and dry, (Smith(29)), yellow; felty, (Trudell)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "composed of small empty tubular chambers, completely enclosed by the peridium", firm when young but often quite gelatinous when old; "yellow-brown to olive-gray", becoming darker (sometimes blackish) when old^, (Arora), "chambered, the chambers small, tubular", (Smith(4)), rubbery; "at first white, later gray then brown", (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  stem "often (but not always) present as a short, thick, narrowed base"; columella present also, either stump-like or branched and extending into the spore mass for a considerable distance; yellow to buff; flesh in stem yellow to buff and firm^, (Arora), stem-columella much-branched, with stump-like base; stem-columella and its base bright yellow, (Smith(4)), "columella stump-like to dendroid, the base and branches of pallid yellowish tissue composed of loosely arranged hyphae" 4-7 microns wide, "sterile base merely the broad base of the columella, citrine yellow, usually arising from yellow rhizomorphs", (Smith(29)), columella pale yellow to yellow (Trudell)
ODOR  none^ (Miller)
TASTE  unknown^ (Miller)
EDIBILITY  edible but reported to have little flavor (Trudell), one report of licorice taste delayed to an hour or two later (Arora)
HABITAT  single to gregarious under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and possibly other conifers, especially in summer and fall, often surfaces when mature or is dug up by rodents^, (Arora), single to gregarious, rarely cespitose [clustered], in the duff or only slightly projecting, usually associated with Pseudotsuga menziesii, late summer and fall, (Smith(29)), with Pseudotsuga, and rarely Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine); fruiting August to December (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-10 x 3.5-5 microns, elliptic, smooth, yellowish to light brown^, (Arora), spores 6.5-9.7 x 3.6-4.2(5) microns, elliptic to suboval, smooth, "yellowish in KOH, darker yellow in Melzer's reagent (in mass ochraceous tawny)", "thin-walled or the wall scarcely thickened and showing no differentiation of a pore at spore apex"; basidia 4-spored, 23-26 x 6-7 microns, narrowly clavate, the sterigmata 5-6 x 2 microns, conic; pseudoparaphyses abundant, 18-30 x 10-17 microns, broadly clavate to subspherical, subcylindric, or subfusoid (almost cystidioid in some); cystidia not seen except for large pseudoparaphyses; subhymenium cellular; tramal plates of hyphae 3-6(8) microns wide, subgelatinous, divergent from a thin central strand; peridial epicutis "possibly a collapsed trichodermium", in revived sections apparently consisting of hyphae 3-15 microns wide, loosely arranged, more or less appressed, "with thin, non-incrusted walls yellowish in KOH"; interior to this a body of hyphae 5-9 microns wide, interwoven-subradial, "slightly gelatinous to floccose in KOH, and almost colorless"; clamp connections readily observed at the cross walls, (Smith(29))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to the citron [a lemon-like fruit]', probably in reference to its surface color
SIMILAR  Rhizopogon laetiflavus A.H. Sm. may be this species.
SOURCES  Arora(1)*, Lincoff(2)*, Smith(4), Smith(29), Trudell(4)*, Zeller(7), Miller(14)*, McKnight(1)*, Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)*, Desjardin(6)*, Siegel(2)*
347
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber anniae  W. Colgan & Trappe  group^  Mycotaxon 64: 438. 1997
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include small, nearly spherical to irregular, crisp, bald fruitbody that is pale yellow when young and brown to dark olive brown with grayish white furrows and patches when mature; spore mass that is dark brown marbled with whitish veins alternating with brownish gray veins; mild to slightly paint-like odor; underground growth in Douglas-fir stands; and microscopic characters including round to broadly elliptic spores with alveolate ornamentation, and 1-4 spored asci that are spherical to elliptic^; description derived from Colgan(3) except where otherwise noted; Berch(4) say "Wang et al. (2013) describe the distribution of the Tuber anniae species complex as including much of North America and Europe. Because morphological data and ITS sequences are insufficient to distinguish between the three clades recognized in Tuber anniae, Wang et al. (2013) treated the three clades as a species complex rather than separate species and suggested that multiple genetic markers would better delimit species boundaries." (Latin name italicized); collections examined from WA and OR: some collections previously assigned to Tuber shearii have been reassigned to T. anniae, (Colgan(3)), T. anniae infrequent, southwestern WA to northwestern OR and ID, (Trappe(13)); fruitbodies of the T. anniae complex have been found at several locations in BC - it is regarded as a native species, (Berch(4))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.6-1.8cm across, nearly spherical to irregular, bald, when young pale yellow, when mature "brown to dark olive brown with grayish white furrows and patches"; consistency crisp, drying hard
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "at maturity with dark brown fertile tissue marbled with narrow, white to ivory veins alternating with brownish gray veins"
STEM  none
ODOR  mild to slightly paint-like
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground, in stands of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), August through December, (Colgan), "Members of the Tuber anniae species complex have been found forming ectomycorrhizas with Corylus avellana in truffle orchards, and also with Pinus contorta, Pseudotsuga menziesii, and Betula papyrifera on forestry sites" (Berch(4), Latin names italicized)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores in 1-spored asci 43-45 microns in diameter excluding ornamentation when round, 45-48(50) x 40-44 microns when elliptic, in 2-spored asci mostly round and 28-45 microns in diameter, in 3-spored asci mostly round and 25-38 microns in diameter, in 4-spored asci mostly round and 20-25 microns in diameter, ornamentation "alveolate, the alveolae 6-10 along the spore and with 5-6 sides" [from the illustration this appears to mean on the visible part, i.e. half the circumference], the alveolar walls 3-5 microns tall and "yellow brown to dark brown in KOH and Melzer's reagent", lens effect "often prominent on larger spores (in transmitted light the alveolae on the underside of the spore are projected to the upper spore surface)"^; asci crowded, 1-4-spored, 75-90 x 50-80 microns, spherical to ellipsoid, colorless, the walls about 1(2) microns thick, without a stem or occasionally with a simple stem 8-20 microns long
NAME ORIGIN  "in honor of Annie Kiel, who facilitated the Fort Lewis Ecosystem Study in many useful ways"
SIMILAR  Tuber monticola is dingy white to gray with mostly round spores that have (8)10-16 alveolae across the spore surface, whereas T. anniae is brown to dark olive brown with mostly round spores that have 6-10 alveolae across the spore surface, and T. shearii is light yellowish brown with mostly nearly round to broadly elliptic spores that have 2-8 alveoli lengthwise along the spore surface, (Colgan(3)); Tuber sphaerosporum and Tuber californicum have uniformly round spores, (Colgan(3))
SOURCES  Colgan(3), Trappe(13), Berch(4)
348
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber asa  Tul. & C. Tul.^
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a convoluted, bald fruitbody that is dark olive with white furrows, 2) a spore mass that is dark gray-brown marbled with off-white veins, 3) a mild odor and taste, 4) growth in association with roots of conifers, 5) nearly round spores ornamented with a tall alveolate reticulum, and 6) 1-spored, 2-spored, 3-spored and 4-spored asci.^ The online Species Fungorum, accessed May 23, 2016, gives this name as a synonym of Tuber oligospermum (Tul. & C. Tul.) Trappe, but neither name is mentioned in the Trappe(13) list of truffles from the Pacific Northwest. RANGE Tuber asa has been found at least in OR, NE, France, (Castellano).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-1.5cm across, nearly spherical, convoluted, "dark olive with white furrows and patches"; bald; peridium "olive, hygrophanous in cross section"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "dark gray-brown marbled with narrow, off-white veins"
STEM  
ODOR  indistinct
TASTE  indistinct
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  found in association with roots of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) at 170-500 microns elevation in Oregon, under Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine) in Nebraska; fruits in July and October
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores round to nearly round, in 1-spored asci 36-45 x 35-40 microns excluding ornamentation, "in 2-spored asci 25-35 x 25-34 microns, in 3-spored asci 20-31 x 19-29 microns, in 4-spored asci 20-28 x 19-26 microns", ornamentation an alveolate reticulum (2)3(4) microns tall, the alveolae with 4-7 sides and (4)5-7(9) across the spore, spores brown with walls 2-3 microns thick^; asci 1-4-spored, 70-85 x 50-70 microns, ellipsoid to nearly spherical, thin-walled, colorless, "sessile or with a short stem up to 15 x 8 microns, inamyloid"; paraphyses absent; trama of hyphae 3-8 microns wide, tightly interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, the cells not or only slightly inflated; peridial subcutis of hyphae 2-5 microns wide, tightly interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, occasional cells inflated up to 10 microns; peridial epicutis 30-50 microns thick, of hyphae 4-10 microns wide, interwoven, pale yellow to yellow-brown, walls up to 1 micron thick, many cells inflated up to 30(40) microns, "appears pseudoparenchymatous in places, other places with abundant, emergent, obtuse to tapered, bulbous, cystidioid or versiform hyphae tips"
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Castellano(1), Trappe(13)
349
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber bellisporum  Bonito & Trappe^  Mycologia 102(5): 1049, 2010
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  The underground fruitbodies are nearly spherical to irregularly lobed and furrowed, colored white to light grayish brown to yellowish brown or orange-brown with ivory to pale brown furrows and patches, the surface downy to scabrous, the interior solid, brown when mature, with white marbling veins. Odor is fruity-farinaceous becoming pungent and "truffly". Fruiting is known from October to June, under Douglas-fir. Four known species occur in the Tuber gibbosum complex, separated most reliably by the size and shape of the alveolate spores (also by molecular techniques): Tuber oregonense and T. bellisporum have narrow spores with those of the latter shorter, while Tuber gibbosum and T. castellanoi have wider spores with those of the latter shorter. Tuber bellisporum is characterized within the complex by narrow spores of medium length, and a mix in the peridium of pseudoparenchyma and prosenchyma. "Immature specimens of all four species may have poorly developed peridia with only scattered inflated cells and few or no one- and two-spored asci, so they often cannot be dependably separated at immature stages by morphology alone." (Bonito). [Even in mature specimens there is considerable variation in spore size and shape, and the size depends on how many spores are in the asci, making determination time-consuming.] Tuber gibbosum complex distinguished from other Tuber species by growth with Douglas-fir, relatively large size (when mature), tendency to develop cracks when old, and strong garlicky odor (when present). (Arora) The Tuber gibbosum complex is distinguished microscopically from other Tuber species in having the mature peridial suprapellis with "scattered to abundant tangled hyphae and hyphal tips" with walls irregularly thickened up to 2 microns in bands to produce a beaded appearance, these structures most evident at maturity. (Bonito) Tuber bellisporum is found west of Cascade Mountains from far southwestern WA south through western OR to northwestern CA at elevations from near sea level to about 500 m.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.4-2(3)cm across, subglobose [somewhat spherical], irregularly lobed and randomly furrowed; white when young, when old "becoming light grayish brown to yellowish brown or orange-brown with ivory to pale brown furrows and patches"; "densely pubescent to scabrous in the patches"
INNER LAYER  peridium 0.015-0.025cm thick
INTERIOR  solid, when mature "the fertile tissue light to dark brown from the color of the spores, with narrow, white, hypha-stuffed veins that marble the gleba and emerge through the peridium at its furrows"
STEM  
ODOR  when young fruity-farinaceous, when mature 'pungent and "truffly"'
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in mesic to xeric habitats, associated with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) in pure stands or in mixture with Tsuga heterophylla, other Pinaceae, or Arbutus menziesii, fruiting October to June
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores elliptic to oval or sometimes round, light brownish golden when mature, excluding ornamentation in 1-spored asci 27-55 x 16-32 microns, length:width ratio Q=(1.0)1.3-2.0(2.1), in 2-spored asci, 24-45 x 15-22 microns, Q=(1.2)1.3-2.1, in 3-spored asci 24-38 x 16-25 microns, Q=1.2-1.9, in 4-spored asci 20-36 x 14-22 microns, Q= (1.1)1.3-1.8(2.0), spore wall 2-2.5 microns thick, ornamentation "an orderly, clean, alveolate reticulum" with straight, 5-6-sided alveolae numbering 5-8(11) along the length of the spore, the corners forming spines 4-5 microns long and 0.5 microns wide, somewhat wider at base, the alveolar walls straight and as tall as the spines^; asci 1-4(5)-spored (but 1-spored asci rare), broadly ellipsoid to pyriform [pear-shaped] when young, when mature mostly nearly spherical to spherical, colorless, thin-walled, 60-77 x 33-58 microns, without stalk when mature; pellis of peridium 150-250 microns thick, varying from prosenchymatic to pseudoparenchymatic in patches, of colorless or nearly colorless or yellowish hyphae 3-5 microns wide, "near the suprapellis with much thickened and refractive walls, often with scattered to clustered, inflated, plus or minus isodiametric cells" 5-15 microns wide
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin 'belli' meaning 'lovely' and '-sporum' meaning 'spored', "in reference to the attractive, tidy ornamentation of the spores", (Bonito)
SIMILAR  Tuber gibbosum has spores that on average are longer and wider, but "spore size might not always be useful in differentiating the two because of its high variability within and among specimens". T. gibbosum consistently has a pseudoparenchymatic pellis, whereas that of T. bellisporum has a mix of pseudoparenchyma and prosenchyma. "Several peridial cross sections are needed to confirm which peridial type occurs on a single specimen". (Bonito) Tuber oregonense has long, narrow, subfusoid spores. (Bonito) Tuber castellanoi has round to broadly elliptic spores. (Bonito)
SOURCES  Bonito(1)
350
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber besseyi  Gilkey^  Ore. St. Monogr. Bot. 1: 40. 1939
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include scarcely lobed deep olive-buff fruitbody 0.8-4cm across, surface minutely scabrous or rarely minutely and irregularly verrucose, spore mass darker than surface, marbled by a few large venae externae and slender, dark venae internae, and microscopic characters including spores 36-70 x 20-40 microns, very narrow with pointed ends to somewhat broadly elliptic, generally coarsely and irregularly alveolate, with 4-9 x 3-6 alveoli across the diameter, asci 1-4 spored, the venae externae sometimes bordered by an interrupted palisade of paraphyses^; distribution BC, OR, PQ, SK, MI, NE, NY, (Gilkey)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.8-4cm across, scarcely lobed; "deep olive-buff"; "minutely scabrous or rarely minutely and irregularly verrucose"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  darker than surface, "marbled by a few large venae externae and slender, dark venae internae"
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  mixed woods
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 36-70 x 20-40 microns, very narrow with pointed ends to somewhat broadly elliptic, generally coarsely and irregularly alveolate [reticulate-pitted], with 4-9 x 3-6 alveoli across the diameter^; asci 1-4 spored; "venae externae sometimes bordered by an interrupted palisade of paraphyses"; "peridium 300-800 microns thick at the exits of venae externae, pseudoparenchymatous near the surface, changing to inner prosenchyma"
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gilkey(3) (color in double quotation marks from Ridgway)
351
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber beyerlei  Trappe, Bonito & Guevara^  in Guevara, Bonito & Trappe, Mycologia 105(1): 198. 2012
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) small, nearly round or irregular, orange-brown fruitbodies with a granulose surface, 2) solid interior that is light brown marbled with white veins, 3) garlicky odor, 4) underground growth in association with conifers or hardwoods, and 5) microscopic characters including spores with reticulate ornamentation, and other details that distinguish it from other Tuber species^; description here from Guevara(1); described originally from OR, (Guevara), fruitbodies have been found from 2 locations in BC and ectomycorrhizae have been sequenced from 2 more, (Berch(4))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-2.0cm across, subglobose [nearly spherical] to globose or irregular; "orange brown, light brown when dried"; peridium granulose to irregularly roughened with 8-10 flat to rounded warts per millimeter
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  solid; "light brown marbled with white veins"
STEM  
ODOR  garlicky
TASTE  not recorded
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), May and November; ectomycorrhizae belonging to T. beyerlei have been sequenced from truffle orchards in BC, Canada, established with Corylus and Quercus spp. that had been inoculated with T. melanosporum (Shannon Berch pers. comm. to Guevara(1)) 
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores excluding ornamentation in 1-spored asci 37-47 x 32-40 microns, in 2-spored asci (26)32-45 x 23-28 microns, in 3-spored asci 20-35 x 20-30 microns, and in 4-spored asci 23-28 x 19-26 microns, "subglobose to broadly ellipsoid or sometimes globose", walls up to 4 microns thick "and reddish brown to brown in KOH, reddish brown in Melzer's reagent", reticulum with (4)6-10 meshes along spore length and 3-8 meshes across, the alveolar walls 3-5(7) microns tall, "some spores subalveolate or with irregular reticulation"^; asci 60-80 x 50-60 microns, "subglobose to broadly ellipsoid, pedicel lacking to prominent", the walls up to 1 micron thick, colorless in KOH, yellow in Melzer's reagent; peridium 200-350 microns thick, pellis a pseudoparenchyma, 100-290 microns thick, the cells 7-30 microns wide, "versiform to angular or isodiametric, grouped to form warts, yellowish to reddish brown in KOH", the walls 2-3 microns thick, dermatocystidia 35-85 x 2-4 microns, colorless, "clustered, tapered to the tip, some sinuate, fragile, thin-walled, septate", subpellis 40-90 microns thick, of colorless, periclinal to interwoven hyphae 3-8 microns wide at the septa; gleba of colorless, interwoven, thin-walled hyphae, 2-5 microns wide at the septa, the cells commonly inflated to 6-15 microns wide
NAME ORIGIN  "In honor of Adrian Beyerle, avid truffle collector, long-term member of the North American Truffling Society and discoverer of the holotype"
SIMILAR  Tuber levissimum has a smooth peridium 420-840 microns thick, and the spores in 1-spored asci measure 36-58 x 32-52 microns according to Gilkey(1939), whereas T. beyerlei has a granulose peridium 200-350 microns thick, and spores in 1-spored asci measure 37-47 x 32-40 microns
SOURCES  Guevara(1), Berch(3), Berch(4)
352
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber californicum  Harkn.^  Proc. Calif. Acad. Sci., Ser. 3, Bot. 1: 274. 1899
ENGLISH NAMES  California truffle
NOTES  Tuber californicum can usually be recognized in the field by patches of white pubescence (under a hand lens) and a tendency to be knobby. It is also told by its round (not round to elliptic) alveolate spores borne in asci, (Arora). Other features include a whitish to ochraceous exterior color, a brown interior marbled with white veins, and a mild to slightly garlicky or somewhat cheesy odor.^ It is abundant among truffles in the Pacific Northwest. It is common for a truffle in CA and OR, (Arora). RANGE Tuber californicum is found at least in OR, ID, CA, and OH (Arora). It is found from southwestern WA to southern CA, (Trappe(13)). It occurs west of the Cascade and Sierra Mountains, from WA to southern CA, (Trappe, M.(3)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  (1)1.5-3(5)cm broad, spherical to ovoid or more often irregularly lobed and/or pitted; very firm, exterior "minutely but evenly pubescent (covered with tiny hairs) and whitish when young, becoming mottled with darker (olive to dingy ochre to brown) areas as it matures, but usually retaining patches of the white pubescence"; sometimes cracked when old^, (Arora), 1.5-2.5cm across, much lobed; whitish to ochraceous; unevenly pubescent, (Gilkey), spherical to somewhat irregular; "white to tan with whitish furrows"; smooth to finely pubescent [downy], (Trappe, M.(3))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "solid, firm, marbled, chipping like wax"; whitish when young, becoming dark brown with large meandering white sterile veins when mature^, (Arora), brown, marbled by large pale veins, (Gilkey), brown, marbled with white veins, (Trappe, M.(3))
STEM  "without a basal mycelial tuft"^, (Arora)
ODOR  often distinctive when old (rather cheesy or like gourmet crackers), (Arora), mild to slightly garlicky (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  yes, some people detect a bitter taste, Arora found strong mushroomy flavor
HABITAT  single to gregarious "in or on soil (but under humus) in woods and at their edges"^, (Arora), in Quercus (oak) and other woods (Gilkey), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Pinus (pine), Quercus, and Corylus (hazel), at low to moderate elevation, October to June, (Trappe, M.(3)), mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest are trees in Pinaceae (Trappe(13))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (30)39-52 microns, round, alveolate (reticulate-pitted), brown when mature^; asci 1-4(6)-spored, "imbedded randomly in flesh between veins", (Arora), spores 39-52 microns, round, alveolate, with 3-9 (generally 6-7) alveoli across diameter of spore, spores dark brown; asci 1-4-spored, rarely 5-spored or 6-spored, 72-100 x 72-88 microns, nearly spherical to spherical, short-stemmed; "palisade of paraphyses sometimes seen in hymenium"; "venae externae large, branching, irregular in width, filled with loose branching hyphae", "venae internae inconspicuous"; peridium averaging 200 microns thick, (Gilkey), "fine pubescence of long, tapered hyphal tips", (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of California'
SIMILAR  Tuber sphaerosporum of Colorado and eastern North America also has round spores but lacks the pubescent exterior and has fewer and larger pits on the spores (Arora). See also SIMILAR section of Tuber anniae.
SOURCES  Arora(1)*, Gilkey(3), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13), Desjardin(6)*
353
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber candidum  Harkn.^  Proc. Calif. Acad. III. 1: 274. 1899;  Tuber eisenii  Harkn.;  Tuber olivaceum  Harkn.;  Tuber lyoniae  Butters [as lyoni];  Tuber lignarium  Gilkey;  Terfeziopsis lignaria  Harkn.
ENGLISH NAMES  cinnamon truffle, red truffle
NOTES  Features include 1) a nearly spherical, light yellowish brown to reddish brown fruitbody, with one furrow or several connected furrows that sometimes form circles of a different color, the surface smooth with occasional small papillae around the furrows, 2) a spore mass that is light tan to dark reddish brown, marbled with thin white veins, the veins mostly large and whitish, converging on the surface furrows, 3) fruiting in association with oak, and 4) microscopic characters including spores ornamented with curved spines.^ It is abundant among truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Tuber candidum is found from western OR to southern CA, (Trappe(13)). The distribution includes WA, OR, ID, and CA, (Frank). The distribution includes OR, CA, MB, PQ, MD, MI, MN, NY, OH, and TN, (Gilkey). Distribution is transcontinental, from southern Canada to Mexico, (Trappe, M.(3)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-4cm x 1-5cm, spherical to irregularly nearly spherical; light yellowish brown to reddish brown; smooth^, (Frank), up to 3.5cm across, nearly spherical, light to orange brown, 'with one furrow or generally several connected furrows, mostly on one side, the furrows sometimes united into circles forming "eyes" of a different color from the general ascocarp surface, usually pinkish in young specimens'; surface of fruitbody "smooth, with occasional small papillae about the furrows", (Gilkey), light yellowish brown to orange-brown; "smooth or with patches or minute warts", (Trappe, M.)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "firm, hard when dried, light tan to dark reddish brown, intricately marbled with thin white sterile veins continuous with the inner peridium"^, (Frank), "veins mostly large, whitish, conspicuous, converging at the furrows", (Gilkey), firm; at first light tan, later becoming orange-brown "marbled with both dark brown and white veins", (Trappe, M.)
STEM  
ODOR  mild to slightly earthy^ (Frank), "mild to slightly earthy and at full maturity of fresh green beans", (Trappe, M.)
TASTE  bland^ (Frank)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  fruits below leaf litter in top 2-7cm of mineral soil, associated with Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak) in southern OR, also associated with Quercus (oak) spp. from Washington and Idaho south to southern California^, (Frank), under trees or shrubs, (Gilkey), primarily with Quercus, but also found with Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), and other conifers and hardwoods; fruiting year-round, (Trappe, M.)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 19-42 x 14-34 microns excluding ornamentation and depending on the number of spores per ascus: in 1-spored asci 36-42 x 26-34 microns, in 2-spored asci 28-36 x 22-30 microns, in 3-spored asci 23-31 x 18-25 microns, and in 4-5-spored asci 19-30 x 14-25 microns, nearly round to elliptic, light brown, ornamented with curved spines 2-5 microns long at maturity, spore walls 1-2 microns thick^; asci 1-5-spored, 60-85 x 45-70 microns, spherical to nearly spherical, colorless, with a double wall and a stem 15-50 microns long and with a forked base, "arranged randomly throughout the glebal fertile tissues", (Frank), spores 28-48 x 22-32 microns, very variable in shape from round-elliptic to long-oval, "surface covered by minute or somewhat coarse spines", brown; asci 1-7-spored, generally ovoid, mainly long-stemmed, readily separated from the hyphae; peridium 200-360 microns, "cortex minutely and compactly pseudoparenchymatous, changing to a subcortical layer of hyphae running parallel to the surface", (Gilkey)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'shining white'
SIMILAR  Tuber quercicola is closely related and has a rough, scaly, red peridium, while T. candidum has a smooth, often tan peridium, (Frank(1)). The European Tuber nitidum Vittad. is similar (Frank(1)).
SOURCES  Frank(1), Gilkey(3), Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13), Desjardin(6)*
354
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber castellanoi  Bonito & Trappe^  Mycologia 102(5): 1051, 2010
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  The underground fruitbodies are spherical to irregularly lobed and furrowed, colored brownish white becoming dull brown with ivory to pale brown lines and patches, with surface that is minutely downy, the interior solid, and whitish to brown with white marbling veins. Fruiting is known from February to June and in December, usually under Douglas-fir.^ Four known species occur in the Tuber gibbosum complex, separated most reliably by the size and shape of the alveolate spores (also by molecular techniques): Tuber oregonense and T. bellisporum have narrow spores with those of the latter shorter, while Tuber gibbosum and T. castellanoi have wider spores with those of the latter shorter. Tuber castellanoi is characterized within the complex by shorter, round to broadly elliptic spores and a lower Q (length to width ratio, calculated by these authors using 40 spores in 1-, 2-, 3-, 4-, and 5- spored asci excluding ornamentation for at least 3 collections of each species). Peridial pellis is a variable pseudoparenchyma. "Immature specimens of all four species may have poorly developed peridia with only scattered inflated cells and few or no one- and two-spored asci, so they often cannot be dependably separated at immature stages by morphology alone." (Bonito). [Even in mature specimens there is considerable variation in spore size and shape, and the size depends on how many spores are in the asci, making determination time-consuming.] Tuber gibbosum complex is distinguished from other Tuber species by growth with Douglas-fir, relatively large size (when mature), tendency to develop cracks when old, and strong garlicky odor (when present). (Arora) The Tuber gibbosum complex is distinguished microscopically from other Tuber species in having the mature peridial suprapellis with "scattered to abundant tangled hyphae and hyphal tips" with walls irregularly thickened up to 2 microns in bands to produce a beaded appearance, these structures most evident at maturity. (Bonito) Tuber castellanoi is found west of the Cascade Mountains from southwestern WA south to southwestern OR to northwestern CA at elevations from near sea level to about 916 m and at one location in the northern Sierra Nevada at 1460 m.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.7-3(8)cm across, spherical to subglobose [somewhat spherical] to irregularly lobed and randomly furrowed; brownish white when young, when old "becoming dull brown with ivory to pale brown lines and patches"; minutely pubescent [downy] "densely in the furrows and more scattered on the exposed lobes"
INNER LAYER  peridium 0.01-0.03cm thick
INTERIOR  solid, when young "the fertile tissue whitish and marbled with mostly narrow, white, hypha-stuffed veins that emerge here and there through the peridium at its furrows", when mature "the fertile tissue light brown to brown from the color of the spores but the marbling veins remaining white"
STEM  
ODOR  not recorded
TASTE  not recorded
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  mostly in relatively xeric habitats, associated with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) in pure stands or in mixture with other Pinaceae or Quercus (oak) spp., also known from one location without Pseudotsuga menziesii; fruiting February to June, December
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores round to broadly elliptic, light brownish golden when mature, excluding ornamentation in 1-spored asci 33-44 x 24-38 microns, length:width ratio Q=1.0-1.6, in 2-spored asci, 24-40 x 20-36 microns, Q=1.0-1.5, in 3-spored asci 24-36 x 20-30 microns, Q=1.0-1.4, in 4-spored asci 20-35 x 18-28 microns, Q=1.0-1.4(1.6), spore wall 2-2.5 microns thick, ornamentation "an orderly alveolate reticulum", the alveolae 5-6-sided numbering (4)5-7(8) along the spore length, the corners forming spines 2.5-4 microns long and 0.5 microns wide, somewhat wider at base, "the alveolar walls as tall as the spines"^; asci 1-4(5)-spored, 50-80 x 40-60 microns, spherical to broadly ellipsoid or ovoid, sometimes somewhat polygonal from spore pressure, colorless, thin-walled, without stalk when mature; pellis of peridium 110-250 microns thick, a variable pseudoparenchyma of several tiers of nearly colorless cells inflated up to 35 microns broad near the suprapellis "with much thickened and refractive walls"
NAME ORIGIN  in honor of Michael Castellano for collecting the type and his contributions to mycology and truffle taxonomy^, (Bonito)
SIMILAR  Tuber gibbosum and Tuber oregonense have longer spores, and Tuber bellisporum narrower spores. (Bonito)
SOURCES  Bonito(1)
355
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber gardneri  Gilkey^  Univ. Calif. Publ. Bot. 6: 317. 1916
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a small, nearly spherical to irregular, brown, minutely warty fruitbody, 2) a spore mass that is brown to purplish brown, marbled with conspicuous, narrow, white veins, 3) underground growth in spring and summer, and 4) microscopic characters including spores with a honeycomb reticulum and nearly spherical, thick-walled asci (the thick walls an uncommon features in Tuber).^ It is common among truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Tuber gardneri is found from western WA to CA and Mexico, (Trappe(13)). The distribution is OR and CA, (Gilkey). It is known from WA south to Mexico (Trappe, M.(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  fruitbody averaging 1.5cm across, nearly spherical, with small convolutions; brown; surface minutely verrucose^, (Gilkey), spherical to somewhat irregular; yellowish brown; minutely warty, (Trappe, M.(1))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  brown when mature, "with wide, conspicuous, white veins"^, (Gilkey), "at maturity brown to purplish brown marbled with very narrow, white veins", (Trappe, M.(1))
STEM  
ODOR  "mild or slightly garlicky", (Trappe, M.(1))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  nearly always associated with Douglas-fir^ (one collection from Oregon, one from the midwest, and one from Mexico are recorded from oak stands), (Trappe, J.), under trees of various species, (Gilkey), with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Pinus (pine), Tsuga (hemlock), and Quercus (oak), May-September, "often in warm, dry habitats", (Trappe, M.(1))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 28-48 (rarely 58) x 24-30 microns, elliptic, alveolate, with 5-14 x 3-11 alveoli across their diameters^; asci 1-5-spored, without stem, nearly spherical or rarely elongated; "outer cortical layer somewhat coarsely pseudoparenchymatous", the cells occasionally reaching 18 microns in diameter, thin-walled, gradually changing to a subcortical layer of unconnected hyphae 2-4 microns wide, (Gilkey), 28-58 x 24-30 microns, nearly round to long elliptic, with a honeycomb reticulum; asci thick-walled, (Trappe, M.(1)), asci are thick-walled (up to 2 microns), a character that is otherwise rather infrequent in the genus, (Trappe, J.)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Tuber whetstonensis is microscopically similar and also has thick-walled asci, but the peridium is scurfy and brown to reddish brown rather than distinctly verrucose and grayish to yellowish. (Trappe, J.). Tuber murinum Hesse of Europe is similar. J. Trappe initially concluded that T. gardneri was a synonym of T. murinum. The only notable difference between the two was color, T. murinum being more gray and T. gardneri more yellowish. After the molecular data began to show that N. America and Europe had a number of similar species that were actually genetically distinct, he decided it was prudent to separate the two pending molecular evidence, and for this reason he reverted to T. gardneri for the Pacific Northwest species. Older Pacific Northwest collections accessioned at Oregon State University may still be labeled T. murinum. (Trappe, J.). See also SIMILAR section of Tuber whetstonense.
SOURCES  Gilkey(3), Trappe, M.(1)*, Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe, J. (pers. comm.), Trappe(13)
356
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber gibbosum  Harkn.^  Proc. Calif. Acad. III. 1: 273. 1899;  Tuber giganteum  Gilkey
ENGLISH NAMES  spring Oregon white truffle
NOTES  The underground fruitbodies are spherical to irregularly lobed and furrowed, colored pale olivaceous to olive brown to dull brown or orange-brown, the surface downy and often cracking, the interior solid, whitish to brown, with white marbling veins. Odor is mild soon becoming strong, pungent and complex, "truffly". Fruiting is known from January to June, under Douglas-fir. Microscopic features are important in differentiating T. gibbosum from other members of the T. gibbosum complex.^ Four known species occur in the Tuber gibbosum complex in the Pacific Northwest, separated most reliably by the size and shape of the alveolate spores (also by molecular techniques): Tuber oregonense and T. bellisporum have narrow spores with those of the latter shorter, while Tuber gibbosum and T. castellanoi have wider spores with those of the latter shorter. Tuber gibbosum is characterized within the complex by fairly wide elliptic spores of intermediate length, and a peridium of pseudoparenchymatic tissue. Of the four species only T. gibbosum forms a well-developed, epithelial pellis of large, inflated cells - "this is usually evident in fairly young specimens". "Immature specimens of all four species may have poorly developed peridia with only scattered inflated cells and few or no one- and two-spored asci, so they often cannot be dependably separated at immature stages by morphology alone." (Bonito). [Even in mature specimens there is considerable variation in spore size and shape, and the size depends on how many spores are in the asci, making determination time-consuming.] The Tuber gibbosum complex is distinguished from other Tuber species by growth with Douglas-fir, relatively large size (when mature), a tendency to develop cracks when old, and a strong garlicky odor (when present), (Arora). The Tuber gibbosum complex is distinguished microscopically from other Tuber species in having the mature peridial suprapellis with "scattered to abundant tangled hyphae and hyphal tips" with walls irregularly thickened up to 2 microns in bands to produce a beaded appearance, these structures most evident at maturity. (Bonito). The descriptions of Smith(4), Arora(1), and Gilkey(3) would encompass both Tuber gibbosum and Tuber oregonense. RANGE Tuber gibbosum in the new strict sense occurs west of the Cascade Mountains from southern Vancouver Island in BC, south through western WA and OR to northwestern CA's San Francisco Bay. (Bonito). Berch(4) lists a fruitbody collection from BC.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-5.5cm across, the smaller specimens spherical to nearly spherical and randomly furrowed, the larger ones irregular, lobed, and deeply furrowed; pale olivaceous, soon becoming olive brown to dull brown or orange-brown; minutely pubescent (densely in furrows and more scattered on exposed lobes), surface often cracking^, (Bonito), "olive to brownish yellow with some brown mottling"; "smooth but with furrows that are minutely pubescent", (Trappe, M.(3)), 1.5-5.5cm across, nearly spherical to irregular; light buff mottled with purplish brown; scabrous to minutely pubescent [finely hairy], (Smith), 1.5-5(8)cm across, nearly spherical to irregularly knobby or potato-like, firm or hard; "whitish when young becoming pale buff to tan or brown, then usually developing darker (reddish to purple-brown) areas when fully mature"; "minutely downy or irregularly roughened but not warted", often cracking when old, (Arora), 1.5-5cm across, nearly spherical, lobed to nearly regular, "meaty, crisp"; "light buff" and "Mikado brown", "with the wide, white endings of the venae externae conspicuous on the surface of fresh specimens", "scabrous to minutely pubescent", (Gilkey)
INNER LAYER  peridium 0.01-0.02cm thick^, (Bonito)
INTERIOR  solid, when young whitish and marbled with mostly narrow, white, hypha-stuffed veins that emerge through the peridium at furrows, when mature light brown to brown from spores but marbling veins remaining white^, (Bonito), spore mass "white when immature, brown with white marbling when mature", (Trappe, M.(3)), more or less solid; "dark purple-brown to brick red marbled with white", (Smith), "solid, marbled, crisp; whitish when young, the fertile tissue becoming brown to dark brown to brick-red when mature, the meandering sterile veins remaining whitish", (Arora), "wood brown" to "brick red" when mature, marbled by distinct shining white veins, (Gilkey)
STEM  without a basal mycelial tuft^ (Arora)
ODOR  mild when young, soon 'strong, pungent and complex, "truffly"'^, (Bonito), '"truffly", a complex of garlic, spices, cheese, and indefinable other essences', (Trappe, M.(3)), usually strong and garlicky when fully mature (Arora)
TASTE  as odor^ (Bonito), mild but like garlic when mature (Miller)
EDIBILITY  choice, but widespread collecting can be destructive, (Arora), commercially harvested for culinary use (Bonito), toxic in a 2010 report: stomach queasy, diarrhea (4x), later fainted (3x), felt cold: consumed brie infused/odor of truffle, (Beug)
HABITAT  below about 600 m in pure stands up to about 100 years old of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) or Pseudotsuga mixed with Tsuga heterophylla, Picea sitchensis, or Abies, often in Christmas tree plantations as young as 5 years (in one such farm the only host species Abies procera), occurs as ectomycorrhizae on Pinus sabiniana; fruiting January to June^, (Bonito), with young to early-mature Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir); January to June, (Trappe, M.(3)), single, scattered or gregarious "in woods or at their edges, associated mainly if not exclusively with Douglas-fir (usually trees between the ages of 8 and 65 years)", normally underground but sometimes on surface, (Arora), almost year-round depending on location and weather conditions, (Ammirati), underground under Douglas-fir, reported under oak (Lincoff)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores elliptic to broadly elliptic, light brownish golden, excluding ornamentation in 1-spored asci 36-60 x 25-37.5 microns, length to width ratio Q=1.2-1.8, in 2-spored asci, 28.5-50 x 20-37.5 microns, Q=1.1-1.8, in 3-spored asci 25-50 x 16-32.5 microns, Q=1.2-1.9, in 4-spored asci 22.5-38 x 17-30 microns, Q=1.1-1.8, in 5-spored asci 25-32 x 19-24 microns, Q=1.30, spore wall 2-5 microns thick, ornamentation "an orderly, alveolate reticulum", the alveolae 5-6-sided numbering (6)7-10 along the spore length, the corners forming spines 3-4(5) microns long and 0.5 microns wide, much wider at base, "the alveolar walls as tall as the spines"^; asci (1)2-4(6)-spored, when young spherical to broadly ellipsoid to ovoid or pyriform [pear-shaped], when mature spherical to broadly ellipsoid, sometimes cylindric or misshapen from spore pressure, colorless, thin-walled when young, walls +/- 1 micron thick when mature, 73-100 x (35)65-75 microns, without stalk when mature; pellis of peridium pseudoparenchymatic, 60-100 microns thick, of several tiers of colorless to nearly colorless or yellowish, isodiametric cells 5-20 microns wide and some intermingling hyphae 3-5(10) microns wide, "near the suprapellis with much thickened and refractive walls", (Bonito), spores 25-45 x 17-33 microns, elliptic with bluntly rounded ends, honeycomb ornamentation; short emergent hyphae from furrows having peculiar, bead-like wall thickenings, (Trappe, M.(3)), spores 35-52 x 17-39 microns, long elliptic, alveolate-reticulate, dark yellowish brown; asci 1-6(8)-spored, saccate to pyriform, (Smith), 35-52 x 17-40 microns, "elliptical or elongated, reticulate-alveolate (ridged and pitted with shallow depressions) when mature but smooth when very young", dark yellow-brown to brown when mature, asci mostly 1- to 6-spored, randomly embedded in tissue between veins, (Arora), spores 35-52 x 17-40 microns, mostly long-elliptic, generally rounded at the ends, alveolate with the "spore surface reticulate beneath the alveoli", with 7-10 x 5-9 alveoli across diameter of spore, spores dark yellowish brown; asci 1-6-spored, rarely 7-spored or 8-spored; "venae externae loose, spongy, generally opening in the surface depressions filled with irregular hairs"; "outer cortical layer pseudoparenchymatous, the superficial cells often forming branched, knotted hairs more or less parallel with the surface", (Gilkey)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'protuberant, humped, crooked'
SIMILAR  Tuber oregonense has long, narrow spores common in 1-spored to 4-spored asci, and generally taller spore ornamentation - the largest spores are subfusoid with length to width ratio Q up to 2.9 and reticulate ornamentation mostly 5-7(8) microns tall (T. gibbosum has only elliptic spores with Q no more than 1.45 and reticulum 3-5(6) microns tall.) The peridium of T. oregonense has a prosenchymatous structure (pseudoparenchymatic in T. gibbosum). Fruiting for T. oregonense is September to mid-March and for T. gibbosum January to June. (Bonito). Tuber oregonense 1) does not have a thin, almost translucent peridium like T. gibbosum, 2) has more reddish orange tones as it matures than T. gibbosum, 3) fruits in October through February whereas Tuber gibbosum fruits in January through June, and 4) differs microscopically in the size and shape of the spores and the anatomy of the peridium, (Trappe, M.(3)). T. bellisporum has spores that are on average shorter and narrower but "spore size might not always be useful in differentiating the two because of its high variability within and among specimens". T. gibbosum consistently has a pseudoparenchymatic pellis, whereas that of T. bellisporum has a mix of pseudoparenchyma and prosenchyma. "Several peridial cross sections are needed to confirm which peridial type occurs on a single specimen". (Bonito). Tuber castellanoi has shorter spores (Bonito).
SOURCES  Bonito(1), Trappe, M.(3)*, Smith(4), Arora(1), Gilkey(3) (individual colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway), Lincoff(2)*, Ammirati(1)*, Miller(14)*, Trappe, M.(1)*, Fogel(8), Colgan(2), Trudell(4), Beug(2), Berch(4)
357
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber harknessii  Gilkey^  N. Am. Flora II(1): 24. 1954;  Tuber caroli  sensu Harkn.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include small scarcely lobed, reddish brown fruitbody, the surface distinctly divided into low polygonal areas, the spore mass compact, paler than surface and marbled by conspicuous white veins somewhat converging at a common base, growth under oaks, and microscopic characters including brown spores 26-35 microns in length, oval or elliptic, clothed with slender spines, and long-stemmed asci^; description derived from Gilkey(3); distribution OR, CA, (Gilkey)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-2cm across, scarcely lobed; reddish brown; "the surface distinctly divided into low polygonal areas"
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "compact, paler than surface, marbled by conspicuous white veins somewhat converging at a common base"
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under oaks
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 26-35 microns in length, oval or elliptic, clothed with slender spines, brown; asci long-stemmed
NAME ORIGIN  means "of Harkness", for H.W. Harkness, pioneer 19th Century truffle taxonomist, (Trappe, M.(1))

SOURCES  Gilkey(3), Trappe, M.(1)

FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber irradians  Gilkey^  Univ. Calif. Publ. Bot. 6: 316. 1916
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include small depressed-spherical, somewhat lobed, brown fruitbody that is irregularly verrucose, spore mass brown when mature, veins few, little branched, and white, and microscopic characters including elliptic brown spores 36-56 x 28-48 microns with alveolate ornamentation, the number of alveoli variable, 3-9 x 3-8 (usually 6 x 5) across diameter of spore with sculpturing 4-6 microns thick, spores 1-3 in an ascus, and asci 70-94 x 44-64 microns, pyriform to subglobose^; description derived from Gilkey(3) except where noted otherwise; distribution OR, CA, (Gilkey), infrequent, OR and northern CA, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  about 1cm across, depressed-spherical, somewhat lobed; brown; irregularly verrucose
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  brown when mature, the veins few, little branched, and white
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in woods^, (Gilkey), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest is Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 36-56 x 28-48 microns, elliptic, alveolate [reticulate-pitted], the number of alveoli variable, 3-9 x 3-8 (usually 6 x 5) across diameter of spore, sculpturing 4-6 microns thick, spores brown; spores 1-3 (generally 1 or 2) in an ascus^; asci 70-94 x 44-64 microns, pyriform to subglobose, sometimes long-stemmed, readily separable from the hyphae; peridium 380 microns thick or more, "pseudoparenchymatous, the cells thin-walled, large (to 24 microns), in more or less clearly distinct radial rows to a depth of 140-160 microns, changing abruptly to a loose hyphal structure"
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Tuber lauryi has smaller spores and a thicker peridium
SOURCES  Gilkey(3), Trappe(13)

FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber lauryi  Trappe, Bonito & Guevara^  Mycologia 105(1): 203. 2012
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Tuber lauryi "can be recognized by its usually thick peridium" (up to 1000 microns fresh and up to 600 microns even when dried), "in combination with its thick-walled asci mostly containing three or fewer spores". Other features include small size, whitish to brown, mostly smooth surface, brown interior marbled with white to cream veins, underground growth in association with hardwoods and conifers, and microscopic characters.^ It was described originally from western OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1.0-1.3cm x 0.6-1.0cm, globose [spherical] to subglobose, ellipsoid, or irregular; whitish to brown; "smooth but in small patches granulose to finely roughened" or with 10-15 rounded warts per millimeter
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  solid; "brown marbled with white to cream veins"
STEM  
ODOR  not recorded
TASTE  not recorded
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground, single in mixed forests of Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) or in pure stands of Pseudotsuga menziesii; July, October, and December; sequence data from ectomycorrhizae confirm that T. lauryi is mycorrhizal with species of Quercus (oak), Notholithocarpus (Tanoak), and Epipactis (an orchid genus)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores excluding reticulate ornamentation 35-40(50) x 30-41 microns in 1-spored asci, 22-38 x 22-35 microns in 2-spored asci, 23-28 x 20-28 microns in 3-spored asci, round to nearly round or broadly elliptic, walls up to 6 microns thick, reticulum with 4-10(14) alveolar meshes along spore length, 3-8 meshes across spore width, alveolar walls 2-4 microns high, "some with a microreticulation within the alveolae", "yellowish to reddish brown or dark brown in KOH, reddish brown in Melzer's reagent"^; asci 60-90 x 40-70 microns, broadly ellipsoid, 1-3(4)-spored, the walls up to 2 microns thick, colorless in KOH, yellowish in Melzer's reagent; peridium 300-1000 microns thick, pellis an irregular pseudoparenchyma 50-150 microns thick, absent in patches, the cells 4-24 microns wide, "angular to isodiametric in groups that form warts, in small areas forming chains perpendicular to the peridium, orange to reddish or light brown in KOH", the walls up to 2 microns thick, dermatocystidia "scattered, tapered to the tip, sinuate, readily collapsing, thin-walled", colorless in KOH; subpellis 300-900 microns thick, near interface with pellis a dense tissue of periclinal to interwoven, colorless hyphae 3-5 microns wide at the septa, "the cells generally not inflated", the walls up to 1 micron thick; gleba of colorless, densely interwoven hyphae 2-5 microns wide at the septa, the walls thin or thickened up to 1 micron, "only scattered cells somewhat inflated"
NAME ORIGIN  "In honor of Dr Daniel Laury, who found the southernmost collection of the species"
SIMILAR  Tuber irradians is similar but the type "has an outer peridium of distinctive radial chains" 140-160 microns long of isodiametric cells, larger spores (36-56 x 28-48 microns), and a peridium no thicker than 380 microns, (Guevara(1)).
SOURCES  Guevara(1)
360
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber levissimum  Gilkey^  Univ. Calif. Publ. Bot. 6: 313. 1916
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include small, clay-brown, smooth fruitbody, with large internal veins that are inconspicuous in color, and microscopic characters^; description derived from Gilkey(3); described from CA (Gilkey), rare in the Pacific Northwest, found from southwestern OR and from CA (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2cm or less across, even; clay-brown; smooth
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  veins large, inconspicuous in color
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under shrubs and trees
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 36-58(65) x 32-52 microns, dark brown, mostly broadly elliptic, spores "alveolate, the alveoli irregular in size and number on the spore", 3-10 x 4-13 across diameter of spore, "the surface of the spore minutely reticulate beneath the alveoli"; asci 1-4(5)-spored, 70-100 x 50-80 microns, subglobose [nearly spherical] to globose [spherical]; peridium 420-840 microns thick
NAME ORIGIN  means 'very smooth' (or very light)
SIMILAR  T. beyerlei has a granulose peridium 200-350 microns thick, and spores in 1-spored asci measure 37-47 x 32-40 microns whereas Tuber levissimum has a smooth peridium 420-840 microns thick, and the spores in 1-spored asci measure 36-58 x 32-52 microns (according to Gilkey(1939)), (Guevara(1))
