FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber monticola  Harkn.^  Proc. Calif. Acad. III. 1: 271. 1899 (as Tuber monticolum)
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include lobed, dingy white fruitbodies averaging 1.5cm across, the surface slightly scabrous, and microscopic characters including round-elliptic spores 32-40 x 28-34 microns that are very minutely alveolate [pitted] with 12-16 x 11-14 alveoli across diameter, asci 2-4-spored and nearly spherical, and peridium 280-640 microns thick^; description derived from Gilkey(3) except where noted; common in the Pacific Northwest, found BC to northern CA and ID, (Trappe(13)), described from CA, reported from OR by J. Smith et al., from WA by Colgan(2)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  averaging 1.5cm across, lobed; dingy white; surface slightly scabrous
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection among firs in dense woods in the Sierra Nevada mountains^, (Gilkey), mycorrhizal hosts in the Pacific Northwest are trees in Pinaceae, (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 32-40 x 28-34 microns, round-elliptic, very minutely alveolate [reticulate-pitted] with 12-16 x 11-14 alveoli across diameter^; asci 2-4-spored, nearly spherical; peridium 280-640 microns thick, "cortex minutely pseudoparenchymatous, the cells varying little in size, the walls not thickened, the pseudoparenchyma changing gradually to very loose, branched hyphae"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'living in the mountains'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Tuber anniae.
SOURCES  Gilkey(3), Smith, J.E.(1), Colgan(2), Trappe(13)
362
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber oregonense  Trappe, Bonito & Rawlinson^  Mycologia 102(5): 1053, 2010
ENGLISH NAMES  fall Oregon white truffle
NOTES  Underground fruitbodies are spherical to irregular, furrowed, white becoming orange-brown to reddish brown, the surface roughened-bald to minutely downy, when old often cracking. The interior is solid, white to brown with white marbling veins. Odor is mild, soon becoming pungent and complex (garlic, spices, cheese, and indefinable other essences). Fruiting is from fall to winter.^ Four known species occur in the Tuber gibbosum complex, separated most reliably by the size and shape of the alveolate spores (also by molecular techniques): Tuber oregonense and T. bellisporum have narrow spores with those of the latter shorter, while Tuber gibbosum and T. castellanoi have wider spores with those of the latter shorter. Tuber oregonense is characterized within the complex by its long narrow spores common in 1- to 4-spored asci (subfusoid in the largest spores), its generally taller spore ornamentation, and its generally prosenchymatous peridial pellis. "Immature specimens of all four species may have poorly developed peridia with only scattered inflated cells and few or no one- and two-spored asci, so they often cannot be dependably separated at immature stages by morphology alone." Tuber oregonense fruits primarily in fall to early winter and is the most commonly collected Tuber species in the fall in the Pacific Northwest. (Bonito). [Even in mature specimens there is considerable variation in spore size and shape, and the size depends on how many spores are in the asci, making determination time-consuming.] Tuber gibbosum complex distinguished from other Tuber species by growth with Douglas-fir, relatively large size (when mature), tendency to develop cracks when old, and strong garlicky odor (when present). (Arora) The Tuber gibbosum complex is distinguished microscopically from other Tuber species in having the mature peridial suprapellis with "scattered to abundant tangled hyphae and hyphal tips" with walls irregularly thickened up to 2 microns in bands to produce a beaded appearance, these structures most evident at maturity. (Bonito) RANGE Tuber oregonense is found west of Cascade Mountains from southern Puget Sound of WA south to southwestern OR. (Bonito), and Beug(3) gives the range as BC to CA. Berch(4) lists two fruitbody collections from BC.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-5(7.5)cm across, the smaller specimens spherical to somewhat spherical and randomly furrowed, the larger ones "irregular, lobed and deeply furrowed"; peridium white when young, "soon developing red to reddish brown or orange brown patches", when old "becoming orange-brown to reddish brown overall"; surface roughened-bald to minutely pubescent, "densely in the furrows and more scattered on the exposed lobes where the pubescence often collapses" when old, often cracking^, (Bonito), peridium white when young, soon becoming yellow to olive mottled with brown to orange-brown or reddish brown blotches and fissures, when fully mature reddish brown; peridium very thin and appears almost translucent, (Trappe, M.), peridium opaque whitish to yellowish or olivaceous, developing prominent reddish orange to cinnamon colors, (Trudell)
INNER LAYER  peridium 0.02-0.04cm thick^ (Bonito)
INTERIOR  solid, when young "the fertile tissue whitish and marbled with mostly narrow, white, hypha-stuffed veins that emerge here and there through the peridium to its surface", when mature, "the fertile tissue light brown to brown from the color of the spores but the marbling veins remaining white"^, (Bonito), spore mass firm, "white when immature, brown with white marbling when mature", (Trappe, M.), spore mass whitish at first, then becomes brownish with white marbling, (Trudell)
STEM  
ODOR  mild when young, 'soon becoming strong, pungent and complex, "truffly"', (Bonito), '"truffly," a complex of garlic, spices, cheese, and indefinable other essences', (Trappe, M.)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  commercially harvested for culinary use (Bonito)
HABITAT  in pure stands of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) forests up to 100 years old or Pseudotsuga mixed with Tsuga heterophylla, Picea sitchensis or Alnus, also in Christmas tree plantations as young as 5 years, and found along golf course fairways; fruits September to mid-March, primarily in fall to early winter^, (Bonito), with young to early-mature Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), October to February, (Trappe, M.), fall to late winter; principally with young, vigorously growing Douglas-firs, (Trudell)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores elliptic to subfusoid with narrowed ends, light brownish golden, excluding ornamentation in 1-spored asci 42.5-62.5 x 17.5-30 microns, Q=1.55-2.5(2.9), in 2-spored asci, 32.5-50 x 15-25 microns, Q=1.5-2.4, in 3-spored asci 27.5-45 x 15-25 microns, Q=1.5-2.0(2.45), in 4-spored asci 25-38.5 x 13-28 microns, Q=1.4-2.2(2.3), in 5-spored asci 28-34 x 22-25 microns, Q=1.3-1.4, spore wall 2-3 microns thick, ornamentation "an orderly, alveolate reticulum", the alveolae 5-6-sided numbering 5-8(9) along the spore length, the corners forming spines (4)5-7(8) microns long and 0.5 microns wide, somewhat wider at base, the alveolar walls as tall as the spines^; asci 1-4(5)-spored, when young spherical to broadly ellipsoid to ovoid or pyriform [pear-shaped], when mature spherical to broadly ellipsoid or misshapen from spore pressure, colorless, thin-walled, without stalk when mature but sometimes base narrowed stalk-like when young up to 15 x 7 microns; pellis of peridium generally prosenchymatous, 200-300 microns thick plus or minus 80 microns, of tightly interwoven hyphae 3-5(10) microns wide, the cells short and with nearly colorless walls 0.5-1.0 microns thick, "where the interior veins emerge through the peridium the cells often forming a localized tissue of rounded cells" up to 12 microns wide, (Bonito), spores 25-52 x 17-40 microns, elliptic or tapered to a tip at both ends, with honeycomb ornamentation, (Trappe, M.)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'from Oregon' "in reference to western Oregon being its central region of abundance"^, (Bonito)
SIMILAR  Tuber gibbosum fruits from fall through winter to early summer, and has spores with a lower length to width ratio (wider and somewhat shorter): the largest spores of T. oregonense are subfusoid with Q up to 2.9 and a reticulate ornamentation mostly 5-7(8) microns tall, whereas T. gibbosum has only elliptic spores with Q no larger than 1.45 and a reticulum 3-5(6) microns tall, (Bonito). T. gibbosum differs in having a peridium that appears almost translucent, and if reddish tones are present they are less prominent than in Tuber oregonense. It also differs in fruiting season, the anatomy of the peridium, and spore size and shape. (Trappe, M.). Tuber gibbosum "occurs in the same habitats ... but fruits during later winter and spring ... it also differs in its almost translucent peridium, and less of a tendency to develop reddish colors in age." (Trudell). Tuber bellisporum has shorter spores, (Bonito). Tuber castellanoi has shorter wider spores, (Bonito).
SOURCES  Bonito(1), Trappe, M.(3)*, Trudell(4)*, Trappe(13), Beug(3), Desjardin(6)*, Berch(4)
363
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber pacificum  Trappe, Castellano & Bushnell^  Mycotaxon 75: 176. 2000
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a small, nearly spherical, convoluted fruitbody that is white with brown areas, the surface shallowly furrowed and felty, 2) a solid spore mass that is brown to blackish brown with narrow, white veins, 3) underground growth in association with Douglas-fir and Western Hemlock, and 4) microscopic characters, including elliptic spores with inamyloid alveolate reticulum (2)3(4) microns tall, and asci 1-4-spored and ellipsoid to nearly spherical, becoming thick-walled at maturity.^ It is rare among truffles in the Pacific Northwest RANGE Tuber pacificum occurs in western coastal OR, (Trappe(13)). It endemic to coastal OR (Castellano(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.6-0.9cm x 0.4-0.9cm, nearly spherical, convoluted; white with brown areas; "shallowly furrowed, felty"^, (Trappe(2))
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  solid; "brown to blackish brown marked with narrow, white veins"^, (Trappe(2))
STEM  
ODOR  not recorded^ (Trappe(2))
TASTE  not recorded^ (Trappe(2))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  underground under and probably mycorrhizal with mature Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), February, June, and July^, (Trappe(2)), in association with roots of Pseudotsuga menziesii and Tsuga heterophylla at 235m, (Castellano)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 39-45 x 29-35 microns excluding ornamentation in 1-spored asci, 36-43 x 28-32 in 2 spored asci, 31-35 x 20-26 in 3-spored asci, 23-25 x 16-26 microns in 4-spored asci, elliptic, ornamentation an alveolate reticulum (2)3(4) microns tall, the alveolae [pits] with 5-6 sides and (4)6-10 along the spore length, spore walls 2-3(3.5) microns thick, spores brown, in Melzer's reagent pale brown and the ornamentation colorless, spores cyanophilic^; asci 1-4-spored, 70-85 x 55-70 microns, ellipsoid to nearly spherical, thin-walled when young but when mature the walls up to 2 microns thick, colorless, without a stem, inamyloid; paraphyses absent; glebal trama with a medullary excipulum composed of hyphae 2-5 microns wide at septa, tightly interwoven, colorless, "occasional cells inflated up to 10 microns, the walls thin or occasionally up to 1.5 microns thick"; "internal veins similar but of less tightly interwoven tissue"; peridium 250-450 microns thick, ental excipulum of peridium (subcutis) composed of hyphae 1.5-3 microns wide, tightly interwoven, colorless, thin-walled, ectal excipulum of peridium (epicutis) 20-30 microns thick, composed of hyphae 2-5 microns wide at septa, appressed to tangled, colorless to pale yellow, walls thin or up to 1 micron thick, many cells inflated up to 8-10 microns, "in places abundant enough and with thickened walls to appear pseudoparenchymatous, other places with abundant, emergent, obtuse to tapered, bulbous, cystidioid or versiform hyphal tips", (Trappe(2))
NAME ORIGIN  referring "to the Pacific Ocean, near which the known localities of this species occur"^, (Trappe(2))
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Trappe(2), Castellano(1)*, Trappe(13)
364
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber phleboderma  (Gilkey) Trappe^  Mycotaxon 9(1): 328. 1979;  == Lespiaultinia phleboderma  (Gilkey) Gilkey;  == Delastreopsis  phleboderma  Gilkey
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include small buff fruitbody with nearly even, minutely scabrous surface, traversed by meandering venae externae continuing from the venae externae of the spore mass, relatively thick peridium, brown spore mass, and microscopic characters including mostly round spores 36-52 microns in diameter and yellowish in color, asci generally 1-2-spored, and a palisade of paraphyses bordering the venae externae in places, but generally deformed by crowding^; description derived from Gilkey(3), rare, Benton County, OR, (Trappe(13)), type collected in OR
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1cm or less across, buff; nearly even, minutely scabrous, traversed by meandering venae externae continuing from the venae externae of the spore mass; peridium thick (0.08cm)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  brown, containing venae externae
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  mixed woods
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 36-52 microns, mostly round, yellowish^; asci numerous, generally 1-2-spored; a palisade of paraphyses bordering the venae externae in places, but generally deformed by crowding, surface of fruitbody traversed by sterile venae externae lined by paraphyses and continuing from the fertile venae externae of the gleba [spore mass]; peridium reaching 800 microns thick
NAME ORIGIN  means 'vein-skin'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gilkey(3), Trappe(13)
365
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber quercicola  J.L. Frank, Southworth & Trappe^  Mycotaxon 95: 232. 2006
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a nearly spherical, dark red to brownish red fruitbody, with the surface minutely warted to scaly and cracked, 2) a spore mass that is firm, light tan to dark reddish brown, and marbled with thin white veins, 3) growth underground in association with Quercus garryana, and 4) spores ornamented with curved spines.^ The description is derived from Frank(1) except where noted. It is common among truffles in the Pacific Northwest. RANGE Collections were examined from OR and northern CA, (Frank). It occurs on the west coast of North America south into Mexico, (Trappe, M.(3)). In the Pacific Northwest it occurs in western OR and northern CA, (Trappe(13)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, spherical to nearly spherical, dark red to brownish red, surface "minutely verrucose to scaly and cracked"^, (Frank), "dark reddish brown to dark brownish red"; finely warty, (Trappe, M.)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "firm, hard when dried, light tan to dark reddish brown, intricately marbled with thin white sterile veins continuous with inner peridium"^, (Frank), white when young, when mature "light yellowish brown marbled with both white and dark brown, narrow veins", (Trappe, M.)
STEM  
ODOR  "mild to slightly earthy or often of fresh green beans"
TASTE  bland
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  fruiting underground in association with Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak) in southern Oregon, below leaf litter in top 2-7cm of mineral soil, March to August^, (Frank), with Quercus and Pinus (pine), especially in warm, dry sites; fruiting year-round, (Trappe, M.)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 20-45 x 15-35 microns excluding ornamentation and depending on the number of spores per ascus: in 1-spored asci 36-45 x 26-35 microns, in 2-spored asci 30-36 x 24-30 microns, in 3-spored asci 22-32 x 20-26 microns, and in 4-5-spored asci 20-28 x 15-20 microns, broadly to narrowly elliptic, light brown, ornamented with curved spines 2-5 microns long at maturity, spore walls 1-2 microns thick^; asci 1-5-spored, 62-80 x 40-55 microns, irregularly spherical to nearly spherical, colorless, with a double wall and a stem 10-35 microns long and with a forked base, "arranged randomly throughout the glebal fertile tissue"
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin "querci-" (oak) and "-cola" (dweller), "dweller with oaks"
SIMILAR  Tuber candidum is closely related and has a smooth, often tan peridium, whereas T. quercicola has a rough, scaly, red peridium, (Frank(1)). The European spiny-spored species, Tuber rufum Pico and Tuber ferrugineum Vittad. are also similar but shown to be distinct by molecular techniques, (Frank(1)). T. rufum has been reported from BC under birch in Richmond (Paul Kroeger, pers. comm.) - this was before the description of Tuber quercicola.
SOURCES  Frank(1), Trappe, M.(3)*, Trappe(13)
366
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber rapaeodorum  Tul. & C. Tul.^  Annls Sci. Nat., Bot., ser. 2 19: 380. 1843
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  The most conspicuous character is the odor of radish or horseradish. Other features include 2) spherical or nearly spherical, convoluted fruitbodies up to 2.5cm across, 3) an outer surface that is white to ochraceous or ochraceous yellow with dark brown patches, 4) an interior spore mass that firm, red-brown to dull yellow-brown, and marbled with straight whitish, pale ocher veins, 5) underground growth in association with hardwoods, and 6) microscopic characters including spores with reticular meshes.^ Tuber rapaeodorum is an example of a European species introduced inadvertently on horticultural plants. Four more European species have been introduced to truffle orchards on purpose (Tuber aestivum and Tuber melanosporum) or accidentally (Tuber borchii and Tuber brumale). Berch(4). The description of T. rapaeodorum below is derived from Halasz(1). RANGE Fruitbodies were found in gardens in BC associated with birch and with willow. (Berch(4)). Tuber rapaeodorum also occurs in Europe.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  up to 2.5cm across, spherical or nearly spherical, convoluted; white to ochraceous or ochraceous yellow with dark brown patches
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  firm, reddish brown to snuff brown, marbled with straight whitish, pale ocher veins
STEM  
ODOR  horseradish-like or radish-like
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  found in gardens in three different BC locations, one of them associated with Betula sp. (birch) and another with Salix scouleriana (Scouler's Willow), (Berch(4)), underground in association with hardwoods (Salix, Populus, Fagus, Carpinus, Quercus), (Halasz)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores elliptic, yellowish brown, spores from 1-spored asci (6-29 %) 40-60 x 28-38 microns (excluding ornamentation), spores from 2-spored asci (15-43%) 32-43 x 22-30 microns, spores from 3-spored asci (17-34 %) 27-41 x 18-27 microns, spores from 4-spored asci (13-45 %) 23-38 x 18-27 microns, spores from 5-spored asci (0-5%) 27-33 x 18-23 microns, 6-spored asci (0-1%); ornamentation 3-6 microns tall, the reticular meshes with 5-7 sides, 4-7(8) along the spore length and 3-5(6) along the breadth, spore walls 1.5-2 microns thick, spores brown in Melzers reagent, with colorless ornamentation, cyanophilic^; asci 70-100 x 45-80 microns, nearly spherical to elongated, short-stalked, the walls at maturity 1 micron thick, colorless, inamyloid; paraphyses absent; peridium 250-600 microns thick (dried)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Tuber maculatum is a very similar European species with a radish odor, distinguished by microscopic characters of the ectal excipulum: that of T. maculatum is prosenchymatic but with clusters of polygonal or rounded, thick-walled elements with a diameter of up to 10 microns, whereas the outer layer of the peridium of T. rapaeodorum is a coarse pseudoparenchyma of cells 6-30 microns broad, (Halasz(1)). Tuber puberulum is another closely related European species that has round to nearly round spores and a very thin, almost translucent peridium with crowded dermatocystidia. (T. rapaeodorum has elliptic spores and "a relatively thick peridium with a well developed outer layer of pseudoparenchyma and sparsely beset with or often lacking dermatocystidia".) (Halasz(1)).
SOURCES  Halasz(1), Berch(4)
367
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber separans  Gilkey^  University of Calif. Publ. Bot. 6(11): 315. 1916
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include small, convoluted, earthy-brown fruitbodies that are minutely scabrous on the surface, spore mass that is similar in color to the outer surface with inconspicuous veins, growth underground under trees, and microscopic characters^; description derived from Gilkey(3) except where noted; described from CA (Gilkey(3)), infrequent in the Pacific Northwest, found western OR, northern CA, eastern US, (Trappe(13) who say it is mycorrhizal in the Pacific Northwest with conifers rather than oak under which it was described)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-1.2cm across, semiglobose, convolute; earthy-brown; very minutely scabrous
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  similar in color to outer surface, the veins inconspicuous
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  beneath oaks in clay soil^, (Gilkey), mycorrhizal hosts in the Pacific Northwest are trees in the family Pinaceae (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 48-58 x 40-56 microns, round-elliptic, alveolate, with 3-10 x 7-11 (commonly 6-7 x 8-9) alveoli across the diameters, spores brown^; asci 1-3-spored, rarely 4-spored, semiglobose, short-stalked; peridium 200-260 microns; "cortex conspicuously pseudoparenchymatous, the cells becoming smaller within and changing to the compact subcortical layer of unconnected hyphae"; "venae externae of loose, tangled hyphae"; "venae internae very compact, the hyphae parallel, often connected, in places becoming pseudoparenchymatous"
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gilkey(3), Trappe(13)
368
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber shearii  Harkn.^  in Murrill, Mycologia 12: 157. 1920
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include somewhat rotund fruitbody that is dull yellowish to yellowish brown and smooth to scabrous, spore mass light brown marbled with white veins, and microscopic characters including brown, broadly elliptic to nearly round spores 32-56 x 28-42 microns, with alveolate ornamentation 3-4 microns tall with 3-9 meshes along the length of the spore, and nearly spherical asci 50-70 microns in diameter^; distribution MD, ME, OH, WI, (Gilkey), but some OR collections tentatively assigned to this species were reassigned in 1997 to the new species Tuber anniae Colgan & Trappe: Colgan(3) says T. shearii "has been reported only from east of the Mississippi"; however, more recently Tuber shearii is included in an authoritative list of Pacific Northwest truffle species as infrequent in western OR, and also found eastern United States, (Trappe(13)), and Trappe, M.(3) gave range as transcontinental in southern Canada and the northern United States, but occasionally south to NC, AZ, and CA, reported from OR by J. Smith et al.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  light dull yellowish to yellowish brown, the furrows white; smooth to roughened^, (Trappe, M.), 0.5-3cm across, somewhat rotund, creamy-buff to rusty-tawny; smooth or scabrous, (Gilkey)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  light brown marbled with white veins^, (Trappe, M.)
STEM  
ODOR  slightly pungent^ (Trappe, M.)
TASTE  slightly pungent^ (Trappe, M.)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in pure stands of Pinus (pine) and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) or in conifer-hardwood mixtures^, (Trappe, M.), in woods (Gilkey)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  32-56 x 28-42 microns, excluding the honeycomb ornamentation 3-4 microns tall, with 3-9 meshes along the spore length, broadly elliptic to nearly round, light brown^, (Trappe, M.), spores 35-56 x 30-56 microns, nearly round to round, alveolate [reticulate-pitted], the alveoli rather uniform, 3-7 x 3-6 across the diameter of the spore, spores dark brown; asci 50-70 microns in diameter, nearly spherical; peridium 160-400 microns thick, "pseudoparenchymatous near the surface, changing within to prosenchyma and separate hyphae", (Gilkey)
NAME ORIGIN  after Shear who identified this taxon as Terfezia oligosperma
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Tuber anniae.
SOURCES  Gilkey(3), Trappe, M.(3)*, Smith, J.E.(1), Colgan(3), Trappe(13)
369
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber sphaerosporum  Gilkey^  Ore. St. Monogr. Bot. 1: 39. 1939
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a brown, bald to scabrous fruitbody 2.5cm or less across, 2) a dark spore mass marbled by a few large and small whitish veins, 3) dark brown round spores 32-58 microns in diameter that are coarsely alveolate, with generally 3-4 alveoli across the diameter and 4) paraphyses sometimes forming a somewhat distinct palisade.^ The description is derived from Gilkey(3) except where noted. It is rare among truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE It occurs in Benton County OR, (Trappe(13)). The type collection from is from TN. The distribution also includes PQ, (Gilkey).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  2.5cm or less across; brown, bald to scabrous
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "dark, marbled by a few large and small whitish veins"
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under trees (Gilkey), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest is Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe(13))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 32-58 microns, round, coarsely alveolate [reticulate-pitted], with generally 3-4 alveoli across diameter, spores dark brown^; paraphyses sometimes forming a somewhat distinct palisade; venae externae of loose hyphae; "outer cortical layer of variable cells, the large and small intermixed, somewhat pseudoparenchymatous or often prosenchymatous, changing within to a loose hyphal structure"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with round spores'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Tuber anniae and Tuber californicum.
SOURCES  Gilkey(3), Smith, J.E.(1), Trappe(13)
370
FAMILY  Tuberaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAMES  Tuber whetstonense  J.L. Frank, Southworth & Trappe^  Mycotaxon 235. 2006
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include small, nearly spherical, light brown to dark reddish brown fruitbody, the surface minutely scurfy and downy, the spore mass inside solid with fertile tissue dark grayish brown marbled with narrow white veins, growth in association with Quercus garryana in dry habitats, spores with fine-meshed reticulum (9-12 meshes along length), thick-walled asci (an uncommon feature in Tuber), and pseudoparenchymatic peridiopellis^; description derived from Frank(1) except where noted; rare, Jackson County OR, (Trappe(13)), described from OR
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.5-1.5cm across, spherical to nearly spherical, rubbery to firm; light brown to dark reddish brown; minutely scurfy and pubescent [downy] with cracks and depressions, often cracked along fruitbody perimeter
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  "solid, with broad, dark grayish brown fertile tissue marbled with narrow white veins"
STEM  
ODOR  mildly peppery
TASTE  not recorded
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  found in association with Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak) in dry habitat
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15-55 x 14-44 microns excluding ornamentation and depending on the number of spores per ascus: in 1-spored asci 42-55 x 34-44 microns, in 2-spored asci 30-40 x 26-38 microns, in 3-spored asci 24-34 x 20-30 microns, and in 4-5-spored asci 15-26 x 14-22 microns, nearly round to elliptic, golden brown, ornamented with an alveolate reticulum 2-4 microns tall with 9-12 meshes along the spore length, spore walls 3-5 microns thick^; asci 1-5-spored, 50-80 x 40-60 microns, spherical to ellipsoid or ovoid, colorless, lacking a stem or sometimes with a stem up to 20 x 10 microns, walls 1-2 microns thick at maturity, "embedded randomly through the tramal tissue"; peridiopellis a pseudoparenchyma
NAME ORIGIN  means 'from Whetstone' in reference to Whetstone Savanna Preserve where the type was found
SIMILAR  Tuber gardneri is microscopically similar including having thick-walled asci, but the peridium is distinctly verrucose and grayish to yellowish rather than scurfy and brown to reddish brown. (Trappe, J.)
SOURCES  Frank(1), Trappe(13), Trappe, J. (pers. comm.)

FAMILY  Endogonaceae, Order Endogonales, Class Uncertain, Phylum Zygomycota
LATIN NAMES  Youngiomyces stratosus  (Trappe, Gerd. & Fogel) Y.J. Yao^  Kew Bull. 50(2): 356. 1995;  Endogone stratosa  Trappe, Gerd. & Fogel  Mycologia Memoir 5: 13. 1974
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include small fruitbodies in the form of layers that are smooth to verrucose, folded and convoluted, the layers containing very large spores (zygospores) enclosed in a tightly adhering mantle, growth on or in soil, and other microscopic characters^; described from OR
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  0.1cm x 0.3-0.6cm, "consisting of smooth to folded and convoluted, or verrucose strata on or in mineral soil, irregular groups of spores often present in soil adjacent to strata", inconspicuous; white to gray; sporocarps on soil surface with white peridium of interwoven hyphae lacking on sporocarps embedded in soil
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type on or in mineral soil under humus in a 40-year-old stand of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  zygospores tightly appressed, at times arranged in somewhat spherical to spherical clusters, 113-177 x 82-149 microns, mostly longer than broad, round, elliptic, oval, oboval, pyriform, or irregular from pressure, colorless, containing uniformly-sized, colorless oil globules, spore wall of two readily separable layers, each 4-8 microns thick, spores "enclosed in a tightly adhering mantle 8-15 microns thick" of hyphae that are 2-6 microns wide, colorless, interwoven, and thick-walled^; gametangia 35-40 microns in diameter, "thin-walled, at spore base separated some distance from each other"; sporocarps on soil surface have peridium of hyphae 1.5-4 microns wide, interwoven, colorless, thin-walled
NAME ORIGIN  Latin "stratosus" (layered), referring to the form of the sporocarp
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gerdemann(1)

FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Zelleromyces alveolatus  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Trappe, T. Lebel & Castellano^  Mycotaxon 81: 204. 2002;  Arcangeliella alveolata  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) J.M. Vidal;  Gymnomyces alveolatus  Singer & A.H. Sm.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical to irregular fruitbody that is dull ochraceous tawny when dried, thin peridium that is fleeting, exposing the pale tan spore mass at maturity, inconspicuous basal attachment, slight columella, and microscopic characters including round spores with inamyloid warts and a partially amyloid broken reticulum, 2-spored basidia, cystidia as crooked filaments embedded in hymenium, and peridial cuticle of interwoven hyphae; the online Species Fungorum, accessed December 23, 2014, gave the current name as Zelleromyces alveolatus (Singer & A.H. Sm.) Trappe, T. Lebel & Castellano; MycoBank, accessed December 23, 2015, gave the current name as  Zelleromyces australiensis (Berk. & Broome) Pegler & T.W.K. Young, Transactions of the British Mycological Society 72 (3): 371 (1979)^; type collection found in OR; infrequent, western OR, (Trappe(13))
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  3-5cm across, pale dull ochraceous tawny when dried, peridium thin and evanescent [disappearing], exposing the chambers of spore mass at maturity^, (Smith), 3-5cm across, spherical to irregular; pale dull ochraceous tawny when dried, "peridium thin and at maturity evanescent", the chambers of spore mass showing as a pattern that is alveolate [with broad pits] on outer surface, (Singer)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  pale tan^ (Smith), "cinnamon-buff" (Ridgway color) when dried; with empty chambers, (Singer) 
STEM  with an inconspicuous basal attachment (almost like a thick rhizomorph), sterile base small and inconspicuous, columella slight, as a few thin lines of sterile tissue penetrating through spore mass to the surface^, (Singer)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type found on soil under duff about 7.6cm deep, under Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), May^, (Singer)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-12 microns, round, warts up to 1-1.5 microns long^; cystidia 30-37 x 4-8 microns, as crooked filaments embedded in the hymenium, sphaerocysts rare in the peridium, cuticle of peridium a cutis of interwoven hyphae, (Smith), spores 9-12 microns, round, ornamentation of scattered warts about 1-1.5 x 1 microns, colorless in Melzer's reagent, "and a low broken reticulum of broad and narrow lines most of which are in part distinctly coated with amylaceous material but on some the non-amyloid basic ornamentation visible", wall thin (0.5 microns) and pallid yellowish in Melzer's reagent, nearly colorless in KOH, sterigmal appendage inconspicuous, inamyloid; basidia 2-spored, 26-33 x 9-11 microns, clavate, thin-walled, colorless in KOH, sterigmata 4-8 microns long, straight, conic, basidioles abundant; cystidia 30-37 x 4-8 microns "as crooked filaments to somewhat ventricose and with a crooked neck", colorless, "thin-walled, rarely with refractive content"; pseudoparaphyses none; subhymenium of filaments 3-9 microns wide, loosely interwoven, much branched; tramal plates composed of hyphae 5-12 microns wide, loosely interwoven, colorless, smooth, thin-walled, nongelatinous, occasional sphaerocysts up to 20 microns present, laticiferous hyphae rare; peridium "not differentiated into layers, in young specimens about 200 microns thick" and of hyphae 4-10 microns wide, closely interwoven, colorless, and nongelatinous, laticiferous hyphae interspersed and sphaerocysts rare to apparently absent, surface with a few projecting hyphal ends but no true turf or hypodermial layer present; clamp connections none, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'alveolate' (with broad pits)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(10) (as Gymnomyces alveolatus), Smith(4) (as Gymnomyces alveolatus), Trappe(13) (as Arcangeliella alveolata)
373
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Zelleromyces oregonensis  Singer & A.H. Sm.^  Mem. Torrey Bot. Club 21: 19. 1960;  Arcangeliella oregonensis  (Singer & A.H. Sm.) J.M. Vidal
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  features include spherical fruitbody that exudes a clear whitish latex when cut, surface cinnamon-buff to dingy pale tawny when dried, thin peridium [surface skin], spore mass marbled with hygrophanous translucent areas, with small labyrinthiform chambers, and when dried cinnamon buff to pale ochraceous tawny, columella branching, growth under Incense-cedar, and microscopic characters including nearly round to broadly elliptic spores with amyloid ornamentation of predominantly isolated rods, and 4-spored basidia^; type found in OR (Singer), infrequent in western OR (Trappe)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  1-3cm across, cinnamon buff to dingy pale tawny as dried, latex clear, whitish^, (Smith), 1-3cm across, spherical, exuding latex that is "clear, whitish", surface cinnamon-buff to dingy pale tawny when dried; unpolished; peridium thin, not opening to expose spore mass, (Singer)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  colored about as peridium as dried^, (Smith), marbled with hygrophanous translucent areas, when dried cinnamon buff to pale ochraceous tawny; chambers small but labyrinthiform, (Singer)
STEM  columella dendroid [branching], the branches pale buff^, (Singer) 
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type collection under Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-cedar), October^, (Singer), under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-13 x 8-11 microns, nearly round to broadly elliptic, ornamentation 1-1.3 microns high^; sphaerocysts absent from mediostratum of tramal plates; cystidia rare to scattered, 46-48 x 9-11 microns, fusoid-ventricose to clavate; cuticle of peridium a turf of cystidia 28-45 x 4-9 microns, (Smith), spores 10-13 x 8-11 microns, nearly round to broadly elliptic, wall colorless in Melzer's reagent, "ornamentation in the form of closely set but unconnected rods" 1-1.25 x 0.4-0.5 microns, "in some spores the rods arranged in crescents or in chains and touching or almost touching each other", amyloid overall or just over upper two thirds, the rods rather readily falling off, "plage area ornamented but the elements reduced merely to amyloid granules", "sterigmal appendage inconspicuous, about 2.5-3 microns long", spore wall only slightly thickened; basidia 4-spored, 32-44 x 9-14 microns, "clavate-pedicellate, thin-walled, collapsing readily"; cystidia rare to scattered, 46-48 x 9-11 microns, "fusoid-ventricose to subcylindric or narrowly clavate, apex obtuse", "content protoplasmic, evenly refractive as revived in KOH (not macrocystidia)"; subhymenium "cellular, 1-2 cells deep and elements up to 18 microns broad (sphaerocysts ?)"; tramal plates with mediostratum of hyphae 5-12 microns wide, interwoven, colorless (in KOH); peridial context (subcutis) "of interwoven filaments, sphaerocysts rare and present near the subhymenium in groups of 2-3, hypodermal layer yellow in KOH, the pigment in the hyphal walls, this zone of more compactly arranged hyphae than that making up the body of the context"; peridial epicutis a turf of dermatocystidia, the elements 28-45 x 4-9 microns, "narrowly subfusoid to filamentose, the walls slightly thickened in some", colorless to yellowish in KOH, "smooth, rarely with refractive content of amorphous material"; laticiferous hyphae present but very scattered; clamp connections absent, (Singer)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'from Oregon'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Singer(10), Smith(4), Trappe(13) (as Arcangeliella oregonensis)
374
FAMILY  Russulaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAMES  Zelleromyces scissilis  (Zeller & C.W. Dodge)  Trappe, T. Lebel & Castellano^  Mycotaxon 81: 205. 2002;  == Arcangeliella scissilis  Zeller & C.W. Dodge;  == Martellia scissilis  (Zeller & C.W. Dodge) Singer & A.H. Sm;  = Zelleromyces gilkeyae  Singer & A.H. Sm.
ENGLISH NAMES  
NOTES  Features include 1) a yellowish to pale reddish brown fruitbody with a smooth peridium that cracks off easily, 2) white latex that is exuded when the fruitbody is cut, 3) a spore mass that is cream-colored to cinnamon, 4) a thin white columella, and 5) microscopic characters including round or nearly round spores with an ornamentation of fine spines and rods with amyloid tips, and 4-spored basidia.^ Zeller(16) says that wood rats and pine squirrels eat the fruitbodies and seem especially fond of the peridium. It is abundant among false truffles in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe(13)). RANGE Zelleromyces scissilis is found from southwestern OR to northern CA (Trappe(13)). The distribution is WA, OR, and northern CA west of the Cascade Mountains, (Trappe, M.(3)). The type collection is from CA, (Zeller(11)). Trappe(3) synonymize Zelleromyces gilkeyae, the type of which was found in OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
OUTER SURFACE  up to 3cm across, irregular; yellowish drying "tawny" (Ridgway color); very smooth; peridium "tough, easily cracking off when fresh"^, (Zeller(16) for Arcangeliella scissilis), yellowish to yellowish brown, when mature mottled with red-brown, (Trappe, M.(3)), up to 3cm across, yellowish drying tawny; very smooth, (Singer for Martellia scissilis), 2-5cm across, pallid becoming pale reddish brown, (Smith for Zelleromyces gilkeyae), 2-3.5cm across and about 2cm deep, pale reddish brown; wrinkled; (Singer for Zelleromyces gilkeyae)
INNER LAYER  
INTERIOR  compact; cream, drying "antimony yellow" (Ridgway color)^, (Zeller(16) for Arcangeliella scissilis), "light yellowish brown, in wet weather exuding a white latex when cut open", (Trappe, M.(3)), compact; cream, drying antimony-yellow, (Singer for Martellia scissilis), pale to rich cinnamon; latex milky white, (Smith for Zelleromyces gilkeyae), cinnamon-buff; white latex reported when fresh, (Singer for Zelleromyces gilkeyae)
STEM  columella thin, extending about halfway to top; white^, (Zeller(16) for Arcangeliella scissilis), columella thin, extending about halfway to top; white, (Singer for Martellia scissilis), columella present (Smith(4) for Zelleromyces gilkeyae), columella reported by Gilkey when fresh, not visible on dried material which was readily attacked by insects in herbarium, (Singer(10) for Zelleromyces gilkeyae)
ODOR  strong of Hamamelis (witch-hazel)^, (Zeller(16) for Arcangeliella scissilis), not distinctive (Trappe, M.(3))
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  under conifers, November, (Singer for Martellia scissilis), collection under Acer circinatum (Vine Maple) in mixed woods (Singer for type of Zelleromyces gilkeyae), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Picea (spruce), and Abies (fir) at low elevations; fruiting September to December, (Trappe, M.(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 11-15 microns, round, "very finely and deeply alveolate-echinulate", dark yellowish^; septa 25-35 microns thick, prosenchyma with lactiferous ducts; peridium "drying 320-400 microns thick, pseudoparenchyma with compact prosenchyma near the surface, and with lactiferous ducts", (Zeller(16) for Arcangeliella scissilis), spores 10-14 microns (minus ornamentation), round to nearly round, ornamentation in the form of fine spines and rods 0.7-1 x 0.5 microns that are amyloid only at tips and are not connected to each other; wall inamyloid, sterigmal appendage prominent, 4-5 microns long; basidia 4-spored, 20-25 x 8-11 microns, short-clavate, thin-walled, sterigmata 3-4 x 1 microns, short-conic, basidioles 15-23 x 8-10 microns, clavate, thin-walled; pseudoparaphyses none; cystidia abundant, 40-55 x 9-16 microns, "obventricose-mucronate, thin-walled, readily collapsing, smooth", content colorless and homogeneous (leptocystidia); subhymenium of cellular structure; mediostratum of tramal plates interwoven, colorless "and with hyphae having walls 0.5-0.7 microns thick, glassy in KOH, no sphaerocysts demonstrated"; peridium a thick hard (when dried) layer of interwoven hyphae with glassy walls in KOH, epicutis "not differentiated but surface hyphae with ochraceous to brownish walls and apparently a sparse covering of narrowly clavate hyphal end-cells forming a spare turf", innermost layer apparently with scattered sphaerocysts; oleiferous hyphae rare; clamp connections none, (Singer for Martellia scissilis), spores 10-15(16) microns, round to nearly round, ornamentation 2-3 microns high; cystidia abundant, 46-62 x 10-14 microns, elongate-mucronate; "scattered sphaerocysts present in mediostratum of tramal plates", "cuticle of peridium a trichodermium, the elements closely packed to form a cellular layer", (Smith for Zelleromyces gilkeyae), spores 10-15(16) microns, ornamentation in the form of rods and spines 2-3 x 0.7-1 microns, "these slightly amyloid near or at the apex, and also in most spores with a darker amyloid reaction around the base or near it, spines closely arranged but no connecting ridges between them, and the wall of the spore between them merely yellowish in Melzer's reagent" and in KOH merely yellowish-transparent; basidia 2-spored, 30-37 x 9-12 microns (possibly a few 4-spored), basidioles 20-35 x 9-11 microns; pseudoparaphyses none; cystidia abundant, 46-62 x 10-14 microns, elongate-mucronate, thin-walled, colorless in KOH "or with scattered refractive amorphous particles within, or content reticulate"; subhymenium cellular, tramal mediostratum "of interwoven filaments and laticiferous hyphae, scattered sphaerocysts also present"; peridium "with an outer layer in the form of a trichodermium with the elements so closely packed together as to form a cellular layer, the end-cells ochraceous brown in KOH", "beneath this layer is one of interwoven subgelatinous hyphae (no sphaerocysts reliably observed)"; clamp connections none but false clamp connections occasional, (Singer for Zelleromyces gilkeyae), spores 10-16 microns in diameter, round, ornamented with colorless rods and spines +/- 1 micron tall, occasional spores with a few amyloid dots on their spines, (Trappe, M.(3))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'that may be split readily', referring to the peridium which cracks off easily when fresh
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Zeller(16) (as Arcangeliella scissilis), Zeller(11) (as Arcangeliella scissilis), Singer(10) (as Martellia scissilis and as Zelleromyces gilkeyae), Smith(4) (as Zelleromyces gilkeyae), Trappe, M.(1)* (as Zelleromyces scissilis), Trappe, M.(3)* (as Zelleromyces scissilis), Trappe(3) (as Arcangeliella scissilis), Trappe(13)* (as Arcangeliella scissilis)
